title: Accord on Return Of Statue to Kom Delights Cameroon
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Oct. 31Officials here expressed much happiness today that a New York art dealer had agreed to return the most sacred statue of the people of Kom to the isolated mountaintop village from which it was taken seven years ago.

title: 50 Die in Bengali Bus Plunge
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 31 (UPI)At least 50 people are believed to have drowned in a bus accident at Sylhet at the eastern tip of Bangladesh, a Dacca newspaper said today. The newspaper, Dainik Bangla, said a bus carrying 60 people plunged into the Kushiyara River on Monday.

title: Chilean Medical Report Calls Allende a Suicide
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31 (Reuters)President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile committed suicide by shooting himself with a submachine gun shortly after the armed forces attacked the presidential palace during the September 11 coup, according to an official medical report published here today.

title: Philharmonic Plans to Issue Statement on Strike Today
description: The board of directors of the New York Philharmonic met last night to consider action in the fiveweekold musicians' strike but adjourned apparently without arriving at a new position.

title: Text of Kleindienst Statement on I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Following is the text of a statement issued by former Attorney General Richard G. Fcleindienst in defense of his role in an antitrust case against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation:

title: Nat'l Hockey League.
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Exxon Resuming Allocation of Gasoline
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, announced yesterday that it was resuming allocations of gasoline to all customer groups in its East and Gulf Coast markets, effective today.

title: Legislature Lingers On
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Massachusetts Legislature is now the only state legislature in the country still in session, and leaders say it might last until Christmas. The state Senate president, Kevin B. Harrington, said yesterday, If we don't get out by Thanksgiving, members may have to plan on hanging their Christmas stockings on the fireplace in my office. A tentative Nov, 17 date has been set for adjournment.

title: Women's Rights Supported
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 (AP)The Christian Chprch (Disciples of Christ) endorsed today the Equal Rights Amendment and called for increased participation of women in their own ranks. The resolutions were passed by the more than 5,000 delegates to the church's Third General Assembly,

title: FRANCE RALLYING EUROPEAN ALLIES
description: PARIS, Oct. 31  France, smarting from what she sees as total SovietAmerican disregard of Europe in the Middle East crisis, took the lead today in trying to restore Europe's world influence by tightening, Common Market ties.

title: Agnew Pays His Fine; Baltimore Gets Check
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 (UPI) A $10,000 personal check from former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew was received at the United States Attorney's office in Baltimore today to pay a fine imposed on Mr. Agnew for income tax evasion.

title: Whooping Cranes Migrating
description: AUSTWELL, Tex., Oct. 31 (UPI)  The only wild flock of the world's whooping cranes has begun its annual migration from the Canadian marshlands to the bird's winter nesting grounds on a remote coastal peninsula in southern Texas., Lee Marlatt, assistant manager of the Aransas National Wild life Refuge, said only four whooping cranes had reached the winter grounds last week, but that the number had increased to 37 today.

title: Boy, 12, Killed in Scuffle Over His Halloween Plans
description: A 12yearold boy was killed last night in an elevator accident as a result of a friendly scuffle with a 22yearold man who tried to prevent him from going on a trickortreat Halloween expedition.

title: Football Is Here to StaySo Wives Take Course in It
description: Hash marks, a group of women learned the other night at an East Side church, are not greasy spots on some careless cook's wall. They are the oneyard markers running the length of a football field.

title: CUSTOMERS OF WEIS SUING FOR DAMAGES
description: Three stockholders who were customers of Weis Securities, Inc., filed a suit in Federal court here yesterday seeking damages for all thosee who failed to receive ful value for securities they had deposited with the financially troubled brokerage company before it closed down last May 24.

title: Aubrey Resigns Top Post At MetroGoldwynMayer
description: CULVER CITY, Calif., Oct. 31 James T. Aubrey Jr., the controyersial, harddriving chief executive of MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., resigned as president and as a director of the company in a special board meeting here today.

title: News Media Moves By Nixon Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Over a onemonth period in the fall of 1969, President Nixon made 21 separate requests to his top aides to take action to counter what the President saw as unfavorable news coverage, according to a memorandum made public tonight by Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: Time to Talk
description: President Sadat's boastful belligerency and harsh rejection of direct peace talks with Israel at a press conference yesterday were in unfortunate contrast the diplomatic initiative that was being pursued concurrently, with apparently serious and constructive purpose, by his new foreign minister in Washington.

title: ANTIQUES FAIR OPENS AT GREENWICH HOUSE
description: Antiques, folk art, sophisticated porcelains and latterday home appurtenances are cornpanionably ensconced at Greenwich House in the settlement's annual antiques fair.

title: Dr. Ernst Hammerschlag, Psychiatrist, 79, Is Dead
description: Dr. Ernst Hammerschlag, a psychiatrist and member of the Academy of Psychoanalysis, died Monday at his home, 300 East 74th Street. He was 79 years old.

title: Milk Coop Is Scrutinized on '72 Funding
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Watergate investigators are looking into the possibility that the nation's largest milk marketing cooperative may have made illegal corporate contributions to both major parties in the last two Presidential elections.

title: 15 ExHeads of Bar Group Say Fuchsberg Slandered Judiciary
description: Fifteen former presidents of the New York State Bar Association yesterday denounced as a flagrant misrepresentation the charge that judges do not do a day's work and criticized the man they identified as author of the charge, Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic nominee for chief judge.

title: HomeRule Advocates Win a Point in United Kingdom
description: LONDON, Oct 31  After four and a half years of study, a royal commission proposed steps today toward limited selfgovernment for Scotland and Wales to counter rising nationalist discontent in both; regions.

title: ETHICS BOARD BACKS JOB FOR CITY AIDE
description: Sanford I. Freedman, an assistant city corporation counsel for the last 10 years, has been offered a post with Loew's Corporation, and the city's Board of Ethics hag ruled that there would be no conflict of interest if he took the job.

title: Soviet Peace Meeting Strikes Snags
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31  The World Congress of Peace Forces, a Soviet experiment in winning broader support in the West for Moscow's version of dtente, ended tonight without appearing to have won over many of the very people it had haped to enlist.

title: Rain Helps Lift Prices of Commodities
description: Rain in the Middle Western harvest areas dominated futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday and prices staged quite a sharp recovery from the recent downturn, although they closed below their best levels of the session.

title: MONTY DENIES GIVING ASSISTANCE TO AVIS
description: Joseph N. Monty denied yesterday that he had ever taken money for performing favors for Avis RentACar Systems, Inc., while he was chief rackets investigator for the Queens District Attorney.

title: ALBERT N. CONNETT
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Oct. 31Albert N. Connett, a former commander in the Naval Reserve, died here today at his home. His age was 87.

title: BASIL ROWE DIES; EXCHIEF PILOT, 77
description: MIAMI, Oct. 31 (AP)Basil L. Rowe, chief pilot for Pan American World Airways for 30 years until his retirement in 1956, died on Sunday at his home in Coral Gables. He was 77 years old.

title: Impeachment Supported
description: Accusing President Nixon of a contempt for law and the administration of justice unknown since the founding of our Republic, more than 200 political scientists yesterday announced formation of Political Scientists for Impeachment, United Press International reported.

title: Government Clears Rebozo of Wrongdoing in Stolen Stock Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The Justice Department said today that it had no evidence that President Nixon's close friend Charles G. Rebozo, had cashed stolen stock certificates.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A parentsponsored boycott took effect yesterday at Public School 37 in Jamaica, Queens, almost halving the normal attendance, with 358 out of 705 registered at the school at 17937 137th Avenue attending classes.

title: Outlook on Oil Spurs Bid By Italy's Fuel Company
description: HOME, Oct. 31The threat of a severe oil shortage this winter is strengthening the nand of Italy's stateowned fuel concern, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, in its current bid to tighten its control of the Italian energy sector.

title: COURT APPOINTS WESTGATE BOARD
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 31 The financially troubled WestgateCalifornia Corporation today became a ward of the Federal District Court here when C. Arnholt Smith formally surrendered control of the $190million conglomerate to a new board of directors selected by Judge Leland C. Nielsen.

title: ColumbiaPresbyterian Gets $5Million Donation
description: The Columbia  Presbyterian Medical Center has received a $5million gift from the Commonwealth Fund toward its fiveyear, $133million expansion program initiated earlier this year.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL ON EMERGENCY CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) The House passed and sent to the White House today $185million threeyear authorization for Federal aid for emergency medical services. President Nixon vetoed a similar measure earlier this year.

title: Interfaith Group Honors Murphy, ExPolice Chief
description: Former Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy received an award for meritorious service and the betterment of police and community relations from the National Conference of Christians and Jews at a luncheon yesterday at Lchow's restaurant.

title: Greece Cashiers 45 Naval Officers for May Plot
description: ATHENS, Oct. 31Fortyfive naval officers who tried to overthrow the Government and restore the exiled King Constantine last May were given dishonorable discharges today.

title: BEAME'S 3 RIVALS REMAIN HOPEFUL
description: Mario Biaggi, Albert H. Blum. enthal and John J. Marchi each indicated yesterday that he was still hopeful of being elected Mayor, despite polls showing that Controller Abraham D. Be me was far ahead.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: LondonJohnny Clark, 115 pounds, Britain, outpointed Hiro Hamada, 119, Japan, 10 rounds.

title: Gurney Concedes Inquiry on Builders' Gifts to Him
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, who is a member of the Senate Watergate committee, said today that the Justice Department was investigating allegations that builders had secretly contributed money to him and expected favors from the Federal Housing Administration in return.

title: Kleindienst Perjury Fear Linked to I.T.T. Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst told Archibald Cox about President Nixon's order to delay the appeal of an antitrust ruling involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation after he became convinced that he might be indicted, according to sources familiar with the circumstances.

title: CURFEWS HINTED IN OIL SHORTAGE
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31The Public Service Commission today envisioned the possibility of shutting down schools, instituting curfews and cutting, off heat in the New York City subways this winter as ft ordered major utility companies to prepare emergency contingency plans within the next two weeks.

title: SOME IN CONGRESS VOICE SKEPTICISM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 4 Reaction on Capitol Hill tonight to the White House statement that two key Watergate conversations had not been recorded ranged from skepticism and incredulity to caution.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Trout and salmon angling has a tradition and literature that is hundreds of years old, but it was not until late in the 19th Century that saltwater sport fishing began to gain recognition.

title: ABUSES BY ISRAEL CHARGED BY SYRIA
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 31 (AP)Syria charged Israeli today with repeated and continuing violations of the 1949 Geneva Convention on the protection of tear victims and said she would not submit lists of Israeli war prisoners until Israel carried out the convention in full.

title: U.S.Soviet Disputes Hamper U.N. Effort to Form Mideast PeaceKeeping Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 31  Efforts to build a United Nations emergency force to assure the Egyptian Israeli ceasefire were stalled today by a series of bitter arguments between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: 2 ChildWelfare Agencies Quitting Protestant Group
description: The key childcare agencies rare resigning from the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies in protest over the federation's criticism of the city's childwelfare system as resulting in religious and racial discrimination and inadequate care.

title: Episcopalians Plan Slum Rehabilitation
description: The Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine announced yesterday that it was organizing a twoyear program for the rehabilitation by prospective residents of 200 abandoned slum buildings containing 3,000 apartments.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A gleaming, airlinerstyled turbo train made the run between New York and Albany yesterday as a symbol of the kind of high speed ttiin New Yorkers could have by 1976. The demonstration by the State Department of Transportation and Atntrak, the nation's rail passenger service, had to be held to a top speed of 70 miles an hour, and only on limited streaks, because of conditions of roadbed.

title: Thieu Says 50,000 Have Been Killed During the Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31 (UPI)  President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that almost one year of the socalled ceasefire had not ended the war in South Vietnam and that Communist forces were preparing for an offensive.

title: Israelis, Split Over War, Peer They'll Be Pawns
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31Premier Golda Meir departed for Washington today, leaving behind an Israel divided over her GovernIment's handling of the war and deeply concerned about the future.

title: Watergate and Crisis in Mideast Are CitedDow Down 11.96
description: Stock prices plummeted across a broad front yesterday for the second session in a row. This week's profit taking was set into motion by renewed uncertainties over the Watergate crisisand its impact upon President Nixonas well as the uneasy road to a peace settlement in the wartorn Middle East.

title: 2 Cubs Have Surgery
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (UPI)Surgery was performed on Glenn Beckert and Jose Cardenal of the Chicago Cubs today and both were in satisfactory condition. Beckert had a spur removed from his left heel. Cardenal had a rectal cyst removed.

title: Mercy Killing Defendant Tells of Shooting Brother
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 31I am here to end your pain, George. Is it all right with you? He nodded yes  the next thing I knew I had shot him.

title: U.A.W. SETS STRIKE AT G.M. FOR NOV. 19
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers has set a 10 A.M. strike deadline Nov 19 at the General Motors Corporation.

title: GUILD AND 2 PAPERS STEP UP THEIR TALKS
description: Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and the Daily News and The New York Times intensified their efforts yesterday to resolve their differences and avert a strike threatened for next Monday.

title: Bell Tolls for Chimes As N.B.C. Trademark
description: The National Broadcasting Company's chimes, an audio trademark since 1929, are being eliminated for a new, more modern sound.

title: West Refines Position at Vienna Talks
description: VIENNA, Oct. 31Western delegates at the talks on troop reductions in Central Europe said today that they did not intend to propose cuts in air forces or nuclear weapns on either side. The Soviet Union's spokesman said both should be discussed.

title: Soviet Press Drops Criticism of Nixon
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31The Soviet Union, apparently moving to smooth over public differences with Washington on the Middle East, today abruptly dropped its criticism of President Nixon's handling of the crisis last week.

title: Gravestone Dealer Accused of Scheme To Bilk Bereaved
description: A New Jersey gravestone dealer was charged yesterday with preying on the grief and despair of bereaved families in a fraudulent inscription scheme that bilked hundreds of people in the metropolitan area.

title: L.I. Woman Held Hostage By Man Fleeing the Police
description: CENTERREACH, L. I., Oct. 31A suspect who fled when a policeman sought to question him broke into a home on Valiant Drive this afternoon and held a housewife hostage for nearly an hour before he was talked into surrendering.

title: Women's Rights Supported
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 (AP)The Christian Chprch (Disciples of Christ) endorsed today the Equal Rights Amendment and called for increased participation of women in their own ranks. The resolutions were passed by the more than 5,000 delegates to the church's Third General Assembly.

title: WIFE A HOSTAGE IN ROBBERY HERE
description: Two gunmen broke into the East Side apartment of a musical booking agent yesterday, and while one kept the man's pregnant wife hostage, the other accompanied the agent across town to a bank, where the victim removed $11,000 from a safedeposit box and gave it to the robber, the police reported.

title: Maine Yard Gets Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Bath (Me.) Iron Works has been awarded a $92million contract to design and build the lead ship of a new class of Navy patrol frigates, Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, announced today.

title: FARMPRICE DROP GAINS MOMENTUM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 The price of raw farm products dropped 4 per cent in October, the Government said today, raising prospects of consumer relief at supermarket food counters later on. Agriculture Department officials said lower prices for cattle, hogs, wheat, broiler chickens and eggs contributed most of the. decline, computed between Sept. 15 and Oct. 15. This was the sharpest drop in more than onemonth.

title: Soviet Launches Satellite For Electromagnetic Study
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31, (Reuters) An artificial earth satellite, Intercosmos 10, has been launched in the Soviet Union under a joint program with other socialist countries to explore space, Tass reported today.

title: INDIA IS ASSAILED ON MIDEAST WAR
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 30  Inlia's fervent support of the Arab nations in the Middle East conflict has come under increasingly vocal opposition.

title: Mr. Nixon and the Press: A 27Year Conflict
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon may be the most elaborately briefed President in our history on what the news media sayand he may be the most badly informed. This does not explain Mr. Nixon's profound animosity toward professional journalism. But it may illustrate how this feeling reinforced.

title: AKZONA IN TALKS ON MERGER DEAL
description: Akzona, Inc., and Cutter Laboratories, Inc., announced jointly yesterday that they were pegotiating for the possible acquisition of Cutter by Akzona.

title: Advertising: Direct Client Deals
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 31As marketing staffs of companies continue to grow and their agencies continue to pare their payrolls, some of the country's leading advertisers are predicting even greater selfsufficiency on the client side. And that includes direct dealings with the media.

title: Swedes Asked to Cut Heat
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Swedes will be asked to lower the heating temperature, in their homes as part of a campaign to save oil, it was announced today. Commerce Minister KjellOlof Feldt said experts had determined that oil consumption could be cut 5 to 6 per cent by lowering temperatures two to three degrees.

title: House Unit Seeks To Stiffen Controls For Commodities
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)The House Agriculture Committee voted informally today to authorize a strengthened Commodity Exchange Authority to set margins, require multiple delivery points, prohibit certain broker trading and regulate all futures trading.

title: On Revisionism
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The November issues of just about every magazine have a story pegged to the tenth anniversary of the death of John F. Kennedy.

title: Richardson Thurston, Head Of Polymer Industries, 49
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 31Richardson Thurston, board chairman of Polymer Industries, Inc., of Stamford, died yesterday at his home in Wilton. He was 49 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As the smoke settles over Washington, we must pause to ask what justice requires of this nation with respect to its President.

title: Mercy Killing Defendant Tells of Shooting Brothe
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 31 I am here to end your pain, George. Is it all right with you? He nodded, yes  the next thing I knew a had shot him.

title: Mandel Returns $53,950 in 1974 Maryland Campaign Funds to Engineers and Architects
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 31Marvin Mandel, the Democrat who succeeded former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew as Governor of Maryland in 1969, reported today that he had returned $53,950 in contributions for his 1974 reelection campaign to 40 consulting engineers and architects who are eligible to receive nonbid contracts from the state.

title: MRS. WILLIAM FELLER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31Mrs. Clara Nielsen Feller, widow of Dr. William Feller, Higgins Professor of Mathematics at Princeton University and, since his death in 1970, technical editor of the Annals of Mathematics, died Friday at her home, 50 Broad Ripple Drive. She was 63 years old.

title: Airstrip to Be Built Upstate
description: TICONDEROGA, N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP)A State Transportation Department spokesman said today that construction of a 4,000footlong airstrip for small aircraft would begin here soon. The spokesman, Paul Vadnais, said the airstrip was being financed by a $187,500 grant approved by the Legislature last year.

title: Vietnam War: Not a Matter of Past Tense in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31There is a strange gap of perception between those who live in Vietnam and many public figures who talk about it from a distance.

title: Israeli Navy Asserts It Is in Control
description: ABOARD MISSILE BOAT GAASH, off Israel, Oct. 30The sleek gray boat was knifing through the blue Mediterranean at 35 knots when it suddenly heeled into a hard, tight turn, throwing up a plume of white water in its wake.

title: High School Sports
description: New York City agreed yesterday to walve its Shea Stadium rental fee if the Public Schools Athletic League wanted to stage its football final there. However, the offer was reluctantly refused by the league, which earlier had been told it would cost $31,900 in deposits and fees to use the ballpark.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: CURFEWS HINTED IN OIL SHORTAGE
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31The Public Service Commission today envisioned the possibility of ishutting down schools, institutling curfews and cutting off heat in the New York City subways this winter as it ordered major utility companies to prepare emergency contingency plans within the next two weeks.

title: 3 I.R.A. Men Escape by Helicopter From Dublin Jail
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 31A hijacked helicopter airlifted three Irish Republican Army men to freedom from a prison exercise yard here today.

title: Byrne, Far Ahead, Still Runs Scared
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Oct. 31With the gubernatorial campaign in the home stretch and Brendan T. Byrne far ahead in the polls, the Domocratic nominee is nevertheless campaigning as if his political life depended upon it.

title: COURT INFORMED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Two White House conversations that were believed to contain evidence critically important to the Watergate criminal investigation were never recorded at all, President Nixon's special counsel said in court today.

title: Cartoonists Honor Walt Kelly In Memorial Service at Lambs
description: Walt Kelly's fellow cartoonists honored him yesterday as a genius in his time at a short memorial service sponsored by the National Cartoonists Society at the Lambs Club here.

title: TV: Love and Other Promotions in the Afternoon
description: What are they showing on afternoon television these days? I'll tell you what they're showing on afternoon television these days. Soap operas and commercials. The commercials remain the same, but the American Broadcasting Company has been tinkering with the soap operas.

title: Music: Detroiters' Roaring Approach
description: The admirable Detroit Symphony, with Rafael Frilhbeck de Burgos officiating as guest conductor, gave a concert on Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall. Two works were presented  Manuel de Falla's Noches en los jardines de Espana, and the everpopular Carmina Burana by Carl Orff.

title: SandmanByrne Issue: Who Runs Railroads
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31Both of New Jersey's gubernatorial candidates agree that only a huge infusion of Federal money can help resuscitate the state's moribund commuter railroads, but each has his own ideas about who should run them.

title: TaxReform Plan Apparently Blocked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Plans to bring up a taxreform proposal in the House of Representatives this week were apparently thwarted today by strategists in two key Congressional committees, some of whom conceded that they were acting under pressure from the oil industry and other businesses.

title: Aide Denies Kissinger Voiced Disgust at NATO
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The State Department denied today that Secretary of State Kissinger had said he was disgusted with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization because of the failure of the members to support United States policies in the Middle East crisis.

title: Lists Close Off on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exhange rose early in the day but finished lower in slackened trading, continuing a downward trek as news that could be constructed as bullish remained lacking. Prices also fell in the overthecounter market in slightly higher volume.

title: A DANCE BY HODES ATTAINS ITS GOAL
description: Among the welter of ideas put forth as finished dances on the Choreoconcerts program Tuesday evening at the New School, Stuart Hodes's Transit Gloria alone translated impulse into finished movement. It was for the most part a program of starts but few creative finishes.

title: 7 Seized in June Riot After Appeals in Park Slope
description: After a twomonth investigation in which detectives, speaking in Spanish and Italian pleaded for neighborhood cooperation, a Housing Authority patrolman and six other persons were arrested yesterday on charges that included attempted murder.

title: Finley on Probation; Warned on Conduct
description: Charles O. Finley, the Oakland A's controversial owner, has been placed on indefinite probation by Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and warned of possible more drastic action for any further infractions, United Press International reported yesterday.

title: Jew Hampshire Compromise
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 31 (AP)  The Executive Council worked out a compromise today between Gov. Meldrim Thomson and the Legislature and voted for a Feb. 19 special session of the General Court. Governor Thomson had ??ught an April 23 session, but the legislature indicated preference for a January session.

title: SAM SAYS HE GOT JUSTICE POST BID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Senator William B. Saxbe, an Ohio. Republican with a reputation for outspokenness who is an occasional critic of President Nixon, said tonight he had been offered the post of Attorney General and had accepted.

title: Smith Wins In Struggle With Fillol
description: PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP)The defending champion, Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., overcame mistakes to defeat Jaime Fillol of Chile, 63, 67, 62, and reach the quarterfinals of the French indoor tennis championships.

title: Muskie Aide Tells of 1972 Sabotage Including Theft of Vital Campaign Paper
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) 4Senator Edmund S. Muskie's residential campaign manager testified today that Republican dirty tricks disrupted strategy, generated suspicion and animosity among Democratic Presidential candidates and demoralized Mr. Muskies. staff workers during the 1972 campaign.

title: NIXON ASKS FUNDS FOR POOR NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) President Nixon asked Congress today to appropriate $1.5billion more as the United States contribution to the International Development Association which funnels long[erm lowcost loans to the world's poor nations.

title: Senate Panel's Hearings on Dismissal of Cox Fall Into Partisan Bickering
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the dismissal of the former special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, fell into partisan bickering today as two Republicans tried to portray Mr. Cox and his staff as indiscreet Democrats out to get the President.

title: Dim Outlook for World Energy Predicted at a Tokyo Meeting
description: TOKYO. Oct. 31A conference of 45 experts on oil and other forms of energy closed here today with a stark projection of the world's energy crisis for at least the next decade.

title: YetiLike Monster Gives Staid Town in Illinois a Fright
description: MURPHYSBORO, Ill., Oct. 31Mrs. Nedra Green was preparing for bed in her isolated farmhouse near here the other night when a shrill, piercing scream came from out by the shed.

title: Webster Exhorts Giants To Show More Hustle
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31With everyone else analyzing what's wrong with the New York Giants, Coach Alex Webster finally offered his theory today  a lack of aggressiveness and hustle.

title: Aqueduct Triple a TV Coming Attraction
description: Saturday telecasts of Aqueduct's getrichquick triple probably will begin within two weeks, a spokesman for the New York Racing Association indicated yesterday.

title: YOUNGSTERS DRAWN TO SQUIRREL CLUB
description: GLENDALE, Calif. (AP)A child can join the Squirrel Club at the Glendale Savings and Loan Association with a $3 minimum deposit in a savings account. Upon making the initeal deposit, he is given a pencil, a decal, a cash box, a balloon, a kite and a copy of the Declaration of Independence. On his birthday, a gift awaits him at his savings headquarters.

title: SADAT THREATENS RENEWAL OF WAR
description: CAIRO, Oct. 31 President Anwar elSadat warned today that pressure from Egypt's army would force him to renew the war if Israeli forces have not withdrawn to the Oct. 22 ceasefire line by the time Secretary of State Kissinger visits here next week.

title: Grandmother Had Slingshot
description: BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 31 (UPI) A grandmother was turned back by security police at Boise Airport until she checked her slingshot in with her luggage. It was an armed slingshot, said A. V. Cox, United Air Lines station manager, and it falls into the category of unacceptable items not allowed aboard an aircraft. The unidentified woman; believed in her 70's, said it was a present for her grandson in Denver. But the guards were adamant after they found the weapon in her purse when she triggered the electronic warning signal yesterday.

title: An Early I.B.M. Trial Urged by Competitors
description: Executives of the Control Data Corporation, Honeywell, the National Cash Register Company and the Sperry Rand Corporation urged officials of the antitrust division of the Departmennt of Justice yesterday to seek an early trial of the Government's pending case against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WIND SHIFTING WEST. By Shirley Ann Grau. 247 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: Bridge: Aces Remain to Be Tested In World Match Next Year
description: The Aces were not tested severely in the international playoff matches in Milwaukee this week. Their two victories, by 106 international match points in the semifinal and by 90 points in the final, reveal the extent to which they outclassed their opponents.

title: Supplies Moving to Trapped Egyptians at Snail's Pace
description: SUEZ, Egypt, Oct. 31A controversial plan to deliver food, water and medical plies to a large force of surrounded Egyptian soldiers is moving at a snail's pace.

title: Away From Their Restaurants, Chefs Are Home on the Range
description: At 11 o'clock every morning and 6 o'clock every evening, the staffs of French restaurants sit down to dine. The classic texts of cuisine ignore these meals, and for a reason: what chefs serve themselves is usually solid fare, such as a rabbit stew with noodles, a hot sausage with potatoes, tripe  la mode de Caen or gras double Lyonnais. This gives them strength for the hours ahead.

title: Nixon Due to Name Saxbe, With Texan as Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The White House is expected to announce tomorrow the nomination of. Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, as Attorney General and the appointment of Leon Jaworski, a Houston lawyer and former president of the American Bar Association, as the new special Watergate prosecutor.

title: 61 FOOD CONCERNS CITED BY THE CITY
description: The Health Department has released the names of 61 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Lolich's Ring Recovered
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Mickey Lolich's stolen World Series ring was recovered yesterday more than two years after a sneak thief took it from a Iocker room at the old Kansas City Municipal Stadium. Lolich received the ring for his participation in the Detroit Tigers' 1968 Series victory. The police said today they found the ring in the pocket of an attemptedrape suspect.

title: Personal Finance
description: Some 10 years ago, soon after the Surgeon General stirred a nationwide controversy by strong criticism of cigarette smoking, a littleknown company in Worcester, Mass.; the State Mutual Life Assurance Company of America, came out with a special life policy for people who didn't smoke cigarettes.

title: Mayor's Budget Message Supports Transit Bonds
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday urged voter approval of the state's $3.5billion transportation bond proposition as he sent the City Planning Commission a message calling for $900million in capital projects within the debt limit for 197374.

title: When Homer Nodded
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31The White House effort to turn Archibald Cox's indiscretion into a high crime and misdemeanor would be funny if it were not so ugly. The men who tapped their colleagues' telephones now lecture us on the sin of breaking confidences!

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1973

title: Navy Man is Killed
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 31 (UPI)A Navy enlisted man was killed yesterday when a 100foot underwater demolition team's vessel rammed a minisubmarine in San Diego Harhoc. The accident occurred as both boats returned to Coronado amphibious base from routine exercises with 40 other vessels. The name of the dead crewman was not released.

title: SADAT THREATENS RENEWAL OF WAR
description: CAIRO, Oct. 31 President Anwar elSadat warned today that pressure from Egypt's army would force him to renew the war if Israeli forces have not withdrawn to the Oct. 22 ceasefire line by the time Secretary of State Kissinger visits here next week.

title: People in Sports: South Africa Opening Door to Ashe
description: Arthur Ashe was told yesterday he could compete in the South African open tennis championships at Johannesburg next month. The black Player, who has been an outspoken critic of South Africa's apartheid policy, was granted a visa to enter the $115,000 tournament after having been refused entry in 1970 and 1971 on the grounds that he had an antagonistic attitude toward the country.

title: Israelis, Split Over War, Fear They'll Be Pawns
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31Premier Golda Meir departed for Washington today, leaving behind an Israel divided over her Government's handling of the war and deeply concerned about the future.

title: $21.3Billion Weapons Bill Passes House by 290 to 103
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Hhe House passed today compromise $21.3billion defense procurement authorization carrying intact all the major weapons systems the Administration requested.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 7 Celtics in Double Figures Beat Cays
description: The Boston Celtics, making amends for a lastsecond loss to Cleveland Sunday night, battered the Cavaliers, 128110, in the Boston Garden last night.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Other Unions Pledge Support To Modern Museum Strikers
description: striking workers at the Museum of Modern Art received assurances last night of aid from other unions in their dispute.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES RAIL RESCUE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 31 (AP) The House Commerce Committee reported out today a $1.4billion aid package structured to salvage the bankrupt Northeastern railroads.

title: 11 City Employes Get New $5,000 Prize
description: Their names never make the headlines, their faces are rarely seen on television and it would not be unusual if the only service award they ever got was a gold watch.

title: So. Cal. Posts Record Net; Other Companies Report
Handless Body Identified
description: CATSKILL, N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP)The state police said today they had identified a body found Monday with its hands cut off as that of a New York City man with a record of drug dealing, Giacomo Spada, 39 years old. The bulletriddled body was found near Route 23A west of a Thruway overpass.

title: Knicks Turn Back Rockets by 10291
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31With Dave DeBusschere back in action, Willis Reed back in top form and their famous teamwork back in evidence, the New York Knicks began a fourgame western trip tonight by beating the Houston Rockets, 10291.

title: Candidates Assess City's Arts Future
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, sees his election as offering the prospect of a major renaissance in the arts and cultural life of New York.

title: Senate Committee to Begin Hearings Today on Ford Nomination as Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Gerald R. Ford will go before a Senate committee tomorrow for the opening round of questioning on his fitness to become Vice President of the United States.

title: Suffolk Elections Board Sees Attempt To Rig Hampton Vote With Absentees
description: YAPHANK, L.I., Oct. 31 The Suffolk County Board of Elections charged today that a concerted campaign was being undertaken to rig the East Hampton Town elections by having summer residents of the wealthy resort community vote illegally by absentee ballot.

title: Alitalia to Expand on 5th Ave. Rather Than Move Out of City
description: With a smiling Mayor Lindsay standing by, Alitalia Airlines announced yesterday that it had decided after a longs study to double its office space on Fifth Avenue rather than move out of the city.

title: U.S. Court Stays Law Allowing Halt to Welfare Cheats' Checks
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31 (AP) A Federal judge today banned the enforcement of a New Jersey law permitting the dropping of convicted welfare cheats from relief rolls.

title: DR. ERNEST LITTLE, DEAN AT RUTGERS
description: DANVILLE, Vt., Oct. 31Dr. Ernest Little, dean emeritus of the Rutgers University. College of Pharmacy and the first president of the American Foundation for Pharmaceutical Education, died here yesterday at his home. He was 85 years old.

title: Mayor's Budget Message Supports Transit Bonds
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday urged voter approval of the state's $3.5billion transportation bond proposition as he sent the City Planning Commission a message calling for $900million in capital projects within debt limit for 197374.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: PITTSBURGHAcquired Jerry Reuss, lefthanded pitcher, from Houston for Milt May, catcher.

title: Nets Drop Fourth in Row, Bow to Rockets, 107103
description: DENVER, Oct. 31  A rookie, Mike Green, and Byron Beck came off the bench in the fourth period to score 17 points between them and give the Denver Rockets a 107103 victory over the New York Nets tonight at the Denver Auditorium.

title: AID TO KILLER, 16, CALLED FAILURE
description: ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Oct. 31A 16yearold youth from the Lower East Side who admitted killing a 70yearold grocer during a holdup last May was put into an upstate experimental rehabilitation program near here that authorities abandoned as unworkable a month after it began.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: LondonJohnny Clark, 115 pounds, Britain, outpointed Hiro Hamada, 119, Japan, 10 rounds.

title: Skylab Count Is Smooth
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 31 (UPI)The countdown for a Friday rehearsal of launching procedures for the Skylab 3 crew moved along smoothly today with testing on key battery and antenna systems. The actual launching is scheduled for Nov. 10.

title: U.S.Soviet Disputes Hamper U.N. Effort to Form Mideast PeaceKeeping Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 31  Efforts to build a United Nations emergency force to assure the Egyptian Israeli ceasefire were stalled today by a series of bitter arguments between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Paul Dudley White Dies
description: Dr. Paul Dudley White, the renowned authority on heart disease who gained prominence as cardiologist to President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1955, died yesterday in Massachusetts. General Hospital in Boston. He was 87 years old. Details on Page 46.

title: Kleindienst Perjury Fear Linked to I.T.T. Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst told Archibald Cox about President Nixon's order to delay the appeal of an antitrust ruling involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation after he became convinced that he might be indicted, according to sources familiar with the circumstances.

title: Notes on People
description: Cambridge University has appointed Archibald Cox, recently dismissed by President Nixon as the special Watergate prosecutor, Pitt Professor of American History and Institutions. The job requires him to visit Cambridge at least once, sometime after next October, to deliver a lecture or course of lectures. Mr. Cox is on leave from his law professorship at Harvard.

title: WATERGATE HELD KEY TO ELECTION
description: PARAMUS, Oct. 31John B. Connally, the former Treasury Secretary and onetime adviser to President Nixon, today called the New Jersey gubernatorial election a referendum on the Watergate scandal.

title: BOUBOULIDI PIANISM ESCHEWS EMOTIONS
description: There are musicians whose talent is so obvious that their failings as performers can be a puzzle and even an irritation. Rita Bouboulidi, a Greek pianist who gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, fell squarely in that class. Immediately, in Beethoven's Sonata in F (Op. 54), she displayed a strong, almost blameless technique and what seemed an austere but defensible conception of the music.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Trout and salmon angling has a tradition and literature that is hundreds of years old, but it was not until late in the 19th Century that saltwater sport fishing began to gain recognition.

title: Airlines Slash Domestic Flights Because of U.S. Fuel Allocations
description: Air service over much of the nation is being reduced today as major airlines cut flight schedules because of the Federal mandatory fuel allocation program.

title: ...Mr. Nixon's I.T.T. Role
description: The effect of White House efforts to put into fair and accurate perspective the 1971 order issued by President Nixon to stop Justice Department prosecution of one phase of the I.T.T. antitrust suit is only to confirm that the President did intervene personally in a case heavily freighted with politics.

title: Skepticism and Caution Are Voiced in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Reaction on Capitol Hill tonight to the White House statement that two key Watergate conversations had not been recorded ranged from skepticism and incredulity to caution. Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., the chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, told reporters that he had been assured by the White House as late as Oct. 19 that all nine tapes sought by his committee for its investigation were intact.

title: ENGINE MEASURE GAINS IN SENATE
description: The Senate Commerce Committee approved yesterday a bill that would require the Secretary of Transportation to develop an energyefficient, lowpolluting automobile engine within four years, and would authorize $200million in loan guarantees and $140million in direct grants to get the job done.

title: Sunday Book World Supplement Is Dropped by Washington Post
description: Book World, The Washington Post's Sunday book review supplement, will end after 10 years when it goes to press this week. During the last Hecade the publication had tenuously maintained itself as part of two nowdefunct newspapers, then as a partnership of two other papers and now, finally, as a separate Post supplement.

title: Mandatory Fuel Allocation To Begin Today in Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31With the nation's oil supplies starting to tighten because of production cutbacks by Arab nations, Washington and the states begin tomorrow a joint mandatory allocation prograrti intended to help the country to scrape through the winter without jeopardy to public health or grave damage to the economy and the education of children.

title: Exxon Ordered to Continue Its Diesel Deliveries to T.A.
description: Justice Albert S. McGrove of Brooklyn Supreme Court has signed a temporary restraining order requiring the Exxon Corporation to continue its contractal delivery of diesel fuel to the Transit Authority, despite the corporation's notice that it would discontinue deliveries as of midnight last night because of a fuel shortage.

title: Lyle Outpoints Middleton
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 (AP) Ron Lyle of Denver scored a unanimous decision over Larry Middleton of Baltimore tonight to record his seveenth consecutive victory. Lyle weighed 218 pounds, Middleton 205.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)The Senate Investigation subcommittee asked the Justice Department today to determine whether Federal laws were violated in the Nixon Administration's handling of the 1972 wheat sale to the Soviet Union.

title: The Missing Tapes..
description: The surprise disclosure yesterday by Presidential counsel J. Fred Buzhardt that two of the nine subpoenaed Watergate tapes do not exist is the latest, and possibly the most serious, blow to both the investigation and White House credibility. The question must be asked why Mr. Nixon permitted the extended controversy over the recordings to proceed through months of public debate, hearings in two courts, negotiations with thespecial prosecutor and ultimately the aborted compromise with Senators Ervin and Baker, without ever indicating that two crucial tapes were missing.

title: 61 FOOD CONCERNS CITED BY THE CITY
description: The Health Department has released the names of 61 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

title: 'Italian Connection' Opens at 3 Theaters:The Cast
description: Say this for "The Italian Connection." It ends in the right place, a Milanese junkyard, with the key figures slaughtering one another amidst piled, worn-out cars.The film opened yesterday at the Penthouse, 86th Street Twin I and 59th Street Twin I theaters.The picture itself is plain garbage, a German-Italian co-production with a splash or two of backstreet Milanese color and one good performance. The pointless plot has a quaking, small-time pinto (Mario Adorf) fleeing two American Rniers (Henry Silva and Woody Strode) and the local Mafia. The language (spoken and dubbed English) is as filthy as the action is dull, for all the bone-crunching and squealing.Apparently, with such a title, the producers hoped somebody would mistake the picture for a sequel to "The French Connection" or even "The Chinese Connection." And isn't there "The Salzburg Connection" due around the bend? As the terrified dimwitted fugitive, Mario Adorf is credible, against formidable odds.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Pentagon Announces PreHoliday Discharges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)The armed forces will permit early discharges for some servicemen for the ChristmasNew Year holiday season, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Canceled Show on Nixon Reset for Sunday on
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, which had canceled a primetime news special on the presidential tapes last Friday, has scheduled a new special this Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Titled The Embattled President, it will replace the evening's episode of The New Perry Mason.

title: Smith Wins In Struggle With Fillol
description: PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP)The defending champion, Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., overcime mistakes to defeat Jairne'Fillol of Chile, 63, 67, 62, and reach the quarterfinals of the French indoor tennis championships.

title: Gloom at West Point: Vietnam Backlash Puts. Football in Doldrums
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 31They still call the Saturday night dances hops, and cannon search the bend in the Hudson River where the British navy once tried to enter.

title: Chapot Fastest In Jump
Pact Between Big Board and Pacific Exchange on Services Seen
description: An agreement between the New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Exchange to merge clearing and depository services is very imminent, perhaps no more than a month or two away, James J. Needham, chairman of the Big Board, told a Houston audience yesterday.

title: Romans Filling Tubs As a City Aqueduct
description: ROME, Oct. 31  Romans filled bathtubs and jugs today as they prepared to go without water supply for four days amid public controversy over whether the ordeal is really necessary.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The scoreless tie Westfield and Nutley played last Saturday was costly for both teams.

title: Times Magazine Post Filled
description: Mary Simons, now editor in chief of Homelife magazine, has been appointed to fill a new position as a senior editor of The New York Times Magazine. She will have special responsibility for the design fashion, food and parentchild departments of the Magazine and its related special sections. She will work under the direction of the editor of the Magazine, Lewis Bergman, and with the assistance of Barbara Wyden and seven other staff members. The appointment is effective Dec. 3.

title: Minis Try for Place in Dachshund Sun
description: Once a year, owners of miniature dachshunds stage a roundup. This year it was at the Lehigh Valley show and of the 144 badger dogs entered at the Pennsylvania fixture, 110 were minis. One, Ch. Yaletowne's Midnite Cowboy, was best wirehaired dachshund and went on to take fourth in the hound group, a tremendous achievement for a mini. The 3yearold was shown by Raymond Patenaude of West Haven, Conn., his ownerbreeder. A member of the board of the Dachshund Club of America, Patenaude also owns five other mini wires, four of them champions. His Ch. Wyndel's Charisma is the nation's topwinning mini bitch.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Superior Court judge refused for a second time yesterday to unseat Newark City Councilman Louis M. Turco, who had pleaded guilty to Federal tax charges. Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman ruled Turco's guilty plea was not equivalent to a conviction, because the former Council President had not yet been sentenced.

title: British Find Way to Detect SteroidsUsed by Athletes
description: LONDON, Oct. 31 (UPI)A major breakthrough in the detection of anabolic steroids, the bodybuilding drugs used by many of the leading sportsmen to improve their performances, has been made by a British research team.

title: Palestinians Willing to Join Peace Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31The Palestinian resistance is favorably disposed toward taking part in a Middle East peace conference, along with Arab governments and Israel, reliable Palestinian sources said today.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: FASHION TALK
description: Everyone's talking about elegance, romance and all that as spring collections continue to be unveiled on Seventh Avenue. But hardly anybody mentions wit and humor. They're too serious about elegance et al.

title: U. S. Indicts Four Tracks On Contributions to Cahill
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31  Three race tracks in New Jersey and one in Florida were indicted today on charges of illegally contributing thousands of dollars to Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign and listing the contributions as legitimate business expenses on corporate income tax returns.

title: Sabres Win On Martin's Three Goals
description: Rick Martin scored three goals at close range to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 32 victory over the California Golden Seals in a National Hockey League game last night in Buffalo.

title: TORTURERS OF HOBOS AROUSE JUDGES IRE
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP)  A Federal judge says that were it in my power to so do he would let hobos who had been beaten and tortured by two former railroad guards reverse the process.

title: Film: Grotesque Effects:Horror Palls in 'Tales Witness Madness' The Cast
description: Considering the generally depressed state of horror films these days, it takes a special kind of optimism to continue seeing them, especially when they are made by Freddie Francis, the distinguished English cinematographer ("Saturday Night and Sunday Morning"), who turned director about 10 years ago. Like a small child who sends off a coupon for a valuable free gift, you keep expecting a treasure, then receive something made of cardboard."Tales That Witness Madness," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is Mr. Franci's glossiest, most absurd, almost-all-star horror film yet. Like his "Torture Garden" and "Tales From the Crypt," it is a collection of unrelated stories that, this time, have as their connecting link a mad doctor (Donald Pleasence) who theorizes to his friend (the late Jack Hawkins) that truth has physical substance that can be isolated, like hormones.At least that is what I think his theory is, but the movie is less interested in theories than in grotesque effects, some of which are comic without being especially funny.There is, for example, the episode in which Kim Novak, playing a London literary agent in her most inept Lyiah Clare style, finds herself the hostess of a luau at which her teen-age daughter is served as a main course. In another episode, which recalls a much more interesting Ray Bradbury story in "The Martian Chronicles," a little boy's imaginary playmate, a tiger, devours his nasty parents.The third tale is about a malevolent family portrait, and the fourth is about a shapely tree stump that comes between a not-so-young married couple played by Joan Collins and Michael Jayston. Jayston falls in love with the tree stump, which he keeps in the living room although the jealous Miss Collins describes it as "ugly, sawn-off, upside-down and vile."That's the best line in a film that otherwise depends on people saying such things as "Darling you're imagining things" and "I just can't believe all this has happened."

title: Arthur Daley
description: Before the awed gaze of countless millions of television addicts, the remarkable O. J. Simpson of the Buffalo Bills gave a truly virtuoso performance against the Kansas City Chiefs on Monday night. He virtually had the electric scoreboard screaming. Near the end of the game it kept lighting up the sullen, rainfilled skies with alternate flashes of Juice and 1,000.

title: Ford Hearing ChiefHoward Walter Cannon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Three years ago former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew prevailed on a Nevada District Attorney to become the Republican candidate to try to replace Senator Howard Walter Cannon, the Democratic incumbent.

title: MRS. MEYER SALEM
description: Mrs. Shirley Salem, president since 1964 of Salem Stores, a retail and mailorder distributor of lingerie, sportswear and hosiery, died of cancer Wednesday in Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens. She was 54 years old and lived at 124 Onslow Place, Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Canada Trade Surplus Off
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Canada's seasonally adjusted trade surplus in the third quarter was $196million, about one third the level of $614million recorded in the second quarter. This compared with $359million in the first quarter, Statistics Canada said.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Julie: Artisans' Gallery, a newcomer to Madison Avenue, provides a showcase for the distincitve clothes, jewelry and home accessories created by a group of some 100 craftsmen.

title: INDIAN MILITANTS APPEAL FOR UNITY
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 31 Leaders of the American Indian Movement have begun negotiating with older, more established Indian organizations in hopes of forming a national coalition to press for Indian rights.

title: Paul Dudley White Dies
description: Dr. Paul Dudley White, the renowned authority on heart disease who gained prominence as cardiologist to President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1955, died yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 87 years old. Details on Page 46.

title: Please Don't Call 911 Unless It's Real Help!
description: A new TV commercial has been made to discourage use of the police emergency number, 911, for minor complaints. Mayor Lindsay saw the film yesterday.

title: 3 I.R.A. Men Escape by Helicopter From Dublin Jail
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 31 A hijacked helicopter airlifted three Irish Republican Army men to freedom from a prison exercise yard here today.

title: Chess: Another FischerSpassky? Possibly, Quite Possibly
description: After a year of considerably less than spectacular results, Boris Spassky catapulted himself to the forefront of the eight candidates seeking to challenge Bobby Fischer by winning the Soviet championship with an impressive 115 score.

title: Turbo Train Runs to Albany as Bond Lure
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31A gleaming, airlinerstyled turbo train was turned loose on the Toonerville trackage of the Penn Central between New York and Albany today as a symbol of the kind of highspeed train that could be running along the Hudson by 1976.

title: Bethlehem Steel Net Up 175% in Quarter
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday record salesand earnings forthe third quarter and first nine months of 1973.

title: Price Rises Forecast for Men's Outerwear
description: The manufacturers of men's ski jackets, parkas, leather coats and other heavy outerwear predict that these items will cost at least 10 per cent more next fall than they cost now.

title: United Cuts Credit Accord
description: United Air Lines announced yesterday that it had reduced a $300million revolvingcredit agreement to $100million. The agreement is with the First National City Bank and 58 participating banks.

title: William M. Ramsey, Backer Of the Early Soap Operas
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 31  William M. Ramsey, who as director of radio advertising for the Procter & Gamble Company, soap manufacturer, backed the daytime serial dramas that gave the country the phrase soap opera, died here today in Jewish Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Neither Lynn Townsend nor John Riccardo, the chairman and president of the Chrsyler Corporation, have their personal 1974  model automobiles. Reason: there aren't enough cars for their paying customers.

title: Extradition of Vesco Sought on a New Indictment Alleging Fraud
description: Several prosecutors said here; yesterday that they were now attempting to extradite Roberti L. Vesco on the basis of a new indictment charging the fugitive financier with fraud.

title: Donald M. Bermingham, 68, Was Senior Editor of Life
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., Oct. 31Donald M. Bermingham, former editor of Life magazine and of the TimeLife News Service died in Glen Cove Hospital on Monday. He was 68 years old and lived here.

title: Prices Are Down on U. S. Bond Market
description: Prices were down yesterday in the Government bond market as investors and dealers digested the twopart, $3.6billion Treasury refinancing.

title: Yen Drops Sharply Against U.S. Dollar
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 1The Japanese yen took a sharp dip in trading against the United States dollar in the Tokyo foreignexchange market this morning.

title: Navy Contract to Bath Unit
description: The Bath Iron Works Corporation, a subsidiary of Bath Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it had been awarded a $92.4million Navy contract for design construction of the first ship of the Navy's new patrol frigate program. The patrol frigate is a destroyertype vessel designed primarily for escort and sea control.

title: Progress for the Past
description: The progress of the amendments to the Landmarks Law has been about as stately as some of the landmarks themselves, but the proposed revisions coming before the City Council today would eliminate loopholes in the current law and strengthen it considerably.

title: Israel Sees Diplomatic Setback
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31Israel was taken by surprise by the speed with which the United States and the Soviet Union agreed less thin two weeks ago to press jointly for a Middle East ceasefire, official sources here say in reviewing the diplomatic and military moves of the Middle East crisis.

title: MRS. MEIR'S VISIT HELD TEST OF TIES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 The Israelis have been urging their supporters in the United States to avoid criticism of the NixonKissinger policy in the Middle East, according to large number of Congressional sources and informed private citizens.

title: Tornado Hits Florida City
description: FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla.. Oct. 31  A tornado struck at this Gulf of Mexico town today, destroying about a dozen mobile homes and causing several injuries, the officials said.

title: World War II Triangle in 'Triple Echo':The Cast
description: "Triple Echo" is tenderly perceptive about such basics as loneliness, love and some aspects of sex, but as drama, the British import that arrived yesterday at the Playboy and Juliet I Theaters is disquietingly clouded. Although its sincerity and tragedy are obvious, the character and motivations of the principals in the World War II triangle involving an English farm woman, her soldier-lover and the rough sergeant who helps destroy their fragile idyll remain as indistinct as a distant echo.One warms to the pastoral romance that develops between Glenda Jackson, as the self-sufficient farmer tending her lonely acres while her husband is a captive of the Japanese, and the errant, young private from a local base. A viewer accepts the eventual love and sex, her lover's decision to desert and her plan to dress him as her "sister" to avoid detection and gossip, among other things.Miss Jackson's portrayal is, at first, poignant and convincing as she projects dignity and understandable desire for the love and companionship she has long missed.But she is somewhat less than credible subsequently as the strong-willed, bickering woman who, for debatable reasons, creates problems and then suffers her somewhat childish lover's alienation because of them.It is difficult to entertain the idea that Oliver Reed, as the brutish broth of a sergeant, would barge in on the household to make loutish advances, and invite the "sister" to an Army Christmas dance and not quickly discover the masquerade. And it seems improbable that Brian Deacon, a newcomer from British TV in the role of the masquerader, would chance the dangers of near-rape as well as exposure as a deserter. He is youthfully handsome but emotionally shallow in a characterization that could benefit by further explanations.Michael Apted, the director; Robin Chapman, the scenarist, and Graham Cottle, the producer, who are also making their movie debuts, fitfully capture nuances of speech and manners as lovely and real as the muted colors of the film's English countryside. But a larger helping of logic could have made their "Triple Echo" resound, rather than whisper.

title: 4 Race Tracks Indicted on Cahill Contributions
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31  Three race tracks in New Jersey and one in Florida were indicted today on charges of illegally contributing thousands of dollars to Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign and listing the contributions as legitimate business expenses on corporate income tax returns.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 John N. Mitchell, then the director of President Nixon's reelection campaign, returned to Washington from a series of routine political affairs in California on the evening of Monday, June 19, 1972.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Don't be caught cold by the fuel shortage! read a newspaper advertisement for a heater last Sunday.

Kleindienst told the Senate Judiciary Committee last year during the hearings on his nomination for Attorney General.

title: XEROX WON'T BACK '72 ELECTION SHOW
description: The television version of Theodore H. White's The Making of the President1972 has been completed but at the moment is without sponsor or network.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Two White House conversations that were believed to contain evidence critically important to the Watergate criminal investigation were never recorded at all, President Nixon's special counsel said in court today.

title: Pentagon Declares Its Worldwide Alert Of Military Is Over
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The Pentagon today ended its worldwide military alert called last week and 350,000 servicemen returned to normal duties.

title: Reduced Winds Help Contain Coast Blaze That Drove Out Hundreds
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP)  Firemen gained the upper hand today in fighting a fierce brush fire that drove hundreds of persons from canyon homes on the outskirts of Los Angeles.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31President Nixon has signed legislation appropriating $5.2billion for the Treasury Department, Postal Service and other Government operations, the White House announced today. The measure is $133.8million less than Mr. Nixon requested.

title: News Media Moves By Nixon Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Over a onemonth period in the fall of 1969, President Nixon made 21 separate requests to his top aides to take action to counter what the President saw as unfavorable news coverage, according to a memorandum made public tonight by senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: The Gannett Papers In Westchester Bar Backing Candidate
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 31Westchester Rockland Newspapers, a member of the Gannett chain, has decided to support none of the three candidates for Westchester Executive.

title: GAS SUPPLY RATED VERY MARGINAL
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday that it was facing far more serious shortages of natural gas than it had originally expected and that its 1.1 million customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island might be in for a rough winter.

title: Dr. Paul Dudley White Is Dead at 87
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31Dr. Paul Dudley White, the renowned leader in the fight against blood and heart diseases, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital at the age of 87. He had been hospitalized since Oct. 15, when he suffered a massive stroke.

title: Dance: Arpino's Nightwings Revived
description: Frankly speaking, ballet heroes should avoid even psychic encounters with birds and most other fauna. It usually ends either unhappily (think of Siegfried in Swan Lake) or inconclusively (remember Ivan in The Firebird). Then consider all those French ballet heroes and heroines who mingled with cats, wolves, butterflies and the likeit never works out.

title: Study of Nursing Homes Calls TwoThirds Deficient
description: A crash survey by state health inspectors of the 104 profitmaking nursing homes here has found accumulations of dirt and garbage, overcrowding, improper infection control or other serious operating deficiencies in nearly twothirds of the facilities, according to a state health official.

title: Presidential Aides Never Mentioned Tape Troubles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31While details supplied by the White House about the case of two conversations that were said to have been recorded, and now reportedly were not, do not directly conflict with what has been made public abaft the recordings, statements by Presidential aides have made no previous mention of tape troubles.

title: Airlines Slash Domestic Flights Because of U.S. Fuel Allocations
description: Air service over much of the nation is being reduced today as major airlines cut flight schedules because of the Federal mandatory fuel allocation program.

title: MAXWELL HOUSE TO RAISE PRICES
description: The Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase its wholesale prices for ground coffees and decaffeinated instant and freezedried coffees on Dec. 3.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SIC TRANSIT The only appropriate way to go to the new exhibition at the Downtown Museum of the Whitney Museum of American Arts, 55 Water Street, near Old Slip below Wall Street (3443195), is by subway. The second exhibition at this spacious new museum branch room is called Watch the Closing Doors: Mosaics of the New York City Subways.

title: U. S. to Restore Funding of Milk Snack
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today that it would restore full funding of the special milk program to provide snack time milk for schoolchildren.

title: Reverse Negativism
description: Cultural institutions ought to be the last place for resort to the law of the jungle in resolving disputes between management and unionized professional employes. Submitting all unresolved issues to determination by impartial experts makes much more sense in such situations than waiting for one side or the other to crack under the strain of a prolonged strike.

title: Advertising: SoupLabel Gifts
description: At the Camden, N. J., headquarters of the Campbell Soup Company some wags kiddingly call its current Labels for Education program the great ripoff.

title: Spicer to Face Dolphins Again
description: The day last month that Rob Spicer made his first start as a New York Jet, the Jets were trounced by the Miami Dolphins, 313. A rookie linebacker out of Indiana, Spicer was initiated by Larry Csonka, Jim Kiick and Mercury Morris, not to mention the big Dolphin line.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Nov. 1, 1973 Petition filed by:

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 429,584 common shares of the Best Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc. at $37.75 per share was made by underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter.

title: IRISH SOCCER
description: GOLD CUP FINAL

title: Leon Jaworski
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1From the start, as the youngest lawyer ever licensed in Texas, Leon Jaworski has triumphed in legal assignments that nobody else wanted.

title: A Possible Club Over Networks
description: A few days before Patrick V. Buchanan, a White House aide, went on television to amplify President Nixon's charges of news distortion by the electronic media, the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy released a report showing how at least 67 new major stations could be added to the television spectrum in the 100 largest urban centers. While the incidents probably were not conspiratorially coordinated, the coincidence was too close for comfort for many in the television industry. Coming together as they did, they illustrated how the policymaking power of the executive branch mayeven unintentionally  keep the federally licensed media in line.

title: Yes on Amendment 1...
description: The vitally important environmental struggle for pure water requires a functioning three  way partnership among the Federal, state and local levels of government. Each level shares a portion of the expense.

title: Palestinians to Consider Soviet Mideast Proposal
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 1The Soviet Union is sounding out the leadership of the Palestinian guerrillas on possible participation in a Middle East peace conference and on the creation of a Palestinian nation in territory now occupied by Israel.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Ford's Testimony at Hearing on VicePresidential Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony today by Representative Gerald R. Ford, Republican of Michigan, who is President Nixon's nominee for Vice President, before the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration:

title: FIREMEN'S TALKS TERMED SERIOUS
description: Eric J. Schmertz, mediator in the contract dispute between the city and its firemen, described the situation yesterday as extremely serious and said the two sides were far apart on the key money issue.

title: Dublin Sets Up Security Inquiry In Wake of I.R.A. Men's Escape
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 1  Prime Minister Liam Cosgrave announced in Parliament today that there would be a judicial inquiry into state security as, a result of the escape by helicopter yesterday of three top Irish Republican. Army men from Mountjoy Prison here.

title: REYNOLDS INDICTED ON IMPORTS OF ORE
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that a New Orleans grand jury had indicted Reynolds International, Inc., a subsidiary of the Rey nolds Metals Company, on a charge of violating sanctions, against Southern Rhodesia by importing 197 tons of an ore used in making aluminum.

title: Red Smith
description: Meeting in Scottsdale, Ariz., the general managers of baseball teams in the National League have been disporting themselves in Marge Everett's swimming pool while their employers fret about Marge's fitness to join their lodge. Chances are that if financial arrangements satisfactory to Mrs. Everett can be made, the club owners will welcome her as partowner of the San Diego Padres, not because they love her more, but because they esteem Washington less. That's Washington, D, C., where Joseph Danzansky and associates are still extending a hospitable hand with $12million in the palm.

title: Roy Jenkins Given Key Post, Restoring Labor Party Unity
description: LONDON, Nov. 1A degree of unity was restored to the Labor party tonight with the election of Roy Jenkins to the Opposition leadership in Parliament.

title: Upstate Landmark Burns
description: BLOOMINGDALE, N. Y., Nov. 1 (UPI)A landmark in the Essex County village of Bloomingdale destroyed by fire last night was listed today by the state police as a probable case of arson. The twostory wooden structure, known as the Old Schoolhouse and not used for about 20 years, was leveled. It was built in 1915.

title: Winds Deal a Wintry Blow to City
description: It was not your kind of day yesterday if you had an easily mussed hairdo, if you were in a house trailer approaching the George Washington Bridge, if you visited the Empire State Building, if you got your electric power over aboveground lines in Westchester County or if you were James Murphy of the Parks Department.

title: Bertolucci Is Beaten By Nastase
description: PARIS, Nov. 1 (AP) Me Nastase of Rumania, the topseeded player, breezed into the men's singles quarterfinals of the French indoor tennis championship today, but Tom Gorman of Seattle was eliminated.

title: Chase Is 3d Major Bank To Reduce Prime to 9%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday cut its prime rate to 9 per cent, joining the first National City Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany as the only three banking giants at this level.

title: 20 Black Women Poets To Honor Phillis Wheatley
description: A Phillis Wheatley poetry festival marking the bicentennial publication of the 18thcentury black poet's Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral, begins Sunday at Jackson (Miss.) State College.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Hospital Workers Vote for Stoppage Despite Injunction
description: In defiance of a Federal District Court order, members Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Union, voted last night to stop work at 48 of the city's voluntary and municipal hospitals Monday morning.

title: Dining Out on Beef: From Gristly Filets to Fair Steaks
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Nov. 1 (UPI)  The Davis Cup committee, by a majority vote, ruled today that South Africa should continue to play in the South American Zone of the global team tennis competition. W. Harcourt Woods of Short Hills, N.J., chairman of the committee, told newsmen after the group's meeting that South Africa was now scheduled to play Brazil on the weekend beginning Nov. 30 in the first round of play.

title: BETHLEHEM SETS 6% CAPACITY RISE
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to spend nearly a half billion dollars through 1977 to increase its steelmaking capacity by 6.8 per cent. This would he the first major expansion in the industry in several years.

title: WELFARE FRAUD LAID TO MOTHER OF SEVEN
description: A 34yearold Brooklyn mother of seven children was arrested yesterday and Charged A 34yearold Brooklyn mother of seven children was arrested yesterday and charged with concealing extensive assets and fraudulently receiving $40,000 in welfare benefits over a nineyearperiod.

title: SHORTAGES COSTLY TO SOUTHERN PACIFIC
