description: The Southern Pacific Company's president, Benjamin F. Biaggini, complained yesterday that the huge system had lost an estimated $22million of business so far this year because of the national shortage of railroad equipment as well as the fact that one of the severest winters in history had held down shipments from the S.P.'s territory of perishable farm products.

title: William Bart Saxbe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The date was Oct. 11; the place was Columbus, Ohio; and the question put to the senior Senator from Ohio was whether the Nixon Administration was corrupt. The Senator's answer: I don't know whether it's one of the most corrupt, but it's one of the most inept. They just couldn't plan a scenario as ridiculous as what's been going on, and if it keeps on, they're going to have to get 'em clown suits.

title: U.S. Bids Jersey Reduce Private Driving
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1  The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said today it planned to order a program to reduce automobile traffic in New Jersey, requiring employers to charge employes high fees for using company parking lots.New York area, would require employers who have 50 or more employes and who provide parking spaces for at least 70 vehicles, to charge $1 above the going commercial parking rate in the vicinity if only one person is occupying a car.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Nov. 1 were:

title: 2 Alleged Mobsters Menacing a Victim Shoot Each Other
description: Two reputed Mafia gunmen allegedly trying to collect a usurous loan squeezed the debtor between pistol muzzles on the front seat of a car moving near the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday, but shot each other as well as their captive when the car lurched out of control.

title: Nixon's Worst Enemy
description: Richard Nixon's worst enemy is not the press and television. Richard Nixon's worst enemy is Richard Nixon. That may have been suspected when Mr. Nixon first fired Archibald Cox, setting off a national uproar, then turned around and agreed to surrender the tape recordings Mr. Cox had been seeking; but it has been made perfectly clear by the remarkable announcement in Mr. Nixon's behalf that two of those tapes never existed.

title: National Gallery samples Some Moderns
description: WASHINGTON  It wasn't so long ago that a New Yorker could go to Washington in the Morning, spend a few hours getting reacquainted with old favorites the city's few and static art museums and get home in time for supper. But it world take a weekend just now to get around to all the good exhibitions in this country's second museum city.

title: About New York Percy Sutton's Rising Star
description: The election Is not yet here, but the people who think deeply about these things say that Abraham Beame will win it handily, and that when he does, it will make Percy Sutton a man to be reckoned with in the next mayoral election.

title: Maple Leafs Tie Islanders on 3dPeriod Goals, 22
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 1 The Toronto Maple Leafs, perhaps the most improved team in the National Hockey League, erased a twogoal deficit in the third period tonight to tie the New York Islanders, 22, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: TV: Two Women Stars
description: Tonight the Columbia Broadcasting System uses two of its three primetime hours as showcases for women. At 9, the special is called Barbra Streisand . . . And Other Musical Instruments. At 10, it's Lily, starring Lily Tomlin.

title: Wood, Field and Stream:
description: Ideally, one should give more than cursory attention to fly fishing tackle when it is put away for the winter, but this rarely happens.

title: For 59 Detectives at Course on Murder, Stress Was on Making Evidence Stand Up
description: The subject was murder, occurring at the rate of fourandahalf a day in New York City. The students were men whom the city depends upon to find out how a murder happened, why it happened and who did it.

title: Cotton Futures Prices Decline; Silver and Wheat Close Higher
description: Cotton futures prices dropped on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, probably reflecting a Government report that showed record world cotton crop for 19731974. This comes at a time when there has been a drop in the United States cotton crop.

title: New Books
description: After Keynes: Papers presented to Section F (Economics) at the 1972 Annual Meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, edited by Joan Robinson (Barnes & Noble, $13.50).

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MAYOR'S NEST The old unanswered question about the Mayor of New York is Who in his right mind would want the job? Well, we not only have a covey of candidates waiting for victory on Tuesday, but we also have two exhibitions telling us about those hardy souls, in right mind or not, who have held it in the past.

title: Arms Panel Nominees Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of J. Owen Zurhellen Jr. to be deputy director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. The committee also approved the nomination of Robert H. Miller to be an assistant director of, the agency. It deferred action on the nomination of Rear Adnn. Thomas B. Davies to be another assistant director.

title: Six Sunday Games Will Be Televised
description: Six of Sunday's 12 National Football League games plus Monday night's game with Washington at Pittsburgh are sellouts and will be televised locally, N.F.L. officials said yesterday.

title: Kings Top Rangers To End Spell, 21
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1The twoweek slump of the New York Rangers continued tonight as they lost to the Los Angeles Kings for the first time in 21 games, spread over four seasons.

title: Notes on People
description: Looking frail but nonetheless proud, Lady SpencerChurchill yesterday unveiled a massive bronze statue of her late husband, Winston Churchill, on Parliament Square, overlooking the houses of Parliament.

title: Merrill Lynch Sets Up Government Bond Unit
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., the holding company parent of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the nation's largest brokerage firm, announced yesterday plans to form a new subsidiary. Merrill Lynch Government Securities, Inc.

title: People in Sports: Trade Stuns Reuss
description: Jerry Reuss, a lefthanded pitcher traded by the Houston Astros to the Pittsburgh Pirates on Wednesday, does not think the Astros received enough in payment for him. The Pirates gave up Milt May, a catcher who hit 269 with seven home runs last season.

title: Richard F. Cancellere, 60, Of Service Employes Union
description: Richard F. Cancellere, secretary treasurer of Local 32B, Service Employes International Union and president of the union's Joint Council No. 11, representing 125,000 service workers in Greater New York, died Wednesday at New York University Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 2700 Henry Hudson Parkway East, Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Amex Ends Ahead Despite Late Drop
description: After making strong gains early in the session, prices hacked down some but still closed higher in moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Prices in the overthecounter market dropped again, however.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In the year since the city's Noise Control Code was enacted, 3,152 violation notices were issued. The Department of Air Resources, which polices the code, said.yesterday that more than 6,300 noise complaints had been received since Oct. 12, 1972.

title: Maryland Inquiry on Senator Ends With No Charges Filed
description: ANNAPOLIS. Md., Nov. 1 The Maryland authorities ended today their fourmonth investigation of secret White House funding in the 1970 campaign of Senator J. Glenn Beall Jr. without bringing any charges against Mr. Beall or any campaign officials.

title: Why Heads Rollin New York Stores
description: In the last two years, the stormy climate of New York retailing has created turmoil in executive suites.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On Nov. 6, the voters of New York State will be asked to vote on Amendment No. 5 to the State Constitution. This is a critical amendment, and yet it has received virtually no publicity and hence most voters are unaware of both its content and its importance.

title: Tough Foes Await Jets And Giants
Toyota Gives to Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1 In what appears to be a growing trend of foreign philanthropy by the Japanese, the Toyota Motor Company today gave $1million to Harvard University to help establish an institute for Japanese studies.

title: 3 Arrested as Plotters Against Bolivian President
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 1 (Reuters)President Hugo Banzer Suarez of Bolivia has survived another plot to overthrow his militarybacked rightwing administration, the Government has announced.

title: Trevino, Ginn Share Golf Lead With 68's
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 1 (UPI)Lee Trevino of Et Paso, Tex., carded a fiveunderpar 68 today to share the lead with Stewart Ginn of Australia in the first round of the $75,000 Chrysler classic at Lakes Course.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $992million, up 6 per scent from the yearearlier $933million. Total retail sales were about $9.9billion, up 10 per cent from last year's $9billion.

title: New Martha's Vineyard Fire
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Nov. 1 (Reuters)  A suspicious fire, the ninth in this exclusive island resort area in the last three weeks, heavily damaged an unoccupied summer home early today. The police and residents maintained a close vigil, especially at night, over homes in the area on the watch for an arsonist believed to be responsible for most or all of the fires.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1973

title: Striking Musicians Seek New Sessions
description: Although the management of the New York Philharmonic announced a total breakdown in the negotiations yesterday, a ray of hope remained glimmering in the fiveweek strike by Philharmonic musicians. Max Arons, president of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, sent telegrams to Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller, saying the union was ready to meet at any time with negotiators and that, if a contract were agreed upon, the 106 Philharmonic musicians would return to work forthwith.

title: Even Today, Freshmen Can Be Homesick
description: The class of '77 has been away from home for almost two months now, and it hasn't been easy.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Baltimore  Ron Lyle, 218 pounds, Denver, outpointed Larry Middleton, 205, Baltimore, 10 rounds.

title: 8 in U.N. Offer Formula On Filling Mideast Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1A group of eight nations tonight proposed a formula that could open the way for troops from Panama, Nepal and perhaps an African country to join the contingents already on duty with the United Nations peacekeeping force in the Middle East.

title: FORD SEES ROLE AS PEACEMAKER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Representative Gerald R. Ford assured a Senate committee today that, as Vice President, he would attempt to be a peacemaker and a calm communicator between the White House and Capitol Hill.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: The Exit of Soviet Jews Via Austria Is Unabated
description: VIENNA, Nov. 1The train from Bratislava on the Czech border arrived in Vienna's south Station today at 12:25, three minutes behind schedule. It brought with it 27 tired and dirty. Jewish emigrants from the Soviet Union, most of whom will be on their way to Israel tonight.

title: Trading Is Quiet in Bond Markets
description: The corporate and taxexempt bond markets were quiet yesterday. Prices of taxexempt issues closed slightly lower.

title: PRESIDENT'S AIDES REPORTEDLY TOOK TAPES FROM SAFE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Secret Service agents testified today that more than 30 tape recordings of Presidential conversations had been removed from a safe by White House aides at the request of President Nixon, and that their return had never been recorded.

title: Crenshaw Cards 65 In Debut
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 1 (AP)Ben Crenshaw, playing in his first tournament after receiving his approved player's card, scored a sixunderpar 65 for the firstround lead today in the $125,000 San AntonioTexas open gulf tournament.

title: M.D.'s Split on Mercy Killer's Sanity
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 1Three psychiatrists testified today in the mercy killing trial of Lester Zygmaniak, and there was disagreement over whether the defendant was sane when the shot his paralyzed brother in a hospital bed last June.

title: People and Business
description: While Congress prepares to deliberate the new trade bill and the issue of tariff concessions to Russia, a top Soviet official is in the United States discussing trade between the two nations.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: COLLEGE BOMBER IS SENT TO PRISON
description: MADISON, Wis., Nov. 1 Judge William C. Sachtjen of Dane County Circuit Court today sentenced Karleton Lewis Armstrong to an indeterminate prison term not to exceed 23 years.

title: 5 Families Tell Who They Want for Mayorand Why
description: After months of campaign oratory, the voters of New York will bring to a conclusion next Tuesday what political observers maintain has been one of the leasteventful mayoral campaigns in years.

title: STRIKERS ACCUSE MODERN MUSEUM
description: Striking workers at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday accused the museum director of deliberately prolonging the labor dispute there in order to starve the union into submission.

title: Futures Panel to Study Trading by Foreigners
description: The Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives has named a special panel to study the possible use of futures trading by foreign governments to influence prices. A year ago there was some feeling that the Russians could have profited by buying wheat futures contracts in advance of the announcement of their large purchases, and that this trading could have been handled quietly through Switzerland.

title: MOHAMMED SAID, EXIRAN PREMIER
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 1 (AP) Mohammed Maraghei Said, a former Premier of Iran, died today after a long illness. He was 92 years old.

title: MAN IS HELD IN RAPE OF A BLIND WOMAN
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge held a young drifter in $50,000 bail yesterday on a charge of raping a young blind married woman in her West Side apartment Wednesday.

title: DARRAGH A. PARK JR.
description: Darragh A. Park Jr., a founder and chairman of the board of Park, Ryan, Inc., municipal bond brokers, died yesterday at his home, 1040 Park Avenue. He was 58 years old.

title: IRISH SOCCER
description: By Reuters

title: Total Daylight Saving Urged
description: BOSTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) Legislation to extend daylight saving time to the entire year in Massachusetts was approved by the state's House of Representatives, 215 to 7, yesterday.

title: Stage Uncertain Molly
description: Kay Ballard strode onstageat the Alvin Theater last .. night to receive a standing ovation. She grinned at the audience with what looked like a mixture of gratitude and relief. She had been Molly in the new musical Molly, and not even a White House electronics expert could have worked harder.

title: New Missiles Are Enabling Infantry to, Counter Planes and Tanks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 A principal conclusion being drawn from the Middle East war by United States militaryanalysts is that relatively simple mobile weapons used ground troops can blunt the effectiveness of fighterbombers and tanks, which for three decades have dominated the battlefield.

title: President Sets Up Panel, Averting L.I.R.R. Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)President Nixon set up a threemember emergency board today to investigate a dispute between the Long Island Rail Road and members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen. The union threatened to strike tomorrow.

title: Revised Lakers to Test Same Old Knick Script
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1Back at the scene of their last great triumph, the championship game of 1973 last May, the New York Knicks found the Los Angeles Lakers, their victims in the only two titles New York has ever won, drastically changed.

title: Vatican Seeking to Broaden Religious Freedom in Spain
description: MADRID, Nov. 1 (AP) Spain and the Vatican began talks today on reopening negotiations for a new Churchstate compact. The Vatican reportedly was seeking the widest religious freedom for Spaniards since the country's Civil War three decades ago.

title: SENTENCES SCORED IN HIJACKING CASE
description: A case study in which a State Supreme Court justice in Queens was found to have permitted eight defendants to continue their criminal careers while serving five years' probation for the possession of $100,000 worth of stolen women's clothing was disclosed yesterday by the State Committee on Crime.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Amsterdam News Aide Quits an Endorsement
description: In a conflict arising out of The New York Amsterdam News's endorsement for Controller, H. Carl McCall, chairman of the paper's editorial board, resigned yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: PRESIDENT'S AIDES REPORTEDLY TOOK TAPES FROM SAFE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Secret Service agents testified to day that more than 30 tape recordings of Presidential con versations had been removed from a safe by White House aides at the request of Presi dent Nixon, and that their re turn had never been recorded

title: Hyland Eager for Giant Role
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 1The promise of tomorrow, which has followed Bob Hyland throughout his pro football career, again stalks him as he sits on the bench for the skidding New York Giants.

title: Giants Give Jersey Till Dec. 1; After That It's a Complex Issue
description: The New York Giants, who play football in New Haven and are planning to move to New Jersey, have agreed to give Jersey until Dec. 1 to show it can float a bond issue to pay for the football stadium in the Hackensack Meadows.

title: What's Best for America?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1In his confirmation hearings before the Senate Rules Committee, Gerald Ford, the VicePresidential nominee, recalled that President Eisenhower had a very simple rule for public men: Get all the facts and all the good counsel you can, and then do what's best for America.

title: 22 INDICTED BY U.S. IN EQUITY SCANDAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1Twenty former executives and employes of the bankrupt Equity Funding Corporation of America and two of the company's former auditors were accused today in a 105count indictment handed down by a Federal grand jury.

title: One Question Marks Ford Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1If one thing was made perfectly clear in this first slow, polite day of Senate committee hearings on the nomination of Representative Gerald R. Ford to be Vice President, it is that consulting a psychiatrist or psychotherapist is still an unforgivable sin for an American politician.

title: The Exit of Soviet Jews Via Austria Is Unabated
description: VIENNA, Nov. 1The train from Bratislava on the Czech border arrived in Vienna's South Station today at 12:25, three minutes behind schedule. It brought with it 27 fired and dirty Jewish emigrants from the Soviet Union, most of whom will be on their way to Israel tonight.

title: Broadway Central CaveIn Laid To Owner's Failure to Fix Wall
description: The collapse of the Broadway Central Hotel last Aug. 3, which killed four persons, was caused by the building owner's failure to repair a badly weakened support wall that was damaged by an apparently unapproved drainagepipe installation about 30 years ago, the Department of Buildings announced yesterday.

title: German Riding Style Applauded
New Perry Mason Series To Be Replaced by C.B.S.
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System has given cancellation notice to The New Perry Mason series on Sunday nights and will replace it on Feb. 10 with a new onehour family series by the creative team responsible for The Waltons.

title: 1969 Rise in Cabinet Pay Could Prove Bar to Saxbe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Senator William B. Saxbe's nomination to be Attorney General ran into constitutional difficulties today, and the Justice Department conceded that remedial legislation would be needed before he could take office.

title: Harvard's Hopes at Stake In Penn Game Tomorrow
description: Penn and Harvard will clash tomorrow in Franklin Field, and this important Ivy League football game may attract 40,000 spectators.

title: U.S. HAD CONSIDERED MORE AGNEW COUNTS
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (UPI)Federal prosecutors considered filing obstruction of justice charges against Spiro T. Agnew after they were told attempts had been made to influence the testimony of witnesses in the inquiry that led to the Vice President's resignation. United States Attorney George Beall said today.

title: Pop Music: Dolls Fans Visit Waldorf for Halloween
description: The trouble with glitter rock in New York is that it brings out so many of the bizarros, and the social takes over from the music. And it was never more so than on WednesdayHalloween.

title: Many Congressmen Still Want Totally Independent Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Despite President Nixon's announcement today naming Leon Jaworski as the new Watergate special prosecutor, the tide in Congress was still running toward setting up the office totally independent of Presidential control.

title: PATRICIA CRAIG SINGS MOVING BUTTERFLY
description: Paricia Craig slipped into the title role of Madama Butterfly for the first time with the company in Wednesday night's performance by the New York City Opera, and she made it fit her with a semblance of comfort, if not with tailormade snugness. Miss Craig, although not robust of voice, made her lyric soprano tell to excellent effect, particularly in the second act, where the Frank Corsaro staging calls for Butterfly to make a touching effort to transform herself into a Western woman.

title: Doctors Differ on Sanity In Jersey Mercy Killing
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 1Three psychiatrists testified today in the mercy killing trial of Lester Zygmaniak, and there was disagreement over whether the defendant was sane when he shot his paralyzed brother in a hospital bed last June.

title: Mandel Announces Bid For Reelection in Maryland
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 1 (UPI)Gov. Marvin Mandel announced today that he would campaign for another term on a record of good clean government.

title: Keeping Options Open
description: Emerging from her highly delicate discussions with President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger yesterday, Premier Golda Meir offered welcomeand, unfortunately, necessaryassurances to her own people that the United States will not sacrifice Israel's basic interests in striving for dtente with the Soviet Union. A mood of disillusionment, even despair, inside Israel has grown into a potential threat to the spirit of accommodation which has to be nurtured on all sides if the present modest beginnings toward a negotiated IsraeliEgyptian settlement are not to be undermined.

title: MatchPlaying Cited in Fire
description: DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 1 (AP)An apartment fire that resulted in the asphyxiation death of three children Oct. 22 was probably caused by children playing with matches, Danbury Fire Marshal Fred Tomaino said today. The victims were identified as Iesha Barnes, 3 years old, and her brother and sister, Marlou, 3, and James, 1.

title: CINEMATHEQUE GETS QUEENSBORO SITE
description: American Cinematheque, constituent of the City Center of Music and Drama, acquired a site yesterday for the construction of a film museum, three movie auditoriums and other related facilities in more than 50,000 square feet of space under the Manhattan approach to the Queensboro Bridge.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Nixon Flies to Florida Without Press
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1For the first time since he has been President, Richard M. Nixon made a longdistance flight today on his Air Force jet without a pool of reporters and photographers on board.

title: Harlem School Unit Under Investigation For Funds Misuse
description: The possible misuse of funds totaling nearly $100,000 by Harlem's School District 5 is being investigated by the Manhattan District Attorney's Office and the office of Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 0.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 190.5 from 191.1 last week.

title: Peronist Union Leader Is Slain; Sixth Political Killing Recently
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1 (AP) A leftist Peronist labor leader was shot to death yesterday after being dragged from his house by an armed group.

title: Indian State Sets New Course
description: BANGALORE, India, Nov. 1  Karnataka! shouted flagwaving children marching beneath the jacaranda trees in Cubbon Park. Karnataka! shrieked the parade marchers stepping along the downtown streets of this cool leafy South Indian capital. Karnataka! exclaimed the chief minister in a speech this morning.

title: FULTON MALL PLAN LAUDED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay unveiled plans yesterday for the $4million Fulton Street Mall in downtown Brooklyn with an elation that contrasted with his disappointment last July when his toppriority Madison Avenue Mall project went down to defect before the Board of Estimate.

title: FIRM HERE CITES STANS FUND PLEA
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 1Maurice H. Stans, President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign finance chairman, unsuccessfully sought a contribution of at least $100,000 from one of the country's largest firms of certified public accountants, the firm's general counsel said tonight.

title: G.O.P. Affair Canceled; Watergate Hurt Sales
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 1 (UPO)The state Republican party canceled today a fundraising dinner with Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois because Watergate developments hurt sales of tickets for the $100aplate affair.

title: 22 INDEED BY U.S. IN EQUITY SCANDAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov, 1Twenty former executives and employes of the bankrupt Equity Funding Corporation of America and two of the company's former auditors were accused today in a 105count indictment handed down by a Federal grand jury.

title: City Acts to Protect Interiors of Historic Buildings
description: A bill that would give the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission the power for the first time to designate interiors of buildings as landmarks was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council Committee on Charter and Government Appropriations.

title: YAKIR IS REPORTED LIVING NEAR MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1 (Reuters) Pyotr Yakir, a former leading Soviet dissident given a threeyear prison sentence in September after pleading guilty to antiSoviet activities, has been freed and is living in exile near Moscow, dssident sources said today.

title: Chains' Sales Gains Lag
description: Sluggish consumer buying, which began in September, became more evident in October as a number of the nation's largest retail chains reported sales gains which were below those of earlier months of the year.

title: Yankees Hire Replacement for MacPhail
description: The New York Yankees, who have 15 owners but no manager, began to reshape their frontoffice team yesterday by hiring an executive vice president from the Houston Astros.

title: Agnew's Lawyer Explains Action Against Press
description: One of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's lawyers said yesterday that Mr. Agnew had not intended in his court case to compel reporters to reveal the sources of their information, but that the news media had forced him to adopt that strategy.

title: Union Carbide to Construct
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it would construct a multimilliondollar vinyl acetate plant at the company's chemicals complex at Texas City, Tex.

title: The Pop Life
description: Charlie Rich swept this year's Country Music Association awards the other week with just one songhis Behind Closed Doors was named best single record, Rich's LP with the same title was the year's best and Rich himself was voted male singer of the year. Behind this overnight success (he has been performing for 25 years) was a smooth operation.

title: MRS. MEIR TELLS OF REASSURANCE IN NIXON MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Premier Golda Meir of Israel, after meeting for more than an hour with President Nixon, said today that she was reassured of continued American support for Israel's security and wellbeing.

title: EQUALIZING ASKED IN FUEL OIL PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Malvin P. Sevin, a Westbury, L. I., heatingoil retailer says he is losing customers to major oil companies because they charge 22 or 23 cents a gallon and he must charge 29.4 cents.

title: MINORITIES' LAG IN PUBLIC TV SEEN
description: Public television, which has taken a leading interest in the problems of minorities, the elderly, the poor and children, must also address itself to the fundamental issue of enriching the quality of minority involvement.

title: New Program Is Sought For Delinquent Children
description: Efforts are under way to revive some form of a new experimental program for disturbed and delinquent children, according to both the State Judicial Conference's Office for Children's Services and the State Mental Hygiene Department.

title: Four on School Bus Killed
description: MADISON, Ind., Nov. 1 (AP) Four junior high school pupils were killed and six others were injured seriously yesterday when a semitrailer truck and their school bus collided. The dead were identified as Brenda Burchfield, 14 years old, Steven Walters, 15, Ernest Kessler, 14, and Janet Kessler, 15.

title: Flyers Top Hawks, 10, With Parent
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov: (AP) Bernie Parent scored his fourth shutout of the season in goal tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 10, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Prices of Fertilizers Increased As U.S. Controls Are Removed
description: Since the Cost of Living Council removed price controls on fertilizers last week, several major producers have raised their prices sharply, Two more Texasgulf and Allied Chemicalmoved yesterday.

title: ISRAEL SAYS EGYPT VIOLATED CEASEFIRE
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 1 (UPI)Israel charged today that Egypt has broken the Middle East ceasefire for the second day in a row by attacking Israeli positions along the east bank of the Suez Canal,

title: Picking a Saxbe Successor Up to Gilligan, a Democrat
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1Confirmation of William Saxbe as United States Attorney General would present variety of options for Ohio Gov. John J. Gilligan, a Democrat, and produce a major headache for the Ohio Republican party.

title: Fuel Rationing's Effect on Air Travel Appears Slight
description: Federal rationing of jet fuel began yesterday with apparently little inconvenience for airline travelers.

title: Guild Picks News for a Possible Strike
description: The Newspaper Guild announced yesterday that it had selected The Daily News as its target fora strike at 7 A.M. Monday if a new contract agreement was not reached by that time.

title: Nixon Names Saxbe Attorney General; Jaworski Appointed Special Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1President Nixon announced today that he would nominate Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, to be his fourth Attorney General.

title: White House Papers Outline Pressure on Networks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The White House undertook a broad campaign in 1970 to pressure the television networks into tempering criticism of President Nixon and refusing free air time to his Democratic opponents, according to White House documents obtamed by the Senate Watergate committee.

title: 49ers Will Start Brodie
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 (UPI)  Coach Dick Nolan said today John Brodie, who already has announced his retirement, would be the starting quarterback Sunday when the San Francisco 49ers play the Lions at Detroit. Steve Spurrier started the last two games for San Francisco, but in both cases Brodie, now in his 17th pro season, had to replace him.

title: Milsteins Quit as Heads of Kinney and Uris
description: Paul Milstein, president of the National Kinney Corporation and his brother Seymour, president of the Uris Buildings Corporation, both resigned suddenly yesterday afternoon.

title: Jackson and Love Urge Congress to Enact Legislation to Deal With the Shortage of Imported Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The principal energy spokesmen for Congress and the Administration stood shoulder to shoulder today and asserted that, Congress should enact enengyconservation legislation to deal with the worsening shortage of imported oil.

title: Crowds and Demonstrators Focus Attention on Beame
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame strolled serenely yesterday amid friendly crowds and yelling demonstrators who seemed to have decided that he was the candidate to focus on as the likely winner in next Tuesday's mayoral election.

title: USLIFE Merger Approved
description: Directors of the All American Life & Financial Corporation and the USLIFE Corporation approved previously proposed terms for the acquisition of All American by USLIFE. The deal involves about 3,31 million shares of USLIFE, valued yesterday at $108.5million.

title: An Entree That's Easy to Prepare
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Mideast Counsel
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Senator Fulbright has rendered a major public service by restating in recent days his conviction that a viable settlement in the Middle East requires not only a United Nations guarantee but also an identical bilateral treaty between Israel and the United Statesnot an executive agreement but a treaty consented to by the Senate  under which the United States would guarantee the territory and independence of Israel within its adjusted borders.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Sex, sports and some good, sensible, go  everywhere clothesthese were some of the topics touched upon in yesterday's batch of spring fashion openings on Seventh Avenue. Sex first, o.k.?

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 1Before Ron San Fillipo could say Kean College he had won his first four football games. Now that he can freely say Kean College, known as Newark State until its name was changed three weeks ago, San Fillipo has lost his last three games and a few players. His biggest problem now is finding substitutes for the substitutes because the substitutes also are hurt.

title: Sears Says Dishwashers May Cause Electric Shock
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co. said yesterday it was trying to contact the owners of some 65,000 portable dishwashers about possible safety hazard.

title: A CLOSE CONTEST SEEN BY SANDMAN
description: MORRISTOWN, Nov. 1Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. said today that his own poll showed him still trailing his Democratic opponent, Brendan T. Byrne.

title: Family of Man Medallion Given To Kissinger for Peace Efforts
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger last night was award ed the gold medallion of the Socity for the Family of Man for massive contributions ward the search for peace and the reduction of world tensions.

title: Canada to Increase Tax on Oil Shipped To U.S. by 375%
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 1 (AP)Canada, the United States top source of foreign oil, announced tonight that she was increasing her export tax on crude oil by 375 per cent.

title: Sympatico Wins jump Test
description: The third session of the National Horse Show ended on what seemed a jet propulsion note last night when Alligator Farm's Sympatico, ridden by Anthony d'Ambrosio, captured the $2,000 Puissance jumping stake at Madison Square Garden after four jumpoffs.

title: 1969 Rise in Cabinet Pay Could Prove Bar to Saxbe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Senator William B. Saxbe's nomination to be Attorney General ran into constitutional difficulties today, and the Justice Department conceded that remedial legislation would be needed before he could take office.

title: U.S. Financial May Delist
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday voted to ask the Securties and Exchange Commission to permit it to delist securities of U.S. Financial, Inc. Trading in U.S. Financial was suspended on Dec. 5, 1972, and the company filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Dean of Buyers, 100, Dies
description: LYNN, Mass, Nov. 1 (UPI)Clarence E. Morse, considered the dean of buyers, who celebrated his 100th birthday June 29, died Wednesday after a brief illness. He had worked for the T. W. Rogers Company department store here since 1898, a decade after he entered the retail buying business.

title: Dispute Over Nixon Call Rises Again
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  A nagging conflict in statements that has persisted throughout the Senate Watergate hearings, arose again in testimony today.

title: Net Income at LTV In Sharp Recovery; Telex Shows Loss
Athens Regime to Let Theodorakis Go Home
description: ATHENS, Nov. 1 (Reuters)  Mike Theodorakis, a Greek composer who went into selfexile because of his opposition to the militarybacked Government, can return to Greece, it was officially announced today.

title: CHRYSLER SETS RISE IN '74MODEL PRICES
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation announced today its intention to raise car and truck prices an average of $63.25 to meet material and labor costs, including wage increases in its recently negotiated contract with the United Auto Workers.

title: DEMOCRATS HERE OBSERVING TRUCE
description: As the mayoral campaign moved into its final five days, the city's warring Democratic factions have declared an unofficial truce in the expectation that they will have a friendController Abraham D. Beanieat City Hall for the first time in 12 years.

title: Kewanee and Husky Discuss Affiliation
description: Kewanee Oil Company and Husky Oil, Ltd., announced yesterday that the two companies were conducting broad general discussions toward possible affiliation.

title: Lyle H. Munson, 55, Publisher Of RightWing Books, Is Dead
description: MATTOON, Ill., Nov, 1 Lyle H. Munson, a former Central Intelligence Agency agent and proprietor of The Bookmailer, a small publishing house, died today. He was 55 years old.

title: Bridge: OverBobbed Aces Team Has A Problem in Communications
description: One of the minor problems of Ira Corn Jr., nonplaying captain of the Aces team, which won the international playoff matches in Milwaukee this week, is one of nomenclature. If he shouts Bob, he may find his summons answered by any of the three senior members of his team, Bob Wolff, Bob Hamman or Bob Goldman.

title: Kheel Admits Some Transit Aid Is Possible Without Bond Issue
description: Theodore W. Kheel conceded during a debate yesterday that some moneys will be forthcoming from other sources to help subsidize the endangered transit fare even if the state's voters reject the proposed $3.5billion transportation bond issue.

title: FORD SEES ROLE AS PEACEMAKER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Representative Gerald R. Ford assured a Senate committee today that, as Vice President, he would attempt to be a peacemaker and a calm communicator between the White House and Capitol Hill.

title: Catherine Drinker Bowen, Holmes Biographer, Dies
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 1Catherine Drinker Bowen, one of America's foremost biographers, died today of cancer at her home here. She was 76 years old.

title: Imperiale's Senate Race: Challenge to Both Parties
description: NEWARK, Nov. 1  Here in the 30th Legislative District, there is one overriding topic in the campaign for State Senator that blurs all other issues and perhaps traditional political allegiances; Anthony Imperiale and what he represents.

title: General Dynamics Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Navy today awarded $500million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation of Groton, Conn., for seven high speed SSN688 attack submarines. General Dynamics's electricboat division won the contract over the Newport News Shipbuilding Company of Newport News, Va.

title: Stage: 2 Church Groups
description: Remember two venerable properties titled Rip Van Winkle and Oklahoma!? They're back, housed in two Off Broadway churches and bless them both.

title: Johnson Helps Q's Top Tams, 103100
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 1 (UPI)Despite a fractured big toe on his right foot, Stew Johnson dropped in his team's final 6 points tonight as the San Diego Conquistadors beat the Memphis Tams, 103100, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Dow Drops 7.75 As Slide Continues
description: Stock prices continued to slide yesterday in a partial correction of the hue sixweek advance that started rolling in midSeptember.

title: 3 in Motorcycle Gang Cleared in Rape Case
description: HACKENSACK, Nov. 1 (UPI)Three members of the Breed motorcycle gang were acquitted today of charges that they repeatedly raped and beat a 15yearold Lodi girl last summer after a party.

title: Seoul Reports Pact on Kidnapping Case
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1 Foreign Minister Kim Yong Shik announced today that South Korea had reached a diplomatic settlement with Japan in their dispute over the abduction of Kim Dae Jung from Tokyo to Seoul last August.

title: Impeachment Then and Now
description: WASHINGTONAs a small boy witnessed the wave of rage and rebellion that swept Washington when Harry Truman sacked General MacArthur. The Truman Administration had already experienced more than its share of scandals (State and Justice Departments, Internal Revenue and White House staff, to name a few disaster sites), and charges of the most corrupt Administration in American history whistled through the air like grapeshot.

title: FastGrowth Cotton May Curb Weevils
description: In an effort to control boll weevils without heavy use of pesticides, agricultural scientists in Texas have developed a smaller, fastergrowing cotton plant They believe the new hybrid will come to maturity earlier in the season before the pests reproduce in large numbers and bore in and ruin the young fibers.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE COMING OF POSTINDUSTRIAL SOCIETY: A Venture in Social Forecasting. By Daniel Bell. 528 pages. Basic Books. $12.50.

title: RUTGERS UNIT ASKS SUIT ON AUTONOMY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 1  Rutgers University was urged today by its University Senate a facultystudentadministrative body, to start legal action against the State of New Jersey to stop alleged encroachments upon the university's statutory autonomy.

title: U. S. URGED TO ACT IN CITY FUEL CRISIS
description: The city has asked the Federal Government to prevent the cutoff of home heating oil to 20,000 families here if a major oil supplier carries out a threat to curtail its business sharply by next week.

title: MRS. MEIR TELLS OP REASSURANCE IN NIXON MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Premier Golda Meir of Israel, after meeting for more than an hour with President Nixon, said today that she was reassured of continued American support for Israel's security and wellbeing.

title: Some Dairy Quotas Lifted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) President Nixon ordered today the temporary lifting of quotas on imports of some dairy products, including butter and cream.

title: Special Prosecutor...
description: Possibly the most important legislation pending Congress today is the bill to establish an independent prosecutor in the Watergate case. Until such an office is established under protection of the District Court the District of Columbia, the files assembled at direction of former Special Prosecutor...chibald Cox are in jeopardy. With each passing day, there is a growing risk that the able staff that Mr. Cox organized may become demoralized and its work brought to a halt. Mr. Nixon's attempt at this juncture to intrude a prosecutor agreeable to himself into the proceedings can only be regarded as a disruptive maneuver.

title: Amnesty Group in Private Soviet Talks
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1Amnesty International, the Britishbased organization that intercedes in behalf of political prisoners around the world, is conducting private talks with Soviet officials' about the treatment of political prisoners here.

title: WHITE HOUSE ENDS PLEA ON TRADE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Administration abandoned efforts to delay House action on the foreigntrade bill today, clearing the way for a debate over Soviet policy on the emigration of Jews to Israel.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Israel Sees to War's Hidden Wounds
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 1About 100 psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers, as well as an equal nun F her of nonprofessional volunleers, are working around the clock in Jerusalem to treat, counsel and help civilian victims of the war: Those who suffer from stress and other emotional problems and the families of the dead, wounded and missing.

title: New Orders Fell in September; Construction Rate Was Also Off
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Commerce Department reported today that new orders for manufactured goods de clined 1.6 per cent in September, a sharp drop that reflected a general slowing down of economic activity.

title: YEN OFF SHARPLY FOR A SECOND DAY
description: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 2  A surge of dollar buying on the foreignexchange market here went into its second day this morning, pushing the value of the Japanese yen to its lowest point since the currency crisis last winter. There was strong evidence that the current chaos in the international oil situation was a major cause.

title: Crenshaw Cards 65 In Debut
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 1 (AP)Ben Crenshaw, playing in his first tournament after receiving his approved player's card, scored a sixunderpar 65 for the firstround lead today in the $125,000 San AntonioTexas open golf tournament.

title: Cambodian History Is Reshaped
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 1The United States Embassy recently reported, somewhat belatedly, that the insurgents attempted to mount a big offensive against the Cambodian capital 10 days after the American bombing halt on Aug. 15, but that it was repulsed, largely by Government artillery.

title: Those Fellows With the Racing Forms Are College Students You Can Beton It
Rail Freight Traffic Is Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.5 billion tonmiles, 5.7 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same period totaled 564,432 cars, 2.7 per cent above the same period last year.

title: A.E.C. Reports Accident at Uranium 235 Test Facility
description: The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed yesterday that an accident occurred Oct. 20 in its experimental facility at Oak Ridge, Tenn., which is used to obtain uranium 235 by the socalled gas centrifuge method.

title: Thanksgiving Fast By Students Urged To Protest Racism
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. A committee of social activists, writers and academicians called on college students today to fast at their family Thanksgiving tables as a national rededication to the struggle against racism in the universities, in the White House and in their home towns.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Nov. 1 were:

title: Byrne Doubts WhiteEthnic Vote Shift
description: MORRISTOWN, Nov. 1 doubt today that many of the voters whom his opponent for Governor, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., calls peripheral urban ethnics Brendan T. Byrne expressed would foresake traditional Democratic loyalties Tuesday to support Mr. Sandman.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Central Regional High School in Berkeley Township was closed yesterday after black and white students began menacing each other in the hallways, according to the police.

title: New Supply Convoy Reaches Beleaguered Egyptian Corps on Eastern Bank
description: CAIRO, Nov. 1The United Nations announced here today that another convoy with food, water and medical supplies this one with 12 trucks  had reached the encircled Egyptian III Corps on the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.

title: Steinberg's Baton Gets Superb Results
description: William Steinberg, not as spry as he used to be but as expert and knowledgeable as ever, conducted the Pittsburgh Symphony on Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Steinberg, who had been ill last year, has a chair on his podium and uses it until he forgets his doctor's advice. Then he rises and engages the music in bodily as well as intellectual contact.

title: FastGrowth Cotton May Curb Weevils
description: In an effort to control boll weevils without heavy use of pesticides, agricultural scientists in Texas have developed a smaller, fastergrowing cotton plant. They believe the new hybrid will come to maturity earlier in the season before the pests reproduce in large numbers and bore in and ruin the young fibers.

title: U.S. Bids Jersey Reduce Private Driving
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1  The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said today it planned to order a program to reduce automobile traffic in New Jersey, requiring employers to charge employes high fees for using company parking lots.

title: Eyes on New Jersey
description: The election of a Governor of New Jersey arouses national interest apart from the fact that it is one of the very few to be held in an oddnumbered year. With 7.2 million people crowded into 7,800 square miles, New Jersey has the greatest population density of the fifty states. It is the most urban, but also the most suburban, state in the Union.

title: The Proceedings In the U. N. Today
About the Jets:
description: There is no truth to the report that Joe Namath is finished for the season. Namath made the remark in a television interview, but he did it in his best puton manner. Told that the television network (American Broadcasting Company) had taken it seriously, the Jet quarterback, who should return for the Nov. 11 or Nov. 18 game, said, I don't take the news seriously. ... Dave Herman, who injured his right shoulder in the last two games, is expected to start at guard Sunday. However, Mike Taylor is still suffering from a charley horse and will be replaced at outside linebacker by Rob Spicer. ... John Ebersole continues at middle linebacker in place of Al Atkinson, who is still out with a thigh pull.

title: Books of The Times
description: DIVIDED SOUL: The Life of Gogol. By Henri Troyat. Translated from the French by Nancy Amphoux. Illustrated. 489 pages. Doubleday. $12.95.

title: Film: Mysticism in U.S.:The Program
description: Lavish hostility has been leveled against the new mysticism by those who feel that the upsurge of religious cults has siphoned off the political energies of the young. However, the charge doesn't seem to be historically validsince many began dropping out of politics well before the latest wave of gurus arrived. Ranging from fatigue to fears of Federal reprisal, fears of further Kent and Jackson States, ravaging fights among those on the same side, and the loss of confidence about being able to remake American society, the reasons for that massive recoil could (and no doubt will) make a book the length of "The Sotweed Factor."Meanwhile, emotional malnutrition has been rampant in this country. Hence it seems rather inevitable that someincluding people who tried and eventually rejected drugs  turned to various forms of religion."Sunseed," which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, offers a sympathetic introduction to the New Age. The director, Fredrick Cohn, partakes of that movement himself. But he doesn't preach or clutch at converts. The documentary, which tours India as well as America, is based on interviews with 10 spiritual leaders and shows some of them meditating with their followers.From the Lama Anagarika Govinda in the Himalayan foothills to Ram Dass (formerly Dr. Richard Alpert) at a New Hampshire farm, or a Sufi meditation camp in Arizona, the stress is on both personal and world peace, receptivity to God (who isand isn'tdefined in a number of ways), a rejection of materialism, and the effort to dissolve the ego. There's also the suggestion that the new consciousness could free the enlightened from vulnerability. But we're also shown one young woman in tears because she feels guilty for not being able to embrace the faith.There are beguiling glimpses of the late Murshid Samuel L. Lewiswho was known as Sufi Sam to his disciples and also described himself as "a roaring borealis"separating egg yolks in his disarrayed kitchen and advising: "Be calm, cool, suave, diplomatic, and crazy." Even skeptics will note that his followers like almost everyone in this picture, do look amazingly happy.Varieties of Buddhism and Hinduism overlap and alternate throughout "Sunseed," along with Yoga, and it's a bit difficult for outsiders to untangle them. But even if the contrasts were clear, it would be impossible for the unconverted to judge the contents of this sensitive and skillfully made film. However, it does show some of the impact of mysticism on young people in America, especially their sense of "skipping over a threshold" into experiences that they've never known before. And it's easy to savor the stunning camera work of Baird Bryant and Robert Frank, along with the singing of the Sufi Choireven if you haven't blissed-out yourself.

title: Arab Oil Boycott Brings Jitters in Rotterdam Port
description: ROTTERDAM, The Netherland, Nov. 2  The Botlekbrug cafe, nestled between the mammoth Shell and Esso refineries on Petroleum Way in Rotterdam, was quiet on Tuesday night when the Government announced a ban on Sunday driving to save fuel following the Arab boycott on supplying oil to this country.

title: Business Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (UPI)Two companies that supply more than 90 per cent of the chromite sand used in the nation's production of steel and iron castings were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of violating antitrust laws. They were identified as Combustion Engineering, Inc., Stamford, Conn., and the American Colloid Company, Skokie, Ill. Also indicted was Charles H. Gehret, a Combustion official.

title: Futures in Wheat Decline Sharply
description: Leading a generally weak market lower, wheat and soybean futures dropped quite sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn and oats futures also declined.

title: Peking Politics: Old Cast, New Faces
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 2The Chinese have a traditional method of political polemics they call using the past to attack the present. Essentially the game is to assail or praisesome figure in ancient history in order to get at a living person who cannot be openly attacked.

title: ExPoliceman Is Found Guilty Of Assaulting Boy Scout Official
description: JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 2 A former New York City policeman was convicted in Superior Court here today of shooting and severely beating a 84yearold Boy Scout executive year ago after a minor traffic accident in the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: 4YEAR TERM GIVEN IN EXTORTION PLOT
description: John A. Masiello Sr., a reputed Mafia captain who on Oct. 23 was named as a coconspirator in the indictment of Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn in an alleged mailcontract plot, was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison for extortion.

title: Merrick and Penn Take First in Run
description: It's nice to keep it in the family. That was Dave Merrick's first thought after winning the individual championship yesterday in the 35th annual crosscountry race of the Heptagonal Game Association.

title: Experts Say the Theft of African Art Treasures Is Widespread
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 2  Discovery of a sacred CameroonIan statue in possession of a New York art dealer has brought to the surface discusSion of the longtime, widespread thievery of African art, contradictions in the private and public collecting of such art and the clash of Western and African concepts of both economics and art.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The police added extra patrols in Berkeley Township in the wake of a racial clash that led to the closing of the Central Regional High School on Thursday. Capt. John J. Sullivan said that the school had remained closed and that two extra patrols had been added as a precautionary measure. Patrolmen will be assigned to the school when it reopens Monday, he said.

title: VINCENT RUSCIANO
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 2  Vincent Rusciano, a highway constructor who built part of the New England Thruway, and the approach to the Tap, pan Zee Bridge in Tarrytown, among other projects, died Wednesday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 51 Echo Bay Drive.

title: Smith Advances in Paris Tennis
description: PARIS, Nov. 2 (AP)The defending champion, Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S.C., advanced today to the semifinals of the French indoor open tennis championships with a 36, 61, 61 victory over Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn.

title: Prestige Key to This Rally
description: A prestigious auto rally that attracts more cars than spectators along its woodsy Michigan route reached the halfway point yesterday, with only twothirds of its small starting field intact.

title: Brooklyn Museum Split in Dispute With Director
description: Eight staff members of the Brooklyn Museum have resigned during the last four months, citing widespread demoralization among museum employes and personality conflicts with the museum director, Duncan F. Cameron.

title: YEN IS DEPRESSED BY DOLLAR BUYING
description: TOKYO, Nov. 2  A massive demand for dollars, predicated on continuing weakness in the yen, dropped the value of the Japanese currency to 275 yen to the dollar today, the lowest since the yen was floated last February.

title: Coal Seen Aiding Europe Energy Needs
description: GENEVA, Nov. 2Western Europe can meet the energy crisis that could result this winter from the reduction of oil shipments by the Mideast without economic damage or severe curtailment of private car use, according to European energy experts.

title: Ballet: A MiniJoffrey
description: One of the happier aspects of the Joffrey Ballet's seasons at the City Center 55th Street Theater, is that the occasion is almost always taken to sneak in the Joffrey II Company for a performance before it sets out on its crosscountry tour.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1973

title: Rivalry Among Bar Groups Marks ChiefJudge Race
description: Nearly every day of the last two weeks, one or several bar associations have announced a stand on the race for chief judge of the New York State Court of Appeals. One day this week the past presidents of the New .York State Bar Association repeated their organization's previously announced view that the RepublicanLiberal candidate, Appeals Court Judge Charles D. Breitel, was the most qualified man for the highest state judicial post.

title: Problems Chase Rangers As. Rocky Trip Continues
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2Despondent was the word for the way the New York Rangers felt today as they left for Chicago, where they will play their next National Hockey League game Sunday night.

title: U.S. Accepts Poland for U.N. Truce Unit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2  The United States tonight accepted the inclusion of Poland, a member of the Communist Warsaw Pact, in the United Nations peace force for the Middle East.

title: MAYOR GETS WRIT TOW FIRE STRIKE
description: The city obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday forbidding its firemen to carry out their threat to strike on Monday.

title: Erotic Art Spans Time and Mores
description: Tenderness, moments of true love, do not figure prominently in the exhibition, Erotic Art, currently installed at the New School Art Center, 65 Fifth Avenue. But various forms of sadism, masochism, lust, rape and bestiality flourish in grand style. Paul Mocsanyi, the director, who selected this loan exhibition of paintings, drawings, prints and sculpture, has ranged widely over time, geography and sexual mores to put together a show that, if not precisely a how to manual on the sexual arts, is still a very lively survey of the art of sex.

title: Gerela Has Tonsilitis
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (UPI) Roy Gerela, puacekicker for the Pittsburgh Steelers, was admitted to Divine Providence Hospital today with acute tonsilitis. He was expected to return to practice Sunday to prepare for the game Monday night with the Washington Redskins.

title: Mayoral Issue
description: Blumenthal: We really do have a very important difference of opinion and a difference of attitude.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: BOROUGH HAUL There's a new Sunday blues and jazz series starting tomorrow at 3 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, (6364100), and getting there can be at least half the fun, if you want to set the day aside for it.

title: The Judicial Candidates
description: Until a better system comes along, once again New York's voters must perform the nearimpossible: judge the judgeships. We have long proposed the appointive method for judgesbut only with the prior screening advice of broadbased citizens' panels representing the bar and the community. With the exception of the statewide Court of Appeals race this year, city voters are forced to choose among unfamiliar candidates.

title: Greasy Neale Dies
description: Earle (Greasy) Neale, colorful coach of two championship Philadelphia Eagle teams and a member of football's Hall of Fame, died yesterday in Lake Worth, Fla. Neale, who also played baseball with the Cincinnati Reds, was 81 years old. Details, Page 32.

title: Four Share Shot Lead In Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 2 (AP)Ben Crenshaw, a rookie on the Professional Golfers Association tour had putting problems today and slipped to a oneoverpar 72 but still retained a share of the lead after the second round of the $125,000 San AntonioTexas open tournament.

title: Helms Memo on Watergate Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Richard Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence, wrote memorandum 11 days after the Watergate burglary that could he construed as showing that he tried to limit the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into the burglary.

title: Syrians in First Contact With U.S. on CeaseFire
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Syria today made her first significant diplomatic contact with the United States in a year as Secretary of State Kissinger widened his efforts to overcome Middle East ceasefire problems and open the way to fullscale peace negotiations.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Referee for N.B.A.Players TV Dispute

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Nixon's Daughter Says Press Sides With Critics
description: Mrs. David Eisenhower said yesterday, that her father, President Nixon, wanted to cooperate with the news media but that his statements were never given the exposure received by those of his critics, The Associated Press reporter.

title: Hogan Return After Election Called increasingly Uncertain
description: Manhattan's Mr. District Attorney, the ailing Frank S. Hogan, is assured of winning a ninth term this Tuesday, but there is growing uncertainty about when, if ever, he will return to office.

title: BarLev Says His Line Limited Egypt's Advance
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 2  The BarLev line, the Israeli system of fortifications along the Suez Canal that the Egyptians overran, did not fail, according to the general for whom it was named.

title: Art: What Van Gogh Loved and Hated
description: Gallery 35, the small one on the second floor where the Metropolitan Museum of Art installs its miniature didactic exhibitions, was already crowded by 11 Thursday morning although the new show had no publicity beyond routine announcements and had been open only one day. The magic name of Vicent van Gogh was, as usual, pulling them in.

title: South Shore Wins
description: South Shore, Washington and Columbus captured Public Schools Athletic League borough crosscountry titles yesterday on the 2.5mile course at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. South Shore took the Brooklyn division as Carlos Ward of Sheepshead Bay was the individual winner in 13 minutes 8.5 seconds. Washington and Columbus won the Manhattan and Bronx sections, respectively.

title: French Price Controls
description: The French Government announced last night price controls on a number of basic foods and consumer goods to hold down the rising cost of living. Page 35.

title: Vote Tuesday May Aid L.I. 3dCounty Plan
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 2In the beginning some called it Atlantis, for the illusory, fabled underwater city and they invoked images of the impossible dream and the quest for the Holy Grail. It had other names, tooSunset, Montauk, Shinnecock and Gardiner.

title: Colonel Victory Ruins Erving's Day and Nets' Night
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 2 Nassau County celebrated Julius Erving Day today, but the Kentucky Colonels refused to participate.

title: Air Canada Plans TakeOvers To Set Up Domestic Industry
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 2 Governmentowned Air Canada has drawn up a plan to buy two foreignowned aircraft manufacturing companies, which would be merged to create the heart of a revitalized Canadian aerospace industry.

title: CHARLES A. POST
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 2 Charles A. Post, chairman of the Citizens Savings Bank of the age of 87. He lived in Barrington.

title: Tennis Players' Unit Throws Out Nastase
description: PARIS, Nov. 2 (Reuters)Ilie Nastase said tonight he had been thrown out of the Association of Tennis Professionals.

title: Press in Russia, for First Time, Deals With Impeachment Issue
description: MOSCOW, Nov, 2  The Soviet Union gave evidence today of serious concern over the position of President Nixon by disclosing in its own press for the first time the Congres sional resolutions on his impeachment and removal from office.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: White House Says Nixon Doesn't Intend to Resign
description: MIAMI, Nov. 2The White House declared today that President Nixon was not giving any thought to resigning.

title: ALBERT RORABACK, CLERGYMAN, IS DEAD
description: CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 2 The Rev. Albert E. Roraback, who was vice president and a director of the Parkhurst Society for the Prevention of Crime at the time of the Seabury investigations in New York City in the nineteenthirties, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 93 years old.

title: The Roaring of a Mouse Is Heard in Auto Land
description: A General Motors executive who was interviewed by Emma Rothschild, a deceptively fraillooking twig of the European banking tree, described her to a male acquaintance as mousey. Well, sometimes mice roar. Miss Rothschild has done just that in a book entitled Paradise Lost, which Random House is publishing next week.

title: BYRNE ATTACKED BY ABORTION FOES
description: UNION, Nov. 2A newly formed ad hoc group opposing abortions disclosed plans today to distribute, in the final days of the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign, a million copies of a brochure denouncing Brendan T. Byrne and endorsing his Republican opponent, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.

title: Kansas Wheat Growers Spend a Lot, but They Worry a Little, Too
description: PRATT, Kan.  When an obviously wellfed customer in the crowded Uptown Cafe (Steaks) commented on the beautiful weather, the cashier held up both hands to show him her fingers were crossed.Another five or six days of this and we'll be out of it, she said, rolling her eyes heavenward.Like so many other people in Pratt County this this week, she was talking about the weather and what it might be doing to the price of the 1974 winter wheat crop.

title: Hofstra Defeats Delaware State
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 2 Hofstra University scored 21 points in the first nine minutes and held on to defeat a persistent Delaware State the 26 to 14, tonight, on the winner's field.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower has spoken out for the first time on rumors, of long years standing, that she has a drinking problem. She denied that such has ever been the case and said, I don't think there's anybody that drinks less than I.

title: Screen: By Danny Lyon:The Program
description: "The Films of Danny Lyon," the new program at the Film Forum, is a collection of three documentary films by the 31-year-old Brooklyn-born still photographer turned film-maker. The two best films in the collection, "Llanito" (61 minutes) and "Soc. Sci. 127" (21 minutes) are defined less by a developed cinematic style than by compassion for the subjects."Llanito" is a sorrowful montage of scenes of Indian life in the tiny New Mexico town of that name. It is not an especially finished film, but perhaps Mr. Lyon does not mean it to be.A couple of Indian men, half-kidding, dance around a beer can in a back alley. We listen to another man boast to the camera about his prowess as a hunter, while his mother mutters that the only thing he is good at is drinking.Juxtaposed against these scenes are others set in a home for the retarded, where, among other things, we listen to a white teen-age boy, who speaks in a high falsetto voice, telling us about freedom, sin, the crucifixion of Christ and the creation of the world ("God made everything out of nothing").Mr. Lyon's fondness for bizarre images is balanced by a kind of solemn respect for his subjects. This is particularly true in "Soc. Sci. 127," about an eccentric, hard-drinking tattoo artist named Bill Sanders, who, while he works, rambles on about Vietnam, lesbians and the art of what he advertises as "velvety tattoos."The third film on the program, "El Chivot" (The Goat) is a series of free associations on the life of goat and Indian. It runs six long, pretentious minutes.Mr. Lyon's skills as a photographer are evident throughout but I had the feeling in each of the films that he was still searching his images to find out what they might mean. This is not quite good enough.

title: Rader's Nadir
description: In an article appearing on the OpEd page, Oct. 22, Dotson Rader wrote of the murder of a friend and his assailant while the friend's wife looked on. Mr. Rader contended that it was the presence of his wife which triggered ... the impulse to act violently, selfdestructively in defense of her. Almost no one agreed with Mr. Rader's interpretation of the origins of male violence.

title: Merrick and Penn Take First in Run
description: It's nice to keep it in the family. That was Dave Merrick's first thought after winning the individual championship yesterday in the 35th annual crosscountry race of the Heptagonal Game Association.

title: Pirates' Alley Retires
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (AP) Gene Alley retired today after 10 years with the Pittsburgh Pirates. A series of operations on his left knee had hampered the 33yearold shortstop.

title: U. S. JOBLESS RATE 45% FOR OCTOBER, AT 3YEAR LOW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 4.5 per cent in October, the lowest level ib three and a half years, the Government reported today.

title: Man Knifed to Death in IRT After Fight With a Family
description: A 62yearold man was stabbed to death in front of scores of horrified morning rushhour passengers yesterday on the southbound platform of the Lexington Avenue IRT's Grand Central station.

title: Mothers With Crafts on Their Hands Find a Place to Sell Them
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y.It's no longer surprising that a pottery kiln is in the basement of an ordinary house, a loom is on a back porch, an easel in a bedroom or jewelrymaking tools in a kitchen. Women who want to stay at home with young children but also yearn to do something creative in art and handcrafts have been encouraged to do both. And more of them are embracing this double life every year.

title: Hospital League Bids U.S. Permit a Wage Rise Here
description: The League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York appealed to the Federal Cost of Living Council yesterday for permission to pay a 5.5 per cent wage increase as an interim step to stave off strike against 48 hospitals here Monday.

title: Princeton Robbery Foiled
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3 (AP)A Salem, Ore., man was arrested today after he allegedly staged a $5,000 robbery at Princeton Bank & Trust Company by threatening a teller with what he said was a bomb. The defendant, Curtis D. Reid, 23 years old, who described himself as a university student in Oregon, was captured by a customer as he fled the bank.

title: Stanfill Here With Rush Order
description: The last time the Jets encountered Bill Stanfill, he forced one quarterback and one offensive left tackle to the bench. The quarterback had a sprained left knee, the tackle an irreparably shattered reputation.

title: Coast Poll Finds Most Doubt Nixon On TV Coverage
description: Twothirds of a crosssection of California residents polled this week disagreed with President Nixon's assertion during his news conference Oct. 26 that recent television coverage of his Administration had includerl outrageous, vicious and distorted reporting.

title: Victory at Stake in Test Of Wills Along the Suez
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 2A virtually silent, undocumented contest of wills is under way between Israel and Egypt that will probably determine who won the war, a question of major political importance for both countries.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market fell sharply yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Korean Premier Apologizes in Japan for Abduction
description: TOKYO, Nov. 2  Premier Kim Jong Pil of South Korea walked into the office of Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan this afternoon, bowed his head and offered his Government's apologies for the abduction of a Korean Opposition leader here last August.

title: Ford and Albert Deal With Deep Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2You might pass them on the street without a second glance  one a tall and trim but now older football hero, the other a bantamsized wrestling champion who became a Rhodes scholar.

title: COMPANY ADMITS ASSISTING CAHILL
description: NEWARK, Nov. 2One of the nation's largest tradingstamp companies said in Federal court here today that it had been acting on instructions from Nelson G. Gross, the former Republican state chairman, when it caused its parent company to claim an illegal tax deduction for a $5,000 corporate contribution to Governor. Cahill's 1969 campaign.

title: AIDE SAYS NIXON KNEW ON SEPT. 29 OF LACK OF TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 President Nixon learned that two key Watergate conversations were not among his White House tape recordings more than a month before his lawyers said so in court, a Presidential aide testified today.

title: Cavaliers Crushed By Bucks
description: When the team with the best record in the National Basketball Association plays a team with one of the worst, guess what happens? Right. The Milwaukee Bucks cruised to their 10th triumph in 11 games last night with a 118100 victory over the downtrodden Cavaliers in Cleveland.

title: Drastic Emergency Steps To Save Energy Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Administration has outlined to Congress an emergency energy act that would give the President sweeping discretionary powers for an indefinite period to suspend all environmental standards, to tax fuels, prohibit pleasure driving, order early closing of schools and businesses, impose rationing and take other steps to curb energy consumption.

title: Press in Russia, for First Time, Deals With Impeachment Issue
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2  The Soviet Union gave evidence today of serious concern over the position of President Nixon by disclosing in its own press for the first time the Congressional resolutions on his impeachment and removal from office.

title: Drastic Emergency Steps To Save Energy Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Administration has outlined to Congress an emergency energy act that would give the President sweeping discretionary powers for an indefinite period to suspend all environmental standards, to tax fuels, prohibit pleasure driving, order early closing of schools and businesses, impose rationing and take other steps to curb energy consumption.

title: Testimony on SpecialProsecutor Bills Is Expected to Delay Hearings on Saxbe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Confirmation hearings on the Attorney Generaldesignate, Senator William B. Saxbe, are expected to be delayed next week while the Senate Judiciary Committee hears testimony on bills to set up an independent special prosecutor in the Watergate scandal.

title: South Shore Wins
description: South Shore, Washington and Columbus captured Public Schools Athletic League borough crosscountry titles yesterday on the 2.5mile course at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. South Shore took the Brooklyn division as Carlos Ward of Sheepshead Bay was the individual winner in 13 minutes 8.5 seconds. Washington and Columbus won the Manhattan and Bronx sections, respectively.

title: PRICE INCREASES FOR FUEL SPREAD
description: More oil companies announced increases yesterday that sent prices to record levels. I There were indications that even higher prices are likely in the near future.

title: U.S. AND 3 ALLIES TRY TO HEAL RIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The United States and three of its principal West European allies have exchanged conciliatory messages in the last week, all designed to patch up differences that had arisen over American policies and actions in the Middle East crisis.

title: Mariner 10 Begins voyage to Take CloseUp Photos of Mercury
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Saturday, Nov. 3Mariner 10, an unmanned, camerabearing spacecraft, was launched early today on a journey to conduct the first reconnaissance of the planet Mercury.

title: REPORTER DRAWS FIVEMONTH TERM
description: DADE CITY, Fla., Nov. 2Lucy Ware Morgan, a reporter for The St. Petersburg Times, was sentenced yesterday to five months in jail for contempt of court after she had refused to disclose her source of information in an article that she had written about a secret report by the Pasco County grand jury.

title: Green Building Is a White Elephant
description: Vincent Scully, the architectural historian, described it as protojukebox modern. Lewis Mumford called it one of the buildings that shaped the future of. New York. Architectural Forum said it was unique.

title: EXPOLICE OFFICER GUILTY IN ATTACK
