description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 2 A former New York City policeman was convicted in Superior Court here today of shooting and severely beating a 64yearold Boy Scout executive a year ago after a minor traffic accident in the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jerseys daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Knicks Defeat Lakers
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2  A 44point performance by Walt Frazier, his career high, enabled the New York Knicks to beat the Los Angeles Lakers tonight, 10691, even though Willis Reed sat out the last 33 minutes because of a strain behind his right knee.

title: FRENCH ANNOUNCE SOME PRICE CURBS
description: PARIS, Nov. 2The French Government announced tonight price controls over a number of basic foods and consumer goods such as cheese, meat and shoes to hold down the rocketing cost of living and check potential social unrest.

title: Democrats Face a New Split On Policing Convention Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Infighting within the Democratic party flared anew today over leadership of the commission that will police the rules on the make up of the party's 1976 national convention.

title: Cahill Forms Agency on Energy For Policy and Fuel Distribution
description: TRENTON, Nov. 2 (AP)Governor Cahill today announced the creation of a new state agency to coordinate energy policy with Federal and Vocal government units and to oversee distribution of fuel.

title: Bank of America Acquires Stock in Montreal Trust
description: The BankAmerica Corporation announced yesterday that the Bank of America (New York) had acquired 341,280 shares of the Montreal Trust Company, a Canadian financial concern active in mortgage lending.

title: Hogan Return After Election Called Increasingly Uncertain
description: Manhattan's Mr. District Attorney, the ailing Frank S. Hogan, is assured of winning a ninth term this Tuesday, but there is growing uncertainty about when, if ever, he will return to office.

title: People and Business
description: Arthur M. Wood, chairman and chief executive officer of Sears Roebuck & Co., Inc., has issued a polite rebuttal to David Packard, the chairman of the HewlettPackard Company, who urged corporations last month to no longger make unrestricted gifts to private education. Mr. Packard said that university boards of trustees could not be counted on to spend the money in ways the corporation could defend to its stockholders.

title: French Price Controls
description: The French Government announced last night price controls on a number of basic foods and consumer goods to hold down the rising cost of living. Page 35.

title: JAPAN TO AID BRAZIL WITH 2 STEEL MILLS
description: TOKYO, Nov. 2The visiting Brazilian Minister of Commerce and Industry announced here today ambitious programs to build two integrated steel mills and a gigantic petrochemical complex in Brazil with the aid of Japanese capital and knowhow.

title: G.M. Recalling 2,600 Cars For SeatBack Adjustment
description: DETROIT, Nov. 2 (Reuters)The General Motors Corporation today recalled some of its 1974 cars.

title: HOWARD GLIEDMAN OF CRIMINAL COURT
description: Judge Howard B. Gliedman of the New York City Criminal Court died Thursday at the Shore View Nursing Home, Brooklyn. He was 60 years old and lived at 1213 East 27th Sstreet, Brooklyn.

title: High School Notes
description: There was lots of excitement among students in the transportation shop at Francis Lewis High School in Queens when the fall term started as Pontiac had donated a 1973 car for them to tinker with. Then somebody stole or misplaced the necessary tools.

title: Hashish Suspect Seized
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)State policemen arrested Greek citizen last night and charged him with possession and sale of 500 pounds of hashish. Stamatics L. Psarodis, 44 years old, who has lived in the United States the last four years, was held on $50,000 bond.

title: U.S. AND 3 ALLIES TRY TO HEAL RIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The United States and three of its principal West European allies have exchanged conciliatory messages in the last week, all designed to patch up differences that had arisen over American policies and actions in the Middle East crisis.

title: JAWORSKI'S FIRM IN MILK LAWSUIT
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 3  The Houston law firm of Leon Jaworski, President Nixon's new special prosecutor, is handling a lawsuit against a milk cooperative that is a target of the Watergate investigation.

title: GREASY NEALE, 81, COACHED EAGLES
description: Earle (Greasy) Neale, a longtime college and professional football coach and a member of Football's Hall of Fame, died yesterday at a nursing home in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 81 years old. The cause of death was not announced.

title: Syrians in First Contact With U.S. on CeaseFire
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Syria today made her first significant diplomatic contact with the United States in a year as Secretary of State Kissinger widened his efforts to overcome Middle East ceasefire problems and open the way to fullscale negotiations.

title: Zellerbach and Lehman Buy a Lumber Company
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and Lehman Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday that a successful bid of $185million was made jointly by Crown Zellerbach and the Southern Timber Trust for the purchase of assets of the Tremont Lumber Company, including 200,000 acres of pine timberland in northwestern Louisiana. Southern Timber was formed by Brookwood Energy and Properties, Inc., a real estate and investment subsidiary of Lehman, to acquire mills and timberlands of Tremont.

title: L. & M. and Aide Enjoined by Court
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that a Federal judge had enjoined Liggett & Myers, Inc., and a company official from further alleged violations of the socalled Inside Information Law.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE 4.5% FOR OCTOBER, AT 3YEAR LOW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 4.5 per cent in October, the lowest level in three and a half years, the Government reported today.

title: JOHN D. ALLEN
description: NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 2John Dewey Allen, a founder of, the Allen Shipping Company of New York, died yesterday in Bridgewater, where he resided. He was 75 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonnell Douglas Raises Earnings
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, like most other companies in the aerospace industry, made more money this year. Judging by its ninemonth record net, the company's profit for all of 1973 will exceed every year in its history.

title: 8 BANKS REFUND AUTOLOAN FEES
description: Eight major metropolitan banks have agreed to repay automobileloan customers more than $100,000 in fees that the state said the banks used for other than the stated purpose.

title: Magnetism Used in GroundTravel System
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Two scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at Cambridge have proposed a revolutionary system of ground transportation that they call electromagnetic flight. Magnetic forces would suspend the the vehicles about a foot above a concave guideway and propel them at high speed. Richard D. Thorton, professor of electrical engineering, add Henry Kolm, senior scientist at the Francis Bitter National Magnet Laboratory, were granted patent 3,766,417 this week, assigning it to M.I.T.

title: ALEX ROSE DENIES HUGGING DE SAPIO
description: Alex Rose, the Liberal party leader, denied yesterday a published report that he embraced Carmine G. De Sapio, the former Democratic County leader of New York County, at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial dinner.

title: LEE TAUB
description: Lee Taub, executive vice president of the Kayser Roth Hosiery Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home 799 Park Avenue. His age was 46.

title: EDITIONS CANCELED AT WASHINGTON POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) The Washington Post canceled all five scheduled Saturday morning editions tonight after a work stoppage by a printers' union to protest the dismissal of one of its members.

title: E.T.C. ORDERS DATA TO BACK AD CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Federal Trade Commission today ordered 14 manufacturers of acne preparations and four manufacturers of deodorants to file reports substantiating various advertisements.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Today, Nov. 3

title: WAR MAY STEP UP U.S. ARMS BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  A senior Defense official said today that the defense budget would probably have to, be increased to help reequip the Israeli forces as well as to cori rect weaknesies in United States readiness that becanie evident as a result of the Middle East war.

title: U.S. to Fund Nearly 70,000 Apartments
description: Ending a long period of uncertainty for New York and other cities, the Nixon Administration announced yesterday that it would approve funding for nearly 70,000 additional apartments  about a quarter of them in New Yorkunder major subsidizedhousing approaches that the President is seeking to terminate.

title: Four Make Debuts At Mayflower Ball
description: Three hundred people attended the 20th annual dinner dance and ball of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York last night at the Plaza and four young women, who are daughters or granddaughters of members, made their debuts.

title: ELIZABETH SEEGER, TEACHER AND WRITER
description: BRIDGEWATER, Conn., Nov. 2Elizabeth Seeger, a teacher at the Dalton Schools in New York for 36 years as well as a writer and portrait painter, died yesterday at her home here. Her age was 83.

title: Networks Weigh Public Reaction to Nixon's Attack
description: The television networks apparently have no desire to make war with the Nixon Administration, even though highranking officials of all three regard the recent attacks on electronic journalism by the White House as unfounded and unjust.

title: Borough Presidencies
description: Among the forgotten candidates in this year's municipal elections in New York City are those seeking the office of Borough President in each of the five boroughs.

title: SANDMAN COURTS UNDECIDED VOTERS
description: UNION, Nov. 2The Republican gubernatorial campaign of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. came down to earth today as the candidate passed up his helicopter for oldfashioned motorcades and walking tours.

title: Antiques: Medici Bowl
description: A 16thcentury Florentine bowlsmall, misshapen and no bigger than a cereal dish was sold Thursday at Sotheby Parke Bernet for $180,000, setting two world auction records and bringing joy to the hearts of five nuns in the audience.

title: Knicks Defeat Lakers
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 A 44point performance by Walt Frazier, his career high, enabled the New York Knicks to beat the Los Angeles Lakers tonight, 10691, even though Willis Reed sat out the last 33 minutes because of a strain behind his right knee.

title: STOCKS PLUMMET; DOW FALLS 13.55
description: Political and economic worries that were reflected in investor confusion sent stock prices down sharply yesterday to cap a week of five straight declines.

title: Nixon Friend Is Called Extortion Target
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 2 (AP)A former auditor for C. Arnholt Smith was arrested today on a complaint charging him with, the attempted extortion of between $10million and $20million from Mr. Smith, a financier and a friend of President Nixon.

title: U.S. Tax Judge Retires
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) The United States Tax Court announced today the retirement of Judge Austin Hoyt after 11 years on the court. Judge Hoyt, a native of Beacon, N. Y., was appointed to the court in 1962 by President Kennedy. He has agreed to serve on recall for further duties with the court as needed.

title: GREAT LAKES PAPER PLANNING EXPANSION
description: The Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd., said in Toronto yesterday that it was planning a $118million expansion of its manufacturing facilities in Thunder Bay, Ontario.

title: Music: Beethoven Cycle
description: Beethoven remains a best seller, and every seat was taken Thursday night at the Hunter College Playhouse, where the Cleveland String Quartet started its Beethoven cycle (six concerts, spaced through next May). The Clevelanders follow standard practice in not playing the works chronologically. Instead an attempt is made at program contrast: a work from each of the socalled three periods. Thus the first program contained the F minor (Op. 95), B flat (Op. 18, No. 6) and A minor (Op. 132) String Quartets.

title: A Picasso Etching Found in Garbage; Tied to Theft Case
description: A Picasso etching that the police believe is stolen property was recovered yesterday in garbage can at an intersection in Queens Village, detectives there reported last night.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The first thing you've got to make up your mind about is that they're not going to feel like the softest cashmere. In fact, they may be downright irritating to tender skin. We're talking about those metallic knits that are all over the stores. Metallic threads have been knitted into everything from hats to scarves to sweaters to dresses, so a woman may either dabble lightly or submerge herself. One New York woman reports that she's been suffering at parties in her scratchy metallic dress for two years now but wears it because she likes the way it looks. Another woman says she's grown quite used to the feel and it doesn't bother her all.

title: Film: Exciting Nureyev 'Don Quixote':The Cast
description: Rudolf Nureyev has done so well with "Don Quixote," his film version of a flawed 19th-century ballet, that he has actually made it more fun than the stage production. The result is a dance film for all audiences, an exciting, intelligently conceived spectacle.It is a film that takes the dangerous risk of wedding cinematic realism with formal ballet conventions and triumphs as a genre of its own. The tone is so consistent that it is not jarring at all to see Sancho Panza hit on the head with a lobster in one scene and to watch a full corps de ballet in tutus in another.Above all, "Don Quixote," starring Mr. Nureyev, Sir Robert Helpmann and Lucette Aldous with the Australian Ballet, is the work of top professionals who have a firm understanding of their material. The film opened yesterday at the Festival Theater.In Geoffrey Unsworth, who photographed "Cabaret" and "2001: A Space Odyssey," there is a cameraman immune to the usual penchant for cutting off dancers' feet and focusing away from the choreographic climax. In the innovative use of an overhead diagonal view, Mr. Unsworth succeeds splendidly in showing the dancer's full body with no foreshortening.This is as much a dramatic film as a ballet film. Not merely a photographed version of Mr. Nureyev's 1970 stage production of "Don Quixote" for the Australian Ballet, it now has crucial nondancing links. In Sir Robert, whose career has spanned ballet dancing and stage and film acting as well as directing, there is a co-director who (one suspects) is largely responsible for the coherence of the dance and nondance passages.There is, finally, the other co-director, Mr. Nureyev. Probably no dancer onstage today has done more to bring the great 19th-century ballet classics alive and make them relevant to a modern audience. This "Don Quixote" is a tribute to his extraordinary understanding of the tradition behind those ballets.Buy understanding the tradition, Mr. Nureyev can afford to depart from it occasionally. "Don Quixote" was not one of the master-pieces of Marius Petipa, the great French-Russian choreographer who is best known for "The Sleeping Beauty." Created in 1869, revised by the Bolshoi choreographer Alexander Gorsky and others, the ballet is not even really about Don Quixote.Mr. Nureyev has made an honest if conveniently spectacular statement about this ballet, by beginning the film in Barry Kay's vast street panorama of color and movement that focuses on the real hero and heroine  Basilio, the barber, and his love, Kitriand not with the usual prologue of Don Quixote in his chamber.The Kitri-Basilio romance is the crux of the story, and one of Mr. Nureyev's several new dances is a sexy duet in which Basilio persuades Kitri to go to bed with him.When she danced the role of Kitri in New York in 1971, Miss Aldousformerly of the Royal Balletwas just a little too tough. Now she gives us a properly earthy village girl, dancing with flourish and just right amount of comic upmanship to meet Mr. Nureyev on his own ground.For this is a comic ballet full of sunlight, and Mr. Nureyev is its Sun King. Those who have never seen him onstage will find the full Nureyev myth here right down to the virtuosity of the smashing final grand pas de deux.Only an actor who was also a premier danseur could handle the part of Don Quixote himself as excellently as Sir Robert. Detached but dignified, he turns the conventional 19th-century dream sequence away from a divertissement into a moment of dramatic truth.There is an exceptional performance from Ray Powell as Sancho Panza, and the Australian Ballet does fine work in what is frankly a back-up position.

title: Secretariat, Maybe, Will Bow Out Again
description: Efforts are being made to arrange a match race between Secretariat and Prove Out, the New York Racing Association acknowledged last night.

title: PROPOSAL BY KINNEY FOR SALE CONFIRMED
description: Andrew J. Frankel, chairman of the board of the National Kinney Corporation, yesterday confirmed reports that Kinney was considering the sale of particular properties owned by the Uris Buildings Corporation, in which Kinney owns 54 per cent of the stock.

title: A Vietnam Hamlet's Forges Feed on Scraps of War
description: PHUONG DANH, South Vietnam  The dirt road is flanked by the clatter of hammers on steel. Throbbing charcoal fires glow and spit sparks. Men and their wives and their sons and daughters, faces glistening with sweat, pound chunks of redhot metal, beating, shaping, forging farm tools from the tools of war.

title: White House Says Nixon Doesn't Intend to Resign
description: MIAMI, Nov. 2The White House declared today that President Nixon was not giving any thought to resigning.

title: Victory at Stake in Test Of Wills Along the Suez
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 2A virtually silent, undocumented contest of wills is under way between Israel and Egypt that will probably determine who won the war, a question of major political importance for both countries.

title: Cairo Discloses Secret OneDay Mission by Sadat to Kuwait and Saudi Arabia
description: CAIRO, Nov. 2  Amid ten?? and Uncertainty here tout what is to happen next in the conflict with Israel, it was disclosed today that Presi?? Anwar elSadat had flown on a secret oneday mission for strategy talks with President Halez al  Assad of Syria, Egypt's battle ally, and the rulers of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, Egypt's financial supporters.

title: The Tapes, the judge and the Law
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  In announcing that there are no tape recordings of two of the disputed Watergate conversations, the White House lawyers in one sense at least, have hardly dmie anything novel.

title: Ford Plans New Sales Effort in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 2The President of the Ford Motor Company, Lee A. Iacocca, disclosed today that his company planned a new effort to export cars to Japan.

title: Convicted Murderer Of Trooper Escapes
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1 (AP)Daniel C. Kremens, a convicted killer of a policeman escaped today from Trenton State Prison.

title: Kheel Sees a 45c Transit Fare If Bond Issue Loses on Tuesday
description: Theodore W. Kheel, a major spokesman for Governor Rockefeller's $3.5billion transportation bond issue, said yesterday that the transit fare here would most probably go to 45 cents if voters rejected the bond proposal next Tuesday.

title: Bring Back Mr. Nice Guy
description: None of the ways being proposed for solving the country's President Nixon problem are going to work. Let us look at the defects in each and then consider a different kind of plan which can bring the nation more relief faster.

title: 5 UTILITIES DISCUSS G.E. TURBINE ORDERS
description: The Union Electric Company of St. Louis said yesterday that a fiveutility group of which it is part plans to enter into detailed negotiations with the General Electric Company for turbine generators for six identical nuclear power plants they have on order. Value of the turbine units is estimated at more than $250million.

title: Saigon Pays Diem Homage After Celebrating His Fall
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2  Thousands of South Vietnamese celebrated the memory of President Ngo Dinh Diem with reverence today, a day after national celebrations marking the anniversary of the military coup d'tat in 1963 in which he was assassinated.

title: Access to the Airwaves
description: By coincidence, President Nixon's charge that he has been the victim of distorted television reporting came on the very day that the Twentieth Century Fund published a report showing how television has given to the incumbent President virtually unlimited access to the American people at any time he chooses to command it. That access is not shared by Congress or the courts by opposition political parties.

title: OIL EXPORT TAX SPLITS CANADIANS
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 2Canadian oil producers reacted with anger today to the Federal Government's decision to more than quadruple its tax on crude oil exported to the United States.

title: Soviet Rifle Becomes BestSeller in Arab World
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct, 29As the Middle East crisis wears on, Arab citizens are paying premium prices for the Kalashnikov, the Soviet assault rifle that has become the most fashionable personal weapon in the Arab world.

title: Money Is Asked to Aid Handicapped Children
description: TRENTON, Nov. 2  If history is any guide, one of the two statewide quesions voters will be asked to approve next Tuesdaya proposed $25million bond issue to expand,btate facilities for severely handicapped children  has a good chance of becoming law.

title: SHULTZ SAYS NIXON GAVE MILK ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said today that the Nixon Administration had reversed its own experts, in 1971, and ordered a large increase in the support price for milk because the Administration was afraid Congress would legislate an even bigger increase.

title: AIDE SAYS NIXON KNEW ON SEPT. 29 OF LACK OF TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2President Nixon learned that two key Watergate conversations were not among his White House tape recordings more than a month before his lawyers said so in court, a Presidential aide testified today.

description: The city obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday forbidding its firemen to carry out their threat to strike on Monday.

description: Dr. Ladislao Reti, an authority on Leonardo da Vinci, die near Milan, Italy, on Oct. 25, according to word reaching here yesterday.

description: BASHIGA, Inner MongoliaRising in a steep tumulus above this village and the endless Mongolian plain that stretches from mountain range to mountain range is the tomb of Shao Jan, reputedly one of the four greatest beauties in Chinese history and queen of the warlike Huns.

title: DR. ROBERT DRIPPS, EXECUTIVE AT PENN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2Dr. Robert D. Dripps, vice president for health affairs at the. University of Pennsylvania and former chairman of anesthesiology at its school of medicine, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Tuesday evening. He was 62 years old and lived in Haverford.

He was ridden by Frank Chapot, the team captain.

title: KELLOCK MYERS
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 2  Kellock Myers, a retired stockbroker who for many years conducted his own business in Wall Street, died Wednesday at his home, 77 Park Avenue. He was 92 years old.

title: The Glories of Matisse Are Displayed
description: The exhibition dominating the art calendar this week is, without question, the Henri Matisse show at the Acquavella Galleries, 18 East 79th Street. Even for those who saw the mammoth Matisse exhibition organized by Pierre Schneider in Paris in the summer of 1970, there are Unexpected revelations to be gleaned in the Acquavella show, which brings together 57 works from American Collections. It opened yesterday, and remains on view through. Dec. 1.

title: Bridge: A Spate of Flannery Hands Arises in the Team Playoffs
description: A curious feature of the international team playoff in Milwaukee this week was the spate of Flannery hands. This convention, originating in Pittsburgh, makes use of a twodiamond opening to show foto spades and five hearts, an awkward hand in standard methods.

description: PARIS, Nov. 2 (AP)The defending champion, Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S.C., advanced today to the semifinals of the French indoor open tennis championships with a 36, 61, 61 victory over Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn.

description: HACKENSACK, Nov. 2The first men's tennis tournament of the indoor season is the New Jersey State championship starting Nov. 9 at the Eastern Clay Indoor Club here. And the people running it have done a wise thing: they've left open several spots in the draw for junior players, giving them a chance to invade the men's ranks.

The contract would give Killebrew 20 years in the major leagues, a qualification needed for the top baseball pension. Killebrew, the club's top career homerun hitter, was offered $60,000 a season for three years. He was paid $105,000 in 1973.

KLEINDIENST, former Attorney General, told the Watergate prosecution staff that President Nixon had personally ordered him not to press antitrust actions against International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. ... S.E.C. filed suit against Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., the accounting firm that certified allegedly false statements of Talley Industries, Inc.... Botany Industries, a men's wear producer, went bankrupt.

description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 3Miss Bonnie Robin Sicular, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon H. Sicular of Sands Point, and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married tonight to Mark David Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert T. Levy of Searington.

title: Miss Swoyer, David Rahilly Plan Marriage
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Nov. 3  Miss Elizabeth Swoyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Swoyer Jr., plans to be married here Nov. 24 to David S. Rahilly of New York, son of Mrs. Bernard J. Rahilly of Westfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Rahilly. The parents of the future bride have announced the engagement.

title: The Winged Colt of Casa Mia
description: There is something uncanny about the way Betsy Byars transcends the book in your hand and gives you living feeling people instead. In her Newbery  Award  winning Summer of the Swans the identification between reader and young heroine casts so powerful a spell as to seem a kind of magic realism. In her fine new book The Winged Colt of Casa Mia the word magic occurs to the reader in another way:

title: Boys' Life Looks to a Healthy Future
description: NORTH BRUNSWICKNorman Rockwell began his career on the magazine, working full time for $75 a month. Salvador Dali and Fletcher Martin are among other nationally known artists who have illustrated its articles and stories.

title: The atheist who hears God's voice
description: East European Jews have produced many stories, narratives, legends, but until our day, very little fiction. In Jerusalem last summer, at a symposium on the sources of Jewish creativity to which Isaac Bashevis Singer was probably not invited (he embodies so many sources of Jewish creativity all by himself), the orthodox Chaim Potok admitted that It is not possible for an orthodox Jew who was committed to esthetics to be honest to both traditions.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Picture Books
description: Sampson is a cat. Netta is a hen. Briggs is a pig in pinstripes. A great many books for young children are not about young children. One reason may be that reading about a near mirror image of oneself leaves little room for imagining, and that could explain why Alice went through the looking glass instead of just standing in front of it. The assorted heroes and heroines in the following picture books range from a bear in overalls to a blueeyed fly with a crew cut.

title: Home Construction Plummets in State
description: TRENTON  Residential construction in New Jersey is in sharp decline, and the experts are predicting that, by year's end, housing starts will fall 25 per cent or more below the 1972 figures. The downturn is expected to continue well into 1974.

title: Canadians Score, 62, over Seals
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (UPI) Guy Lafleur, Murray Wilson and Henri Richard scored, in the second period and Guy Lapointe assisted on all three goals tonight as the Montreat Canadians skated to a 62 victory over the California Golden Seals.

title: Taut Economy
description: The sharp drop in unemployment last month from 4.8 per cent to 4.5 per cent was a welcome surprise. The improvement was broadbased, as jobless rates came down both occupationally and demographically. The rise in employment provides even surer evidence the economy's continuing strength.

I A hurdle of water, and O these waters are cold (warm at outset) in the dirty end. Murder on murder on murder, where I stagger, whiten the good land where we have held out. These kills were not for loot, however Byzantium hovers in the mind: were matters of principlethat's worst of all& fear & crazed mercy. Ruby, with his mad claim he shot to spare the Lady's testifying, probably is sincere. No doubt, in his still cell, his mind sits pure.

title: Copenhagen Burglars Are No DingaLings

description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  Argentina will sell! up to a million tons of cereal grains yearly to China under, terms of a new commercial! agreement to be signed shortly, the Foreign Ministry an pounced today.

It was a strange place for an Irish wake. But that's really what was going on there in the rearmost compartment of Air Force One as it roared through a dark southland sky toward Washington. Still febrile Secret Service agents stalked the length of the plane's narrow passageway. Up front, Lyndon B. Johnson, Clifton Carter and Bill D. Moyers were sitting as an ad hoc committee on the transition of Government, already plotting agendas for meetings with Congressional leaders. But in the back, Lawrence F. O'Brien, Kenneth P. O'Donnell, David F. Powers and Mrs. John F. Kennedy sat with the heavy metal casket that contained the body of the 35th President of the United States. The first series of shocks had passed, and now, with the widow listening, the others swapped stories about the dead man, all of them trying to fix in their minds the still incredible fact of his death. They had not yet begun to imagine what their personal futures might be like.

title: The President
description: WASHINGTONNo one, not even the most chronic Nixon hater, could have done more than the President and his men had done to shatter the credibility of the Nixon Presidency. The shock from the President's firing of special Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox on.Oct. 20, and its bizarre aftermath of resignations, had barely subsided; then, the President's lawyers disclosed another figuratively and, to many, literally incredible, development and set off a new wave of suspicion, anger and anguish.

title: HOUSE FIGHT NEAR ON LAND USE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3An intense fight in the House of Representatives is shaping up over the land use planning bill now being molded in the Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.

title: Parents Carry Football Off the Field
description: The place was Thomas Jefferson High School's Big Orange Stadium in the Flatlands area of Brooklyn; the event, a football game, between Jefferson and South Shore High School that would decide the title in the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn Division II.

title: People and Business
description: A new early warning fire and smoke detector for residential use has been developed by Pyrotronics, a concern in Cedar Knolls, in Morris County.

title: Turf
description: Morton Place is a thin wisp of asphalt, a oneblock side streetnear the intersection of West Tremont and University Avenues in the West Bronx. Gypsy cabs, unmuffled old Plymouths and gaudy whitewalled Caddies fly by it every day, but Morton Place is empty of cars. The air is filled instead with human noise: roller skates scratch the pavement, women shout from window to window, a tinny transistor radio screeches a funky Latin number. Heavy, red brick buildings line one side of the street and half the other; two wood buildings on the northwest end of the street are crumblingone, half burnedout, the other, flanked by a gigantic garbage heap whose foundation is the rotting carcass of an old Chevy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1973

title: Ocean Democrats See Upset
description: TOMS RIVERIt has been 65 years since Ocean County voters have sent a Democrat to the State Legislature.

title: Ozzard Battling Kean on P.U.C. Proposal
description: TRENTON  Governor Cahill's legislative recommendation for a fulltime State Board of Public Utility Commissioners has created a bitter controversy involving William E. Ozzard, the board's president, and Thomas H. Kean, the Assembly Speaker. Both are Republicans.

title: Harvard Conquers Penn With a Late Pass, 3430
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3In a tense contest that required more than three hours to complete, Harvard moved back into contention in the Ivy League football race by beating Pennsylvania, 3430, at Franklin Field today.

title: Musicians Reject Final Bid, Including a $50 Raise
description: Musicians of the New York Philharmonic, on strike since Sept. 26, have rejected a final offer from the management, it was announced yesterday.

description: KINGSTON, R. I., Nov. 3 (AP)Steve Crone threw for two touchdowns and scored once as Rhode Island defeated New Hampshire, 4016, today.

description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 3Miss Alice Owen Chasan and Matthew L. Edelman plan to be married in January.

title: 3 IN CREW KILLED AS PLANE CRASHES
description: BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  A Pan American World Airways 707 cargo plane with smoke reported in the cockpit and fire in one of its holds crashed today while attempting an emergency landing at Logan International Airport. The three crew members were killed.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Knicks return to Madison Square Garden Thursday to play the Boston Celtics, 7:30 P.M., and then face the Cleveland Cavaliers on Saturday, 8:00 P.M. Last year the Knicks and Boston played for the Eastern Conference championship after splitting eight games during the regular season. New York won the 7game playoffs, 43. The Knicks have played the Celtics once this season in Boston and lost, 11310. Against the Cavaliers, in their last meeting in Cleveland, the Knicks won, 9290.

title: SCHOLARS' GROUP ELECTS A BLACK
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 3  Dr. Absolom Vilakazi, a South African anthropologist at American University in Washington, took office today as president of the African Studies Association the first black man to preside over the predominantly white organization.

title: Camera World: New SLR Has Electronic Shutter
description: A NEW fully automatic 35mm singlelensreflex camera with electronically controlled shutter has recently been introduced by Yashica, Inc. in the United States. Called the Yashica Electro AX, the camera has actually been available for some time in Japan and Europe, but it is only now reaching the American market.

title: Grand National
description: For real horselovers, as opposed to mere bettors, there is no more thrilling name than that of England's Grand National steeplechase, an event in which each fence has its name and associated legends; the course is so grueling that the majority of starters never finish, and handicapping is virtually impossible. John R. Tunis has written a story (based loosely on true events) concerning the disasterhaunted attempt of an American horse to capture the crown of British chasing.

title: Lynn Stein Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Stein of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Stein, to Anthony Igel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Igel of New York and Highland Mills, N. Y.

title: Family Dispute Attracts Gang
description: A family dispute in the South Bronx early yesterday morning spilled out into the street and ended with one man shot to death, another wounded, one 16yearold gang member shot by a police officer, and three gang members under arrest for murder.

title: TV May Be Giving Sex a Bad Name
description: TELEVISION programs managed to steer clear of the bedroom for a remarkably long time, considering the sexual atmosphere that was thickening around the rest of American popular culture during the sixties. The clean apron that Mom Anderson wore on Father Knows Best covered up sexuality on TV until January of 1971, when the Bud YorkinNorman Lear All in the Family made its debut and opened a Pandora's box of taboo topics. CBS reportedly formed early contingency plans to cancel the show if the viewing public reacted too negatively to Archie Bunker's bigotry. But when the controversy  and there was a lot of itdied down, the network found itself with a monstrous hit on its hands, and Lear and Yorkin steadily broadened their exploration of subjects never treated on television before.

title: Alan Dybvig Weds Mary McGavern
description: In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Miss Mary Katherine McGavern, daughter of Mrs. Charles Leighton McGavern Jr. of Syracuse and the late Mr. McGavern, became the bride of Alan James Dybvig. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Dybvig of Lake Angelus, Mich., and Stuart, Fla. The Rev. Michael Gallagher performed the ceremony.

title: Rachmaninoff: An Incandescent Romantic
description: IT would be impossible to overstate the value of RCA's fabulous edition of The Complete Rachmaninoff. Here, in five boxed sets of three disks each, are assembled every known recording (piano rolls excepted) made by Sergei Rachmaninoff between 1919 and 1942 as piano soloist, chamber music player and conductor. It is by far the most important classical release from RCA in many years, and the performances contained herein provide many hours of fascinating listening, not a few jolts and much sheer pleasure in hearing one of the century's greatest pianists at work.

title: The Court Of the Stone Children
description: Eleanor Cameron is one of the most distinguished names in children's literature; therefore, one approaches her work with an admitted prejudice. The Court of the Stone Children, however, is not just a fine book but a brilliant oneand, in an age when writers are engulfing children with an almost gratuitous realism, it is exciting to read a story that glances back into the literaty shadows of memory, fantasy and dream. In her unabashed romanticism, Mrs. Cameron now seems as daring as those who once brought a whole Pandora's box of social problems into books for the young. Trends in literature are hard to follow. Happily, Mrs. Cameron is not following any of them.

title: Miss Feldman Wed To Richard Rotman
description: Miss Susan Lee Feldman and Richard Everett Rotman were married here this afternoon by Rabbi Charles Sheer, a Columbia University chaplain, in his study at the university.

title: U.S. PANEL URGES JOB FREEZE HERE
description: A Federal advisory committee has advocated a temporary ??uspension of all Civil Service ??ppointments for policemen, ??iremen, welfare workers, nar??oticscontrol officers and cor??ection officers here and in the tate and local governments.

title: Teaching About Watergate
description: Some of the children in the fifthgrade class that Joanne Cortellino teaches in Amherst, N. H., have been coming up to her in recent days and saying that they think that President Nixon may not be telling the truth about Watergate. Then, they ask her what she thinks. How do I answer them without having the wrath of the community come down on my head? wonders Miss Cortellino.

title: Miss Elizabeth Anne Dugdale Is Fiancee of Mark R. Murray
Arrest of 113 in Barcelona Shakes Franco's Opponents
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 3 Organized opposition to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Government has been dealt a heavy blow with the arrest of 113 of its leaders.

title: What Is an Impeachable Offense?
description: Two of the major public problems raised during the continuing exposure of scandal in Government concern the possible impeachment of President Nixon and the possible indictment and prosecution of other, former high Government officials. And beneath those problems, yet to be resolved, are two difficult Constitutional questions:

title: Milton Tops Groton
description: GROTON, Mass., Nov. 3John Griffin, a senior halfback, scored three touchdowns as Milton Academy chalked up its fifth victory in six games today by topping Groton, 3621. Besides plunging over from the 1yard line, Griffin also took passes of 18 and 30 yards from Fred Klann, the senior quarterback.

title: Lafayette Is Upset By Lincoln, 14 to 6
description: Lafayette, heading into the semifinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League championship next Sunday as the Brooklyn Division I representative, was upset yesterday by Lincoln, 146, on the loser's field. It was the first loss in six games for the Frenchies, whose semifinal opponent will be South Shore.

title: What's Opened at the Movies?
description: MEAN STREETS, directed by Martin Scorsese from a screenplay by Mardik Martin and Scorsese and starring Robert De Niro and Harvey Keitel, got 12 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Archer Winsten, Post; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Andrew Sarris, Village Voice; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Pauline Kael, New Yorker; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World), 6 mixed (Kathleen Carroll, News; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Robert Hatch, The Nation; Richard Schickel, Time) and 2 negative (Rex Reed, News; Judith Crist, New York). At the Cinema I.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3  Valery Panov, the ballet dancer whose application to go to Israel has been blocked for more than 19 months, said yesterday that he had begun a hunger strike to protest the Soviet Government's refusal to let him and his wife emigrate.

title: Great Swedish Fairy Tales
description: For all those who take delight in the only universally convertible currency that never depreciates, the one drawn on the various national treasuries of fairy tales, this collection helps fill a conspicuous gap. At least for readers in English, Sweden's contribution to the world bank of what we call children's stories has seemed comparatively remiss (Tolkien rightly reminds us alleged grownups that children's stories are far too crucial to our own psychic health to be consigned to the nursery). Elsewhere, the Scandinavian genius for lyricism and fantasy has raised gossamer monuments to instant recognition: in Denmark, the inimitable tales of Hans Christian Andersen, and in Norway, the enchanted, eastofthesun, westofthemoon realms of Asbjomsen and Moe. And yet, from childhood memories of readingsaloud by my mother, whose family came from Dalama, that part of Sweden where the grace in old things is especially cherished, I can only conclude that the rich heritage of the Swedish fairy tale has been unduly neglected.

title: YALE IS PLANNING A SUMMER TERM
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3Yale University is gearing up for voluntary summer term in 1975its first since World War IIwithout any idea of how many students will want to attend but with high hopes that it will prove profitable.

title: 10 AMENDMENTS ON STATE BALLOTS
description: When the New York voter closes the curtain on the polling booth Tuesday he will face a lengthy stretch of legalese at the top of the ballot involving 10 proposed amendments to the State Constitution that will affect the state's courts, forests and rivers and maybe even the political future of Long Island.

title: Best Seller List
description: GENERAL

title: Pike Builds Big Service Area
description: RIDGEFIELD  The first portion of what is described as the largest and most elaborate service area for New Jersey Turnpike motorists will be opened here just befor Christmas. Eventually, it will have a 300room, fourstory hotel, the only such structure directly on the 142milelong toll road.

title: Why Bring a Show to Broadway at All?
description: BROADWAY! The very name once flashed like some magical marquee in the mind of every producer, playwright, actor and director. It was the place where you were finally recognized for what you were worth, and with that recognition came the rewards of fortune and distinction. But times have changed, and Broadway's luster has dimmed as its costly risks have multiplied. Lately, even wellreceived shows have been known to sicken and die.

title: Hugh Mehorter, 74, Dies; Led N.J. Racing Commission
description: WOODBURY, N.J., Nov. 3 ((UPI)  Hugh L Mehorter, chairman of the New Jersey State Racing Commission, died this morning. He was 74 years old.

title: BEAUX ARTS EXCELS IN 2 DVORAK TRIOS
description: The Beaux Arts Trio has been making something of a specialty of the Dvorak, piano trios, The three musicians recorded the set of four not long ago, and on Friday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium they performed the Trio No. 2 in G minor and No. 3 in F minor, prefaced by Haydn's Trio in A.

title: Miss Adelberg Engaged
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 3 The engagement of Miss Kathryn Adelberg of Philadelphia to William Martin Greenhouse Jr. of Elkins Park, Pa., and Harvey Cedars, N.J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Greenhouse, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Adelberg of Boca Raton.

title: Bronx Store Owner Killed in a Holdup; Suspect Is Seized
description: The owner of a dry cleaning business near the Bronx Zoo was shot and killed early yesterday morning in an apparent holdup attempt.

title: Riverdale Rally Tops Hackley, 198
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 3  Undefeated Riverdale had to rally today to beat Hackley, 198, for its seventh victory today. Damon Powell, the Riverdale fullback, gained 176 yards and scored a touchdown, his 10th of the season. Paul Meltzer, a Riverdale halfback, scored two touchdowns.

title: Shrinking Enrollments and Rising Costs Plague Parochial Schools
description: A new school year is under way for the 148,000 students at Roman Catholic parochial schools in Brooklyn and Queens, and with the painful delay of the fourweek lay teachers' strike at eight diocesan high schools behind them, the planners and administrators who oversee Catholic education in the two boroughs have started the familiar annual task of looking to the year ahead.

title: AUSTRALIA ISSUE: HOMOSEXUALIT
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov.  A few days ago a cabin minister declared in the Au tralian Parliament that beatir up homosexuals was virtuall a recognized civilian tea sport here.

title: Time for Hollywood to Stop Playing It Safe
description: LOS ANGELES AMERICAN movies have always been terrified of social and political ideas. Hollywood celebrates action and leaves the messages for Western Union. But ideas can be dramatically exciting; literate films don't have to be preachy. Our movies desperately need conversations and confrontations that reflect the concerns of intelligent adults; and that means some recognition of the social and political issues that are as much part of life as gunfights, car chases and karate chops.

title: Utah Upsets Ariz. State By 3631
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 3 (AP)Utah capitalized on seven firsthalf turnovers to build a runaway lead, thenfought off an Arizona State rally in the fourth quarter to beat the eighthranked, Sun Devils, 3631, today in a Western Athletic Conference football game.

title: LETTERS
description: Merchants Go Electronic (Oct. 28) is the typical uncritical paean that one comes to associate with all EDPphiles. Obviously, it never occurs to Mr. Peacock that some price must be paid for all these miracles.

title: The Met's Troyens'? Not Perfect, But Getting There
description: THERE have been some disparaging remarks around town about the new production of the Berlioz Les Troyens at the Metropolitan Opera. Like Trader Vic's! snorted one customer, referring to the sets. And it is true that the sets are ornate: in the style of an Aida, to say the least. But, after all, Les Troyens is supergrandopera, and it needs a setting in the fairly colossal range.

title: RELIEF CASE LOAD IS LEVELING OFF
description: A Congressional study suggested yesterday that 91 per cent of all eligible poor families headed by women had gone on the welfare rolls so that case loads have begun to level off and should continue to do so.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Hamid
description: MARGATE, N.J., Nov. 3Mr. and Mrs. George A. Hamid Jr. of Margate and Princeton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Patricia Hamid, to William Bailey Roberts. He is a son of Mrs. Raymond B. Roberts of Waban, Mass. and the late Mr. Roberts.

title: Chess Rook Against Minor Piece Poses Problem Sophisticated
description: End games involving a rook against a minor piece are difficult for the lessexperienced player to master, since they require more sophisticated techniques than those of pawnahead endings, ings.

title: Laboring Classes and Dangerous Classes
description: Most of the themes of our contemporary obsession with urban crisis weave through this book: overpopulation; human and physical congestion; disintegration of the family; social inequalities in the ledger of disease and death; stagnant and desperate poverty; violent, murderous crime; hovering threats of riot and insurrection; a literature of sensation fixed upon these problems, magnifying them and according them a strange grandeur. The cumulative image is that of an acute urban pathology.

title: ITALY GIVING IN TO TAX LAGGARDS
description: ROME, Nov. 3The Government has offered a deal to Italy's recalcitrant taxpayers to buy forgiveness by settling a fraction of their debts.

title: Saigon's Ladies of Night Find Their Day Fading
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 (AP)The micromini and the braless look are disappearing from the streets of Saigon.

title: GOVERNOR'S RACE WEIGHED BY BUSH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3George Bush, chairman of the Republican National Committee, is taking a private poll of Texas to guide his imminent decision on running for Governor there next year.

title: East Jersey Group Recreating Village
description: HILLSBOROUGH TOWNSHIPWe are interested in preserving a visual conception of our past so that young people can conjure up a picture of the way it was in Colonial times, said Dr. Joseph Kler as he picked his way among the rubble of a house dating back to 1750. That is really how the East Jersey Olde Towne project started.

title: Arturo de Cordova, 66, Actor In More Than 100 Films, Dies
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3 (AP)Arturo de Cordova, a Mexican actor who played Augustin in For Whom the Bell Tolls and had roles in more than 100 other American and foreign films, died today. He was 66 years old.

title: 70 Cars Entered In Rally Saturday
description: SOMERVILLEAbout 70 cars, some equipped with sophisticated calculators and computers, are expected to arrive at the Somerset Shopping Center at 7:30 P.M. next Saturday.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The Congress is 535 people, mostly men, mostly white, mostly lawyers and mostly out when you need them.

title: CITYSTATE PACT SET ON COMPUTER
description: After months of strained relations, city and state socialservice officials have signed truce calling for joint development of computer systems for statewide welfare and Medicaid programs.

title: Ann Whitehead Engaged to Ensign
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 3 The engagement of Miss Ann Rhodes Whitehead to Ens. Jared Taylor Kieling, U.S.N., son of Capt. Robert Taylor Kieling, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Kieling of Sacramento, Calif., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Van Cleve Whitehead Jr. of Princeton and Squam Lake, Holderness, N. H.

title: A CAR FOE PLANS STREETLESS CITY
description: The only way to keep autos out of the city is to build a city without streets, Dr. Paolo Soleri, who is working on the prototype of such a city in the Arizona desert, said at a symposium here last week on the revitalization of cities.

title: The Meaning
description: Autumn isn't a particularly good time for humility, but when the countryman has brought in his harvest he cannot fail to understand that nature, the earth, the seasons, the basic stuff of life and growth, had a hand in it. He didn't do it all himself. He cooperated, and he helped achieve a harvest. That's the sum of it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Successful Beachcomber Is. One With Imagination
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass., Oct. 30Scoured by 35 years of wind, sand and waves, the smashed rib cage of a fishing vessel protruded from the sand.

title: Seab Books for Young People Fall 1973
description: THE LITTLE RED HEN Retold and illustrated by Paul Galdone

title: Unfaithful Heart Wins $175 for $2 Show Bet
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 (AP) Robert John finished, third and paid $175.20 for a $2 show ticket at Thistledown Race Track yesterday.

title: HARRY GRUMPELT, 88, EXLIBRARY BURSAR
description: YONKERS, Nov. 3Harry J. Grumpelt, who retired in 1950 as bursar of the New York Public Library after 45 years in its service, died today. He was 88 years old and lived here.

title: Ecumenism Thrives in Leonia
description: LEONIA  Church unity on the grassroots level is a reality here, with Presbyterians, Episcopalians and Methodists operating for the third consecutive year what they have proudly labeled the Leonia Ecumenical Sunday School.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS FORM FIRST LOBBY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3For the first time, the nation's private and parochial schools, many of them financially hard. pressed to survive, have an organization to represent them before Congress.

title: West Berlin Destination For Some Soviet Jews
description: BERLIN, Nov. 3The two Soviet Jews from Vilna, ithuania, came to West Berin a few days ago on the di rect railway route, via the Moscow  Warsaw  Berlin  Paris express. The man and his wife had been permitted to leave the Soviet Union on the German quota.

title: Soviet Jails 3 in Visa Protest
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3 (UPI)Three Jews were arrested at the passport office in Leningrad today for staging a brief demonstration to protest their I failure to obtain visas for Israel, and were sentenced to 15 days in jail, informed sources here said.

title: With Raisin, He Rises to the Top
description: THE theater has its Agnes deMille, its Jerome Robbins, its Bob Fosse, its Michael Kidd, its Gower Championdancers and choreographers who become directors to give new excitement and originality to the Broadway musical. In Donald McKayle, we behold the latest man to follow this unusual courseand the first black.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: What's selling? At a time when retail sales are sliding a bit and merchants' optimism over the forthcoming holiday season is weakening, a search for bright spots does not have to be fruitless.

title: Music: Grilles Concert
description: Before Charles Griffes died in 1920 at the age of 35, he was thought to be one of the great hopes of American music. He had composed fluent works reflecting influences of Germanic training and Debussy's style, and was thought to be finding an idiom of his own. Unfortunately, he had not produced enough music of individuality to assure him a prominent place in American music, and his works are rarely performed nowadays.

title: The Juniper Tree
description: Folks choose the folk tales they needor deserve. This has been noted by transactional analysts like Eric Berne (the author of Games People Play), who says that your favorite fairy story is as much a giveaway of character and life history as your most recurrent dream. The boy who once admired Jack the Giant Killer has grown up to work for Ralph Nader; the girl who loved the tale of The Frog Prince is married now to an ugly but very successful man, while the one who preferred Little Red Riding Hood still keeps getting deceived and seduced, often with rather nasty consequences for her seducer.

title: Joan V. Stevenson Is Betrothed
description: SALT POINT, N. Y., Nov. 3 Mrs. Edward Vicars Stevenson Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Vicars Stevenson, to Daniel Warfield Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron S. Lewis of Southport, Conn.

title: Geraldine Treacy Wed To Peter B. Young
description: SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 3Miss Geraldine Ireland Treacy and Peter B. Young were married here this afternoon at the nome or Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rauscher. Officating at the interfaith ceremony were the Rev. Will Campbell, executive director of the Committee of Southern Churchmen; the Rev. John McGovern of St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church here and the Shekh Hamiel Wadud, leader of the Sunni Muslim community in Newark.

title: CALIFORNIA FACES KEY VOTE TUESDAY
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 3A 5,000word constitutional amendment that would drastically alter the way state and local governments in California raise and spend money will be submitted to the state's voters Tuesday.

title: The President and the People
description: To the Editor:What are the high crimes and misdemeanors that President Nixon is charged with as the justifications for impeachment?

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: MILAN, ItalyThe region of Parma, an hour's drive east of Milan, is renowned for its food, including its delicate hams. It is also considered pretty much the fiefdom of Attilio Monti, one of Italy's most powerful oilmen.

title: The scandal that rocked Spain
description: I write of the great scandal that took place in 1967, coinciding with the Six Day War between Israel and the Arab states. The scandal rocked Madrid. It helped shatter the Spain of Solana, the Spain of the Generation of '98, and the derivative Spain of the Franco Era, so explains C. O. Jones, the American financieroil tycoonnarrator of Fergus Reid Buckley's panoramic novel, Servants and Their Masters. Police investigation, in part precipitated by the strangulation murder of the 71yearold dowager Odette Caro Perez de Barradas, XVIIth Marquesa del Peregrino, by her 69yearold maid and the subsequent gathering of her peers and heirs, reveals that the scandal includes, in addition to murder, architectural bungling, blackmail, customs officials' bribery, demonic possession, estate bankruptcies; false jailing, fraud, gangsterism, genocide, illegitimacy, infant substitution, maiming, pornographic photos, rape, sexual orgies, the siphoning of nobles' titles, stock manipulation and torture as well.

title: Quebec Vote
description: MONTREAL  On election night here last week, as the returns showed the stanchly federalist Liberal party piling up seats in the provincial legislature, a young leader of the separatist Parti Qubcois was asked if the Liberal landslide spelled the end of Quebec separatism.

title: Jamaica's Strawberry Fields: Where Camping Comforts Are Real
description: WITH the springing up of the hippie campground three years ago in Negril, word leaked out that Jamaica had become the Morocco of the Caribbean.

title: Portugal's Colonies
description: A week ago Portugal, held an election that changed little in that country's national life. One significant matter, Portugal's military suppression of tative movements in her African colonies, was barred as a campaign issue. Hers is a report on the colonies:

title: BARRIERS TO VOTING FOUND NATIONWIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Barriers imposed by state and local voterregistration requirements ate the major reason that about 37 per cent of the electorate (50 million people) failed to vote in the 1972 Presidential election, a survey prepared for the National Student Vote by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., indicates.

title: In Spain, Part of His Dream House Is a 12thCentury Watchtower
description: PINEDA DEL MAR, SpainCastles in Spain, visitors soon find out, rarely live up to their legends. They tend to run to huge, icy rooms full of gloomy furniture. When Manuel Pertegaz, the couturier who dresses the cream of Spanish society, went looking for a dream house a decade ago, he did much better than a castle.

title: Home Improvement
description: AN extremely powerful colorless adhesive that comes readymixed in small tubes is now available to homeowners and doityourselfers for bonding almost anything together. Actually used industrially for quite a few years to replace rivets and many other fastening methods, this type of adhesive has only recently been put on the market in small packages and in a form that is suitable for use by any consumer. Generically classified by the tonguetwisting name of cyanoacrylates, these powerfully strong adhesives are unlike epoxies in that they require no mixing; and they form a strong bond in just about one minute or less.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Union County K.C. allbreed, National Guard Armory, Walnut Street and Magnolia Avenue, Elizabeth, N. J.; 642 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: JOHN G. NEIHARDT, POET OF THE WEST
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 3Dr. John G. Neihardt, poet laureate of Nebraska and once widely regarded as one of the foremost poets in this country, died today at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Hilda Petri. He was 92 years old.

title: From Jefferson To Nixon
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 3At this time of year, the drive from Fiery Run to Charlottesville along the country roads in the lee of the Blue Ridge is almost enough to take a man's mind off Watergate. It is not as colorful as New England in the autumn or as spectacular as Virginia itself at dogwood time in the spring, but the hills are calm and solid and Virginians take a long view of life.

title: Notre Dame's 7th in Row
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov 3 Navy may not be able to beat the best teams in America, but it can size some of them up for you.

title: Music
description: Los ANGELES NOT everyone can be a star. Most of the hundreds of record albums languishing wistfully on record racks belong to young musicians who will never make the cover of Rolling Stone, The turnover rate of artists at large companies can approach 40 per cent annually; that trans lates into a lot of broken dreams and boxloads of unsold records.

title: Benefits
description: Tickets for the following vents may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Foundling
description: Bard, wizard, founder of the kingdom of Prydain, Lloyd Alexander displays all his skills as he returns to the scene of his famous chronicles. He comes now primarily, it seems, as a master weaver to pick up threads in his tapestry, to fill in scattered bits of background. The characters are familiar to those of us who have adventured before in Prydain, but in this book we journey farther back both in time and mystery..

title: Bahamian Says U. S. Lags In Bid to Extradite Vesco
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 3A high Bahamian official with direct knowledge of the matter says that the United States Government has made very little effort here to extradite Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: The Repairman For Nuns on L.I. Is Sister Fixit...
description: In 1951, a slender, shy girl named Joan Marese entered the Sisters of St. Joseph, Brentwood, L.I., bound on a career as a teacher in Roman Catholic elementary schools of the Brooklyn Diocese, width then covered all Long Island.

title: Ideological bombshells from an atomic scientist
description: MOSCOW. In person, Andrei Sakharov hardly seems the man to stir an international furor. Almost automatically now, he is paired with Aleksandr Solzhenitsynvilified in the Soviet Union as a renegade and turncoat who has slandered and betrayed with black ingratitude the motherland which nurtured him; sanctified in the West as a champion of individual rights, a beacon of freethinking liberalism, a symbol for humanizing dtente.

title: LookBobby's Slipping Into Brando's Shoes
description: BOBBY is the next Brando! bursts the biggerthanlife woman on the other end of the telephone. She should know: she's Shelley Winters, a longtime fan and friend of both Marlon Brando and Bobby De Niro.

title: When Herbs Are Grown Indoors ...
description: IN the popular literature on herb culture, one is assured that keeping herbs growing indoors is quite easy. Actually, this is not quite accurate. Many a potted herb plant has withered and died in an overheated house, and the grower has accused herself of having a deadly thumb. Herbs can be brought indoors and encouraged to survive but basic needs of the plants must be met.

title: 600 BUS DRIVERS WIN WATTS POINT
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3On the night of Oct. 13, Edward: Cusiter, 30 years old and the father of two, was driving his No. 92 bus home through the South Central area of Los An geles. By the time the bus: reached Watts most of the passengers had gotten off. Left on the bus were about 15 youths, who began calling him names and spraypainting the windows. The driver was eventually shot by one of the youths, with what the police said was a homemade weapon: The bullet, which lodged near his spine, temporarily paralyzed his left arm.

title: Is the Folk Gone from Folk Music?
description: TRADITIONAL concepts of what constitutes a folk song have been all but abandoned, now that many people are claiming their favorite folk singers to be such performers as Simon and Garfunkel, James Taylor and Joni Mitchell. It often seems as though the use of an acoustic guitar is what defines the style, rather than such characteristics as sociocultural orientation, oral transmission (becoming, as Ben Botkin once put it, aural transmission, thanks to the phonograph record) with its resultant communal recreation.

title: Portentous, Long Shot, Coast Victor
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP)Portentous, a long shot paying $77.20, captured the $100,000 Oak Tree Invitation at Santa Anita today.

title: On the Nature of the U.N. Peace Force
description: A new international peacekeeping effort has been launched in the Middle East. For the second time, a United Nations Emergency Force has been introduced. The first force was established in 1956 following the Suez War and remained in the area until it was withdrawn in May 1967. Generally, the first force (and now the second) was intended to separate the antagonists, provide a buffer, establish ceasefire lines and supervise them and help create peaceful conditions that lead to meaningful negotiations. There are, however, a number of differences between the two forces stemming from their respective backgrounds.

title: JAWORSKI CAREER COVERS 46 YEARS
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 3  Leon Jaworski, President Nixon's new special Watergate prosecutor, has pleased and antagonized both liberals and conservatives in Texas in his 46year career in law, commerce and parttime politics.

title: Brick Lifts Streak to 24 by 210
description: Brick Township now has New Jersey's longest winningstreak. Brick wrapped up the Shore Conference A Division championship yesterday with a 210 victory over Neptune in Brick.

title: Shultz Wants Controls Replaced By Agency to Monitor Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz would like the present wageprice controls system replaced by a small Federal inflationmonitoring agency, with virtually no power to intervene in the economy.

title: Cuba to Flee a Canadian Imprisoned as C.I.A. Man
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 3 (UPI) Cuba has told Canada that it will release a Canadian citizen who has spent 10 years in prison for smuggling weapons for the United States Central Intelligence Agency, the External Affairs Department announced today.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Add one more shortage to the lengthening list: mason jars for home canning. Blame the fine summer weather, industrious home gardeners, soaring food prices and Government environmental requirements.

title: How some cities got together
description: The crises of cities, in the mid20th century, have sharpened historical attention paid to the complex process of modem urbanization. It is now conventional and in some ways appropriate to link this process to the industrial revolution, and within these terms the English cities of the 19th century demand special attention, since it was there, on this reading, that the whole process began.

title: NEW BOOKS
description: THE COURIER By CLEMENT R. HOOPES $6.95

title: Architect to Wed Linda Neshamkin
description: Dr. and Mrs. Oliver M. Neshamkin of New York and Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Christine Neshamkin, to John Winfield French, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. French of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE last thing in the world I would dream of doing is arguing with Ada Louise Huxtable about architecture. But when she writes in her piece: on Presidential libraries [Selling the President, Architecturally, Sept, 30) It is hard to think of anything that has gone quite as monumentally wrong as the whole idea of Presidential libraries, she is invading the field of research and scholarship. Perhaps a historian may be permitted a few words of rejoinder. She goes on to speak of the creation of false and unnecessary needs, masterful imageselling, the competitive pantheon business, this extravagant exercise in egogratification and so on. One feels that in this unwontedly overwrought flow of language Mrs. Huxtable's customary lucidity deserts her.

title: T.W.A. and Cabin Employes Hold Talks With Mediators
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  Representatives of Trans World Airlines and its cabin attendants met today with mediators from the National Mediation Board.

title: Twilight of the Gods
description: There is no need to use the somber sounds of the Gotterdarnmerung, but melancholy marks the realization that the twilight of the gods is enveloping far too many of the Titans who once bestrode the sports firmament with heroic grandeur. Reaching out for them is the inexorable sequence of going, going, gone. However, the only one definitely gone is, Willie Mays.

title: FIREMEN'S TALKS AT IMPASSE HERE
description: Negotiators for the city and its 10,900 firemen worked yesterday to narrow their differences, but Eric J. Schmertz, the mediator, said that they were still far apart and he described the situation as ominous and grim.

title: Fordham Defeats Georgetown, 130
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Brian Murray threw, a 37yard scoring pass to Mark Branca in the third period today to help Fordham defeat Georgetown, 130.

title: In Guadalajara, a 12Man Orchestra is Yours for Just 20 Pesos But, Senor, They Inevitably Play Guaddaalaahaarah
description: YOU are sitting at an outdoor cafe on the Plaza de los Mariachis in. Guadalajara, Mexico. It is o'clock in the evening, and all hell Is about to break loose. Half a dozen knots of men gather at one end of the plaza, 8 to 12 in a grow. They are mariachisstrolling troubadoursmiddleaged, for the most part, with dark, grave Indian faces. They wear broadbrimmed sombreros and short jackets of red, blue, black or tan ornamented with silyer but tons. Each group unlimbers violins, guitars, a trumpet or two and a peculiarly Mexican instrument caged guitarron, a potbellied bass guitar almost the size of a cello. The action begins.

title: Power Memorial, Molloy Win Runs
description: Power Memorial and Archbishop Molloy won Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional crosscountry titles yesterday at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx.

title: Museum in Bergen Is Seeking Exhibits
description: PARAMUSUrgently wanted by the Bergen Community Museum for the new Nature Room of its soontobe opened Science Hall are live or mounted frogs, salamanders, turtles, large insects, snakes, snails, fish and native plants.

title: Blazers' 4thPeriod Rally Downs Knicks by 107100
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. (AP)Geoff Petrie led a late fourthquarter rally to pace the Portland Trail Blazers over the New York Knickerbockers, 107100, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Super Red Will End His Affair With Fans
description: With chances for a match race with Prove Out all but vanished, Secretariat will make his final appearance on a race track next Tuesday at Aqueduct.

title: Many in Cairo Expect New Fighting
description: CAIRO, Nov. 3The official ceasefire took effect almost two weeks ago, but Egypt remains a country at war, and in Cairo most people believe there will be fighting again soon.

title: Donohue, on the Way Out, Views Things From Top
description: In the nineteen fifties, when Dwight Eisenhower was President and Marilyn Monroe was the queen and Elvis Presley was becoming king, Mark Donohue was growing up in Summit, N.J., when the hot rod phenomenon came East from California and caught me up in it. Now it's hard to picture Donohue 36 years old, slouching like James Dean or wearing his blond hair in a D.A. and one wonders what his father, the patent lawyer, must have thought of his son, the race driver. But through a remarkable racing career, Donohue has maintained a counterculture image, assuming that the fifties were a culture.

title: Some are punished in their old age
description: During the decades after World War II, exsoldiers wrote about combats the sociallyconscious wrote about suburbia and slums; Jews, if they could master their horrifying material wrote about concentration camps. It is no coincidence that now, in the seventies, several writers have turned their attention to old people and old people's homesthose proliferating symbols (blending innocuously into the landscape of every American town and city) of institutionalization. For it is in institutions that we hide our untouchables and commit our. most unspeakable acts.

title: O'Donoghue Is Harrier King Again
description: Tim O'Donoghue of Montclair State showed no effects of a recent leg injury yesterday morning as he successfully defended his individual title in the annual Collegiate Track Conference cross country championships at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Cynthia Parke Sets Nuptials
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Comdr. Everett Austin Parke, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Parke have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Ann Parke, to Lieut. John Frederick Beukema, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Frederick Beukema of Pittsburgh.

title: Jersey Republicans Fear A Major Defeat Tuesday
description: TRENTON, Nov. 3As New Jersey's campaign for Governor drew to a close this weekend, many state Republican leaders reported today that final efforts by Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. to avert defeat had failed and that he and the Republican party appeared headed toward a political disaster in Tuesday's election.

title: Sussman Speech Case Gets Court Test
description: TRENTON  A unique court suit, one that raises constitutional questions about freedom of speech for public officials, has been filed by Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state's controversial Director of Consumer Health.

title: Ridgewood Library Fills Director Post
description: RIDGEWOODThe Ridgewood Library has announced the appointment of Robert D. Ross as its director. He succeeds Mrs. Esther Baker Fishler, who retired on Oct. 1.

title: New & Novel
description: After a decadeplus of marriage, four children, analysis and consciousnessraising, a Washington matron named Coco Berman seems on the road to maturity. It has taken Coco a good deal of recidivism to arrive at this starting point, during which she has sought a Perfect Lover, upbraided her husband interminably and marched on Washington. When her husband leaves her she feels surprisingly bereft.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Dance
description: THE decentralization, of the theaterbe it dance, drama or operais a Matter of considerable importance to the future health of the performing arts. We have, in a bewilderingly short time, seen Washington become a major theater town. Elsewhere across the country, in San Francisco and Chicago, fornexample, things theatrical seem to be moving.

title: Sadat Holds Talks With Other Arab Chiefs
The First Mate is 22 and a She
description: Debby Young, a spunky 22yearold sailor with an impish face framed by Shirley Temple curls, sat crosslegged on a pile of planks. Debby, a Britisher, had been energetically pulling up the floorboards in the hold of the brig Unicorn, a square rigger from Finland. Miss Young is the ship's first mate and navigator. The Unicorn had been docked for seven weeks at the South Street Seaport and was scheduled to return there in two weeks.

title: Despite Its Closeness, Race for Westchester County Executive Fails to Stir Great Interes
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2 A race for County Execuiive that may be the closest in Westchester's history has run its course without generating more than routine interest.

title: Bridge
description: When two married couples gather for an evening of bridge the obvious procedure is for the husbands and wives to play as partners. This is the only possible course if money stakes are envisioned, but it can injure marital harmony and has been under a cloud since 1929, when John Bennett of Kansas City was shot dead by his wife, partly because he had criticized her bidding and partly because he had failed to make his contract.

title: EVE Helps Worn en Realize Job Goals
description: UNIONThe biggest problem we have is overcoming theirr sense of inadequacy. They feel they are important people in their children's lives, and there is constant conflict between a fear that they are neglecting their children and fear that they are neglecting themselves.

title: Carole Lane Bride Of Joel P. Koeppel
description: Miss Carole Susan Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Lane of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Palm Beach, Fla., was married last night to Joel P. Koeppel of Hollywood, Fla.

title: British Theater Is Coming to Brooklyn
description: London may be the permanent home of some of the world's finest Englishlanguage theater, but next January the scene will shift temporarily to a new location  Brooklyn.

title: Borrowers Getting Amnesty
