description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 7West European nations moved today to conserve oil supplies and to meet the problems caused by cutbacks by Arab producing nations.

title: Struck Hospitals Discharging Thousands of Patients
description: Struck hospitals in the metropolitan area discharged thousands of patients yesterday and closed entire floors, and three nursing homes, whose resources were being exhausted by the threeday oldstrike, announced they would be sending home all 1,347 patients within the next week.

title: New Mayor a Courtly Man of Caution
description: To work for Abraham D. Beame, James A. Cavanaugh, says, is to expect to get a lot of telephone calls: He's got this tickler list  this little padof things to get done. And he calls you right away. He's a very efficient man,

title: Mills Sees Nixon Quitting in Short Period of Time
description: KENSETT, Ark., Nov. 7 (AP)Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, predicted tonight that President Nixon would resign within a short period of time.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Writers ReElect. Durso
description: Joseph Durso of The Times was reelected chairman of he New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America yesterday. Phil Pepe of the Daily News was elected vice chairman and Jack tang of The Long Island Press was reelected executive secretary.

title: Deciding Which Patient Must Go
description: Doctors examining patients on rounds at Mount Sinai Medical Center here yesterday had to put an emergency disaster plan into effectin reverse.

title: CHARLES W. FRANKLIN
description: Charles W. Franklin, a member of The New York Times for 26 years and assistant sub scription manager in the circulation department since 1968, died Monday of a heart attack at his home, 326 West 20th street. His age was 52.

title: ExGov. Hughes Is Named As Chief Justice by Cahill
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7Governor Cahill today nominated former Gov. Richard J. Hughes to be Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: Advertising: New Colgate Lines
description: Twice within six months ColgatePalmolive, the 167yearold soap and toiletries marketer, has gone national with new products of a completely alien nature, except, of course, that they were packaged goods.

title: Ryder Is Seeking Toro
description: Ryder System, Inc., a leader in the truckleasing field, has reached, an agreement in principle to purchase the privately owned Toro Petroleum Corporation, blender of petroleum components, at Houston.

title: City G.O.P. Devastated
description: A year after President Nixon swept New York State and nearly captured the city, the landslide victory of Controller Abraham D. Beame left the city Republican party shattered and showing signs of the splits that have plagued the Democratic party here.

title: Islanders, Penguins in 11 Deadlock
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (UPI) Garry Howatt's first National Hockey League goal gave the New York Islanders a 11 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins last night.

title: Some Issues Approved
description: Voters aren't in much of mood to borrow.

title: Welsh Corgi in Ithaca Herds a Child to Bed
description: My dogs are never going to herd cattle, said Neil McLain of Ithaca, N. Y., so I'm not too worried about their working abilities. I'm more concerned with good temperament, which they must have. All the herding they do is right in our home. At night, when we give the word, they herd our youngster up to bed. McLain, who is vice president of the Pembroke Welsh Corgi Club of America, originally had miniature poodles. My wife, Kathryn, and I started in obedience and one of our miniatures went through to a C. D. X. [companion dog excellent], he said. Kathryn still teaches at the Ithaca Dog Training Club.

title: A MOTORIST SAVES POLICEMEN'S LIVES
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Nov. 7A passing motorists who rammed a stolen car with his own vehicle early this morning was credited by the police with saving two radiocar officers from possible death at the hands of gunmen.

title: Radio
Some of Santiago Poor, Criticizing Junta, Say They Can't Make Ends Meet
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 7Everywhere a visitor goes in shantytowns in the Santiago area, people say that they do not have enough money for foodlet alone anything elsebecause of the big price increases allowed by the military junta.

title: Byrne Says His Victory Reflects Significant Lack of Public Confidence in Nixon
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7  Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne said today his stunning 2to1 victory over Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. was evidence of a significant lack of public confidence in the Nixon Administration.

title: Cairo Revisited
description: After more than six years of artificial and largely symbolic estrangement, the United States and Egypt have agreed to resume diplomatic relations. This adds to the encouraging side of the balance in which the Middle East hangs so precariously; its counterweight is the increasingly ominous threat of renewed ArabIsraeli combat at any moment, this time with a real possibility of Soviet military participation. These are surely critical days for peace or war in the Middle East.

title: Soviet Charges China Suppresses Minority Uprisings
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7  The Soviet press charged today that China had forcibly suppressed minority uprisings in six regions in recent years and killed more than 12,000 people in Tibet last year.

title: G.M. IS INCREASING OPEL PRICES BY 7%
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it was increasing prices on its 1974 Opel automobiles imported from West Germany by an average of $225, or 7 per cent.

title: TV: Focus on Directors
description: The Men Who Made Movies, a series of eight profiles on prominent film directors, began its weekly run on public television last Sunday. The first installment, devoting 90 minutes to Raoul Walsh, will be repeated tonight at 9 on Channel 13. With original programing at a premium these days, everything on public television is quickly repeated at least once.

title: A GAP IN TAPES REPORTED BY AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7A Presidential aide testified today that a gap had been discovered in one of the White House tape recordings and that as a result another conversation between President Nixon and John W. Dean 3d, then his counsel, might be unavailable.

title: Democratic Mayor and Council Named in Race in Minneapolis
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 The voters of Minneapolis returned to the liberal Democratic fold last night by choosing Albert J. Hofstede as Mayor and rejecting Charles S. Stenvig, the conservative incumbent.

title: Oil Find Is Reported
description: PARIS, Nov. 7 (Reuters)The French oil company, Compagnie Franaise des Petroles, announced today it had struck oil in the British sector of the North Sea. Tests at the new well brought 3,000 barrels of oil a day and the find appeared to have important potential, the statecontrolled company said.

title: ALBERT DE CHIARA
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. Albert de Chiara, retired president of Drico Industrial Corporation, maker of airfiltration products in Wallington, N. J., died today in Stamford Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: City G.O.P. Devastated
description: A year after President Nixon swept New York State and nearly captured the city, the landslide victory of Controller Abraham D. Beame left the city Republican party shattered and showing signs of the splits that have plagued the Democratic party here.

title: Jersey Bids Little League Let Girls Play on Teams
description: NEWARK, Nov. 7Little League baseball in New Jersey was ordered today to permit girls to play on local teams throughout the state.

title: People in Sports: A Goal Is Near for Chris Evert
description: Chris Evert's virus has become South Africa's gain. The third  ranked women's tennis star in the United. States said yesterday she would compete in next week's South African open championship in order to gain enough points to capture the Commercial Union Grand Prix title.

title: Defeat of Reagan's Tax Plan Seen as Loss to Him for 76, but He Denies Setback
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7Gov. Ronald Reagan refused today to interpret voter repudiation of his state fiscal management plan as a personal defeat, but political observers here see the result as lessening his chances to be the Republican Presidential nominee in 1976.

title: Transcript of President's Address on the Energy Situation
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's broadcast address on energy from Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Consumer Notes
description: Buying by credit card is more convenient and at times less expensive than installment buying, but it affords the consumer much less recourse's against fraud, misrepresentations and defective merchandise.

title: Cahill Acts to Meet Imminent Serious Energy Crisis
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7In a farreaching, statewide fuelsaving effort that combines mandatory restrictions with appeals for public cooperation, Governor Cahill today announced a program to meet an imminent serious energy crisis that would include the lowering of the state's cleanair standards this winter.

title: Buffalo Voters Turn Down Plan for Convention Center
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 7 (UPI)A proposal for a new downtown convention center here was narrowly defeated in yesterday's election.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: There seems to be little chance that Dickinson High of Jersey City will win its football game tommorrow. Its opponent is Lincoln, which has won six of seven games and is one of the strongest teams in North Jersey. Dickinson has not won a football game in more than four seasons, 39 games. Not even a tie.

title: Nixon Has No Intention Of Leaving White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7President Nixon, besieged recent weeks by demands for his resignation or impeachment, said tonight that he had not violated the trust of the American people and that he would not quit.

title: Vassar Junior Defeats Republican Incumbent
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 7Daniel O'Keefe of Poughkeepsie, a 20yearold Vassar College junior, has defeated Mrs. Jean Murphy, the threeterm Republican incumbent, for a seat on the Dutchess County Board of Representatives. Mr. O'Keefe, who will be one of the youngest elected officials in the history of Dutchess County, won by a vote of 1,009 to 1,001

title: Nixon Sounds Note of Normality
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7President Nixon took the high road tonight.

title: Firefighter's Union Contract Dispute Goes to Binding Arbitration Before ThreeMan Impasse Panel
description: The dispute between the city and its fire fighters, which produced the first strike of firemen in 108 years, went into binding arbitration yesterday before an impasse panel in a move that was described as cordial and serious by the parties in the talks.

title: Con Ed to Seek Substantial Rate Rise For Electricity Before End of the Year
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, the metropolitan area's largest utility, will seek a substantial increase in electric rates before the year's end.

title: NATO TALKS OVER; GAINS ARE REPORTED
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 7 (Reuters)Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger of the United States and several of his European counterparts concluded a twoday meeting here today with both sides reported reassured that Atlantic alliance solidarity was on the mend.

title: A New Constable, 19
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP)Steven Custer, 19 years old, got only seven votes yesterday, but it was enough to elect him constable of this Philadelphia suburb. He was a writein candidate. Neither the Democrats nor the Republicans entered a candidate.

title: U.S. AND EGYPT SET RENEWAL OF TIES, CUT SINCE '67 WAR
description: CAIRO, Nov. 7The United States and Egypt announced today that they had agreed to resume diplomatic relations and would exchange ambassadors within 10 days or two weeks.

title: Girl, 13, Is Seized In a $2,167 Holdup At Savings Office
description: A 13yearold girl robbed a savingsandloan office in Greenwich Village of $2,167 yesterday but was seized seconds later as she tried to escape with a bag containing the money, the police said.

title: The Little Three: Still Pure Amateur
description: I had heard of the Little Three before I came up here, said Bob Odell, Williams' head football coach since 1971. But I never really knew the importance of it. It's sort of the way college football should be. Odell, formerly the head coach at Bucknell and Penn, learned about the Little Three in a hurry. His first two Williams teams won the roundrobin series with Wesleyan and Amherst. Odell's Ephmen open defense of the Little Three title at Wesleyan Saturday. Amherst, which is undefeated, beat Wesleyan, 4126, in the roundrobin's opening game. The 1973 series will end when Amherst and Williams meet Nov. 17, in their usual season finale.

title: Sisco Flies to Tel Aviv to Brief Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 7Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco arrived here unexpectedly tonight to brief an apprehensive Israeli leadership of the discussions held earlier today between Secretary of State Kissinger and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Welsh Corgi in Ithaca Herds a Child to Bed
description: My dogs are never going to herd cattle, said Neil McLain of Ithaca, N. Y., so I'm not too worried about their working abilities. I'm more concerned with good temperament, which they must have. All the herding they do is right in our home. At night, when we give the word, they herd our youngster up to bed. McLain, who is vice president of the Pembroke Welsh Corgi Club of America, origi nally had miniature poodles. My wife, Kathryn, and I started in obedience and one of our miniatures went through to a C. D. X. [companion dog excellent], he said. Kathryn still teaches at the Ithaca Dog Training Club.

title: Saigon Raids Red Areas
description: The South Vietnamese military command said yesterday that its planes had bombed two Communistheld areas north of Saigon in what it described as its largest air strike since the signing of the ceasefire agreement in January. Page 5.

title: Decals to Urge Fuel Saving
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 7 (UPI)Stateowned vehicles in Connecticut will soon bear decals reading, Conserve energy. Do not exceed 55 M.P.H. on their dashboards. The cars will also have a sticker on their speedometers pointing to the limit. The move is part of an energy conservation campaign.

title: JERSEY TO EASE CLEANAIR RULES
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7In a farreaching, statewide fuelsaving effort that combines mandatory restrictions with appeals for public cooperation, Governor Cahill today announced a program to meet an imminent serious energy crisis that would include the lowering of the state's cleanair standards this winter.

title: Personal Finance
description: This year roughly 175,000 persons will resort to bankruptcy to get a fresh start in life.

title: Sharp Turn in Mideast
description: CAIRO, Nov. 7The dramatic Middle East developments today have occurred with such rapidity and secrecy that several crucial questions remain unanswered. On the basis of what was announced it seemed to many Americans traveling with Secretary of State Kissinger that Washington's relations with both Egypt and Israel may never be quite the same again. The announcement that President Anwar elSadat agreed this morning to the restoration of diplomatic relations with the United Statesthe prime military supporter of Israeldespite the apparent uncertainty of the current ceasefire seemed to bear out Mr. Kissinger's personal view that for the first time in many years the United States could engage in a serious with the Arab world.

title: Bucks Turn Back Lakers For 10th Victory in Row
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 14 of his 28 points in the first quarter last night in Milwaukee to lead the Bucks to a 109102 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Nassau Weathers Democratic Storm
description: MINEOLA, L. I. Nov. 7While Republicans were losing their grip on suburban elective offices every where else in the New York area, the powerful G.O.P. organization in Nassau County convincingly won all county and town contests in Tuesday elections.

title: Politics in Virginia Is Still in Disarray
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 7  Ever since Harry Byrd and the poll tax died, the only thing clear about Viginia politics has been the confusion.

title: Rockland's Democrats To Control Legislature
description: WEST NYACK, N. Y., Nov. 7 Rockland County politicians credited the Watergate scandal and a local corruption issue with having helped the Democrats in their stunning victories in yesterday's voting.

title: Republicans Add to Edge In New York Legislature
description: The Republican party will go into the 1974 legislative session in Albany with comfortable majorities in both houses and will retain the ability to pass legislation without having to go to the Democrats for support.

title: Arsonist Blazes a Trail
description: TOKYO (UPI)  The police said they arrested an arson suspect through fingerprints left on, an empty bottle five years ago. The suspect, an apprentice bartender, was on the police wanted list for 20 cases of arson reported in the Sumida Ward since 1960.

title: Saigon Writer Finds Everyone Guilty
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7She writes in careful detail about the cultural degradation that South Vietnam suffered under the Americus, daughters turned into whores and rentawives, whole families dedicating themselves to trafficking in stolen postexchange goods, an artificial, competitive prosperity disrupting marriages, friendships and social relationships.

title: T.W.A. Strike in 3d Day
description: TransWorld Airlines' entire fleet of 249 planes was still grounded in the third day of a strike by the airline's 5,000 cabin attendants, The Associated Press reported.

title: Rangers Set Back Bruins
description: The Rangers live!

title: Other News of Election
description: TRANSIT: A new battle to save the 35cent transit fare was under way in the aftermath of the overwhelming rejection of the transportation bond issue. But some experts, among them Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, believe the new campaign is doomed. Page 53.

title: Panel Plans Perjury Inquiry on a Ford Witness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The Senate Rules Committee agreed today to consider asking the Justice Department to bring perjury charges against a onetime Washington lobbyist who said he once lent $15,000 to Gerald R. Ford.

title: EGYPT PACT ENDS A SIXYEAR BREAK
description: The startling decision by the United States and Egypt to resume relations ends a diplomatic rupture of siz and a hall years that has defied several peace overtures.

title: Prices Move Slightly Higher on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market rose slightly yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Westchester Winner
description: Alfred B. Del Bello sat behind his desk in his small law office in Yonkers yesterday, accepting occasional telephone calls of congratulations but mostly just catching up on his paper work.

title: Nastase, Smith Win In Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 7 (UPI) Ilie Nastase and Stan Smith easily advanced tonight in the $75,000 Stockholm indoor tennis tournament.

title: The Things We Might Have Seen
description: DURHAM, N. C.Suddenly everybody and his uncle is raising the question of Mr. Nixon's fitness as personto be President. For 27 years, Richard Nixon has been trying to tell us the answer. That what moves and excites him is not principle or policy or result, but an endless struggle for control. First to control himself. He is and has beenat least since 1946 a man who seemed to be hounded by the selfimposed temptation to let his enemies have it, to get them, to let all his dammedup anger find release in some glorious outburst.

title: HALDEMAN MEMOS ATTACK SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7In October, 1969, H. R. Haldeman, President Nixon's chief of staff, ordered White House aides to organize a campaign of letters, telegrams and telephone calls. to Senators Charles E. Goodell of New York, Charles McCMathias Jr. of Maryland and Charles H. Percy of Illinois, all Republicans, blasting them on their consistent opposition to the President.

title: 200'Clash at Wisconsin U. Over I.T.T. Job Recruiter
description: Three persons were arrested when the police attempted to disperse the crowd by spraying Chemical Mace and swinging their nightsticks.

title: Oil for the Lights of Tokyo Is Scarce
description: TOKYO, Nov. 7The lights are going out all over the Ginza, the bright bubble of Tokyo's nightlife, despite the Japanese Government's efforts to put a calm face on the oil crisis.

title: Harry Schwartz, 75, Dead; An F.A.A. Chief Engineer
description: Harry Schwartz, former chief engineer in the aviation facilities division of the Federal Aviation Agency, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 75 years old and lived at 13743 70th Road, Flushing.

title: U.S. INQUIRY SET FOR CITY SUBWAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Claude S. Brinegar, the Secretary of Transportation today acceded to the request by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beanie for a Federal investigation of safety conditions in the New York City subways. The request was rejected when it was first made June 8.

title: A GAP IN TAPES REPORTED BY AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7A Presidential aide testified today that a gap had been discovered in one of the White House tape recordings and that as a result another conversation between President Nixon and John W. Dean 3d, then his counsel, might be unavailable.

title: John Sharbough, 73, Dies; Partner of Eastman Dillon
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 7  John W. Sharbough, who retired in 1967 as a general partner of Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co., New York,, died yesterday at his home, 24 Avon Road. He was 73 years old.

title: A Summary Of Fuel Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Following is a summary of fuel shortages as presented in a fact sheet distributed tonight by the White House:

title: Fire Damages Props Of Metropolitan Opera
description: A fire swept through a twostory warehouse of the Metropolitan Opera Company in the Bronx late last night, destroying scores of props and costumes from current and past productions.

title: CHICAGO 7 LAWYERS FREED OF 7 CHARGES
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (Reuters) A Federal district Judge dismissed today seven of 14 contempt charges against William M. Kunstler and Leonard Weinglass, who represented the Chicago Seven in the riot conspiracy trial in 1969.

title: Britain's Phase 3 Program Wins Approval in Commons
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuters)Prime Minister Heath's new antiinflation policy, setting a basic seven per cent limit for wage's increases during the next 12 months, won approval in the House of Commons tonight by a 39vote majority.

title: Namath Works Out, May Start Sunday...
description: Seven weeks after he suffered a shoulder separation, Joe Namath may start against New England here Sunday. And if he dodges the Patriots' defensive 11 as adroitly as he avoided New York's reportorial 12, his return will be a smashing success.

title: N.B.C. SUED ON ADS FOR KENNEDY FILM
description: The distributor of Executive Action, the movie by Dalton Trumbo about a conspiracy to assassinate President Kennedy, filed a $1.5million, breachofagreement suit yesterday morning in New York State Supreme Court against the National Broadcasting Company for canceling a television commercial promoting the film.

title: U.S. Waiving Entry Rules For 20,000 Cubans in Spain
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Over 20,000 exiled Cubans now living in Spain have been granted permisssion by the United States Government to emigrate here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Silver Futures Prices Fall Here As the Dollar Advances Abroad
description: As the dollar showed strength abroad, silver futures prices, fell yesterday in active trading. Silver contracts on the Commodity' Exchange here dropped more than 9 cents an ounce for some deliveries.

title: $32.7Million Deal Completed By British Unit of Sterling Drug
description: Sterling Drug, Inc., said yesterday that its British subsidiary, SterlingWinthrop Group, Ltd., had completed the acquisition of the Izal business and related assets and liabilities formerly held by Central and Sheerwood Trust Group, Ltd. The purchase price was 13.5million, or about $32.7million, based on yesterday's closing prices on foreignexchange markets here.

title: Spectator Denounces Newark's Council
description: NEWARK, Nov. 7  The Newark City Council heard itself denounced from the spectators' section today by a woman who said she was appalled by the way the Councilmen were acting in a public business sesslob.

title: Stage: Small Delights
description: See The Sea Gull before it closes Sunday afternoon at the Philip Nolan Theater (2438900), 15 Vandam Street. To witness what the new Ensemble Theater Company has done with the Chekhov classic is a tingling reward. Another, smallerscale off Off Broadway treat is Carlo Goldoni's The Mistress of the Inn, performed by the West Side Community Repertory Theater (8749400 and 6663521.) at 252 West 81st Street. This one, an amusing vintage lollipop dating back to 1752, also ends its run Sunday.

title: Outstanding New Englander
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7 (AP)Deane Davis, a former Governor of Vermont; has been chosen the outstanding New Englander of the year by the New England Council.

title: Election Decimates the G.O.P.'s Ranks in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7Democrats apparently swept to the largest legislative victories in modern New Jersey history with margins so great in both houses that the few Republicans who survived the Brendan T. Byrne landslide in yesterday's election will have little if any leverage during their terms.

title: MOTIVE UNKNOWN IN COAST KILLING
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 7Residents of Oakland expressed today shock and anger over the ambush killing of school superintendent here, Marcus A. Foster. The question they asked most was why, and it remained unanswered.

title: OpenAdmission Police College Survives Lively Identity Crisis
description: One day in a class on constitutional law at John Jay College of Criminal Justice the discussion got around to the rights of demonstrators and the right of the police to control them.

title: ...and Knicks' Reed Is Likely to Miss Celtic Game
description: The Knicks play the Boston Celtics tonight at Madison Square Garden and the New Yorkers may have to do it without Willis Reed.

title: Odom on Shrine Team
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (UPI)Steve Odom, the University of Utah's 165pound wide receiver, became the first player selected for this year's Shrine EastWest football game at Candlestick Park Dec. 29.

title: Escaped Prisoners Hold 3 Hostages in Minnesota
description: WADENA, Minn., Nov. 7 (AP) Two escaped prisoners freed three children today but kept three other members of a farm family hostage while waiting to flee aboard a commandeered airplane.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A further milk price increase confronted New Yorkers as negotiators for 120 dairies and representatives of their 3,000 employes bargained over a new contract against 4 P.M. Sunday deadline. Price increases of 1.5 cents per quart at retail were a result of the last, twoyear contract between the Greater New York Milk Dealers Labor Committee and Local 584 of the International Brotherhood Teamsters, representing workers who help supply milk the city, Westchester and Nassau Counties and part of Suffolk County. The present price of a quart of milk in supermarkets is generally 39 cents.

title: A DELAY IS ARRANGED ON SOVIET TRADE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) Carl Albert, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, agreed to a personal request from President Nixon to delay House action on trade legislation containing sanctions against the Soviet Union.

title: Roman Catholic, 18, Slain By TeenAgers in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 7 (Reuters)An 18yearold Roman Catholic youth died tonight after having been shot at close range by four teenagers as he stood at a bus stop in Belfast's Springfield Road district.

title: F.D.A. Recalls Products, Citing Peril of Mushrooms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration announced today that the recall of frozen beefstaks, frozen veal parmesina and frozen sailsbury steaks that mays contain underprocessed mushrooms.

title: Defeat of Transportation Bond Issue Sets Off a New Fight to Save 35Cent Fare
description: The decisive defeat of the state transportation bond issue on Election Day set off a desperate new battle yesterday to save the 35cent transit fare  a campaign that many transit experts already believed is doomed to failure.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: People and Business
description: Arthur T. Roth, chairman of the Bank of Suffolk County, which has assets of $50million, has dropped his intention to acquire the $49million Oysterman's Bank and Trust Company in Suffolk County and has temporarily shelved his plan to acquire the $53million First National Bank of Glen Head. And yesterdaythe day after a rival bid by the $6.3billion Charter. New York Corporation to take over the Glen Head bank was turned down he explained why.

description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Breitel Wins Decisively In Race for Chief Judge
description: Appeals Court Judge Charles D. Breitel, one of the most reluctant campaigners on Tuesday's ballot, won a decisive victory of more than 300,000 votes over his leading opponent, Jacob D. Fuchsberg, in the race for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesten. day was:

title: Notes on People
description: The Secret Service, the Treasury Department agency responsible for the protection of the President, the Vice President and other officials, got a new chief yesterday. He is H. Stuart Knight, a 52yearold career agent who has been assistant director for administration since April, 1971.

title: CHILEANS SEAL OFF EXCUBAN EMBASSY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 7 (UPI)Chilean troops sealed off the former Cuban Embassy ?? Santiago today with the Swedish Ambassador, Harold Edelstam, and a number of refugees from the Sept. 11 military coup inside.

title: Chess: Hello Out There in TV Land, It's Checkmate Time Again
description: For the first time since the summer of 1972, when the Bobby FischerBoris passky world championship telecasts gave it the largest audience it ever had, WNETChannel 13 is presenting a chess match. This time around it's a fourgame match between the champions of the two strongest clubs in New York, George Kramer of Manhattan and Sal Matera of Marshall.

title: Israelis at Last Vent Grief for Dead
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 7After a month of containing her grief, Israel mourned her dead today in the first public ceremonies of the war.

title: On Legitimacy
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7In the turmoil of feelings and ideas in America today there is one consistent theme: The country aches for legitimacy. It is weary of surprise, evasion, deception. It yearns for steadiness, trust, openness, law. It yearns for a restored sense of the fitness of things.

title: EXENVOY REPORTS ON LOSSES IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) A former United States Ambassador to Laos today blamed a lack of accountability for the disappearance of millions of dollars worth of surplus military equipment his embassy requisitioned from bases in Southeast Asia.

title: The 27th Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Because the President's popularity has nosedived in the public opinion polls, we are told, he has lost the ability to govern: On that eminently practical ground, some of our pragmatic editorialists insist, the wise and patriotic course would be for Richard Nixon to resign.

title: CHARGES DROPPED IN FT. WORTH CASE
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 7Federal Judge Leo Brewster of the Northern District of Texas has officially dismissed contemptofcourt charges against the five IrishAmericans from New York City who have come to be known as the Fort Worth five.

title: STADIUM COSTS UP BY $15.8MILLION
description: The price tag for rehabilitatng Yankee Stadium has risen to $39.8million, the Lindsay administration said yesterday, announcing it would seek new $15.8million allocation for the controversial project.

title: Suspense Film Dramatizes Kennedy Assassination:The Cast
description: If disbelief is one of our healthiest national reflexes, at least it has been well exercised in the years between the Warren Report and the latest protestations about the nonbeing of those Presidential tapes. The only danger is that fact itself can be a victim of disbelief: Ugly news that happens to be true becomes easier to ignore, and good news gets rejected with a cackle."Executive Action," which opened yesterday at the Coronet, offers a tactful, low-key blend of fact and invention. The film makers do not insist that they have solved John Kennedy's murder; instead, they simply evoke what might have happened, according to various researchers, including Mark Lane.The result is a cool, skillful, occasionally confusing argument for conspiracy. Wealthy rightwingers (Burt Lancaster and Robert Ryan) wanted Kennedy removed because he was going to sign the test-ban treaty, "lead the black revolution" and probably pull out of Vietnam. The last two points may give you the hiccups, but that is what these characters say.Like calm businessmen, they organize the event. While three talented marksmen rehearse by shooting at dummies in a car driven through the desert, the conspirators search for a nut to use as a patsy.Throughout the stress is on technology  even Oswald's name comes out of a computer. The movie follows the "second Oswald" theory, and this part of the plot is deftly constructed, as is the disappearance of the three marksmen, also the calculations to "have the F.B.I. watching the C.I.A." and vice versa, while relying on the inefficiency of the Secret Service.The conspirators are cleverly cloaked in the style of Camelot itself. Lancaster and Ryan appear as pensive, practical semi-academics, rationally planning an act as bloody as a small foreign invasion. (They admit that they sometimes "sound like gods," since they are also planning the world's future  "Well, somebody's got to do it.") Both have the confidence and the casual class that we recall in many Kennedy appointees. Lancaster, looking miraculously young, overdoes the "sincerity" at momentsan old habit of his. And there are too many shots of the conspirators smiling ironically at once another. But Ryan is wonderfully benign and wry, wisely underplaying where others might have gone all out for evil.However, it is far more painful to think of Ryan's death  a few weeks after this movie was finished  than Kennedy's. And that is the problem lurking in this movie. Television footage is used to paw at the public's sentiments; we see Kennedy smiling and golfing and kissing his children, as well as making speeches. But "Executive Action" is emotionally disconnected from history to the degree that those with an affection for suspense can enjoy the build-up of the plotting  even though we know how the assassination turned out.Despite the flags crawling down flagpoles and the drumbeats, a national trauma has become a competent thriller. And it is just as well. Reliving the shock of that killing would hardly benefit any kind of audience now.So whether you chime with this interpretation, or, like a few I know, decide to embrace all the conspiracy theories of the assassination, the movie is useful in rousing the questions once again. The film's sternest and strongest point is that only a crazed person acting on his own would have been acceptable to the American public  which, at that time, certainly did not want to believe in a conspiracy.

title: Books of The Times
description: MALCOLM LOWRY, A Biography. By Douglas Day. 483 pages. Illustrated. Oxford. $10.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1973

title: G.E. Calls Nuclear Power Answer to Crisis
description: The chairman of the General Electric Company said yesterday that the solution to the nation's energy crisis in this century lies with proper utiliIzation of light water nuclear reactors and coal for electric power generation.

title: Pro Hockey
description: TUESDAY NIGHT

title: Energy Crisis May Begin at Home Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 That vague, ominous term, energy crisis, may be translated into concrete discomforts for millions of Americans this wintersuch as paying higher fuel bills, breathing dirtier air, wearing more sweaters indoors, flying on crowded airplanes, getting up in the dark, and searching for parking spaces.

title: MASS MURDER CASE IS STUDIED BY JURY
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Nov. 7  A jury of six men and six women began deliberations today in the mass murder trial of Edmund Emil Kemper 3d here.

title: Chief Judge Breitel
description: The elevation of Associate Judge Charles D. Breitel to Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals is a victory for the independence of the law and a tribute to the discrimination of the voterswho wisely decided that the state's highest court demanded an experienced jurist with proven record of service.

title: Patriarca Denied New Trial
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. (AP)A motion seeking a new trial for Raymond L.S. Patriarca, a reputed leader of organized crime, was rejected yesterday by Superior Court Judge James C. Bulman. Patriarca is at Rhode Island's state prison, serving a 10 year sentence.

title: ExGov. Hughes Is Named As Chief Justice by Cahill
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7Governor Cahill today nominated former Gov. Richard J. Hughes to be Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Aiken Urges House: Impeach President Or Get Off His Back
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 7Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont, the influential dean of Congressional Republicans, declared today that the House of Representatives should either impeach President Nixon or get off his back.

title: Allegheny Airlines Is Fined For No Flights on a Route
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) Allegheny Airlines has been fined $2,500 for having failed to provide agreedupon service to New HavenBridgeport, Conn., for a period of four months.

title: Struck Hospitals Discharging Thousands of Patients
description: Struck hospitals in the metropolitan area discharged thousands of patients yesterday and closed entire floors, and three nursing homes, whose resources were being exhausted by the threeday oldstrike, announced they would be sending home all 1,347 patients within the next week.

title: MOE SCHNEEBAUM
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Nov. 7  Moe Schneebaum, chief of the earth observation systems at the Goddard Space Flight Center at Green Belt, died Monday at his home here. His age was 53.

title: Customer Insurance Plan Is Set by Paine, Webber
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., yesterday became the third stock brokerage firm to provide special insurance protection to customers.

title: FAMILY FOOD COSTS ROSE IN SEPTEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP)  New Government figures, show it cost a family of four at least $40 a week to eat in September, up $3.30 in five months, even if the family bought plenty of beans and avoided expensive meat.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Experts Debate Naming of Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Only one of five constitutional experts who were called before Congressional committees today recommended that President Nixon be left with the power to choose a special prosecutor in the Watergate investigation.

title: Byrne Says Vote Reflects A Lack of Faith in Nixon
description: TRENTON Nov, 7  Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne said today his stunning 2to1 victory over Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. was evidence of a significant lack of public confidence in the Nixon Administration.

title: Director of Cost Council Worried About Oil Shortage
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 7 (Reuters)  The director of the Cost of Living Council, John Dunlop, said today that the current oil shortage could have an adverse effect on industry and jobs.

title: Massachusetts Town Elects College Senior
description: GARDNER, Mass., Nov. 7 (AP)Stephen J. Erickson, 21 years old, a premed student in his last semester at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, was elected Mayor yesterday in a doortodoor campaign that stressed getting city officials and townspeople back together.

title: JERSEY MOTORIST SAVES POLICEMEN
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Nov. 7  A passing motorist who rammed a stolen car with his own vehicle early this morning was credited by the police with saving two radiocar officers from possible death at the hands of gunmen.

title: Daylight Time Bid Loses
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7 (AP)A bill to bring back Daylight Saving Time next month died a quick death yesterday in the Massachusetts Senate after the House last week backed it overwhelmingly. In its place, the Senate adopted a resolution calling on Congress to institute yearround Daylight Saving Time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Chairman Burns of the Federal Reserve Board badly misses the point in his letter of Oct. 29 arguing the case against General Accounting Office audits of the Fed. He states that the issue is whether G.A.O. audits would assist Congress in evaluating monetary policy. I agree that this is the issue. Chairman Burns asserts that G.A.O. audit would not be helpful to the Congress. He doesn't know that it won't. There is no way that he could know that it won't. On the contrary, all of the evidence which is relevant to the issue indicates that G.A.O. audits of monetary policy would be of great value to Congress. G.A.O. would assist Congress in this area by analyzing the same sort of hard question it analyzes in its other audits

title: Wholesale Prices Off 0.3% in Month; Oil Index Up 7.2%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 7  A further drop in farm and food prices brought a second consecutive monthly decline in the wholesale price index, but the rest of the economy continued to display strong inflation in October, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Sacramento, Calif.Hedgemon Lewis, 147 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Rudy Barro, 143 Stockton, Calif., 3 rounds.

title: Text of Congressional Resolution on War Powers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Following is the text of the war  powers resolution enacted today by the House and the Senate:

title: Nastase, Smith Win In Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 7 (UPI) Ilie Nastase and Stan Smith easily advanced tonight in the $75,000 Stockholm indoor tennis tournament.

title: Strike at News Ends
description: Striking members of the Newspaper Guild accepted a new contract offer from The Daily News yesterday and went back to work. Details, Page 24.

title: Saigon Planes Bomb 2 RedHeld Areas
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 8  The South Vietnamese military command said yesterday that its planes had bombed two Communistheld areas north of Saigon in what the command described as its largest air strike since the signing of the ceasefire agreement in January.

title: Suit Contests Impoundment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) Representative Fred B. Rooney, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said today that he had filed suit challenging the White House's impoundment of $400million intended to help local governments to develop water and sewer facilities.

title: MATTHEW GUILTY IN MEDICAID FRAUD
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the outspoken advocate of black capitalism was convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court on 21 counts of illegally diverting Medicaid funds intended for his interfaith hospital.

title: NEW STUDY ASKED IN BLACKS' DEATHS
description: Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged yesterday there was probable cause to believe that Fred Hampton, a Black Panther leader, was murdered in the legal sense of the word in 1969 in a predawn police raid in Chicago.

title: OFFICIALS WELCOME NIXON ENERGY TALK
description: Public utility and environmental officials last night welcorned President Nixon's special message on the nation's energy crisis as an indication that he was aware of the seriousness of the situation.

title: Squires Rally, Hand Nets 7th Straight Loss
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 7The New York Nets blew a 17point thirdperiod lead tonight and dropped a 111107 decision to the Virginia Squires before a crowd of 5,578.

title: Tax Refund for Reynolds
description: R. J, Reynolds Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that a $19million refund of Federal income taxes and interest for the years 1961 to 1972 will affect previously reported earnings for 1961 by 4 per cent and less than 3 per cent for 1962 to 1972. Net earnings for last year will be reduced to $231million, or $5.17 a share, from $237million, or $5.32 a share. The refund resulted from settlement on the company's lastin, firstout method of pricing its inventories in the tobacco business.

title: Long Goodbye Proves a Big Sleeper Here
description: Robert Altman believes it's just possible that his film The Long Goodbye, starring Elliott Gould, could have been the year's blockbuster movie  if only it had opened first in New York. He's probably right.

title: Tax Exempts Active
description: Borrowers ranging from the Port of Seattle to the New Jersey Mortgage Finance Agency and the New York State Dormitory Authority marketed new offerings yesterday in the busy taxexempt sector of the bond Market.

title: TEAMSTERS SHIFT STAND ON COAST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, indicated today that his union would continue to honor contracts with grape growers in California despite a tentative agreement with the A.F.L.C.I.O. president, George Meany, to get out of the vineyards.

title: MayorElect Confident
description: Mayor  elect Abraham D. Beanie moved quickly yesterday to assume authority over the city that gave him a landslide victory at the polls on Tuesday.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS CONGRESS FOR ENERGYCRISIS ACTION; INSISTS HE'LL STAY ON JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7President Nixon asked Congress tonight to give him a variety of Jarreaching powers to deal with the deepening shortage of oil.

title: 1,200 Cambodians, Abandoning Town, Caught in Ambush
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 7 (UPI)Twelve hundred Cambodians, about half of them soldiers, abandoned a besieged town southwest of here last night and ran into an ambush. Reports from the field quoted survivors as saying that at least 700 were slain or taken prisoner.

title: BANK ROBBER HELD IN BOMBING HERE
description: A 28yearold convicted bank robber who had been the subject of a nationwide manhunt since he escaped from Federal prison last February was charged yesterday with the bombing of a Union Square savings bank in which 10 persons were injured.

title: SUFFOLK SHOWING BUOYS DEMOCRATS
description: YAPHANK, L.I., Nov. 7 Democrats in Suffolk County made their strongest showings in two decades yesterday, nearly doubling their strength in the County Legislature and taking control of three of the county's 10 town halls.

title: Bill Changes Asked On Eve of Rail Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7On the eve of the scheduled House vote on a bill to solve the railroad problem in the Northeast, the Administration put forward several amendments today aimed at avoiding the risk of. . . unnecessary taxpayer costs.

title: U.S. Gives to Bengali Effort
description: GENEVA, Nov. 7The United States has pledged a $2million contribution for the exchange of some 200,000 people now under way between Pakistan and Bangladesh, the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees announced today.

title: ExPoliceman Is Convicted In 2 Waterbury Slayings
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 7 (UPI)A Superior Court panel of judges has convicted a former Waterbury policeman, Daniel Mecca, on a charge of manslaughter in the slaying of a husband and wife on Oct. 16, 1972.

title: PAN AM SEEKING TO CUT SERVICE
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it faced massive shotfalls of jet fuel and sought emergency Federal approval for negotiations with other airlines that could lead to the most extensive voluntary restraints ever imposed on world civil aviation.

title: Canada Oil: Pipeline, Not Supply, Inadequate
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 7Canada is the only Western country that produces more oil than she consumes. But oil is nonetheless the subject of increasing public bewilderment and sharp Political dispute.

title: Town Manager System Rejected in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 7 Voters rejected yesterday the replacement of this town's 57yearold governing body, a fiveman Board of Commissioners, with a new councilmanictown manager form of government. The referendum vote was 7,169 to 4,793.

title: European Football
description: EUROPEAN CUP WINNERS CUP

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: REINHARDT REVISITED Max Reinhardt was the theater man extraordinaire, constantly directing and producing, at borne in Salzburg and Hollywood and points in between, an Austrian who left his native land, as a Jewish refugee. He directed his last work, Irwin Shaw's Sons and Soldiers on Broadway, before he died 30 years ago in a New York hotel.

title: The Stage: Remarque's Full Circle
description: A philosophical melodrama might be one way to describe Erich Maria Remarque's play Full Circle, which opened last night at the ANTA Theater. However, most people are likely to find Mr. Remarque's only play, which has been adapted by Peter Stone, rather more melodramatic than philosophic.

title: F.T.C. DROPS CASE AGAINST HIC ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission dropped today all charges of false advertising against HiC fruit drinks, ending a threeyear case once regarded as a major part of a Government crackdown on advertising.

title: Nixon Has No Intention Of Leaving White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7President Nixon, besieged in recent weeks by demands for his resignation or impeachpent, said tonight that, he had not violated the trust of the American people and that he would not quit.

title: Street Lights Go Out
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Nov. 7 (AP)  Half of the 60 street lights on this 10squaremile resort island have been put out in an effort to conserve oil.

title: U.S. Says Soviet Arms Flow To Mideast Is Continuing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The Defense Department reported today that the Soviet airlift of war material to Egypt and Syria had paused for two days but had now resumed.

title: New York's Problem One
description: The same election that gave Controller Abraham Beame his landslide victory for Mayor also gave him his first major headache: rejection of the $3.5billion transportation bond issue and the resulting need for einergency action to save the 35cent fare on New York City's subways and buses.

title: New Jersey and Beyond
description: It is hazardous to read national trends into elections as varied and scattered as those held Tuesday, but some qualified assessments are in order. The Democratic Party is clearly recovering from protracted internecine warfare and the crushing defeat of its 1972 Presidential candidate; the old Roosevelt coalition has reappeared impressively in spots; Watergate has obviously hurt many Republican candidates. Lawandorder and racial troubles have somewhat diminished as effective campaign appeals.

title: Massachusetts Council Votes To Oust District Court Judge
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7 (AP)  The state's Executive Council voted today to remove Judge Jerome P. Troy from the bench of the Dorchester District Court.

title: Strike at News Ends
description: Striking members of the Newspaper Guild accepted a new contract offer from The Daily News yesterday and went back to work. Details, Page 24.

title: Soviet Union Displays What May Be a New ICBM
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7The Soviet Union today displayed what Western military specialists believe to be a new intercontinental ballistic missile  the first major new military hardware to be shown off in a Soviet parade since 1967.

title: ENCIRCLED TROOPS SEEN IN NO PERIL
description: ALONG THE SUEZ CANAL Nov. 7The encircled. Eiyptiar III Corps has possession of sev eral springs, wells, and water holes within its periineter axle is in no, immediate danger, of being forted to surrender through thirst, a senior Israeli officer asserted today.

title: N. B.C. Offers Marchi a Chance To Reply to Remarks by Stokes
description: The National Broadcasting Company invited State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday to reply to a commentator's electionnight remarks to which the Senator strongly objected.

title: Saigon Raids Red Areas
description: The South Vietnamese military command said yesterday that its planes had bombed two Communistheld areas north of Saigon in what it described as its largest air strike since the signing of the ceasefire agreement in January. Page 5.

title: I.R.S. Obtains List of Holders In HartfordI.T.T. Stock Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The Internal Revenue Service, which is reconsidering a controversial 1969 tax ruling that allowed the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to acquire the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, has taken a significant step in the case, according to sources close to the tax service.

title: Congress Overrides
description: The vote in both houses of Congress yesterday override President Nixon's veto of the war powers bill marks a turning point in the continuing struggle restore the American constitutional system of checks and balances.

title: LOUIS J. RICE
description: MANCHESTER, Conn., Nov. 7  Louis J. Rice, chairman of Hagedorn & Co., New York insurance brokers, died yesterday in a convalescent home here. He was 87 years old and lived at the Union League Club in New York.

title: GUILD VOTE ENDS STRIKE AT NEWS
description: Striking members of the Newspaper Guild voted yesterday to accept a new contract offer from The Daily News, and within an hour began streaming back to work.

title: ...but Mendenhall Is Doubtful for the Giants...
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 7 The New York Giants, who have had trouble starting and stopping anything in recent wceks, may have to face Calvin Hill and the Dallas Cowboys without their best defensive player, John Mendenhall, at Yale Bowl Sunday.

title: A CARPENTER BUILDS COFFIN FOR HIMSELF
description: WEST HAMLIN, W. Va. (AP)  When Albert Adkins leaves this world, he has made certain the trip will be made in style and comfort.

title: 200 Clash at Wisconsin U. Over I.T.T. Job Recruiter
description: MADISON, Wis., Nov. 7 Nearly 200 demonstrators clashed today with the police inside the Engineering Building on the University of Wisconsin campus here during a protest against the presence of a job recruiter for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Public Utilities Commission agreed yesterday to answer a series of questions from municipalities relating to the safety and operation of the ErieLackawanna Railroad's controversial Greenwood Lake branch. Railroad representatives also agreed to provide municipal autorities with advance notice of combustible freight cargo so that proper emergency measures could be taken.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP)A bitter 14week strike by 156 electricians that tied up the Chrysler Corporation's auto production in Britain ended today when the men accepted a pay deal worked out in 40 hours of secret talks.

title: House Again Postpones Action on Trade Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) At President Nixon's personal request, the House again is postponing action on a trade bill with sensitive provisions affecting the Soviet Union, Speaker of the House Carl Albert said today.

title: Housewife Rescues Child Of Neighbor but Her 3 Die
description: MANTI, Utah, Nov. 7 (UP)A housewife rushed into her burning home in time to carry a neighbor's child to safety yesterday, but she returned too late to savet he lives of her own three children.

title: GENERAL TIRE ASKED TO RETURN TO CHILE
description: Joseph W. Foss, president of General Tire International, an affiliate of the General The and Rubber Company, said yesterday that the company had been invited by the new Chilean Government to resume the general management functions at a joint venture tire plant in Chile.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Wood Field and Stream: On Hunting
description: It may be a mistake, as was done in Massachusetts and other states this year and years past, to make it legal to hunt Canada geese before the opening of the regular waterfowl season.

title: House Panel Backs TwoStep Social Security Rise Totaling 11% Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 The House Ways and Means Committee, enlarging considerably on a decision it made only yesterday, voted today to give the nation's 29 million Social Security recipients a 7 per cent increase next April, and 4 per cent more in July.

title: Screen:'Screaming Tiger' Runs True to Its Stripe
description: The "Screaming Tiger" that crashed into local theaters yesterday is proof that the Chinese movie makers are still doing their kung fu thing with bloody, stultifying regularity. Wang Yu, the only one identified in the meager credits of this latest exercise in puerile, perpetual motion, plays the clean-cut Chinese karate champ who has come to Japan to knock off droves of Sumo wrestlers and other grimacing types before dispatching the dastard who murdered his family.Oh yes, he's an acupuncture expert, too. And acupuncture seems to be the only regimen that could possibly help this "Screaming Tiger."

title: Kissinger Inspects Pyramids, but He Is the Whole Shou
description: CAIRO, Nov. 7 Cheered by children along the way, Secretary of State Kissinger took time out today from weighty affairs of war and peace for sightseeing at the pyramids of Giza, the Pharaonic wonders that already were old when Moses led the Israelites out of Egypt.

title: At This Salon, the Works Were Edible
description: On a landing at the New York Coliseum, an artist does an oil painting in 10 minutes that may hang for decades in some motel room.

title: Donor Says Stans Vowed A Favor or Money Back
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7A Miami homebuilder testified today that Maurice H. Stans, President Nixon's campaign finance chairman, agreed to try to help him with his problems with the Federal Housing Administration last year in return for a sizable campaign contribution.

title: MayorElect Confident
description: Mayor  elect Abraham D. Beame moved quickly yesterday to assume authority over the city that gave him a landslide victory at the polls on Tuesday.

title: Westchester's Democrats Gain Top Post First Time
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7 Alfred B. Del Bello, the 39yearold reformist Mayor of Yonkers, emerged today after a night of uncertainty as the first Democratic County Executive in Westchester County's history.

title: Contractor Filed No Plans On Garage That Collapsed
description: A contractor who performed $80,000 in alterations on threestory garage that collapsed in September consulted neither architects nor engineers, filed no plans and secured no building permit.

title: DR. DUNCAN REID, 67, TAUGHT OBSTETRICS
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7Dr. Duncan E. Reid, professor emeritus of obstetrics and of gynecology at Harvard University and former chief of staff of Boston Lyingin Hospital, died today in Tucson, where he was teaching at the University of Arizona. He was 67 years old.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The biggest change in fashion for spring is the development of room at the top, Kasper told his audience at the opening of his new collection for Joan Leslie yesterday morning. He was talking about the fluttery jackets, bloused bodices and roomy armholes that make poor looking and skinny clothes look uptight. The idea, of course, was to direct attention away from hemlines and it works. Nobody talks about hemlines very much. It's in poor taste, rather like eating peas with your spoon.

title: Soviet Dissident Backs Better U.S. Ties
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7  Roy A. Medvedev, a prominent dissident and unofficial historian of the Stalinist purges, urged the West today to proceed with relaxation of tensions and warned that Congressional restrictions on SovietAmerican trade could have a negative effect on prospects for emigration from the Soviet Union.

title: OpenAdmission Police College Survives Lively Identity Crisis
description: One day in a class on constitutional law at John Jay College of Criminal Justice the discussion got around to the rights of demonstrators and the right of the police to control them.

title: KERR SUBPOENAED TO RENT HEARING
description: The city's top housing official was subpoenaed by a state commission yesterday after he did Tat appear as a witness at a commission hearing on apartmentrent rises. But the official later derided the subpoena as funny because, he said, he has long been prepared to testify before the commission next Monday, when the subpoena orders him to.

title: LastPlace Finish Spoils Return of Kathy Kusner
description: Kathy Kusner, the American Olympic showring riding star turned jockey, returned to Aqueduct yesterday for the first time in two years. She is the attractive brunette who in 1968 became the first woman licensed to ride at recognized thoroughbred tracks. But her reappearance at the Big A was a disappointing one. Riding Mrs. William G. Christmas's Lady Galaxy, the 30to1 outsider in the sevenfurlong fourth race, she came home last. The 7yearold mare showed some early foot but then lost interest.

title: Connecticut Track Loses
description: SOUTHINGTON, Conn., Nov. 7 (UPI)  A proposal to build Connecticut's first horseracing track was defeated yesterday, 5,815 to 4,132. The $15million) project, which had been rejected earlier by the town planning commission, would have provided harness and thorough bred racing.

title: Wings Name Delvecchio Coach After Loss to Flyers
description: Alex Delvecchio, the last superstarof Detroit when the Red Wings were dominating the old sixteam National Hockey League, was named coach of the club last night.

title: George Biddle, Artist, Is Dead; Muralist and Portraitist Was 88
description: George Biddle, the muralist and portrait painter who helped organize. Federal arts projects during the Depression, died Tuesday at his home in CretononHudson, N.Y. He was 88 years old.

title: Aiken Urges House: Impeach President Or Get Off His Back
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont, the influential dean of Congressional Republicans, declared today that the House of Representatives should either impeach. President Nixon or get off his back.

title: SCANDALS' EFFECT ON VOTE IS MINOR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 The Watergate scandals had little impact on turnout or results in yesterday's elections, according to official Republican and Democratic analyses here today.

title: Action by House Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Connecticut, urged the House Judiciary Committee today to act quickly on a police survivors benefits bill before becoming immersed in impeachment proceedings and the confirmation of the VicePresidential nominee, Gerald R. Ford. The bill calls fora $50,000 Federal payment to the family of any law enforcement officer or fireman killed in the line of duty.

title: SEOUL OPPOSITION BIDS CABINET QUIT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. The opposition party submitted to the National Assembly today a draft resolution urging the Cabinet to resign in acceptance of responsibility for the abduction of a prominent opposition politician in Tokyo in August.

title: A Scientist's Study of Firefly's Mating Habits Finds All's Fair in Insect's Wooing
description: In firefly mating, skulduggery, rather than fair play, seems to be the rule according to a study done in the highlands of New Guinea.

title: DETROIT MEASURES POLLUTION CONTROL
description: DETROIT, (AP)  Detroit's MURC Index has nothing to do with car production.

title: Orioles' Palmer Beats Ryan for Young Award
description: Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles joined Tom Seaver of the New York Mets in the winner's circle yesterday when he was chosen for the Cy Young Award as the American League's best pitcher of 1973.

title: GRUMMAN MAKES STRONG RECOVER
description: The Grumman Corporation reported yesterday a sharp recovery in its statement for the third quarter and first nine months reflecting increases of 83.2 per cent in sales and other income for the quarter and 53 per cent for the nine months. The leading supplier of military aircraft for the United States Navy incurred large deficits in 1972 and 1971 because of cost overruns on the F14 aircraft.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE OVERRIDE VETO BY NIXON ON CURB OF WAR POWERS; BACKERS OF BILL WIN 3YEAR FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The House and the Senate, dealing President Nixon what appeared to be the worst legislative setback of his five years in office, today overrode his veto of a measure aimed at limiting Presidential power to commit the armed forces to hostilities abroad without Congressional approval.

title: Little League in jersey Ordered To Allow Girls to Play on Teams
description: NEWARK, Nov. 7 Little League baseball in New Jersey was ordered today to permit girls to play on local teams throughout the state.

title: Connecticut Voting Gives 32 Towns to Democrats
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 7 The Republican party suffered setbacks in municipal elections throughout the state yesterday, losing 32 town governments to the Democrats and gaining only 10.

title: Purchases by City Indicate Cut In Cost of Thanksgiving Dinner
description: Thanksgiving meals for New Yorkers who will be municipal guests in city hospitals, jails or other facilities will be cheaper this yearand there's a hope for a similar break for the folks at home.

title: New Mayors, and Some Old Ones, to Run Big Cities
description: Like New York yesterday, Dayton, Louisville, Miami and Raleigh were among the larger cities whose voters elected new Mayors.

title: SIRICA REBUFFS SIX ON WATERGATE PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) Federal District Judge John J. Sirica rejected today a motion to overturn the convictions of six of the original Watergate conspirators and ordered them to appear in court Friday morning for final sentencing.

title: $500,000 Golf to Start Minus $850,000 of Talent
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 7 This peaceful little village set among holly and pine trees with 385 private homes and a population of 1,500 is to be the setting for tomorrow's start of the controversial new $500,000 World. open golf tournament.

title: MARY C. HOWELL
description: Mary Catherine Howell, associate editor of Interior Design magazine for the last eight years and formerly a columinst for Women's Wear Daily, died of a stroke in St. Vincent's Hospital on Tuesday. She was in her fifties and lived at 41 Fifth Avenue.

title: School Attendance Doubles
description: LOCHIEL, Ariz. (AP)EnrolIment is up 100 per cent in the Lochiel Elementary School. School officials reported six students attending the oneroom schoolhouse, up from three a year ago.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Frank Burns and Fred Gruningere were giyen permanent status yesterday, as football coach and athletic dirertor, respectively, at Rutgers. Both were hired last year. We are delighted with the outstanding performance of the football team [five victories, two defeats], said Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, university president. I have been deeply impressed with the managerial and organizational skills exhibited by Mr. Gruninger during a difficult period. Burns received a new threeyear eontract, and Gruninger was named a member of the faculty.

title: ,Hughes Was Authority on Juveniles During Earlier Career on the Bench
description: Richard J. Hughes, the newly nominated Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, is a lifelong resident of the Garden State who received his law degree from the Rutgers University School of Law.

title: DR. WOLFGANG RAMM
description: NEPTUNE, N.J., Nov. 7. Dr. Wolfgang Ramm, a nuclear physicist, died yesterday at Jersey Shore Medical Center here. His age was 65.

title: Following Thoreau's Urging, They Built the House Simply
description: BRANFORD, Conn.  I really believe Thoreauyou should build your own nest, insisted William R. Burch Jr.

title: Exxon CrudeOil Supply Cat 17% by Arab Moves
description: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest oil company, said yesterday that its total worldwide supplies of crude oil had dropped 17 per cent because of Arab moves to cut the flow of oil to the West.

title: SURVEY FINDS MOST BACK A NEWS SHIELD
description: An increasing majority of Americans believe a newspaper reporter should not be required to reveal confidential sources if he is taken to court to testify about information appearing in a news article.

title: RULES HELD LAX FOR MEAT PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The General Accounting Office reported today that faulty administration of the Wholesome Meat Act of 1967 had resulted in acceptable ratings for many meat plants that did not comply with Federal Sanitation and inspection standards.

title: McGee and Fong Ask Cut In Attorney General's Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, and Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii, will introduce a bill tomorrow that would cut the Attorney General's salary from $60,000 to $35,000 a year in a move to settle a constitutional complication arising from William B. Saxbe's nomination to the post, Mr. McGee's office said.

title: Raymond Fullerton Dies; Trained Columbia Teams
description: Raymond J. Fullerton; an athletic trainer at Columbia University, died, apparently of a heart attack, while at work Wednesday. He was 66 years old and lived at 2015 Cedar Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Japan to Slash Supplies of Oil To Industry in Crisis Program
description: TOKYO, Nov. 8 (UPI)Japan's Government said today it would slash oil supplies to big industries starting Dec. 1, and asked the Japanese to halt pleasure driving and put out pilot lights on stoves and water heaters.

title: Love Uses Limousine And Goes Extra Mile
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  The morning after President. Nixon urged Americans to conserve energy through personal sacrifice, the former Colorado Governor John A. Love, emerged from his southwest Washington townhouse and stepped briskly into a waiting White House limousine.

title: The Ivory Coast Breaking Diplomatic Ties With Israel
description: ABIDJAN, the Ivory Coast, Nov. 8 (Agence FrancePresse) The Ivory Coast broke diplomatic relations with Israel today, the national press agency announced here.

title: A BridetoBe, 19, Is Found Murdered Near Queens Holm
description: A 19yearold Queens girl who was to have been married next month was found stabbed to death yesterday afternoon it the high weeds of a vacant lot about a block from her home near the northeastern edge of Kennedy International Airport.

title: CONGRESS WORKS ON ENERGY CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8With some of its corridor lights dimmed to save electricity, Congress began work today to give President Nixon manybut probably not all  of the emergency powers he has sought to deal with the energy crisis.

title: Bausch & Lomb Receives Amended Patent Complaint
description: Bausch & Lomb announced yesterday in Rochester that it had been served with an amended complaint started against it a year ago by the National Patent Development Corporation in New York State Supreme Court.

title: Boston Wins in 3d, 21
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)Dave Forbes's goal at 13 minutes 18 seconds of the final period tonight carried the Boston Bruins to a 21 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Overnight Shift in Mood
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 8The news of a peace proposal worked out by Secretary of State Kissinger brought a dramatic overnight change in the mood of Israel's leaders.

title: Attica Defense Asking If Phones Are Tapped
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 8The Attica Brothers Legal Defense filed affidavits in State Supreme Court today asking if state investigators have been tapping the telephone lines at defense headquarters here.

title: Vietcong Claim Border Victory And Say Saigon Killed Civilians
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 (AP)The Vietcong asserted today that their forces had decisively defeated Government troops along the Cambodian border over the weekend, and also accused the Saigon Government of inflicting more than 100 civilian casualties during an air strike.

title: Notes on People
description: The White Honse announced yesterday that President Nicolai Ceausescu. of Rumania would begin an official vist to this country Dec. 4, at President Nixon's invitation.

title: About New York
description: This is a true story, something like a love story. It is about a man from Queens who drives a truck and delivers pies. His great hobby was the breeding of dogs, and he had begun with Weimaraners, and then gone on to other breeds, and at times he would own as many as 30 dogs in all shapes and sizes.

title: Dr. Edwin MacDowell Dies; Medical Researcher Was 86
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Nov. 8  Dr. Edwin Carleton MacDowell, former resident investigator of the station here for experimental' evolution, genetics department, Carnegie Institution of Washington, died yesterday in the Huntington Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived here.

title: Institutions Being Struck
description: Fortyeight voluntary, nonprofit hospitals and homes for the aged are affected by the strike by Local 1199. In the following list of affected institutions there are fewer than 48 because some have more than one branch or facility:

title: Kissinger Pledge Reported
description: CAIRO, Nov. 8Egypt today waited for the first sighs that Israeli forces were beginning to lift their siege of the city of Suez as part of a package deal reportedly worked out yesterday by President Anwar el1Sadat and Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Residents Patrol at Night At Stony Brook Dormitory
description: STONY BROOK L. I., Nov. 8 More than 15 residents of Eugene O'Neill College, a dormitory at the State University Center here, have volunteered to stand night watch and check the identification of all those wishing to enter the dormitory.

title: Stage: New Papp Home
description: Joseph Papp, William Shakespeare and their Festival arrived, officially, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater last night, to take their place as the resident theater company of Lincoln Center. The policy of the theater has changed slightlywhereas in the past it was a classic theater company, with modern plays being produced in the Forum Theater, that small auditorium underneath the main stage, now the main theater is to be largely, a platform for modern playwrights, while the small theater (now known as the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater) will be a new home for Shakespeare.

title: Amex Stocks Show the Largest Gain in 21 Sessions
description: Posting their largest gain in 21 sessions, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose sharply yesterday in increased trading. Prices in the overthecounter market also advanced.

title: LABOR DRIVE IS ON FOR IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations began a formal nationwide campaign today to demand the immediate impeachment of President Nixon.

title: A.E.C. Seeks to Speed Nuclear Facility Building
description: Since June, the Atomic Energy Commission has had a special task force studying how to cut four years from the more than nine it now takes to build and license nuclear power plants nuclear power plant construction, after carrying out the environmental review required under the 1971 United States Appeals Court decision in the Calvert Cliffs case. That decision, which the A.E.C. did not tappeal, halted all operating liIcenses for 17 months.

title: Nine Entered in Laurel's International
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 8The draw for the Washington D. C. International took place today. Nine names were called out by Frank Gabriel, the racing secretary of the Laurel Race Course, and everything became set for the 22d running of the famous turf event on Saturday.

title: Latest Giant Blow: Mendenhall Is Out
description: The other shoe dropped on the New York Giants yesterday: Xrays showed that their best defensive player, John Mendenhall, has been suffering from a torn cartilage in the left knee and he will be lost for the rest of the season.

title: Jersey Cuts Speed
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8In what is believed to be the first statewide response of its kind to President Nixon's appeal for fuelsaving efforts, New Jersey's major highspeed tollways reduced their speed limits today to 50 miles an hour.

title: Stars Inflict 8th in Row On Nets
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 8 The New York Nets, in an effort to determine why they had lost seven straight American Basketball Association games, planned a meeting before tonight's game against the Utah Stars. But the rap session was postponed because the players were tired after an eighthourh trip from Norfolk, Va.

title: CHARLES H. BITNER
description: OLD LYME, Conn., Nov. 8Dr. Charles H. Bitner, a retired Navy captain who was a founder of a leper hospital in Puerto Rico, died yesterday in the Naval Submarine Medical Center in Groton. He was 73 years old and lived here.

title: Business Briefs
description: Du Pont to Cut Shipments of Dacron

title: Champion to Acquire A W. (Securities)
description: Champion International, formerly known at U. S. PlywoodChampion Papers, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire A. W. (Securities), Ltd. a British carpet manufacturers.

title: Miss Woods Says Tapes Contain Inaudible Parts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8President Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, said today that some of the tape recordings of White House conversations were of such poor quality that the President and his visitors were inaudible or drowned out by extraneous noises.

title: Text of the Modified Draft of a U.S.Common Market Statement
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 8 Following, in the original Englishlanguage version, is the text of a draft for an Atlantic declaration to be made by the European Economic Community and the United States.
