It was proposed by the Americans Sept. 29 on the basis of an Economic Community deaft that was presented Sept. 20 and published in The New York Times Sept. 24. United States emendations to the Eurepean version appear in italics; deletions lire. In brackets.

title: LOVE IS DOUBTFUL ON GAS RATIONING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 John A. Love, director of they Energy Policy Office, told the Senate Interior Committee today that he had strong reservations about gasoline rationing because of the costs of administering such a program to conserve fuel.

title: It's Costly to Be Women Golf Pro
description: If you want to become a woman golf professional, you kave to have a sound game, $5,000 in the bank and be ready to spend $200 to $500 per week for travel, caddie fees and for your hairdos, advised Marilyn Smith yesterday.

title: Del Bello to Reorganize Westchester Bus Links
description: YONKERS, Nov. 8  Westchester's newly elected County Executive, Mayor Alfred B. Del Bello of Yonkers, said today that his first priority on taking office would be a major reorganization of the county's bus service under a strengthened Department of Transportation.

title: 6th Fleet Still on Alert in Mediterraneanl
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. JOHN F. KENNEDY, in the Eastern Mediterranean, Nov. 8  The reinforced United States Sixth Fleet, faced by a formidable Soviet force in the Mediterra. nean, is still at the same degree of alert as it was at the height of the Middle East crisis.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE GOES ON AS UNION DEFIES U. S COURT
description: Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union announced late yesterday that it would continue its strike against 48 hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area, despite $500,000 court fine and the judge's promise of further daily fines if the walkout continued.

title: Threshold of Peace?
description: Israel's Defense Minister Moshe Dayan, a man not given to premature euphoria, is saying that Egypt and Israel are at the threshold of a true peace settlement. In Cairo an official Government spokesman said yesterday, We may soon go to a peace conference, perhaps after a few days.

title: BUSINESS LOANS ROSE FOR WEEK
description: Business loans at New York City banks increased $272million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed is its preliminary report for the period.

title: Justice Inches On For Attica lnmates 2 Years After Riot
description: BUFFALOAlmost two years after a grand jury began looking into the Attica prison uprising, 60 men who were inmates during the insurrection are awaiting 40 trials involving 1,300 charges.

title: INDUSTRY ACTING ON ENERGY CRISIS
description: Utilities, chain stores, insurance companies, CocaCola and a good cross section of American industry took steps yesterday to cut back on their use of energy. However, leaders of the petroleum and coal industries cautioned that there were no quick solutions to energy shortages and several top executives of the chemicals industry said the President had acted too late and not strongly enough in planning action on the energy crisis.

title: Indian Cabinet Reshuffled To Solve State Problems
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 8Prime Minister Indira Gandhi shuffled her Cabinet today in an effort to solve leadership problems in the states.

title: Hospital Tragedy
description: The decision of the striking hospital union to continue its lethal assault on the safety of patients in the face of official declaration of a health emergency and a stern new judicial backtowork order is an act of scandalous irresponsibility.

title: Dance: Balanchine Fillip
description: A rather unusual range of works by an even more unusual range of choreographers marked the second program of the National Ballet of Washington on Wednesday night at the City Center.

title: Economic Adviser Backs Wage Rise Deceleration
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Government will have to maintain some degree of restraint on the expansion of the economy to achieve a needed deceleration of the present rate of wage increases, a member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said tonight.

title: 15 INDICTED HERE IN BOND FORGERY
description: $500,000 in Government Securities Involved Federal and state prosecutors yesterday announced indictments against 15 persons believed to be an organizedcrime clearing house responsible for the handling of $500,000 in stolen and forged government bonds.

title: Borg Upsets Nastase at Swedish Net
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 8 (Reuters)Bjorn Borg of Sweden upset Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 62, 46, 75, in the third round of the Swedish Grand Prix indoor tennis tournament tonight.

title: Books of The Times
description: D. H. LAWRENCE: NOVELIST, POET, PROPHET. Edited by Stephen Spender. 250 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: 3 Escapees Still at Large
description: BEACON, N. Y., Nov. 8 (UPI)  Three of four escapees from Matteawan State Hospital were still at large today, the state police said. The four escaped last night by cutting through a window bar in the main building. One man, identified as John Szwalla, was recaptured. The three others were identified as James Griffin, 30 years old, convicted of armed robbery; Jose Burgas, 29, convicted of murder, and Carlos Jumines, 28, convicted of firstdegree manslaughter.

title: U.S. MAY SUSPEND REBOZO BANK AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The staff of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has decided to recommend the suspension of Franklin S. DeBoer, a vice president of the Key Biscayne Bank and Trust Company, which is headed by President Nixon's close friend Charles G. Rebozo, according to sources close to an investigation of the bank.

title: Justice Inches On For Atticalnmates 2 Years After Riot
description: BUFFALOAlmost two years after a grand jury began looking into the Attica prison uprising, 60 men who were inmates during the insurrection are awaiting 40 trials involving 1,300 charges.

title: Rest Lures Pincay More Than $4Million Record
description: Just when it seemed Laffit Pincay Jr., the muscular Panamanian, was a shooin to become the first rider to earn $4million with his mounts, in a single year, along came the Latin star at Aqueduct yesterday to cast doubt about such a possibility.

title: Bridge: Luck as Well as Skill Needed For Appreciating a Double
description: A beginner learns that there are two kinds of doubles, takeout and penalty, and with luck he can distinguish between them. But for the experienced player the double covers a wide range with some delicate shades of meaning.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: A's Series Harvest: $24,760 Apiece

title: Court Says BaseRent Plan Must Go On
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the city had to continue the program permitting rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many rentcontrolled apartments.

title: COAST MAN GUILTY IN EIGHT MURDERS
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Nov. 8 A jury of six men and six women today convicted Edmund Emil Kemper 3d, 24 years old, of Murdering eight women, including his mother, her best friend and six student hitchhikers here.

title: S.E.C. to Lift Suspension Of Trading in Teleprompter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today, that it would lift at midnight, Nov. 11, the trading ban in the stock of the Teleprompter Corporation of New York.

title: U.S. RULES URGED FOR BLOOD SUPPLY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8The American Public Health Association is asking Congress to create a nationally coordinated blood service system that would include Federal licensing of blood banks, all volunteer donors and better methods of preserving and decontaminating blood.

title: Varied Audience Hears Simon Assail Rail Bill
description: Cary Grant, Jennifer Jones, a representative of the Department of Transportation, some of Wall Street's most expert securities analysts and hundreds of others flocked to the, WaldorfAstoria yesterdayto hear Norton Simon try to stir up a public protest about the crisis of the nation's railroads.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: The Poor of Venice, Calif., Struggle to Save Their Beachside Slum
description: VENICE, Calif., Nov. 8By now the sun has disappeared on the horizon over the Pacific Ocean, but they are still out here on the beach, fixed on the green wooden benches where they watch as darkness blots out the thin orange glaze left on the evening sky. Old women huddle in shawls and worn woolen coats. Teenagers drink from bottles wrapped in brown paper bags. Some of the younger women are with their men. Others have their children.

title: Energy Volunteerism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8President Nixon told the Amerlean people last night that the key to the success of his energy conservation proposals lay not just here in Washington, but in every home in every community across this country. Indeed, as far as energy conservation by the public was concerned Mr. Nixon seemed to be relying heavily on volunteerism, not government compulsion, to get the country through this winter's deepening oil shortage. For the longer haul, Mr. Nixon renewed pleas to Congress to create an energy research agency, to end Federal regula tion of natural gas prices at the wellhead and to regulate strip mining of coal. He also reiterated his desire to speed the lengthy process of building and licensing nuclear power plants, which officials say privately is easier said than done.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1973

title: EUGENE VAN CLEEF
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8 (AP)  Eugene Van Cleef, an urbanologist and meteorologist, died yesterday after a heart attack here. He was 86 years old.

title: 17 on Trial in Greece in Attacks on Police
description: Outside the heavily guarded downtown Athens building hundreds of students who were denied access to court staged a loud demonstration. They were soon dispersed by strong police forces.

title: House Leaders Plan Vote On Ford's Post by Dec. 6
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) The House will vote on confirmation of Representative Gerald R. Ford as Vice President the week of Dec. 3, the Democratic leadership announced today.

title: Newspaper Access Ordered in Suffolk For Inmates of Jail
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn has ordered Suffolk County jail authorities to grant prisoners free access to newspapers despite the county's assertion that it would have disruptive effects upon the inmates.

title: Chiang Ching Adds Western Touches To Chinese Dance
description: Chiang Ching does eccentric leaps that would please Martha Graham and classical grands battements that would delight George Balanchine. She also does traditional Chinese dances that would please anyone, and she combined them all in An Evening of Chinese Dance Wednesday at Town Hall.

title: People and Business
description: Bess Myerson, who has been both a New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs and a Miss America, has been named a consumeraffairs adviser for the First National City Bank.

title: Tahoe for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
After 8 Years, Columbia Expects Balance Budget
description: Colombia University will balance its budget for the first time in eight years next year, ?? president, Dr. William J. McGill, disclosed yesterday.

title: HEPATITIS OUTBREAK LINKED TO OYSTERS
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)A hepatitis outbreak spread by an infected shipment of Louisiana oysters has hit 100 persons, and health officials said yesterday that the liver disease may infect as many as 1,000.

title: Common Market Urges Action Against Multinationals' Abuses
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 8  The Commission of the European Economic Community, in a longawaited report on multinational companies in Europe, urges the nine member countries today to take joint action against various abuses such as tax evasion, monetary speculation and disregard for workers' rights.

title: Alabama and Notre Dame Seem Sugar BowlBound
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8 (AP)The expected pairings today are secondranked Alabama and fifthranked Notre Dame in the Sugar Bowl and Louisiana State (No. 7) against Penn State (No. 6) in the Orange Bowl.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 8While Rutgers has taken its longest trip in 105 years of collegiate football visiting the Air Force Academy, Jersey City State, the only undefeated team in New Jersey, will take a short trip to Upper Montclair to meet the Indians and Upsala will stay home and play host to Fordham.

title: Rally of Stocks Is Paced By EnergyRelated Issues
description: Railroads, oils and other energyrelated issues moved into the Wall Street limelight yesterday to lead a strong market rally accompanied by the heaviest trading in four weeks. Volume rose to 19.65 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, exceeding Wednesday's turnover by more than 3 million shares, amid a pickup in largeblock acitivity.

title: WILLIAM HUSTED, 58, INDUSTRIALIST, DIES
description: William H. Husted, a financier, industrialist and founder of corporations, died Saturday of a pulmonary embolism in Doctors Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 235 East 46th Street.

title: Whitlam Sees Area Role for Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 8  Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, just back from Japan and China, today outlined a possible role for Australia as an honest broker among the powers interested in the region, including Peking.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A special threemember impasse panel with powers to dictate the terms of a new contract met for a second day of testimony by the Uniformed Firefighters Association yesterday. The factfinding proceeding at the Office of Collective Bargaining, 250 Broadway, was agreed upon as the 10,900member union ended a strike that left the city withthout fire protection for five and a half hours last Tuesday.

title: U. S. PANEL BALKS AT HOSPITAL RAISI
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Cost of Living Council official said today that they would not be pressured by the New York hospital workers strike int?? granting a wage settlement sub?? stantially greater than raise in other areas of the economy.

title: Dartmouth Coach Gives Columbia Edge
description: How important is the psychological edge in a football game? Jake Crouthamel of Dartmouth feels Columbia will have a decided edge in Baker Field tomorrow because of the resignation of Frank Navarro as head coach. We had not counted on that. We did count on the fact that they would be playing at home and that they will be a hungry team, the Dartmouth coach said. Navarro, whose Lions have won only one game this season, said, I don't really know what effect my resignation will have. I haven't felt too much of a difference in practice this weeks.

title: Curbs Put on Heat
description: At least 29 states reported yesterday that they had cut speeds of stateowned vehicles or reduced temperatures in stateowned buildings to save fuel. Seven said they had acted earlier, but the others responded to President Nixon's appeal Wednesday night for them to set good examples.

title: HOUSE APPROVES RAILROADAID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  A bipartisan bill to head off the threatened collapse of rail service by restructuring railroads in the Northeast was approved by the House of Representatives today, 306 to 82. The legislation now goes to the Senate.

title: ASSAILS SUPERIORS ISRAELI GENERAL
description: ROME, Nov. 8The general who led Israeli forces across the Suez Canal says he believes that his superiors were too slow to reinforce and exploit his breakthrough, losing the chance to achieve a decisive victory over Egypt.

title: Murry Bergtraum, 56, President Of School Board in '70'71, Dies.
description: Murry Bergtraum, a member of the city Board of Education since 1969 and its president in 197071, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital, where he had been confind after a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived at 14420 68th Street in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.

title: U.S. IS MEDIATOR
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Friday, Nov. 9Israel and Egypt have agreed on new arrangements under the ceasefire that are expected to take effect within the next few days, opening the way to fullscale peace negotiations by the end of the year, aides to Secretary of State Kissinger said early today.

title: ISRAELI GENERAL ASSAILS SUPERIORS
description: ROME, Nov. 8The general who led Israeli forces across the Suez Canal says he believes that his superiors were too slow to reinforce and exploit his breakthrough, losing the chance to achieve a decisive victory over Egypt.

title: A Bicyclist, 13, Is Killed By a Train in Oceanside
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Nov. 8 (UPI)  A 13yearold bicyclist was killed by a Long Island Rail Road train today at the Wydner Avenue crossing here.

title: Screen: 'Robin Hood':Animals and Birds Star in Disney Version The Program
description: Once upon a time in Sherwood Forest there lived a fox named Robin Hood who, with his good friend, a sportive brown bear named Little John, stole from the rich to give to the poor.Nearby Nottingham was occupied by elephants, rhinos, hippos and snakes, who were the escorts, advisers and chums of the evil Prince John, a scrawny lion whose crown was too big and who, in moments of national crisis, sucked his thumb and pulled his ear lobe. Nottingham Castle was run by incompetents. Guard duty was left largely to a dim-witted vulture who liked to yell "one o'clock and all's well" when it was often three o'clock and everything was terrible.An all-animal/bird version of Robin Hood? Good grief! But then, why not?The legend about the bandit of Sherwood Forest has survived more than a dozen screen adaptations, including "Son of Robin Hood" (1959), which was really about a daughter, and 165 half-hour television films.Walt Disney's multigenus, animated film version, which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, testifies to the legend's elasticity and durability. It should also be a good deal of fun for toddlers whose minds have not yet shriveled into orthodoxy.The visual style is charmingly conventional, as gently reassuring as that of a Donald Duck cartoon, sometimes as romantically pretty as an old Silly Symphony. Roger Miller, the composer ("King of the Road") and humorist, provides the voice for Allan a Dale, the rooster who acts as the film's narrator, thus giving this "Robin Hood" a decidedly odd but not unpleasant country-and-Western flavor.The other voices are supplied by Peter Ustinov (Prince John), Terry-Thomas (Sir Hiss), Andy Devine (Friar Tuck), Phil Harris (Little John), Brian Bedford (Robin Hood) and Pat Buttram (the Sheriff of Nottingham), whose voice, like Ustinov's, is a very funny mixture of villainy and absolute fraud.On the stage the Music Hall is presenting its annual Christmas show, including "The Nativity." It's not only that time flies, but also that the Music Hall helps rush it along.

title: E.P.A. Lists 63 CleanAir Act Violations By Pittsburgh Mill, U.S. Steel's Largest
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8The regional office of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency cited today the world's largest privately owned steel mills, the Clairton Works of the United States Steel corporation outside Pittsburgh, for what it termed 63 violations of air pollution standards.

title: CHEERLEADER RAPED AND BEATEN IN BRONX
description: A 16yearold cheerleader at Evander Childs High School in the North Bronx told the police last night that she had been abducted by four youths in a car, blindfolded and raped repeatedly by several men at two locations in the South Bronx before she escaped.

title: REFINERY IS PLANNED ON THE PERSIAN GULF
description: Construction of a joint refinery on the Persian Gulf in Iran has been proposed in a memorandum of understanding signed by the National Iranian Oil Company and five American companies.

title: Pioneer 10 Spacecraft Is Nearing Jupiter
description: The unmanned spacecraft Pioneer 10 has penetrated within the orbits of the satellites of Jupiter and will soon face two showdown encounters, first with dust that may encircle the giant planet, then with the Jovian radiation belt.

title: City Hall Pensive as Lindsay Era Wanes
description: The, Mayor's office is going through more than eight years of documents, speeches and correspondence with an eye toward compiling The Lindsay Papers and giving them to Yale University's Sterling Memorial Library.

title: College, School Results
description: SOCCER

title: N.B.C. Chief Assails Buchanan Talk on Splitting Up Networks as Dangerous
description: Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, yesterday labeled as dangerous thinking the recept statements by Patrick J. Buchanan, a Presidential assis tant, that the television networks have too much power and should be decentralized or broken up.

title: Nixon Aides Hold a Grand Old Party
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8In what may have been one of the bolder events of the Washington fall social whirl, a group of former workers for the Committee to Reelect the President got together last night to drink, dance and reminisce about the good old days before Watergate:

title: Ban on Construction Ordered in Camden
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8The State Department of Environmental Protection today ordered a virtual areawide ban on new construction throughout populous Camden County because of overloaded and inadequate sewagetreatment facilities.

title: Chinatown Dining: Whole Community Deserves
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: ALEXANDER KRUGER, LED CITY HOSPITALS
description: Dr. Alexander W. Kruger, general superintendent of New York City hospitals from 1948 to 1951, died Wednesday. He was 76 years old and lived at 150 West End Avenue.

title: TV: Sunshine on C.B.S. Studies Dying Woman
description: For the Columbia Broadcasting System, Sunshine a film drama being presented at 8:30 this evening, is special enough to merit two and a half hours of prime time. For Universal Television, the producing studio it's one of the very special, prestige productions of 1973. For the television audience, it is certainly one of the more interesting programs of the season.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 191.9 from 190.5 last week.

title: Widing's Goal Decides
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (UPI)Whitey Widing Capped a superb conibination passing play tonight with a goal that gave the Los Angeies Kings a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers, the leaders of the West Division of the National Hockey League. The goal came with 2 minutes 30 seconds to play.

title: Stock Market Rallies
description: The stock market rallied briskly yesterday in active trading as the DowJones industrials gained 12.57 points. The rally was touched off by President Nixon's talk on energy and the lessening of Mideast tensions. Details, Page 57.

title: Congress Recess Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) Thirteen House Republicans sought today to open a drive to cancel the 10day Thanksgiving recess so Congress could continue work on pressing legislative issues. Representative Louis Frey Jr., a Florida Republican, said a 10day break is completely out of order at this time, when the nation is facing serious and pressing issues.

title: President's Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8People have come and gone, says Murray Chotiner, and Rose Woods remains and goes on forever. Mr. Chotiner, an old associate of President Nixon, was alluding to the shifting tides that have swept the Nixon staff in the past months. H.R. Haldeman, John. D. Ehrlichman and a number of others are gone, but Rose Mary Woods is still there with the Bossas she calls Mr. Nixonjust as she has been for 22 years.

title: Kissinger Pledge Reported
description: CAIRO, Nov. 8Egypt, today waited for the first signs that Israeli forces were beginning to lift their siege of the city of Suez as part of a package deal reportedly worked out yesterday by President Anwar elSadat and Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Miss Woods Says Tapes Contain Inaudible Parts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8President Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, said today that some of the tape recordings of White House conversations were of such poor quality that the President and his visitors were inaudible or drowned out by extraneous noises.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1billion, up 10 per cent from last year's $919million. Total retail store sales were about $10.2billion, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $9,2billion.

title: Celtics Top Knicks At Garden, 9484
description: Madison Square Garden, which used to be a sort of Garden of Eden for the Knicks, seems now to have turned into a torture chamber. Reverting to the befuddled play that has marked their home performances early in the National Basketball Association season, the Knicks stumbled again last night in a 9484 setback at the hands of the Boston Celtics before the standard cacrowd of 19,694.

title: Schlesinger Asserts Allies Endorsed Alert
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (Reuters)Secretary of Defense James B. Schlesinger said tonight that America's NATO allies had fully endorsed the United States military alert on Oct. 25 in response to reported Soviet threats in the Middle East. Mr. Schlisinger, who returned tonight from a twoday meeting in the Hague with defense ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said that his counterparts understood the necessity for action without prior consultation in an emergency.

title: JAPANESE REBUFF ARAB'S PRESSURE
description: TOKYO, Nov. 8A senior Japanese official said today that Arab nations had tried to persuade Japan to break diplomatic relations with Israel, impose an official embargo on trade with Israel and extend military aid to the Arabs in return for a stable oil supply. The overtures were rejected, he added, but he and other officials have indicated that Japan was trying to lean to the Arab side.

title: Omens Are Muffled
description: WASHINGTONProbably nothing happened on Election Day, 1973, that was half as important politically as what happened the day after. That was when the House of Representatives, with four votes to spare, overrode Richard Nixon's veto of the war powers bill.

title: Hundreds Are Donning Volunteers' Smocks in Hospital Strike Here
description: Mrs. Edith McLernon has visited her husband regularly at St. Johns Episcopal Hospital in Elmhurst, Queens, since he became a patient there last Oct. 20. But since Monday, when 250 members of the hospital's staff of 700 went on strike, she has had less time to sit at his bedside. Pitching in to help care for him and other patients, she has handed out meal trays, cut up meat, made beds, given bed baths and dusted floors.

title: Tree Will Be Dimmer In Rockefeller Center
description: Rockefeller Center's 65foot Christmas tree will be a little less bright this year. Officials of the office complex said yesterday that the tree would be decorated with about 25 per cent fewer lights than in past years and would be turned off several hours earlier each night. The exact schedule has not yet been determined.

title: Hughes Appointment
description: The nomination by Gov. William T. Cahill, a Republican, of Richard J. Hughes, a Democrat, to be Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court is altogether admirable. It returns to public service not only an exceptionally able former Governor, but a jurist of broad experience, well qualified for the powerful position from which Chief Justices Arthur T. Vanderbilt and Joseph Weintraub won national acclaim.

title: Mrs. King Criticizes Nixon
description: ATLANTA, Nov, 8 (UPI)Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that the nation distrust the Nixon Admiistration, but she stopped short of calling for the President's resignation.

title: Missing Link of I80 Opened In Ceremony Near Columbia
description: COLUMBIA, Nov. 8 (AP)The fourmile missing link of Interstate Route 90 was opened today, completing the New Jersey section of the artery that will eventually cross the country.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Bass Master
description: Late last month, Rayo Breckenridge, a Paragould, Ark., cotton farmer, won $15,000 for catching more than 52 pounds of largemouth bass in the threeday Miller High Life Bass Masters Classic at Clark Hill Reservoir in Montgomery, Ala.

title: It's Costly to Be Woman Golf Pro
description: If you want to become a woman golf professional you have to have a sound game, $5,000 in the bank and be ready to spend $200 to $500 per week for travel, caddie fees and for your hairdos, advised Marilyn Smith yesterday.

title: Polish Aide to Visit Pope
description: ROME, Nov. 8 (UPI)Foreign Minister Stefan Olszowski of Poland arrived here today for a meeting with Pope Paul VI and three days of talks with Italian Government officials. The meeting with the Pope will be the first by a Polish Foreign Minister.

title: ACCOUNTING BOARD STUDYING MERGERS
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board announced yesterday that it had decided to consider how to account for business mergers.

title: The Last Question
description: OAKLAND, Calif. The apartment we had shared was right on Tu Do Street, so I had to walk past it several times a day. Sometimes, I would find myself sitting there in the coffee shop across the street, just staring up at the two big windows as if waiting for a familiar face to pop out of memory (dreams, and nightmares) and say, Hey, man, come on up and let's get stoned.

title: Biaggi Is Reported Being Investigated By Nadjari and U.S.
description: Law enforcement sources disclosed yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx has been the focus of investigations by the offices of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, and the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Paul J. Curran.

title: Soviet Believed Uninvolved In Kissinger Mideast Move
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8The Soviet Union gave no public indication today of having been directly involved or clsely consulted by Washington about a compromise apparently worked out by Secretary of State Kissin ger for stabilizing the ceasefire along the Suez Canal.

title: The Pop Life
description: Its finally becoming realized that we have something to say, commented Gladys Knight. Miss Knight, who leads her soul group, the Pips, into a threeweek season their first everat the WaldorfAstorias Empire Room this week, wasnt talking about her own group, but about black soul groups in general. Over the past four or five years, a lot of doors have opened for groups like ours, a lot of ears have suddenly become attuned. Now soul groups can appear more or less anywhere, she added.

title: Plans Made to Abolish All Stops on Highways
description: Commuters on heavily trayeled toll roads leading into big cities may no longer have to stop to pay tolls, as a result of a new system being developed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Electronics Magazine said yesterday.

title: Court Ends Antinoise Curfew On Jets at Morristown Airport
description: MORRISTOWN, Nov. 8  A Superior Court Judge today lifted a curfew imposed in 1970 on the landings and takeoffs of jet aircraft at Morristown Municipal Airport. He acted after a lengthy trial in which nearby residents complained of the aircraft noise.

title: Overnight Shift in Mood
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 8The news of a peace proposal worked out by Secretary of State Kissinger brought a dramatic overnight change in the mood of Israel's leaders.

title: Bridge Tolls Ordered Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)  Federal Highway Administrator Norbert F. Tiemann has ordered tolls on two Delaware River bridges cut from 60 to 50 cents, effective Jan. 1, His order gave the Delaware River Port Authority, operators of the Ben Franklin and Walt Whitman Bridges, 20 days to seek reconsideration of his ruling.

title: City's New First Lady Sees Herself as a Bit of a Prude
description: Mary Beame thinks there's too much permissiveness in society. She would like to do away with pornographic movies. She abhors the violence she sees on television. She thinks women are a major force in politics, but she'd never call herself an ardent supporter of the women's liberation movement.

title: U.S. Is Shutting Down Its Uganda Embassy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)The State Department announced today that the United States Embassy in Uganda was being closed and the last American there, Robert V. Keeley, was being returned home. He is the charg d'affaires.

title: EDGAR C. ROW
description: DETROIT, Nov. 8 (Canadian Press)Edgar C. Row, president of the Chrysler Corporation of Canada, Ltd., from 1951to 1956, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 77 years old.

title: Professional Football Statistics
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: Fund Chairman Resigns At Democratic Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, confirmed today that Joseph E. Cole of Cleveland would step aside as the party's finance chairman early next month. No replacement has been found.

title: Treasury Aide Cites Low Taxes on High Incomes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 A high Treasury Department official said today, without mentioning President Nixon by name, that the taxreform plan advocated by the Treasury would have forced the Nixons to pay about $80,000 in Federal income taxes in 1970 and 1971, instead of the total of about $1,700 that they reportedly paid for the two years.

title: Study Finds One in Five Women Checks to Detect Breast Cancer
description: American women are more concerned about breast cancer than about any other disease, yet fewer than one in five examines her breasts regularly, and only half have an annual breast examination performed by a physician, according to a special Gallup study released yesterday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Nov. 8 were:

title: Coast Bar Unit Sends Segretti Data to Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (AP)The California Bar sent records on the conviction of Donald H. Segretti, the political trickster, to the State Supreme Court today for possible disciplinary action.

title: Curbs Put on Heat
description: At least 29 states reported yesterday that they had cut speeds of stateowned vehicles or reduced temperatures in stateowned buildings to save fuel. Seven said they had acted earlier, but the others responded to President Nixon's appeal Wednesday night for them to set good examples.

title: Stock Market Rallies
description: The stock market rallied briskly yesterday in active trading as the DowJones industrials gained 12.57 points. The rally was touched off by President Nixon's talk on energy and the lessening of Mideast tensions. Details, Page 57.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Utility Plans 2 More Nuclear Units

title: Nonunion Site Vandalized By Construction Workers
description: About 300 construction workers stoned and vandalized a building being renovated on the northwest corner of 11th. Street and Broadway for more than an hour yesterday morning.

title: NearRecord Fund Issue Is Sold by Merrill Lynch
description: The secondlargest mutualfund sale in the history of the fund industry has just been completed, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., disclosed here yesterday.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on U.S. railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.6 billion tonmiles, 6.8 per cent above the corresponding week last year. This is a single week record, slightly higher than the total for the week ended Oct. 20. The A.A.R. also reports carloadings in the same week totaled 570,782 cars, 3.5 per cent above the same week a year ago. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported I intercity truck tonnage was 5.7 per cent above last year.

title: Boulez Ending Exile With Post in Paris
description: Pierre Boulez, who exiled himself from France 13 years ago in protest against what he felt was the mediocrity of musical life in his native country, will return to Paris in 1975 at the invitation of President Pompidou to direct a new institute for the study of contemporary music.

title: U.S. ROLE BAILED BY MANY AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8United States prestige has been enhanced by its success in getting Egypt and Israel to accept its peace proposal, delegates here commented today. They noted that the success came at a time when many diplomats and officials here feared that a renewal of hostilities was possible.

title: Cahill, Anticipating a Budget Surplus, Orders $150Million More to Schools
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8Governor Cahill said today he had ordered the State Education Commissioner to provide an additional $150million in state school aid under an existing formula that had never been fully implemented.

title: HUGO GEMIGNANI
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 8 (AP)Hugo Gemignani, former chief designer for the Hickey Freeman Company, makers of men's clothing here, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., at the age of 77.

title: Upstate Ski Area Opens Tomorrow
description: HUNTER, N. Y., Nov. 8Having benefited from a roundtheclock snowmaking operation for 24 hours, Hunter Mountain will be the first ski area to open in New York this season. The popular Greene County complex, just south of Albany, will be in business on Saturday, at least on a limited scale, for its earliest opening in its history.

title: Advertising: The Squeeze on Oil
description: Many of the suggestions for energy conservation made by President Nixon Wednesday night should have come as no surprise to fans of oil company advertising. They have been singing that song now individually and as an industry for well over a year.

title: Biaggi Is Reported Being Investigaged By Nadjari and U.S.
description: Law enforcement sources disclosed yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx has been the focus of investigations by the offices of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, and the United States Attorney for the Southern District of. New York, Paul J. Curran.

title: Energy Gap
description: Faced with oil shortages this winter that some experts believe could amount to as much as 21 per cent of normal consumption, President Nixon has finally acknowledged that the nation is headed into an energy gap that requires drastic Federal action.

title: PROFIT SOARS 274% FOR DUTCHSHELL
FASHION TALK
description: The musical accompaniment to the spring fashion shows on Seventh Avenue in the past two weeks concentrated on golden oldies such as Paper Moon and I've Got You Under My Skin with an occasional bit of soft or raucous rock. Too often the clothes reflected the period.

title: RESEARCH BACKED IN PSYCHOSURGERY
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 8  A panel of scientists agreed at meeting have today that, despite recent public furor, the treatment called psychosurgery should not be banned.

title: Farm Family, Held Prisoner for 33 Hours, Flees
description: WADENA, Minn., Nov. 8 (AP) A farm family held prisoner for more than 33 hours escaped today after the, two jail fugitives who held them captive fell asleep. Two hours later, the fugitives surrendered.

title: 3 on Transit Board Want Plan To Freeze Fares for 2 Years
description: The three city members the 11man Metropolitan Transportation Authority board yesterday assailed Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman the authority, and said that regional plan could be worked out to save transit and commuter rail fare levels for two years.

title: P.S.A.L. Disallows Football Protests
description: The Public Schools Athletic League football semifinals will go on as planned. Final appeals of rulings by the football commissioner were turned down yesterday by the Executive Committee of the High Schools Games Committee.

title: A Korean Journalist, Citing Fear, Won't Return to Seou
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) Julie Myung Ja Moon, South Korean journalist, said today that she would not return to Seoul because she win afraid of physical harm from the. Korean Central Intelligence Agency for reporting that Unit ed States officials were critical of the Government's role in the Kim Dae Jung kidnapping case.

title: KROGH ASKS COURT TO SUMMON NIXON
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov, 8 (AP) Egil Krogh Jr., a former. White House aide, contending that President Nixon has refused to cooperate with Mr. Krogh's attorneys, has asked a California court to subpoena the President for questioning concerning conversations about Daniel Ellsberg.

title: Damascus Reports Downing Israeli Jet On Southern Front
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 8 (Reuters)A military spokesman here said that Syrian antiaircraft defenses shot down Phantom jet today when an Israeli formation tried to violate Syrian airspace on a reconnaissance mission.

title: Conservation Groups React Cautiously To Nixon's Bid to Ease Pollution Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Environmental protection and conservation organizations reacted cautiously today to President Nixon's proposals to ease the national energy shortage by waiving temporarily some controls on air, water and land pollution.

title: Road to Impeachment
description: President Nixon has given this reply to the mounting calls for his resignation: I have no intention whatever of walking away from the job I was elected to do.

title: In a Hospital on Nile: Israeli War Stories
description: CAIRO, Nov. 8On Oct. 22, just before the ceasefire on the EgyptianIsraeli front, Lieut. Ran Rozen of the Israeli Air Force was ordered to fly his small observation plane from Sharm el Sheik, in the southern Sinai Peninsula, toward the. Suez Canal to report the location and movements of Egyptian forces.

title: Red Smith
description: When Robert Lee Steiner, aged 16, left home to make his way in the harsh world of rodeo, he wrote back to his father, Tommy: Dad, if you ever need me, get in touch. And if I need you, I'll do the same. Tommy Steiner is a prosperous stock contractor whose string includes some of the most redoubtable rogues that ever bucked a cowboy into the bleachers. He owns fat acres in the hill country west of Austin, Tex., where the dammedup Colorado River forms lakes with names like Travis, Lyndon B. Johnson and Marble Falls. He has a thriving Western store in Austin. Somehow Tommy managed to scrape along without the aid of his second son. And Bobby, earning $19 riding bulls in his first year on the road and $133 in his second, never called on the folks for help. He was that determined to make it on his own.

title: Messages To the President
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8This city is always looking for clues to the futureparticularly now clues to the future of the Presidentand in the last few days it has seen two events of considerable importance.

title: Jaworski Asserts He Got Pledges of Independence
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, in his first appearance before Congress today, told members of the House that he had taken the job only with what I consider the most solemn and substantial assurances of my absolute independence.

title: The Critics' Critic
description: WASHINGTONThe ambitiousness of Ben Bagdikian's attack upon the President's daily news summary [OpEd, Nov. 1] should not go unnoted. What other press critic in America possesses the singular effrontery to fob off on The New. York Times 900 words of critique and analysis about a publication he has never seen nor read?

title: Agriculture Department Sued By City Group on Impoundment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  A New York City nutrition group asked a Federal judge today to hold the Department of Agriculture in contempt of court for not starting a $40million program to feed impoverished pregnant women and young children.

title: Skylab Repair Work Is Going Smoothly
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 8Workmen jacked the Saturn 1B ever so slightly off the launching pad today and began replacing the rocket's damaged tail fins, an operation aimed at getting the Skylab 3 mission under way with a minimum of a fiveday delay.

title: Chilean Police Release Wife Of an Expelled Journalist
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8 (Reuters)  Mrs. Margareta Sourander, the wife of an expelled Swedish journalist, was released here last night after being held my the Chilean police for more than 24 hours.

title: Gilbert's 62 Leads World Open
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 8 (AP)Libby Gilbert, who almost quit the pro golf tour in disgust earlier this season, matched the best score of the year with a nineunderpar 62 today for the firstround lead in the $500,000 World Open.

title: White House Making Copies of the Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)  Conceding concern over the fragility of the secret Watergate tapes, White House lawyer, Samuel Powers, disclosed today that copies of the tapes were being made to make sure that all recordings of subpoenaed Presidential conversations were preserved.

title: People in Sports: The Linen Hangs Indoors
description: He probably won't be coach of the year, but Dan Devine of the slumping Green Bay Packers may win some votes as diplomat of the year.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Soybeans, which have been lingering at prices nearer their contract lows than highs, jumped the 20 cents a bushel daily limit yesterday as a result of some enthusiastic buying.

title: HOUSE APPROVES RAILROADAID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  A bipartisan bill to head off the threatened collapse of rail service by restructuring railroads in the Northeast was approved by the House of Representatives today, 306 to 82. The legislation now goes to the Senate.

title: Officials Here Say They Are Step Ahead on Fuel
description: Officials in the tristate area said yesterday that they had already urged many of the voluntary measures President Nixon called for in his energycrisis message.

title: Common Market Said to Resist U. S. on Joint Statement
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 8A diplomatic source said today that the Middle East crisis had reinforced Western European opposition to American efforts to insert such words as interdependence and partnership into a proposed joint, declaration on relations between the United States and the Eurogan Economic Community.

title: Congressional Election Set
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP)A special election to fill the United States House of Representatives seat of the late Representative John P. Saylor, Republican of Pennsylvania, will be held Feb. 5, 1974, Gov. Milton J. Shapp's office said yesterday.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE GOES ON AS UNION DEFIES U.S. COURT
description: Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union announced late yesterday that it would continue its strike, against 48 hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area, despite a $500,000 court fine and the judge's promise of further daily fines if the walkout continued.

title: Jets Favored to Win and Giants Are Not
description: The big game in pro football on Sunday is Pittsburgh at Oakland. But don't expect to watch these playoff teams battle on television. Because both the Jets and Giants are playing at home, albeit in New Haven for the Giants, the game in Oakland cannot be televised locally according to a threeyearold league rule. The New York teams' games will be televised starting at 1 P.M. When the home team plays at home, a station is forbidden from

title: Poets Extol a Sister's Unfettered Soul
description: JACKSON, MissTo mark the 200th birthday of the first book published by a black living in America, 20 black women poets from all over the country gathered here this week to celebrate the legacy of its author, Phillis Wheatley, a pretty little slave girl who managed at 17 to become a poet.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MEANY PLEDGES AID TO T.W.A. STRIKERS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8George Meany said today that the strike of flight attendants, which has grounded Trans World Airlines since Monday, was forced upon the union by an employer who does not know that this is the 20th Century.

title: ICELAND WILL SIGN ACCORD WITH BRITAIN
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 8 (AP)  The Icelandic Cabinet today accepted a proposal to resolve the dispute with Britain over fishing rights.

title: Soviet Accuses 3 Arab Nations Of Echoing Peking Propaganda
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8  A prominent Soviet monthly has accused the leaders of Libya, Tunisia and Morocco of echoing the Chinese propaganda line in the Middle East.

title: This Weekend, How About Chicken Liver Soup?
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Four Groups Join to Study RevenueSharing Program
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)  Four organizations announced today the formation of a coalition to monitor and study the effectiveness of the Administration's revenuesharing program.

title: U.S. IS MEDIATOR
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Friday, Nov. 9Israel and Egypt have agreed on new arrangements under the ceasefire that are expected to take effect within the next few, days, opening the way to fullscale peace negotiations by the end of the year, aides to Secretary of state Kissinger said early today.

title: Borg Upsets Nastase at Swedish Net
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 8 (Reuters)Bjorn Borg of Sweden. upset Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 62, 46, 75, in the third round of the Swedish Grand Prix indoor tennis tournament tonight.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOOK AND LISTEN The filmfestival season reels along, with a different slicing of the cinema world each time. The Eighth Annual New York Independent Filmmakers Festival has been under way at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, and it consists of 327 films, 16 and 35 mm., about 10 minutes long on the average, made by professional film people in this country, Japan, New Zealand, Canada and a halfdozen nations of Europe.

title: Hughes Quits Panel on Sports Complex
description: NEWARK, Nov. 8Noting with a broad grin that a funny thing happened on my way here, Richard J. Hughes said at a news conference here today that he was going to have to bow out as one of the titular heads of the Governor's Nonpartisan Committee that is backing the financially troubled Hackensack MeadowJands sports complex.

title: Jersey G.O.P. Moderates Urge Party Purge Itself of Sandman's Leadership
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8In the aftermath of the worst election disaster in the Jersey's political history, moderate Republican leaders and county chairmen today demanded a purge of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s leadership of the state party.

title: 2 Fugitives Booked for 9 Murders in California
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 8 (AP)Two fugitives were arrested here and booked for investigation of murder today in the slaying of nine persons in a a Central California home.

title: Jersey Cuts Speed
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8In what is believed to be the first statewide response of its kind to President Nixon's appeal for fuelsaving efforts, New Jersey's major highspeed tollways reduced their speed limits today to 50 miles an hour.

title: Truckers Seek Exemption From Proposed Speed Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)  Citing possible 12hour delays in freight shipments, the nation's trucking industry urged today that 1.7 million motor carriers, such as moving vans and other longdistance haulers, be exempted from a proposed reduction in nationwide speed limits.

title: 15 INDICTED HERE IN BOND FORGERY
description: Federal and state prosecutors yesterday announced indictments against 15 persons believed to be an organizedcrime clearing house responsible for the handling of $500,000 in stolen and urged government bonds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS WORKS ON ENERGY CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 With some of its corridor lights dimmed to save electricity, Congress began work today to give President Nixon many but probably not all  of the emergency powers he has sought to deal with the energycrisis.

title: J. & L. Sets a Price Rise
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (Reuters)The Jones & Laughlin steel corporation said today it was raising prices, effective Pan. 1, on flat rolled products in line with those announced previously by other manufacturers.

title: Nixon Signs Bill Raising School Lunch Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Nv. 8 (UPI)  President Nixon has signed into law a bill authorizing about $220million in additional subsidies to help hold down the cost of school lunches, it was disclosed today.

title: 14% Rise in Capital Outlays Is Expected
description: American industry plans to invest a record $113.9billion next year for new plant and equipment, or 14 per cent more than the estimated spending of $100.2billion in 1973, according to McGrawHill's latest survey, which is to be released today.

title: Litton Indictment Is Part Of Satellite Crackdown' Litton Indictment Is Part of Satellite Crackdown
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 8The Federal indictment of a Litton Industries subsidiary on charges of conspiracy to evade $216,000 in customs duties is part of an intensive crackdown on American industries that use satellite assembly plants just across the border with Mexico.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: TRADING IS ACTIVE IN BOND MARKETS
description: The taxexempt bond market remained active yesterday as underwriters and investors confronted two $100million issues. Corporate activity picked up as well and prices of older issues firmed. Government issues rallied, but closed below the day's highs. With Federal funds trading in a range of 9 to 9 11/16, the Federal Reserve entered the market, offering reverse repurchase agreements of four, five or seven days, a longer period than the one or twoday agreements carried out of late, The Fed's action, dealers said, pushed the Federal funds rate to 9 to 9 per cent.

title: Scotswoman Leads Her Party To Election Victory Over Labor
description: LONDON, Nov. 8A Scottish Nationalist scored a notable byelection victory over the Labor party today by beating it in the workingclass Govan constituency of Glasgow.

title: SHOP TALK
description: One could spend hours browsing at Patina Antiques, a small Greenwich Village shop where the ceilinghigh glass cabinets are full of curios and bibelots.

title: City Health Code Gives Board Broad Authority in Emergency
description: The Board of Health, in detlaring the third health emergency in the city in more than 40 years yesterday, was exercising broad authority granted at under the City Health Code.

title: Plunkett Would Prefer to Call Plays Against Jets
description: The frustrated New York Jets should find out by tomorrow whether Joe Namath or Al Woodall will lead them Sunday against the New England Patriots. The Patriots, however, with the same losing record (two victories, six defeats), know who is going to lead themJim Plunkettbut their quarterback is frustrated, nevertheless.

title: Lindsay and Beame Complete Transition Plans at Gracie Mansion
description: Mayor Lindsay and Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday disclosed completion of plans for an orderly transition of administrations at a joint news conference in Gracie Mansion.

title: MILWAUKEE'S MAYOR CALLS AN EMERGENCY
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 8 (UPI) Mayor Henry W. Maier declared a state of emergency here today after firemen rejected the city's final offer in their contract dispute.

title: Government Fails, Danish Premier Calls Electio??
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 8 (UPI)New Danish Parliamentary elections were called by Premier Anker Jorgensen today after his Social Democratic Government was narrowly defeated on a tax measure. The elections were set for Dec. 4.

title: Bill to Raise the Ceiling On Mortgage Rate Gains
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8 (AP)The chairman of the Assembly Banking Committee said today that the committee, would probably release a bill raising, the maximum interest ceiling on mortgages to 9.5 per cent.

title: ExCity Aide Forbidden To Practice Law for 3 Years
description: Michael Freyberg, a lawyer who once headed the city's Tax Commission and who in 1966 paid former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus $1,300 to influence a City Planning Commission decision, was ordered by the Appellate Division not to practice law for the next three years.

title: Amex Unit Asks Repeal Of Ban on Duel Trading
description: A special committee of the board of directors of th American Stock Exchange, after two months of study, has concluded that the exchange's constitutional prohibition against dual trading  that conducted on both the Amex and another exchange  should be repealed.

title: Pop Music: TailorMade With a Three Dog Look
description: Three Dog Night believes in the visual. If you were counting Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, when the group appeared, there were 21 costume changes, from an outfit that appeared to be composed of handkerchiefs to customdecorated suits, designed, according to a publicity aide, to reflect each member's personality.

title: PENSION APPROVAL MADE FINAL IN PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) A divided House Ways and Means Committee stamped its final approval today on a bill to increase Social Security benefits 11 per cent next year and to increase the payrolltax wage base to pay for them.

title: U.S. Aides Expect The Energy Crisis To Go On Anyway
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8American officials were pessilmistic that the Middle East agreement would bring any relief in the energy crisis.

title: Bond Vote Faces Recount
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 8 (UPI) Hartford's Corporation Counsel, Alexander A. Goldfarb, says the city will recount votes on a $25million bond issue for downtown development. The bond question was approved Tuesday by 39 votes, but the city charter requires that 15 per cent of Hartford's electorate must vote for a bond ordinance in order for it to be binding.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: NEW YORK

title: BASERENT SYSTEM ORDERED TO GO ON
description: A State. Supreme Court jusMice ruled yesterday that the city had to Continue the program permitting rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many rentcontrolled apartments.

title: Jersey Republicans Urge Party Purge
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8  In grim aftermath of the worst election disaster in New Jersey's political history, moderate Republican leaders and county chairmen today demanded a purge of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s leadership of the state party.

title: Doctors Support Nixon on Cooler Homes
description: President Nixon's prescription for achieving healthier lives by turning down the the thermostat 6 degrees met with support from many medical leaders yesterday.

title: Aides Discuss Senate Panel Bid to Talk With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Lawyers for the White House and for the Senate Watergate committee met tonight to discuss the committee's request for a meeting with President Nixon.

title: French Ask Action In Common Market To Counter Inflation
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 9  France, whose 10 per cent inflation rate is becoming a big domestic political issue, asked her Common Market partners today to agree rapidly to emergency antiinflation measures.

title: Tightrope
description: Any moves toward peaceful settlement in the Middle East inevitably generate concentric circles of uneasiness about what lies ahead. Considering the state of tensions in which Arab and Israeli peoples have lived for so long, it is hardly surprising that both sides want to be insulated against surprises or imprecisions in any commitments they may undertake.

title: Atlantic Partnership
description: The crisis in the Western alliance set off by the Mideast war throws an ironic light on the draft text of the new Atlantic Charter submitted by the United States to its European allies on Sept. 29, and, published in The Times on Friday.

title: Reds Trade Tolan, Tomlin to Padres for Kirby
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 9 (UPI) The, Cincinnati Reds traded Bobby Tolan, a discontented outfielder, and Dave Tomlin, a pitcher, to the San Diego Padres today in exchange for Clay Kirby, a pitcher.

title: A Steady Diet of Children
description: PEKINGLike Saturnand like rill twentiethcentury revolutions  the Chinese revolution has devoured a great many of its own children. Among the numerous top leaders and close associates pf Mao Tsetung who have either died or disappeared since the People's Republic was declared in 1949 are the following (and this is but a short list):

title: Suns Drop 9th in Row To Celtics
description: BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Boston Celtics, sparked by Jo Jo White's 17point third period, scored their fifth consecutive National Basketball Association victory, 122 to 107 tonight, and handed the Phoenix Suns their ninth straight loss.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 9 (UPI)The World Boxing Association today ordered George Foreman, the heavyweight champion, to enter into serious negotiations for his next title defense against the leading available contender in the division. Bill Brennan, chairman of the W.B.A.s championship committee, said the rules allowed Foreman one year from Jan. 22, 1973when he won the titleto defend the crown against the leading available contender.

title: Political Sheath on the Arab Oil Weapon
description: PARIS, Nov. 9 While the progress toward peace in the Middle East as a result of the Kissinger mission is not expected to have any immediate. effect on the Arab oil embargo, there are a variety of other pressures on the Arab states, political as well as economic, not to carry that embargo too far. The embargo has limited aims: to enforce a mildIy proArab policy in Europe and to get the United States to ease its support of Israel. And the shortage of petroleum now being felt in Europe, Japan and the United States shows that the Arabs are dead serious.

title: Major Figures in Speech Gather Here for a Palaver
description: This is the town of the talk: The Speech Communication Association is holding its annual convention in verbal harmony with The American Forensic Association.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Isolation of Livingston College Given As One Reason for the Student Unrest
description: PISCATAWAY, Nov. 9Livingston College sits on a former Army camp isolated from shopping centers, bars, movie houses and the rest of Rutgers University.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 70yearold widow, her son and a woman visitor were burned to death after they apparently were trapped in their small thirdfloor apartment in a brick building built in the early nineteenhundreds in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn.

title: Rebozo Bank Aide Quits in Face of Removal Action
description: MIAMI, Nov. 9 (AP)A vice president of the Key Biscayne Bank and Trust Company confirmed tonight that he had resigned in the face of a removal acion by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Big Board Stocks Show Biggest Drop Since May 28, 1962
description: The biggest stockmarket dedine since May 28, 1962, hit Wall Street yesterday amid spreading fears that the energy shortage would crimp industrial output and perhaps cause a recession in 1974.

title: Quick Test for Heart Attacks Is Reported
description: Anew urine test that reportedly can detect a heart attack moments after onset has been developed by a Hartford physician.

title: 6 Get Watergate Terms; Hunt Given 2 to 8 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 E. Howard Hunt Jr., the former spy who was hired by the White House to carry out clandestine operations, was sentenced today to two and a half to eight years in prison and fined $10,000 for his role in planning the Watergate breakin.

title: Net Income Falls at Continental Phone
C.A.B. Allows Airline FlightCut Talks
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board granted the airline industryforeign and domestic  broad new authority yesterday to negotiate agreements reducing competitive flights because of fuel shortages.

title: Flames Tie Rangers, 33, After Trailing by 3 Goals
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 9  Rattled by a band of tough young hustlers who came back fighting in the last two periods, the New York Rangers dropped a 30 lead tonight at the Omni and let the Atlanta Flames tie them, 33.

title: Size of Corn Crop for 1973 Lagging but Still a Record
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The size of the 1973 corn crop, the livestock feed grain most needed to step up consumer food supplies next year, deteriorated last month but still will be a record 5.67 billion bushels, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: People in Sports: Pacers' Pilot Penalized
description: Bob Leonard, the coach of the Indiana. Pacers of the American Basketball Association, has been fined $1,000 and suspended for two days. The fine, announced by Commissioner Mike Storen was the largest in the league's history.

title: 3 Pollock Paintings Stolen From a Harvard Professor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 Three paintings by the late Jackson Pollock, valued at nearly $500,000, were stolen yesterday from the home of Reginald R. Isaacs, a Harvard University professor who had been a close friend of the late artist.

title: Special Republican Panel Will Meet Nixon Monday
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9A Republican coordinating cornmittee, born in the party crisis that followed the Goldwater defeat of 1964 and revived in the crisis over President Nixon's leadership, accepted today Mr. Nixon's invitation to a White. House breakfast on Monday.

title: Kissinger Fails to Sway Saudis From Oil Embargo
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 9Secretary of State Kissinger has been unable to Obtain relaxation of Saudi Arabia's oil embargo on the United States but he has reportedly convinced King Faisal of his sincerity in the search, for peace in the Middle East.

title: INFLATION DANGER CITED BY BRIMMER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he had concluded that the fight against inflation must be pursued in the period ahead even if it means a relatively sluggish economy.

title: Harry Uviller, Impartial Arbiter Of Dress Industry Here, Is Dead
description: Harry Uviller, impartial chairman of New York's dress industry since 1936, who played a major role in maintaining peaceful managementlabor relations in the garment trade, died yesterday at his home, 930 Fifth Avenue. He was 76 years old.

title: Rigged Weel's
description: The cleanair people, being understandably worried about the danger of breathing in New Jersey, have a Rube Goldberg plan for improving matters.

title: Rrinegar Sees G.N.P. Hart by Oil Embargo
description: The Secretary of Transportation, Claude S. Brinegar, said yesterday that if the Arab oil embargo caused an energy shortfall in the United States of as much as 15 per cant, we could well see a G.N.P. fall of 2 per cent.

title: Iran Steering a Caxeful Course in Mideast Crisis
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9 Iran his remained carefully aloof and noncommittal in the latest ArabIsraeli crisis.

title: WINE TALK
description: FLORENCE, Italy  In 1447, a Florentine named Pietro da Lucha tried to get his taxes reduced. He wrote to the collector: I have a ho ise to live in, situated in Sancto Felice in Pizza.... I have nothing but debts and I am poor and I cannot do anything but dress flasks ...

title: STUDENT BOYCOTT SPREADS IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov.9 More university students joined today in a spreading boycott of classes to protest Government, policies. The boycotts now effect eight colleges in the Seoul area.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: Cofounder of Goldstein Firm Gets 15 Years for Mail Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9Harold Goldstein, 28yearold cofounder of a once highflying commodities options company, was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for mail fraud.

title: Laborites Set Back in OffYear Election
description: LONDON, Nov. 9The Labor party, which has been leading the governing Conservatives in the popularity polls, suffered a severe setback today in the final returns In four offyear lections.

title: H D. ARMSTRONG
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9H. D. Armstrong, who retired in 1971 as treasurer of the Standard Oil Company of California, died yesterday at his home in Woodside. He was 66 years old.

title: Policemen Troubled By Women Officers; Cawley Calls Parley
description: A growing apprehension among New York policemen about the steadily increasing number of women police officers here has prompted Commissioner Donald F. Cawley to call a private meeting of top commanders to discuss the role of women within the department.

title: Ballman Retires, Ending a Sad Season
description: It should have been a happy 12th wedding anniversary yesterday for Gary and Judi Ballman. Instead, the 33yearold Ballman took the occasion to announce his immediate retirement from professional football.

title: Israelis Charge Europe Yields on Oil
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 9  Israel today accused the nine member governments of the European Economic Community of showing greater concern for  their petroleum supplies than for the peace of the Middle East.

title: NIXON TO RELEASE CONTENT OF TAPES THAT CO TO JURY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9President Nixon told Repubilcan Congressional leaders today that he planned to make public the White House tape recordings and other Watergate documents after they were submitted to the Federal grand jury.

title: STATE AIDE SAID TO WEIGH NEVI JOB
description: The State Environment41 Commissioner, Henry L. Diamond, has been asked by Governor Rockefeller to join His National Commission on Crit?? cal Choices and is reported to be preparing to resign and beits director next month.

title: Complex Chief of Hospital Union Leon Julius Davis
description: At the negotiating table, Leon Julius Davis can wheedle, cajole, threaten, scream and softsoap. He has been known to hurl things, and he has gone to jail for his convictions. His enemies call him abrasive and impossible to deal with, but his followers virtually idolize him. To them, he is a gentle, almost shy man, a connoisseur of art, music and the theater who tends flowers lovingly and is responsible for improving the lives of thousands. It is a complex picture of a complicated man. After 41 years at the helm of his unionnow known as Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Unionhe is more than its president. He is its patriarch, and he looks ita man of 60 with flowing beard.

title: Niagara Mohawk Expanding
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced yesterday plans for building a new power plant in Western New York with a capacity of 1.1million kilowatts. A spokesman said the actual site has not yet been decided but it would probably be along the shore of Lake Erie or Lake Ontario. Construction is expected to begin in four years and the plant should be ready for operation in 1988. The utility expects to use either nuclear fuel or coal to run the plant.

title: Vizzini Keeping Secret Firemen's Strike rote
description: Richard J. Vizzini, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, yesterday refused to divulge the figures of the strike vote taken by secret ballot among union members late last month.

title: HEARINGS ARE SET ON AUTO INCREASES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Cost of Living Council his scheduled public hearings to determine if price increases requested by the four automobile makers are justified.

title: Continental Illinois in Pact To Buy Capital Financial
description: The Continental Corporation of New York and the Continental Illinois Corporation announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle on a proposal for the purchase by Continental Illinois of Capital Financial Services, Inc., a subsidiary of Continental.

title: People and Business
description: Robert P. Koenig, a veteran executive in the metals industry, has been named the chairman of the Foote Mineral Company, a producer of ferroalloys and lithium products. The post has been vacant since the death last year of Louis G. Bliss.

title: It's a Great Day for U.S.
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9 According to a couple of American trainers, the United States will finish one, two, three in the $150,000 Washington D.C. International tomorrow and the six other horses in the race might just as well have remained in Europe. The American horses are Tentam, London Company and Big Spruce.

title: U.S. Reports Accord With Bonn on Shipments to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger says that the United. States has smoothed over a diplomatic dispute with the Bonn Government by working out arrangements for possibl future shipment to Israel of American military equipment in West Germany.

title: MANY FEEL IMPACT OF AIRLINE STRIKE
description: Many hundreds of businessmen bound for home after week of working in New York and other cities were turned away by airlines yesterday as the fivedayold strike by trans World Airlines employes and fuel shortages combined to hamper the nation's air trans port system.

title: Music: To Rachmaninoff
description: Some can and some can't. Enjoy all Rachmaninoff recitals, that is. There are those who find Rachmaninoff's music emotionally too limited to support an entire evening. There are those who respond, on the other hand, finding constant enjoyment in Rachmaninoff's coruscatingly brilliant piano writing and not objecting in the least to an emotional steambath.

title: Fulbright, Supporting Kissinger, Calls for a Comprothise Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Senator J. W. Fulbright endorsed Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East policy today and attacked Senator Henry M. Jackson's challenge to the policy of accommodation with the Soviet Union.

title: Modern Master Drawings Are Shown
description: In the exhibition of Modern Master Drawings at the Allan Frumkin Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, there are four works by the German, painter Lovis Corinth. Three are selfportraits, and onethe earliest, dating from 1912 is a portrait of Charlotte BerendCorinth, the artist's wife, herself an artist, seated at the easel in their apartment.

title: Nixon Daughter at Show
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Mrs. David Eisenhower visited today the Soviet Youth Show, an exhibition of more than 2,500 items sent to this country under the U.S.Soviet cultural exchange program.

title: RAY E. POWELL, 85, ALUMINUM EXPERT
description: Ray Edwin Powell, who retired in 1967 as a director of Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., after 44 years' service that included the presidency of the Alumini um Company of Canada, died yesterday at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Montreal. His age was 85, and he lived in Montreal.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9A leading insurance company told Congress today that the insurance industry could not. quickly take over most of the functions of insuring business investment in lessdeveloped countries now performed by the Government's Overseas Private Investment Corporation.

title: Sadat Decision Not to Insist on Oct. 22 Lines Called Key to Mideast Agreement
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 9President Anwar elSadat's decision to drop Egypt's insistence on an Israeli pullback to the Oct. 22 ceasefire line was a major factor in reaching Middle East agreement, a senior American official said today.

title: 6 Others Are Indicted on Charges of Conspiring to Get Cocaine Into U.S.
description: Montreal's reputed top leader of organized crime, two other Canadians, two Mexicans and a New Yorker were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that they had conspired to import and distribute cocaine into the United States.

title: Eisendrath, 71, Dies Just Before Address
description: Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, leader of Reform Judaism in the United States, died of a coronary attack last night as 3,500 members of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which he has headed for 30 years, were gathering at the New York Hilton for their biennial meeting.

title: Senate Panel Speeds Bill To Meet Energy Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Senate Interior Committee, pushing to finish work quickly on a bill giving President Nixon emergency powers to deal with the energy shortage, sidestepped action today on controversial regulatory provisions on natural gas and the environment.

title: The Stage
description: Off Off Broadway one can find the most expert and the most incompetent productions. Only incompetende was in evidence during a recent visit to the New York Theater Ensemble's first production of the season, an evening of. StrindbergPlaying With Fire and The Creditors.

title: 5 AT CITY OPERA NEW IN THE MAGIC FLUTE
description: In the New York City Opera's performance of Mozart's The Magic Flute on Wednesday night, a number of roles were taken by singers who had not appeared in them previously with the company.

title: JAMES M. SPINNING
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 9 (AP)Dr. James M. Spinning, retired school superintendent of this city, died yesterday at the ages of 81.

title: New 4Channel Record Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Columbia Broadcasting System is introducing its new quadraphonic disk record, with which sounds can be reproduced that seem to come from the four corners of a room. Benjamin B. Bauer, vice president for acoustics and magnetics at C.B.S. Laboratories, Stamford, Conn., was granted Patent 3,770,901 this week for the SQ record, it is trademarked.

title: Soviet Plant to Convert Oil to Protein for Feed
description: The Soviet Union has completed the construction of a large industrial installation that obverts petroleum into protein for animal feed, and ultimately into meat.

title: House Unit Backs Strip Mine Curb In Surprise Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Members of the House Interior Committee voted tentatively today to impose a $2,50aton Federal fee on the production of coal and then added a feeexemption schedule that was calculated to encourage underground mining and to penalize heavily most surface or strip mining.

title: GIBBON APPOINTS KEY NEWARK AIDE
description: NEWARK; Nov. 9Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today named Corporation Counsel William H. Walls is the new City Business Administrator to replace Cornelius Bodine Jr. Mr. Bodine resigned 10 days ago after charging that the city administration had violated the municipal charter law by restricting his duties.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: U.S. Navy Setback Giving Soviet an Edge in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The strategic balanee in the Middle Esst has tipped in favor of the Soviet Union and its Arab allies in the aftermath of the October war, according to United States military sources.
