title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: CITY SEEKS TO AID YANKEES AT SHEA
description: The city administration will ask the Board of Estimate to permit the New York Yankees to rent Shea Stadium for $1 a year for the next two years to help offset revenue losses there on the sale of refreshments and other items.

title: Taiwan Confident It Can Ride Out Storm
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 9 The bulletins on Secretary of State Kissinger's journey to Peking through the capitals of the Middle East have received the kind of careful attention here this week that is devoted to bulletins on an approaching typhoon.

title: Basketball Tonight
description: GARDEN, 8 P.M.

title: Still a Noose
description: The strangulation by strike of the city's voluntary hospitals has been somewhat eased by the union's agreement to go along with a request from Mayor Lindsay for passage of essential supplies through the picket lines. This utterly unconscionable blockade on movement of fuel, food and medicine for five days has caused untold hardship to the ill and the infirm. But, even with a lifting of the blockade, the absence of 33,000 employes and the forced closing of many wings and services in a siege that victimizes the aged, the sick and the dying are still an intolerable affront to the people of New York City.

title: HOUS UNIT VOTES STRIPMINE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Members of the House Interior Committee voted tentatively today to impose a $2.50aton Federal fee on the production of coal and then added a feeexemption schedulet that was calculated to encourage underground mining and to penalize mayfly most surface or strip mining.

title: Ashe Match and Foster Baut Mean More Erosion of Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 9Two major events comingup in South Africa illustrate that the winds of change ate wafting through the sporting life of the country of apartheid.

title: Slain Woman's Friends SadBut Not Surprised
description: Neighbors of 19yearold April Fell, who was found murdered in a vacant lot near her home in Springfield Gardens, Queens, on Thursday, were saddened and embittered yesterday as they talked about her death but not surprised.

title: Campus Notes
description: New York University is trying to account for about $40,000 worth of equipment missing in its move from its former University Heights campus to its central facilities in Washington Square.

title: An Exploding Illinois Suburb Learns How to Cope
description: SCHAUMBURG, ILL., Nov. 7I SAID, he said, WE USED TO KEEP THE BEES OVER THERE.

title: Merritt Pkwy. Rebuilding Is Slated Despite Protests
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 9  Modernization of sections of the rustic Merritt Parkway in Fairfield County will proceed as planned, despite community opposition, the State Transportation Department said today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: It happens rarely, but when Bruce Naszimento, the nation's leading scorer in collegiate football with 23 touchdowns, is not doing inspiring things on the field for Jersey City, State, he says inspiring things on the sidelines.

title: State's Capitol Full of PostElection Smiles
description: TRENTON, Nov. 9There was an uncommon air of buoyancy around the State Capitol this week, considering that the Republican tandidate for Governor lost on Tuesday.

title: SLAYER OF 8 GETS LIFE IN CALIFORNIA
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Nov. 9 (UPI)Edmund E. Kemper 3d, a young man described at his trial as extraordinarily intelligent, was sentenced today to life in prison for the murder of eight women, including his mother.

title: WINE TALK
description: FLORENCE, Italy  In 1447, a Florentine named Pietro da Lucha tried to get his taxes reduced. He wrote to the collector: I have a ho ise to live in, situated in Sancto Felice in Pizza.... I have nothing but debts and I am poor and I cannot do anything but dress flasks ...

title: FREDERICK L. KNOWLES
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 9 (AP)Frederick L. Knowles, a biochemist who had made important advances in malaria research, died yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: Salant Disputes White House on Cronkite Interviews
description: The White, House allegation that Walter Cronkite, news anchorman for the.lumbia Broadcasting System, showed partiality to newsmakers who were unfriendly to the Administration has been rebutted, in a background memorandum by Richard S. Salant, president of C.B.S. News.

title: WALDHEIM ORDERS PEACE FORCE TO ACT
description: UNTED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 9  Secretary General Waldheim directed the head of the United Nations peace force in the Middle East today to carry out measures immediately for stabilizing the ceasefire accepted by Egypt and Israeli.

title: ISRAELIS SEEkING U.S. ASSURANCES
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Nov. 10The Israeli Government announced today that it had accepted in principle the Americansponsored ceasefire agreement with Egypt, but said it would seek further clarifications on the details from the United States.

title: Big Board Stock's Show Biggest Drop Since May 28,1962
description: The biggest stockmarket dedine since May 28, 1962, hitWall Street yesterday amid spreading fears that the energy shortage would crimp industrial output and perhaps cause a recession in 1974.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Soybean traders had some second thoughts yederday. As a result, enough of them sold contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade to drop prices by the 20centsabushel daily limit. This decline came after a vigorous trading day Thursday when prices jumped the 20cent limit.

title: A Retrospective at Hirschl and Adler
description: The American masterworks included in Retrospective of a Gallery, now on view at the Hirschl and Adler Galleries, 21 East 67th Street, will come as no surprise to regular gallerygoers. The gallery, which is celebrating an anniversary with this benefit showing for the Youth Consultation Service, has, in its 20 years of existence, been stanchly associated with American art from the Colonial period to the early 20th century. But the number of firstrate French paintings the firm has placed with private and public collections over the last two decades should offer an unexpected delight to many viewers. There is a stunning and luminescent Bonnard, Soleil d'Avril, with two somnolent alts sunning themselves on a windowsill, a shimmering Monet Waterlines, a beautiful Degas pastel, Dancer With Upraised Arms, and equally impressive works by Cezanne, Sisley, Renoir, Pissarro and Derain. Hirschl and Adler, it appears, has been one of the quieter traders in giltedge securities.

title: Groucho Marx Sues to Stop Book of His Unedited Remarks
description: Groucho Marx has filed suit in State Supreme Court to halt distribution of a book on his family, Marx Bros. Scrap Book.

title: Oil Drilling Curb Favored
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) The Florida delegation in the House introduced today a bill that would prevent any oil drilling that would interfere with defense test ranges in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: SALES AT RETAIL UP 211% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Retail sales rose strongly in October after being steady in August and September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Pelican Bowl Is Off
description: DURHAM, N. C., Nov. 9 (AP)  The second Pelican Bowl, matching the MidEastern Athletic Conference champion against the winner of the Southwestern Athletic Conference, was canceled today because of a conflict of dates at Tulane Stadium in New Orleans Dec. 1.

title: Stocks on Amex Show a Big Decline
description: The possibility of a slowdown in the economy because of the energy crisis, as well as profit taking, sent prices tumbling yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market. Prices had been up sharply the day before.

title: One Man's Bitter Porridge
description: TEMPE, Ariz.When I wrote the letters that eVentually led to the public revelation of the My Lai massacre, I hoped for many things. Chief among them was that, it would show the American people and their Government that the policies of force abroad and deception at home were not only antithetical to the principles of a democratic society brit low, mean, stupid, brutal and selfdestructive as well.

title: Votes in Congress This Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Brandt and Scheel Will Visit Prague to Establish Relations
description: BONN, Nov. 9  Chaincellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Minister Walter Scheel will make their longpostponed trip to Prague to establish diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia on Nov. 28, according to reports from Prague.

title: HOUSING POLICEMAN BEATEN WITH BATS
description: A 43yearold Housing Authority policeman was in critical condition at Lincoln Hospital yesterday after having been beaten with baseball bats, the Housing Authority police said, by a man and a teenage couple in the South Bronx.

title: Art: Good Shows for Gallery goers
description: With five good shows falling to this reporter's lot this week, the thing to do is to avoid implications of preference by taking them up geographically from 57th Street to 86th. By coincidence this would also have been alphabetically by artist, except that June Leaf, with a new show at Dintenfass, 18 East 67th Street, is interruptive. But Miss Leaf is an exception to everything, including every specific esthetic standard ever formulated, and I am going to throw her out pending a session with Roget's International Thesaurus to see whether there is a synonym for repellent that means attractive and whether it is possible to invent some verbal dodge that will equate her roughand  ready, three  sheets  tothewind and basesfull technique with the acuity of her perceptions. Until I get this figured out, I can only suggest a visit to her show, which closes Nov. 24.

title: WEICKER ATTACKS NIXON'S TV OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. attacked the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy today as a danger to the freedom of the press, and introduced legislation that would abolish the office.

title: Senate Gets Plan to Elect President if Nixon Quits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Senator William D. Hathaway, Democrat of Maine, urged Congress today to provide for a new national election if President Nixon should leave office before Vice Presidentdesignate Gerald R. Ford was sworn in as his successor.

title: Antiques: FolkArt Sale
description: The two major Americana sales at Sotheby Parke Bernet next week pose some pleasures and problems for folk art and antiques collectors and dealers.

title: Raped Cheerleader and Police Look for Site of Crime in Bronx
description: The police yesterday took their investigation of the Thursday rape and beating of a 16yearold Bronx girl onto the streets and into the gang hangouts of the Hunts Point section of the Bronx but turned up few leads.

title: 8.670% Rate Is Set At Treasury Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The average rate for the United States Treasury's 61.1billion strip of weekly bills in today's competitive sale was 8.670 per cent.

title: Uncertainty in Britain
description: The British continue to be disenchanted with both the Conservative Government and its Labor opposition; but now they also seem to be calling at least a temporary halt to the hitherto impressive comeback of the oncemighty Liberal party. Four elections to fill House of Commons vacancies have brought setbacks for all three parties and may reflect disillusionment with the capacity of the Parliamentary system to solve Britain's ills.

title: 6 Get Watergate Terms Hunt Given 2 to 8 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 9 E. Howard Hunt Jr., the former spy who was hired by the White House to carry out clandestine operations, was sentenced today to two and a half to eight years in prison and fined $10,000 for his role in planning the Watergate breakin.

title: Quick Test for Heart Attacks Is Reported
description: A new urine test that reportedly can detect a heart attack, moments after onset has been developed by a Hartford physician.

title: CARDINAL ASSAILS ULSTER ON KILLINGS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 9William Cardinal Conway, Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, said today that not enough was being done by authorities in Northern Ireland to combat what he described as the campaign of slaughter and intimidation against Catholics.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: CITY IS SUCCEEDING IN EFFORTS TO AID STRUCK HOSPITALS
description: The city claimed some success yesterday in its, stopgap efforts to help 48 metropolitanarea hospitals and nursing homes struck last Monday by Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union, as the union continued to defy courtimposed fines.

title: How to Cope
description: If there is among us, in these trembling times, anyone who wants to find out how to understand dogs, how to stay young until death, how to make friends with the opposite sex, how to cast an astrological chart, how to create your own marriage ceremony, how to shop in supermarkets or how to survive as a man who is suddenly single, then buy a book. One has been written tell how it.

title: Man Who Saved 2 Policemen In Passaic Is Felon Out on Bail
description: PASSAIC, Nova 9  Frank Schneider, who was credited with saving the lives of two Passaic policemen in a gunfight here on Wednesday was disclosed today to be a convicted felon who is free on bail pending an appeal of his case.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE STIR LABOR'S IRE
description: The dispute over the contract between the hospital workers, union and 48 hospitals and nursing homes here, resulting in the current strike, illustrates many of the criticisms labor makes of the Federal Cost of Living Council.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Stephen Zwerling's Oct. 23 letter concerning national service for young people between high school and college argues convincingly for the need to identify new, more than symbolic forms of service. How about using able and welltrained young volunteers to augment police patrols in combating street crime?

title: OIL IMPORT PLAN SCORED BY WOLFF
description: Representative Lester L. Wolff, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he had been told that American oil companies were shipping oil or oil products from the United States abroad and importing them back to avoid the Cost of Living Council's regulations on domestic oil and to take advantage of the lack of controls on imports.

title: Gilbert Has 2Shot Lead At 136 Despite 74 Round
description: PINEHURST, N. C, Nov. 9 (AP)Gibby Gilbert, who hada fivestroke lead after a firstround. 62 yesterday, lost five strokes in one stretch of three holes today, but retained the lead in the world's richest golf tournament.

title: ISRAELIS SEEKING U. S. ASSURANCES
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Nov. 10The Israeli Government announced today that it had accepted in principle the Americansponsored ceasefire agreement with Egypt, but said it would seek further clarifications on the details from the United States.

title: Man Dies in Snowball Attack
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 9 (AP) A 56yearold crippled man collapsed and died last night under a snowball barrage by several youths, the police said. The victim, Manuel Reil, who had a history of heart trouble, was walking with the aid of a cane and trying to dodge the snowballs when he fell, witnesses told the police.

title: Yasuda's 65 Paces Japan Golf
description: KAWASAKI, Japan, Nov. 9 (AP)Haruo Yasuda Japan took a threestroke lead by shooting a sevenunderpar 65 today in the first round of the $23,900 Rolex gold tournament: Tony Jacklin of Britain, the only foreign corn, petitor invited to the tournament, shot a par 72 and tied for 10th place with two Japanese pros.

title: Judge to Rule on Action Challenging Cox's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell agreed today to consider the legality of the dismissal of Archibald Cox as special Watergate prosecutor and of the order temporarily abolishing his prosecution force.

title: Railbirds Are Home to Roost Today
HUGE TAX ON GAS UNDER DISCUSSION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Top officials of the Nixon Administration are seriously discussing the possibility of asking Congress to enact a large tax on gasoline as an alternative to rationing, informed sources said tonight.

title: Irish, 'Barna Get Bowl Fever
description: The probable pairings for two of the four major bowl games remain as they were a week ago. However, the sites have been switched. Notre Dame and Alabama are now expected to meet in the Sugar Bowl instead of the Orange Bowl, which leaves Penn State and Louisiana State as obvious Orange Bowl opponents.

title: Agnew Now 55t Found in Good Spirits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, who became 55 years old today, has spent the last month sorting out the remnants of his aborted political career. Friends have found him in good spirits but say they have no idea what, if any, plans he has for his future.

title: Dining Out in jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: NIXON TO RELEASE CONTENT OF TAPES THAT GO TO JURY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 President Nixon told Republican Congressional leaders today that he planned to make public the White House tape recordings and other Watergate documents after they were submitted to the Federal grand jury.

title: When Youve Walked a Mile in Their Shoes
description: WASHINGTON  When I went to live among the Navajos on their vast Southwestern reservation in early 1972, I packed very lightly, but immediately felt weighted down by my own values and conceits.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Demonstrating Tenants Win Shelter

title: Bullets That Killed Oakland Educator Contained Cyanide
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 9 The Alameda County coroner's office said today that the bullets used in the ambush slaying of Marcus Foster, the school superintendent, on Tuesday contained cyanide.

title: Boyle Is Ordered to Pittsburgh To Answer Yablonski Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9W. A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers who is accused of ordering the killing of Joseph A. Yablonski, an antiBoyle challenger in a 1969, union election campaign, was formally ordered today to answer the murder charge in Pittsburgh on Nov. 21.

title: ESMERALDA DANCED BY NATIONAL BALLET
description: The National Ballet of Washington showed off a new showpiece Thursday night at the City Center as part of its brief local season, which closes tomorrow evening with a benefit gala.

title: NIXON AT RETREAT REPORTERS, CURBED
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Nov. 9 (AP)The White House said President. Nixon flew to his mountaintop retreat today, but, in a change of procedure, newsmen were not permitted to watch the President's helicopter take off from the White House South Lawn or land at this closely guarded compound.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Guide Going Out
description: WALK TALK While most weekend walking tours are designed to reveal tuckedaway architectural beauty or to recall past grandeur, the one scheduled for 11 A.M. out of St. Luke's Church, 308 West 46th Street, is in a way a battleground survey. It is sponsored by the Municipal Art Society and will be led by William Bardel, director of the Office of Midtown Planning.

title: MIAMI NEWS EDITOR RESIGNS IN DISPUTE
description: MIAMI, Nov. 9  Sylvan H. Meyer, the editor of the Miami News, resigned today because of unspecified disagreements with the Cox Publishing Company, which owns the afternoon Miami newspaper.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Notes on People
description: The former Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, will return to Harvard University in January as Williston Professor of Law, it was announced yesterday by Harvard's president, Derek C. Bok.

title: Brooklyn Utility Bids For 2d Gas Increase Within 3 Months
description: Barely three months after it received a $15.7million rate increase, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company has asked the Public Service Commission for an increase of 22 per cent, or $39.8million a year, including a temporary rate rise of $16.3million to take effect on Jan. 1.

title: Senate Unit Speeds Bill to Give Nixon Special Energy Powers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Senate Interior Committee, pushing to finish work quickly on a bill giving President Nixon emergency powers to deal with the energy shortage, sidestepped action today on controversial regulatory provisions on natural gas and the environment.

title: HOSPITAL UNION IS MILITANT ONE
description: Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union, on strike since Monday against 48 hospitals and nursing homes here, is an aggressive, militant labor or ganization that was formed by Jewish drug clerks in Harlem and the Bronx at the outset of the Depression.

title: A Big Day for the Bridegrom's Home Town
description: GREAT SOMERFORD, England, Nov. 9Gwyn Lewis bowed a customer out of his butcher shop the other morning and warned her with mock solemnity:

title: Eisendrath, 71, Dies Just Before Address
description: Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, leader of Reform Judaism in the United States, died of a coronary attack last night as 3,500 members of the Union of American Hebrew Congregadens, which he has headed for 30 years, were gathering at the New York Hilton for their biennial meeting.

title: Soviet Portrays a Weakened Nixon Under Pressure to Quit Presidency
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9Millions, of Soviet newspaper readers today were given the sharpest and most negative view of President Nixon yet to appear. in the Soviet pressa picture of a President whose resignation is being demanded, whose honesty questioned and whose power is curtailed.

title: War Dispute Helps End Brotherhood Effort
description: A dispute over the war in the Middle East his apparently helped end one of the city's bestknown experiments in religious brotherhood.

title: Vesco Yacht Mast Stay In Miami, Judge Rules
description: A $1.4million yacht belonging to the fugitive financier Robert L. Vesco must remain tied up at a Miami dock, a Federal judge here ruled yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

title: Otto P. Kohl, 80, Founded Curtiss Aviation Museum.
description: BATH, N.Y., Nov. 9 (AP)Otto P. Kohl, founder of the Glenn Curtiss Aviation Museum in nearby Hammondsport, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: Typewriters Don't Type, Pens Don't Scratch
description: ZURICH, Switzerland  There is silence among the writers. The great namesigners don't sign their names any more.

title: Man Who Saved 2 Policemen In Passaic Is Felon Out on Bail
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Nov. 9Frank Schneider, who was credited with saving the lives of two Passaic policemen in a gunfight here on Wednesday, was disclosed today to be a convicted felon who is free on bail pending an appeal of his case.

title: U.S. RESTSITS CASE AGAINST G.M., FORD
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9The Federal Government rested its case today in its antitrust suit, against the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company on charges of price fixing in fleetcar sales.

title: Health Board Team in a War Room Keeps a Vigil Over Struck Hospitals
description: A small thirdfloor office containing a large chart, a battery of seven telephones and a handful of dedicated sanitarians is the war room from which the Board of Health is waging its battle to keep the hopital strike from becoming a disaster for thousands of ill and elderly people.

title: Auto Industry in Two  Way Squeeze
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9The energy crisis is squeezing the automobile industry from two directionsshortages of power for making cars and shortages of gasoline for driving them.

title: Text of the New Middle, East Agreernent
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9Following, us made public today by the United States Mission, is the text of a letter setting forth the EgyptianIsraeli agreement carrying out the Middle East ceasefire:

title: JOB TITLES CHANGER TO END SEX CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Housemaids now will be known to the Government as lodging quarters cleaners, and foremen as blue collar worker supervisors, all in the interest of eliminating sex designations from job titles.

title: Suns Drop 9th in Row To Celtics
description: BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Boston Celtics, sparked by Jo Jo White's 17point third period, scored their fifth consecutie National Basketball Association victory, 122 to 107 tonight, and handed the Phoenix Suns their ninth straight loss.

title: Music Milstein, Rare
description: As the record books will have you believe, Nathan Milstein 70 years old on the last day of this year. But would anyone who was in the audience at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night find that statistic credible? Mr. Milstein, playing with undiminished authority and only occasional faltering of his renowned precision and control, put on a recital that reminded one what virtuosity on the violin is all about, at its best.

title: Homebuilder Is Fined in an Illinois Bribery Case
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 9Kaufman & Broad, Inc., the largest builder of private homes in the nation, was fined $50,000 in United States District Court today after, pleading no contest to charges of conspiracy and the bribery of former village officiels in suburban Hoffman Estates.

title: A RIFT WITH EUROPE DISCOUNTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  United States officials today discounted reported differences between the United States and Europe on a new Atlantic charter and expressed irritation at publication of American draft proposals tor a joint declaration.

title: JEWS CITE RISE IN INTERMARRIAGE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9About one out of three American Jews who married in recent Years had a nonJew for a mate, a new demographic study of the American Jewish community disclosed today. But the study, commissioned by the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, also reported that a large majority of the intermarried couples were rearing and educating their children as Jews. The study was released at the 42nd annual general assembly at the Marriott Hotel.

title: A Call to Republicans
description: With his defiant reply to calls for his resignation, President Nixon has made it easier for Congress to move ahead with the impeachment process. Such a course should not, however, preclude the possibility that Mr. Nixon may change his mind and avail himself of the opportunity of sparing the nation the protracted agony of Congressional investigation and trial.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fire Kills 3 in Brooklyn Apartment

title: Memory Loss Linked to Electroshocks
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 9  Repeated electroconvulsive shock treatments, commonly used to treat severe mental depression, can impair a patient's memory of longpast events, according to a report at a brain research meeting here.

title: $65Million Street Value EstimatedPlot Began in Atlanta Penitentiary
description: A lawyer, a carpenter and a convict were found guilty in Federal Court here yesterday as participants in a conspiracy that Federal authorities said was responsible for smuggling 600 kilograms of heroin, o?? more than 1,300 pound, into New York.

title: NIXON SPEED CURB COMES UNDER FIRE
description: Confused and angry bus and truck operators mounted strong protests yesterday to the 50mileanhour speed limit President Nixon proposed to save energy, saying it would mean expensive schedule changes and even burn up more gasoline because, engines were designed to run at higher speeds.

title: Sextuplets' Parents Find That Multiple Births No Longer Lead to Instant Wealth
description: DENVER, Nov. 9  Two months after his wife gave birth to sextuplets, Eugene Stanek a 31yearold accountant, is finding that multiple births do not reap the financial bonanza they used to.

title: Egypt Is Firm on Accord Despite Israeli Questions
description: CAIRO, Nov. 9  Egypt stood firm tonight on her acceptance of an AmericanEgyptian agreement on ceasefire arrangements on the EgyptianIsraeli front despite reports that the Israeli Government was seeking further assurances about it.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE NOTEBOOKS OF MARTHA GRAHAM. Introduction by Nancy Wilson Ross. 464 pies. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich $25.

title: Bridge: GrandSlam Hands Come Up Oftener Than Most Relieve
description: Most players underestimate the frequency of slam hands. A hand in the slam zone should appear about once in every 10 deals, so there should be two or three in the course of an average evening. But of course the fates may decree that in a particular evening you receive a wealth of slams or none at all.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Congressional Election Set
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP)A special election to fill the United States House of Representatives seat of the late Representative John P. Saylor. Republican of Pennsylvania, will be held Feb. 5, 1974, Goy. Milton J. Shapp's office said yesterday.

title: Rocket Repairs on Skylab Fall Behind
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 9  Launching crews uncovered more traces of corrosion on the Saturn rocket today and fell behind in their efforts to replace the eight cracked tail fins in time to get the Skylab 3 mission under way Thursday.

title: Dr. Harold Ehrensperger Dies; Active in Theater and Religion
description: GILMANTON, N. H., Nov. 9 Dr. Harold Ehrensperger, a professor emeritus at Boston University, died on ninday.

title: Grape and Lettuce Boycott to Widen
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 Cesar Chavez said today that the United Farm Workers Union was expanding its boycott of grape and lettuce growers from 32 cities to 65 cities and was preparing to put 1,000 more union members to work on the boycott.

title: Political Sheath on the Arab Oil Weapon
description: PARIS, Nov. 9 While the progress toward peace in the Middle East as a result of the Kissinger mission is not expected to have any immediate effect on the Arab oil embargo, there are a variety of other ressures on the Arab states, political as well as economic, not to carry that embargo too far. The embargo has limited aims: to enforce a mildly proArab policy in Europe and to get the United States to ease, its support of Israel. And the shortage of petroleum now being felt in Europe, Japan and the United States shows that the Arabs are dead serious.

title: STARS ON MIR TOES FOR BALLET BENEFIT
description: All my life I've wanted to be in a real ballet, said Gwen Verdon, and on Sunday night she will be. Like other stage and television personalities, Miss Verdon will appear in a special version of the wedding act of The Sleeping Beauty with Dame Margot. Fonteyn and the National Ballet of Washington.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Campus Notes
description: New York University is trying to account for about $40,000 worth of equipment missing in its move from its former University Heights Campus to its central facilities in Washington Square.

title: Candidate Role Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The United States Supreme Court has upheld New Hampshire's sevenyear residency requirement for gubernatorial candidates. The Court affirmed a ruling by a threejudge Federal panel that held that the requirement was a minimal infringement.

title: Robert Thomason, 94, Dies; ExCongressman, U.S. Judge
description: EL PASO, Tex., Nov. 9 (UPI)Robert Ewing Thomason, who moved to El Paso for his health in 1912, and became its mayor, speaker of the Texas House, member of the House of Representatives and United States district judge, died yesterday at the age of 94.

title: Cut Speed Voluntarily, Rockefeller Urges Drivers
description: Governor Rockefeller yesterday urged that motorists in New York State voluntarily reduce speed limits to 50 miles per hour wherever possible, as requested by President Nixon as a way to conserve energy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1973

title: Connors, Okker Gain Semifinals In $75,000 Stockholm Tennis
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 9 (UPI) Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., swept aside the challenge of Manuel Orantes of Spain today when he won a battle of lefthanders, 62, 61, to gain the semifinals of the $75,000 Swedish open indoor tennis championship.

title: Bumper Grain Crop In Soviet Is Causing Woes, Pravda Says
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9  The Soviet press indicated today for the first time that the Soviet Union might be having trouble coping with this year's bumper grain harvest.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the cold swirl of Shea Stadium yesterday, the wind was blowing harder than Joe Namath could throw. When he warmed up, with a gray hood above his green satin jacket, he was pushing the ball, not whipping it easily. And later, out of three passes in a practice drill, he twice. threw into the hard worn grass in front of the receiver.

title: Kissinger Fails to Sway Saudis From Oil Embargo
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 9Secretary of State Kissinger has been unable to obtain a relaxation of Saudi Arabia's oil embargo on the United States but he bas reportedly convinced King Faisal of his sincerity in the search for peace in the Middle East.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Grumman Corporation has received a $28.1million addition to a previouslyannounced Navy contract for F14A carrierbased fighter planes.

title: Bullets That Killed Oakland Educator Contained Cyanide
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 9The Alameda County coroner's office said today that the bullets used in the ambush slaying of Marcus Foster, the school superintendent, on Tuesday contained cyanide.

title: 76ers Defeat Knicks
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9What will the Knicks think of next?

title: Guggenheim Modifies Alteration
description: The Guggenheim Museum, which set off a storm of controversy with its decision last winter to add a tearoom and visitors lobby to the front of its building, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, on Fifth Avenue, has altered its plans considerably in the face of widespread protest from architects, planners and residents of the surrounding Upper East Side community.

title: Woodall Is Sharp as Jets Prepare for Patriots
description: Joe Namath, his head shrouded by a hooded sweat shirt, threw three official passes yesterday at the New York Jets practice in cold Shea Stadium, tossed a dozen or two more on the sidelines. did a few leg exercises and, then called it a day.

title: CITY IS SUCCEEDING IN EFFORTS TO AID STRUCK HOSPITALS
description: The city claimed some success yesterday in its, stopgap efforts to help 48 metropolitanarea hospitals and nursing homes struck last Monday by Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union, as the union continued to defy courtimposed fines.

title: Prices of Stocks Plummet; Dow Industrials Sink 24.24
description: Stock prices plummeted yesterday in the biggest singleday decline since the massive market break known as Black Monday on May 28, 1962. Trading volume remained moderate at 17.32 million shares.

title: Roads to Vietnam City Appear to Be Cut
description: GIA NGHIA, South Vietnam, Nov. 9  Communist forces have apparently cut all roads leading to this provincial capital in the Central Highlands 105 miles northeast of Saigon.

title: C. Arnholt Smith: A Fortune at Stake in Bank Failure
D.I.C. to Proceed On British Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (Reuters)British bankers meeting with, United States officials here have expressed concern over the International implications of the failure of the United States National Bank of San Diego, a Federal Reserve Board spokesman said today.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I have just phoned the insurance company. It is as thought. They will not pay any part of the $840 it will cost to stop the secondfloor bathroom from leaking into the firstfloor living room.

title: Bus Systems Fear Fuel Rationing Will Cut Service Just, as Riders Are Returning
description: Transit systems across the country say that Federal rationing of diesel bus fuel is threatening to curtail their operations just as many have begun to halt their loss of riders to the automobile.

title: Progress Is Reported in Talks Aimed at Getting New Milk Pact
description: Progreis was reported yesterday in negotiations between wholesale milk distributors and Local 584 4of the International Brotherh of Teamsters on a new contract teat is expected to increase the cost of milk to consumers in the metropolitan The present twoYear contract area. between the Greater New York Milk Dealers Labor Committee and Local 584 expires at 4 P.M. today. Although the union has not scheduled a strike, it has long had a no contract, no work policy and struck the dealers for one day two years ago. Earlier Rise Cited Involved In the talks at the

title: Truckers Assail New U.S. Pollution Curb
description: EAST BRUNSWICK  The state's trucking Industry says that new Federal regulations designed to control air quality in New Jersey, will cause enormous disruptions in the longestablished shipping and receiving patterns of hundreds of industrial and commercial enterprises in the northern part of the state.

title: Helicopter Is Helping To Protect Wetlands
description: TRENTONTwice a month a helicopter chops its way through the New Jersey skies, its crew performing one of the state's newest and most extensive environmenta policing jobs.

title: Garven: Heritage of Reform
description: TRENTONIn what may become his legacy to New Jersey's judicial system, Pierre. P. Garver, the late Chief Justice of the State Supreme. Court, urged Municipal Court judges to accept reforms or face removal from the bench.

title: Carol Hannum Engaged
description: UNIONVILLE, Pa., Nov. 10 United States District Judge John B. Hannum of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Hannum have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Averell Hannum, to Bruce Davidson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Davidson of South Westport, Mass. The wedding is planned for Jan. 5 at the Christ Episcopal Church in Philadelphia. The father of the future bridegroom is a mechanical engineer.

title: The Iceman Cometh Too Close
description: FROM the opening frames of John Frankenheimer's film version of Eugene O'Neill's The Iceman Cometh, you get the feeling that you're being taken on a guided tour of one of the greatest American plays ever written, instead of seeing a screen adaptation with a life of its own.

title: Village in Vietnam
description: LONG TRACH, South Vietnam. Mrs. Nguyen Thi Le, a slight, stooped peasant woman, lives alone in her large brick house now, surrounded only by endless fields of green rice ripening under the relentless sun. Many years agoshe does not recall exactlyshe shared the house and worked in the fields with a husband and five sons. They have all been claimed by the war, and, more recently, by what is called peace.

title: The Presidential Controversy
description: To the Editor: Now that the august Times has culminated its schedule of everincreasing dramatization of the Nixon business by asking for his resignation, especially to avoid the traumatic and divisive process of impeachment proceedings [editorial Nov. 4], perhaps your editors will come to the realization that you are as devious and calculating as is, ;undoubtedly, the President.

title: Sports Today
description: CROSSCOUNTRY

title: Scientist Describes New Device That Controls Artificial Arm
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 10An artificial arm that works by the same almostautomatic mental control that governs natural arm movements was described at a meeting of brain research scientists here today.

title: News of the Camera World
Arms (the Civil War) and the man (the American writer)
description: Daniel Aaron's third book, like its predecessors, Men of Good Hope (1950) on the American Progressives and Writers on the Left (1961) on the parr played by our writers in the American Stalinist movement, deals with the relation of individuals to grave social issues. Aaron has steadily maintained, despite the continuing erosion of political awareness and dedication among writers, and the diversion of critical energies into new criticism, myth criticism and so on, the possibility and value of seeing thinkers and writers in the context of their engagement with society and politics. He has tried to keep alive the hope of the Progressives for rational institutional change that would fulfill the original promises of an society of free men.

title: Son to Joseph Dowlings
description: ARLINGTON, Mass., Nov. 10A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. John Joseph Dowling on Oct. 26 at the Boston LyingIn Hospital. The child has been named. Timothy Darche.

title: Housing Department Is Studied on Charges of Job Favoritism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10A Federal investigation has begun into charges that high officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development violated the law by appointing political favorites to career civil service jobs.

title: WALTER W. GLOCER
description: Walter W. Glocer, founder and president of Tricoma, Inc., importers and distributors of knitting machinery, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 993 Park Avenue.

title: Scientists to Help Indochina Recover From Deforestation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Plans to establish a research institute of agricultural botany in North Vietnam to help Indochina recover from the effects of deforestation and other war damages were disclosed this week by a group of American scientists.

title: Travels Through Jewish America
description: Harry Golden, through nearly 20 books, has rambled back and forth across his own history and times, an inexhaustible, shrewd, matzo ball philosopher, breezy, deeply unruffled and garrulous. He is also liberal, funny, concerned, indulgent and relaxed. How can anyone avoid reading him in the spirit with which he offers himself? Only if every word is thought to be precious Wand holy. If words are holy, Golden uses them too looselybut be would be the first to grant that he's not a holy man. If he had any patience with the argument, he might add that words are the tools of play and only fragile and sanctified in use by the great poets and prophets.

title: QUESTIONS
description: If you have a question, or know the answer to a question asked in these columns, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. We will publish questions of general interest and the practical solutions. Please enclose a stamped seyaddressed envelope.

title: Police Officer Held in Killing Of Woman in Bronx Home
description: A Transit Police lieutenant with 18 years on the force allegedly shot and killed woman the police described as his commonlaw wife with his 38caliber service revolver yesterday afternoon.

title: Bergen Hears Blake on Unity
description: PARAMUSThe only hope for the future of the organized church lies in the ultimate reunion of Christianity, according to one of the world's leading ecumenists.

title: Academy A Regional Film Center
description: The American Film Institute, founded in 1967 to preserve the heritage and advance the art of film in America, has established a regional center at the Brooklyn Academy, of Music.

title: The Management Doctors
description: One of them gives corpomations the ABC's of antidiscrimination laws.

title: Skiing the Andes and Drawing Fire From the Border Patrol
description: WE have been climbing for six hours since early morning but the spectacular snowcovered Chilean Andes still tower above us. There are seals strapped to, our skis. The lay of the fur prevents the skis from sliding backward as we climb. It is silent and desolate, up here at 13,000 feet, with the soft sound of the wind whistling through faraway valleys. It is a word of sharp contrasts: the brilliant sun, the blindingly white snow, the clear blue sky and the fierce, craggy peaks.

title: Clifton Trounces Passaic Valley, 39 to 0
description: Unbeaten Clifton combined a powerful ground attack with the effective passing of Dale Oostdyk yesterday to knock Passaic Valley out of the undefeated ranks 390, in Little Falls.

title: Oil ShortageThe Economy's New Puzzle
description: WASHINGTONLast Tuesday, exactly a month after the eruption of war in the Middle East and a day before President Nixon's energy message, the. Administration started an urgent study to try to find out whether the output and employment of the American economy in 1974 would be held back not for the familiar reason of deficient demand but because of a shortage of petroleum.

title: STRUCK HOSPITALS MANAGE TO COPE FOR ANOTHER DAY
description: The 48 metropolitanarea hospitals and nursing homes struck since Monday functioned at reduced occupancy and were continuing to turn away all but urgent cases. The overall situation was quiet, city officials said, as pickets allowed most deliveries of essential material.

title: Celestial interloper
description: After all that 1973 has brought so far, what can we expect next? Well, would you believe a comet? A big one. It's called Kohoutek (CoeHOEtek), after its discoverer, and it should start being visible through binoculars about the middle of November and to the naked eye in early December. From midDecember to midJanuary, it should be the brightest object in the night sky apart from the full moon. Those early appearances will be very low in the southsoutheast (better take up position atop the World Trade Center) just before sunrise (bring a Thermos of black coffee). By January, it will be high in the southwest sky, just after sunset. Much easier to cope with.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Almost everyone is talking about the energy crisis (roughly defined as the shortage of gasoline and fuel oil) and we are being urged to do something about it, from unscrewing the unneeded light bulb to turning off the furnace to  heaven help us  selling the family station wagon.

title: Andover Triumphs; Lewis Scores Two
description: EXETER, N.H.Andover took advantage of an early Exeter mistake for one touchdown, then rolled to a 320 victory today in below freezing weather. It was the 93d meeting of the schools.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Kehler Runs Revive Westfield
description: Westfield, its 48game unbeaten streak ended a week ago by Montclair, returned to winning form yesterday with a 466 victory over Linden in Westfield.

title: MAJOR GAS STATE FACES A SHORTAGE
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 10Gov. Edwin W. Edwards is considering convening an emergency session of the Legislature in an effort to keep more Louisiana natural gas for use in this state.

title: Namath Likely Absentee
description: While virtually everybody else focused on Joe Namath's right arm during the last week to see if he would be ready to play aginst New England today, the Jets worked on polishing their running attack. That is the most likely weapon for beating the Patriotsif the Jets are good enough to beat the Patriots.

title: WomenWatching in East Africa
description: The females are always the hunters, our, guide says as we watch six lionesses tear away at the massive hulk of an elephant that has just been killed by a cobra in Kenya's MasaiAmbosei Game Reserve. A lion with a kill is one of the most gory, yet compelling, sights to be seen in Africa, but as look on horified, the guide's words penetrate my raised feminist consciousness. Thus is set a sort of theme for my threeweek stay in Africa: observations of wildlife interspersed with glimpses of the status of African women.

title: Harrison Tops Rye, Avenges Last Loss
description: Harrison avenged yesterday its only loss in two seasons by defeating Rye, 208, in their 42d meeting before 12,000 fans at Rye Stadium. Coach Art Troilo's team, unbeaten in eight games, ended Rye's 15game streak, won the Central Westchester League title and assured itself a Section 1 playoff berth.

title: Public Whets Its Taste for Apple Cider
description: TRENTONNot since the eighteenforties, when apple brandy, also called Jersey Lightning, was in its heyday, has apple juice enjoyed such popularity.

title: Williams Routs Wesleyan, 44 to 0
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 10A hardcharging offense and a stingy opportunistic defense led Williams to a 440 victory over Wesleyan, today, setting up the Little Three showdown next Saturday between Amherst and the Ephmen in Williamstown. Both squads have now defeated Wesleyan.

title: Mozambique Slum Clearance
description: BEIRA, Mozambique, Nov. 10 (AP)A sixyear, $40million slum clearance program is scheduled to begin early in 1974 in the Portuguese territory of Mozambique in East Africa.

title: The Profligate Society
description: The most profligate society in history received a rude awakening last week when President Nixon warned Americans they must face the very stark fact [that] we are heading toward the most acute shortages of energy since World War II.

title: Life and death of the great African cats
description: One of the truly heartening developments in our times has been the sharply rising public appreciation of the importance of ecology that has marked the last decade, and most particularly the last five years. One of the major by products of the years of lunar exploration, indeed, may well prove to have been the sudden appreciation, by very many people in many different walks of life, of the fragility of our lonely planet, which it is so much within human power, now, to conserve or to destroy.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON, in a televised address on the energy crisis, asked Congress to pass an emergency act before it recesses in December. The act would empower him to relax environmental standards, reduce speed limits, regulate transportation schedules, impose yearround daylight saving time and provide contingency plans for rationing gasoline. . . . Congress began working to give the President many of these powers.... Many states reduced temperatures in stateowned buildings. Industry reacted by taking steps to cut back on its use of energy, but several executives said the, President's action was too late and too weak.

title: ParkingLot SoloCross Offers a Different Twist
description: Mrs. Gayle Schilling of Far Rockaway was having trouble with her 5yearold son's buttons and her car's gear box. Alan Meschkow, 28, an artist, also from Far Rockaway, had problems remembering where to turn on the parking Jot. Pete Rehm, 21, of Basking Ridge, N. J., was feeling slightly guilty about waking up at 7:30 in the morning and driving all the way to that parking lot outside Long Beach, L. I., instead of studying for a test the next morning at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: CONFLICT IN GOALS ON HEALTH NOTED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10An implicit conflict in goals developed among health professionals who examined the current and future state of medical services at the 101st annual meeting of the American Public Health Association here.

title: Lindquist Sets Record In Title CrossCountry
description: BINGHAMTON, Nov. 10In weather more conducive to skiing than running, Gary Lindquist of Bellmore, LI., completed an unbeaten crosscountry season today with a record breaking victory in the state intersectional crosscountry championships at the State University campus here.

title: MAIN OPERATIONS OF APPLETON SOLD
description: The principal operations of one of the country's oldest publishing companies, AppletonCenturyCrofts, have been sold by its parent concern for $5.5million to PrenticeHall, Inc., of Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayNorth Shore Equestrian Center, C.W. Post College show grounds, Northern Boulevard, Greenvale, L. I. Green and junior working hunters, preliminary jumpers, ponies, equitation. 9 A.M.

title: New Orleans Voters Renominate Mayor; Garrison in Runoff
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 10 (UPI)  Mayor Moon Landrieu easily won renomination today, gaining almost 70 per cent of the votes in his Democratic primary, but District Attorney Jim Garrison was forced into a runoff against a former Federal prosecutor, Harry Connick.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Unusual Showing Of English Prints
description: Crowds have been pouring into the Brooklyn Museum to see the remarkable Akhenaten and Nefertiti exhibition but have been missing another worthwhile show. On the museum's second floor is a show of. English prints and drawings from the 18thcentury to the present that merits the attention of visitors for its selectivity and quality.

title: I'm Not Even a Tough Cop
description: LOS ANGELES. IN the daylight hours between 8:30, when Joseph Wambaugh begins his working day, and 4:30, when he points his new Cadillac toward Pasadena and drives home to the elegant suburb of San Marino where he lives with his wife, Dee, and their two sons in comfort bought by the success of his two bestselling novels, The New Centurions and The Blue Knight, he works, as he has for the past 13 years, as a cop.

title: Yale Wins As a Pass Fools Penn
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 10Yale scored last on a trick play, a pass from a halfback to a quarterback, and defeated Pennsylvania today, 2421, thus knocking Penn out of a tie for first place in the ivy League, which Harvard and Dartmouth continued to share.

title: News Summary and Index
2 SHOT IN HOLDUP OF M'DONALD'S HERE
description: The manager and assistant manager of a McDonald's restaurant near Madison Square Garden were shot last night during a holdup, according to the police, who said, two of the four robbers were later arrested when their getaway car was spotted in Harlem.

title: Grambling Wins Eighth
description: NORFOLK, Va. Nov. 10 (UPI)Sammy White caught one touchdown pass and ran for another score today as powerful Grambling routed Norfolk State, 326. It was the eighth victory in 10 games for Grambling.

title: 28,108 Fans At Aqueduct Despite TV
description: Secretariat was back in the barn at Belmont yesterday preparing for his final trip home to Kentucky, and most of the other big horses were at Laurel racing the invaders from Europe.

title: The President
description: WASHINGTONIt was hardly the happy anniversary he might have envisioned. Only a year earlier, on Nov 7, 1972, a jubilant Richard Nixon had fairly bounced into the Regency Room of the Shoreham Hotel, grinning, flashing upraised fingers in his Vforvictory signal, and savoring What he told cheering partisans may be the greatest victory in American political history.

title: In France, It's Called St. Trop in the Snow
description: COURCHEVEL, FranceStaying at a hotel in snobbish Gstaad is strictly outr; if you go there you're supposed to own your own chalet, preferably one big enough to have a bowling alley. In St. Moritz, it is permissible to stay in a hotel, but only in one: the Palace, where you might even spot the Aga Khan. Each of the Palace Hotel's suites has four buttons: one for the chambermaid, one for the porter and one for the waiter. The fourth will summon your personal valet. If you can't pay the bill for pushing the fourth button, but are used to pushing the other three, and don't own a chalet in Gstaad, then Courchevel is the place for you.

title: PARIS DENOUNCED FOR WIRETAPPING
description: PARIS, Nov. 10The Government taps 1,000 to 5,000 telephones every day in France on a permanent or spot basis, almost all of them illegally, according to a Senate report just made public.

title: The Riverside Villas Murder
description: I acquired a taste for the traditional English detective story when I was 13. The headmaster of my boarding school read an Agatha Christie aloud to us on Sundays in installments, and, as anything outside routine boarding school is bliss, and Agatha Christie's skill was impressive, I became hooked on murders at country houseparty weekends from my thirteenth to my fifteenth years. I then dropped the whole genre overboank And, I must say that a recent visit to Sleuth at a London theater filled me not with nostalgia, but with an angry boredom at all the time I had wasted so long ago. I echo another Wilson  who cares who killed Roger Ackroyd?

title: State Panels on Women Split
description: TRENTON  After three years of confusion and occasional acrimony the New Jersey State Commission on Women is drafting legislation that would abolish the state's Office on Women.

title: Columbia Beaten, 246
description: Dartmouth pushed over touchdowns in the opening seconds of the first and secand periods yesterday and went on to beat Columbia, 246, and stay tied for the Ivy League lead with Harvard.

title: Penn State Rally Beats N.C. State
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 10  Bill Ward, the chairman of the Orange Bowl selection committee, said today, The indications are very strong that we will have Penn State and Louisiana State.

title: Epilogue
description: The special milk progranit that was drastically reduced by the Department of Agriculture last July has now been restored under pressure from a protesting Congress and school officials. The program, intended to provide $97.1 worth of snacktime milk for all school children, was reduced to $25 million by the department and limited to those schools not participating in regular, lunchtime plans. The full amount will now be available for reimbursement of school districts providing milk at snack breaks, whether or not they are also receiving Federal funds for the distribution of lunchtime milk.

title: Legislature: Last of the Old
description: TRENTONFaced with resolving a number of highly controversial issues, the lameduck Legislature reconvenes here tomorrow for what promises to be one of the most significant postelection sessions in recent New Jersey political history.

title: Please Pass The Guilt
description: His name is Nero Wolfe. You may have heard of him. Is he on TV? Miss Foltz inquired. Don't be silly, Miss Dowd told her. How could he be? He's real. Some who have watched the Sam Ervin show, for instance, may well agree with Miss Dowd's notion of appearance and reality. Nero Wolfe, his assistant Archie Goodwin, his chef Fritz Brenner and Theodore Horstmann, the orchid valet, who live (except Theodore) and work in the old brownstone on Thirtyfifth Street are by now quite as real as ever Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson were at 221B Baker Street.

title: CALIFORNIA LOOKS TO GOVERNOR RACE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10Political attention in California shifted this week away from Gov. Ronald Reagan, whose tax limitation plan was soundly defeated in a special election, and into a fuzzy focus on next year's race for Governor.Mr. Reagan has often said that he will not run for a third fouryear term.

title: Margaret Heidbreder Is Married
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Nov. 10Miss Margaret Aim Heidbreder of New York was married here this afternoon to Dr. Arthur M. Eastman, head of the English depart nient at the CarnegieMellon University. The ceremony was performed in the Traverse City Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Donald W. Ferguson.

title: Fewer Heart Attacks for Drinkers in One Study
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 (AP)  Drinkers had fewer heart attacks than teetotalers in a large California study, the American Heart Association was told today.

title: Karen Larsen, Social Worker, Wed in Jersey
description: PRINCETON; N.J. Nov. 10 Miss Karen Ruth Larsen, daughter of Mrs. Henry Bertram Larsen of Sioux City, Iowa, and the late Mr. Larsen, was maried here this afternoon to Dr. Michael A. Giuliano, son of Superior Court Judge James R. Giuliano and Mrs. Giuliano of Newark and Spring Lake.

title: No Room at Top: Six Tied for First
description: After yesterdays action six of the teams in Nassau County South. Shore. Division III are right back where they were when the season started tied for first place. They are, in alphabetical order so no one gets even more confusedare Elmont, Hempstead, Malverne, New Hyde Park, South Side and Valley Stream South. Their wonloss records are 52 with one game to go.

title: An Architect Lends His Good Offices to the Underground
description: CHERRY HILL  From Route 70, the passerby sees only a patch of grass and shrubbery, plus a circular brick driveway. Little does he know that beneath the earth's surface lies a novel experiment: a spacious, sunny suite or underground offices.

title: Lobbying in Midtown Manhattan
description: FOR stayathome Manhattanites and for visitors to Manhattan who like to do their traveling on foot, I can recommend no better offbeat and free sightseeing trip than a stroll through the blocks of monoliths that stand sentinel along the west side of the Avenue of the Americas from 48th to 55th Streets These monoliths are office buildings, of course, but, more than that, they are mysterious civilizations, serene compact continents surrounded by an ocean of noise, dirt, people and cars. They are waiting to be explored by anyone with a long lunch hour to spare, and they need not be explored by walking up or down the Avenue of the Americas and popping into the buildings. They can be walked through, one after the other, in an almost straight line, with the sightseer popping out into the open just to traverse the cross streets from one lobby to the next.

title: Mrs. Anderson Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence. L. Anderson Jr. of Cincinnati on Oct. 24 in the Fort Hamilton Hospital In Hamilton, Ohio. Mrs. Anderson is the former Miss Lee Edwards of Rumson, N.J. The child, the couple's fifth, has been named Tobias Belford.

title: Yorty Is Target of 2 Inquiries Into '69 Los Angeles Land Deal
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 A Federal grand jury and a City Council committee here are looking into allegations of wrongdoing and misconduct on the part of several high city officials, including the former Deputy Mayor and former Mayor Sam Yorty.

title: PARLEY SOMBER AT RABBI'S DEATH
description: The mood was somber, but the spirit to carry on was quietly evident yesterday as the Union of American Hebrew Congregations ended the second day of its fiveday biennial convention in the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Dream Tax Exploded
description: California voters, not invariably immune to the bizarre nostrums of ambitious politicians, showed good sense last week in emphatically rejecting Gov.Ronald Reagan's scheme for shrinking state spending and state income taxes by constitutional amendment. In doing so, they dealt a blow to the 1976 Presidential ambitions of the Governor, who had expected to exploit his dream tax package heavily in his drive for the Republican nomination.

title: THEATER OPENINGS
description: THE FOURSOMETomorrow, Astor Place Theater, 7. A play by E. A. Whitehead.

title: Sisco Meets Lebanese Aides And Reports Productive Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10 (REUTERS)  Joseph J. Sisco, the United States State Department's top expert on Mideast affairs, met tonight with Lebanese officials for more than two hours to discuss prospects for peace.

title: Pope Holds Special Rites Preparing for Holy Year
description: ROME, Nov. 10Pope Paul VI left the Vatican by car tonight to officiate at a special service in, the ancient Basilica of St. John Lateran, his cathedral in his capacity as Bishop of Rome.

title: PENALTY FOR LBaM1 IS CUT $93MILW0N
description: A. Federal judge who found the International Business Machines Corporation in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act announced yesterday that he had reduced the amount, of damages to be assessed against the company from $352.5million to $259.5million.

title: Judith Van Ingen Plans Nuptials
description: MANHASSET, L. I. Nov. 10Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Van Ingen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Van Ingen; to Robert Alan Miness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Miness of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Hegemony, Hasty Flyer Are Victors
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 (AP)Hasty House Farm's Hasty Flyer and Herbert Allen's Hegemony won divsions of the split 1 1/16mile Garden State Juvenile Stakes today at Atlantic City Race Course.

title: Air Force Passes Down Rutgers, 3114
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Nov. 10 (AP)The Air Force quarterback, Rich Haynie, threw for three touchdowns to engineer a 3114 football victory over Rutgers today.

title: Mary Glover Is Fiancee of David Forer
description: LOCUST, N. J., Nov. 10The engagement of Miss Mary Adelaide Glover to David Brett Forer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Harvey Glover, parexits of the future bride. Her finance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Forer of New York and (Locust. An early spring wedding is planned.

title: Montclair Snaps Brick's Streak at 24
description: Montclair, Summit and Bloomfield scored important victories yesterday to improve their bids for state rankings in New Jersey.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONAlmost exactly 300 years ago, King Charles II, his reign troubled by rumors of popish plots, was forced by the English Parliament to give up his warring in the Netherlands to win new levies to replenish his treasury.

title: Growing old alone together
description: BERKELEY, Calif.To enter RossmoorWalnut Creek you must first stop at the gatehouse, where a uniformed guard asks whom you want to see. the resident you name has not left word at the gate beforehand, the guard will make a telephone check. After that, he will give you a small map of Rossmoor on which he will mark the address you are looking for and the route you should take, and he will gently remind you to park in the areas marked Visitors' Parking and not on the streets. Only then are you free to enter the peaceful 2,200acre valley, which was once part of a lush ranch and now the site of a retirement community of condominium apartments housing some 7,000 people near the San Francisco Bay area.

title: COURTROOM CALM AT CHICAGO TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 10In an atmosphere of studied calm, the contempt trial of two lawyers and five of the defendants in the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial of 1969 ended its second week yesterday with several more charges against the lawyers being dropped and with testimony by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark that the 1969 trial should never have been held.

title: Moral Paralysis
description: It right is to prevail, the line between right and wrong that has become so badly blurred must first be redrawn. Too many of the current public arguments, and particularly the statements emanating from the White House, have the effect of further erasing that line.

title: Something of Algren for everyone
description: It's about time! When we've got a living American writer as surefooted and as fast off the mark as Nelson Algren, it's almost criminal not to have something of his in hard covers at least once a year, to heft and roar at and revel in. Having, early in his career, ceded the Chicago territory to Sandburg, Farrell and Algren, Ernest Hemingway later paid our man the ultimate tribute: Mr. Algren can hit with both hands and move around and he will kill you if you are not awfully careful. Was he, like Seymour Glass, never wrong?

title: Point of View
description: In a Point of View article published Oct. 14, Lewis H. Spence, executive director of the housing authority in Somerville, Mass., criticized the Nixon Administration's plans to adopt housing allowances to the poor as a major vehicle of Federal housing policy. In the following article, a member of the staff of the Hudson Institute, who is also a consultant to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, defends the Nixon policy.

title: Dance
description: IN a collection of her notices published a year or so ago, a critic who can remain nameless opened a review with the words: A balletomane is a person who reacts instantly if a step has been changed in a ballet, even if he hasn't seen the ballet in years. I am not one. She then goes to explain that she is unequipped to discern, describe or evaluate the differences between two productions of a standard classic.

title: Problems Plaguing Newark's Anticrime Plan
description: NEWARK  After five months on the job, Hubert Williams, director of the city's federally financed High Impact Anticrime Program, is finding that its campaign to curb crime has been slowed by a host of problems, ranging from interagency conflicts to small but annoying internal crises.

title: The Small Town
description: Ask almost anyone, even government policymakers, what is happening to the American small town and the answer will quite likely be: It is dying, or is already dead. Like the nickel beer and free parking, the small town, the nation's bedrock, is universally accounted among the late and much lamented.

title: Miss Henschel To Be a Bride
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Nov. 10Mr. and Mrs. George F. Henschel hate announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Louise Henschel, to Clifton D. Willard, son of the Rev. and Mrs. C. Lawson Willard of New Haven.

title: After Retirement, A Plunge Into Growing Activity
description: FAR from being a stopgap measure to ward off boredom, retired people with home greenhouses often find themselves plunged into fulltime activity.

title: Colgate Pins 4942 Defeat on W. and M.
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 10 (UPI)Mark Van Eeghen and John Anderson scored three touchdowns each to pace Colgate to a 4942 victory over William and Mary today.

title: Groton Victor By 1410
description: SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Nov. 10  Will Bundy squeezed through on a 2yard run in the last minutes today to give Groton a 1410 victory over St. Mark's. Groton leads in the series with 51 victories, 29 losses and 4 ties.

title: Fashion Show for the Elderly
description: Although he has little interest in fashion and hates shopping in department stores, Stephen Siegel runs a traveling department store for nursing home residents.

title: Colleges Vie to Get Psychology School
description: PISCATAWAY  Rutgers University and the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey are vying to establish a Graduate School of Practical Psychology.

title: Army Loses 8th Game to Miami, 197
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 10With one eye on its next opponentNo. 2ranked Alabamaand one eye on the task at band, Army, the University of Miami, almost by instinct, handed the Cadets their eighth straight defeat, 197, today.

title: What's Opened In the Theater?
description: MOLLY, a musical based on The Goldbergs by Gertrude Berg, with book by Louis Garfinkle and Leonard Adelson, music by Jerry Livingston and lyrics by Mr. Adelson and Mack David, got four mixed reviews (Barnes, Times; Watts, Post; Lewis, Bergen Record; Sanders, WABCTV) and 17 negative reviews (Watt, News; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gaver, UPI; Harris, WCBSTV; Stewart Klein, WNEWTV; Bookspan; WPIXTV; Probst, WNBCRadio; Alvin Klein, WNYCRadio; Woodruff, WMCARadio; Kalem, Time; Gill, New Yorker; Kroll, Newsweek; Simon, New York; Stasio, Cue).

title: Carol J. Renneburg Is Bride in Maryland
description: GIBSON ISLAND, Md., Nov. 10Miss Carol Jane Renneburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Norris Renneburg of Baltimore, and Randall Nicoll Pratt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pratt of Wilmington, Del., were martied here this noon in St. Christopher'sbytheSea Episcopal Church by the Rev. Peter Fulghum.

title: OAKLAND ARMY PUZZLES POLICE
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 10 Weary police officials here conceded today that they had no knowledge of the Symbionese Liberation Army, the group that says it is responsible for the ambush slaying of Oakland's school superintendent.

title: Patricia Sheeran to Wed
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 10 Dr. and Mrs. Archibald D. Sheeran have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Sheeran, to Richard A. Keenley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Keenley of Westport, Conn.

title: MRS. ALICE N. NAGER
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 10 Mrs. Alice Norton Nager, a portrait painter of Scarsdale, died toaty in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. She was 68 years old.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: City Council Schedule Is Listed for the Week
description: The following City Council sessions will be held this week:

title: Lifting of DDT Ban Sought in Poconos To Combat Moths
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Nov. 10 The Pocono Mountains Vacation Bureau, representing scores of resorts in this region, has started a campaign to appeal to Congress to have the Federal ban on DDT lifted temperarily to permit the spraying of area forests.

title: Meetings Scheduled On School Board Vote
description: Four public meetings have been scheduled to give candidates in the forthcoming school board election in Community School District 17 in Brooklyn a chance to present their views and answer questions about school issues. The election, to be held Nov. 27 in the Crown HeightsFlatbush district, was ordered by a state judge who found that the original election last May 1 was tainted by irregularities.

title: Sideburns Ouster Barred
description: MADISON, Wis., Nov. 10 (UPI)The Leverenz Shoe Company of Sheboygan has been ordered to reinstate an employe who was discharged because he refused to get his mutton chop sideburns gut to company standards. The Department of Industry, Labor and Human Relations ruled for Gregory Riker, who had sideburns longer than company policy allowed. It also said Mr. Riker should get back benefits and wages. He was dismissed in May, 1972.

title: It's a Shoeing Center, but Disguised
description: MYSTIC, Conn.No matter what anyone says, Olde Mistick Village is not an 18thcentury town but a brand new shopping center.

title: County Libraries Endangered
description: TRENTON  State public library officials are upset over the results of referendums last week in Burlington. Camden and Gloucester Counties. They view the votes as countering their hopes of establishing a strong county library system in New Jersey.

title: Kentucky Beats Vanderbilt
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 10 (UPI) Mike Fanuzzi passed for 138 yards and two touchdowns and Sonny Collins, the leading rusher in the Southeastern Conference, scored twice today as Kentucky won its fifth game in nine decisions, defeating Vanderbilt, 2717.

title: Mr. Kissinger's Mideast Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON  As Secretary of State Henry Kissinger completed his breathless race through the capitals of Islam, two images came to mind. One is of a speededup Charlie Chaplin movie in which Charlie desperately rushes around a collapsing house trying to prop up one wall while the others threaten to fall. The other is of a jigsawpuzzle solver determined to fit or force together the pieces of a puzzle that defies solution.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market, which has swung wildly this auturnn, made big news Friday when the DowJones industrial average plunged 24.24 points to register its biggest singleday decline since the 1962 break.

title: People and Business
description: Not long ago, Arthur Hasselbach had his own fleet of aircraft, which he operated from his own private airport near Cranberry, in Middlesex County. Today, the planes are gone and the airstrip, because of the development of industrial parks and other construction in the area, is inoperative.

title: They met as men in Rattigan's bar
description: The Gift quickly induces a sense of dj vu and predictability, which is unusual in a work with autobiographical overtones. Uniqueness of experience or perception is almost completely absent as Peter Hamill, fresh out of Navy boot camp, heads home to Brooklyn for the 1952 Christmas holidays. His girl, Kathleen, has stopped writing, and he worries whether they'll make up. Re also wonders when he and his brooding father will come to an understanding and meet as men in Rattigan's bar.

title: Israel Authorizes General to Sign the New CeaseFire Agreement With Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 10Premier Golda Meir announced tonight that her Government had authorized Maj. Gen. Aharon Yariv to sign the new ceasefire agreement with Egypt tomorrow.

title: CAPE COD FLIGHTS STUDIED BY C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10New Yorkers vacationing on Cape Cod next summer may not have the luxury of a jet flight between the two points as in the past, but they may have more flights to choose from.

title: Margaritondo Scores 3 As N. Arlington Wins
description: EMERSON, N.J., Nov. 10Vito Margaritondo, Bergen County's leading scorer before the game, scored three touchdowns to pace North Arlington to a 326 victory over Emerson Borough today.

title: The Kremlin, Reassessing Nixon Finds Him Still Operative
description: MOSCOWThe calls in the United States for President Nixon's resignation have puzzled and dismayed some important people in Moscow. Irritated as they may have been at Mr. Nixon's handling of the recent Middle East crisis, they still consider him preferableinsiders here make clearto any possible alternative in Washington as a partner for detente. At the same time, as political insurance, the Soviet leadership is preparing the Soviet public for a possible change in the White House and is putting some distance between itself and Mr. Nixon.

title: Some dilemmas of the churchman
description: The Catholic Andrew Greeley and the Protestant Martin Marty have many things in common: an identical birth date (Feb. 5, 1928Aquarius, no less), a common home ground (the University of Chicago and environs), at least one coauthored book (What We Believe, along with Stuart Rosenberg) and now a common publisher of two books about the state of religion in America.

title: FOOD OVERPRICING CITED BY SENATOR
description: Consumers were overcharged more than $2billion in 1972 because of monopolistic control of the food industry by 13 companies, according to Senator James Abourezk.

title: Fear of Flying
description: Isadore Zelda White Stollerman Wing, J.A.P. (Jewish American Poet), the narrator of Erica Jong's first novel, finds herself on a plane with her second husband, Bennett, a ChineseAmerican Freudian analyst, and 116 other psychoanalysts, as well as their families. Where are they going? To Vienna. Why? To attend a psychoanalytic convention right in Freud's old backyard. This convention is not called a convention, it's a Congress. You know what that means: An ideal beginning for the nightmare the trip was going to become.

title: The New York City Ballet
description: America is a land with singularly few wellestablished theatrical institutions. It grew up as a land with puritans rather than princes. Not only were there no court theaters, those precuraors of present  day national theaters all over continental Europe, but the country's early puritan ethics, inherited from the dissident English, positively frowned on theatrical folly. Interestingly, England, suffering from that same lingering puritanism and from the indifference of princes, also failed to institutionalize and stabilize its theater.

title: Kerr on Moonchildren
