title: Redskins Profit From 49ers' Errors and Win, 339
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Redskins found their missing offense today and crushed the San Francisco 49ers, 339, as Bill Kilmer passed for 267 yards. Subjected to straight defeats by New Orleans and Pittsburgh plus the growing skepticism of the local press, Washington won its sixth game and remained in a tie for first with Dallas in the National Conference's Eastern Division.

title: Bocks of the Times
description: MAD DUCKS AND BEARS; Football Revisited By George Plimpton. 421 pages. Random House, $7.95.

title: Mrs. Johnson Calls Husband's Methods WatergateProof
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that the Watergate scandal could not have happened during her husband's Administration because he minded every detail as best he could.

title: JURY EXEMPTIONS SCORED AS SEXIST
description: A class  action suit challenging the constitutionality of the New York State statute that allows women to exempt themselves for jury duty because they are women was scheduled to ourt be filed today in Federal Court.

title: LOUIS H. ROSOFF
description: Louis H. Rosoff, a retired certified public accountant, died here yesterday at the age of 87. His home was at 1150 Park Avenue.

title: Gas Chamber Used In Playground Area Near State Prison
description: CANON CITY, Colo., Nov. 11 (UPI)  Penal authorities looking for a use for an obsolete gas chamber have placed it in the playground outside the sandstone walls of the state penitentiary.

title: Atlanta Fans Sing A New Tune As Falcons Win Fifth Straight
description: Five weeks ago, Coach Norm Van Brocklin of the Atlanta Falcons was under heavy pressure from the home fans. They were screaming for his job as the Falcons lost for the third week in row and failed in each loss to score a touchown. Things have changed.

title: CHINA STORES RICE AGAINST DISASTER
description: CANTONChinese in the southern province of Kwangtong have heeded Chairman Mao Tsetung's injunction to dig tunnels deep and store grain everywhere.

title: Gen. Williston B. Palmer Dies; ExArmy Vice Chief of Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Gen. Williston B. Palmer, a former Vice Chief of Staff of the Army and the first director of military assistance of the Department of Defense, died yesterday in the Walter Reed Hospital. He would have been 74 years old today.

title: SUSPENSION ENDS FOR BLACK PUPILS
description: BERKELEY TOWNSHIP, Nov. 11  Thirteen black students, suspended from Central Regional High School more than a week ago, will return under court order tomorrow morning while school officials prepare to hold hearings to determine if new suspensions are justified.

title: Bucks Halt Bullets for 12thin Row
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md. Nov. 11 (AP)  The Milwaukee Bucks, paced by Kareem AbdulJabbar and Oscar Robertson, won their 12th straight game tonight with a 11091 National Basketball Asseia tion victory over the Capital Bullets at the University of Maryland.

title: Constance E. Lawn Is Married Here
description: Miss Constance Ellen Lawn of Washington and Stephen Rappaport of Arlington, Va., were married here last evening at the Plaza. Rabbi Joseph Goldman performed the ceremony.

title: VIETCONG SAY TOWN WAS HEAVILY BOMBED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 (AP)The Vietcong charged today that dozens of people had been killed or wounded in a Government extermination bombing of the Communistheld town of Lo Go, 70 miles northwest of Saigon.

title: BarLev Disputes Sharon on Suez Attack
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 11Lieut. Gen. Haim BarLev today accused Maj. Gen. Ariel Sharon of wrongly claiming credit for the Israeli breakthrough against Egypt last month. He said that documentary material would prove otherwise.

title: SHOP TALK
description: As fall goes about the business of laying waste the city's foliage turning it into biodegradable litter to be swept away by the Sanitation Department or by the windthe time has come to concentrate on the greenery that survives indoors.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CURRENT EVENTS The American Composers Alliance set up shop as a membership organization of composers in 1938. It used to give concerts way back (one of the first public electronic music concerts in '52), but it has not sponsored one in 10 years. Tonight at 8, the Alliance is once again presiding over a concert, at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (5824536). It's mostly a performance of computergenerated music, to be played on tape over four large speakers  works by Ussachevsky, Smiley, Smith, Bassett, Tanenbaum, Olive, Dodge and Randall.

title: JEWISH FAMILIES EXPLORE SABBATE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11Six months ago Ira and Jane Silverman of Washington, D.C., a Jewish couple with a 2yearold son, introduced a radical change in their way of life, They triedand found some. thing that they enjoyedkeep. ing the Sabbath.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT SIGN AGREEMENT FOR A CEASEFIRE
description: ON THE CAIROSUEZ HIGHWAY, Egypt, Nov. 11Egypt and Israel today signed the sixpoint ceasefire agreement sponsored by the United States and immediately began direct discussions on carrying it out.

title: 84 College Papers Urge Impeachment
description: Students newspapers at 84 colleges and universities across the country have called on Congress to impeach President Nixon.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT SIGN AGREEMENT FOR A CEASEFIRE
description: ON THE CAIROSUEZ HIGHWAY, Egypt, Nov. 11Egypt and Israel today signed the sixpoint ceasefire agreement sponsored by the United States and immediately began direct discussions on carrying it out.

title: The Theater
description: A grand reprise of Call Me Madam, Irving Berlin's ripe, 1950 tunecase for Ethel Merman, is lighting up the sky at the Equity Theater (6632028), which at this point is supplying a splendid variety of revivals.

title: Jersey Pike to Get New Alert System To Cut Accidents
description: TRENTON, Nov. 11  Engineers for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority have devised an electronic monitoring system designed to alert motorists to such traffic problems as congestion and crashes on the northern end of the heavily traveled expressway.

title: Kissinger Meets Chou For 3 Hours in Peking
description: PEKING, Nov. 11 (AP)Secretary of State Kissinger and Premier Chou Enlai met again today.

title: Nixon Cables Kissinger And Returns to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House today from Camp David after cabling congratulations to Secretary of State Kissinger, on the Middle East peace agreement.

title: Needed: City Planner
description: When New York fails, it fails spectacularly, and when it succeeds, no one pays very, much attention. One area in which the Lindsay administration has been setting exceptional standards of achievement is planning, a subject of little political sex appeal but enormous impact.

title: Hospital Peace?
description: The decision by the Cost of Living Council trimming the wage increases and other benefits originally ordered by a state arbitration board will be a bitter pill for New York's striking hospital workers to swallow. But their paramount responsibility to the needs of the sick and dying makes it imperative that they accept the reducedbut still substantialpackage and end their weeklong strike this morning. The union's leaders last night wisely urged such acceptance.

title: DR. ROBERT C. TOWSE, PROCTOLOGIST, DIES
description: ALBANY, Nov. 11Dr. Robert Collins Towse; a retired proctological surgeon, who had practiced here and in Westchester County, died today at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Latham.

title: NEW BOND ISSUES POST AN INCREASE
description: An estimated $1.6billion in taxexempt and corporate bond offerings is scheduled to be marketed this week, making it one of the busiest so far this year. The prospect is matteroffactly described as a good healthy calendar by seasoned underwriters and dealers who recall comparable weekly volumes in 1970 and 1971. The latest issues will include an estimated $951million in straight corporate debt and $611million in new taxexempt issues.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City received a twoday reprieve from a milk deliverymen's strike yesterday when wholesale milk distributors and a drivers' and plant employes' union agreed to extend their contract expiration deadline to 4 P.M. tomorrow. The distributors, members of the Metropolitan Dairy ??stitute, and the union, Local 584 of the Teamsters, had been negotiating at the Sheraton Inn at La Guardia Airport against a deadline of 4 P.M. yesterday. Unable agree on a contract to replace the expiring twoyear pact, they were able to agree to continue talking. The 120 dairies involved distribute milk to retail stores in the city, Westchester and Nassau Counties and parts of Suffolk.

title: Jrets Win on Turnovers, 3313
Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Back Pay Withheld From ExCity Aide In Inquiry on Ethics
description: The city is withholding more than $7,000 in overtime and vacation pay claimed by Paul Levine, who resigned a city post last month to become a top executive of a manufacturing company that the city had helped to expand by relocating some residents of the Northside section of Brooklyn.

title: TV Pressure Play Is Denied
description: The American Broadcasting Company yesterday denied charges that it pressured Alabama and Notre Dame to meet in the Sugar Bowl game on New Year's Eve. A.B.C., which has the contract with the National Collegiate Athletic Association to televise the college football game of the week during the regular season, also has a contract to televise the Sugar Bowl game on Dec. 31.

title: Fire Pact Is Drawn
description: An impasse panel submitted contract proposals yesterday aimed at ending the dispute between the city and its firemen. The terms were not disclosed. The firemen staged a 5hour strike Tuesday before accepting arbitration. Page 37.

title: Theodore Simon, 82, Dies; A Textile Manufacturer
description: Theodore Simon, a retired textile manufacturer and an officer in both World Wars, died here Thursday at the age of 82.

title: U.S. Said to Urge Peace Talks On Mideast Early Next Month
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11The United States has proposed that an IsraeliArab peace conference be convened in Geneva early in December under American and Soviet auspices, Government sources here said today.

title: TASS GIVES VERSION OF MIDEAST ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11  Tass, the official Soviet press agency, today implied that the compromise signed by Egypt and Israel was an agreement to abide by the Middle East ceaselire and to return to their Oct. 22 lines.

title: Israeli General Tells How Bridgehead Across the Suez Canal Was Established
description: ROME, Nov. 11  During lengthy conversations in the Egyptian desert last week, Maj. Gen. Ariel Sharon, the commander who seized a bridgehead west of the Suez Canal, gave the first detailed narrative made public of how the Israeli plan to cross the canal and split the Egyptian Army was conceived and executed. This is General Sharon's story of one of the most bitter battles ever fought by Israel.

title: Vandalism Termed A Growing Problem In City Cemeteries
description: Representatives of all 30 Brooklyn posts of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States were told yesterday that the problem of vandalism of cemeteries of all religions was growing throughout the city and that cemetery officials and city officials were doing nothing about it.

title: Miss Kapelman Becomes Bride At the St. Regis
description: Miss Jacqueline Ann Kapelman, a senior at Barnard College, and Donald John Barton, a student at the Albert. Einstein College of Medicine, were married here yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by a rabbi in the Library of the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Deroyalization
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The imminence of gasoline rationing provides political figures with a golden opportunity: to shuck off some of the antidemocratic luxuries that encrust and demean the seats of power.

title: Bacherlor Fathers Who Are Planning to Adopt More Children
description: John Wetterer and Peter Bailey are young, single, successful and popular. Despite it all, they can't wait to get home at night. They are also fathers.

title: TESTS WILL SEEK A NEW BIRTH DRUG
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Nov. 11A synthetic modification of brain hormone is to be tested in humans here within the next several months as a step toward a radically new kind of longacting birth control drug.

title: CITY BALLET FACES STRIKE BY DANCERS
description: Dancers of the New York City Ballet voted yesterday to go on strike at noon tomorrow unless the management assured them employment for a full season by reaching a settlement with the City Ballet's orchestra. The company was scheduled to open its 14week fallwinter season at the State Theater tomorrow night.

title: Personal Finance: Minitrusts Growing
description: If you have a few hundred thousand dollars to invest to take care of you in your old age or to provide for others after your death, trust officers almost everywhere have long offered a broad range of tailormade services to meet your needs.

title: Speeded Repairs Avert Delay in Skylab Launching
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 11With repair work on the rocket now progressing more rapidly, space agency officials decided today against any further delay in launching the Skylab 3 astronauts.

title: About New York The Joys of the Rich and Social
description: Bonwit Teller had just opened its doors, and there were only two customers on the floor where the better dresses were sold. Separately, the customers looked at things, and then on coining close together they looked at each other.

title: Newark's Housing Worst, 30City Survey Concludes
description: NEWARK, Nov. 11Housing in Newark was rated the worst, and the best was found in San Jose, Calif., according to a 30city survey whose results were announced over the weekend. New York City ranked high in some of the five categories of the survey data, and low in others.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 60yearold gambler was discovered yesterday morning shot to death from very close range, his body slumped in the back of his blue Cadillac, which was parked on the 96th Street transverse road in Central Park.

title: Strike in Colorado Ends
description: DENVER, Nov. 11 (UPI)A retail clerk's strike against five major supermarket chains in Denver and Colorado Springs ended today. An estimated 4,500 members of the 6,500member Retail Clerk's Union Local 7 gave nearly unanimous approval to a new contract offer by the Mountain States Employers' Council.

title: Butcher Cuts Out Advertising Baloney In Drive to Help Buyers of Bulk Meat
description: PARSIPPANY, Nov. 11A oneman battle against baitandswitch tactics in the meat business is being waged by John Schimenti, a local butcher who spends almost as much time at the lectern as he does behind the counter.

title: Victors by 179
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 11 Both defenses were dominant today on a soggy field, but the Oakland. Raider offense threw a series of spectacular mistakes into the balance and helped the Pittsburgh Steclers to a 179 victory in a meeting between division leaders in the American Football Conference.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Arab States Went All Out In Welcoming Kissinger
description: PEKING, Nov. 11Secretary of State Kissinger's spokesman, Robert J. McCloskey, held his daily news conference today on the 10th floor of the Mintzu Hotel. It was one of the few times in the last week that he has been able to meet with newsmen at less than 30,000 feet.

title: Justified Leniency
description: In fixing the final sentences for the Watergate conspirators, Chief District Judge John J. Sirica has put the actual breakin into the Democratic campaign headquarters in its proper perspective against a background of far more serious crimes committed at higher echelons. Only E. Howard Hunt, the former White House consultant and C.I.A. operative, faces longterm imprisonment of at least two and a half years for his part in planning the burglary. None of the five other defendants is likely to serve more than one year, and three of them may soon be eligible for parole.

title: Tv Comic and Wife Are Found Slain
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 11 (UPI) David Akeman, the lanky television comedian known as Stringbean to fans of Hee Haw and Grand Ole Opry, and his wife were shot to death early today after apparently surprising burglars in their isolated home near here.

title: $20,000 Grant Given To Monmouth Museum
description: The Monmouth Museum of Lincroft, a traveling community institution, has received a $20,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to try out its proposal for a threepart exhibition entitled Man and His Shelter.

title: Newark Housing Scored
description: A survey of 30 cities by the Council on Municipal Performance has found the worst housing in Newark and the best in San Jose, Calif. New York City ranked high and low, depending on the categories, in five comparisons. Page 37.

title: ExPremier Says He's Shamed By Police Brutality in Greece
description: ATHENS, Nov. 11A conservative exPremier said in court today that he felt ashamed as a Greek bcause police brutality was being used as an administrative practice.

title: TWO SIDES CONFER BUT DO NOT AGREE
description: ON THE CAIROSUEZ HIGHWAY, Egypt, Nov. 11Egypt and Israel were unable to agree in, two bargaining sessions on the first steps toward carrying out the ceasefire agreement they signed today.

title: Proposal on Fire Contract Given to City and Union
description: Compromise recommendations by an impasse panel for ending the contract dispute between the city and its firemen were handed yesterday to both sides, but the amounts by which the fire fighters' salaries will be increased were not made public.

title: Proxmire Says Open Bids Could Slash Arms Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Large reductions in weapons costs could be achieved if the Defense Depart. ment opened contracts to competitive bidding, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said tonight.

title: Reform Judaism Alexander Moshe Schindler
description: The mantle of leadership for America's more than one snugly and easily on the shoulders of Rabbi Alexander million Reform Jew's falls Moshe Schindler, new president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. Rabbi Schindler, who succeeds the late Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath to Reform Judaism's most influential and presigious post, has served the congregational arm of the Reform movement for almost 15 years, first as a regional director and then as eiducaton director.

title: Diplomacy Triumphant
description: The governments of Israel and Egypt have met facetoface negotiation and signed a mutually binding contractual agreement to resolve their military confrontation. Such a statement, unthinkable for most of the past two decades, would have been laughed off the page had it been made as a prediction just six short weeks ago. Today it is historical fact.

title: New U.S. Envoy Arrives in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Nov. 5 (AP)Hermann F. Eilts arrived here today to become the first United States Ambassador to Egypt since Cairo broke diplomatic relations with Washington during the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Bridge: Brazilian Tearn Favored In South American Event
description: The South American championships being contested in Brazil this week will determine the representatives of that zone in the world team championship in Italy next May. Judging by past results, and by the splendid form of the Brazilian team in the 1973 world championship, the home team will score a victory, with Argentina and Venezuela as its nearest rivals.

title: Esposito Gets 19th as Bruins Score, 42
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)The scoring leader, Phil. Esposito, got one goal and assisted on another tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 42 victory over the Vancouver Canucks in a penaltyriddled National Hockey League game.

title: Dual Showings for Their Fur Fashions
description: It isn't every day that a fashion company gets to celebrate its 250th anniversary. So Revillon Frres, which dates back to 1723, just had to have a party.

title: So. Shore Tops Lafayette To Reach P.S.A.L. Final
description: South Shore needs one more surprise.

title: Jets Win, Giants Lose
description: Bobby Howfield had four field goals yesterday as the Jets beat the New England Patriots, 3313, at Shea Stadium. At Yale Bowl in New Haven, the Giants lost their seventh game in a row, 2310, to the Dallas Cowboys. Details on Page 45.

title: Lions Bow, 287
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 11The undefeated and untied Minnesota Vikings clinched a tie for the National Football Conference's Central Division crown today by beating the Detroit Lions, 287, before 47,911 fans.

title: 3Day Negotiations Leave the Israelis Breathless, Wary
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11The ceasefire accord signed near Suez today is the culmination of 72 hours of intensive negotiations that left officials here breathless at the pace of Secretary of State Kissinger's diplomacy, deeply suspicious of Egyptian motives and, at the same time, cautiously hopeful about the future.

title: Corruption Questions Stir Italy
description: ROMEThe discovery of an electronic eavesdropping device in the office of an investigating magistrate here last month has stirred a furor because of the implication of skulduggery in high finance and big business.

title: 2,000 Attend Eisendrath Rites; Hear Eulogies to Reform Leader
description: Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, the spiritual leader of American Reform Judaism who died here Friday at the age of 71, was eulogized yesterday as the man who rescued us as Reform Jews from becoming a transient sect in the Jewish movement in American life.

title: Reform Jews Reclaiming Tradition They Once Rejected
description: Jerome Zeffren and his family welcome the Sabbath every Friday evening by baking their own bread, lighting candles and blessing wine. They fast on Yoni Kippur and have Opecial set of dishes for Passover. All four of them either know or are learning Hebrew.

title: Laver Tops Newcombe In Net Final
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 11 (AP)  Rod Laver, upset John Newcombe, a fellow Australian, 36, 75, 63, 36, 64, today and won the singles title in the $50,000 Australian indoor tennis championships.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: A U.S. JEWISH LEADER SEES TRUCE AS FAIR
description: The president of the American Jewish Congress, Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, has described the ceasefire agreement signed yesterday by Israel and Egypt as apparently fair to both sides and expressed the hope that it would be honored by them.

title: HOSPITAL PAY RISE CUT TO 6% BY U.S; STRIKE END SEEN
description: The advisory committee, of the Federal Cost of Living Council yesterday issued its salary recommendations in the weeklong strike at 48 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes here, and the union's leadership voted overwhelmingly last night to approve the recommended raise.

title: CALIFORNIA DEPUTIES FIND 2 MORE BODIES
description: OAKDALE, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP)Two nude bodies were found today in a remote creek bed, and the authorities said they believed that they were victims of two men already charged with nine murders and linked to several others.

title: Soviet Accepts Exit Papers, Ballet Dancer's Wife Says
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11 (AP)Soviet authorities accepted emigration applications from Valery Panov, a Jewish ballet dancer, and his wife today, but he will continue a 10dayold hunger strike until they receive permission to leave for Israel, Mrs. Panov said.

title: Brezhnev's Popularity at a High
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11Leonid I. Brezhnev, the soviet leader, has apparently escaped any notable backlash from his close personal dealings with President Nixon and is now riding a new crest of personal strength at home.

title: THRUWAY SPEED IS LIMITED TO 60
description: Polled by telephone, the New York State Thruway Authority has voted that, at midnight tonight, the speed limit on the 559mile road will be dropped to 50 miles an hour15 miles below the current level  to help cope with the energy shortage.

title: Soviet Puts New Stress On ResearchBased Units
description: Taking a leaf from American corporate experience, the Soviet Union is fostering the founding of researchbased corporations to speed innovation in an economy that has not kept up with technological advances in the West.

title: UraniumSupply Lag Plagues Utilities
description: Electric utilities are convinced that nuclear power is the best way to beat the problems of rising costs for fuels and environmental problems.

title: Letters to the Editor The Ford Nomination: What Is Needed From Congress?
description: To the Editor: There is inconsistency in having the Senate and the House carry out hearings for the confirmation of Representative Gerald R. Ford as Vice President.

title: The Governor Has a Cold, or How Energy Saving Goes in Oregon
description: SALEM, Ore., Nov. 11Oregon has three months of experience with the kind of energy  saving program that President Nixon has proposed for the entire country  and Gov. Tom McCall has a cold.

title: Light in the Dark
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11President Nixon is reportedly planning one last effort to dispose of what he calls the deplorable Watergate matter. He may make himself available to Senator Sam Ervin's committee for questions. He may publish the version of the White House tapes prepared by his secretary, Rose Mary Woods. He may put out a white paper answering a whole range of charges, from the Watergate coverup to his challenged tax deductions.

title: VIRTANEN IS DEAD A NOBEL CHEMIST
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Prof. Artturi Virtanen, winner of the 1945 Nobel Prize for chemistry, died here today at the age of 78.

title: Oilers' Six Runs Its Streak to 10
description: TORONTO, Nov. 11 (UPI) Eddie Joyal, Jim Harrison and Ron. Clime scored in a, span of 1 minute 28 seconds in the second period to help the Edmonton Oilers defeat the Toronto Toros, 42, in the World Hockey Associa tion tonight.

title: Venezuela Reviews Role in Oil Balance
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 10Venezuela, the second largest foreign supplier of oil and petroleum products to the United States and the largest to Canada, can do nothing to help the United States and other energyconsuming nations out of the supply difficulties brought on by Arab production cutbacks and embargoes. And there are some indications that even if the Venezuelans could increase oil production, they wouldn't.

title: Met. College Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS Eastern Division

title: Vesco in Bahamas: Intrigue and Debate
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 11  The political and ecbnomic forces at work here behind the scenes of this week's hearing on a United States move to extradite Robert L. Vesco, the financier, would do justice to one of those Graham Greene novels about the intrigues of life in the Caribbean.

title: Jets Win, Giants Lose
description: Bobby Howfield had four field goals yesterday as the Jets beat the New England Patriots, 3313, at Shea Stadium. At Yale Bowl in New Haven, the Giants lost their seventh game in a row, 2310, to the Dallas Cowboys. Details on Page 45.

title: So. Shore Tops Lafayette To Reach P.S.A.L. Final
description: South Shore need one more surprise. The Vikings defeated Lafayette, 188, yesterday and advanced to the Public Schools Athletic League football final Saturday against Bayside.

title: Australian Chief Drops Role of Foreign Minister and Turns to Political Tasks
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 11  Following his return from visits to Japan and China last week, publicized here as highly successful diplomatic ventures, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam has turned to the urgent task of repairing his Labor Government's sagging political fences at home.

title: FARMERS OPPOSE GENERATOR PLAN
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 11 Conservative farmers around the Plum Bayou community south of here are trying to build an alliance with Harvard University to force changes in the plans for a huge coalfired electric power plant that is to be built upwind from them.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Ousted Turkish Premier Is Asked to Form Cabinet
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 12 (AP)President Fahri Koruturk, seeking to end Turkey's political crisis, asked former Premier Suleman Demirel today to form a new cabinet.

title: 41 FOOD OUTLETS ARE CITED AGAIN
description: The Health Department has cited 41 more food establishments for failure to pass their second inspection. It warned that persisting healthcode violations found upon a third and final inspection later this month could lead to closing orders. The department also listed 25 establishments that had their final results. The results follow:

title: White Husband Is Set, Ablaze In Abduction With Black Wile
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 12 (AP)A gang of black men abducted a white man and his black wife, doused the husband with a flammable fluid and set him afire, the police said today.

title: Columbus Bus Drivers Out
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP)Columbus was without bus service today after drivers for the Columbus Transit Company voted to walk off the job.

title: Graham Crusade Ends
description: ST, LOUIS, Nov. 12 (UPI)The 10day Billy Graham St. Louis Crusade, which concluded yesterday, drew 224,400 people to the St. Louis Arena. More than 5,600 stepped forward during: the end of the. 10 crusade services and dedicated themselves to Christ.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger said that the United States was considering a mutual security treaty with Israel as one of the possible ways of guaranteeing Israel's boundaries once a formal peace agreement has been achieved in the Middle East. Mr. Kissinger also said the Arabs' embargo on oil shipments to the United States would probably continue for the indefinite future but would not provoke the United States into dropping its support for Israel. He made the remarks in an interview for American television networks filmed in Peking. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Kissinger Interview in Peking for U.S. Television
description: PEKING, Nov. 12 (UPI)Following is a transcript of an interview today in Peking between Secretary of State Kissinger and representatives of the three major American broadcasting networks:

title: A Trial Veteran at 30 Richard BenVeniste
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Richard BenVeniste, one of the Watergate special prosecution force's most aggressive young lawyers, walks softly and confidently in the Federal courtroom where he has been questioning witnesses in connection with the White House tape recordings, but insists that I don't take myself too seriously. Heconcedes that he is selfconfident, as indeed he appears: If you make it in New York, the 30yeasold assistant special prosecutor said, you have some confidence in yourself. And for a young trial lawyer, Mr. BenVeniste could be said to have made it in New York by the time he left the office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to join the Watetgate task force in July. Mr. BenVeniste had prosecuted several celebrated cases, including that of Martin Sweig, the veteran administrative assistant to Representative assistant to Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, former Democratic Speaker of the House, and had a reputation as a tough prosecutor.

title: Film: The Homecoming
description: Harold Pinter's rabid comedy The Homecoming, has been turned into a movie of astonishing dynamism by Peter Hall, who also directed the original London and Broadway productions, with six extraordinary English actors who, with one exception, appeared in the play on the stage. The film, the second offering in the American Film Theater series, opened yesterday at selected theaters.

title: AntreassianDedeyan, Soprano, Returns
description: Astghig Antreassian  Dedeyan, a soprano who was born in New York but whose career in recent years has centered on Europe, returned Sunday night for a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall. Although she calls herself a lyric soprano, the recitalist produced an appealingly dark and smoky tone that suggested a mezzosoprano coloration, and reasonable agility in florid music such as an aria from Bellini's Il Pirata.

title: Nixon Reportedly Sent An Affidavit to Sirica
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) President Nixon has prepared an affidavit covering what he believes will clarify his relation to the Watergate scandal, The St. Louis PostDispatch said today.

title: Japanese Plan Construction Of Cotton Plant in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 12 (AP) Gov. Dolph Briscoe announced today that one of Japan's major textile concerns, the Daiwa Spinning Company, would build a large cotton spinning plant near Plainview, Tex., on the South Plains.

title: KISSINGER SAYS ES, WEIGHS PACT TO DEFEND ISRAEL
description: PEKING, Nov, 12Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States was considering a mutual security treaty with Israel as one of the possible ways of guaranteeing Israel's boundaries once a formal peace agreement has been achieved in the Middle East.

title: Segretti Starts 6Month Sentence at Federal Prison on Coast
description: LOMPOC, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP)Looking pale and nervous, Donald H. Segretti surrendered, today at a Federal prison here to begin a sixmonth sentence for political sabotage.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HARLEM The Dance Theater of Harlem has been a municipal adornment since 1968, since which time it has developed a professional dance company and a school that teaches classical ballet and other dance. Keeping up with other cultural organizations, whether the Metropolitan Opera or the New York City Ballet, it, too, needs money. That is why, on this date last year, it staged a Harlem Homecoming benefit for itself at Loew's Victoria Theater, 125th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. It was an occasion that brought out a galaxy of talent and did so to such good effect that Harlem Homecoming II, subtitled An Evening of Ballet, Blues and Gospel, is going on at the same place at 8:30 tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Reports of progress were issued as negotiations on a new contract continued at the Sheraton inn at La Guardia Airport between representatives of 3,000 workers and 120 dairies that distribute milk to retail stores in the city, Westchester and Nassau Counties and parts of Suffolk County. The contract expired at 4 P.M. Sunday, but members of the Metropolitan Dairy Institute and Local 584 of the Teamsters agreed to continue talks against a new deadline, 4 P.M. today.

title: DEFICIT REPORTED BY PITNEYBOWES
Bond Agency Cuts Rating For Jersey Housing Issue
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12A major bondrating service, in a move that carries serious implications for both the financially strapped New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority and other quasipublic bodies, is in the process of downgrading the quality of New Jersey Housing Finance Agency bonds.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: 4.9% BuildingTrades Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)  Union wages rates for building trades workers in major cities rose 4.9 per cent over the last year, the smallest increase since 1966, the Labor Department reported today. As of last month, wage rates in the building trades averaged $7.74 an hour.

title: MRS. MAY KENNEDY
description: Mrs. May Fitzpatrick Kennedy, mother of William J. Kennedy Jr., president of New York Printing Pressmen's Union Local 2, died Friday in the Woodbury (L. I.) Nursing Home. She was 80 years old and lived at 79.15 212th Street, Flushing, Queens. A sister, Mrs. Alice Egan, also survives.

title: Byrne Stand Kills BondPledge Bill
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne today refused to support legislation that would have placed the state's moral commitment behind the financing of a major sports development in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: An Israeli Warning
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 12Israeli officials said tonight that unless a deadlock over control of the CairoSuez highway was resolved and Israeli prisoners promptly returned, Israel would have to reconsider the ceasefire agreement, including her pledge to permit the continuing supply of the Egyptian III Corps.

title: Manhattan, Hartnett Win in Run
PRICES ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market fell sharply yesterday in moderate trading.

title: MACHINE GUN USED IN $300,000 HOLDUP
description: Eight masked gunmen locked 12 employes of a Jamaica, warehouse into a security cage last night and drove off in three small trucks loaded with an estimated $300,000 worth of watches and watch parts.

title: Manufacturing Halt Set By House of Edgeworth
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 12 CAP)Larus & Bro. Co., the House of Edgeworth, will close its manufacturing and stenunery operationsone of Richmond's landmark businessesearly next year.

title: N.Y.U. IS FIGHTING UNIONIZATION BID
description: New York University is conducting a lowkey but intense effort to discourage its faculty members and librarians from voting in favor of having a collectivebargaining agent.

title: Soviet Union Kicked Out Of World Cup in Soccer
description: GENEVA, Nov. 12 By its refusal to play in Chile, the Soviet national team has barred itself from the final round of the 1974 World Cup soccer competition, the International Football Federation (F.I.F.A.) ruled today. And that ruling could lead to a boycott by other East European countries.

title: High School Sports
description: Two football coaches used similar strategies to stop their opponents last Sunday. For one, Vinnie O'Connor of St. Francis Prep, the plan worked and his team won in a rout. For the other, Marty Senall of South Shore, the strategy backfired but his team won anyway.

title: Annette Goldman, Who Fought Use of U.S. School Tests, Dies
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 12 Mrs. Annette Perskin Goldman, Superintendent of Community School District 19 in the East New York area of Brooklyn, who recently led her district in a confrontation with the United States Office of Education, died today in North Shore Hospital aftee an illness of nine weeks. She was 56 years old and lived at 934 Beth Lane, Woodmere, L. I.

title: Woodall, Demory Wait On Return of Namath
description: The emphasis in the Jets' workouts this week will be on quarterbacks  offensive quarterbacks, defensive quarterbacks, backup quarterbacks, deactivated quarterbacks.

title: Women Students Join the Protest Drive in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 12Four thousand students at South Korea's largest university for women held a rally today to demand a genuine democratic system in this country in the latest development in the spreading student protest against the Government.

title: ARTHUR S. GOW
description: WAYNE, Pa., Nov. 12Arthur S. Gow, former vice president of the Curtis Publishing Company, died Sunday at the Caley Nursing and Rehabilitation Center here. He was 80 years old.

title: Her Word Against Case History of a Sex Charge
description: This is an account of one of 3,500 complaints of sexual offenses that will be made in the city this year. It is based on interviews with each of the key participants; the conflicting statements and points of view are given, illustrating the ambiguities jurors are called on to resolve.

title: Firefighters' Strike Vote Disclosed to Jury
description: The head of the Honest Ballot Association, George J. Abrams disclosed to a Manhattan grand jury yesterday the result of the vote that preceded the five  and  a  half  hour strike last Tuesday by 10,900 city firemen.

title: Notes on People
description: The blunt truth is that people don't trust their leaders any more, so I intend to run for the United States Senate on an honesty ticket, Gary Hart, who was comanager of Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign, announced in Denver yesterday.

title: License to Sell Beer and Wine Sought for Site of Gallo Slaying
description: The owner of Umberto's Clam House, the site of the murderexecution of a major organizedcrime figure, has moved in State Supreme Court to obtain a license to sell beer and wine that the restaurant has sought in vain for 15 months.

title: Big Crowd Marks Antiques Fair Start In White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 12It was an unusually lively opening for the Eastern States Antique Fair, with the heaviest attendance in several editions of the show. Many of the visitors to the fairgrounds at the Westchester County Center weren't just looking. Their exodus was marked by accompanying packages and a trail, inside, of Sold signs.

title: Court Petition Filed To Disbar Agnew For Tax Evasion
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 12 (UPI)The Maryland State Bar Association began action today that could lead to the former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's being barred from practising law anywhere in the United States.

title: Chess:
description: In a rare flash of insight for such a hardheaded man, David Janowski (18681927) once described his game as being like Mary, Queen of Scots  beautiful but unfortunate. Living for the dazzling, elegant blow, the Polish master all too often succumbed to the mundane.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Alaska Legislature Raises Oil Taxes for North Slope
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 12 (AP)  The Alaska Legislature has ordered a 50 per cent rise in petroleum production taxes on the oilrich North Slope.

title: 7 Belfast Bombs Injure 13
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 12Seven bombs exploded in Roman Catholic areas, of Belfast today, injuring at least 13 persons and destroying five bars.

title: WILLIAM HANNON
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 12 (AP)William Hannon, executive director of the Child Caring Agencies of New York State, died here of a heart attack today. He was 63 years old.

title: FactFinding on Contract Asked By Municipal Employes Union
description: A union representing 125,000 city employes broke off contract negotiations yesterday, but did not threaten to strike.

title: S.E.C.Said to Investigate Hughes Airline Purchase
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (AP)The Securities and Exchange. Commission is investigating the purchase by billionaire industrialist Howard Hughes of Air West, a regional airline, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: Arrogance of the Press
description: MANCHESTER, N. H.  President Nixon should not now resign or be impeached because to do so would take control of the nation away from the voters and give it to a small group of arrogant selfappointed rulers in the form of radio and TV commentators, newspaper editorialists and publishers.

title: Jaworski Scores National Security as a Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)Leon Jaworski, in his first major legal argument since taking office as Watergate prosecutor, said today that not even the highest office in the land has the authority to break the law in the name of national security.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The 20,395 police officer who took the examination Saturday for promotion to sergeant were also asked to Ali in a confidential questionnaire about thear race, age, educational achievements and age.

title: Heating Up Berlin
description: It has long been evident that East Germany would cause more trouble for EastWest dtente and West Germany's Ostpolitik than any of the other Soviet allies Europe. Even construction of the Berlin Wall in 1961, which cut off the flood of East German refugees to West Berlin, failed to dissolve the insecurity of East Germany's Communist leaders in any relationship with the prosperous, democratic Federal Republic.

title: AMEX CENSURES HAYDEN CONDUCT
description: A disciplinary panel of the American Stock Exchange censured Hayden Stone, Inc., yesterday for conduct inconsistent with just and equitable principles of trade and fined the brokerage house $20,000.

title: Harsher Penalties Urged For Income Tax Evaders
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)  Harsher punishment of tax dodgers would deter other income tax cheaters, says Donald C. Alexander, Internal Revenue Commissioner.

title: G.O.P. Revives Rolicy Unit Independent of President
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Republican party establisped today what it hoped would be a policy voice independent of President Nixon lust as the White House said it was beginning to win the counteroffensive against its Watergate critics.

title: William Gegenheimer, 96, Set Up Printing Press Firm
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 12  William Gegenheimer, founder and honorary chairman of the BaldwinGegenheimer Corporation and a pioneer in inventions for printing presses, died yesterday at his home on Wilson Road in Rowayton. He was 96 years old.

title: Two SmallBusiness Aides Are Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The administrator of the Small Business Administration recalled the area director and the regional director of the agency's Richmond office today after a House subcommittee disclosed over the weekend that it had uncovered what appeared to be substantial criminal abuses in theagency's field offices.

title: All Right to Be Sick
description: Striking hospital workers are back on the job after a week in which the hazards of illness or accident for thousands of New Yorkers were gravely increased by a drastic curtailment in the availability of quality care. No postmortem on the effects of the strike will ever provide a precise measure of its toll in health damage to the ailing and infirm, both those who suffered neglect in the struck institutions and those who needed hospitalization but could not be accommodated.

title: United Aircraft in Pact For Essex International
description: The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Essex International, Inc., manufacturers of electriccurrent carrying and controlling devices and related metal and plastic products.

title: AntreassianDedeyan, Soprano, Returns
description: Astghig Antreassian  Dedeyan, a soprano who was born in New York but whose career in recent years has centered on. Europe, returned Sunday night for a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall. Although she calls herself a lyric soprano, the recitalist produced an appealingly dark and smoky tone that suggested a mezzosoprano coloration, and reasonable agility in florid music such as an aria from Bellini's Il Pirata.

title: Agriculture Panel Votes Bill Letting, Butz Approve DDT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)  The House Agriculture Committee approved unanimously today a bill to give Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz power to approve use of DDT in emergency situations, such as when a forest is threatened by destructive insects.

title: Brazil Denounced in Prisoner's Death
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12A prominent Brazilian law professor and former member of Congress has charged that his son was the victim of homicide while under detention and has asked for an investigation by the military police.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: MADRID, Nov. 12Some 95 members of the strikebound New York Philharmonic Orchestra opened a tour of the Iberian peninsula tonight with the approval of the musicians union but under the cloud of a possible lawsuit by the Philharmonic's management.

title: Article 3  No Title
President's Attack On Television Seen As Planned Move
description: A brief exchange between. President Nixon and a C.B.S. News television producer before the President's Oct. 26 press conference raises the possibility that his nowfamous at tack on the news media may have been less spontaneous than it seemed.

title: T.W.A., UNION MEET WITH U.S. MEDIATORS
description: Trans World Airlines, grounded since Nov. 5 by a strike of 5,000 flight attendants, and Local 550 of hte Transport Workers Union, said yesterday that they were meeting with officials of the National Mediation Board in Washington.

title: Abducted U.S. Oil Executive Is Ransomed in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 (AP)  A kidnapped American oil executive was released unharmed yesterday and left for the United States shortly afterward, it was reported here.

title: 18 Horses in Idaho May Get Reprieve From Meat Packer
description: IDAHO FALLS, Nov. 12 (AP) Eighteen horses shipped from Idaho for slaughter last winter have been returned and may again roam freely in the high country near Howe.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of those shortterm securities.

title: Barnes Trial Begins
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 12 (AP)The selection of a jury began today in the trial of Providence College's basketball star, Marvin Barnes. He is charged with assault with a dangerous weapon in an altercation with a former teammate, Larry Ketvirtis, at the college in October, 1972.

title: Bishop Gill of Seattle Dies; Developed Child Care Unit
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 12 (AP)The Most Rev. Thomas E. Gill, Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of Seattle, who was credited with building Catholic Children's Services into the largest private childcare agency in this state, died yesterday in Washington. His age was 65.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Today, Nov. 13

title: Amsterdam News Editor Withdraws His Resignation
description: H. Carl McCall, who resigned recently as chairman of the editorial page of The New York Amsterdam News in a dispute with the publisher over a political endorsement, has withdrawn his resignation.

title: 5TH AVE. WILL DIM HOLIDAY LIGHTING
description: Fifth Avenue and Rockefeller Center will be bereft of some of their holiday glitter this year because of the energy crisis, spokesmen for many of the major stores said yesterday, though they added that the area would not be less festive.

title: Garrett Proposes Antitrust Leniency For Wall St. Firms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Ray D. Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed today that the securities industry be exempted from the antitrust laws but backed down to a less sweeping position in the face of a critical response from Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the Senate Securities subcommittee.

title: HOUSE APPROVES ALASKA PIPELINE; ENERGYBILLGAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Two major bills to deal with the energy shortage cleared important hurdles in Congress today.

title: Byrne Refuses to Back Bond Pledge, Forcing Cahill to Abandon Sports Bill
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne today refused to support legislation that would have placed the state's moral commitment behind the financing of a major sports development in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Inquiry on Justice Rinaldi Over Leniency Is Reported
description: Justice Dominic. S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has been under investigation for nearly four months by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, concerning alleged judicial misconduct involving improperly lenient sentences for criminal defendants, highly placed sources said yesterday.

title: The City Ballet Fan Extraordinaire
description: Nobody goes to the New York City Ballet quite as often as Edward Gorey, who has attended virtually every performance here by the company for the last 17 years.

title: Ashe Easy Victory
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Nov. 12 (AP)Arthur Ashe crushed Patrice Dominguez of France, 62, 62, today and led the field into the second round of the $48,000 Nottingham indoor tennis tournament.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: DOW INDUSTRIALS FALL BELOW 900
description: Fears that the energy crisis will curtail economic activity and corporate profits  in 1974 rocked the stock market again yesterday. Trading held to a moderate pace.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: CAMBODIAN BATTLES ON ROUTE 4 REPORTED
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 12 (UPI)  Cambodian Government forces reportedly fought through the day today in an effort to dislodge insurgent troops who cut Phnom Penh's road to the sea yesterday.

title: LameDuck Republicans Wind Up Trenton Duties
description: TRENTON, Nov, 12  Listlessly, almost aimlessly, and under what some said was a dark cloud hanging over the party, defeated Republican legislators cast votes in the State Senate and Assembly today. But they were deprived by a sense of political reality even of taking positions on major issues that will face the new state government coining to power next January.

title: Japan Warns on Oil
description: In the strongest Government statement to date on the fuel crisis, a Japanese official warned that Arab oil cutbacks threatened Japan with the first serious blow to her economy since World War II. Page 61.

title: National Rise in Syphilis Is Reported to Be Slowing
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 12 (UPI) A nationwide increase in syphilis appears to be leveling off, the National Center for Disease Control has reported.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE BY 30,000 ENDED
description: Hospital workers returned to their jobs yesterday after voting to accept a wage settlement scaled down by the Federal Cost of Living Council, thus ending a weeklong walkout that had crippled 48 hospitals and nursing homes in the area.

title: A Little Chutzpah Goes a Long Way
description: They met at a party, by the buffet. He was tall, dark and starving. She was blond and zaftig. There were only two knishes left. She took them both.

title: NIXON CAMPAIGNER INDICTED IN ILLINOIS
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP)Williain H. Rentschler, who managed President Nixon's 1968 campaign sin Illinois, was named today in a Federal indictment charging him with a, $1million fraud scheme involving banks and a New York City credit union.

title: Braniff Is Fined For Gift To Nixon's '72 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) Braniff International Airways Inc. and its board chairman pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of having made an illegal $40,000 corporate cash contribution to President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign.

title: A Bitter Resignation Fills Ranks of Hospital Pickets
description: Hospital workers at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx passed the morning yesterday in quiet clumps of four or five talking about the wage increase the Government had approved 6 per cent, or 20 per cent less than they had wanted and had struck for.

title: No Grave Danger Seen To Economy in Oil Cut
description: A 17 per cent reduction in the nation's oil supply will not really do any serious damage to the economy next year, a Nixon Administration official said here yesday.

title: Nixon Offers Sirica Data On the Two Conversations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 President Nixon offered today to furnish Federal District Judge John J. Sirica with background information on two conversations sought by Watergate investigators that the secret White House recording system failed to record.

title: Networks to Cover Princess's Wedding Starting at 5 A.M.
description: The wedding in London tomorrow of Princess Anne and Capt. Mark Phillips will be given extensive television coverage via communications satellite by the three major networks, but only early birds will be able to watch all of it.

title: BILL RATES CLIMB IN LATEST ISSUE
description: Interest rates on Treasury billsthe securities the Government sells when it borrows for a short period  soared yesterday, adding pressure to other rates throughout the money and capital markets.

title: FRENCH CRITICIZE U.S.SOVIET ROLE
description: PARIS, Nov. 12In the strongest official denunciation of SovietAmerican accords yet heard in Western Europe, France's Foreign Minister said today that the brutal crises in the Middle East confirmed his Government's doubts about the superpowers' capacities to keep peace.

title: Next Session Tomorrow
description: CAIRO, Nov. 12Egyptian, and Israeli negotiators today failed for the second day to make progress toward agreeing on steps to carry out their ceasefire agreement, and their next session was put off until Wednesday.

title: Some Watergate Queries G.O.P. May Ask
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Over the next four days, President Nixon is scheduled to meet with all the Republicans in Congress to answer their questions about the Watergate scandal and related activities of the President and his aides.

title: KISSINGER SAYS U.S. WEIGHS PACT TO DEFEND ISRAEL
description: PEKING, Nov. 12Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States was considering a mutual security treaty with Israel as one of the possible ways of guaranteeing Israel's boundaries once a formal peace agreement has been achieved in the Middle East.

title: New York Death Penalty Voided As High Court Declines Review
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12New York's death penalty statute was permanently voided today when the Supreme Court refused to set aside last June's ruling by the New York Court of Appeals that the state law was unconstitutional.

title: Belmon e's Steady Diet: A Wait for Right Weight
description: Eddie Belmonte rode in only one race at Aqueduct yesterday and didn't do too well, finishing out of the money on an 11to1 shot. That sole outing for one of the top riders in the nation generated curiosity as to why Belmonte wasn't working more. Why dont I get more mounts? That's easy. Mr. Noe put too little weight on the horses, was the jockey's own explanation. I mean that there are too many horses carrying less than 115 pounds, and even though I am offered mounts, I don't like to accept them if I have to reducecept them if I have to reduce too much.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: 3d Trial in Murder Case Ruled Out

title: Events Today
description: GIGI, a musical, book and lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner, music by Frederick Loewe, directed by Joseph Hardy, choreography by Onna White, starring Alfred Drake, Maria KernHove, Agnes Moorehead and Daniel Massey with Karin Wolfe In title role; Uris Theater, 51st Street and Broadway, 6:45.

title: Major Independents
Technical Problem Cited In Sonatrach Gas Shutdown
description: Norton Q. Sloan, president of the Distrigas Corporation of Boston, advised the Federal Power Commission that the recent shutdown of two liquefaction lines in Algeria by Sonatrack, the Algerian national petroleurn organization, had been found to have been caused by technical problems. This has interrupted deliveries of liquefied natural gas to the East Coast since Oct. 23.

title: EDUCATORS SEEK SUCCESS FACTORS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Nov. 12 More than 100 scholars, educators and evertunent officials from 22 countries convened here today to begin weeklong conference on some of the thorniest questions facing both industrialized and underdeveloped countries.

title: Widening of Parkway May Be Completed in One Year
description: WOODBRIDGE, Nov. 12 (AP)  The widening of the Garden State Parkway south to Asbury Park should be finished by next November.

title: Cox Calls for Legal Guarantee Of Independence of Prosecutor
description: Cox Calls for Legal Guarantee Of Independence of Prosecutor Archibald Cox said last night that President Nixon, and not the courts, should be allowed to appoint a new Watergate prosecutor but that his independence should be guaranteed by Congressional statute.

title: New Drive On to Make Rape Convictions Easier
description: Convinted that last year's revision of the state law for sex offenses is not working, the women's movement and many prosecutors are preparing a fresh effort to make conviction of offenders easier.number of convictions gotten under the law. The most recent evidence is a study last year by the Police Department's Criminal Justice Liaison Division.firstdegree sodomy and attempted rape in the first degree.

title: Bridge: Simple Suit Combinations Can Produce Complexities
description: Some suit combinations that appear childishly simple may have unexpected complexities in special circumstances. Textbooks for beginners often show the reader an acequeen combination in dummy to illustrate a finesse, and leave the reader with complacent assumption that he now knows all there is to be known about such a holding.

title: Vandals Shoot Out Tires On School Bus Upstate
description: WELLSVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 12 (AP)School bus drivers reporting to work this morning found that one tire on each of the local school district's 17 buses had been shot out.

title: Blades Lose in Overtime
description: BOSTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)Hugh Harris scored an overtime goal at 3 minutes. 21 seconds of the suddendeath period tonight to give the New England Whalers a 32 victory over the New York Golden Blades in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Nov. 5.

title: FRANK B. RAMEY, LED JESSOP STEEL
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 12 Frank B. Rackley, who at the age of 33 in 1950 became president of the Jessop Steel Company here, died today in a hospital near his winter home in Orlando, Fla. He was 57 years old and remained a director of Athlone Industries, which acquired the major interest in the company in 1968.

title: U.N. AIDE REPORTED ON P.O.W. MISSION
description: NITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12Secretary General Waldheim has sent one of his top aides to the Middle East to try to work out an exchange of war prisoners held by Syria and Israel, according to qualified sources here.

title: CHARTER MEETING SET BY DEMOCRATS
description: ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 12 (AP) A drafting committee for a Democratic party charter will meet in Washington in December, a party spokesman said at the close of a weekend meeting of the Democratic party Charter Commission.

title: Books of The Times
description: I find Sexual Suicide the most reasonable and comprehensive book published so far on the relation between men and women in American society. This is not to say that Mr. Gilder is always right. In a sense, it hardly matters, because what he has to say is so lifeenhancing, his book offers such a beautiful view from the Mountain of Venus, that I would admire it even if it were wrong. He sounds more like a loverdefining and defending love than the usual propagandist or polemicist.

title: Innis and Shockley To Debate Genetics Dec, 4 at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 12 A student organization at Princeton announced today that Roy Innis, the director of the Congress of Racial Equality, and Dr. William B. Shockley, the Nobel laureate, had accepted an invitation to hold their controversial debate here next month.

title: RATIONING OF OIL BY STATES URGED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. An estimate that the nation facet; a daily shortage of 4 million to 6 million barrels of oil a day by midwinter led a scientist member of the House of Representatives to call here today for immediate rationing of petroleum, to be administered at first by state Governors.

title: ALLAN MICE, 58, A CORRESPONDENT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12Allan A. Michie, a World War II correspondent and author of numerous books, died of a heart ?? yesterday at his home, ?? Parkway. He was 58 years old.

title: McGovern Says Nixon Should Be Impeached
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 12 (UPI)President Nixon's best chance of establishing his innocence now lies in the impeachment route, the Democratic Presidential nominee he defeated last year said today. Senator George McGovern, of South Dakota said at a news conference that the President no longer can restore his credibility and the confidence of the American people by doling out information he thinks they should have.

title: STRIKE THREATENS BALLET OPENING
description: Negotiations failed yesterday to head off a threatened strike by dancers that would prevent the New York City Ballet from opening its 14week fallwinter season tonight.

title: Tracing AmericanAllied Clash: Events Outpaced the Attitudes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Misunderstandings, lack of information and a basic divergence in perceptions of the nature of the Middle East crisis led to the recent sharp public rift between Europe and the United States, according to American and allied diplomats.

title: JAMES ABBE, 91, DIES; A PHOTO JOURNALIST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12James Abbe, pioneer photo journalist and reporter whose career spanned the era from wet plates and flash powder to color television, died yesterday at his home here. He was 91 years old.

title: San Francisco Has Quake
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI)A light earthquake was felt in the San Francisco Bay area today, but there were no immediate reports of damage. Seismologists at the University of California Seismographic Station said the temblor had been centered in the south bay area and had been felt as far north as Marin County across the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: A Brooklyn Assemblyman Indicted on Bribe Charge
description: Assemblyman Calvin Williams was indicted yesterday by a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn on charges of allegedly bribing the driver of a gypsy cab to drop charges of assault, robbery and auto theft against Mr. Williams's 21yearold son.

title: TV: Maude the Director
description: It's surprising what can be stuffed into a situation comedy. This evening's example is, not surprisingly, Maude, which has Norman Lear as executive producer.

title: FUTURES IN CORN ADVANCE IN PRICE
Advertising: Audience Measure
description: An extra large wave has been generated on advertisidg's stormy seas by a controversy over the proper methodology for syndicated magazine audience research.

title: Court to Act on Political Ads in City Buses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Supreme Court agreeed today to decide whether a political candidate has a constitutional right to put his campaign advertisements on city buses that carry advertising for such products as soda pop and perfume.

title: Cubs' Beckert Goes to Padres
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP)Glenn Beckert, whose string offour AllStar appearances at second base was snapped by injury this year, was traded by the Chicago Cubs today to the San Diego Padres for an outfielder, Jerry Morales.

title: Abner Mikva to Run
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP)Abner J. Mikva, a fiveterm Democratic state legislator and former Illinois Representative announced today his candidacy in the 10th Congressional District. Mr. Mikva, 47 years old, will run against Representative Sam Young, a Republican who narrowly defeated Mr. Mikva in last year's election.

title: In Hospital, Patients and Staff Rejoice
description: When the strikers come in to work, the hospital tells me we can get going right away oh, I hope so! said Linda Perrette, a secretary from Jersey City, sitting up in bed yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital, First Avenue and 16th Street.

title: Robert H. Morgan, Official Of Hill School, Dies at 62
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 12Robert Handel Morgan, senior master of the Hill School, died of a heart attack Saturday in the Arts and Crafts Building of the school. He was 62 years old and lived here.

title: Carrier Strike Ends
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 12 (AP)Union workers voted to end their strike against the Carrier Corporation today, and company officials said that work would resume tomorrow. The strike, began Oct. 29.

title: Music: Isaac Stern & Co.
description: Isaac Stern and His Friends is a title that rolls off the tongue more smoothly than, say, The IstominSternRose Trio Plus One, another possible identifying tag for Sunday afternoon's concert at Carnegie Hall. And there was indeed a friendly feeling generated both in the audience and on stage that helped promote a chambermusic ambiance in the large hall.

title: Liddy Cited at Contempt Trial for 5 of Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UP1)The name of a member of the Watergate cast cropped up today in testimony at the, contempt trial of five of the Chicago Seven defendants.

title: Abner Mikva to Run
description: CHICAGO. Nov. 12 (AP)Abner J. Mikva, a fiveterm Democratic state legislator and former Illinois Representative announced today his candidacy in the 10th Congressional District. Mr. Mikva, 47 years old, will run against Representative Sam Young, a Republican who narrowly defeated Mr. Mikva in last year's election.

title: Polish Minister Talks With Pope In First Official Visit to Vatican
description: ROME, Nov. 12Foreign Minister Stefan Olszowski of Poland had a 50minute audience with Pope Paul VI todaythe first member of the Communist Government in Warsaw to pay a visit to the Vatican.

title: House Panel Backs A Plan f or Court To Pick Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) A House Judiciary subcommittee, on a 5 to 4 party line vote, approved today legislation to create a courtappointed special Watergate prosecutor. The full committee takes up the measure tomorrow.

title: Corning in Foreign Deals
description: The Corning Glass Works announced yesterday It had signed contracts with two foreign companies to supply substrates for use in automobile emissioncontrol catalytic converters. The concerns are Degussa of Frankfurt, West Germany, and Johnson Matthey & Co., Ltd., London, both of which supply Volkswagen.

title: Music: Isaac Stern & Co.
description: Isaac Stern and His Friends is a title that rolls off the tongue more smoothly than, say, The IstominSternRose Trio Plus One, another possible identifying tag for Sunday afternoon's concert at Carnegie Hall. And there was indeed a friendly feeling generated both in the audience and on stage that helped promote a chambermusic ambiance in the large hall.

title: Israel Terms Her Cut in Fuel an Act of Solidarity
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 12An official said today that restrictions on fuel consumption introduced here were intended largely as a gesture of solidarity with countries that were suffering because of Arab oil boycott.

title: Japan Warns on Oil
description: In the strongest Government statement to date on the fuel crisis, a Japanese official warned that Arab oil cutbacks threatened Japan with the first serious blow to her economy since World War II. Page 61.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Among the actions taken by the Supreme Court today were the following:

title: Art Takes New Form In Children's Hands
description: Nearly 60 children a day visit a new and unusual facility in a renovated storefront on the West Side to learn drawing, weaving, pottery, papermaking, printing and photography.

title: GUSTAVE LOEBEL
description: Gustave Loebel, who retired in 1967 as a vice president and director of the Continental Grain Company, one of the largest commoditytrading concerns, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 400 East 56th Street.

title: Back to the Coal Mine
description: With speed limits on the turnpikes reduced to 50 miles an hour, some Americans may feel that they have come at last to that slowdown era so long foretold by Cassandras with the perverse belief that finite resources do not last forever. For most, fears of a rundown future will be offset by popular visions of glamorous new energy sources in the offingclean, cheap, safe, inexhaustible and waiting only the application of money and technical knowhow. A quick look at those possibilities might be timely if not exhilarating.

title: Bishops Seek Latitude on Children's Confessions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The nation's Roman Catholic bishops indicated today that they favored a broad interpretation of a Vatican demand that they stop the practice of delaying the first confession for children until several years after they receive first communion.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PARAMUSThe rumor mills were circulating the story as to whether Dick DeTeresa had accidentaly or intentionally sidelined his roommate for the football season. After all, they were on opposite teams and DeTeresa's roommate was considered an outside threat, being described as small but fast.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
description: Nov. 13, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M.

title: MISS MATHE DANCES IN SLEEPING BEAUTY
description: On Saturday night, the National Ballet's Carmen Mathe, took the lead in Sleeping Beauty at the City Center 55th Street Theater. She was ably partnered by Dennis Poole.

title: Giants Regain Spirit
description: O. K., so the New York Giants didn't quit against the Dallas Cowboys last Sunday. But they didn't win either, so where does that leave them with only five games left? Do they really want the No. 1 choice in the college draft?

title: The Mysterious Tapes
description: Initially, the controversy over the Watergate tapes focused primarily on the question whether President Nixon would defy the courts. Now that Mr. Nixon has agreed to obey court orders to turn the tapes over to Chief District Judge John J. Sirica, the issue of Presidential defiance has given way, once again, to the question of Presidential credibility. His latest promise to turn over to the court new, unsubpoenaed material does notas yetmeet this basic problem.

title: Defendant Shoots Complainant, Then Wounds Himself in Court
description: A 39yearold defendant crit* ically wounded a woman and apparently shot himself in the head with a 22caliber revolver in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday as the presiding judge ducked under the bench and screaming spectators scurried for cover in the crowded courtroom.

title: Inquiry on Justice Rinaldi Over Leniency Is Reported
description: Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has been under investigation for nearly four months by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, concerning alleged judicial misconduct involving improperly lenient sentences for criminal defendants, highly placed sources said yesterday.

title: Music
description: Bach's Mass in B minor is one of the great monuments of music, but experience has taught us that conscious efforts to make it sound monumental can turn it into a bewildering, shapeless monster. Over the last few years, as symphonic fever has begun to die out among those who concern themselves with Bach, the B minor Mass has begun to be revealed in its more or less natural state, and its glories are becoming increasingly apparent.

title: The ABC's of Gas Rations
description: Many people 35 years of age and older probably remember the family car with its A, B, C or X stickers in the lower righthand corner of the windshield during World War II. This told the servicestation attendant at glance how much gasoline the driver was entitled to. The days of fill 'er up were gone for most people.

title: FIRE BURNS AN HOUR IN COLLAPSED HOTEL
description: A smoky fire burned for more than how yesterday after noon in the remains of the University Hotel, known in its better days as the Broadway Central, at 673 Broadway and West Third Street.

title: BREZHNEY MEETS TITO IN UKRAINE
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12President Tito of Yugoslavia flew to the Soviet Union today and began talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev centering on the Middle East and dealing with the improving trend of their political and economic relations.

title: Her Word Against His: Case History of a Sex Charge
description: This is an account of one of 3,500 complaints of sexual offenses that will be made the city this year. It is based on interviews with each of the key participants; the conflicting statements and points of view are given, illustrating the ambiguities jurors are called on to resolve.

title: Wood Field and Stream: Wild Game Made Palatable
description: That time of year his come in the Northeast when yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang upon the boughs which shake against the cold, and the wives of huntters are once again being called upon to make, something palatable of the game their husbands bring home.

title: Minor Electrical Fire Delays BMT Service
description: Electrical power was cut off on BMT subway tracks at the Broadway and Canal Street station for 13 minutes last evening while firemen put out a minor electrical fire in the rear of a local, headed from Astoria, Queens, to Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.

title: People in Sports: Congratulations to Aaron
description: At last congratulations were in order yesterday for Hank Aaron, although not for hitting another home run. The 39yearold Atlanta Braves' slugger, who was only one homer shy of tying Babe Ruth's career mark of 714, was married to Mrs. Billye Williams in Kingston, Jamaica. It was the second marriage for each. Aaron has two sons and two daughters by his previous marriage and Mrs. Williams, a widow, has one daughter. At the ceremony were two of the children, a Jamaican Government official and about six members of the press.

title: Fistfights Reported
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, Nov. 13Finnish troops of the United Nations Emergency Force established two checkpoints on the CairotoSuez road yesterday and held them in spite of a threat of attack by Israeli forces, highly placed sources reported. They said fistfights broke out between Finns and Israelis in the process.

title: Con Edison Asks Free Hand to Burn Dirty Fuel
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, saying it was running out of oil, asked at an unusual government hearing yesterday for a free hand to bypass all environmental controls on the fuel it used to generate electricity.

title: G.O.P.'s State Committee Will Convene to Rebuild
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12John Spoltore, the New Jersey Republican chairman, said today that he would soon convene meeting of the state committee to start to rebuild the party in the wake of its Election Day defeats.

title: PARKCHESTERASKS FULL CONVERSION
description: Harry B. Helmsley, one of the city's largest realestate operators, said yesterday that he was now seeking to convert the entire 12,000family Parkchester housing complex in the Bronx  the nation's second largest apartment development  into a condominium.

title: Grocers' Strike Is Spreading in France
description: PARIS, Nov. 12A grocers' strike in protest against price curbs is spreading in France as shopkeepers, joined by the major trade unions, head for a new confrontation with the Government over its antiinflation policies.

title: South African Bank Enlists Aid of Black Leaders
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  A white South African South bank has enlisted the support of three prominent black leaders in an advertising campaign overseas against economic boycolts of South Africa.
