title: Policemen Taking a Test Are Asked for Racial Data
description: The 20,395 New York police officers who took the fourandahalfhour examination Saturday for promotion to the rank of sergeant were also asked to fill out a separate questionnaire about their race, age, sex and educational achievement.

title: Schindler Asserts Reform Jews Will Press for Status in Israel
description: The newly elected head of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations said yesterday that it would press on a political level to achieve a more prominent status for Reform Judaism in Israel's religious life.

title: HEATH IS ASKED TO AID ON P.O.W.'S
description: LONDON, Nov. 12Premier Golda Meir urged Prime Minister Heath today to use his influence to speed the release of Israeli prisoners of war, particularly those held by Syria, a nonsigner of the ceasefire agreement.

title: People and Business
description: Savings banks in New York are unlikely to again experience a steady and assured deposit inflow with an easy spread between rates on savings and rates on mortgages, according to Harry W. Albright Jr., the State Superintendent of Banks.

title: Equity Financing
description: The New England Electric System's offering of 1.3million shares of common stock was won by a group of underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation. The group bid $20.888 a share and will reoffer them at $22 a share. New England Electric closed yesterday at 22, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 6 College Papers Accused On Illegal TermPaper Ads
description: Advertisements for prewritten term papers have appeared in six college newspapers here, State Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky charged yesterday.

title: Drivers Doubt Lower Speeds Will Save Gas
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 12 Sam Fields patted the fender of his 1971 Cadillac while he gassed up at the William F. Halsey service area on the New Jersey Turnpike. Speed limit doesn't bother me, he said. I've got a regulator. Just set it at 50 and let er roll. Mr. Fields, who lives at 40 Central Park South, Manhattan, was one of some 200,000 motorists who drove the turnpike with the new 50mileanhour speed limit today. The new limit was imposed last Thursday as a fuelconservation measure.

title: Rethinking the Cabinet
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y.The resigntions of Attorney General Richardson and Deputy Attorney General Ruckelshaus are important not only in themselves but also as a fundamental parture from the unwritten rules American political behavior. It remains to be seen whether this departure marks the beginning of a new constitutional tradition.

title: Big Crowd Marks Antiques Fair Start In White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 12It was an unusually lively opening for the Eastern States Antiques Fair, with the heaviest attendance in several editions of the show. Many of the visitors to the fairgrounds at the Westchester County Center weren't just looking. Their exodus was marked by accompanying packages and a trail, inside, of Sold signs.

title: Richard V. Pitchford Dies; Magician Known as Cardini
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 12Richard V. Pitchford, who as Cardini was a prominent sleightofhand artist and was president of the Magicians Guild in 1945, died today in Kingston Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Gardiner.

title: Church's Window Stolen
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (UPI) The search continued today for four Tiffany stainedglass windows, worth up to $150,000, which were stolen from a church on the city's East Side. A custodian who lives in the basement of the Humanist Fellowship of Liberation church discovered the theft of the 4by12foot windows yesterday.

title: MOSCOW PRESSES FINLAND ON TRADE
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12The press renewed Soviet public pressure on Finland today not to affiliate with the European Common Market with a warning that this would subordinate the country's economy to the interests of major international monopolies.

title: Results of Firefighters' Vote on Calling a Strike Here Are Disclosed to Grand Jury
description: The head of the Honest Baligt Association, George J. Abrams, disclosed to a Manhattan grand jury yesterday the results of the vote that preceded the five  and  a  half  hour strike last Tuesday by 10,900 city firemen.

title: Aide Says Curb May Cut Gain of Economy
description: TOKYO, Nov. 12  In the strongest Government statement so far on the fuel crisis, a senior economic official warned today that the Arab oil cutbacks threatened; Japan with the first serious blow to its economy since World War II.

title: New Drive On to Make Rape Convictions Easier
description: Convinced that last year's revision of the state law for sex offenses is not working, the women's movement and many prosecutors are preparing a fresh effort to make conviction of offenders easier.

title: Ecological Survey Says New Center Passes U.S. Tests
description: Officials of the West Side convention center corporation released a report yesterday on the environmental effects of the project that they said showed that traffic, noise and pollution generated by the $200million complex would be within Federal standards.

title: 2 Flee Burning Truck
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 12 (UPI) A truck driver and his passenger ran from their burning truck north of here late yesterday to escape injury when the flames set off the load of dynamite. The driver, Orin IC, Miller, said his truck had caught fire and he had pulled the vehicle off to the side of the highway. He said that he and passenger, Roy Wittenmyer, had run like hell.

title: High Court Backs New I.C.C. Rules To End Rail Lines
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) The Supreme Court upheld today new Interstate Commerce Commission rules designed to simplify and speed up railroad abandonment procedures.

title: FarmCity Week Designated
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) President Nixon designated Nov, 16.22 as National FarmCity Week today to emphasize and strengthen the bond between America's farms and cities in promoting the nation's economic wellbeing and progress.

title: Nixon Offers Sirica Data On the Two Conversations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 President. Nixon offered today to furnish Federal District Judge John J. Sirica with background information on two conversations sought by Watergate investigators that the secret White House recording system failed to record.

title: Stage: The Foursome
description: British playwrightsor at least many of themseem interested nowadays in a kind of microscopic reality, virtually a documentary thea??er, probably borrowed from the cinema, that makes its points with a relentless insistence en time, place and minute detail.

title: $4Million Suit by Otepka Against Times Is Dismissed
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 A Federal judge dismissed today a $4million libel suit brought against The New York Times by Otto F. Otepka, a former employe of the State Department.

title: Defendant Shoots Complainant, Then Wounds Himself in Court
description: A 39yearold critically wounded a woman and apparently shot himself in the head with a .22caliber revolver in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday as the presiding judge ducked under the bench and screaming spectators scurried for cover in the crowded courtroom.

title: FRENCH CRITICIZE U.S.SOVIET ROLE
description: PARIS, Nov. 12In the strongest official denunciation of SovietAmerican accords yet heard in Western Europe, France's Foreign Minister said today that the brutal crises in the Middle East confirmed his Government's doubts about the superpowers' capacities to keep peace.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE BY 30,000 ENDED
description: Hospital workers returned to their jobs yesterday after voting to accept a wage settlement scaled down by the Federal Cost of Living Council, thus ending a weeklong walkout that had crippled 48 hospitals and nursing homes in the area.

title: THOMPSON MITCHELL OF RCA GLOBAL UNIT
description: Thompson H. Mitchell, who retired in 1966 as president of RCA Global Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of RCA, died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had been living. He was 72 years old.

title: Factory Job Loss in State in Face of Gains in Projects Scored
description: The State Commerce Department reported yesterday that nearly four times as many new manufacturing projects started as closed or shrank since 1959, but a joint legislative committee also heard that the state had lost 300,000 manufacturing jobs in the period.

title: HOUSE APPROVES ALASKA PIPELINE: ENERGY BILL GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Two major bilis, to deal with the energy shortage cleared important hurdles in Congress today.

title: STRIKE THREATENS BALLET OPENING
description: Negotiations failed yesterday to head off a threatened strike by dancers that would prevent the New York City Ballet from opening its 14week fallwinter season tonight.

title: BOTH RIGHT AND LEFT ASSAIL MRS. GANDHI
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 12Prime Minister Indira Gandhi faced an angry opposition in Parliament today as a sixweek winter session began.

title: Club in Englewood Hires Black Pro
description: Jack Wiley, who says he is the first black to become head professional at a private golf club in the metropolitan area, will take over his post Jan. 1 at the Englewood Golf Club in New Jersey.

title: Royal Wedding Is Hardly Topic A in New York
description: If there's one subject New Yorkers don't seem to be talking about it's Princess Anne's $240,000 wedding tomorrow in Westminster Abbey. The big event, to be held in the presence of millions of television watchers around the world, just isn't generating much excitement in New York.

title: Substitute's Spark Enlivens a Dull Garden Season
description: Wingo, Wingo That was the only happy cry last Thursday night from Knick fans at Madison Square Garden. The following evening in Philadelphia even some 76er fans found themselves chanting, Wingo,. Wingo. Back at the Garden Saturday night, Knick fans with little to cheer about an 87 wonlost record again resorted to, Wingo, Wingo.

title: N.F.L.Players Want Real Thing
description: Eightyfive per cent of the National Football League's 1,300 players prefer playing on grass than on artificial turf. This was a claim made yesterday by the N.F.L. Players Association at its oneday conference in Washington presided over by an athlete with a leg in a cast. The basic complaint was that the artificial surfaces are too, hard and too hot, increasing the probability of injury. It's like playing on a concrete yard, said Tom Keating of the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Energy Official Warns U.S. on Waste
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 12  Gasoline rationing may begin as early as Jan. 1, 1974, the President's energy adviser said here today.

title: Controversy Over the Ceremony's Cost
description: LONDON, Nov. 12A story whispered in the aristocratic echelons of British society has it that Princess Anne's wedding will be so expensive that Prince Charles will not be permitted to marry before 1976 at the earliest.

title: CRUISE IS CANCELED BY A LABOR DISPUTE
description: A labor dispute aboard the Holland America Cruises' Statendam caused the cancellation yesterday of a 14day Caribbean trip. The 24,294ton liner was supposed to have sailed yesterday at 5 P.M.

title: SMALL RISE SHOWN IN STEEL PRODUCTION
description: Steel production for the week ended Nov. 10 edged ahead 0.1 per cent to 2,932,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 2,929,000 tons poured in the preceding week. The weekly production index rose to 120.2 from 120.1 in the week ended Nov. 3.

title: HOUSE UNIT SEEKS 3% DEFENSE SLASH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The House military appropriations subcommittee has cut the defense budget by $2.9billion, a far smaller reduction than committee leaders had planned before the Middle East war.

title: George Bradshaw, Writer, Dies; Many Stories Adapted as Films
description: George Bradshaw, a writer whose short stories were often adapted for the screen, died Sunday night while riding in a taxi near his home at 68 East 86th Street. His age was 64.

title: Slain TV Comic and Wife Carried $5,700 in Cash
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 12 (AP) David Akeman, the television comedian, and his wife had $5,700 in cash hidden on them when they were murdered Saturday night in what was believed to be a burglary, a police source said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
Phillippines to Organize Panel To Pursue Soviet Trade Talks
description: MANILAPhotos of trade delegations from Communist nations appear increasingly in the newspapers. And some of the language institutes here are offering lessons in Russian and Mandarin Chinese for the first time.

title: Competitive Bidding
description: The House Ways and Means Committee has voted to increase Social Security benefits by 11 per cent next yearreversing its previous day's decision to boost benefits by 10 per cent. The extra amount split the difference between Republicans, who wanted a 10 per cent increase, and Democrats, who were going for 12.

title: U.A.W. Tries to Overcome Opposition to Ford Pact
description: DETROIT, Nova 12Leaders of the United Automobile Workers tried today to stem wide opposition, particularly among skilled trade workers, to a tentative national contract reached with the Ford Motor Company last, Oct. 26.

title: Detectives Study Possible Link In Two GanglandType Killings
description: Detectives were investigating yesterday a possible link between the killings of a numbersrackets gambler found slain in Central Park Sunday and of another gambler found dead in his car in the Bronx a week ago.

title: Fistfights Reported
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, Nov. 13Finnish troops of the United Nations Emergency Force established two checkpoint's on the CairotoSuez road yesterday and held them in spite of a threat of attack by Israeli forces, highly placed sources reported. They said fistfights broke out between Finns and Israelis in the process.

title: SKYLAB 3 LIFTOFF POSTPONED AGAIN
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 12The Skylab 3 aunching was postponed again today after technicians discovered more cracks in the eightyearold Saturn 1B rocket.

title: Text of President Nixon's Statement on Status of Evidence in Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Following is the text of President Nixon's statement issued by the White House today on the status of the evidence in the Watergate case:

title: Chiefs Win by 197, Gain Tie for Lead
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 12 (UPI)Jan Stenerud booted four field goals in the first half, one after time had run out, and Mike Livingston hooked up with Otis Taylor on a 24yard touchdown pass in the third quarter tonight as the Kansas City Chiefs defeated the Chicago Bears, 197, in a National Football League game.

title: SHOP TALK
Caso Proposes Nassau Budget With Tax Rise of $29 a Year
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12 Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, released his proposed county budget for 1974 today, one that would result in an increase in the property tax rate of about 38 cents for each $100 of assessed valution for most taxpayers.

title: G.O.P. Revives Policy Unit Independent of President
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Republican party established today what It hoped would be a policy voice independent of President Nixon just as the White House said it was beginning to win the counteroffensive against its Watergate critics.

title: East Side Man Convicted Of LoanSharking Murder
description: An East Side copywriter and freelance journalist was convicted late yesterday of murder and attempted murder in a loansharking dispute in an East Village afterhours bar.

title: NATHAN'S PLANNING UNITS ON WEST COAST
description: Nathan's Furious, Inc., the 57yearold restaurant chain, announced yesterday that it planned to open its first, West Coast unit next summer following a franchise agreement concluded with the American Fast Foods Corporation, of Los Angeles. At least 19 Nathan's restaurants will eventually be in operation on the West Coast, starting with the first in suburban :Los Angeles, it was said.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: POUND FILES GOING TO L. I. RESEARCHER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12C. David Heymann, a doctoral candidate at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, identified himself today as the researcher who is scheduled to receive the Federal Bureau of Investigation's secret files on Ezra Pound, the poet.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Doubt can tear a man apart. It also can ravage a football team, For six straight weeks feelings of uncertainty kept gnawing with increasing intensity among the New York Giants, They had begun to snap and snarl at each other. A week ago Bob Tucker offered the most cutting recrimination of all. We're just a bunch of quitters, said with a growl.

title: State Death Penalty Permanently Voided
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 12 New York's death penalty statute was permanently voided today when the Supreme Court refused to set aside last June's ruling by the New York Court of Appeals that the state law was unconstitutional.

title: Too Late and Too Little
description: When Richard Nixon and John B. Connally Jr. discussed the possibility that Mr. Nixon might nominate Mr. Connally to fill the VicePresidential vacancy, the two men never actually talked. Mr. Nixon spoke to his aide, General Haig, who talked to Mr. Connally, then carried the response back to Mr. Nixon; and so on.

title: Dobrynin Calls Expanded U.S. Trade Vital for Political Dtente
description: Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz said here yesterday that the United States should seek to improve economic relationships with others not only for economic but also political gains.

title: C.B.S. Cancels Order Barring Instant Analysis of Speeches
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System has done away with its shortlived policy prohibit. ing its news correspondents from commenting on, or analyzing, Presidential addresses immediately after they are delivered.

title: Next Session Tomorrow
description: CAIRO, Nov. 12Egyptian and Israeli negotiators today failed for the second day to make progress toward agreeing on steps to carry out their ceasefire agreement, and their next session was put off until Wednesday.

title: Business Briefs
description: Frankfurt, West Germany, Nov. 12 (Reuters)The dollar reached its highest level since midsummer on Western European money markets today with a continuing wave of buying orders indicating that its strong recovery this month had not yet reached its peak.

title: Group Honors Surgeon
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 12. (AP) Dr. William W. L. Glenn of the Yale Medical School will share the American Heart Association's highest award for volunteer leadership this year. Dr. Glenn, president of the association in 197071, developed the Glenn procedure in openheart surgery for sending blood past the heart's right chamber to the lungs while correcting certain heart defects.

title: An Israeli Warning
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 12Israeli officials said tonight that unless a deadlock over control of the CairoSuez highway was resolved and Israeli prisoners promptly returned, Israel would have to reconsider the ceasefire agreement, including her pledge to permit the continuing supply of the Egyptian III Corps.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger said that the United States was considering a mutual security treaty with Israel as one of the possible ways of guaranteeing Israel's boundaries once a formal peace agreement has been achieved in the Middle East. Mr. Kissinger also said the Arabs' embargo on oil shipments to the United States would probably continue for the indefinite future but would not provoke the United States into dropping its support for Israel. He made the remarks in an interview filmed in Peking. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: House Subcommittee Backs Strip Mining Control Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI A subcommittee of the House Inter Committee gave its final approval today to a nationwide strip mining control bill, after rejecting attempts to strengthen safeguards for Western ranchers on federally owned coal deposits.

title: Combustion Tests Of Radioactive Gas Are Due to Begin
description: DENVER, Nov. 12The Colorado State Health Department issued today a permit allowing production testing of radioactive natural gas produced by an underground nuclear explosion on May 17 near Rio Blanco in northwestern Colorado.

title: Villagers Lingering in Misery in Safe Site Near Saigon
description: BINH HOA, South VietnamIt has been nearly seven years since American troops suddenly surrounded the prosperous village of Ben Suck forced its residents into a barren makeshift camp 20 miles away and then burned, bombed and bulldozed the village out of existence.

title: $750Million Plan In Australia Ended By 6Nation Group
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 13 A sixnation consortium planning a $750,000million processing plant for bauxite ore in northern Australia has dropped the project because of the high exchange rate of the Australian currency.

title: Phillips Is Ordered to Delay Ending Pact at Consumers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (UPI)The Phillips Petroleum Company was ordered by Federal appeals court today to postpone at least until Jan. 1 termination of its gasoline supply contract with the Consumers Oil Corporation, Trenton.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: HIGH NOON There's a new, regular theater in town, housed in the 240seat theater in the, round, the Martinique (in the hotel of the same name), 49 West 32d Street (5657134). It's called Muse for Lunch and the Idea is to provide middaybreak entertainment to anybody who's in the busy neighborhood and wants, to see a show at either 12:15 or 1:15.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Musicals Remembered
description: Three on Broadway the anthology that began this season's Matinee Series Monday at Theater de Lys, covers 70 years of the American musical theater  from Victor Herbert to Burt Bacharach.

title: Political Aspects of World Oil Crisis
description: Will peace between Israel and Egyptassuming the Kissinger plan holds together cause the Arabs to lay down the oil weapon they have taken up against the United States, Western Europe and Japan? This possibility seems highly unlikely because the monopoly profits to be earned by the producers' cartel, facing a divided assortment of buyers and a highly inelastic demand for their product, are enormous. The submissiveness of the Europeans and Japanese to Arab political demands has, in the view of some American oil experts, only spurred the Arabs' appetite.

title: Bankers Hail Gold Move; See Strength of Dollar
description: Bankers interviewed last night termed the decision by the United States and the other nations to end a fiveyear ban on gold sales in the market a logical one and suggested that it was prompted by the recent strength of the dollar in world currency markets.

title: FM Stations Silenced By Antenna Problem
description: A number of FM radio stations were off the air last night for up to two and a half hours because of a mechanical problem with an antenna at the Empire State Building.

title: Pay Due for Maternity Leave
description: BRISTOL, Conn., Nov. 13 (UPITwo teachers dismissed last year for maternity reasons will get back pay and sick leave credit. The Board of Education voted in favor of the teachers yesterday after the City Council and Corporation Counsel had advised them to do so.

title: Harlequin Tales, Other Entertainments
description: Harlequins are like U.F.O.'s. The city can go months on end without hearing about a single one, then suddenly they show up in pairs.

title: Rochdale Village Facing Cutoff Of All Fuels by Thanksgiving
description: One of the city's larger housing developments, Rochdale Villags in Queens, will go cold and dark next week unless alternative fuel supplies can be found.

title: NATIONS END BAR TO GOLD TRADING IN FREE MARKET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The United States and six European countries have terminated the fiveyearold agreement that barred them from transactions in gold in the free market.

title: Washington Women Lobbyists Are Making Themselves Heard
description: WASHINGTONThe image of the lobbyist as a cigar smoker, a wisecracker, a gladhander, a backslapper and, above all, a man, is being challenged by the capitol's small but growing band of women lobbyists.

title: Woman Shot in Courtroom Under Arrest in Hospital
description: A 32yearold legal secretary who is in critical condition after being wounded in Monday's shooting in Manhattan Criminal Court, was placed under arrest yesterday on a charge of possession of a deadly weapon. She is in the intensivecare unit of BeekmanDowntown Hospital.

title: Pregnant Whale Is Well Again
description: Francis, the pregnant white whale at the New York Aquarium, has resumed her normal appetite after a brief respiratory infection. Her whitecell blood count is down to normal and she looks happy and fatter.

title: Music
description: Joseph Fuchs ended his violin program in Tully Hall on Monday night by having his sister, the violist Lillian Fuchs, and a chamber orchestra join him in a performance of Mozart's Sinfonia concertante in E flat (K. 364).

title: PRISONER ESCAPES BRONX HOSPITAL
description: A 22yearold man arrested last Wednesday and charged with robbery and reckless endangerment escaped last night from a guarded room in the BronxLebanon Hospital, the police reported.

title: Meskill Begins a Tour To Listen to the People
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Nov. 13 Borrowing an idea from Governor Rockefeller, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut conducted an open meeting last night with the people of Meriden, the first in a series of planned community forums designed to bring the government closer to the people.

title: Even Texas Is Running Short
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 13Gov. John Love, the President's energy assistant, is even gloomier in private than he is in public about the duration of the energy crisis. And even Texas is beginning to wonder about the future.

title: Samuels Seeks to Head Balanced Ticket
description: While trying to line up sup, port for the Democratic nomi, nation for Governor next year Howard J. Samuels is urging Democratic politicians to work for an ethnically and geo graphically balanced ticket.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Clemente Pilot Had Lost License

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Penguins Set Back Stars, 52
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (UPI)  Lowell MacDonald scored three goals in 4 minutes 17 seconds tonight to lift the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 52 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Life in W.H.A.: It's Better Than In Bush Leagues
description: Although she can sleep later if she wants to, Stacy Morrison will get up at 9 o'clock this morning so me and Kevin can have breakfast together.

title: EMIGRATION RISE FROM CHINA CUT
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Nov. 14China appeared today to be responding to British diplomatic pleas to put the brakes on legal immigration to this overcrowded colony.

title: A Lot of Little Learning
description: PEKINGThe advances of China in highly specialized fields such as nuclear physics, missile engineering and medicineincluding ingenions and effective new uses of acupuncture and herbal curesdemonstrate that learning in this ancient seat of wisdom has not been stifled by the superficially static code of Mao. Tietung thought or addled by the whirling experimentation of revolutionary practice.

title: Museum Strikers Picket Mrs. John D. Rockefeller
description: The striking professional and administrative employes of the Museum of Modern Art have thrown up pickets in front of the 1 Beekman Place home of Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d, chairman of the museum's board of trustees,

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)The Federal Aviation Administration attempted in 1971 to ground permanently the man who piloted the plane that carried Pittsburgh Pirate baseball star Roberto Clemente to his death last year, government records shim The F.A.A.'s order revoking the commercial license of Arthur Rivera never went into effect. Rivera appealed the decision to the National Transportation Safety Board and his license was suspended for 180 days.

title: James Lyons, 47, Writer, Dies; Edited American Record Guide
description: James Lyons, editor and publisher of The American Record Guide since 1957, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 47 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey dally lottery number yesterday was:

title: Beneficial Corp.'s 3Month Profit malls 8% as Finance and Merchandise Divisions Lag
Fisheries Compromise
description: After more than a year of acrimonious debates and bruising confrontations at sea, Britain and Iceland appear to have reached a fair and pragmatic settlement of the dispute which began when Iceland arbitrarily extended its fisheries limit to fifty miles and sought to restrict the operations of British and other foreign trawlers.

title: Knicks Topple Sonics
description: The Knicks just beat the best playground team in the National Basketbal Association.

title: Butz Hints U.S. Weighed Food Embargo on Arabs
description: ROME, Nov. 13Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz indicated today that the United States had been contemplating an end to food exports to Arab countries in retaliation for their oil embargo, but would probably refrain from such a measure.

title: A Wide AntiMarxist Purge in Chile Is Shaking the Universities
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 13 Two months after the military coup that overthrew President Salvador Allende Gossens, a vast antiMarxist purge is shaking the Chilean university system to its foundations.

title: Ward Sets Mark In School Run
description: Carlos Ward, a Sheepshead Bay junior, set a meet record yesterday, while winning the Public Schools Athletic League individual crosscountry title at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Edward Redman, Managed The Dartmouth Club. Here
description: HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 13Edward B. Redman, manager of the Dartmouth Club of New York from 1935 to his retirement in 1957, died yesterday in the Hanover Convalescent Center. He was 88 years old.

title: Fuel Costs for Electricity Reported Up Here by 20%
description: Fuel costs for each kilowatt hour of electricity have risen 20 per cent in New York City and Westchester, Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the Public Service Commission, said in a report made public by Governor Rockefeller yesterday.

title: Farmers Fear New Federal Crop Policy May Lead to Scarcities
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The big combine clattered to a stop at the edge of a soybean field and Kenneth Cheers climbed down from its glasswalled cab to greet a waiting visitor. A friendly smile creased the dust smudges of the young Iowa farmer's face as he remarked:

title: Libya, on Sidelines in the Fighting, Takes Own Steps Against Israel
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Nov. 8While other Arab nations are trying to extend the Middle East truce, Libya is taking steps to keep military and diplomatic pressure on Israel.

title: ALASKA PIPELINE VOTED BY SENATE NIXON GETS BIB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13In an atmosphere of crisis, the Senate approved the Alaska pipeline bill today and sent it to President Nixon. The vote was 80 to 5, and there was only perfunctory debate.

title: Nixon Plays Piano In a Surprise Visit At Senator's Party
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) President Nixon made a surprise appearance tonight at the 75th birthday party of Senator Wallace F. Bennett, Republican of Utah.

title: FUEL SUPPLIERS MAY CURB BUSES
description: The Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority, which absorbed all 10 private bus lines in Nassau County last spring, faces a complete shutdown of all operations at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow unless diesel fuel supplies can be obtained, officials announced last night. About 75,000 daily riders would be affected.

title: S.E.C. Adopts Proposal Calling For Fuller Corporate Disclosure
description: A proposal to require corporations to disclose more fully their liquidity and borrowing costs was adopted in Washington yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Books of The Times
description: ELSEWHERE, PERHAPS. By Amos Oz. Translated From the Hebrew Malcom alter by Nicholas de Lange. 309 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $7.95.

title: Local Voting Held in Spain
description: MADRID, Nov. 13 (Reuters) Spaniards voted today for town councilmen and local political representatives in a rare if limitedchance to participate directly in public affairs. The elections were for a small minority of councilmen in the nation's 8,653 city and town councils, and for local representatives of the National Movement, Spain's only legal political organization.

title: FourCar Crash Ties Up Van Wyck Expressway
description: A fourcar crash last night on the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens blocked all three southbound lanes between the Long Island Expressway and Jewel Avenue for more than an hour.

title: Independent Inquiry
description: The most urgent need in the Watergate investigation is a special prosecutor chosen by the judicial branch of the Government and known to be totally independent of the Nixon Administration.

title: Monday's Fights
description: Felt ForumJorge Ahumada, 176 pounds, Argentina, knocked out Billy Kelly Wagner, 175, Cleveland, 7 rounds.

title: GUILD UNIT AT TIMES APPROVES NEW PACT
description: Members of the Newspaper Guild at The New York Times approved a new twoyear contract yesterday by a vote of 704 to 246, it was announced by Bernard Stein, unit chairman.

title: Prices Off Again on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market plunged again yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Municipal League Meeting
description: DALLAS, Nov. 13 (UPI)The National Municipal League will open a fourday meeting here tomorrow on the theme, Changing Roles in the New Federalism. The meeting is the league's 79th national conference on government.

title: Gulf and Ashland Fined for 1972 Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Two major oil corporations and a top executive of each pleaded guilty today to having made illegal campaign contributions of $100,000 apiece with corporate funds to the 1972 reelection campaign of President Nixon.

title: Driver Dies in Gas Explosion
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 13 (AP) A liquid propane gas tanker truck crashed through a bridge and exploded here last night, killing the driver and sending up flames visible nearly 20 miles. The victim was identified by the police as Darrell Bailey, 38 years old, of Arlington.

title: H.E.W. Invests $120,000 In an Economy Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)A team of executives Hired to slash wasteful welfare spending is scheduled to Move next month into a suite of Federal offices remodeled at a cost of $120,000.

title: Fresh Fire to Douse
description: This may be the twilight of the floundering Federal wageprice control program, but New Yorkers would never guess it from the pivotal role the Cost of Living Council is playing in determining what happens to this city's vital services.

title: Brandt Criticizes U.S. Policy Methods
description: STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 13 (AP)  Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany demanded today that the United States treat the ninenation European Common Market as an equal partner.

title: Two Heart Researchers Win Albert Lasker Awards
description: An 87yearold electrical engineer who developed the technique of external heart massage for people whose hearts have stopped beating, and a medical researcher whose theories on electrical control of heart rhythm led to the development of the pacemaker, are the winners of the 28th annual Albert Lasker Clinical Research Awards.

title: DOLLAR RISER HALTED IN EUROPEAN TRADING
description: LONDON, Nov. 13 (UPI)The dollar's weeklong rise on European markets was halted today after the Bink of England raised its minimum lending rate to a record 13 per cent from 11 per cent, pushing the pound upward.

title: Kissinger Assures the Chinese U.S. Policy Will Stay Constant
description: PEKING, Wednesday, Nov. 14 Secretary of State Kissinger publicly assured Chinese leaders last night that American policy toward Peking would remain constant no matter what happens in the United States in the future.

title: Wilkins and Gibson Tour Inner City; Rights Leader Calls Jobs the No. 1 Need
description: NEWARK, Nov. 13  Roy Wilkins, the executive direc??or of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said here today that the main need of innercity people, in Newark and elsewhere, is jobs.

title: McCord Appeals Conviction For Breakin at Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) James W. McCord Jr. appealed his conviction today for conspiracy, burglary and wiretapping in the Watergate breakin, and asked to be released until a Federal appellate court acts.

title: T.W.A. Strike Talks Continue
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UN) Contract talks continued today between Trans World Airlines and striking stewards and stewardesses but one source close to the negotiations said the two sides were still far apart. They're trying to get on the runway, the source said. But they're still not close to a settlement. The strike began Nov. 5.

title: City Ballet Strikes.
description: A strike by the dancers of the New York City Ballet caused cancellation of the opening of the fall season last night. It marred the celebration marking the company's 25th year, which was to have taken place after the performance. Page 47.

title: Oct. 1 Fiscal Year Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (Reuters)The Federal Government would start its fiscal year Oct. 1, rather than July 1, starting in 1975 under a budget control bill approved today by the House Rules Committee.

title: $500,000 Golf On Today.
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 13 Golf's richest tournament, the $500,000 World open, resumes tomorrow after a twoday intermission with Gibby Gilbert leading by five strokes. But the tournament's future was uncertain.

title: Nixon Has Council's Support
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI)The sevenmenber City Council of this Orange County beach community voted unanimously yesterday to support President Nixon during the domestic crisis caused by Watergaterelated matters.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES BUDGET REFORM BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) A bill providing for Congress to approve an overall budget and then adjust individual spending measures to fit it was approved today by the House Rules Committee after months of study.

title: About New York Balanchine Loses a Bet
description: The dancers struck more in sorrow than in anger yesterday, and the New York City Ballet did not open last night. The dancers do not look like militant union members, and when they talk about their strike, they do not sound like them. They are dancers, and they say that dancing is all they ever want to do.

title: FELONY SENTENCES BY JUDGES SCORED
description: The chairman of the State Select Committee on Crime said yesterday that New York judges had illegally freed defendants in at least 247 felony narcotic cases in the last few years.

title: YealePrinceton Game Saturday Marks 100th Year of Rivalry
description: In some quarters the Jvy League has been referred to as the Ancient Eight. Although the league begin formal, round robin play until the 1956 season, some of its rivalries date, back to the misty beginning of college football. One of those is the YalePrinceton game, which will be played this Saturday Palmer Stadium. The game will mark the 100th anniversary of the gridiron rivalry between the Big Three power.

title: HOSPITALS SEEK STRIKE PAYMENT
description: The 48 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes struck last week by 30,000 hospital workers, are asking the state and Blue Cross to pay them more than $5.2million they say they lost because of the work stoppage.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1973
description: Israeli forces demonstrated that they retained full control of the road leading to the city of Suez despite the two United Nations checkpoints that were set up Monday. Israeli soldiers with machine guns at the ready and standing shoulder to shoulder held back about 120 newsmen and cameramen who had come from Cairo to the point on the CairoSuez road called Kilometer 101. [1:4.]

title: BEAME'S SON GETS JOB OF SCREENING
description: Mayor  elect Abraham D. Beame has given virtually total authority for screening top appointees to his administration to his 37yearold son, Bernard, who was his campaign manager.

title: Catholics Find More Support For Abortions in Certain Cases
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 13 (UFO A majority of Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews favor abortion if the mother's health is endangered, in cases of rape or to prevent birth of a defective child, according to a survey conducted by The National Catholic Reporter.

title: House Panel Votes to Limit Nixon Impoundment Power
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)The House Rules Committee approved legislation today to limit President Nixon's power to impound funds and to create a new House committee to oversee the Congresisonal budgetmaking process.

title: Briton Charged in $170,000 Stock Case
description: A pinstripesuited Englishman who allegedly swindled $170,000 from a Wall Street brokerage house through a girlfriend's account, was arrested here in a new guisethat of a bearded hippie, the police said yesterday.

title: Justice Rinaldi Is Indicted On Lying and Obstruction
description: Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court Brooklyn has been indicted on a charge of lying under oath and seeking to obstruct a state investigation into judicial corruption, the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, announced yesterday.

title: Girl Athletes Given Support in Court
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov, 13 (UPI)The State of Pennsylvania filed suit today to force the Pennsylvania Interscholastic Athletic Association to permit girls to compete along with boys in all high school sports except wrestling and football.

title: MARA STILL SET ON JERSEY HOME
description: TRENTON, Nov. 13Wellington Mara, the president of the New York Giants, said today he was still enthusiastic about moving his football team to northern New Jersey despite new demands that the contract involving the Giants' commitment to move there be renegotiated.

title: G.O.P. Debt a New Threat to Spoltore
description: TRENTON, Nov. 13  Reports circulating today that the gubernatorial campaign debt incurred by Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. and his supporters could reach $300,000 inspired new discussion of the possibility of a protracted battle over Republican party leadership.

title: Symposium Envisions a Lasting Peace
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13A threeyear series of symposiums that will explore mankind's seemingly irresistible urge to make war began at the University of Pennsylvania last night. Members of a distinguished panel generally agreed with the keynote speaker, Dr. R. Buckrainster Fuller, that a peaceful world was possible today, probably for the first time in history.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Our mail is filled with nostalgia. For example, about apples: Having been raised in Ohio, writes a Woman from Port Washington, I early learned that the only apple worth losing summer to autumn for was the Jonathan. It was probably a Jonathan that konked Newton on the head, for it is the smartest, the crispiest, the best of all apples.

title: BALANCED TICKET ASKED BY SAMUELS
description: While trying to line up support for the Democratic nomination for Governor next year, Howard J. Samuels is urging Democratic politicians to work for an ethnically and geographically balanced ticket.

title: NORTON SIMON SEES EARNINGS INCREASE
description: Norton Simon, Inc., expects to increase earnings in its second fiscal year ending December by about 7.5 per cent from $18.9million, or 48 cents a share, earned in the similar three months last year with sales up, about 8.5 per cent from $378million, David J. Mahoney, chairman and president, said following annual meeting of stockholders in the Commodore Hotel here yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Natele Marcone, president of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn to making a false statement in an application for a $6,000 bank loan.

title: Chill for the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) The order by the Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, to lower the temperature to 68 in the Senate to save fuel prdduced a chilly climate today.

title: Dance: The Inbal Theater of Israel
description: Inbal, Dance Theater of Israel is a watchcharm folk company, modest in size but with a warm humorous quality. One has the impression of seeing exotic children at play much of the time. The group began its season last night at the City Center.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Senate Commerce Committee said yesterday that it would hold hearings tomorrow and on Friday on a bill that was passed last week in the House and which would restructure the Penn Central and six other bankrupt Eastern railroads.

title: Center Faces Unending Deficit
description: There are no laborsaving devices in the arts, a weary Norman Singer, executive director of the City Center of Music and Drama, said yesterday. A quartet still requires four musicians, a pas de deux takes two dancers.

title: Soccer Results
description: WORLD CUP

title: In Britain, Pomp Is Same, but Not the Circumstances
description: LONDON, Nov. 13Britain is demonstrating to the world that while she may have lost her empire, she hasn't lost her touch. More than 500 million people will watch the pageantry of a royal wedding tomorrow, but what they won't be seeing is the disquietsome call it malaisethat infects the fabric of British life these days. The British have no peers in pomp. But they do have plenty of problems stirring the political and social atmosphere, worrying the Government of Prime Minister Heath, occupying pages of space in the press, and recalling the 17thcentury words of Samuel Pepys: Every day things look woes eand woese.

title: Jury Indicts 8 ExOfficers Of Equity Funding Life Co.
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (UPI)A Lake County grand jury indicted today eight former officials of the Equity Funding Life Insurance Company and its parent concern on charges of conspiracy and forgery.

title: Nixon Meets 15 Senators; Watergate Doubts Remain
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13President Nixon met for more than two hours tonight with 15 Republican Senators and apparently persuaded most of them that he intended to tell everything that he knew about Watergate and allied scandals.

title: O. J. Day Means Rushing at a Hectic Pace
description: In the second quarter of the Buffalo Bills' game with the Baltimore Colts a few weeks ago, O. J. Simpson suddenly went to the end of the bench and sat there alone.

title: MRS. STEWART HOOKER
description: STONE HARBOR, N. J., Nov. 13Mrs. Mary P. Hooker, wife of Stewart Hooker, publisher of The Daily Racing Form, died here today of cancer at her home. Her age was 59.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES WATERGATE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The House Judiciary Committee moved today to link the special Watergate prosecution to the committee's inquiry into whether to impeach President Nixon.

title: Guided Missle Scores By HalfLength at Big A
description: Guided Missle took the lead shortly after the start yesterday at Aqueduct and led the remainder of the way to capture the $15,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares.

title: Two Ford Plants Struck
description: LORAIN, Ohio, Nov. 13 (UPI)Some 7,550 members of the United Auto Workers Local 425 struck two Ford Motor Company plants today when agreement on local issues was not reached.

title: SENATE APPROVES ALTERED U.S.I.A. BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)The Senate accepted today President Nixon's objection to providing internal Government documents on demand from Congress and passed a new. United States Information Agency bill without that controversial provision.

title: 2 STATES MOVE TO CONSERYE FUEL
description: States and municipalities around the country continued yesterday to take actions to deal with the oil shortage.

title: Suspended Student Sues
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 13 (AP)Steven Kornblatt of New York, an Emory University student, has filed suit in Federal court following his suspension from the university for the fall quarter on charges of cheating. The suit says the suspension effectively bars him from entering the field of medicine. It asks $1,039,750 in damages.

title: INQUIRY EXPECTED OVER KENT STATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Justice Department is likely to convene a Federal grand jury within the next 30 days to hear evidence on the slaying of four students at Kent State University by Ohio National Guardsman in 1970, Assistant Attorney General J. Stanley Pottinger disclosed today.

title: Jackson Unanimously Most Valuable
description: Reggie Jackson of the Oakland A's was voted unanimously yesterday the American League's most valuable player of 1973 by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Britain, Reporting Worst Trade Deficit, Takes Series of Stern Economic Actions
description: LONDON, Nov. 13Britain's deteriorating economic position forced the Government today to adopt a series of drastic measures to shore up her balance of payments, curtail the money supply and cope with labor disputes that threaten to cause widespread power blackouts.

title: Ran Is Found Guilty Here In Fatal Beating of Daughter
description: A Washington Heights father was convicted yesterday of firstdegree manslaughter in the rubberhose beating death of: his 16yearold daughter. He contended he had a legal right to impose discipline.

title: Red Smith
description: There was an encouraging piece in the paper the other day about the inroads sport has been making into the policy of apartheid in South Africa, where Arthur Ashe is playing for the national tennis championship and Bob Foster is to defend the lightheavyweight championship of the world against South Africa's white hope, Pierre Fourie. Now, if sport could do as much in Augusta, Ga., it would be a comparable victory over bigotry. Is it too early, now in November, to hope that a black American will be invited to play in the Masters' 40th anniversary tournament next April? Or too late?

title: MOSCOW ASSAILS CHINA ON MIDEAST
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 13The So viet press added a new charge today to its accusations agains China: that Peking has been trying to perpetuate Middle East tensions to provoke a confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Gigi is Here Again as Stage Musical
description: GIGI; a musical based on the novel by Colette. Book and lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner; music by Frederick Loewe; setting by Oliver Smith; costumes by Oliver Messel; lighting by Thomas Skelton; orchestrations by Irwin Kostal; dance arrangements by Trude Rittmann; musical direction by Ross Reimueller; dances and musical numbers staged by Onna White; directed by Joseph Hardy; musical associate, Harper MacKay; associate director, Martin Allen; production stage manager, M. William Lettich. Presented by SaintSubber and Edwin Lester. At the Uris Theater, West 51st Street.

title: LILA LEE, 68, DIES; SILENT FILM STAR
description: Lila Lee, a star of silent movies and nineteenthirties action films whose romantic adventures on and off the screen were widely followed in fan magazines, died of a stroke and complications yesterday at Will Rogers Memorial Hospital in Saranac Lake, N. Y. She was 68 years old.

title: New Korea Student Protest
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 13 (AP)About 4,000 students of Ewha Woman's University today staged the second rally in two days to protest what they called dictatorship under President Park Chung Hee.

title: St. Louis Rated No.
description: St. Louis University was named No. 1 in the Intercollegiate Soccer Football Association of America ratings yesterday.

title: Northwest Airlines Is Declared Guilty Of Sex Bias Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 13 (UPI)United States District Judge Aubrey E. Robinson found Northwest Airlines guilty today of practicing sex discrimination in its flight crews. The ruling could mean retroactive pay increases of tip to $250 a month for 1,100 stewardesses.

title: 49ers' Fall More Shocking Than Giants'
description: As the Giants and 49ers have sadly found out this season, the margin that separates a winning team from a losing one in the National Football League can be thin and almost transparent. Alex Webster, the Giants' coach, and Dick. Nolan, his old teammate coaching the San Francisco 49ers, have no ready replies when asked what went wrong with their clubs this season.

title: New Books
description: New Books

title: Advertising: Comparison Issue
description: Although traditionally decried by the advertising industry, comparative ftdver fising (the actual naming of competitors) is now very much a fact of life.

title: Mrs. Meir Says She Believes Israel and Egypt Can Resolve Truce Differences
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 13Premier Golda Meir told the Israeli Parliament today that she believed Israel and Egypt would be able to overcome their differences and carry out the American sponsored ceasefire agreement along the Suez Canal.

title: QUEENS AIDE KILLED AS TRUCK HITS CAR
description: Jeffrey P. Cohen, who was identified by the police as an assistant to Donald R. Manes, Borough President of Queens, was killed last night when his car was hit by a tow truck.

title: City Ballet Strikes
description: A strike by the dancers of the New York City Ballet caused cancellation of the opening of the fall season last night. It marred the celebration marking the company's 25th year, which was to have taken place after the performance. Page 39.

title: A Retarded TeenAge Boy Killed in Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 13A 15yearold retarded boy died in a hospital here today 15 hours after his abduction from a reform school. He had been shot in the head in a park in northern Belfast with a placard pinned to his clothing saying: tout, the word used by the Irish Republican Army for informer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Impeachment proceedings are not a benign exercise but have the potential of seriously polarizing the body politic and compromising the effectiveness of the executive branch of government. Wisely, the Constitution requires a twothirds vote of the Senate for conviction, and, in view of the exhaustive Watergate committee hearings, the Senate is substantially wellinformed as to the nature of the charges that would probably be brought against the President.

title: Nets Win In Unruly Contest
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov 13  The New York Nets played sound basketball it walloping the Memphis Tams, 10892, tonight at the MidSouth Coliseum. But the game was marred by the ejection of a player, five technical fouls, questionable officiating and nearriot conditions.

title: Skilled Trades Reject Pact at Ford
description: DETROIT, Nov. 13In an unusually bitter struggle over a contract ratification, the United Automobile Workers union announced today that its skilled tradesmen had refused to ratify a tentative agreement negotiated with the Ford Motor Company.

title: People in Sports: Wekome, Bob Foster
description: This is worse than New York, proclaimed a weary Bob Foster in Johannesbarg yesterday when a crowd of about 1,000 swarmed around the world lightheavyweight champion at the airport. Foster will make history Dec. 1 when he becomes the first professional black boxer to meet a white in South Africa.

title: Nixon Has Council's Support
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI)The sevenmember City Council of this Orange County beach community voted unanimously yesterday to support President Nixon during the domestic crisis caused by Watergaterelated matters.

title: The New Leader at 50
description: By the standards of Life, Look and dozens of other longgone magazines of mass circulation, The New Leader has always ranked as a pygmy. But this estimable biweekly of news and opinion, celebrating its fiftieth birthday this week, never depended on numbers for either its usefulness or its influence. It rarely pays for an article; yet over the years its columns have carried thoughtful contributions by the famous and the obscure many of which have helped to reshape history. In the words of Myron Kolatch, its executive editor, one would have to be a schizophrenic to agree with everything in The New Leader. It is precisely that quality of openness to reasoned divergence that makes it at once lively and respected as it moves into its second halfcentury.

title: About New York
description: The dancers struck more in sorrow than in anger yesterday, and the New York City Ballet did not open last night. The dancers do not look like militant union members, and when they talk about their strike, they do not sound like them. They are dancers, and they say that dancing is all they ever want to do.

title: Hockey Player Hurt
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 13 (AP) Bret Leavins, 20yearold rookie wing, for the Richmond Robins of the American Hockey League, is out Tor the season because of injuries suffered today in an auto accident. He sustained a broken left leg, a double fracture of the left ankle, and cuts and bruises below the waist.

title: Ukrainian Writer Pardoned After Renunciation
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 13A prominent Ukrainian writer and critic has been pardoned from a sentence of 10 years in prison and exile after renouncing his former attacks on Russian influence in the Ukrainian republic, the Soviet press agencyTass reported today.

title: UTURES PRICES HAVE MIXED DAY
description: A wide variety of factors influenced commodity futures prices yesterday, pointing up the importance of viewing each commodity on an individual basis.

title: JUDGE SUSTAINS F.T.C. ON OCTANE RATING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)A Federal judge today upheld the authority of the Federal Trade Commission to require the posting of octane ratings of gasoline on servicestation pumps.

title: Liftoff of Skylab 3 Set for Friday Despite Trouble
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 13After a reexamination of the troubleplagued rocket, space agency officials decided today to continue with a countdown aimed at launching the Skylab 3 astronauts Friday morning.

title: Jersey Extends Tenure Of Investigative Unit
description: TRENTON, Nov. 13 (AP)Governor Cahill signed legislation today extending the life of the controversial State Commission of Investigation for five years.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mrs. AndersonIvantzova, Dancer and Teacher, Dies
description: Elisabeth AndersonIvantzova who had taught here since 1937 the dance methods she had leaned in the Imperial School of Ballet at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, died Saturday at her studio and apartment, 139 West 56th Street. She was the widow of Ivan Ivantzoff, an operatic tenor and coach and was believed to be in her late 70's or early 80's.

title: FELONY SENTENCES BY JUDGES SCORED
description: The chairman of the State Select Committee on Crime said yesterday that New York judges had illegally freed defendants in at least 247 felony narcotic cases in the last few years.

title: 9 STATES WARNED OVER INTEGRATION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Department of Health, Education and Welfare rejected today as far short of being acceptable the courtordered racial desegregation plans for public college and university systems submitted by nine states.

title: City Bids for Franchise in New Pro Football League
description: New York City moved yesterday to bring back a football team to Yankee Stadium when it invited Robert Schmertz, a collector of sports franchises, to begin negotiations.

title: The Convention Center
description: New York needs the proposed new convention center. The competitive disadvantage of this city's present inadequate tradeshow facilities is evident, as is the pressing need for employment opportunities particularly for minoritiesthat the center would create. The project is in a sense a major defensive operation, to enable the city to keep and enlarge its tradeshow business as critical support for its allimportant tourist, hotel and service industries.

title: Joint Solution on Energy Is Urged by International Businessmen
description: International business experts issued an appeal here yesterday for major energy  consuming nations to seek joint solutions and avoid destructive competition for available supplies of oil and gas.

title: Stock Prices Drop; Dow Off at 891.03
description: Stock prices continued to fail yesterday as investors sought to assess the impact, of the energy crisis, including the future availability and price of gasoline that is so critical to many industries.

title: Center Faces Unending Deficit
description: There are no laborsaving devices if the arts, a weary Norman Singer, executive director of the City Center of Music and Drama, said yesterday. A quartet still requires four musicians, a pas de deux takes two dancers.

title: EXPANSION IS SET AT WEYERHAEUSER
description: A major forest products company and a major farm equipment maker announced separate plans yesterday for spending a total of some $2.3billion over the next three years on expansion projects.

title: TYPHOON BILLS 51 IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 14The Goveminent said today that a violent storm struck six coastal provinces over the weekend, killing at least 51 persons, forcing evacuation of at least 145,000 and flooding several cities with waters as deep as 10 feet.

title: Dr. Henry Colmore Dies at 69; Found Bon Vivant Soup Toxins
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 13Dr. Henry P. Colmore, the physician Who two years ago identified the botulism toxin in cans of Bon Vivant soup that led to a Federal investigation into the company, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Bedford Hills.

title: Whooping Cranes in Texas
description: AUSTWELL, Tex., Nov. 13 (UPI)  Wildlife specialists at the Aransas National Wildlife Refuge said today that 43 whooping cranes had arrived from Canada. More are expected. The flock last year totaled 51.

title: 2 TELL OF SCHEME TO HIDE NIXON GIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Two employes of the American Ship Building Company told Senate investigators today that their chief, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, had devised illegal schemes to contribute thousands of dollars in corporate funds to President Nixon's reelection campaign and then had induced them to lie about it to agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Strict Controls Ordered On Three Barbiturates
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) The Drug Enforcement Administration ordered strict Federal controls today on three commonly used barbiturates because of findings that they have high potential for addiction.

title: 2 Kidnapped and Raped in Bronx; 4Y ouths and 7 Girls Are Charged
description: Four youths and seven young girls were arrested last night in the Bronx and charged with the kidnapping and sexual assault of two teenaged girls.

title: 3 Boys Are Charged in Bronx Slaying
description: A 14yearold Riverdale boy and two 16yearold bakery deliverymen from the South Bronx who all hung out in the same vestpocket parkhaveI been charged with the robbery and murder of Joseph Lifshitz, a 78yearold restaurateur, last July 16.

title: On Eve of Its 25th Year, the City Ballet Goes on Strike
description: About to, perform for the gala opening of its 25th year, the New York City Ballet was shut down last night by the first strike of its dancers in the company's history. This is the fourth major strike against a cultural institution in the city this fall.

title: A. U.S. Judge Orders Pentagon To Review Discharges on Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13A Federal court judge ordered the Department of Defense today to notify about 3,400 Vietnamera veterans who received lessthanhonorable discharges that they were entitled to a review and possible upgrading to an honorable discharge. The veterans were discharged for drug abuse before a change in defense policy in 1971.

title: Role for Women in Jewish Ritual Backed by Conservative Group
description: The United Synagogue of America, a lay organization representing Conservative Judaism, voted 2 to 1 yesterday in favor of allowing women to participate directly in ritual.

title: City's Congressmen Ask V.A. to Act Quickly to Aid Vietnam Veterans Here
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13New York City's Congressional delegation today resolved to seek in emergency meeting with the Veterans Administration to ease the plight of the city's 350,000 Vietnam veterans.

title: The Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTONThe appointment of Mr. Jaworski as the new special prosecutor is not responsive to the valid, sustained public demand for an independent prosecution of Watergate and other cases that had been under investigation by Archibald Cox. The appointment of Mr. Jaworski within the executive branch to investigate the executive brancha person who could be dismissed by the President as abruptly as was Mr. Coxwill, with good cause, fuel public concern that justice is not being pursued thoroughly and without constraint.

title: Mara Still Wants Giants To Move to New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Nov. 13Wellington Mara, the president of the New York Giants, said today he was still enthusiastic about moving his football team to northern New Jersey despite new demands, that the contract involving the Giants' commitment to move there be renego: tiated.

title: ISRAEL STRESSES CONTROL OF ROAD
description: ON THE CAIROSUEZ ROAD, Egypt, Nov. 13Israeli forces today demonstrated that they retained control of the road leading to the city of Suez despite the two United Nations checkpoints that were set up yesterday.

title: Bugner, Finnegan Win 10Rounders in London
description: LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP)The European heavyweight champion, Joe Bugner, scored a 10round decision over Mac Foster of Fresno, Calif., in a dull fight at Wembley Empire Pool tonight.

title: Life in W.H.A.: It's Better Than In Bush Leagues
description: Although she can sleep later if she wants to, Stacy Morrison will get up at 9 o'clock this morning so me and Kevin can have breakfast together.

title: Survey Finds Rent Gap Widens Under Vacancy Decontrol Here
description: The city's top housing official said yesterday that preliminary results of a city survey indicated that rent levels in apartments removed from rent control under the vacancy decontrol law were, on a citywide average, 50 per cent higher this year than apartments still under control.

title: Meskill Is Told Commuters Face a 70% Fare Increase
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 13 (UPI) A commuter group warned Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today that Fairfield. County commuters faced a 70 per cent increase in fares on the Penn Central's New Haven line.

title: Jackson Unanimously Most Valuable
description: Reggie Jackson of the Oakland A's was voted unanimously yesterday the American League's most valuable player of 1973 by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Derringer's First
description: Here it is 1973, and Rick Derringer is reworking the Tell Laura I Love Her story, with no apparent sense of parody or satire, on his debilt album, All American Boy (Blue Sky Records KZ 32481, $5.98). Derringer's Teenage Queen has no musical or lyrical similarity to Tell Laura, a hit 13 years agoit's just that both songs deal with an automobile crash that leaves the singer the sole survivor, the only one left to pray. It wasn't much of a wreck/But enough to take my teenage queen away, wails Derringer.

title: BRITAIN AND ICELAND END FISHING FEUD
description: LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP) Britain and Iceland formally ended their 15month feud over fishing rights today with a twoyear pact cutting back the annual catch British trawlermen can take out of Iceland's claimed waters.

title: 35c Fare Is Doomed, Governor Contends
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he did not see any way to save the 35cent transit fare here and that anyone who said it could be saved was kidding the public.

title: College Teachers Consider Strike at 8 State Campuses
description: TRENTON, Nov. 13  Crucial talks are under way between the State Department of Higher Education and the New Jersey State Federation of Teachers that will determine whether the state college teachers' bargaining unit will decide Saturday whether to strike.College (formerly Newark State), William Paterson College and Trenton State and Ramapo and Stockton State colleges, the newest additions the state highereducation system.

title: Herb Olson Is Dead at 68; WaterColorist and Author
description: WESTPORT. Conn, Nov. 13 Herbert V. Olson, a watercolorist, died yesterday in Fairfield, His age was 68. He lived at 6 Florian Court here.

title: Soviet Ouster Assailed
description: BUDAPEST, Nov. 13 (UPI) The Soviet Union's disqualification from the World Cup soccer championships for its refusal to play in Chile was branded as unjustified by Hungarian newspapers today. One newspaper, Nepszabadsag, said the International Football Federation's decision was all the more questionable as it had allowed Portugal and Bulgaria to play Northern Ireland on neutral ground because of the political events in Belfast.

title: People in Sports: Welcome, Bob Foser
description: This is worse than New York, proclaimed a weary Bob Foster in Johannesburg yesterday when a crowd of about 1,000 swarmed around the world lightheavyweight champion at the airport. Foster will make history Dec. 1 when he becomes the first professional black boxer to meet a white in South Africa.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Thruway to Auction Jewelry
description: ALBANY, Nov. 13 (UPI)More than 200 rings and bracelets, including 48 wedding bands, that have been found on property of the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in the last decade will go to the highest bidder tomorrow. The Thruway Authority said bids for the entire collection, of gold and silver jewelryfound at restaurants, gas stations and rest areas along the 559mile road must be submitted by 3 P.M.

title: CORPORATE BONDS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Corporate Corporate bond prices fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as the market turned its attention to several new offerings.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Fans to Be Allowed To See Secretariat
description: PARIS, Ky., Nov., 13 (AP) A limited number of visitors will get a chance to see Secretariat at Claiborne Farm beginning on Monday, the president of Claiborne, Seth W. Hancock, announced today.

title: Music to Plug In or Punch Out or Just, Maybe, to See
description: The specter of a computer controlled society, which once seemed a ridiculous nightmare of the sciencefictionist's, overactive brain, no longer appears outlandish. Whole historical libraries may now be erased or rendered inoperative at one push of the erase button. As Orwell foresaw, the man behind the console may soon control the writing and rewriting of history, for instance, and a slave society is a reasonable possibility if the computer is made to lie to us.

title: CAMPAIGN SOUGHT FOR FREE TUITION
description: City University Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee called yesterday for a nationwide campaign, patterned after the civil rights movement of the early nineteensixties, to obtain tuitionfree undergraduate education at all public colleges and universities across the country.

title: TV : Blue Knight Turns Out Smartly for New Beat
description: In a week topheavy with specials, the most special began last night. It is The Blue Knight, an adaptation of Joseph Wambaugh's bestselling novel.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: No passenger ship arrivals are scheduled for today or tomorrow

title: NATIONAL MARKET IS GIVEN SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)The chairman of the two major stock exchanges differed today on aspects of a proposed national market system, although both basically supported legislation for such a system.

title: Mayoral Race Reversed
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13 (PI)An apparent technician's error has reversed the ofinish )f the race for Mayor of this city in last Tuesday's general election. At the conclusion of Monday's recanvass, the incumDent Mayor, Fostor Pettit, totaled 20,368 against, Municipal Judge James Amato's 20,314. The switch erased Judge Amato's apparent 112vote victory, and puts Mr. Pettit in the lead by 54 votes.

title: Agnew's MotherinLaw Dies
description: BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 13 (UPI)Mrs. Ruth Elinor Judefind, motherinlaw of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, died today after suffering a heart attack and, stroke yesterday. She was 76 years old.

title: RELIEF COST RISES AS ROLLS DECLINE
description: The cost of welfare and Medicaid programs throughout the state is expected by officials to rise 6 per cent id the current fiscal year, a far slower rate than the average annual rise of 26 per cent from the fiscal years 1964 to 1971 and the 10.3 per cent increase for the year ended last March 31.

title: An Arrested Priest Asserts Bishops Accept Repression
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) An activist priest who said that America's Roman Catholic bishops were meeting here in an atmosphere of repression Was arrested along with four other persons this afternoon for refusing to leave a downtown Washington hotel.

title: Pros Term College Crop A Lean One
description: Pro football scouts, who drooled over last season's rich crop of college seniors, are calling this year's harvest the leanest in a long time.

title: Connors, Nastase Score Indoor Tennis Victories
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Nov. 13 (AP)Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., became the first player to reach the quarterfinals of the $48,000 Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today, by trouncing Gerald Battrick of Britian, 61, 63. Ilie Nastase also won, as did Tom Okker.

title: Start Rationing Now, Oilmen Advise
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 13 The need for strong measures to combat the nation's energy crisis was a theme voiced by seemingly all of the 2,000 oil industry executives attending the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute here since they arrived Sunday. Today the meeting closed with the strongest statement yet.

title: 2 GABLE SYSTEMS ASK RISE IN RATES
description: New York City's two franchised cable television systems, SterlingManhattan Cable and Teleprompter Manhattan Cable, have applied to the city for permission to raise their basic service rate to subscribers from $5 to $8 a month and the rental fee for the optional converter from $1 to $2 a month.

title: Trajectory of Mariner 10 To Be Altered Slightly
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI)  The trajectory of the Mariner 10 planetary probe, launched 12 days ago toward Venus and Mercury, will be altered slightly in a planned midcourse correction next Monday.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RUTHERFORD, Nov. 13To the spectators and opposition of Fairleigh Dickinson University's club hockey team, that 5foot10inch center on the second line may look, like just another stickman on Coach Dick Trimble's squad. But those familiar with the skating Knights are aware that John Pierce is a Franciscan priest.

title: STEPHEN PHILBIN, LAWYER, 86, DIES
description: Stephen H. Philbin, a senior partner in the law firm of Fish Neave, died yesterday at his summer home in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 86 years old and lived at 141 East 72d Street.

title: Records
description: Gregorian chant is just one form of medieval ecclesiastical music. It owes its first debts to earlier Christian Music, and back from there to a variety of ancient and Oriental models. Yet it is still rightly regarded as the earliest surviving ancestor of presentday art music, since we don't really know how to perform what precedes it and very little of the other collections has come down to us.

title: TruckCar Crash Kills Two
description: GARDEN CITY, Utah, Nov. 13 (UPI)  An outofcontrol tractortrailer smashed into a parked car and carried the vehicle over a steep embankment yesterday, killing the truck driver and a passenger in the auto. The victims were Michael G. Besserman, 39 years old, of Madisonville, Ky., driver of the truck, and Bernice Hymas, about 20, of Rexhurg, Idaho.

title: Justice Rinaldi Is Indicted On Lying and Obstruction
description: Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has been indicted on a charge of lying under oath and seeking to obstruct a state investigation into judicial corruption, the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, announced yesterday.

title: 7 NATIONS END BAR TO GOLD TRADING IN FREE MARKET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The United States and six European countries have terminated the fiveyearold agreement that barred them from transactions in gold in the free market.

title: Walkout Casts a Pall Over Gala
description: We always have Hamlet without the Prince of Denmark, said W. McNeil Lowry, a vice president of the Ford Foundation, after the guest of honor to whom he had just proposed a toast, seemed to vanish from a crowded party at the State Theater last night.

title: Critics Ridicule India's Austerity Plan
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 13 ??rime Minister Indira Gandhi rode to work the other morning in a horse and buggy. An opposition politician promptly went to parliament on a bullock cart. A High Court judge now climbs on a bicycle and pedals to his office.

title: Two Degrees in Five Years
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 13 (AP)  Holy Cross College and Worcester Polytechnic Institute said today that they had established a cooperative program in which a student may earn two bachelor degrees in five years at the two schools. The announcement said students in the program may earn a bachelor of arts degree in any major at Holy Cross and a bachelor of science degree in any major at Worcester Tech.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Executive Fined in TaxBribe Scheme

title: Move to Extradite Vesco Is Snagged By Question of U. S.Bahamas Treaty
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 13 A hearing on the extradition of Robert L. Vesco, the international financier facing Federal charges of fraud and conspiracy in New York, was snagged almost immediately today on the question, raised by Mr. Vesco's counsel, of whether there was an extradition treaty between the United States and the Bahamas.

title: TransitFare Hopes Dimmed by Upstate Opposition
description: Even before the Governor made public his latest transit dictum yesterday that the 35cent fare was dead in New York City, he was reliably reported to have cautioned Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame in a private chat not to get locked into a hard save the fare posture.

title: Lloyd's Electronics Issued Restrainer on Its Chairman
