description: The first items in Mayor Lindsay's final legislative package were submitted to Albany yesterday, with Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame's transition team informed but noncommittal.

title: The Pop Life
description: Good news for Stevie Wonder fans. Several people who saw him as emcee and performer at the homecoming benefit of Shaw University in North Carolina last weekend report that the blind young black musician seems completely recovered from his automobile accident this year.

title: Court Picks Trustee In I.T.T. Divestment Of Its Grinnell Unit
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 15  A trustee was named today to supervise the divestiture by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation of the fire protection division of the Grinnell Corporation.

title: 52 Teamster Volunteers to Train Truckers in Israel.
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, Nov. 15Fifty New Jersey truck drivers and two master mechanics will be selected tomorrow night from among 120 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who volunteered to spend 90 days in Israel training Israelis in the use of new trucks being shipped there from the United States.

title: U.S. Says Unidentified Ship Fired on Vessel in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The State Department said tonight that art unidentified warship had fired a shot across the bow of the United States freighter La Salle as she sailed from the Red Sea through the Bah el Mandeb strait on Oct. 14.

title: U.N. Told of Israeli Causeway on Canal
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15Egypt has complained that the Israelis were filling in part of the Suez Canal and inspection by a United Nations patrol confirmed that what appears to be a causeway is being constructed, according to a United Nations report issued today.

title: A VESCO LAWYER REBUTS WITNESS
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 15The chief counsel for Robert L. Vesco read to a Bahamian magistrate today an affidavit from a key United States Government witness that the lawyer said contradicted what the witness had said in an affidavit given to American authorities.

title: Soviet Concedes Accords With U.S. Averted a Confrontation
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 15  The Soviet Union asserted today for the first time in public that the general improvement in SovietAmerican relations had averted a dangerous confrontation between the two big powers in the Middle East and had made possible a speedy ceasefire.

title: A.B.C. Is Pressing Cavett to Accept A Cut to One Show Every 2 Weeks
description: The American Broadcasting Company has given Dick Cavett what amounts to a takeitorleaveit offer for a drastically reduced schedule of broadcasts after the first of the year. If Mr. Cavett rejects it, he is expected to lose his lateevening program, the Dick Cavett Show, when his present contract expires in late Deember.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1973

title: Corrigan Is Victor In CrossCountry
description: Myles Corrigan won the individual title and led La Salle to team honors yesterday in the Manhattan Catholic High Schools crosscountry championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: 35C FARE LINKED TO CLEAN AIR ACT
description: Former United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau has urged the Federal Government to order the state to freeze the city's 35cent mass transit fare. Such a move is neccesary, he says, to insure compliance with Federal airquality standards here.

title: Historic Handclasp ...
description: The road to peace in the Middle East is still long and tortuous, but Egypt and Israel have taken a momentous first step in highlevel discussions this week that broke a deadlock over the ceasefire and cleared the way for the prisoner exchange that began yesterday.

title: Jousting Politics in Two Stage Arenas
description: Faced with the current state of the nation, one might question the need for political theater. How can you top Watergate itself as theater of the absurd? But it could be argued that today we are more desperately in need of political theaterto increase public awareness and concern and to bring a little reality back into our lives.

title: Those Grain Silos Are for Living In, Too
description: We always liked the idea of living in a tower, said Anna Audette, a printmaker. But discovering Unadilla was what really made it happen.

title: McCord Bond Unopposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) The Government said today that it did not object if a Watergate conspirator, James W. McCord Jr., remained free on bond while he is appealing his conviction. McCord was given 15 days to wind up his affairs last wek after Federal District Judge John J. Sirica sentenced him to 1 to 5 years in prison for conspiracy, burglary and wiretapping.

title: Australian Leader Exchanges Insults With Legislators
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 15 Parliament was in disarray today in the aftermath of a cocktail party given by Prime Minister Gough Whitlam for the visiting Prime Minister New Zealand, Norman Kirk.

title: LONDON STOCKPRICES FALL TO 2YEAR LOW
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) Prices on the London stock exchange fell today to their lowest level in more than two years amid rumors of imminent tax increases by the Government.

title: The Super Cincago and a New Henze
description: Sir Georg Solti and his Chicago Symphony Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night with something of a blockbuster. The Chicago Symphony is hailed these days as a super orchestra, so it was only right that it should give the New York premiere of Hans Werner Henze's supercolossal orchestral piece with the longtitle of Heliogabalus Imperator, Allegoria per musica.

title: CREDIT TIGHTENS IN BARK SYSTEM
description: Credit conditions in the nation's banking system tightened during the week ended Wednesday, data released by the Federal Reserve yesterday showed.

title: COPPER FUTURES PASS $1 A POUND
description: For the first time copper futures for nearby delivery slightly exceeded $1 a pound yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The exchange has traded futures in the basic metal since 1933.

title: Tough Bargaining Seen in Laos Before 2 Sides Form Coalition
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 15 Officials and diplomats here say that the Laotian Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma and the proCommunist Pathet Lao still have weeks of tough bargaining ahead before they will be ready to install the coalition envisioned in their accord of Sept. 14.

title: CHILE HELPING U.S. FIGHT DRUG RINGS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 15 An extensive crackdown on the traffic in cocaine destined for the United States is under way here with close cooperation between the Chilean authorities and American narcotics officials.

title: The Shockley Case
description: Dr. William Shockley is a noted physicist of dubious qualification for his view on genetics, which is that heredity rather than environment is the primary cause of the disadvantaged position of blacks in society. His particular case not only raises the usual First Amendment questions about offensive ideas, but a corollary: To what extent is a free society obligated to create opportunities for the expression of such ideas?

title: REALTY MEN HAIL NIXON AS HE VOWS TO REMAIN ON JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15An audience of more than 4,000 real estate executives cheered and applauded today as President Nixon told them he was not going to walk away from his job until he completed it

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MILITARY RAISING DOMESTIC OIL USE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The Defense Department said today that the Arab oil embargo would force the military to take 300,000 additional barrels a day out of the domestic supply of petroleum products in order to maintain the readiness of the armed forces.

title: A Lamb and Vegetable Casserole
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Shirley Chisholm Facing U.S. Inquiry Into 3 Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Representative Shirley Chisholm, the Brooklyn Democrat who in 1972 became the first woman to seek the Presidential nomination of a major party, is me target or Federal investigations into three areas of alleged wrongdoing, law enforcement sources said today.

title: JACKSON OPPOSES AID TO SOVIET ECONOMY
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson believes that if the Soviet Union's economy is badly in need of help, that help should come through a reordering of Soviet priorities away from the military into the civilian sector.

title: NEW ZONING FIGHT IN STATE FORECAST
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15As soon as the New Jersey Supreme Court settles the emotionladen issue of exclusionary zoning, Prof. Jerome G Rose of Rutgers University said today, there will be a new round of legal attacks on zoning ordinances.

title: CITY REMOVES 60 AT NURSING HOME
description: All 60 patients of the Liberty Nursing Home in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn were transferred to a Conye Island nursing home Wednesday night after city and state officials said the owner's funds had been cut off by incometax liens, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Seoul Students Clash With Police as AntiPark Protests Mount
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 15About 2,000 students at Korea University demonstrated for about four hours today in the most sustained and violent outburst in the spreading defiance of the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: The Voter Lobby
description: WASHINGTONEach day's news bombards us with fresh campaigngift horror stories: $50,000 of Howard Hughes' cash reportedly handed to Hubert Humphrey in the back of a limousine, $100,000 of Mr. Hughes' cash stashed away in Bebe Rebozo's bank box for three years, major corporations succumbing to the Government shakedowns, doctoring their books and making patently illegal contributions. What more does Congress need to hear before putting an end to government for sale? It could do that by passing a public financing program in time for the, 1974 Congressional elections.

title: PAYMENT BALANCE SHARPLY IMPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Two measures of the United States's balance of international payments showed further improvement in the third quarter, with both in surplus, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Schools' Puerto Rican Week Varies
description: This week is Puerto Rican Discovery Week in city schools and despite Board of Education urgings that all students be given the opportunity to learn about the island's culture and history, there has been more activity in heavily Puerto Rican areas than others.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 15The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week totaled an estimated $1.2billion, up 19 per cent from a yearearlier $993million. Total retailstore sales climbed 12 per cent to $10.1billion from $9billion a year earlier.

title: INQUIRY WIDENED IN B.A. CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Alleged corruption in the Small Business Administration was described today as much more widespread than heretofore reported, according to sources close to a Federal investigation.

title: Pop Music: Twin Talents Of Ashford and Simpson
description: Nick Ashford and Valerie Simpson arrived Sunday at Alice Tully Hall with lockedin reputations as songwriters. The couple have, for the last nine years, mainly out of Detroit, been responsible for some of the major soul hit songs. Lately, however, they have taken to the stage as singers. Naturally, they perform their own material.

title: The Anatomy of an Art Sale: Profiting on Worst Painter
description: A week ago at Sotheby's Belgravia, the chic auction house in London, 35 paintings by the Victorian academician Sir Lawrence AlmaTadema were sold for $570,000.

title: Nixon Hostility to TV Press Is Assailed
description: Representative Torbert H. Macdonald, not renowned as a defender of the television networks in his role as chairman of the House Subcommittee on Communications and Power, denounced the Nixon Administration's treatment of the electronic press and said that the Congress was the insulation between a hostile executive branch and the news media.

title: REALTY MEN HAIL NIXON AS HE VOWS TO REMAIN ON JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15An audience of more than 4,000 real estate executives cheered and applauded today as President Nixon told them he was not going to walk away from his job until he completed it.

title: Bridge:
description: Keen analytical vision and ability to calculate percentages is usually an advantage at, the bridge table. But sometimes it results in a considerable expenditure of mental effort, a need for aspirin, and little profit.

title: About New York The GoingsOn at City Hall
description: There is a sweaty pulse about government in New York City, and the things about politics that agitate citizens are not necessarily the things that agitate politicians. This is because politicians and citizens have a different set of priorities, and while politicians speak one way to citizens they speak another way among themselves, and then there is confusion.

title: Crew of Skylab 3 Due to Go Up Today On 84Day Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 15  Final preparations were under way tonight for the launching tomorrow morning of the Skylab 3 astronauts for a record 84day mission aboard the nation's orbiting laboratory.

title: BlackedOut Giants Choice Over Cards
description: Television viewers have chance to see a game on Sunday in which neither New York team is involved. Channel 2 will telecast the Rams and 49ers game from Los Angeles at 4 P.M. Because the Yale Bowl was not sold out at noon yesterday, the Giants' game against St.

title: KENNETH L. MILBURN
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 15. (AP)  Kenneth L. Milburn, former general manager of The Akron Beacon Journal and a Knight Newspapers officer, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Knicks Keep Braves From Winning Here
description: The mystique of the Knicks continues. Although they were missing such key contributors as Willis Reed, Jerry Lucas and Earl Monroe last night, they still retained enough of the memorized skills of their recent past to turn back the Buffalo Braves, 9786, before an appreciative crowd of 17,462 at Madison Square Garden.

title: UTILITY LEADERS CALM ON ENERGY
description: Only one top executive on a panel of 14 electric utility lead ers yesterday seemed genuinely worried that there was a real crisis in the energy business. The one exception was the chairman of a major East Coast utility, who warned that some East Coast utilities get more than onehalf of their basic fuel from the Middle East.

title: Junior League Aids City's Fight on Y.D.
description: The Junior League of New York and the city's Bureau of Venereal Disease Control yesterday announced a joint campaign to get women to demand regular testing for gonorrheanow the most prevalent disease that women here have to worry about and rapidly moving into the suburbs and Park Avenue, a bureau spokesman said.

title: Navy Tests Destroyer Fueled by Oil Derived From Coal
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15A World War II Navy destroyer, the U.S.S. Johnston, steamed out of port here today to become the first ship in history to use coalderived oil to power its engines.

title: Drug Case: Call for Action
description: What made George Burman, a relatively unknown reserve center, risk his career as a pro football player by revealing that some of his Washington Redskin teammates took amphetamines to charge themselves up before games? Was he right or wrong for popping off about pillpopping?

title: Stage: HardEdged Play by Laurents
description: Some of the boys in the band are leaping out of their closets like damp firecrackers or 19thcentury jacksinthe boxes. No, I don't really mean to start my review on Arthur Laurents's well crafted and bitchily witty play, The Enclave, which opened last nght at Theater Four, like that. But, damn it, yes I do.

title: U.N. Troops Supervising Flow of Supplies to Suez
description: ON THE CAIROSUEZ HIGHWAY, Nov. 15The United Nations Emergency Force today began to exercise its right to supervise the daily flow of food, water and medical supplies to Suez city. But in every other respect Israeli forces remained in control of the access roads.

title: Governor Names His Indicted Doctor to Unpaid Post
description: Governor Rockefeller's personal physician, who was indicted last April on charges of Federal incometax evasion, was named by the Governor yesterday as one of 10 unpaid members of a new state advisory commission on alcoholism.

title: DELURY GIVES TERMS FOR NEW CONTRACT
description: John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said yesterday that members of his union wanted pay increases that would compensate for a 20 per cent increase in productivity and 13 per cent increase in the cost of living during their 30month contract that expired last June 30.

title: UNIONS TO MEET IN BALLET STRIKE
description: Officials of unions affected by the dancers' strike at the New York City Ballet will meet Monday to discuss the labor dispute, but yesterday the main parties involved  the orchestra and management had no future talks scheduled.

title: Crangle Upbraids Rockefeller For His Silence on Watergate
description: Attempting to link Governor Rockefeller with the Watergate scandal, the Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, charged yesterday that the Governor was abdicating his responsibility by his silince on the issue.

title: Slaying of One of the Last Black Liberation Army Leaders Still at Large Ended a 7Month Manhunt
description: The slaying of Twymon Meyers, which Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said yesterday broke the back of the Black Liberation Army, came after seven months of dogged pursuit of the 23yearold fugitive by the department's Major Crime Investigating Unit.

title: Back to Base Rents
description: The City Council's demagogic action last spring repealing the soundly conceived formula for Maximum Base Rents in 1.1 million rentcontrolled apartments has suffered its expected reversal in State Supreme Court.

title: 5 CLASHES IN 2 DAYS REPORTED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 (AP)  North Vietnamese and Government troops clashed five times yesterday and today in the remote Cambodian frontier province of Quang Due, the Saigon command announced. Two of the battles were said to have involved handtohand fighting and the use of aircraft and armor.

title: Libyan Leader Voices Dismay At EgyptianIsraeli Negotiation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 15 The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, said in a message made public here tonight that he was extremely furious at what was happening on the CairoSuez road.

title: BLAZE TAKES TOLL OF MET COSTUMES
description: Thousands of Metropolitan Opera costumes destroyed in a fire in a Bronx warehouse last week included priceless rarities, some of which dated back 30 years or more.

title: For the First Black Winery in the U.S., 1973 Was NOT a Good Year
description: PRATTSBURG, N.Y.  Fall is a busy time in the wine country 30 miles northwest of Elmira. The grape crop is in, the must is fermenting and earlier vintages are being bottled and shipped for holiday sales.

title: Taxi Board and Union Meet To Discuss a New Contract
description: Negotiating teams for the Metropolitan Taxi Board of Trade and Local 3036 of thet Taxi Drivers Union met in the Commodore Hotel last night to discuss terms of of a new contract.

title: WRITER WILL TESTIFY ON WATERGATE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. The Senate Armed Services Committee announced today that it would hear testimony in executive session tomorrow from Andrew St. George, a New. York writer, about his recently published allegations that the Central Intelligence Agency knew in advance of the Watergate burglary.

title: Business Briefs
description: Gold Price Is Steadier in Europe

title: How to Win Every thing but Polls
description: Penn State, long an alsoran among the top 10 college football teams may never be voted No. 1. It will have to play its way to the top.

title: EXTENSION OF FILL IN QUEENS BARRED
description: A plan to extend by 196 acres a landfill site in the Howard Beach section of Queens was defeated unanimously by the Board of Estimate yesterday under heated pressure from families living in the area.

title: FIRING REPORTED ON GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 15 The two opposing armies on the Golan heights front have dug into fighting positions in which proximity leads to incidents, according to diplomatic sources.

title: VENEZUELA WILL GET ADDED OIL ROYALTIES
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 15 (AP)Venezuela will take in $18.6million additional per month in royalties from foreign oil companies under an agreement that takes effect this month, Mines Minister Hugo Perez la Salvia announced today.

title: Dakota Town Dumfounded at Criticism of Book Burning by Order of the School Board
description: DRAKE, N. D., Nov. 15Already there is in the Dakota air a chill foretaste of the great Arctic gales that sweep down out of Canada, driving temperatures to 30 below zero, flinging across the plains a curtain of snow that wipes from view the water tower and grain elevator that are the main landmarks of this trackside hamlet. The 650 people who live here are a flinty breed, used to such storms. They simply hunker down until the blow is over, and then step outside to enjoyyes, enjoythe cold brittleness that makes it feel, as one resident put it, as if you could take a piece of air in hands and break it.

title: Guild Urges Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) The executive board of the Newspaper Guild, which created a controversy last year by, endorsing Senator George McGovern for President, urged Congress today to begin impeachment proceedings against President Nixon without further delay.

title: EXTENSION OF FILL IN QUEENS BARRED
description: A plan to extend by 196 acres a landfill site in the Howard Beach section of Queens was defeated unanimously by the Board of Estimate yesterday under heated pressure from families living in the area.

title: FORD'S NET WORTH PUT AT $256,378
description: WASHINGTON, Nov., 15 According to a statement of net worth prepared by Gerald R. Ford's tax accountant, the figure for the Vice presidentdesignate as of Sept. 30 was $256,378.

title: NADJARI TO STUDY ILLEGAL FREEINGS
description: The state's special anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, has decided to ask the county clerks in the city to find the names of the judges who in recent years illegally freed convicted narcotic defendants.

title: Pompeo Borra, 75, Painter Headed Academy in Milan
description: MILAN, Italy, Nov. 15 (AP)Pompeo Borra, a painter and former director of Milan's Brera Arts Academy, died of heart ailment yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: PAYMENT BALANCE SHARPLY IMPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Two measures of the United States's balance of international payments showed further improvement in the third quarter, with both in surplus, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Advertising: That Pepsi Feelin'
description: Did you ever get the feeling that most of the stirring music and upbeat pictures of American life on television are bunched up in the commercials?

title: HOUSE APPROVES A 2STEP, 11% RISE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The House approved today an 11 per cent increase, in two steps, in Social Security benefits for some 29 million retired Americans.

title: ExConvict Held in Sex Attack At a BMT Station in Brooklyn
description: A 25yearold Brooklyn man, released from prison last year after serving five years on robbery and rape charges, was charged yesterday with a sexual attack in a subway train Tuesday and, according to the police, was held as a likely suspect in several unsolved recent subway sex crimes.

title: SUSPECT IS CLEARED IN NEW ORLEANS FIRE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 (Reauters)The District Atorney's office said today that it would not press murder and arson charges against the man who confessed to setting a French Quarter fire that killed 32 persons.

title: IndustrialOutput Gain Eases
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Industrial production continued to rise at a good pace in October, though less rapidly than in late 1972 and early this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Brinegar Warns Senators Rail Bill Veto Is Possible
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Secretary of Transportation Claude S. Brinegar warned the Senate Commerce Committee today that a Houseapproved bill to deal with the Northeast rail crisis faced a possible veto.

title: 3 More Corporations Tell About Illegal Aid to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Executives of three more big corporations told the Senate Watergate committee today how they channeled cash through foreign countries in an attempt to hide their illegal Use of corporate funds for conto the Committee to Reelect the ??on campaign.

title: Emergency in Britain
description: Just at the moment when its political prospects seemed at last on the upgrade, partly due to an economic boom, the British Government has been forced abruptly to declare a state of emergency and cut back the money supply drastically. These measures, coupled with the record monthly trade deficit that helped provoke them, are highly embarrassing to Prime Minister Heath's Conservatives in a period regarded as prelude to a general election that must be held within eighteen months.

title: PROSECUTOR'S JOB IS CONGRESS ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The Federal court decision that Archibald Cox was dismissed illegally as special Watergate prosecutor put renewed pressure on Congress today to protect the new prosecutor against any discharge by the President.

title: Ski Show Bounces In For 4 Days
description: Hotdog skiing, trampoline exhibitions and slalom running on a moving deck were some of the highlights as the annual Ski Show started its fourday stand at the New York Coliseum last night.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: 8 GET LIFE TERMS IN LONDON BLASTS
description: LONDON, Nov. 15Eight of the 10 members of an Irish Republican Army squad accused of setting off bombs beside London's Criminal Court last March were sentenced to jail for life today.

title: Jets Draw 3 of a Kind, Need an Ace
description: It was that time again yesterday. Under balmy breezes in Shea Stadium, the New York Jets practiced Who's the Quarterback?, a weekly show starring Joe Namath, Al Woodall and Bill Demory.

title: ExDallas Policeman Convicted In the Fatal Shooting of Boy, 12
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 15 (UPI) An allwhite jury convicted Darrel L. Cain, a former Dallas police officer, today of murdering a 12yearold MexicanAmerican boy whom he sus. pected of being a burglar by shooting the youth pointblank in the head.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will be urged today to agree to anew rail commuter service linking Westchester County communities, Coop City and Parkchester in the Bronx with Pennsylvania Station by way of the Hell Gate Bridge. Two Democratic Representatives, Jonathan B. Bingham of the Bronx, and Ogden Reid of Westchester, will join with other officers and civic leaders to press the proposal in a meeting at 3:30 P.M. with Dr. William J. Ronan, the M.T.A. chairman. The proposed route would use existing New Haven division tracks and would extend from Stamford, Conn., to Penn Station. Existing commuter service from Stamford has Grand Central Terminal at its New York end. The new plan would be an extra service to make West Side trains available to Westchester, Coop City and other Bronx riders.

title: Arizona Is Working With 10,000 Families to Prevent Heart Disease When It Startsin Childhood
description: The State of Arizona is now working with 10,000 families of preschool children in an effort to prevent heart disease when it really startsin early childhood. The program, which focuses on diet, exercise, blood pressure, obesity and cigarette smoking, will be expanded to 13,000 additional families next year, at a cost of $10 to $13 a family.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Peron Will Visit New York Next Month to Address U.N.
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 15 (AP)President Juan D. Pern will travel to New York to address the United Nations General Assembly in the first week of December, Argentina's Foreign Minister said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, Nov. 15 (UPI)The United States Equestrian team all but clinched the jumping championship at the Royal Winter Fair horse show last night when Rodney Jenkins rode to his second victory in the weeklong meet. The international faultandout speed class was much to the liking of Jenkins's top mount, Idle Dice, the gelding scaling 14 fences in a time allowance of 60 seconds for 28 points. With three events remaining, West Germany or Britain would have to win every class to get back into contention. The Americans had 75 points to 47 for Britain, 46 for Germany and 37 for Canada.

title: Kissinger Briefs South Koreans on Peking Visit
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Nov. 16  Secretary of State Kissinger flew into and out m Seoul today in an effort to assure the South Koreans that he had made no deals with the Chinese at the expense of South Korea.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE IMPERIAL PRESIDENCY. By Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. 505 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $10.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT EXCHANGE P.O.W.'S
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 15  The first 26 Israeli prisoners released by Egypt, all of them wounded, arrived from Cairo today, beginning a prisoner exchange that is expected to last a week.

title: City Is Investigating 40 Deaths Among Aged in Hospital Strike
description: Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, tin city's Health Commissioner, said last night that his agency was looking into reports that about 40 nursinghome patients had died as a result of the weeklong strike by 30,000 hospital workers that ended or Monday.

title: Princeton Society Thrives on Controversy
description: PRINCETON, Nov. 15Calling itself the oldest college political and debating society in the world, the American Whig  Cliosophic Society of Princeton University has thrived for two centuries on a diet of argument and controversy.

title: Holiday Lights Seen Saving Electricity
description: A Christmas without Christ. mas tree lights seems incomprehensible to some people particularly to people who make Christmas tree lights. And then came the energy crisis.

title: Soviet Held Unaffected by Arab Oil Cuts
description: While the United States and other advanced industrial nations are struggling with the proipect of serious energy shortages this winter, the Soviet Union and its East European allies appear to be virtually unaffected by the Arabs' cutbacks in oil production.

title: Developer of Cyclamates Urges Drug Agency to End pan on Use
description: A petition to rescind the threeyear ban on cyclamates, the artificial sweetener, was riled with the Federal Food and Drug Administration in Washington yesterday.

title: MRS. CLAUDE M'SPADDEN
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 15 (AP)  Kate McSpadden, who is believed to have inspired the World War 1 marching song KKKKatie, died yesterday, She was 91 years old.

title: Soviet Lofts TV Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Nov, 15 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has launched a communications satellite, Molniya 1, designed partly to transmit television programs to remote areas of Siberia, the Far East and Central Asia, lass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: Ford Claims a Role in Nixon's Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Gerald R. Ford indicated today that he had had a key role in persuading President Nixon to be more forthright about the Watergate matter, both with Congress and the American people.

title: Dr. I. W. Schmidt, a Dentist Who Became Photographer
description: Dr. I. W. Schmidt, who retired as a dentist in 1940 and became a leading amateur photographer, died yesterday in Madison Avenue Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 15900 Riverside Drive West.

title: Brief for the President
description: LOS ANGELESWhen one looks at the public reports on the question of resignation, it would seem that the ayes have it. Yet, this is not borne out by most polls, and I frankly doubt if it reflects a cross section of opinion. Most newspapers which have urged resignation or impeachment report readers disagreed.

title: EXCHANGE OFFER SET BY BENGUET
description: Benguet Consolidated, Inc., announced yesterday in Manila that it was offering to exchange shares of its wholly owned subsidiary, the Intercontinental Diversified Corporation, for Benguet stock on a shareforshare basis.

title: ... and Next, Syria
description: Historic though it is, the IsraeliEgyptian agreement on exchanging their war prisoners is only half of the human story. So far there is no accord on a similar exchange between Israel and Syria.

title: Judge in Krogh Case Bars Dismissal of the Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI A Federal judge refused today to dismiss criminal charges against Egil Krogh Jr., who headed the White House plumbers unit.

title: Big Student Protest Continues in Athens
description: ATHENS, Nov. 15The Government bowed today to a request by the Polytechnic University's senate to keep the police off its grounds, which have been forcibly occupied by hundreds of students.

title: Fuel Lack Bothers Metals Producers
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15The fuel shortage has not curtailed production of metals significantly as yet in the United States, but it has stationed the aluminum, steel and other metal industries on very thin ice.

title: Market Place: PE Ratios Low In Some Stocks
description: More than one stock market observer has looked at the priceearnings ratios shown in the daily stock tables and has concluded that the current market is discounting not only the future but the hereafter as well.

title: People and Business
description: William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, decided earlier this year to replace the 550gallon fueloil tank at his Sands Point, L.I., home with a 4,000gallon tank. Unfortunately for Mr. Tavoulareas, before it could he installed, the energy crisis intervened and word of his plans leaked outand he will be using the smaller tank for a while longer.

title: Dance Hall Is Closed
description: TISHOMINGO, Okla., Nov. 15 (UPI)Burley's Dance Hall, the cause of many complaints from the citizens of Milburn, Okla., was closed yesterday by permanent injunction of District Judge Joe Thompson. Several elderly residents who live near the dance hall, testified that loud music played there late at night disturbed them.

title: Blacks at Rutgers Protest With Huge Book Checkout
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 15 6.Black students from Rutgers, the State University, have been checking out large numbers of books from two college Libraries in an apparent attempt to back up demands for improved conditions.

title: Eandscape/Cityscape, a Photo Exhibition
description: The image of the city as seen through Landscape/ Cityscape, an exhibition of more than 100 photographs, which opened Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is of a place that is at once terrifyingly powerful and extremely beautiful. It is not a brutal view of the city, but very romantic one, and in its best examples, such as the work of Berenice Abbott or Paul Strand, it is very mov ing.

title: Bruins Humble Rangers
description: BOSTON, Nov. 15 The New York Rangers, bearing no resemblance at all to the club that beat the Boston Bruins eight days ago, let the Bruins walk all over them here tonight with a 102 beating and no end of humiliation.

title: CHARLES M. BAHLER
description: Charles M. Bahler, president of Portescap U. S., Inc., importers of Swiss miniature motors for medical equipment and also president of the Incabloc Corporation, manufacturers of watch components, died of cancer Wednesday at the New York Hospital. His age was 45 and he lived at 1040 Park Avenue.

title: ROBERT GIBNEY
description: Robert Gibney, a writer formerly with Parade magazine, died Sunday at his home in Charlotte Amalie, the Virgin Islands. He was 58 years old.

title: Harlem Development Unit Hails It's Supporters and Looks Ahead
description: After quietly amassing nearly $20million in assets over a sixyear period, the Harlem Commonwealth Council, a federally financial local development group, felt secure enough to pat itself on the back last night, as well as to honor publicly some of the people who helped along the way.

title: Connally Denies Getting Dairy Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) John B. Connally denied tonight that he ever accepted money for his help in arranging higher Federal support prices for the nation's dairy industry.

title: New PrivateLine Rates Sought by Bell System
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) The Bell System filed today for approval of a new rate structure designed to help it meet the growing competition it faces from other companies to provide intercity private line voicegrade communications for businesses.

title: EWER GETS A RECORD BUDGET
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian filed his 16th and final budget today, indicating record spending but lowered costs for Westchester County taxpayers.

title: JEWS ARE WARNED OF OIL BACKLASH
description: The leaders of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith cautioned yesterday that ArabIsraeli hostilities and the nation's fuel crisis might arouse an antiSemitic reaction in the United States.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 15Clary Anderson of Montclair State, who has never had a losing season in his 33 years of coaching football, including 27, on the highschool level, is the type of man who has kind words for his opponents. Saturday night, his Indians will be host to Glassboro State, in a game that will determine the winner of the state conference, and Anderson talked today about Richard Wackar, the coach at Glassboro State.

title: A BALMY 77 MELTS MARK FOR NOV
description: The city enjoyed a flashback to summer yesterday as the temperature peaked at 77 de grees. It was the second day it a row of record heat fot November.

title: MARX IS DENIED BID TO BAR SCRAPBOOK
description: A request for an injunction against the distribution of The Marx Bros. Scrapbook, a collection of intimate observations by Groucho Marx, was denied in State Supreme Court yesterday by Justice Nathaniel T. Hellman.

title: School to Auction Antiques
description: The Village Community School, 272 West 10th Street, will hold its second antique country auction tomorrow at P.M. Items to be auctioned include a grandfather's clock, a porcelain bird cage, crocks, quilts and architectural ornaments. Proceeds will go to the school's scholarship fund. Viewing of articles to be auctioned will start at 5 P.M.

title: Watergate's Effect on the Press: Good and Not So Good
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The Watergate disclosures have touched off what many Washington journalists believe to be at least a minor revolution in the craft of news reporting. And newsmen are pretty much agreed that, like most revolutions, this one combines the good with the bad.

title: GEORGE BOKAT, 69, JUDGE FOR N.L.R.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) George Bokat, retired chief administrative law judge of the National Labor Relations Board, died today on his 69th birthday at the George Washington University Hospital.

title: FUEL FEAR VOICED IN NEW ENGLAND
description: An unemployment rate of 8 per cent, closed public buildings and schools and spot cutoffs of electricty by early 1974 because of fuel shortages were forecast yesterday for New England by officials of the New England Council meeting in Boston.

title: Aussies Lead in Davis Cup
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Nov. 16 (UPI) Australia moved to a 10 lead against Czechoslovakia today when Rod Laver defeated the Wimbledon champion. Jan Kodes, 63, 75, 75, in the opening singles match of the Davis Cup semifinals.

title: Private Buyers Enjoy Bargains At American Folk Art Auction
description: Bernet owned the collection, but this was vehemently denied by the gallery.While most dealers sat on their hands yesterday and Wednesday night at the auction of American folk art collected by the late Edith G. Halpert, scores of big, small and neophyte collectors snapped up bargains.

title: APlant's Closing Stirs Plea on CleanAir Rules
description: NEWARK, Nov. 15 (AP)The Public Service Electric & Gas Company today called for a relaxation of airpollution controls in the wake of the shutdown of its nuclear generating station in Peach Bottom, Pa., because of an electrical failure in the generator.

title: BLAZE TAKES TOLL OF MET COSTUMES
description: Thousands of Metropolitan Opera costumes destroyed in a fire in a Bronx warehouse last week included priceless rarities, some of which dated back 30 years or more.

title: SENATE REJECTS GAS DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The Senate rejected today an amendment to the pending National Energy Emergency Act that would have directed President Nixon to put gasoline rationing into effect on Jan. 15.

title: Expansion Study For N.B.A. Set
description: The Board of Governors of the National Basketball Association, meeting in New York yesterday, directed Commissioner Walter Kennedy to make a detailed study for possible expansion of the league.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: G&S The Gilbert & Sullivan Society is one of our city's more hardy perennials, gathering monthly to celebrate the inspirations of the duo whose name it bears. Tonight at 8, the meeting in Steinway Hall, 111 West 57th Street, presents something new in G&S interpretation: a puppet performance of The Pirates of Penzance, done by the Family Robinson, a group of teenage youngsters from Connecticut who work only in Savoyard operettas and make all of their own equipment, puppets and all.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Nixon's Last Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15President Nixon took a chance when he invited the Senators and Representatives to the White House to question him about Watergate, but he has made some progress in these strange and unprecedented efforts to restore confidence in his battered Adminiitration.

title: Chargesof Contempt Are Filed Against Fire Union Leaders
description: The City went into State Supreme Court here yesterday to seek the punishment of leaders of the Uniformed Firefighters Association for criminal contempt in directing last week's fiveandonehalfhour strike against the Fire Department.

title: Notes on People
description: British Airways said no special arrangements had been made for two of the firstclass passengers booked on flight 695 from London to Barbados yesterday. But it was noted that the young couple were surrounded by flowers while waiting in the airport lounge; that they were the last two to board the plane, having been driven across the tarmac in a marroon RollsRoyce, and that before reaching the cabin door, they turned and waved to 300 wellwish wishers. The couple were, of course, Princess Anne and her new husband, Capt. Mark Phillips. As for their traveling companions on the first phase of their wedding trip, it was said that at least nine of the other firstclass passengers were journalists.

title: Pentagon Denies Planning OpenAir Nerve Gas Test
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)  A Pentagon spokesman said today there are no plans at all for openair testing of nerve gas.

title: BrownHarvard No Cinch for Crimson This Year
description: For most of the 18 seasons the Ivy League has been in formal existence, Brown usually was locked in a struggle with Columbia for last place.

title: Dow Index Is Up by 4.67; Volume Tops 24 Million
description: The stock market put together the semblance of a rally yesterday after four days of precipitous declines touched off by the energy crisis.

title: Junior League Joins City in Fight on V. D.
description: The Junior League of New York and the city's Bureau of Venereal Disease Control yesterday announced a joint campaign to get women to demand regular testing for gonorrheanow the most prevalent disease that women here have to worry about and rapidly moving into the suburbs and Park Avenue, a bureau spokesman said.

title: Nixon in 8th Phase of Counterattack
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The counterattack President Nixon is now vigorously conducting is at least the eighth major effort he has made this year to put the Watergate scandals behind him.

title: People in Sports: Fanning Backs Right to Criticize
description: Instead of scolding his top relief pitcher, Mike Marshall, for saying those nasty things about the competence of the team, the Montreal Expos' general manager, Jim Fanning, said yesterday he understood.

title: Truck Tonnage Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 4.7 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. Truck tonnage last week was 4.2 per cent below the immediately preceding week. The ATA reported that based on a terminal survey of 35 metropolitan areas, increased tonnage from a year ago was reported at 27 localities.

title: Planned Visit by Nixon Stirs Protest at School
description: MACON, Ga., Nov. 15 (UPI) Telegrams protesting President Nixon's planned visit to Mercer University were sent to Washington today by 300 students and 35 faculty members.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A 2STEP, 11% RISE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The House approved today an 11 per cent increase, in two steps, in Social Security benefits for some 29 million retired Americans.

title: Capital Punishment
description: ERIE, Colo., Nov. 15 (AP)School children and parents questioned an inmate of Colorado State Penitentiary at speech on prison life. Capital punishment was one question and Duncan, 25 years old, who is serving a 30year term for hank robbery, responded: Anyone for capital punishment ought to try it once.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange turned around ysterday and closed higher for the first time in six sessions although declines still outnumbered advances. Analysts at tributed the rally to bargain hunting by some investors Prices in the overthecounter market, however, continued lower as declines in prices there also far outnumbered advances.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Nastase Ousts Moore
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP)Mark Cox of Britain, a lefthander, defeated Toni Gorman of Seattle for the first time in his career today and gained the semifinal round in the Dewar Cup tennis tournament. The scores were 63, 16, 62.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Convention Center Approved by Board
description: The Board of Estimate approved last night funding to begin construction of the last great project of the Lindsay administration  the $200million convention center on the West Side along the Hudson River.

title: Reduction Would Hurt 700,000 Workers, Lazarus, of Federated, Predicts
description: Major segments of the nation s retailing industry yesterday urged the Federal Government not to urge curtailment of store hours in the coming Christmas shopping season as a means of conserving energy.

title: Dispute Erupts in House On Meetings With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., accused President Nixon today of trying to curry favor with his prospective grand jurors by inviting members of Congress to meet with him at the White House.

title: Troy Threatens to Delay Funds For Work at Yankee Stadium
description: Further financing for the city's purchase and renovation of Yankee Stadium and its surrounding area will be held up until the Lindsay Administration provides final cost figures, Matthew J. Troy Jr., chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, said yesterday.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: Tickets matching only the last two win five 50cent tickets for any subsequent weekly drawing when shown to any lottery vender.

title: Shirley Chisholm Facing U.S. Inquiry Into 3 Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Representative Shirley Chisholm, the Brooklyn Democrat who in 1972 became the first woman to seek the Presidential nomination of a major party, is the target of Federal investigations into three areas of alleged wrongdoing, law enforcement sources said today.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 1.1 From Last Week's Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 190.8 from 191.9 last week.

title: U.S. AIDE IS CALLED IN BUSFUEL CASE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn, saying it was impossible for the courts to deal with the growing energy crisis, yesterday directed United States Attorney Robert B. Morse to appear before him Monday morning to tell how the executive branch was handling the allocation and supply of fuel oil.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Slight Loss of Stealth
description: LEMPSTER, N. H.Somewhere in Thoreau's writings it may have been Walden he confessed that although he possessed a certain knack for fishing he had reached a stage in his life where he could no longer pursue the sport with total devotion.

title: U.A.W. AIDE POSTS BOND IN SHOOTING
description: DETROIT, Nov. 15David L. Mundy, a leader of the United Automobile Workers union, was arraigned today on a charge of assault with intent to murder in the shooting of a worker last Tuesday.

title: Crew of Skylab 3 Due to Go Up Today On 84Day Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 15  Final preparations were under way tonight for the launching tomorrow morning of the Skylab 3 astronauts for a record 84day mission aboard the nation's orbiting laboratory.

title: Red Smith
description: The Intellectual Digest is a monthly magazine whose content, generally speaking, is described by the title. In the November issue, for example, we find an interview with the rebel Soviet poet, Andrei A. Voznesensky; a piece entitled The Sigmoid Curve of Jonas Salk and one on Sexual Adequacy in America; an excerpt from Robert E. Ornstein's The Psychology of Consciousness; Peter Fenwick on The Neurophysiology of Meditation and excerpts from the journal that the Trappist, monk, Thomas Merton, kept on the Asian visit that was his last journey.

title: Fed Permits Holding Units To Operate Courier Service
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that had decided to permit bank holding companies to engage in the courier service business, but it took no action on an mored car services.

title: Legislators Say Changes In Rape Law Are Likely
description: Legislative leaders at a hearing on revision of the laws for sex crimes said here yesterday that the repeal of at least some portions of the state's strict corroboration requirements was likely this winter in Albany.

title: Solution at Hand
description: The counteroffensive launched by the White House to break the Watergate siege and shore up President Nixon's dwindling public support is clearly aimed minimizing the outstanding issues and suggesting that they are about to be resolved.

title: State Unhappy at DrunkDriving Test
description: EDISON, Nov. 15  A state attempt to publicize the dangers of driving after drinking went wrong today, and officials of the Division of Motor Vehicles said they would change their testing technique.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The superchic won't have to fly to Paris to do their Christmas shopping this year. Even the friend who has everything shouldn't snub a small, charming bag of glossy crocodile priced at $1,445. Or a sevenounce crock of foie gras for $55. Both of these goodies are to be had without one's limousine leaving the area of Fifth Avenue in the fifties.

title: I.C.C. Again Rejects Fare Rise for PATH
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission has again rejected a proposal for a 20cent fare increase for PATH commuters and, barring a court reversal of the decision, appeared to foreclose the possibility of any, fare increase on the transHud son line at least until early July.

title: Talks Are Continuing Here On Milk Union's Contracts
description: Contract talks between negotiators for 3,000 delivery men and other dairyplant workers and 200 milk distributors in the New York metropolitan area continued yesterday after passing a bargaining deadline. The talks are in the Sheraton Inn at La Guardia Airport.

title: JAPAN TO RATION FUEL AND POWER
description: TOKYO, Nov. 16The Japanese Government announced an emergency program today to ration oil and electric power for industry and appealed to the Japanese public to conserve fuel voluntarily at home, at work and on the highway.

title: TROOPS IN ATHENS MOVE ON CAMPUS TO QUELL PROTEST
description: ATHENS, Saturday, Nov. 17 Greek troops using a tank crashed through the iron gates of the Athens Polytechnic University early today to help the police dislodge some 2,000 students who had seized the campus and demanded the overthrow of the Government.

title: Sohio Stock Split Approved
description: CLEVELAND, Nov, 16 (AP) The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said that shareholders approved overwhelmingly today a 2for1 stock split. New certificates representing the additional shares will be mailed to stockholders Dec. 17.

title: Celtics End Buck String; Nets Beaten
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) Dave Cowens scored 14 points in the fourth period to help the Boston Celtics defeat the Milwaukee Bucks, 10590, tonight in a National Basketball Association game snapping Milwaukee's 13game winning streak.

title: President's Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)Following is the text of President Nixon's Thanksgiving Day proclamation for 1973 issued by the White House today:

title: A Delay Is Granted In Case Against Pair In 17 Coast Killings
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI)  A municipal court judge today granted an 11day delay in proceedings against two young men charged with the murder of nine persons and eight other killings so the prosecution could seek formal indictments.

title: Rangers Reel From Boston Battering
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16A bellman in the hotel where the New York Rangers were staying put it aptly: This is a disaster area.

title: Mission's Civilian Scientist in Residence
description: To Edward George Gibson, the 37yearold civilian scientistastronaut and author of a book called The Quiet Sun, the chance to spend eight weeks or more aboard Skylab, operating an array of solar telescopes, is the opportunity of a lifetime.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic oh U.S. railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.2 billion tonmiles, 6 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings during the same period totaled 558,107 cars, 2.9 per cent above last year.

title: Former Dallas Policeman Given 5 Years in Murder of Youth, 12
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 16 (UPI) A jury sentenced Darrell L. Cain, a former Dallas policeman to five years in prison today after ruling that he murdered 12yearold Santos Rodriguez with malice.

title: America's 2 Giant Pandas Get New Playground in Zoo
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) America's giant pandas have a new playground at the National Zoo complete with 12footdiameter pools, bamboo and weeping willows.

title: Russell, Smithwick Dead
description: Obituaries on John (Honey) Russell, a member of the Basketball Hall of Fame, and A. P. (Paddy) Smithwick, former champion steeplechase jockey, appear qn Page 38.

title: Business Briefs
description: Prices for Floridaproduced phosphate rock to foreign markets will be increased by about 100 per cent beginning Jan. 1, the Phosphate Rock Export Association announced yesterday.

title: Dairylea Milk Adulteration Admitted at State Hearing
description: ALBANY, Nov. 16  The Dairylea Cooperative, Inc., one of the country's largest producers of milk, admitted at formal hearing today that it had adulterated and mislabeled milk and milk products sold in New York State, including New York City, from 1967 until early this year.

title: SANDMAN RAN UP $400,000 DEFICIT
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s campaign for Governor apparently has run up a nearrecord campaign debt of $400,000 to $500,000, according to sources close to the state Republican finance committee.

title: TROOPS IN ATHENS MOVE ON CAMPUS TO QUELL PROTEST
description: ATHENS, Saturday, Nov. 17 Greek troops using a tank crashed through the iron gates of the Athens Polytechnic University early today to help the police dislodge some 2,000 students who had seized the campus and demanded the overthrow of the Government.

title: Barcelona Province Chief Hits Back at Churchmen
description: MADRID, Nov. 16The Government struck back harshly today against attacks on its policies by members of the Roman Catholic church with two statements that seemed to rule out any reconciliation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 16 (AP)The Soviet Union informed the International Football Federation (FIFA) today officially and finally that it would not play the World Cup preliminary match next Wednesday against Chile in Santiago because of the overthrow of the Communist regime there in September.

title: Farms, Buses and Oil Dealers Are Given Diesel Fuel Priority
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) The Government designated today three priority users of disel fuel, particularly crop and livestock farmers, for 60 days of preferential treatment in obtaining extra supplies under the mandatory allocation program that began Nov. 1.

title: Watson's Lead Cut to 2 Shots
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 16I'll be satisfied only if I win, said Tom Watson, the 24yearold professional who held the lead going into tomorrow's final round of the $500,000 World open golf tournament.

title: The Devil's Work
description: Acting on a teenaged girl's complaint that Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhotse Five was profane, the school board of a town in North Dakota ordered all copies of the book burned, after a search of students' lockers to ascertain that they harbored none of the dangerous contraband. Among other books that may be proscribed is an anthology of American writers including Hemingway, Faulkner and Steinbeck. The young teacher who assigned the Vonnegut book has been told he may not be rehired next year.

title: FIREMEN VOTED AGAINST STRIKE; BALLOTS MISSING
description: The city's firemen, who staged an unprecedented fiveandahalfhour strike on Election Day last week, had voted 4,119 to 3,827 against any strike, the head of the Honest Ballot Association said last night.

title: For Roland, ExCardinal, The Cleat's on Other Foot
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 16When the St. Louis Cardinals meet the Giants in the Yale Bowl Sunday, Johnny Earl Roland, the New York fullback, will have more than an ordinary interest in the game.

title: Captain Suspended in Gun Authorization
description: A city police captain with 22 years on the force was suspended without pay yesterday for authorizing the issuance of a pistol permit for the, chauffeur of Thomas Eboli, the slain organizedcrime figure, the Police Department reported.

title: 24 Die as Flames Engulf Stair Well in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (UPI)  Flames swept up an open staircase like a gigantic chimney today, engulfing a threestory apartment house and killing 24 persons in the worst residential fire in the city's history. Fiftytwo persons were injured.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Gadgetaddicted of the world take note: The latest machines to be uncrated at Hammacher Schlemmer, that haven for gimmickminded shoppers, don't always work and they come without instructions and warranties. But no one seems to care.

title: Dozens Evacuated by Fire In Lincoln Square Hotel
description: Dozens of guests and residents were routed from the Lincoln Square Hotel on West 75th Street early today when Fire broke out on the eighth Floor, sending dense, choking smoke billowing into rooms and hallways of the 16story, structure.

title: Hunter in Soccer Final
description: UNION, N. J., Nov. 16Hunter and New Haven College advanced today to the final of the second annual Eastern College Athletic Conference soccer tournament at Newark State College. Hunter defeated William Paterson College, 21, and New Haven set back Newark State, 41, in overtime. The winners meet for the championship tomorrow.

title: President Signs Measure To Allow Alaska Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16President Nixon signed the Alaska pipeline bill today and hailed it as a first step toward making the United States wholly selfsufficient for its energy supplies by 1980. An official of the Department of the Interior expressed confidence that the law authorizing the 789mile pipeline from Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's North Slope to the warm water port of Valdez would survive any challenge in court.

title: THAI SAYS CHINESE OFFER TO SELL OIL
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 16A wellinformed Thai official said today that China had let it be known that she had Mideast oil to sell.

title: Braves' Owner Roughed Up, Too
description: Paul Snyder, the owner of the Buffalo Braves, was unhappy after his team lost on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden to the Knicks. But worse was in store. He returned to the Plaza Hotel and rushed into an elevator. A man grabbed him from behind and Snyder turned and hit the man in the face. A scuffle developed and spilled out into the lobby.

title: Nixon Embargo Statement Sends Stocks Up Sharply
description: A statement by President Nixon indicating that Arab nations might soon relax their embargo on oil to the United States, Europe and Japan sent stock prices sharply higher yesterday in active trading.

title: KOREA CAMPUS SHUT TO QUELL PROTESTS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 16 Korea University, where 3,000 demonstrators clashed with police yesterday, closed down today for one week to prevent students from gathering at the school for further demonstrations.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: FIREMEN VOTED AGAINST STRIKE; BALLOTS MISSING
description: The city's firemen, who staged an unprecedented fiveandahalfhour strike on Election Day last week, had voted 4,119 to 3,827 against any strike, the head of the Honest Ballot Association said last night.

title: SOVIET EXCHANGE ON CROP DATA SET
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16A joint SovietAmerican Committee on Cooperation in Agriculture met here this week, and statistics on Soviet crops are expected to start flowing soon to United States officials.

title: Skylab 3 Crew Docks With Lab in Orbit As Astronauts Begin 84Day Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 16Three American astronauts were launched here today on the nation's last manned space flight for at least a year and a half, a planned 84day mission aboard the earthorbiting Skylab space station.

title: First Commercial Mission To U.S. Planned by China
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 16China will send its first commercial mission to the United States early, next year and follow up with a trade exhibition, probably in 1975, a delegation of American business leaders announced here today.

title: MILK PRICE RISING 3 OR 4C PER QUART
description: Milk distributors in the metropolitan area reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a contract with 3,000 employes whose pay raises, together with rawmilk price increases decreed by the Government, will send the retail price of milk up 3 or 4 cents a quart on Dec. 1.

title: MILK PRICE RISING 3 OR 4C PER QUART
description: Milk distributors in the metropolitan area reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a contract with 3,000 employes whose pay raises, together with rawmilk price increases decreed by the Government, will send the retail price of milk up 3 or 4 cents a quart on Dec. 1.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Teachers' leaders at eight state colleges in New Jersey and the State Department of Higher Education met yesterday at Rutgers, the State University, in a continuing effort to resolve differences in contract negotiations.

title: Braves' Owner Roughed Up, Too
description: Paul Snyder, the owner of the Buffalo Braves, was unhappy after his team lost on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden to the Knicks. But worse was in store. He returned to the Plaza Hotel and rushed into an elevator. A man grabbed him from behind and Snyder turned and hit the man in the face. A scuffle developed and spilled out into the lobby.

title: PENTAGON TO FLY LAWMAKERS SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Defense Department, which contends that it is limiting fuel consumption to essential military requirements, will fly two planeloads of Congressmen and friends to Georgia Sunday to help celebrate the 90th birthday of former Representative Carl M. Vinson.

title: Alan Watts, Zen Philosopher, Writer and Teacher, 58, Dies
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif., Nov. 16Alan Watts, the philosopher whose writings influenced the beat and hippie generations and helped popularize Zen Buddhism in the United States, died today at the age of 58.

title: Brezhnev Says U.S., Soviet Share Mideast Peace Aim
description: The United States and the Soviet Union share a common desire for peace in the Middle East, Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, said yesterday in an interview in his office in the Kremlin.

title: L. I. TV STATION ON AIR TOMORROW
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Nov. 16 At 830 A.M. on Sunday, the first commercial television station in New York's suburbs signs on the air herea response, the founders and operators say, to their contention that until now no one in New York City television has provided the kind of news and programing we feel we deserve.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Nixon Reportedly. Asserts Cox Reneged on Tapes Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16President Nixon reportedly accused Archibald Cox today of reneging at the last minute on a compromise settlement of the Watergate tapes case.

title: BASKETBALL
description: Colleges

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LIFE WITH FATHER Bla Bart the Hungarian composer whose work pioneered so much in music, came to America in 1940 and died in New York five years later. He had two sons by two wives. The older one, Bla Jr., has lived his whole life in Hungary, where his work has nothing at all to do with music or with his father's life.

title: Bridge: VictoryPoint Swiss Scoring Is a Method With a Hole in It
description: The Greater New York Bridge Association is out of step with the rest of the country in one important MA: Swiss Teams here are si:bred on a victorypoint Wale instead of on a windrawlose plan.

title: Nixon Reportedly Asserts Cox Reneged on Tapes Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16President Nixon reportedly accused At chibald Cox today of reneging at the last minute on a compromise settlement of the Watergate tapes case.

title: Mrs. Ruth Natowitz Rewed
description: TONAWANDA, N. Y., Nov. 16Mrs. Ruth S. Natowitz and Sidney J. Cohen of Williamsville were married here this afternoon by Rabbi Herman Horowitz in his study at Temple Beth El. The bride's former marriage ended in divorce. Her husband, whose first wife died, owns a chain of drivein movie theaters in Buffalo suburbs and is president of the New York State Association of Theater Owners.

title: The Life and Works of Horace Walpole Are the Life's Work of a Scholar in Connecticut
description: FARMINGTON, Conn. Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis and his motherinlaw were driving past the corner of East 56th Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan some years ago when Mr. Lewis observed what he later called a luminescent light shining from a bookstore.

title: Bowl Bids Only a Formality
description: Ten of the 11 major bowls may officially extend invitations to the teams of their choice today. In almost every case the act will be superfluous. Bowl pairings have been agreed on for more than a week even though the National Collegiate Athletic Association has a rule stating that Nov. 17 is the first day bowl officials may contact the colleges involved.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Jewish Theological Seminary of America has conferred its Herbert H. Lehman Ethics Medal on Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, for having contributed strongly to the ideals of rectitude and justice between and among men, and between government and the people. Eight others, prominent in business, civic and Jewish religious affairs, received the seminary's 17th annual Louis Marshall Memorial Award. They were David Berg of New York; Jack E. Gindi of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Herman Gross of Great Neck, L.I.; Marvin H. Itts of Youngstown, Ohio; Samuel P. Mandell of Philadelphia; Ira Sollar of Lawrence, L.I.; Samuel Stein of Fort Lee, N.J., and Irving Strum of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: 15.4% Increase Is Granted In State Telephone Rates
description: A $304million gross increase in ratesabout 15.4 per cent was authorized yesterdiy for the New York Telephone Company by the State Public Service Commission.

title: Cawley Praises Drive To Catch BribeGivers
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley yesterday praised his department's, crackdown on those who try to bribe policemen, saying it had demonstrated that the police officers of this department are not for sale.

title: Theater: Black Portrait
description: Three years ago a number of black theaters in the boroughs of New York formed the Black Theater Alliance. Most of these companies not only produce plays, but also offer classes and workshops they are vital grassroots community centers.

title: Clarence P. Oakes Dead; Headed Strategy Institute
description: DOVER, Del., Nov. 16 (AP)Clarence P. Oakes, director of the Institute for American Strategy, Boston, Va., since 1961 and a former Kansas State Representative and Senator, died last night at the Dover Air Force Base. He was 73 years old.

title: Reed Is Rated Possible To Face Bucks Tonight
description: Wayne Embry, the general manager of the Milwaukee Bucks, is a cautious man. Coming into Madison Square Garden tonight with the team that has the best record in the National Basketball Association, Embry is skeptical about the Knicks being a weakened opponent because of some injury problems.

title: Even the Daring Designers Know How to Play It Safe
description: Most women are more adventurous about the paintings they put on their wall than the clothes they put on their back.

title: MRS. MARK C. FEER
description: Mrs. Helene Feer, vice president of the Westchester Association for Retarded Children and wife of Mark C. Feer, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Co., investment bankers, died Wednesday after heart surgery at the New York Hospital. Her age was 48, and she lived in Scarsdale.

title: BUSTRUCK PLEA ON SPEED DENIED
description: New York State's Commissioner of Transportation, Raymond T. Schuler, has turned down appeals from bus and truck operators for exemptions from the new energysaving 50mileanhour speed limit.

title: People and Business
description: The life of an accountant is generally prosaic, but George M. Edwards, a senior accountant with Touche Ross & Co., had more than his share of excitement during the concern's audit of the Equity Funding Corporation of America after that company's spectacular collapse last spring.

title: Reorganized Rails
description: Congress appears at long last to be moving energetically toward adoption of a comprehensive plan for assuring continuation of essential railroad transportation in the Northeast. The energy shortage and the consequent need for transferring traffic from highways to rails have added urgency to a task that always deserved higher priority than Capitol Hill gave it.

title: NIXON IS HOPEFUL OIL BAN WILL END
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16President Nixon expressed hope today that what he called the real progress in the Middle East might lead to a lifting of the Arab embargo on oil shipments to the United States.

title: Stock Prices Climb on the Amex, but Fall on OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday for the second straight day, with advances outnumbering declines for the first time in several sessions. Prices in the overthecounter market, however, again were lower even cltough advances outpaced declines.

title: Finley Ready to Appeal Beyond Kuhn
description: In a 5hour meeting with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn that included two witnesses, lawyers and a legal stenographer, Charles O. Finley yesterday made his formal appeal to get back the $7,000 he lost in fines for his actions during the World Series.

title: Cahill Will Practice Law And Teach in Princeton
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16Governor Cahill will practice law and become a senior teaching fellow at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs after he leaves office here Jan. 15.

title: Rhodesia Says Zambia Seizes a PowerCompany Aide
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  The Rhodesian Government said today that Zambian security forces had seized a white employe of the Central African Power Corporation from the Rhodesian side of the Kariba Dam that straddles the two countries and had taken him to Lusaka, the Zambian capital, where he was being held.

title: Kissinger Assures South Korea About His Talks With Chinese
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 16Secretary of State Kissinger tried to assure President Park Chung Hee of South Korea today that he had made no agreements with China contrary to Korean national interests.

title: Colonel on the Spot
description: When Spyros Markezinis was sworn in last month as Premier of Greece's first allcivilian Cabinet since 1967, he promised impeccable parliamentary elections in 1974 and a constructive dialogue with rebellious students who had provoked a crisis for the military regime last February.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: BOGOTA, Nov. 16At first glance you might mistake the young man dashing across the Bogota High School field for a member of the football team. But the young man, decked out in purple and gold, is the head coach24yearold Bill Medea.

title: Financial Writers' Show Lampoons Sacred Cows
description: The ups and downs of business and finance in one its most frenetic years were presented in living color last night at the 1973 Financial Follies.

title: Pompidou and Heath Hold Talks on Common Market
description: LONDON, Nov. 16 (Reuters) President Pompidou arrived here today for two days of talks with Prime Minister Heath on the European Common Mars ket and its future relations with the United States and Japan. They also planned to discuss Middle East developments.

title: Treatment to Stop Dental Pain Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16About one out of every 10 extracted molars leaves a dry socket that may cause excruciating pain for a week or two. A patent was granted this week for what it describes as the first treatment that stops the pain and permits normal healing. Leslie L. Balassa assigned Patent 3,772,432 to Lescarden, Ltd., a pharmaceutical research and development company in Goshen, N.Y., of which he is president.

title: REPORTS SAY SAUDIS CONSIDER SOVIET TIE
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16  Arab diplomats report that Saudi Arabia, a country that has long regarded the Soviet Union as dangerous foe, is considering establishing diplomatic relations with it.

title: Senate Votes to Curb Chauffeured Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Senate voted today to take away assigned, chauffeurdriven limousines from most high Federal officials in an effort to conserve gasoline.

title: Screen: 2 Documentaries
description: The Film Forum, that small but enterprising showcase for experimental movies on West 88th Street, rings the bell solidly with its new doubledocumentary bill.

title: BitPart Spider Walks On
description: A small red spider appeared on TV screens across much of the country last night when it walked across the lens of a WNBC projector showing of the final segment of The Blue Knight, starring William Holden. Surprised WNBC technicians said the spider appeared at 10:08 during a restaurant scene that included a belly dancer. It took about eight seconds for it to cross the screen twice. It was a small walkon part, quipped one technician,

title: Ford Defends His Record On Civil Rights Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Gerald R. Ford defended his civil rights record today, declaring that every American is entitled to equal treatment.

title: Ruth M. Gonchar Is Married Here
description: Miss Ruth Miriam Gonchar, an instructor at Hunter College, was married here last evening to Daniel Edward Brennan 3d, executive assistant to Hunter's president. Judge William Riegler of the Family Court of Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: U.S. and Soviet Agree To Environmental Study
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)The United States and Russia announced today an expanded program of environmental study designed to find out, among other things, if the air in St. Louis is dirtier than the air in Leningrad.

title: West Germany to Ban Sunday Driving
description: BONN, Nov. 16  Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that West Germany, facing shortages resulting from the Arab oil embargo, would ban Sunday driving beginning Nov. and impose other restraints on oil consumption.

title: The Screen:'Some Call It Loving' Is Diffuse Fantasy
description: "I feel a need to be fulfilled," says one of the principals in "Some Call It Loving," which opened yesterday at the 59th Street Twin Theater. James B. Harris, the film's producer-director-writer, may have been fulfilled, but it is awfully difficult for even a willing viewer to appreciate the sadly diffuse fantasies of an erstwhile sideshow sleeping beauty, a rich, weird temptress and the bemused young man they both seem to adore.Since this odd affair was inspired by John Collier's short story "Sleeping Beauty," it should be noted that the setting has been changed from Britain to a baronial mansion on the West Coast owned by Carol White, who not only goes for Zalman King, a jazz saxophonist, but also for Tisa Farrow, the resuscitated "beauty" he brings to that strange household. Miss White, by the way, also digs Veronica Anderson, the blonde maid, and loves to dress up as a nun.Mr. King, who sports a wild mane of hair and a woebegone expression, cannot be faulted for appearing confused most of the time. Miss White, who is slightly imperious and sexy as the seductress, spouts such dialogue as "When a woman loves a man, there's no limit to her understanding."
