Tisa Farrow (Mia Farrow's younger sister) is pretty, but essentially juvenile, as the innocent, awakened beauty.Mr. Harris, who produced Stanley Kubrick's "Paths of Glory," "Lolita" and "The Killing" and produced and directed "The Bedford Incident," has provided "Some Call It Loving" with sumptuous, rococo dcor. But he has fashioned a rambling, contemporary fable that is merely pretentious.

title: Music
description: There are half a dozen young string quartets in the world today that are a step or two away from the kind of unchallenged superiority that was exercised in recent decades by the Budapest and the Juilliard. But the best of the new groups will have to step fast to keep up with, let alone surpass, the Tokyo String Quartet, which opened a threeconcert series Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Agency Sees Apparent Violations in Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. The General Accounting Office has recommended that the Justice Department take legal action for the alleged mishandling of funds in Representative Shirley Chisholm's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: JAPAN TO RATION FUEL AND POWER
description: TOKYO, Nov. 16The Japanese Government announced an emergency program today to ration oil and electric power for industry and appealed to the Japanese public to conserve fuel voluntarily at home, at work and on the highway.

title: Clerics and Professors Set Ecumenical Service Here
description: Roman Catholic, Protestant, Jewish and Greek Orthodox leaders will join professors of law and philosophy tomorrow to reaffirm national moral values in an ecumenical service at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: PRISONER FOUND HANGING IN CELL
description: A 39yearold man whose trial for murder had been pending for nearly 10 years was found dead yesterday, apparently a suicide in his cell on Rikers Island.

title: Useful or Delicate News
description: PEKINGAn American journalist must travel through Lewis Carroll's looking glass to try and understand the role of the press and other media in the People's Republic of China. It is not a question of giving the people light so that they will find their own way or of publishing all the news that's fit to print. It is more a matter of directing the people along a way to find the selected light, or printing the news that fits.

title: Representative Planning to Seek Reelection
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm declared yesterday that it was her definite intention to ??un for reelection to her seat ??n Congress next year.

title: Gamble by the British
description: LONDON, Nov. 16Britain has been forced to try to slow the expansion of her economy with a series of measures designed to give her trade partners renewed confidence in the pound and in the ability of the Governinent to contain inflation. The shock of an enormous October trade deficit totaling $715million just when Britain's trade balance was widely expected to show an improvement has raised serious doubts about the Government's economic programs. As a result, Prime Minister Heath has chosen to gamble that he can slow the boom without tipping the economy into recession.

title: U.S and Soviet Negotiators Recess Geneva Arms Talks
description: GENEVA, Nov. 16  The United States and the Soviet Union today recessed the second phase of their talks here on the limitation of strategic arms to permit the negitiators to return to their capitals for consultations.

title: Cahill Will Practice Law And Teach in Princeton
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16Governor Cahill will practice law and become a senior teaching fellow at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs after he leaves office here Jan. 15.

title: Honeywell to Get $3Million From Sperry Rand on Suit
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation settled yesterday a patentinfringement suit brought by Honeywell, Inc., with an agreement to pay Honeywell $3million.

title: Archeologist Hopes State Will Help to Finance Digs
description: WEST ORANGEAt the rate New Jersey is being macadamized, the record of its first 12,000 years of human habitation will be buried even deeper in the next two decades, according to an expert on New Jersey Indian life.

title: TEXACO ENDS DEAL ON COASTAL STATES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) Texaco, Inc., has agreed to shelve plans to take over the Coastal States Gas Producing Company, the largest independent supplier to independent gas stations.

title: MARINO JEANTET, 59 QUEENS CIVIC LEADER
description: Marino Jeantet, a leading Queens civic worker who served as chairman of Community Planning Board 3 for Corona, Elmhurst and Jackson Heights, died Thursday of a heart ailment in Bellevue Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 10120 Nicols Avenue, Corona.

title: WINE TALK
description: In a recent letter, a reader confessed that she continues to find the subject of wine impenetrable. What's more, she said, the proliferation of books and articles on the subject only makes it all the more complicated.

title: War and Peace Side by Side in a Mekong Delta Hamlet
description: CAI LAY, South Vietnam Nov. 4The people who live in the villages and hamlets of this lush, wet, green Mekong Delta area say their lot has not changed much since the signing of the ceasefire in Paris last January.

title: Outstanding Double Bill at Guggenheim
description: A double bill of extraordinary exhibitions has come to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum this week. One is a show of paintings, drawings and instructional charts by the Russian modernist, Kasimir Malevich. The other is a selection of important works from the Lydia and Harry Lewis Winston Collection of modern painting and sculpture. Each separately would constitute a considerable event for the public interested in modern art. Together they form an indispensable survey of major aspects of the European avantgarde in the early decades of the century.

title: Hanoi Troops Counter Saigon's Thrust
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 16 (Reuters)The battle for control of South Vietnam's border with Cambodia in the Central Highlands has intensified with the North Vietnamese Army counterattacking a Govenunent thrust to recapture border bases.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: N.B.C.'s My Fair Lady Is C.B.S.Money Maker
description: The National Broadcasting Company has a television blockbuster scheduled for Thanksgiving night, and the Columbia Broadcasting System will realize a handsome sum of money from it. That is the anomaly of the first television presentation of the 1964 movie, My Fair Lady.

title: Dairylea Milk Adulteration Admitted at State Hearing
description: ALBANY, Nov. 16  The Dairylea Cooperative, Inc., one of the country's largest producers of milk, admitted at formal hearing today that it had adulterated and mislabeled milk and milk products sold in New York State, including New York City, from 1967 until early this year.

title: Faculty at N.Y.U. Facing a Runoff On Selection of a Bargaining Agent
description: The collectivebargaining election at New York University last Wednesday and Thursday will probably result in a runoff sometime next month between the United Federation of College Teachers' N.Y.U. chapter and the no agent position backed by the university administration.

title: Pro Aide Looks Into Drug Issue
description: Bernie Jackson, a top security official of the National Football League, met yesterday with George Burman of the Washington Redskins to discuss Burman's charges that onethird of the Redskins used amphetamines to charge themselves up before games.

title: OTB a Jumping Place Today
description: Can an aristocratic but impoverished old matron find happiness with a brash, wellheeled hustler young enough to be her grandson?

title: Debate Over Detente
description: The argument by Roy Medvedev, the dissident Russian historian, that liberalization of the Soviet regime is better advanced by dtente than by making American trade and credits conditional upon internal change in the U.S.S.R. comes at a time when Congressional sentiment in Washington is moving the other way.

title: High School Notes
description: Two comprehensive high schools are using student interest in flying and sailing as tools to spark greater achievement in traditional academic subject matter.

title: HONEY RUSSELL, 70, OF SETON HALL DIES
description: John (Honey) Russell, former coach of noted basketball teams at Seton Hall University and a member of the Basketball Hall of Fame, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home, 57 Hazel Avenue, Livingston, N.J. He was 70 years old.

title: 15 Policemen Keep Money Lost in Test
description: In a Police Department experiment this fall in which 51 patrolmen were handed lost wallets containing $20 or more by strangers, and were asked to turn them in, 15 officers apparently kept the money without making a report.

title: SIRICA WILL DEFER LISTENING TO TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Judge John J. Sirica has decided not to listen to the subpoenaed Watergate tape recordings until a panel of technical experts has examined the tapes to determine if they have been tampered with.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Witness Contradicts Kalmbach On Political Gift by Milk Group
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16A former lawyer for milk producers has given a sworn statement indicating that Herbert W. Kalmbach, one of President Nixon's chief fund raisers, solicited campaign contributions a year earlier than he testified to before the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Smallest Horse Given Biggest Shot at Stakes
description: Coraggioso is one of the smallest thoroughbred campaigners in training, but Tony Basile, who trains the filly for Millard Waldheim, does not spare her at all in workouts.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 2 Named in Gambler's Death
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 16 (AP)  Two men, George H. Skokan Jr., 26 years old, of Niskayuna, and Jack Hill, 26, of Schenectady, today were charged with murder in last Saturday's killing of Richard J. DeLoreto of Schenectady, convicted gambler, the police said. Mr. DeLoreto's body was found in an automobile in nearby Rotterdam. He had been shot three times in the face, the police said.

title: NO DANGERS YET SEEN IN OIL PINCH
description: PARIS, Nov. 16Officials from member governments of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development expressed the belief today, that industrial activity could be protected from oil shortages by cutbacks in nonessential uses of oil and the drawing down of existing stockpiles.

title: CHADBOURN LOSS WIDENS IN YEAR
description: Chadbourn, Inc., which suffered from declines throughout the hosiery industry, reported yesterday a loss of $6.8million in the fiscal year ended July 28. This was made up of a $1million loss from continuing operations and a $5.7million loss from discontinued operations including its ladies' hosiery and pantyhose division and a small carpet operation.

title: For 200, City Is High School Without Walls
description: Changing classes in high school is usually no more difficult than walking across the hall or up and down a staircase. But for approximately 200 students, going from class to class means a bus, subway or, even ferry ride beCause, in a sense, their school is New York City.

title: When Jimmy Slipped Away
description: Jimmy was up in a chair today, the other nurse told me after he died. We sat him in the hall, and he couldn't talk, of course, because of the tracheotomy, but he knew where he was, and God, he was just beginning to write. Here's the last thing he wrote.

title: GOVERNOR SCOFFS AT SAMUELS POLL
description: Governor Rockefeller yesterday dismissed Democratic polls and predictions that he could not win reelection by noting that such things had been said three or four times in the past and it never happened.

title: TV Review
description: Last evening's hourlong special with Sammy Davis Jr., over the National Broadcasting Company, was a nice surprise. Even the program's timing seemed propitious, after the network's cancellation of N.B.C. Follies, a Davis showcase.

title: Strike Watch
description: A report on current labor negotiations in the arts.

title: Paddy Smithwick Is Dead at 46; 5Time Steeplechase Champion
description: A.P. (Paddy) Smithwick, retired champion steeplechase jockey, died Wednesday night in Baltimore after a long illness. He was 46 years old.

title: Representative Planning to Seek Reelection
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm declared yesterday that it was her definite intention to run for reelection to her seat in Congress next year.

title: Outside the Yale Bowl It's Bullish on Giants
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16When the crowd at Giant football games in Yale Bowl chants Goodbye Alex, there is no echo for total withdrawal in New Haven's business community. The Chamber of Commerce wants to keep the Giants here beyond next year.

title: Aussies Tied, 11, In Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 16 (AP)  Czechoslovakia, surprisingly tied Australia, 11, today in the opening singles matches of their semifinal round of the Davis Cup competition at Kooyang Stadium.

title: Meany Says Teamsters Renege On a Farm Labor Peace Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) George Meany accused the Teamsters union today of reneging on a farmlabor peace agreement with the A.F.L.C.I.O. and threatened to retaliate with a nationwide boycott of some California agricultural products.

title: C.I.A. DENIES IT HAD WATERGATE PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Central Intelligence Agency officials denied to Congress today a report in the current issue of Harper's magazine that the agency had advance knowledge of the Watergate breakin last year.

title: Arriving at Democratization and Detente
description: MOSCOWIt is certain that among the widest masses of our people and the intelligentsia, dissatisfaction and discontent not only exist but are also growing over many aspects of our reality, as well as over the inadequately slow pace of economic, social and cultural progress, over the centralized and bureaucratic management system and over mismanagement, over the lack of information, and over our lagging behind Western countries in many. respects.

title: Kennedy Son to Undergo Amputation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 12yearold son, Edward M. Jr., is scheduled to have his right's leg amputated above the knee tomorrow in an effort to halt bone cancer.

title: Bids on Oil and Gas Leases Invited for Gulf of Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, announced today that 147 tracts covering 817,000 acres in the Gulf of Mexico off Mississippi, Alabama and Florida would be offered in an oil and gas lease sale next month. The tracts will be the first offshore areas opened for oil and gas drilling off any states other than Louisiana, Texas and California.

title: Antiques: Eastlake Style
description: YONKERSAs recently as a decade ago, the machinemade furniture of the Eastlake eracarved and embellished to the tastes of robber barons  was disregarled or openly disparaged.

title: Spurs to European Unity: Mideast War and Strains in Atlantic Ties
description: PARIS, Nov. 16The shock of the Middle Eastern crisis and strained Atlantic relations have given Western European governments a firm new impulse toward their longreceding goal of developing some political unity.

title: MRS. EUGENE C. SLAKE
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 16Valina Gillespie Blake, wife of Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, former president of the National Council of Churches and former general secretary of the World Council of Churches, died yesterday at her home, 256 Country Club Road, after a long illness.

title: Skylab 3 Commander, a Patient Astronaut
description: Before he went aloft on his first space flight for eight or more weeks as the commander of the Skylab 3 crew, Gerald Paul Carr, a closecropped lieutenant colonel in the Marine Corps, said exuberantly, I'm looking forward most to sticking my nose up against the wardroom window and watching earth go by. The 41yearold pilot had to be patient in waiting for this view, which sweeps by the round window of the orbiting workshop 16 times a day. Colonel Carr has been an astronaut for seven years, during which 11, of the 18 pilots selected with him as astronauts in April, 1966, have already flown in space.

title: Lebanese Report a Brief Foray By Israelis Across the Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 16An Israel armored force pushed briefly into Lebanese territory this morning, but pulled back when it came under artillery fire, the Lebanese Defense Ministry reported.

title: JOB DRIVE BACKED BY FLEWS CHIEF
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that his department's drive for equal employment in higher education did not compel universities to set quotas.

title: TEACHER UNIT SCORES STATE EVALUATION
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 (AP)The New Jersey State College Faculty Association charged today that the State Department of Higher Education was exceeding its legal bounds in drawing up evaluation procedures for college faculty members.

title: RCA Makes Offer for Oriel Roods
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it had made an offer to acquire Oriel Foods, Ltd., a major British food wholesaler and distributor of edible oils, for the equivalent of $26million in cash. The offer is subject to approval of definite arrangements by the RCA board and appropriate British Government agencies.

title: Mercedes Recall 3,626 Cars
description: MONTVALE, N. J., Nov. 16 (UPI)  MercedesBenz announc today that it is recalling 3,626 of its 1973 model 450SE and 450SEL cars because of a possible defect in the right frontwheel brake linings.

title: Visual Arts Gallery Promises Much
description: The portentous title of the exhibition, Some Things They Never Told You About the 1940's, 1950's and 1960's, now on view at the Visual Arts Gallery, 209 East 23d Street, promises a good deal more than it delivers. Organized by Thomas B. Hess, art critic for New York magazine, the show actually features a small number of works of painting, sculpture and collage by such artists as Phillip Pavia, Julian Beck, the late Landes Lewitin and the late Frederick Kiesler.

title: Books of The Times
description: CECIL B. DE MILLE. By Charles Higham. Illustrated. 335 pages. Scribners. $10. GWTW: THE MAKING OF GONE WITH THE WIND. By Gavin Lambert. Illustrated. 238 pages. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $7.95. PIECES OF TIME. By Peter Bogdanovich. 269 pages. Arbor House/Esquire. $7.95.

title: Notes on People
description: George Bush, the Republican National Chairman, says he won't be running for governor of Texas next year. Mr. Bush, who has been under pressure from some elements of the Texas G.O.P. to make the race, said, I have made a final decision. But he took pains to counter speculation that his decision was based in part on dim Republican prospects as a result of the Watergate scandal. The Republicans can win that election in 1974, he said. Mr. Bush admitted the prospect of being Governor carried enormous appeal. But, he said, our political system is under fire, and I have an enormous sense of responsibility that compels me to remain in job.

title: Paris Is Paris Again As Shops, Cafes Open
description: PARIS, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  French shopkeepers reopened for business today after a nationwide 24hour shutdown that seriously disrupted normal life in the cities and deprived many people of food for the day.

title: For 200, City Is High School Without Walls
description: Changing classes in high school is usually no more difficult than walking across the hall or up and down a staircase. But for approximately 200 students, going from class to class means a bus, subway or even ferry ride because, in a sense, their school is New York City.

title: Ballet: Pennsylvanians
description: During intermission at the opening of the Pennsylvania Ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Thursday night, avoice was overheard to say, I didn't tink it would be so good.

title: Kissinger Back
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington today and planned to give top priority to working out the final details for the stare of a Middie East peace conference that he hopes can be convened next month.

title: DR. ORDWAY TEAD EDUCATOR, 82, DIES
description: Dr. Ordway Tead, who served for 15 years as chairman of the Board of Higher Education here, died Thursday evening at Norwalk Hospital, Conn., of a heart attack. An educator, editor, publishing executive and prolific author, Dr. Tead was 82 years old and lived in Westport.

title: SURPLUS IS SEEN FOR ROLLSROYCE
description: LONDON, Nov. 16RollsRoyce, Ltd., the bankrupt shell that once housed the world's most revered names in automobiles and aircraft engines, may still be worth a considerable sum to its remaining stockholders.

title: President Signs Measure To Allow Alaska Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  President Nixon signed the Alaska pipeline bill today and hailed it as a first step toward making the United States wholly selfsufficient for its energy supplies by 1980. An official of the Department of the Interior expressed confidence that the law authorizing the 789mile pipeline from Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's North Slope to the warm water port of Valdez would survive any challenge in court.

title: COPPER FUTURES HIGHER AT CLOSE
description: Copper futures for January delivery closed yesterday on the Commodity Exchange at 94.90 cents a pound, up from 94.50 on Thursday.

title: Art: Francis Haden Revisited
description: You could have knocked me over with a stylus, but I found the exhibition of etchings by Sir Francis Seymour Haden at the AAA galleries, 663 Fifth Avenue, refreshing.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1973

title: Mideast Truce Going More Smoothly
description: CAIRO, Nov. 16In contrast with the tension earlier this week, measures for carrying out the first stage of Egypt's ceasefire with Israel proceeded smoothly today.

title: Queens Truck Driver Held In Slaying of Police Officer
description: A 37yearold Queens truck driver was arrested last night and charged with the slaying of an offduty police officer during the robbery of a Bronx tavern Oct. 10, the police reported.

title: 15 Policemen Keep Money Lost in Test
description: In a Police Department experiment this fall in which 51 patrolmen were handed lost wallets containing $20 or more by strangers, and were asked to turn them in, 15 officers apparently kept the money without making a report.

title: Packwood Forthright to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16When Bob Packwood, a 41yearold firstterm Republican Senator from Oregon, went to the White House last. night to talk to President Nixon about the Watergate case, he was thoroughly prepared.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It has been seriously argued that for the sake of American foreign policy, specifically the military support of Israel, the suggested impeachment of Richard Nixon should be temporarily, if not permanently; suspended. The choice appears agonizing: the continued existence of Israel versus the continued existence of constitutional government in America. But is this a real dilemma?

title: Veteran Pension Rise Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 ((UPI)The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a 10 per cent increase in pension benefits for lowincome war veterans who became permanently disabled from nonservice  connected causes, The measure passed on a voice vote.

title: NIXON IS HOPEFUL OIL BAN WILL END
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16President Nixon expressed hope today that what he called the real progress in the Middle East might lead to a lifting of the Arab embargo on oil shipments to the United States.

title: Dave Anderson
description: His cold sniper's eyes almost disappeared between narrow lids. Charles O. Finley was in Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office yesterday to appeal fines totaling $7,000 and probation for his conduct during the World Series, notably the exile of Mike Andrews, a second baseman who made the mistake of making two errors. But the Oakland A's owner wasn't wearing his green blazer. He had on a black pinstriped suit and a silver tie. Those are the colors of the Oakland Raiders, not the A's, who prefer green and gold. The proponent of the blackandsilver color scheme is Al Davis, the Raiders' major domo. Strange that Oakland should attract both Charles O. Finley and Davis, two of a kind. Each is a man of intrigue. Each is part tyrant, part rebel. Each appears putting others on the carpet, just as each appears to enjoy being on the carpet himself.

title: A Veteran Pilot With a Penchant for Math
description: Lieut. Col. William Reid Pogue of the Air Force has run hundreds of miles this year to lose 20 pounds and otherwise prepare himself for the weightless conditions of space in his Skylab 3 mission.

title: Reed Is Rated Possible To Face Bucks Tonight
description: Wayne Embry, the general manager of the Milwaukee Bucks, is a cautious man. Coming into Madison Square Garden tonight with the team that has the best record in the National Basketball Association, Embry Is skeptical about the Knicks being a weakened opponent because of some injury problems.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Screen: A Real Loser:Fassbinder's 'Merchant of Four Seasons' Here The Cast
description: It gets harder and harder to believe in victimsin people who do not precipitate what happens to them. But Rainer Fassbinder's "The Merchant of Four Seasons," which opened this week at the Greenwich Theater, projects a kind of loserism that the main character seems powerless to control.This German movie focuses on a stolid depressive (Hans Hirschmuller) whose middle-class family has always been ashamed of him, and its lack of enthusiasm appears to be the main cause of his breakdown and eventual suicide. They are also disgusted by his career of selling fruit in the streets, rather as though he were pimping.Because of turgid directing and acting, most of the emotions in this picture ring false. When the hero's wife phones her lawyer for a divorce, her husband has the unlikeliest heart attack in movie history. And when he finally drinks himself to death in front of his relatives, they watch and gape like paralyzed puddings until his scene is played outor like obedient actors who know that they must not interrupt the star.Fassbinder's fiercest weakness is the way that his characters respond to one another. He also specializes in delayed reactions. Throughout, eyes lock in significant glances or in prolonged, stunned stares. A man slaps a woman; she gasps and grabs her cheek, then both of them freeze. A wife learns that her husband is getting drunk in a bar, and she clutches the telephone receiver to her chest to show distress. Two long separated friends meet in a cafeteria: One drops a tray of food (astonishment). And there is a maddening moment when the fruit vendor yells down the stairs for his wife, and then weepswhich is simply a crude crib from Brando in "Streetcar.""The Merchant," which was shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center in 1972, is not so bad as Fassbinder's "The Bitter Fears of Petra Von Kant," one of the silliest movies I have seen in years. But here it looks as though the director was torn between chronicling a crackup and making a film about how to run a small business. The problems of hiring a reliable staff and the proprieties of bookkeeping take up a good deal of footage, and that is boring. But this soggy picture allows the disintegration of a human being to be almost as dull as the way he earns his livingand that is appalling.

title: Minimum Stock Value Is Urged For Planned Northeast Railway
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16A trustee of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad urged the Senate today to set a minimum value on the stock to be issued by the proposed Northeast Rail Corporatign.

title: Governor Says Rise in Tolls Could Aid Mass Transit
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that doubling the tolls on bridges and tunnels operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey could be one way of financing masstransit projects.

title: Coast Airline Struck
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (Reuters)About 1,000. employes of California's major commuter airline, Pacific Southwest Airlines, walked off their jobs here today as teamsters union members began a strike for higher wages and benefits.

title: Celtics End Buck String; Nets Beaten
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)Dave Cowens scored 14 points in the fourth period to help the Boston Celtics defeat the Milwaukee Bucks, 10590, tonight in a National Basketball Association game. snapping Milwaukee's 13game winning streak.

title: Still a Mystery
description: A smog of rumor and suspicion still clouds the question of President Nixon's finances. In the unhealthy atmosphere left by Watergate, full financial disclosure is an essential in restoring public trust in the nation's elected leadership. The conviction of Spiro Agnew on single count of incometax evasion underscores the necessity of such disclosures.

title: $15.9Million More Is Voted for the Stadium Project
description: The Board of Estimate, by a vote of 14 to 8, reluctantly approved an additional $15.9million yesterday for the renovation of Yankee Stadium.

title: Peter Max Party Recaptures 60's
description: Shades of the frivolous, freaky sixties. It was all there the other nightthe farout clothes, the frantic frugging (as they used to call it) to discothque music, the mob of chic New Yorkers jampacked together and sweating on each other.

title: Agency Sees Apparent Violations in Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The General Accounting Office has recommended that the Justice Department take legal acSin for the alleged mishandling of funds In Representative Shirley Chisholm's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Stage: Folksbiene Gives Aleichem's Stempenyu
description: What beats one fine production of Sholom Aleichem in a New York Yiddish theater season? To answer a question with a quesiton: how about two? And that's what we have with the opening on Wednesday of Stempenyu by the versatile Folksbiene Playhouse in the Central Synagogue's commodious auditorium at 123 East 55th Street.

title: G.M.'s Saginaw Gear Unit To Build Plant in Alabama
description: SAGINAW, Mich., Nov. 16Vhe Saginaw Steering Gear division of the General Motors Corporation, with seven plants in the Saginaw area, announced today plans for an eighth plant, to be built t Dectur, Ala. The new plant, which will he about 500,000 square feet and employ about 750 workers, is the first for the division outside the midMichigan area.

title: About the Jets:
description: After watching Joe Namath work in Shea Stadium's wind yesterday, Coach Weeb Ewbank said he still didn't know whether the Jet quarterback would start and that he would wait until after today's workout in Cincinnati to make up his mind. Ewbank doesn't have to announce his decision until an hour before game time tomorrow... Al Woodall, meanwhile appears to have a healthy elbow again and could start if Namath doesn't.... John Elliott, who missed the New England game with an ailing knee, will return to the defensive line, but Ed Galigher may missing from it with a bad knee.... Rob Spicer will start at outside linebacker with a small cast on his cracked thumb. Still missing is Al Atkinson, whose pulled thigh muscle prevents him from making quick lateral movements effectively.... The Bengals will be without Tom Casanova, a safety, who has a pulled hamstring.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: DATA ON ECONOMY SHOW SLOWDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Statistics covering four different major aspects of the economy disclosed today a pattern of slowdown.

title: TELEPHONE RATES INCREASED 15.4%
description: A $304million gross increase ratesabout 15.4 per centauthorized yesterday for the New York Telephone Company by the State Public Service Commission, While the company is to submit a detailed statewide rate schedule for approval, that percentage would mean an increase of $2.14 in the average monthly residence bill in New York City, which the company said has been $13.90 before Federal and state taxes.

title: Argentina and Uruguay End A 100Year River Dispute
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 (AP) Argentina and Uruguay announced yesterday that they had solved a centuryold dispute over the Rio de la Plata estuary.

title: The World Could Be Outfitted With Pruning Hooks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.  Once again the General Assembly is debating arms control and the reduction of military expendituresthe biblical injunction of Isaiah to turn spears into pruning hooksat a moment in modern history when nation has lifted sword against nation. The superpowers in recent days have observed their sophisticated weapons tested in the sands and over the skies of Sinai; blood has flowed on both sides of the Suez Canal. Whether hot war, cold war or detente, the military budgets spiral upward.

title: City Officials Praise New Narcotics Laws
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16The State League of Municipalities praised New York's tough narcotics laws today and urged New Jersey to enact similar ones.

title: Solutions to last week's Topical and DoubleCrostic Puzzles
description: ARTHUR HERZOG: THE B.S. FACTORA Poll Fact becomes a fact by having appeared in print, as when a magazine palms off a poll to show that it has a higher passaround factor than its competitors; politicians produce Poll Facts to prove the public likes them best.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ALMOST overlooked in the welter of momentous news developments recently has been the rising militancy of labor wage negotiations. A relatively quiet and agreeable year on the labor front is turning into a rather tense one in the waning months of 1973, posing a worrisome threat for next year, when a fairly large number of contract renewals come up in several key industries.

title: Clarkstown North Wins Finale, 290
description: Clarkstown North, the 1973 Rockland County champion, finished its season undefeated yesterday by trouncing secondplace Suffern, 290.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Since the country is probably beyond shock by this time, there can be no harm in telling the truth at last about the first Thanksgiving Day.

title: It's Happening Successfully, Right There in Iowa City, Iowa
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa is one of the small towns, U.S.A., a nice place to live. Project GREEN happens there and because the project's success is so secure, its story needs telling.

title: Chronicle of a pogrom The Oath By Elie Wiesel. Translated from the French by Marion Wiesel. 283 pp. New York: Random House. $7.95.
description: When I was six my mother told me the story of a, pogrom. It happened, she told me, when she was exactly my age and lived in Russia. She told me how the neighboring Christians had crashed drunkenly through the village on their Easter crusade. I thought it was a pretty good story. There were enough picturesque details to interest a kidmy small mother hidden on top of stove, galloping Cossacks and running Jews, doors smashed in, women grabbed and shrieking, men crucified with knives against a fence. At six I took this in calmly, as one more Grimm story to ponder.

title: The Food of the Gods Puts Samos on the Map
description: YOU know manita? Mr. Horiatopoulos asks us. He is the tourist rest information agent on the Greek Island of Samos.

title: For Benjamin Rubin, Front and Center
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK More than 800 people are expected to turn out on Dec. 4 for a testimonial dinner honoring 65yearold Benjamin Rubin, one of central Jersey's most popular and colorful residents.

title: Lehigh Wallops Lafayette, 4513, For 7th Success
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 17  Lehigh University rated No. 1 in the Lambert Cup standing, routed Lafayette today, 45.13.

title: News of the Stage
description: Eugene O'Neill's last play, A Moon for the Misbegotten, costarring Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst, will be revived on Broadway this season for a limited run.

title: Wolverines Win, 349
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 17 (AP)Dennis Franklin, a quarterback, scored two touchdowns and passed for a third today in pacing unbeaten Michigan to a 349 victory over Purdue in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: End of Giant Loss String Seen in the Cards Today
What's Doing in PHILADENPHIA
description: NIGHT LIFE  William, Claude (Whitey) Dukinfield, whose aver. sion to his home town was probably traceable to the fact that he spent his formative years here being chased by cops and irate saloon keepers, did not do Philadelphia any good in later years when, after adopting the name W. C. Fields, be was wont to say that Philadelphia was the only town of his acquaintance that closed on Sundays. The master, alas, is gone, but his assessment unfortunately lingers. Even love in Philadelphia is brotherly. Nevertheless, for those disposed to see what there is of night life here, there is a Vegasstyle glitter at the nearby Latin Casino (215WA 34343) across the Delaware River in Cherry Hill, N.J. The nightly features are the food, the drinks and the likes of Tom Jones and Ray Charles. Considerably hipper is The Spectrum (FU 95000) at Broad and Pattison, right in Philadelphia, a sports hall that books groups like the J. Geils Band for dance concerts. Prices along the nightclub circuit are gradually inching up on those in New York, It is advisable to phone first for covers and minimums. Palumbo's (MA 7.7272) in South Philadelphia, Mayor Frank Rizzo's favorite boite, is big, noisy and serves Sergio Franchi with the spaghetti and scungilli. On the other hand, since Frank Rizzo is the guy who vetoed the purchase for the city of a Jacques Lipchitz statue, dubbing it an abortion that looks like some workmen dropped a load of wet plaster, those with more worldly sensibilities might prefer a place in which, His Honor would not be caught dead  Harlow's (WA 29222), named for a former male, whose sexchange operation made her the switch hit of the city, or if not Harlow's then one of the other trendy clubs nearby. Longhairs and kindred types will feel more at home in the downtown Sansom Village area at places like Artemis (LO 79958), Oops (LO 76800) and Snagletooth (LO 78304), where the sounds are, as they say, heavy. Older heads will like Just Jazz (LO 73189), on downtown Arch Street, where you might hear the MJQ or Jimmy Smith. The Parson's Table (WA 54447) has decent food downstairs, contemporary sound upstairs. Nothing you like? Pick up Philadelphia Magazine's Guide to Philadelphia. At $2.95, it knows all and Philadelphia.

title: The Bankers Intrude on Wall St.
description: The banks and the brokers are spoiling for a fight.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey; daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Auto Workers
description: DETROITWhen Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers union, was asked at a press conference last week to evaluate the feelings of the skilled trades workers in the U.A.W. he replied: I'm not a psychiatrist. I'm just a collective bargainer.

title: N. J. Stadium
description: TRENTON  How much are the New York Giants, a football team that has lost its last seven games, worth to either New Jersey or New York? If the extraordinary pressures being generated by the Governors of the two states are any indication, the Giants apparently are worth anything it takes, in Trenton's view, to get them to move to New Jersey, or, in Albany? view, to keep them in New York.

title: The Region
description: A man's home may be his castle but in the feifdoms of the region, the castle is encrusted with special taxes that often turn it into a keep under seige. What is particularly frustrating to suburban homeowners is not only the seemingly endless increase in their property taxes, but the seemingly indiscriminate and random nature of the way they are levied.

title: Strike Called in Calcutta
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 17 (UPI) The Communist Party of India called a general strike for today in Calcutta to protest rising prices. Several persons have been injured and about 1,000 arrested during the week in violent demonstrations.

title: Mrs. DeMarco Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hees DeMarco of New York on Oct. 29 in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. DeMarco is the former Miss Diana Zwirn of Moravia, N. Y. The child has been named Jonathan Zwirn. He is a grandson of Dr. Roland R. DeMarco, president emeritus of Finch College. The infant's father is a senior systems engineer with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Mortgage Fund Trial Proceeding Slowly, but Proceeding
description: Last Monday, one of the jurors in Federal courtroom No. 9 in Brooklyn fell asleep during a long testimony by Government witness.

title: U.S & China
description: WASHINGTON  it was Henry Kissinger's sixth trip to China. Its goal, the Secretary of State said on his first day in Peking a week ago, was to complete the process of normalizing relations between the two countries as rapidly as possible.

title: Too Many Howes, Financial Ultimatum Bedevil Blades
description: Gordie Howe returned to halfempty Madison Square Garden yesterday, a diamond plucked from Tiffany's window and put in a bargain basement.

title: Ira Hershkowitz to Wed Gayle Geltman
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 17Judge and Mrs. Morris Aarons have made known the engagement of Mrs. Aarons's daughter, Miss Gayle Harriet Geltman, to Ira Paul Hershkowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Hershkowitz of Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Father and Son Seized in Arson Death
description: A Queens father and son were arrested yesterday on charges of murder, arson and conspiracy in connection with an explosion last March 15 that destroyed a twostory building they owned. One man was killed in the blast.

title: VOTING AUDITORS IN THE LIMELIGHT
description: The Honest Ballot Association, which has refereed thousands of elections in the last 60 years, came under considerable public scrutiny itself last week in the aftermath of the disputed firemen's strike vote and the destruction of the controversial ballots.

title: Nixon Confirms Ordering Tap Put on His Brother's Telephone
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17President Nixon confirmed tonight that he had ordered a tap put on his brother's telephone. As he has on other delicate matters in the last year, the President said it was for security reasons and I will not go beyond that.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: The Region: Dirtier Air, Slower Speeds
description: While Washington officials tried to look ahead to discern the dimensions of the fuel shortage, down on the ground, state and local officials were acting on the premise that the problem is already here and likely to get worse. In New York and New Jersey, speed limits were ordered down to 50 miles an hour; in Connecticut, the Governor requested the public to reduce its speed; and throughout the region a variety of emergency steps were taken:

title: Pitt Routs Army, Will Go to Bowl
description: WEST POINT, N.Y. Nov. 17Pittsburgh's rejuvenated football team easily defeated Army, 340, at Michie Stadium today and then, to the surprise of no one, accepted a bid to play in the third Fiesta Bowl game Dec. 21 in Phoenix, Ariz.

title: The Middle East
description: WASHINGTONA sage said about the Middle East that it is a riddle within a sphinx within a pastrami sandwich. Another wise man is known to have reduced this aphorism over the years to a simple prediction: The ArabIsraeli conflict is unsolvable. Now, as Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger is setting out to prove himself a false prophet.

title: Firemen The Strike Vote That Wasn't
description: It was an unprecedented incident in an unprecedented strike. Just when things appeared to be settling down last week after New York firemen staged a five and a half hour walkout on Nov. 6, the first in the city's history, law enforcement sources revealed Friday that the firemen had actually voted against a strike.

title: Wife of a Ford Asks Divorce
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17 (UPI)The wife of Walter Bunl Ford 3d, the greatgrandson of Henry Ford, filed suit for divorce yesterday in Wayne County Court. She is seven months pregnant with the couple's fourth child.

title: RIZZO REJECTED BY PARTY LEADERS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, seriously hurt by the Democratic sweep of the elections here earlier this month, finds himself a man without a party today.

title: Nontenured Members of Faculty Get 5Year Job Plan at Vassar
description: Nontenured faculty members at Vassar College will be guaranteed employment for at least five years under the terms of controversial new contract recently drawn up by the college.

title: Rewards Spur the Nonverbal
description: MARLBORO  We were interested in doing something for those kids. They were the only kids at Marlboro that had no form of education there.

title: Guessing Santa's Mood
description: Rarely during the year do so few days mean so much to so many retailers.

title: Mob Figure to Lose Home
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 17 (AP) The deposed Mafia chieftain Joseph Bonanno will have to move again. The city has announced that his home is among 15 to be acquired for a streetwidening project. Officials said the houses would be acquired by condemnation if the owners refused offers based on appraisals.

title: Fordham Prep Falls In Jesuit Meet
description: Fordham Prep was edged by McQuaid High School of Rochester yesterday in the Jesuit Brothers scholastic crosscountry championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Roslyn Braeman Fiancee of Lisle Payne
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 17Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Braeman have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Roslyn Fay Braeman of New York, to Lisle Warren Payne of Palo Alto, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lisle D. Payne of Des Moines, Iowa.

title: Best Seller List
description: GENERAL

title: BILL ON PIPELINE HAILED IN ALASKA
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 17.Alaskans are ready and sager to build the 789mile oil pipeline from Prudhoe Bay to Valdez planned by the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company.

title: Head of Associated Press Says Internal Fights Threaten Media
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 17 (AP)Wes Gallagher, president and general manager of The Associated Press, said today that quarrelsome struggles within journalism and not Government attacks might represent the greatest threat to a free press.

title: Murrays vs. McDonnells Real Lace America's Irish Rich. By Stephen Birmingham. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.
description: The American Irish Catholic rich are, here we go again, different from you and me. They are also, presumably, sufficiently different from the American Protestant rich (The Right People) and New York's Jewish rich (Our Crowd) to justify yet another Stephen Birmingham social history, Real Lace.

title: Editor to Wed Mrs. Seebohm
description: Lord and Lady Seebohm of London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Caroline Seebohm of New York, to Walter H. Lippincott Jr., an editor at Harper & Row, publishers here. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lippincott of Haverford, Pa.

title: Miss Malamed Bride
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I., Nov. 17 Miss Margery Joan Malamed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Malamed of Great Neck, was married this evening to Mark SandersGermain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Germain of White Plains. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Glen Head Country Club. The bride's father is executive vice presidentadministration of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc.

title: A School Without Degrees
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.A fading sign still points the way to the Fishcove Inn, but the collection of fake logcabin bungalows is now given over to the Lindsfarne Association, a combination of college, weekend retreat for cityshocked seekers, cosmic bullsession and just possibly a very important new departure in American educational culture.

title: Confessions at Age 7
description: WASHINGTON  In his autobiographical novel The Last Catholic in America John R. Powers recalls his horror when, as a secondgrader, he discovered that he had misrepresented during his first communion the number of times he had disobeyed his parents.

title: Yardsticks
description: The bond market has often been viewed as a safe, stodgy place populated by unimaginative, patient investors whose principal tool was a pair of scissors for clipping coupons.

title: Real Estate Game
description: If I were a better golfer I might be more interested in that game. But, for me, real estate is the best game around  and when you're ahead in a game you like to keep playing.

title: For The Long Goodbye, A Warm Hello
description: IF The Long Goodbye, Robert Altman's updated film version of Raymond Chandler's 1953 novel, turns out to be a national boxoffice success following its hit engagement at the TransLux East Theater here, those of us who are the film's partisans should be glad for Altman, its director, Leigh Brackett, who wrote the screenplay, and for Elliott Gould, its star who hasn't had hit in time.

title: Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Rutgers to Get Pubs Soon
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Rutgers University Student Centers are counting on the establishment of beer and wine pubs to bail them out of serious financial difficulties.

title: A G.O.P. Responsibility
description: Although political parties are nowhere mentioned in the written Constitution, the twoparty sysem has become a major stabilizing influence in the nation's conduct of constitutional government.

title: Vietnam G.I. Bill in 7 Years Assists Record Numbers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) The number of veterans receiving college level benefits under the Vietnam G.I. bill has already exceeded the number trained in the 12year World War II program, the Veterans Administration reported today.

title: Ethiopia Says Famine Was Covered Up
description: DESSYE, Ethiopia, Nov. 11 The Ethiopian Government says that for months it was kept in ignorance of the gravity of drought and famine in a remote northern province, and it has ordered an inquiry into the disaster.

title: Bridge
description: If you want to make your partner believe that your mind has become completely unhinged, try discarding a trump in the middle of the play. For example, the declarer on your right is about to ruff in the dummy and you cannot follow suit. Instead of discarding from a considerable collection of plain suit cards, you put a baby trump on the table which the declarer gloatingly overruffs. Your partner is not allowed to comment, but he raises his eyebrows half way to the ceiling. The underruff he has seen before. But a preruff? What's that?

title: Towns Act to Curb Speeding
description: KENILWORTHThe scene is all too familiar: A Dre. chalant policeman steps out of his unmarked black car and waves down a radartrapped motorist who has been burning along at maybe 40 or 45 miles an hour in a residential area.

title: Home Luprovement
description: HUOMEOWNERS have always men interested in methods for lowering their fuel billsprimarily because this is one way to cut down on the high cost of maintaining a home. Nowadays, however, there is a special urgency in following a program of this kind, not only because fuel costs more than ever before but also because of the widely publicized energy crisis in many parts of the nation. Thus, cutting down on the amount of fuel consumed is not only an economy measure, it is also a civic responsibility in which all citizens are asked to cooperate and it may in some cases spell the difference between having enough fuel for the coming winter and running out at a critical time.

title: Opera Goes to Church
description: IT TAKES just as much artistry to create a beautiful small etching as it does to cover a wall with a majestic mural. So when Nathaniel Merrill turned to directing Benjamin Britten's one  hour musical parables in a small church right after deploying hundreds of people on the Metropolitan Opera stage in Berlioz's fivehour Troyens, the contrast was not as amusing as it might have seemed at first. The Britten works, Curlew River, The Burning Fiery Furnace and The Prodigal Son, will each be given three times between Nov. 28 and Dec. 19 at St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, presented by Concert Artists Guild with the cosponsorship of the Carnegie Hall Corporation and the assistance of several music school.

title: L.I. Builder Killed At Home in an Area Of Recent BreakIns
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, LI., Nov. 17A 38yearold building contractor was found shot dead outside his home last night shortly after he responded to a caller who had rung his frontdoor bell:

title: PRESIDENT IS BRIEFED BY KISSINGER ON TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (Reuters)Secretary of State Kissinger today briefed Presdent Nixon and defense and intelligence chiefs on his 12day tour of the Middle East and China.

title: Railroad Car Retired
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP)  A railroad car used by President Eisenhower in his 1952 campaign made its last run Thursday and was retired to become part of a restaurant ate Forts Washington.

title: An Englishman's Week
description: LONDONThe wedding is over and the couple are off on their honeymoon, but the question is whether Britain herself will live happily ever after.

title: Energy: Iowa Town Mutes Its Carillon to Save on Fuel
description: JEFFERSON, Iowa, Nov. 17 There was a strange silence over this town's central square yesterday and an unusual dimness at dusk.

title: Diagramless, 21 by 21
description: ACROSS

title: Mrs. Constance Thiesing Married
description: Mrs. Constance Myles Thiesing and Waldemar J. Dittmar, a partner in the law firm of Arenson, Gelinas, Dittmar & Karban, attorneys for the Public Administrator of New York County, and a member of the board of trustees of the Consular Law Society, were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Luke's Hospital Center. The Rev. Carleton J. Sweetser, chaplain of St. Luke's, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Moon Crater Renamed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) Macrobius A, a large bright crater on the near side of the moon, has been renamed in honor of the late Dr. Leonard Carmichael, a former secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, it was announced today.

title: Integrated Dance For the Inner City
description: Donald McKayle, a black choreographer who moved from his native New York to Los Angeles four years ago, has been spending a lot of time in his home town these days.

title: Thanksgiving Meal at Gallups Rates High in Family Poll
description: PRINCETON  In the opinion of the Gallup family, their mother's cooking is favored 100 per cent by every member.

title: Love and death and points in between
description: This young Mississippian's first novel, Geronimo Rex, was published last year to general, if tempered, praise; it is a crazy and messy piece of work which unravels in the end, but it has admirable energy, exuberant humor and a genuine feel for what it is like to grow up in the contemporary South. But Nightwatchmen is another matter altogether; it is simply a mess.

title: Texas Wins; Leaks Runs To Record
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 17 (UPI)  Roosevelt Leaks, a junior fullback, smashed the Southwest Conference season rushing record and Marty Akins, quarterback, accounted for three touchdowns today as Texas routed Texas Christian University, 527, and earned the host spot in the Cotton Bowl for the sixth straight year. Nebraska will be the opponent.

title: When Taj Comes On, You Get the o00000ooh
description: SAN FRANCISCO. AT the Boarding House in San Francisco one recent Saturday night, the theater upstairs was packed to capacity and the shows were running late, very late. By the time country blues singer Taj Mahal came onstage for the third show it was nearly 3 A.M., and the management had long ago stopped serving drinks, but the number of diehard fans who had stayed was surprisingly large.

title: Dr. Abraham Kotsuji Dead; Hebraist Scholar and Writer
description: Dr. Abraham Kotsuji, the Japanese Hebraist who was credited with having saved many Jewish refugees in World War II and later turned to Judaism himself, died on Oct. 31 in Kamakura, Japan, friends in New York reported this weekend. He was 74 years old.

title: Numismatics
description: CANADA's massive 1976 Olympic commemorative sterling silver coin issue is now ready to go. The only thing holding it up was an official decision on prices, and that obstacle was cleared away last week. The first fourcoin issue (there will be seven separate issues) will cost $70 for proofs and $50 for uncirculated coins (add $2.50 for shipping and insurance). The ordering address is:

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market took a beating last week in very active trading, although a rally on Friday managed to reduce the size of the earlier losses.

title: Williams Wins Title By 3014
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 17  Williams defeated Amherst, 30 to 14 today to win the Little Three title. It was the second year in a row that Williams defeated an unbeaten Amherst team in the final game. In the second quarter Dick Klonoski of Amherst recovered a fumble on the Williams 17. Two plays later Jeff Osborn hit Freddie Scott, a split end, in the end zone for Amherst's first touchdown Osborn's kick was wide.

title: Democrats Appoint Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) Donna Kay Smith, administrative assistant to Gov. Wendell Ford of Kentucky, has been named executive director of the Democratic Governors Conference, effective Jan. 1.

title: Which BestSeller Shall I Write?
description: TAKING a job in a Chinese restaurant isn't the only road open to a starving actor. If you don't want to go around smelling like peanut oil, you can write a dirty book. This minute, I am sitting here looking at an ad for a book by a lady named Raina Barrett. It is called First Your Money, Then Your Clothes. My Life and Oh! Calcutta! and the ad says, At 31 a suburban housewife, mother, schoolteacher. At 33, living with her lover in Greenwich Village and starring nude on the stage. The publisher describes the author as an exceptional woman who threw away her ordinary secure life to exchange it for the unsure existence of the actress, a sexual life of considerable variety, and a mature understanding that happiness is more than just getting what you think you want. Told with an honesty as compulsive as it is brutal.

title: Reed Paces 10093 Verdict
description: With Willis Reed back after a sevengame absence and playing one of his strongest games, the New York Knicks showed almost no weaknesses as they turned back the Milwaukee Bucks, the team with the best record of this National Basketball Association season, 10093, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Harborfields Surprised By Commack South, 70
description: Commack South, Suffolk's AA1 champion, used a bit of deception to record a 70 upset of previously unbeaten Harborfields yesterday in the AA conference championship game at Central Islip.

title: Future of Tract Stirs Tenafly
description: TENAFLY  In the protracted battle over the use of New Jersey's diminishing land resources, conservationists and housing proponents have frequently been the chief antagonists.

title: Dr. Gary A. Udis Marries Ann Lowy
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Nov. 17Miss Ann Lowy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman J. Lowy of Harrison, was married here this evening to Dr. Gary Alan Udis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Udis, of Melrose Park, Pa. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Brae Burn Country Club.

title: GOLDIN PROPOSES HOUSING SUBSIDY
description: The use of $100million or more from the New York City capital budget to subsidize private construction of lowincome and moderateincome housing, reducing the cost to tenants by as much as 50 per cent, has been proposed by a special task force commissioned by Controllerelect Harrison J. Goldin.

title: We Opened in Moscow, Then on to...
description: WELL, we're all safe and sound (except for Leningrad flu), all 68 of us in Washington's Arena Stage company, back from our Russian love affair. Seventeen simultaneously exhilarating and frustrating, exhausting and liberating, tearfilled and uproarious, mad, painful joyous days of being with Soviet theater artists, Soviet technicians and Soviet theater audiences. About par for theatrical love affairs. Nobody in our company defected, although now and then, impressed with the way theater over there was alive and cared for, a couple of us considered doing that. trical love affairs. Nobody in our company defected, although now and then, impressed with the way theater over there was alive and cared for, a couple of us considered doing that.

title: 80% IN POLL BACK WARPOWERS CURB
description: Four out of five Americans support in principle the new warpowers law enacted by Congress Nov. 7 over President Nixon's veto, the Gallup Poll organization said yesterday.

title: City Offers Proposals To Upgrade Rockaways
description: An 88page report on the Rockaways, released by Mayor Lindsay last week, calls for the cutback of 500 units of proposed housing in Arverne, construction of a major eastwest artery across the peninsula, rehabilitation of the eroded beachfront and weatherworn boardwalk and construction of facilities to meet the collegelevel needs of the community.

title: Wagner Defeats Gettysburg, 1410
description: Glen Galante, a freshman quarterback, guided Wagner College to a 1410 victory over Gettysburg College yesterday at Fischer Memorial Field, in Staten Island.

title: Sandra Procter Young Married to William J. Adams
description: DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 17In the Noroton Presbyterian Church this afternoon, Miss Sandra Procter Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Young of Darien, became the bride of William Joseph Adams of Ardmore, Pa. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Adams of Waltham, Mass.

title: Chess: With Mecking and Korchnoi There's a Cold War in Site
description: The quarterfinals in the series to determine who will challenge Bobby Fischer for the world championship are only eight weeks away. Tigran Petrosian will play Lajos Portisch in Minorca, Anatoly Karpov will play Lev Polugaevsky in Moscow and I will play Boris Spassky in San Juan. But, the site of the Viktor KorchnoiHenrique Mecking match is still undecided.

title: Move Recalls History of Police Building
description: As the Police Department removes the last of its equipment from the old headquarters at 240 Centre Street, it is leaving behind one of New York's most interesting civic buildings. The handsome structure sits on a wedgeshaped plot bounded by Grand, Centre and Broome Streets and Centre Market Place, blending with the smaller buildings all around like a European hotel de ville.

title: Carolyn Danisi Is Bride
description: Miss Carolyn Danisi, an assistant account executive with the Bernard Hodes advertising agency, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luca Danisi of Hartford, Conn., was married here yesterday morning to John P. Nanovic, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Nanovic of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the nondenominational ceremony in the chapel. The bridegroom is publicrelations manager with the Chemical Bank. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Mrs. Ogburn Is Remarried
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17Mrs. Anne Wotherspoon Ogburn of Greenwich and W. Ogden Ross of New Haven were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Sidney Lovett, chaplain emeritus (Protestant) of Yale University, performed the ceremony in Yale's Dwight Memorial Chapel.

title: Bowl Pairings
description: COTTON, Jan. 1 at Dallas  Nebraska (811) vs. Texas (72).

title: Joanna Quinton Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony M. Quinton of Oxford, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanna Quinton, to Francis Fitzherbert  Brockholes, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. FitzherbertBrockholes of Garstang, Lancashire, England. The future bride is a granddaughter of Mrs. Maurice Wegier of New York and the late Mr. Wegier. A June wedding in Oxford is planned.

title: Winter Doesn't Wait
description: Winter doesn't wait on the calendar. You need no almanac to recognize its coming. Like Indian summer, winter comes over the hill and down the valley quietly that all you hear is crisp leaves skittering or, figuratively, a few flakes nudging each other as they fall.

title: U.S. & Europe A Step Further From Unity
description: PARISThe Year of Europe proclaimed by the Nixon Administration has proven to be a painful irony.

title: Legislature Shelves Disputed Measures
description: TRENTON  Now that Democrats in the Legislature have refused to support any major bills that do not enjoy the endorsement of Gov.elect Brendan T. Byrne, the lameduck legislative session is expected to limp through its final two scheduled meetings without tackling any controversial measures.

title: Charity
description: Corporations are becoming less charitable these days.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Myriam Kova, Parisian singer who owns a team of professional bicycle racers, believes the way to success is through the men's stomachs: During nightly stopovers, my men will dine on meatballs cooked in lemon juice and olive oil. After such meals, they'll sleep as lightly as angels.

title: Are We Ignoring the Thumris?
description: THE charm of Indian classical music, and especially of the North Indian style as exemplified by Ravi Shankar and All Akbar Khan, has so dazzled western listeners in recent years that the rewarding subtleties of other forms of Indian music have often been ignored. The North Indian soloists have won their large and loyal followings with unprecedented virtuosity as well as with the sensuality and fire of their performances, but their virtual domination of the American market for Indian recordings has contributed to a narrow and onesided view of their country's musical traditions.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, who lost to the New York Knicks in the National Basketball Association final last season, come into town Tuesday for game at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. Earlier this month the Knicks defeated the Lakers in Los Angeles, 10691. On Saturday at 8 P.M. New York will face the Golden State Warriors, whose roster includes Oazzie Russell, a former Knick, and Rick Barry, who played with the Nets two years ago.

title: Coaches Hope Recruiting Changes the Face of Local College Basketball
description: College basketball coaches in the metropolitan area live with an eye on the past and hope for the future.

title: Susan Lamarine a Bride
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 17In the Wesleyan University Chapel here this afternoon Miss Susan Gay Lamarine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Lamarine of Meriden, was married to Sumner McCall Dommerich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley H. Dommerich of Old Greenwich.

title: Bruins Drub Wings, 80, As Esposito Scores 20th
description: BOSTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)The National Hockey League scoring leader, Phil Esposito, got his 20th goal of the season, a modern league record for 18 games, and the Boston goalie, Gilles Gilbert, posted his first shutout of the season tonight as the Bruins notched their fifth straight triumph, 80, over the Detroit Red Red Wings.

title: Blues Pin 40 Loss on Islanders
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 (UPI) Nick Harbaruk scored one goal and assisted on two others tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 4  0 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game.

title: William W. Early, 72, Dies; Director at Church Center
description: William Wallace Early Sr., who retired several years ago as director of information for the Episcopal Church Center in New York, died Friday in University Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Stamps
description: THE subjects of five commemorative stamps and one item of postal stationery coming out next year have been made known by the United States Postal Service. With the two commemoratives announced earlier, roughly onethird of the 1974 program has now been set.

title: Upset Knocks Larsen Out Of Filipino Chess Tourney
description: MANILA, Nov. 17 (AP)  A major upset today knocked Denmark's Bent Larsen out of the Marlboro International Chess Classic. That left Lubomir Kavalek of the United States tied for the lead with Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia after seven rounds.

title: Harrison, Rye, Pleasantville, Tuckahoe Win in Bowls
description: Harrison, Rye, Pleasantville, Tuckahoe and Roy C. Ketcham registered victories yesterday in State Section I postseason bowl games.

title: What's New at the Movies?
description: ROBIN HOOD, a Walt Disney animated feature, directed by Wolfgang Reitherman and written by Larry Clemmons, got 6 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Ann Guarino, News; Frances Herridge, Post; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Judith Crist, New York; Donald J. Mayerson, Cue), 3 mixed (Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Gene Shalit, NBC) and 1 negative (Joseph Gelmis, Newsday).

title: the travel'er world
description: WASHINGTON  On Oct. 15, Robert T. Murphy ended nearly 13 years of service as a mernber of the Civil Aeronautics Board, being replaced by another Democrat, Lee West, a state court judge from Ada, Okla. This maintained the board's political balanceno more than three of its five members may be of the same political party. The board is an independent agency created by and responsible to Congress but with its members appointed to sixyear terms by the President with the consent of the Senate.

title: Beyond the Airlines' Profit Horizon
description: Analysts are divided over what effect flight reductions caused by the fuel shortage will have on airline earnings.

title: Laurel Dexheimer Wed to Oleg Mashouri
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Nov. 17 Miss Laurel Ellen Dexheimer and Oleg Vadim Mashouri, son of Mr, and Mrs. Vadim Mashouri of Kensington, Md., were married here this afternoon in the United Methodist Church by the Rev. Nishan J. Najarian, chaplain and director of student activities of FairleighDickinson University.

title: CHANGE IS FOCUS OF JEWISH PARLEY
description: Conservative Judaism, born 60 years ago to strike a balance between Orthodoxy and Reform, ended its fiveday biennial congregational convention in Klamesha Lake, N. Y., last week still convinced that the soundest course is to conserve what is valuable while changing that which requires change.

title: SENATE PROPOSAL SETS RELIEF TEST
description: Thousands of New York City welfare mothers who were found to be disabled in medical tests over the last two month would have to be tested again under a measure pending ?? Congress, even though ?? officials said the results probably would be about the same.

title: Cemeteries Are Urged to Fight Vandalism
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has urged cemetery officials throughout the city and state to immediately institute practices aimed at easing the grief experienced by families who find that the gravestones of their loved ones have been desecrated.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SEES LABOR PEACE IN '74
description: The top labormanagement troubleshooter for the Nixon Administration has cautiously predicted that 1974 will be a year of Peace on the bargaining front.

title: Show Group Seeks End Of a Tranquilizer's Use
description: An allout campaign to wipe out the use of reserpine, a potentially lethal drug, in the show ring has been launched by the American Horse Shows Association, along with a group of leading scientists and chemists.After a symposium in Washington attended by more than 30 experts in the drug field, the A.H.S.A. has mapped a plan to attack the tranquilizing drug, on several fronts.

title: Job in Isolated Region Attracts 800 Inquiries
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 17Officials of the State Game and Fish Department are convinced that Americans all over the country are more willing than ever to go to great lengths to get away from it all.

title: Skylab Astronauts Are Reprimanded In 1st Day Aboard
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 17A serious reprimand from Mission Control marred the Skylab 3 astronauts' first day aboard their earthorbiting space station.

title: 3 Iderly Women to Be Evicted From Homes in N.Y. U. Building
description: New York University is about to evict three elderly women from a student dormitory where they have lived for more than 30 years.

title: Emergency Center Is Opened
description: LINDENWOLDWhat is said to, be the state's first regional emergency communications center, a, facility capable of instantly linking 82 fire companies and 37 fescue squads and dispatching manpower and equipment whereever they are needed, is now in full operation in Camden County.

title: Travel to Europe. Shows the Sharpest Drop in a Decade
description: Travel by Americans to Europe this fall appears to have fallen into its biggest slump in more than a decade.

title: UnCanadian Talk About Fuel for the U.S.
description: Mr. Prime Minister, the United States is heading for another winter of disastrous shortages of natural gas... . Canada has the natural gas. The United States has paid for its discovery, and by rights we own the stuff. We must have it, and must have it fast.... I want commitments by 6 o'clock tomorrow night.The President of the United States, talking to the Prime Minister of Canada, in Ultimatum, a new Canadian novel set in the year 1980.

title: No one show ever looked like another
description: Last year, a shabby and inept touring company of Hair passed through Los Angleles, and I wondered how the management could have allowed their raunchy masterpiece to fall apart. After reading this artless, often petty but generally convincing account by one of the original Broadway cast, I begin to understand. The show started deteriorating when the performers started realizing they were not Clove tribe, just a bunch of actors for hire, Lorrie Davis says. Such realization must have come very early, for her book is the sad chronicle of a show which seems to have gone downhill almost from the moment it opened.

title: State is Allocating Funds to Handicapped
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Education has formulated tentative plans on how to begin spending $25million to improve the physical and educational programs for New Jersey's 2,000 severely handicapped children.

title: House Votes Aid to Black Ousted From Army in '06
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)The Houes has passed and sent to the Senate legislation providing compensation for a Minneapolis resident who is the last known suriving member of a group of black Army veterans dishonorably discharged 66 years ago by President Theodore Roosevelt.

title: In Cold Print: Writers and Underwriters
description: Not since the days when Maxwell Perkins and F. Scott Fitzgerald exchanged letters on such matters as how to bring the mysterious Getsby into better focus  Couldn't he be physically described as distinctly as the others, and couldn't you add one or two characteristics like the use of the phrase old sport?  has there been a more stimulating set of editorauthor letters than the recent correspondence between Doubleday editor Tom Congdon and author Richard Harris, the New Yorker writer who has given us, among other books, Justice, that alarming and prophetic report on John Mitchell's Justice Department.

title: MORRIS SARNOFF
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 17 Morris Sarnoff, a retired insurance man and corporate executive, died yesterday at Golden Isles Hospital here at the age of 79.

title: CITY TO GIVE GROUPS BEAUTIFICATION AID
description: The city announced yesterday that it would help pay for local beautification projects undertaken by community groups to improve their neighborhoods.

title: Housing Proposal Protested In Queens
description: Residents of the College Point section of Queens turned out in force last week to oppose and denounce plans for a 2,500unit housing complex in their community.

title: Clifton 340 Victor; Streak Reaches 18
description: Dale Oostdyk got off to a bad start yesterday, then completed 10 of his last 11 passes to lead unbeaten Clifton to a 340 victory over Garfield in Clifton. It was Clifton's 18th victory in a row. Garfield has lost 18 straight.

title: New & Novel
description: If the Forsytes had gone in for open marriage, what would have become of the saga? And if the late R. F. Delderfield's Adam Swann had joired a commune, would he still have felt that God is an Englishman?

title: Black Elected Bishop
description: A 44yearold black clergyman, the Rev. Harold Louis Wright, was elected suffragan bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday. Page 39.

title: Figaro won the 3,500 mile race in a breeze
description: There are sublime uses for the clich. An example was Westbrook Pegler's, reminiscing about the fascist demagogues of the 1930's. He came to Gerald L. K. Smith. It was Smith, Pegler wrote, who said about Franklin Delano Roosevelt: That liar, that scoundrel, that thief! You could hear Pegler pausing on the page before going on to write, with a sigh, I wish I had said that. It is a clich that sunsetsatseaarebeautiful, that crossing the ocean in a small sailing boat is a dangerous and exhilarat? ing experience, that the sea is the enemy but a seductive enemy. And there are many books about crossing the ocean in sailing boats, some of them as overindulgent as a banana split, some as telegraphically dull as the log of a Coast Guard cutter. Both extremes have, however, yielded classics in the literature, Joshua Slotum's at the Apollonian end, Conrad's at the other.

title: U.S. JEWS GAUGE EXTREMIST ATTACK
description: Right and leftwing extremist groups pounced on the Jewish state with the hostility, and zeal of the Arab armies, according to a study of public reaction in the United States to the Middle East war released yesterday by the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: Belgium's Struggle to Secure Iranian Oil
description: BRUSSELS  Negotiations between the Belgian and Iranian Governments to set Op a jointly owned oil refinery in eastern Belgium are being affected by oil nationalizations by the Arabs, war in the Middle East, environmentalist objections and even the perennial conflict between the Flemish and the Walloons.

title: The life, times and future of Homarus americanus
