description: GREENVALE, L. I., Nov. 17 C. W. Post capitalized on five Fordham turnovers to trounce the visiting Rams, 330, in a Metropolitan Conference football game today.

title: A pattern of rising power
description: The celebrants of Presidential powerSorensen, Neustadt, Burnshave busily if rather quietly gone to work on their palinodes. Naturally, they try to save as much of the prior fabric as they can, amending here, canceling there and subtly restating throughout. Since they all agree that the last good Poiverful President was Mr. Kennedy, and that the main count against his successors is Vietnam, the obvious course is to claim that Presidential power remains a blessingall but the warmaking power, which must be cut back.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17A coalition of national conservation groups has chided the Soviet Union's refusal to comply with international conservation measures for whales as more greedy, imperialistic and exploitive than any capitalist nation, with the exception of Japan.

title: Tennessee Bows, 2818, To Ole Miss
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov, 17 (AP)A reserve tailback, Jim Reed, sliced through Tennessee's stunned defenses for two touchdowns today as firedup Mississippi scored a 2818 Southeastern Conference upset over the Volunteers.

title: Why Is Good Evening So Very, Very Funny?
description: THERE is an item I rather like in the thoroughly untrustworthy program notes that Peter Cook and Dudley Moore have provided for the new entertainment called Goad Evening. (They have also provided all of the entertainment for Good Evening, which is decent of them.) It seems that when four frolicsome fellows got together oh, some 10 or 20 years ago, to engage in a game of cerebral leapfrog known as Beyond the Fringe, only Mr. Cook was a professional. The others were then amateurs, schoolboys really, but no matter: all would be treated as equals, each would receive exactly the same salary. The result was that Mr. Cook earned, throughout that show's gallop into eternity, 10 per cent less than his altogether inexperienced colleagues. You see, he had an agent.

title: Okla. Hands 4820 Defeat To Kansas
description: NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 17 (UPI)Steve Davis scored twice on goalline dives and Joe Washington added two touchdowns on short runs to pace Oklahoma to a 4820 victory over Kansas today.

title: Kohoutek Watchers
description: The enormous scientific value of the achievements in space of the crews of Skylab 1 and 2 was made abundantly evident months ago. Now the astronauts of Skylab have been successfully launched and guided to rendezvous with their temporary home in orbit. Once they have got well settled in and begun work, important new information is sure to be gathered from observations of earth, from study of the solar system and from experiments conducted in the space station itself, notably on man's capability of living and working successfully for long periods in that unnatural capsulated environment.

title: At Marks and Spencer, Even Princess Anne May Be the Next in Line
description: WHAT may be the biggest tourist attraction in London is included in no sightseeing trip, nor does it appear on any list of historic places. Yet hundreds of thousands of foreign visitors rush off to it almost as soon as they arrive. As they sprint off, sometimes in excitable, unmanageable throngs of a couple of hundred or more peoplealmost all womenthey can be heard muttering Mox and Spenser! or maybe Marrks y Spennsairre! or even Mahrk et Sponsair! These organized invasions are aimed not at Westminster Abbey, or the Houses of Parliament, or the crown jewels in the Tower of London. Instead, the hordes are headed for the department store with the fastest moving stock in the world, Marks & Spencer, to snap up British woolens in such a frenzy that you might suppose the very last English sheep in the world had just been laid low by a new strain of vicious moth. But never fear, no matter how fast the sweaters, cardigans, suits, turtlenecks and knit dresses are snatched off the counter, they are immediately replaced, over and over, forever and ever.

title: Film:'England Made Me':Novel by Greene' Is Lost in Adaptation
description: "England Made Me," a screen adaptation of Graham Greene's ironic novel written in 1935, proves that a little hindsight can often be too much. In this case it's fatal.Peter Duffell, the director of the film, which opened yesterday at the Paris, and co-author of the screenplay with Desmond Cory, has had the presumption to straighten out Graham Greene by transferring the story's locale from Sweden in the midnineteen-thirties to Nazi Germany, which is fast becoming a rather sick movie joke.If, as some recent films would have us believe, the Nazis spent so much time at orgies, slurping up the old bubbly and snapping bra straps, it's a miracle they could ever stagger into the Rhineland, much less manage a coherent blitzkrieg.The shift in place has had the effect of transforming Greene's novel, based loosely on the last days of Ivar Kreuger, Sweden's swindling match king, from a post-Depression story of ambition and fatigue into one of those heavily ominous, pre-holocaust dramas that see every event as an indication of Things To Come. It also allows for orgies, parades of storm troopers and other picturesque if irrelevant details.Even though this is not Greene, "England Made Me" might have worked, were Mr. Duffell and Mr. Cory less superficial movie makers. They've retained a surprising amount of the Greene plot, even a lot of original dialogue, but the story is no longer comic and rueful, just wildly melodramatic. The prototypical Greene characters are evident, but they look out of place. The scenery is wrong. It throws everything out of focus.This is most apparent in the performances of Peter Finch and Michael York. Mr. Finch plays the Kreuger character, now portrayed as a swindling German financier who has no love for the Nazis, but who doesn't hesitate to use Nazi strong-arm tactics. Mr. York is Tony Farrant, the twin brother of the financier's English mistress, Kate (Hildegard Neil), a supposedly charming scapegrace and liar whose English backbone finally stiffens when he is confronted with Mr. Finch's extraordinary amorality.Unless you have read the novel, I doubt whether you'll have any idea of the relationships among the characters. Mr. Finch looks tired and glum, and Mr. York incapable of having the shabby past that is attributed to him. When he tells his sister "I'm not a sponge," you believe him, which is wrong, Similarly, I never did believe the passion that Miss Neil is meant to have for her brother. They all seem to be play-acting.The only spot of pure Greene in the entire film is Michael Hordern as Minty, the scroungy, old-school Englishman who makes a living as a newspaperman in self-imposed exile. Poor old Minty, who once had a canary that sang too much and died, is a recurring theme in Greene's novels. When Minty is on screen, "England Made Me" suggests many levels of consciousnessof decisions made too late, of scruples wasted, of empire's endthat are nowhere else evident.It's not that Mr. Duffell is an unread director. At one moment he lets the camera linger on a beaten-up copy of "The Waste Land" on the floor by Minty's unmade bed. He's just a very clumsy one.

title: I.T.T. Concerns Bombed
description: NUREMBURG, West Germany, Nov. 18 (Reuters)  A bomb exploded in the cellar of a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company here today, causing extensive damage, the police said. It was the second attack against a subsidiary of the giant American company in West Germany in 48 hours. Yesterday a similar homemade bomb rocked an I.T.T. building in West Berlin.

description: GURNEE, Ill., Nov. 18 (UPI) Voters in this northeastern Illinois village of 3,500 overwhelmingly approved yesterday a proposal for construction of a giant amusement park, hotel and industrial park complex on 600 acres to be annexed by the village.

title: Music
description: There were a few unsettled moments during the intermission of Oleg Kagan's New York recital debut at the Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday night when it became apparent that stench bombs had been released at the end of the first half of the program. The hall did not have to be cleared, however, and following a relatively brief delay, the concert resumed with most of the audience still present to hear it.

title: Title to Rough Riders
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 18 (AP)The Ottawa Rough Riders posted a 2314 victory over the Montreal Alouettes today to win the Eastern Conference title in the Canadian Football League and a berth in next week's Grey Cup.

title: Bruins Top Flames, 52, As Hodge Paces Attack
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)Ken Hodge got a goal and three assists tonight as the Boston Bruins whipped the Atlanta Flames, 52, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Coast Man Triumphs In Monopoly Tourney
description: I feel excited, said Lee Bayrd, after his victory. It was very elating to play people of this caliber.

title: American Bishops Showing a New Readiness to Take Issue With the Vatican
description: The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church are showing an increasing willingness to engage in open disagreements with Vatican officials over what is best for the church in this country.

title: 2d Congressional Group, All Democrats, Visits Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Nov, 18 (AP) Seven Democratic Congressmen, led by Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal of New York, arrived today to make personal appraisal of Israel's needs.

title: Concert
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's program Friday night in Tully Hallrepeated late yesterday afternoonproved typically refreshing. It was Frenchoriented, presided over by Zino Francescatti, the French violinist, and Gaby Casadesus a distinguished pianist in her own right and widow of Robert Casadesus. And, curiously enough, it contained two concertos.

title: St. Joseph's Victor
description: St. Joseph's of Buffalo placed: five runners among the top 10 finishers to capture team honors in the Christian Brothers scholastic crosscountry run yesterday at:,Van Cortlandt Park in the, Bronx. Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn was second. The individual winner was Paul Bdttermark of St. Peter's, who clocked 12 minutes 47.8 seconds, and beat Loughlih's A1 Paris by 10 yards.

title: Israel Orders Judicial Inquiry Into War
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 18The Is raeli Cabinet today ordered judicial inquiry into the country's military preparedness for the latest Middle Eastern war

title: HARVEY O. BROWN
description: Harvey O. Brown, organist and choirmaster of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church and organist for Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, died yesterday in the New York Infirmary. He was 66 years old and lived at 294 West 92 Street.

title: Gigante vs. Velez in Ring of glum Politics
description: Two longtime archenemies from the South Bronx  one a proud and powerful selfmade Puerto Rican militant, the other a shrewd, ambitious, committed Roman Catholic priest will be sitting together in the new City Council.

title: Aussies Reach Davis Cup Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 18 (AP)Rod Laver and John Newcombe powered Australia into the final round of the Davis Cup tennis competition against the United States by winning their singles matches today from Czechoslovakia and completing a 41 semifinal victory.

title: Bridge:Mixed Foursome Gains Lead In Swiss Teams Title Play
description: A powerful mixed foursome took the lead going into the final session of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton here last night. John and Judi Solodar, Alvin Roth, all of New York, and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N.J., scored 129 victory points of a possible 180, heading the field of 56 teams after three sessions.

title: NEW MEXICO DEFIES LAW ON WILD HORSES
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 18  In a direct challenge to Government regulations controlling the protection and management of wild, freeroaming horses and burros, the New Mexico Livestock Board has notified Federal authorities that it claims ownership of all of these animals in this state under the stray laws of New Mexico.

title: Nixon Cheered and Jeered in Georgia
description: MACON, Ga., Nov. 18President Nixon was jeered as well as cheered in conservative central Georgia today as he joined in a 90th birthday tribute to former Representative Carl M. Vinson.

title: Credit Rules for Women Are Eased by 2 Banks
description: NEWARK, Nov. 18Women will be able to get credit more easily in at least two banking institutions in the state as a result of agreements announced last week.

title: Saturday's Surprises Fail to Change Bowl Picture
description: Auburn and Missouri did not brighten the day for Sun. Bowl officials Saturday as these teams were upset before accepting formal invitations to meet in the postseason game at El Paso, Tex., on Dec. 29. Tennessee also lost before Gator Bowl directors went through the motions of an official invitation to the Vols and Kansas lost prior to getting the prearranged Liberty Bowl bid.

title: FIRE UNION LEADER CONCEDES HE LIED ON STRIKE VOTING
description: Richard J. Vizzini, the president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, has conceded that he lied when he reported his membership had voted overwhelmingly in secret ballots to endorse a strike.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: REAL THING Youngsters, to make a sweeping generalization, are often smitten with pictures that move, a condition that has given rise to a multiplicity of film and videotape projects for youth around town. A senior citizen of this movement is Young Filmmakers, which has been giving youngsters, ages 14 to 20, a chance to make their own movies since 1968. It works out of its 16mm club at 4 Rivington Street on the Lower East Side, where its membership includes kids from all ethnic and economic categories. It sees that their short productions get seen, whether in libraries, churches, outdoor schoolyards or, any other place.

title: $200 in Pennies Spilled
description: GRANITE CITY, Ill., Nov. 18 (UPI)  A SMEI trailer truck eastbound from the Denver Mint with $56,000 worth of pennies cracked under the load, spilling about $200 worth of pennies in bags to the ground.

title: Banker and 2 Senators Urge Rationing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Two Senators and one of the nation's top bankers, taking sharp issue with President Nixon, said today that gasoline rationing was essential.

title: Boy Is Poisoned by Clams
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP)Officials said today that a 10yearold boy was hospitalized in critical condition after he had eaten clams contaminated by toxins from red tide algae. The Health Department said another boy was affected by the poisoning but recovered in a few hours.

title: Pope, Optimistic, Says Church Is Revitalized
description: ROME, Nov. 18Pope Paul VI, speaking with a tone of optimism he has not expressed in some time, said today that he had witnessed an upsurge of vitality in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Philadelphia Fire Kills 3
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (AP)  A 35  year  old woman and two young granddaughters were killed and two persons were critically injured today when fire destroyed their West Philadelphia row house, the police reported, The dead were identified as Mrs. Inez Young and her granddaughters, Anitra, 3, and Tameka, 9 weeks,

title: Uncertainties Cloud Alaskan Pipeline's Future
description: The signing of the TransAlaskan Pipeline Bill by President Nixon Friday ended a major battle in the fouryear effort by the oil industry to tap the large reserves of Alaska's North Slope, but some uncertainties remain to cloud the future of the $4.5billion project.

title: Kissinger's Parents Accept An Award for Him Here
description: Louis and Paula Kissinger yesterday accepted an award honoring their son, Secretary of State Kissinger, for courageous leadership in governmental service.

title: NEW ARAB OIL CUT TO EUROPE VOIDED
description: PARIS, Nov. 18  Arab oil exporters made a conciliatory gesture to Western Europe today in announcing that petroleum supplies would not be cut back further to most European Common Market states.

title: Watergate Service at St. John's Quotes Prophet Daniel and Plato
description: Rabbi Nathan Perilman, the recently retired rabbi of Temple EmanuEl, said yesterday that he believed that the Prophet Daniel provided words for reflection in the time of Watergate.

title: 400 Demonstrate Here Against Greek Government
description: About 400 opponents of the Greek Government demonstrated yesterday at the Greek Mission to the United Nations at 69 East 79th Street for an nour and a half without incident, the police reported.

title: U.S. Equestrian Team Wins Toronto Title
description: TORONTO, Nov. 18The United States Equestrian Team won the International Championship in a runaway last night at the closing session of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

title: St. Paul's on 59th St. Could Be Razed
description: A proposal to demolish the historic Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, its school, convent and rectory to save the parish from bankruptcy, will be discussed at a public hearing in the church auditorium on Dec. 2.

title: Morton Announces Offer Of 147 Oil Tracts in Gulf
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, announced today that 147 tracts covering 817,000 acres in the Gulf of Mexico off Mississippi, Alabama and Florida would be offered in an oil and gas lease sale next month.

title: Echoes of a Strike Linger Among City Fire Fighters
description: Through the quiet Sunday afternoon, the alarm bells and buzzers that become part of a fireman's life in Brownsville periodically emptied the modest firehouse on Watkins Street that is home for Ladder Company 120 and Engine Company 231.

title: Deborah BozBeckian Wed to Physician
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 18  In Old First Church (Congregational) here this afternoon, Miss Deborah Ann BozBeckian of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. A. BozBeckian of Springfield, became the bride of Dr. Vassilios Raptopoulos of Washington. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Demetrios Raptopbulos of Thessalonica, Greece.

title: Undisclosed Gifts Are Reported Traced to Gurney Office Safe
description: MIAMI, Nov. 18 (AP)Federal agents have traced thousands of dollars in unreported cash contributions from builders who do business with the Federal Housing Administration to a safe in the Washington office of Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, The Miami Herald reported in its Sunday editions. Mr. Gurney is a member of the Senate Watergate committee.

title: The Guilty Party
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18If the Nixon problem is not resolved, warns the editorial voice of The New York Times, the Republican party will suffer a political holocaust in the 1974 and 1976 elections.

title: Sir Gerald Nabarro Dies at 60; Flamboyant Conservative M.P.
description: LONDON, Nov. 18Sir Gerald Nabarro, a maverick Conservative Member of Parliament, who was long an effective goad to ConserVative and Labor Administrations alike, died today at his home in Worcestershire. His age was 60, and he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage last week.

title: Printers Ratify Contract With Commercial Shops
description: New York Typographical Union No. 6 ratified a contract yesterday giving a $22aweek pay increase to 4,600 printers in 250 commercial printing shops in the city.

title: Mrs. Schulman Remarried
description: RYE, N. Y., Nov. 18Mrs. Doris Guttman Schulman of Scarsdale, widow of Dr. N. Jerome Schulman, a gynecologist, was married here this morning to Benjamin Franklin Lee, a widower who is president of the B. L. I. Development Corporation of Nanuet. Rabbi Jacob Shankman performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton Inn. The bride is a graduate of the College of New Rochelle. The bridegroom's company builds nursing homes and residences for the aged.

title: Thinking Changes On Money Reform
description: PARIS, Nov. 18Important changes are taking place in the thinking of international financial officials about reform of the monetary system.

title: Occidental's Chief Signs Pact With Poland on Plant
description: WARSAW, Nov. 18 (AP)Armand Hammer, the 75yeerold president of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, signed an agreement with Poland yesterday to help build a metalfinishing plant that would have a $10million annual output.

title: NEW ARAB OIL CUT TO EUROPE VOIDED
description: PARIS, Nov. 18  Arab oil exporters made a conciliatory gesture to Western Europe today in announcing that petroleum supplies would not be cut back further to most European Common Market states.

title: Rome: The Sad Plight of Opera in Italy
description: ROME, November 18This is the time of year when the singers, musicians, dancers and stagehands of Italy's 10 statesubsidized opera houses walk out of rehearsals and in a strident chorus ask for more money. Above the din, the anguished voices of operatic managers can be heard begging the Government for yet another round of hefty handouts to save the lyric drama. As every year, a harassed administration has sent a leggina  little bill  to Parliament to get new funds for grand opera and symphony orchestra. However, the present Government, pledged to curing inflation with financial austerity, has shown itself signally unenthusiastic about having to shell out the $20,million needed to pay the bank debts that the opera houses have run up.

title: Namath Back but Jets Lose by Foot; Giants Win After 7 Defeats in Row
description: Joe Namath, taking over with five minutes to play after a sevengame absence, rallied the Jets within a foot of the tying touchdown yesterday in Cincinnati, but time ran out at the goal line and the Bengals won, 2044.

title: Oakland Group Rescinds Shoot on Sight Warrant
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI)An organization claiming responsibility for the slaying of a school superintendent apparently has rescinded its socalled shoot on sight warrant for other educators.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DEVIL AND JOHN FOSTER DULLES. By Townsend Hoopes. 562 pages. Illustrated. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $15.

title: Time, Bengals Foll Late Heroics in 2014 Setback
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 18be Namath, whose story??ok career has been punc??ated with miraclelike chievements, tried to pull ??ff another improbable feat ??ay, but the clock and the ??incinnati defense wouldn't ??t him.

title: Israeli Inquiry on War
description: Israel announced yesterday that she would conduct a judicial inquiry into the nation's military preparedness at the time the war broke out on Oct. 6. Page 3.

title: 3 Dartmouth Students Die In Vermont Plane Crash
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Nov. 18 (UPI)  Three Dartmouth College students were killed early today when a singleengine plane they had borrowed from the campus flying club for a flight to Schenectady, N.Y., crashed into 3800foot Mount Equinox.

title: Policeman Is Slain During Hours Siege Of Newburgh House
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 18 (AP)A Newburgh city patrolman was killed late last night during an hourlong shootout with an unidentified gunman, the police said

title: Former Knicks Player Arrested On Charge Involving Marijuana
description: Tom Hoover, a former player for the New York Knicks basketball team and now a City Hall troubleshooter in the city school system, was being held in $100,000 bail yesterday in a New Jersey jail on charges involving 1,580 pounds of marijuana with an estimated street value of $1.8million.

title: Plan Group Questions Need for a 4th Jetport
description: Forecasts of a huge expansion of air travel into and out of New Yorkpredictions that have been used by Metropolitan Transportation Authority consultants to justify the need for a fourth jetportmay never be realized, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.

title: Teachers Ask Impeachment
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 (UPI)  The 150,000  member New Jersey Education Association called this weekend for the impeachment of President Nixon, contending that he had weakened confidence in the Government of the United States.

title: Alice in Wonderland
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18In his Florida press conference last night President Nixon conveyed the impression of man frustrated in his efforts to publish the facts of Watergate. I wanted the evidence out, he said, expressing his very great disappointment at the nonexistence of two tapes.

title: MISS FURNESS ASKS UTILITY RATE CURB
description: The setting of utility rates should be brought back under the Federal Government's Phase 4 controls, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Betty Furness, said yesterday.

title: Prague Is Backing Away From Accord With Bonn
description: BONN, Nov. 18An agreement between West Germany and Czechoslovakia that would pave the way for the establishment of diplomatic relations between them has been withdrawn by the Czechoslovaks, apparently because of pressure from East Germany, according to Communist end Western sources.

title: Pop Music: Isis Plays Gusty SoulRock
description: Allwomen groups are not unknown in rock 'n'roll, but they generally confine themselves to the usual lineup of guitars and drums. Isis, a sevenpiece unit, steps out of that particular rut by employing a gusty front line of trumpet, trombone and tenor saxophone (doubling flute) that gives a definite soulrock feeling to the band.

title: PRISON ESCAPEE KILLED BY POLICE
description: An escapee from a New Jersey prison who killed a state trooper seven years ago was shot to death in the Times Square area yesterday as he attempted to elude a detective stakeout, the police said.

title: About New York A Certain Type of Woman
description: New York women are different from other women, and there are among them women who belong only to New York. They are a type, really, and they burn with what is supposed to be a gemlike flame, and they add to the gayety of the city and to the sexual tension as well.

title: Qaddafi and Military Chiefs Visiting Tito
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 18Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the. Libyan revolutionary leader who is at odds with most of his fellow Arab leaders, arrived in Belgrade today for hurriedly arranged talks with President Tito.

title: Evans J. Liolin, a Leader In Albanian Orthodox Sect
description: Evans J. Liolin, a prominent layman of the Albanian Orthodox Church in this country, died here Friday. He was 76 years old and lived at 8023 190th Street, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LAKEWOOD, Nov. 18Loren Murchison, 76 years old, seldom talks about the 1920 Olympics in Antwerp, but he thinks about those days a lot. Not about the first gold medal he won as a relay sprinter, but about the World War I transport the team sailed on, how the athletes attempted to organize a boycott and how they got tricked.

title: 3 SLAY BRONX MAN IN STREET HOLDUP
description: A Bronx man who went out to buy a Sunday newspaper and some ice cream for his wife was stabbed to death Saturday night by three youths who tried to rob him, the police reported yesterday.

title: The President and the People
description: To the Editor: It has become popular to issue regular assaults on the character of the President. A sampling of public opinion would indicate that he is probably guilty of sundry crimes against humanity.

title: Five on Tugboat Rescued
description: MONHEGAN, Maine, Nov. 18 (AP)Five men were rescued last night when an 85foot tugboat sank off the eastern side of Monhegan Island, the Coast Guard said.

title: FASHION TALK
description: And now, add the name of Fernando Sanchez.

title: Canadian to See Gromyko
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press)  Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, Mitchell W. Sharp, arrived here tonight prepared to urge the Soviet Union to permit more of its citizens to move to Canada. He said he would give to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko a new list of prospective emigrants sponsored by relatives in Canada.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
4 Gold Medals for U.S.
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 18 (Reuters)The United States won four gold medals on the first day of the PanAmerican Wheelchair Games which opened here yesterday. Lucy Broemer and Liz Nixerf each took a gold in wheelchair slalom events, In table tennis, Bob Dunn also won a gold, and Gene Geissinger and Zigg Klemens won gold and silver medals in archery.

title: Whitlam's Party Loses Badly In Populous Australian State
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 18 The conservative coalition government of New South Wales, Australia's most populous state, badly defeated Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's Labor party in an election yesterday. The defeat was considered a significant pointer to the declining national popularity of the Whitlam administration, now almost a year old.

title: FRENCH PRESENT NEW NATO IDEAS
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 18France presented new suggestions for a declaration of Atlantic alliance principles last week, mentioning a just sharing of alliance costs and the need to remove the sources of economic conflict among the allies.

title: Miss Ellen Kelly, Gerald Tierney, Lawyers, Marry
description: The Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes in Queens Village, Queens, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Ellen Catherine Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Q. Kelly of Queens Village, to Gerald Miles Tierney Jr., son of Mrs. Tierney of Arlington, Va., and the late Dr. Tierney.

title: They Sing in Praise of Matzoh Brei
description: Of course Mayor John V. Lindsay was invited to the Fourth Matzoh Brei Convention, but he realized that slimness is allso he made do with telegram: I wish you continued success in your endeavors to further ideas that we all affirm.

title: Southern Black Mayors Give Wallace Standing Ovation at a Conference
description: TUSKEGEE, Ala., Nov. 18Looking fit and talking like a man in quest of black votes, Gov. George C. Wallace was given a standing ovation and the key to this famed Negro college town when he came here today to discuss industry, jobs and education with members of the Southern Conference of Black Mayors.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Public Office, Public Funds
description: WASHINGTONPerhaps some of us who have been in the eye of the Watergate storm can be forgiven if we look for a silver liningif we suggest that out of the public turmoil and personal agony, there has emerged an historic opportunity for longoverdue political reform.

title: Scrabble Title Tourney Dwsra 85 Nctosetnsta
description: Joan Singer stared hard at the RPFIAYB she pulled out of the small purple bag lying on the table. She did not even watch as her opponent placed DATA on the board.

title: NORMAN LEE, MADE AIR HISTORY IN '39
description: Norman C. Lee, a retired stockbroker who in 1939 became the first regular passenger to fly around the world using scheduled commercial plane service, died Saturday night in the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 24 East 82d Street.

title: Tax Levied on Cars Given to Schools
description: HARRISBURG, Nov. 18 (AP) Some Pennsylvania car dealers who donate autos for high school driver education courses got a shock this year when they were told they were evading state sales taxes.

title: Red Smith
description: Gaylord Ravenal stepped out of here over the weekend. though that isn't how the obituaries identified him. They used his square name, Lloyd Mangrum. Ravenal was what his companions on the professional golf circuit called him because his rakish good looks and meticulously trimmed mustache gave him a debonair jauntiness that they associated with the riverboat gambler in Edna Ferber's Show Boat.

title: G.O.P. GOVERNORS WEIGH STRATEGY
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 18  Republican Governors marked off this afternoon the outer limits of their forthcoming debates on President Nixon and Watergate.

title: Broncos Beat Indifferent Steelers, 2313
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 The Denver Broncos, the National Football Ledgue's only team that has never experienced a winning season, came closer to that goal today by upsetting the Pittsburgh Steelers, one of the league powerhouses. The score was 2313 and it was merely the Steelers' second loss in 10 games. Why did it happen and how?

title: Where Did the Time Go? Asks Namath
St. Joseph's. Victor.
description: St. Joseph's of Buffalo placed five runners among the top 10 finishers to capture team honors in the Christian Brothers scholastic crosscountry run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn was second. The individual winner was Paul Buttermark of St. Peter's, who clocked 12 minutes 47.8 seconds, and beat Loughlin's Al Paris by 10 yards.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: PRISON ESCAPEE KILLED BY POLICE
description: An escapee from a New Jersey prison who killed a state trooper seven years ago was shot to death in the Times Square area yesterday as he attempted to elude a detective stakeout, the police said.

title: Met. College Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: B Smith Hopkins 3d Marries Alice S. Prince in New Jersey
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Nov. 18 Miss Alice Sara Prince, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Prince was married here this morning to B Smith Hopkins 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hopkins Jr., of Urbana, Ill. Mayor Donn Snyder of Westfield performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: ASTRONAUTS TRY TO MAKE UP TIME
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 18 CAP)Scrambling to get back on schedule today the Skylab 3 astronauts sorted out and stowed thousands of items they will need for their three months aboard the orbiting space station.

title: Florida Seeks to Curb Runaway Growth
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 18Florida's runaway development binge, a phenomenon achieved by lax laws and technological advances that subdued and transformed a wild subtropical peninsula, is rapidly moving the state toward a showdown over the basic issue of property rights.

title: Pentagon Queried on Bands
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, a leading critic of Pentagon spending policies, suggested today that the armed services did not need 143 bands costing a total of $48.4million a year. He did not call for an end to all military music but said 143 bands around the world is a little too much. This doesn't contribute one iota to national defense.

title: From Bills
description: The Miami Dolphins had an opportunity to clinch their third straight division title yesterday and methodically, as always, went to work. Looking like the defending champions of the National Football League, which they are, Coach Don Shula's Dolphins overpowered the Bills, 170, at Buffalo. They are now assured of first place in the American Conference's Eastern Division.

title: Bruins Beat Flames, 52, As Hodge Sparks Attack
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)Ken Hodge got a goal and three assists tonight as the Boston Bruins whipped the Atlanta Flames, 52, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Brooklyn Duo Wins City Doubles Title
description: It wasn't a day for tennis, but they played the final of the New York City public parks doubles championship yesterday at Central Park. Retaining their title in an uphill battle were Joe Cerrato and Biligere Kripanidhi of Brooklyn, who defeated Vern Morgan and Brian Squires of Manhattan, 4.6, 6.7, 62, 6.1, 61.

title: ExKnicks Player Is Held on a Marijuana Charge
description: Tom Hoover, a former player for the New York Knicks basketball team and now a City Hall troubleshooter in the city school system, was being held in $100,000 bail yesterday in a New Jersey jail on charges involving 1,580 pounds of marijuana with an estimated street value of $1.8million.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the Transit Authority was wasting $8million a year through inefficient maintenance and manning of its buses and subway token booths.

title: E.P.A. Testimony Is Invited
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has been asked to testify before a Senate subcommittee on regulations governing the amount of lead permitted in gasoline, Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, announced today.

title: Over the Fence
description: To no ones surprise, the cost estimate for a renovated Yankee Stadium is soaring out of sightnow about $50million, compared with Mayor Lindsay's original proposition of half that amount. With even more urgency than when the idea was first raised, it is appropriate to ask whether this egotrip for city boosters is really necessary.

title: Theater: Misanthrope
description: It is a beautiful theater a nice place to be, and an unusually effective machine for drama. The place is the Abbey Theater on East 13th Street, the new home this season for the always enterprising CSC Repertory.

title: MUSICUS WARNS CITY FACES FUEL CRUNCH
description: Milton Musicus, the city's Municipal Services Administrator and chairman of the Mayor's Emergency Energy Committee, said yesterday that the city did not face a fuel crisis for the next few weeks but that the situation looks pretty bleak in the near future.

title: Major Bills In Congress
Librarian Marries Brenda N. Starling
description: Miss Brenda Nora Starling, a pediatric social worker at the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn, was married yesterday at noon to Solomon Becker of Forest Hills, Queens, senior reference librarian at the city's Municipal Reference and Research Center; the city's repository for documents.

title: Help for the LearningDisabled Child
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.In this town the only job the kids are allowed to do is take out the garbage, Martin Weiss commented as he sampled a steak dinner cooked by four of his five sons and smiled. Son Number 5 was serving the drinks.

title: FIRE UNION LEADER CONCEDES HE LIED ON STRIKE VOTING
description: Richard J. Vizzini, the president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, has conceded that he lied when he reported his membership had voted overwhelmingly in secret ballots to endorse a strike.

title: IMPRISONED PRIESTS ARE MOVED BY SPAIN
description: MADRID, Nov. 18The Government sought to relieve tensions in its relations with the Roman Catholic Church today by transferring seven priests from their special prison in Zamora to the hospital of Carabanchel Prison outside Madrid.

title: Moon Rock for the Sudan
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 18 (Agence France Press) President Nixon has given Sudan a piece of moon rock and the Sudanese flag that went to the Moon on the last Apollo mission.

title: Chinese Watch Seton Hall Teach Their Language
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Nov. 18Four language scholars from China received a glimpse today of how American students at Seton Hall University here were taught to speak, read and write Chinese.

title: Medicare Held Gold Mine For Doctors in Manhattan
description: The first public disclosure by Ithe Federal Government of Medicare fees charged by doctors shows that Manhattanbased physicians usually charge moresometimes much morefor an identical service than other practitioners in the metropolitan area.

title: Mother of Aurobindo Ashram, A Religious Sect in India, Is Dead
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 18Mira Richard, the Mother of the Aurobindo religious movement in India, died of a heart attack last night in the coastal town of Pondicherry. She was 95 years old.

title: Medicare Held Gold Mine For Doctors in Manhattan
description: The first public disclosure by the Federal Government of Medicare fees charged by doctors shows that Manhattanbased physicians usually charge moresometimes much morefor an identical service than other practitioners in the metropolitan area.

title: GAULLISTS SETTLE ON NEXT LEADER
description: NANTES, France, Nov. 18The dominant but divided Gaullist party ended its biennial convention here today with a clear endorsement of Jacques ChabanDelmas, the former Premier, as its next candidate for President of France.

title: Victim's Father Is Bitter At U.S. Handling of Case
description: The father of a 31yearold American filmmaker and writer killed in Chile during the September coup believes that the handling of his son's case by United States officials in Sandago was either a coverup or an incredible apathetic bit of stupidity.

title: Sotheby's Hong Kong Sale Sets Record
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 18There was a time when Western connoisseurs prowled through antique shops here in search of bargains in Chinese porcelain. Now Sotheby & Co., the London auction house, has demonstrated the futility of such expeditions by holding on Friday the most successful auction of Chinese are objects ever held anywhere.

title: MRS. SPIRIDOVITCH
description: Mrs. Marguerite Spiridovitch, widow of Gen. Alexander Spiridovitch who was chief of the bodyguard of Czar Nicholas of Russia in World War I, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. Sh was 78 years old and lived at 34 East 61st Strpet.

title: BEAME'S VACATION IS DUE TO END TODAY
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame is due back lit his desk in the Controller's office at 9 A.M. today, aides said yesterday, with two main items confronting him after his postelection vacation.

title: Connecticut in Concrete
description: In light of President Nixon's energy report and subsequent official warnings that gasoline rationing and sharply higher gasoline prices are imminent, one would think that every American by now had got the message that the days of high speed, everexpanding automobile traffic in this country are over, at least for the duration of anticipated prolonged fuel shortages.

title: 2 Million Italians Are Voting In Scattered Local Elections
description: ROME, Nov. 18  Nearly two million Italians, representing about 5 per cent of the electorate, vote today and tomorrow in local and regional elections In scattered parts of the country.

title: New Math at Banks: Add Hours, Get More Depositors
description: Bankers, it seems, do not keep bankers' hours any more.

title: West Title to Eskimos
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press)A 5yard touchdown pass from Bruce Lemmerman to George McGowan with 74 seconds left gave the Edmonton Eskimos a 2523 victory over the Saskatchewan Rough Riders and the Western Conference title in the Canadian Football League today. The Eskimos will meet the Ottawa Rough Riders in the Grey Cup game for the league championship next week.

title: China as Silent Partner
description: STANFORD, Calif.China's position as an emergent nuclear power has increasingly influenced the calculations of the superpowers. It is becoming a silent partner at the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks.

title: OVERMYER CO. FILES CHAPTER XI PETITION
description: The D. H. Overmyer Company, Inc., operators of public warehouses in more than 30 states, has filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the Federal District Court here seeking an arrangement with creditors.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Israeli Inquiry on War
description: Israel announced yesterday that she would conduct a judicial inquiry into the nation's military preparedness at the time the war broke out on Oct. 6. Page 3.

title: Florida Seeks to Curb Runaway Growth
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 18Florida's runaway development binge, a phenomenon achieved by lax laws and technological advances that subdued and transformed a wild subtropical peninsula, is rapidly moving the state toward a showdown over the basic issue of property rights.

title: PHILIP VOGELMAN OF ONONDAGA SILK
description: Philip A. Vogelman, a leader in the silk industry and a philanthropist, died yesterday at his home, 784 Park Avenue. He was 80 years old.

title: KENNEDY SON GETS MESSAGES OF CHEER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 12year old son, Edward Jr., making a satisfactory recovery after his right leg was amputated above the knee, received thousands of telephone messages today from people offering support and prayers.

title: PROTESTERS FIGHT POLICE IN ATHENS IN BRIEF CLASHES
description: ATHENS, Nov. 18Demonstrators defying Greece's dayold martial law clashed today with the police in scattered fights throughout the Athens area.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Stars Beat Spurs Third Time, 8380
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 18 (AP)The Utah Stars continued their mastery over the San Antonio Spurs with an 8380 victory tonight. A late field goal by Zelmo Beatty helped clinch matters. The victory was Utah's third over the Spurs this season.

title: Illegality Compounded
description: The mass desertion of duty by striking firemen on Election Day exposed New York City to greater peril than it had ever suffered before through the excesses of its overstrong municipal unions. Now, under pressure of a grand jury investigation, comes official disclosure that this outrageous walkout was ordered by leaders the Uniformed Firefighters Association in the face of a vote by their members to stay on the joba vote the union deliberately falsified in its public statements.

title: 43 Injured in Bus Plunge
description: TRUCKEE, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI)A bus carrying, tourists and gamblers from the casinos in Reno, Nev., skidded off icy Interstate 80 today and overturned, injuring 43 persons.

title: Albany's View of City Brightens
description: Last July, when Governor Rockefeller invited the chief city officials to his office to hear his transit plan, Mayor Lindsay emerged from the meeting first and held his news conference on the sidewalk outside the West 55th Street office, while the other principals stayed inside. But Controller Abraham D. Beame, now the Mayorelect, used the Governor's own press room, replete with lectern and TV lamps. And as the Democratic candidate spoke slowly into a cluster of microphones, the Governor and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz slipped into the back of the room. They carefully yielded the limelight to Mr. Beame and stood there grinning, two offyear politicians admiring a third professional going through his paces.

title: Touche Ross and a Bank Sued on U.S. Financial Tie
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 18 (AP)An Ohio bank has filed two $4million lawsuits accusing a Los Angeles bank and an accounting firm of helping U. S. Financial, Inc., record millions of dollars in fictitious profits.

title: Assembly May Vote Today On FullTime Utility Board
description: NEWARK, Nov. 18Like other regulatory bodies throughout the country, the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners is taking longer these days to decide rate cases. Some major decisions have taken as long as two years to reach.

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS BEHIND SCHEDULE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 Under intensified Government pressure to provide a sharply increasing share of energy for an energyshort nation, the United States nuclearpower industry this week heard two forecasts: for the long term, sunny; for the short term, cloudy.

title: Mrs. Scheinman Wed
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Nov. 18Mrs. Estelle Karon Scheinman, widow of Eli Scheinman and former woman's and society editor of The LongIslander, a Huntington weekly, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Morris Robert Keen, a Huntington urologist. Rabbi Lloyd Tennebaum performed the ceremony at Temple Kehillath Shalom. The bride is the dauhgter of Morris Karon of South Fallsburgh, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Karon. Dr. Keen, whose first wife died, is a former president of the Suffolk County Medical Society.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP)  The fate of the Grand National, tile prestigious steeplechase race first run in 1837 at the Aintree Race Course near Liverpool, is expected to be announced tomorrow.

title: East Side Neighborhood Group Takes Part in Mass for the City
description: Celebrating their locally designated Love Thy Neighborhood Day, an interracial group of 200 Upper East Side residentswho have battled against demolition and relocation in their communityjoined yesterday in a Mass for the City of New York.

title: Braves Win As McAdoo Scores 43
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md. Nov. 18 (UPI)Bob McAdoo staked the Braves to an early lead tonight and his 43point performance sealed the victory as Buffalo defeated the Capital Bullets, 112101.

title: School Football
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Blades Beat Cougars, 53; Remain Behind in Rent
description: While the World Hockey Association and the owners of the New York Golden Blades are apparently bargaining over who will have to pay Madison Square Garden $8,000 by tomorrow, the Blades' players yesterday kept their part of the bargain, which is playing and, in this case, winning.

title: Prague Is Backing Away From Accord With Bonn
description: BONN, Nov. 18An agreement between West Germany and Czechoslovakia that would pave the way for the establishment of diplomatic relations between them has been withdrawn by the Czechoslovaks, apparently because of pressure from East Germany, according to Communist and Western sources.

title: Court Backs F.C.C. Ruling On Shift of Radio Format
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals said last week that it was all right for a radio station to be sold and the new owners to switch, over listener protests, from classical to rock music if another station in the areas presented substantially similar classical music.

title: Rangers' Giacomin Stops Penguins, 70
description: Eddie! Eddie! Eddie! the owd yelled in admiration

title: Myra Kremenko Bride of Steven Cohen
description: The Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale in the Bronx was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Miss Myra Theodora Kremenko, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barney Kremenko of Riverdale, to Steve Howard Cohen. He is the son of Mrs. Charles Cohen of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Cohen.

title: TV Review
description: Frank Sinatra's highly touted return after a twoyear retirement made a winning hour last night over the National Broadcasting Company.

title: Javelin's Mine Strike Rich In Ore and Controversy
description: PANAMA CITY  John C. Doyle, the chairman and major shareholder in Canadian Javelin, Ltd., who has been embroiled in legal battles with governments and fellow stockholders, has apparently struck a rich new mine of controversy with the Panamanian Government over what the company says is a huge deposit of copper it has discovered here.

title: Syria Gets Soviet Arms and Seeks New Equipment From West
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 18 Large amounts of new Soviet weapons have been put into service by the Syrian armed forces, which are offering Western suppliers cash in advance for quick delivery of radar and other airdefense equipment.

title: Aussies Sweep 505 Sail.
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Australia swept, to the Far. East 505 sailing championship today, capturing the first three places. Australia's Mark Bethwaite took the championship easily, having piled up enough points to that he did not have to take part in today's fifth and final race.

title: MANSFIELD EXPECTS NEW FACES IN 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, predicted today that his party would look for new faces in selecting a 1976 presidential candidate and that older line politicians would find it difficult to get the nomination.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: ROME  The Vatican's new Collection of Modern Religious Art will be open to the public in the next few days. The 55room extension to the Vatican museums was inaugurated by Pope Paul VI on June 23. It contains about 600 works by 250 artists, most of them living.

title: Rhode Island Cuts Speed
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 18 (AP)The Rhode Island Traffic Commission reduced the state's maximum speed limit yesterday to 50 miles an hour.

title: TeenAge Policemen Applauded By a Town in New Mexico
description: SILVER CITY, N. M., Nov. 18 When the 26th Amendment to the Constitution extended Federal voting privileges to 18yearold citizens two years ago, Police Chief Thomas Ryan thought that this southwestern New Mexico mining community should make a similar age change in its regulations on the employment of law enforcement officers.

title: Buyers' Group Elects
description: Henry Doneger, president of Henry Doneger Associates, has been elected president of the Association of Buying Offices, a trade group. He succeeds Nathaniel H, Mendelson, president of the Youth Fashion Guild, who has been president of the association for the last three years.

title: Theater: Mrs. Holroyd
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 18It is perfectly possible that one of the most important playwrights of the nineteenseventies will turn out to be a man who died in 1935. The name is D. H. Lawrence.

title: SENATE IN SNARL ON 39 U.S. AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Thirtynine executive appointments were being held up today in the Senate because of a contest between Secretary of State Kissinger and Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz for the services of man each wants to work for him.

title: A Missing Face in Mao's Study
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 17In two striking respects, the reception Secretary of State Kissinger received, in Chairman Mao Tsetung's booklined study in Peking the other day broke the almost ritualistic pattern of the Chairman's recent conversations with foreign visitors.

title: Falcons Halt Vikings' Streak, 20 to 14
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 19The Atlanta Falcons, a team that had stood still for most of its six years in the National Football League, said Hey, look at us, tonight to a nationwide television audience and upset the Minnesota Vikings, 2014.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Stock Prices Drop on Amex and 0TC
description: Prices plunged yesterday on the American Stock Exchange after a slight comeback on Friday. Prices also fell sharply in the overthecounter market.

title: Greece CourtMartids 4 And Holds More Students
description: ATHENS, Nov. 19Several scores of young people who had gathered at the approaches to Athens University were taken into custody today on charges of unlawful assembly, and four men were courtmartialed on similar charges and sentenced to four years in prison.

title: People and Business
description: When the Lydia E. Pinkham Medicine Company closes its factory in Lynn, Mass., the last of her descendants still working for the corporation will be among those losing their jobs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1973

title: Nixon Statements and the Record
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19President Nixon declared Satur day that he wanted the facts out about the Watergate scandais because the facts will prove that the President is telling the truth. But Mr. Nixon'?? latest explanations of th?? events that have plagued hi?? Administration appear to be in completeand, in some instances, to News conflict with pubAnalysis lic records and testimony about the Watergate case and its offspring.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL TO LET NIXON IMPOSE FUEL CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Declaring that a nationwide energy emergency exists, the Senate approved today a bill that would give President Nixon broad discretionary powers to require energy conservation measures by business and individuals.

title: Family Week Observance
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) Representative John T. Myers, Republican of Indiana, asked Americans yesterday to join in the observance of National Family Week, this week. Mr. Myers is author of the resolution establishing the observance.

title: Nation Is Living on Less Energy For Travel, Heating and Lights
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ward of Detroit began turning off the lights last week when they brushed their teeth or talked on the telephone at night, to save electricity.

title: A.M.A. Voices Concern About the Quality of Young Doctors Given Accelerated Training
description: The American Medical Association voiced concern yesterday about the competency and immaturity of a growing number of young doctors as a result of accelerated medical training programs.

title: Questions and Answers on History And Ramifications of City Fire Strike
description: The disclosure that the city's fire fighters had actually voted against a strike although their president said the vote in favor of a walkout was overwhelming has touched off a series of questions in the legal and labor areas. The following questions and answers examine the background of the strike and its subsequent legal ramifications.

title: Astronaut Overcomes a Snag While Repairing Cooling Lines
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)Lieut. Col. William R. Pogue of the Air Force successfully filled the Skylab's vital equipment cooling system with a fresh supply of fluid today after a series of delays caused by faulty repair equipment

title: A Summary of Various Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: A NEW NOTE It's not so long since the Chinese Government, which has its offices in Peking, fielded a breathtaking acrobatic troupe at City Center. Now, Nationalist China, which makes its headquarters on Taiwan, is vying for cultural prestige at the same address, the City Center 55th Street Theater, 131 West 55th (2468989) with eight performances of the National Chinese Opera Theater Company starting at 7:30 tonight and ending next Sunday.

title: Clocks and Calendars
description: The approaching holidays, unlike those earlier in the year, offer the attraction of being celebrated when they should be.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes was confirmed by the State Senate yesterday as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court. Mr. Hughes, who served as Governor from 1961 to 1969, was nominated to the $47,500ayear post by Governor Cahill to succeed Pierre Garven, who died last month.

title: Ronan Urges Modification For Northeast Rail Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, urged the Senate Commerce Committee today to modify Northeast rail legislation to prevent the interruption of New York commuter rail service.

title: The Memphis Blues
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 19  Things ought to be looking up for governors these days. In most states, the fiscal crunch of the sixties has been surmounted, in part because schoolage population has leveled off, and with it the cost of education. Nationally, attention has swung from the Cold War and Vietnam to domestic problems, so that once again governors are looked upon and see themselvesas possible Presidents.

title: LEE THAYER, WROTE DETECTIVE STORIES
description: Lee Thayer, whole 59th or so mystery book, Dusty Death, published in 1965, was probably the first detective story written by a nonagenarian, died Sunday in Coronado, Calif. She was 99 years old.

title: GOVERNOR TO SEE BEAME ON FARES
description: Returning to work yesterday after a 10day vacation, Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame promptly announced that he would meet today with Governor Rockefeller to discuss keeping the transit fare at 35 cents.

title: Watergate Unit Suspends Investigator Over a Leak
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19An investigator for the Senate Watergate committee was suspended from duty today because Samuel Dash, the committee's chief counsel, believed that he was the source of newspaper article that was highly critical of the committee staff.

title: BRITAIN REDUCING DELIVERIES BY 10% FOR OIL PRODUCTS
description: LONDON, Nov. 19Britain escalated her attack on the national energy crisis today with a Government directive that deliveries of all petroleum products be reduced by 10 per cent immediately.

title: Stock Market Off 28.67; Drop Sharpest in 11 Years
description: Stock prices had their sharpest drop in more than 11 years yesterday amid growing fears by investors that the widening energy crisis could cause a recession. The widely followed DowJones industrial average tumbled 28.67 points to 862.66, its low for the session. Volume fell to a modest 16.7 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. widely followed DowJones industrial average tumbled 28.67 points to 862.66, its low for the session. Volume fell to a modest 16.7 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SCHOOL BASKETBALL
Hopes and Fears on Rise With New Harlem Skyline
description: A new Harlem skyline is emerging in bold vertical thrusts that are altering the traditional low profile of the community and providing new residential and office space.

title: Archdiocese Here to Start an Advertising Drive to Recruit Priests
description: Faced with a shortage of priests and an uncertainty among the public of just what a priest does, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has launched a 13week campaign that will place advertisements in newspapers and magazine's throughout the 10county diocesan area.

title: EARNINGS TUMBLE AT R. H. MACY & CO.
description: The decline in consumer confidence was cited yesterday in the earnings reports of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., and the S. S. Kresge Company, two merchandising chains. Kresge, which of a total of 1,000 stores operates only about 50 in. New York, reported record sale! and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended Oct. 31. R. H. Macy & Co., on the other hand, bowed a decline in the October quarter. The decline was its fourth since 1962.

title: Bid for Markborough Is Lifted By Campeau to $18.50 a Share
description: The Campeau Corporation, an Ottawa real estate development company, increased yesterday its offer for shares of Markborough Properties, Ltd., another Canadian company, from $16 to $18.50 a share.

title: TV: No. 1 of The Killers
description: With the accent firmly on educational television, the Public Broadcasting Service last night began a monthly series of documentaries called The Killers. Produced at WNET/13, and made possible by a grant from the BristolMyers Company, five 90minute documentaries will examine heart disease, genetic defects, pulmonary disease, trauma and cancerwhich together account for three out of every four deaths in the United States today.

title: A Matter for Greeks
description: If Colonel Papadopoulos really believes that the demonstrations against his harsh rule are the work merely of an insignificant anarchist minority in Athens, why reimpose martial law on all Greece? Why arrest hundreds who may oppose the regime but who evidently had no connection with the protest that erupted at Athens Polytechnic University? Why shatter Greek tradition by sending tanks into the campus sanctuary, rather than merely surrounding it and waiting out the student rebels?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: BRITAIN REDUCING DELIVERIES BY 10% FOR OIL PRODUCTS
description: LONDON, Nov. 19Britain escalated her attack on the national energy crisis today with a Government directive that deliveries of all petroleum products be reduced by 10 per cent immediately.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: MORRIS EPSTEIN OF YESHIVA DIES
description: Dr. Morris Epstein, author, editor and chairman of the English department at Yeshiva University's Stern College for Women, died Sunday of a heart ailment in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 207 West 86th Street.

title: Greece CourtMartials 4 And Holds More Students
description: ATHENS, Nov. 19Several scores of young people who had gathered at the approaches to Athens University were taken into custody today on charges of unlawful assembly, and four men were courtmartialed on similar charges and sentenced to four years in prison.

title: GOVERNOR TO SEE BEATE ON FARES
description: Returning to work yesterday after a 10day vacation, Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame promptly announced that he would meet today with Governor Rockefeller to discuss keeping the transit fare at 35 cents.

title: POLL FAILS TO END CENSORSHIP ISSUE
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 19 Clarkstown's new censorship committee put the question squarely to its constituency last week: shall we go on? The answer was: yes and no.

title: ULSTER'S LEADERS GET BRITISH PLAN
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 19A crucial stage in the effort to find a political solution in Northern Ireland began today as Britain presented a plan for a coalition government to moderate Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders.

title: Sohio Unit Plans Testing Of LowSulphur Coal Fuel
description: The Old Ben Coal Corporation, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), said yesterday it planned a $73million multicompany project to test the commercial potential of a process for converting coal to a lowsulphur cleanburning fuel. Construction is expected to take about five years at a facility near Sohio's refinery at Toledo, Ohio.

title: PYRAMID TO BECOME PART OF HARCOURT
description: An agreement has been reached for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich to acquire Pyramid Communications, Inc., an independent publisher of paperbacks in the inspirational, health and familyreading fields.

title: G.M. IN AGREEMENT WITH AUTO UNION
description: DETROIT, Nov. 19In bargaining that had little of the tense and bitter moments of past negotiations, the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation reached a tentative contract agreement this morning.

title: 9 Die in Mexican Bus Crash
description: OAXACA, Mexico, Nov. 19 (AP)A bus skidded off a highway and overturned today about 100 miles north of this southern Mexico city, killing nine persons and injuring 29, the Red Cross reported.

title: City Eases CleanOil Rule, Fearing Crisis This Week
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administration decided yesterday to relax its pollutioncontrol restrictions on fuel oil in the face of an energy shortage that has deepened to a point, according to an official, where it is apparent to us that there may be problems of supply as early as this weekend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Unless a comprehensive Middle East peace settlement is achieved while the situation is still in flux and before a humiliating defeat is imposed on one side by the other, or they return to the old intransigence, a fifth ArabIsraeli war is guaranteed. To assure seriousness of intent and the highlevel international importance of negotiations, they should progress directly between Israel and Egypt, Syria, Jordan and the Palestinians under the chairmanship of the United Nations Secretary General.

title: Jerusalem Paper Attacks Policy on War Information
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 19 (Reuters)The Jerusalem Post, an Englishlanguage paper, today attacked Israel's policy on war information and called for a reorganization of her information services. It said that a dangerous credibility gap had developed in the country during the war that began Oct. 6.

title: NEPHEW IS HELD IN DEATH OF TWO
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 19A 36yearold former mental patient who killed his parents four years ago was arrested as he sought readmission to a state hospital here last night, he was accused of having stabbed his aunt and uncle to death in Pennsylvania earlier in the day.

title: HighAtmosphere Explorer Unveiled
description: PRINCETON, Nov. 19An exploration of the earth's upper atmosphere, which has never been studied previously by a spacecraft, will be undertaken next month by a new unmanned satellite laboratory unveiled here today by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the RCA Corporation.

title: FIRE UNION LEADER TELLS WHY HE LIED
description: Richard J. Vizzini, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association; said last night that he had been badgered and needled by reporters into lying about the results of a strike referendum that preceded his union's fiveandahalfhour strike on Election Day.

title: Strike Disillusions a FiremanAuthor
description: Dennis Smith is a fireman. He is also the author of the bestseller Report From Engine Company 82, a book about firemen. And he is a union member who reluctantly obeyed his union's call to strike.

title: Vesco Reported to Be Planning To Take Refuge in Argentina
description: Robert L. Vesco, the financier whom the United States has been trying to extradite from Nassau in the Bahamas to face fraud charges here, has arranged to move to Argentina, where he has been guaranteed a haven by President Juan Pern, the Wall Street Journal reported yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Vineyard Deer Ordeal
description: For many residents of the island of Martha's Vineyard, Mass., the state's oneweek deer season has become an ordeal, and there is no justifiable reason why that ordeal should continue.

title: Hopes and Fears on Rise With New Harlem Skyline
description: A new Harlem skyline is emerging in bold vertical thrusts that are altering the traditional low profile of the community and providing new residential and office space.

title: Sued Owners Sue Over Hotel Collapse
description: In an unusual legal coincidence, two apparently conflicting suits were filed yesterday in State Supreme Court involving the collapsed Broadway Central Hotel.

title: Jersey Power Shift Kills 2 Major Bills
description: TRENTON, Nov. 19  The political futility and malaise that has gripped the lameduck session of the New Jersey Legislature helped kill two major measures here today dealing with publicutility regulation and homemortgage interest rates.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: ExDetective Sentenced for Rapes

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Chessex's L'Ogre Wins Goncourt

title: NEPHEW IS HELD IN DEATH OF TWO
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 19A 36yearold former mental patient who killed his parents four years ago was arrested as he sought readmission to a state hospital here last night. He was accused of having stabbed his aunt and uncle to death in Pennsylvania earlier in the day.

title: Lakers to Show Strange LineUp
description: Lakers may be a strange nickname for a team from arid Los Angeles, but the team using it may seem even stranger to New York basketball fans tonight in a game against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Gives Grand National Life
description: LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP)Mrs. Mirabel Topham sold today for $7.2million the 300acre Aintree race course, saving the Grand National steeplechase for at least five years.

title: High Court Refuses A ClassSuit Review On Bank's Service
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)The Supreme Court refused today to review a challenge to the legality of an investment service of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

title: BenGurion's Condition Is Reported Improved
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 19 (Reuters)David BenGurion, Israel's first Premier, was reported slightly improved today.

title: Passengers Watch As 2 on Subway Hit And Rob a Woman
description: A Brooklyn woman was struck on the head with a stick and robbed of $35 by two men on a subway train yesterday afternoon, and about 20 other passengers in the car watched and did nothing as she screamed, bled, and finally got off to seek help.

title: ELIZABETH S. WESTON
description: Elizabeth Stewart Weston, former executive editor of McCall's magazine and managing editor of Harper's Bazaar, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital following a stroke. The widow of Dr. Archibald M. Gaulocher, a physician, she was 58 years old and lived at 420 East 23d Street.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, Nov. 19Several gigantic football players have entered Princeton University this fall. Unfortunately for the Tiger varsity, the players will not try out for the team, which is resting at the bottom of the Ivy League.

title: PreHoliday Special: Hope on the Hoof
Chess: Prophylaxis, for Petrosian, Is the Application of Pacifism
description: What would Tigran Petrosian be doing in a wild brawl? The former world champion from Armenia, who is again a finalist in the coming knockout candidates' matches to select Bobby Fischer's challenger, abhors violence. His answer to it is his uncanny skill in prophylaxis, carrying it far beyond what its originator, Aron Nimzovich, ever would have dreamed possible.

title: LAWYER SAYS HE GOT SECRET MILK FUNDS
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP)Disguised payments of more than $176,000 were made by the Associated Milk Producers, Inc., to a lawyer who said in sworn testimony today that he passed the same amount on to a political operative for AMPI, the nation's largest dairy cooperative.

title: Sixth Fleet's Alert Ends; Some Vessels Due Home
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) The Pentagon said today that the United States had canceled the sixweekold military alert for the 60 ships of the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean.

title: Jets See A Score On Film
description: If there ever was any doubt about the kind of electricity Joe Namath can generate on the football field, consider this: in just 4 minutes and 40 seconds, he ignited more excitement and more controversy than the Jets had experienced in the first 595 minutes and 20 seconds of this season.

title: News Summary and Index.
description: Syria, after long hesitation, has reportedly declared herself willing to attend a peace conference under United Nations auspices aimed at establishing a durable Middle Eastern peace, it was disclosed in Cairo, where, officials said, the Syrian Foreign Minister, Abdel Halim Khaddam, conveyed Syria's position to President Anwar elSadat. [1:1.]

title: ARTHUR J. MORRIS OF CREDIT PLAN, 92
description: OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 19Arthur J. Morris, the banker and financier who created the Morris Plan, which made consumer credit available to working people, died yesterday at Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown. He was 92 years old and lived here.

title: NIXON GIVEN DELAY TO YIELD EVIDENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)The White House was granted a sixday delay today for surrendering the first of President Nixon's subpoenaed Watergate evidence.

title: Stock Market Off 28.67; Drop Sharpest in 11 Years
description: Stock prices had their sharpest drop in more than 11 years yesterday amid growing fearE by investors that the widening energy crisis could cause a recession. The widely followed DowJones industrial average tumbled 28.67 points to 862.66, its low for the session. Volume fell to a modest 16.7 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Sad Young Saigon Cartoonist Wields an Angry Pen
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5President Nixon, dressed as a fiendish doctor, prepares a wicked  looking hypodermic needle filled with a serum of dollars. Cambodia's President, Lon Nol, in diapers, lies on the floor clutching a baby bottle in the form of a bomb.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL TO LET NIXON IMPOSE FUEL CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Declaring that a nationwide energy emergency exists, the Senate approved today a bill that would give President Nixon broad discretionary powers to require energy conservation Measures by business and individuals.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The General American Transport Corporation said its subsidiaries had ordered four large crudeoil carriers to be constructed in Taiwan at a cost of $70million each. The four 445,300  deadweight  long  ton oil carriers would be chartered by four subsidiaries of the GATX Oswego Corporation to a major oil company under longterm charters. They would be delivered in 1977, 1978 and 1979. GATX Oswego alsoreported it was buying a 25 per cent equity in the China Shipbuilding Corporation, which would build the tankers.

title: Overmyer Seeks Hearings To Allow Lease Canceling
description: D. H. Overmyer Co., Inc., has filed a motion in the Federal District Court for Southern District of New York for hearings to obtain permission to cancel leases on from seven million to eight million square feet of warehouse space in Texas, Nevada, California, Washington, Missouri, Louisiana, New York, Georgia, Massachusetts, North Carolina, Connecticut, Maryland and Colorado.

title: Oklahoma Jolts Strong Teams Before They Get Bids to Bowls
description: If you can't get your football team into a bowl game you might as well have some fun tarnishing the records of teams going to bowls or even knock a team or two out of a bowl. At least that seems to be the approach of Barry Switzer, the coach of the Oklahoma Sooners, who are undefeated, ranked third but barred from bowl participation this winter and next while they serve a twoyear probation for violation of Big Eight admission rules.

title: Suspect Aids His Arrest
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 (AP) Michael Mora, 18 years old, was charged with smoking marijuana after he was arrested Saturday night as he smoked in the police headquarters while waiting to visit a prisoner.

title: 230 Inducted as Housing Police; One Is the First Woman Recruit
description: Two hundred thirty recruits rose snappily on command at the Brooklyn War Memorial yesterday and took their oath as new police officers of the city's Housing Authority Police Department, which its leaders call the last neighborhood police force.

title: Park Ave. Address for 4Ton Nevelson Sculpture
description: Louise Nevelson's 22foothigh CorTen steel environmental sculpture Night Presence IV, which she gave last year to the city, was installed in its permanent location on the center island at Park Avenue mall and 92d Street yesterday, and officially dedicated.

title: Bridge: 2 Mixed Partnerships Win Striking Victory in Tourney
description: Two of the country's strongest mixed partnerships scored a striking victory in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss Team Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel here during the weekend.

title: Five Soviet Artists Paint Bleak Scene of Life Here
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 19  A subdued, almost sullen composite portrait of American life has gone on display at the House of Friendship, an international culture center here.

title: Cordle, Bassoonist, Miller, Clarinetist, Give Joint Recital
description: Andrew Cordle, a bassoonist, and Douglas Miller, a clarinetist, are both in their early twenties, both took undergraduate degrees in North Carolina, and both will receive Master of Music degrees this year from New York schools. And Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall they gave a joint recital.

title: Theater
description: One of the best offOff Broadway bargains in town is Ubu Roi and its newly opened sequel, Ubu Bound, at the Night House, 249 West 18th Street (6917359). Seen separately, in the company's repertory, the effect is impressive. The two together (only on Fridays) even more so.

title: Randolph Acts to Widen Defense Against Charges of Zoning Bias
