description: So deep is Samuel Beckett's depression, so great his gloom, that next to him the various absurdists, chroniclers of the dismal, and cosmic comedians seem so many Rotarians. He is the wastelander of all wastelanders. After journeying through Beckett country, the land of Eliot  with its lidless eyes, picked bones, stony places and rats slithering through vegetation  seems almost a resort, a Cannes, a White Sulphur Springs of literary vision. Beckett offers perhaps the narrowest range in modem literature and the most unrelieved landscape. To him only a single human datum appears of real interest  that we are born to die. They give birth astride of a grave, as Pozzo says in Waiting for Godot, the light gleams an instant, then it's night once more. From his earliest work through his most recent, Beckett has viewed life as a terminal illness.

title: Jennifer Keith Wed To English Curate
description: Miss Jennifer Estelle Keith, daughter of Col. Quentin Keith U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Keith of Red Bank, N.J., and the Rev. Christopher Philip Hultson, curate of St. Peter's Church in St. Albans, Hertfordshire, were married in London yesterday afternoon, The Anglican ceremony was performed by the Rev. Austen Williams, Queen's Chaplain, at St. Michael's Church in Chester Square.

title: Food Sculpture Taught to Gourmets
description: WAYNE  When it comes to unusual careers, that of Florrie Paul should not be overlooked. Mrs. Paul, an enterprising housewife, now lectures on and demonstrates the art of food sculpture to gourmet teachers and restaurant owners.

title: Man, 102, Survived By 228
description: PITTSBURGH (AP)John J. Funk, a former dry goods merchant here, has died at the age of 102, leaving 228 survivors in four generations. Among the survivors are 8 of his children, 57 grandchildren, 136 greatgrandchildren and 27 greatgreatgrandchildren.

title: SCRANTON HAS EYE ON ENERGY CRISIS
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 24In this city that once called itself the anthracite capital of the world anthracite production is at zero despite the energy crisis.

title: City Official Urges Immediate Park Aid
description: The administration of Abraham D. Beanie may have its hands full tackling crime, welfare and rising taxes, but Donald E. Simon thinks there is one problem that cannot wait for attentionthe parks.

title: Food: Taste of the Orient in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH  When Mrs. Conchita Paguia and her daughter, Mrs. Vilma Gatchahart opened the Oriental Food Store at 700 Jersey Avenue two years ago, their aim was to cater to the middleclass Oriental families that were settling in the area, the Elflora section of Elizabeth. Surprisingly, students and graduates of Chinese cooking classes now number among their leading customers.

title: Catskills Hotel Sold as Meditation Center
description: LIVINGSTON MANOR, N. Y.This is it! Welcome. The Waldemere, proclaims a sign atop the redandwhite guardhouse at the end of a back road about four miles east of this Catskill community.

title: The Brief Greek Uprising
description: ATHENSwhat has happened in this volatile city these past few days wasn't just a student rebellion. It was the most serious challenge yet to the military junta that rules the country and the students were joined for the first time by young construction workers angered by a runaway cost of living. If the Government fails to resolve the economic difficulties that produced the angry coalition, the events of recent days may be a foretaste of more serious clashes to come.

title: Anatomy of the October Alert
description: WASHINGTONIt is the night of Oct. 24, 1973. President Richard M. Nixon is facing what he described two days later as the most difficult crisis we have had since the Cuban confrontation of 1962.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the slattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: Brown Is 3714 Victor
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 24Brown, long accustomed to the cellar, finished with its best Ivy League record in 15 years as it defeated Columbia today, 3714.

title: Energy and Ecology...
description: Few will quarrel with the finding of the United States Senate that a nationwide energy emergency exists. That is the driving force behind the Senate's overwhelming passage of a bill to give President Nixon wide discretionary powers to meet the energy crisis, as it similarly motivated New York City's decision to ease the restrictions on the sulphur content of fuel oil.

title: GOVERNORS SCORE NIXON OVER TAPE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24, (UPI)Less than 24 hours after President Nixon had assured Republican Governors this week that he knew of no more Watergate bombs, the White House dropped another oneand as a result the confidence Mr. Nixon had tried to instill at the Memphis meeting was damaged.

title: Officials Ask Holiday Donors to Check on Groups
description: With yearend holidays approaching, persons considering charitable donations were urged yesterday to check any doubts about fundraising appeals with the State Board of Social Welfare or the Contributors Information Bureau of the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: Rangers Tie Kings Here, 55
description: The Los Angeles Kings, a humble seventhplace club coming off a string of five straight defeats, invaded the home ice of the New York Rangers yesterday afternoon to embarrass the Rangers with a freewheeling 55 tie.

title: Penal Code On Juveniles Is Eased
description: TRENTONThe threat of long periods of reformatory incarceration for youngsters who commit minor offenses is being eliminated in New Jersey.

title: Peapack a Refuge For Mrs. Onassis
description: PEAPACKWhen Mrs, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis wants to lead the simple life, she escapes not to a showplace villa nor a lavish penthouse, but to an unpretentious sevenroom house that serves as a base for her frequent weekends in the country.

title: Rogan Guides Elis
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24The white handkerchiefs came out early today and the Yale fans were waving them in the taunting gesture almost as ancient as the 98yearold HarvardYale rivalry. The hankies came into view early in the fourth quarter after the Elis had scored their fifth touchdown in a surprising 350 rout of the Crimson before the Ivy League's largest crowd of the season, 41,247.

title: New & Novel
description: The Alchemist

title: Mrs. Susan Aschaffenburg Is Wed to William D. Hess
description: Mrs. Susan Jane Okun Aschaffenburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Okun of New York, was married here last evening to William Dargan Hess, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Hess of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: ATHENS MINISTER ABRUPTLY RESIGNS
description: ATHENS, Nov. 24Greece's chief prosecutor, Panayotis Therapos, resigned today as Minister of Public Order one week after martial law, imposed to quell a student revolt, stripped him of all power and made the Greek Army responsible for law and order.

title: Thank Heaven For Alfred Drake
description: CAN a Broadway musical version of a movie really do anything the movie couldn't have done as well, or better, in the first place? Well, yes, I suppose there are a few things, and they do help out where help is needed in Gigi.

title: G.M. Cut in Production to Affect 7,800 in the Metropolitan Area
description: Plans by General Motors to curtail auto production next month will mean a week's layoff for 7,800 auto workers in the metropolitan area, but 6,700, of them will receive nearly full pay and the rest will be eligible, for unemployment compensation.

title: Boiardo Associate Found Slain In Gangland Style in Newark
description: NEWARK, Nov. 24The body of 68yearold John Malangadescribed by the police as close associate of Ruggiero Boiardo, a reputed Mafia memberwas found with a bullet wound behind the right ear on Third Street near First Avenue.

title: A Visiting Birdwatcher Adds to List
description: MORRISTOWN  Alan and Elizabeth Durand live in a 400yearold, thatchedroof cottage in East Anglia, in the northeastern corner of England. The area, largely agricultural, is often teferred to as Constable Country because John Constable, the artist, grew up and painted there.

title: U.S. Riders Finish Year With Flourish at Toronto
description: The United States Equestrian Team's runaway victory at the Royal Winter Fair horse show in Toronto was astonishing in more ways than one.

title: Commuters Given a Credit
description: BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP)Motorists on the Mystic River bridge will he able to use their $2 commuter stickers for three additional months under an agreement reached between the Massachusetts Port Authority and the state Attorney General's office. The bridge was closed three months for repairs this summer and fall.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Edward J. King Dies at 57; Barnard Chemistry Head
description: Dr. Edward Jasper King, professor of chemistry and chairman of the department at Barnard College, died yesterday in Newcastle, England, where he had been doing chemical research, during a sabbatical at the University of NewcastleonTyne. He was 57 years old and lived at 54 Morningside Drive.

title: European Scene
description: PARISThe Arab oil weapon is hitting Arab friends harder than it is Arab enemies as oil shortages in Western Europe threaten to tumble the Continent into its deepest economic recession since World War II.

title: Jean Canale Is Bride
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 24  Miss Jean Christin Canale, personnel director with Bonwit Teller, Philadelphia, was married here this afternoon to Robert Gregory DeSantis, son of Mrs. C. J. DeSantis of Philadelphia. The Rev. John J. Weist performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Canale of Manhasset. Her husband is a real estate broker in Philadelphia.

title: State Aid Is Offered Historians And Artists
description: TRENTON  History and art buffs and professionals can now turn to the state for assistance in completing a favorite project. The aid, awarded in the form of grants, is available through the New Jersey Historical Commission and the State Council on the Arts.

title: Conservationist, Urban Style, Collects Land
description: Some people like to collect stamps or coins. Others save butterflies or fourleaf clovers. But Jack Gasnick, the 55yearold coowner of a Manhattan plumbingsupply and hardware store, prefers oddsized vacant lots.

title: Kerr on The Enclave
description: THERE is a party scene in Arthur Laurents's The Enclave that is meant to be awkward and false. Trouble is, It comes out awkwardly awkward and falsely false.

title: HiFi
description: DURING the questionandanswer period at a West Coast hifi show earlier this year a young man attacked me, as a presumed spokesman for quadriphorlics, with a series of rhetorical jabs: Isn't it true that all the fuss about fourchannel sound was cooked up by the equipment manufacturers so that they could sell everyone new sets? Doesn't the advent of quadriphonic records mean that our stereo records aren't going to sound as good as they used to? In sum, isn't fourchannel sound just a colossal ripoff?

title: U.A.W. ASSAILS G.M. ON LAYOFF TIMING
description: DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP)A top United Auto Workers official assailed General Motors today for ordering layoffs at 16 assembly plants before the Christmas and New Year's holiday break.

title: Shop Talk: On Right Track With a Train Specialty Store
description: LYNBROOK, L. I.  As Christmas draws near, parents are beginning to wonder what to give their children, many of whom they believe have just about everything already. Electric trains, an old standby that is drawing renewed interest, might solve, the problem.

title: Skylab Crew Takes Day Off for Rest
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 24 (AP)The. Skylab 3 astronauts, tired, behind schedule and still not organized, took the day off today to rest and tidy up their cabin in the sky.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX, the Government's measure of the cost of living, rose 0.8 per cent in October to 136.6 per cent of the 1967 base period. The largest increases were in housing and transportation.... The Treasury on Wednesday will auction $2billion of taxanticipation bills maturing in June plus $1billion of taxanticipation bills maturing in April.

title: Fight Is On to Save Antipoverty Project
description: NEW BRUNSWICKNew Jersey's local antipoverty agencies, set up under President Lyndon B. Johnson's Economic Opportunity Act of 1964, are facing a threatened cutoff of $15million in Federal funds from the Office of Economic Opportunity in Washington.

title: SKI INJURY RISKS PUT AT 6 IN 1,000
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (UPI)  The Insurance Federation of Pennsylvania says that six of every 1,000 persons who take to the nation's ski slopes for a day this winter will be injured, two of them seriously.

title: LITTER BASKETS NET CITY PROFITS
description: The hexagonal concrete litter baskets that have become familiar fixtures on busy streets in midtown Manhattan and in shopping districts in the other boroughs will soon begin paying dividends to the municipal coffers.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 25 (Reuters)  Premier Kakuei Tanaka today appointed Takeo Fukuda as Finance Minister in a Cabinet reorganization.

title: Kathy Reid Married
description: DEMAREST, N. J., Nov. 24 Miss Kathy Anne Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin K. Reid, was married here this afternoon to Jonathan Carl Watkins, son of Mrs. Edwin R. Watkins of Palo Alto, Calif., and Carl E. Rodehau of Douglaston, Queens. The Rev. Evan Jezioro and the Rev. James Tiller officiated at the ceremony in the United Methodist Church here. The bridegroom's name was changed legally to that of his late stepfather.

title: Center for Latin Students Approved for Columbia
description: Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, has approved final plans to establish a center for Latin students at the university before next fall.

title: JEWS ASSAY LIFE IN SMALL TOWNS
description: Jewish communities in towns with 250 or fewer Jewish families are concerned by their dwindling numbers, lack of communal services and isolation from the urban mainstream of Jewish life, yet they remain deeprooted communities with a strong will to survive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While the extent of the crisis of confidence in the President is difficult to assess, it would seem that it is due in great measure to those elements of the news media that have been attempting to promote this theme to the public in much the same manner that they sell their advertising: by innuendo, halftruths, exaggerations and the like.

title: The Flowering of Haiti
description: THERE are so many astonishing works in the show of Haitian primitive painting now at the New York Cultural Center, it's hard to pick favorites. But I know I won't soon forget one canvas by Pilom Obin, painted in 1945 and titled Apotheosis of Franklint D. Roosevelt. Roosevelt is pictured on a tower, wrapped in an American flag and with arms outstretched to a cloudy sky in which a cyclopic eye is set and two Byzantinelooking angels soar. A printed legend in French tells us that FDR is interceding in the beyond for the union of the Ameriand world peace.

title: Yule Tree Will Glow At State Arts Center
description: HOLMDELThe New Jersey Highway Authority will light the Garden State Arts Center's Christmas tree on Dec. 6. However, in the interest of energy conservation, it will eliminate illumination from decorations elsewhere on the Garden State Parkway.

title: EVIDENCE IS FOUND FOR BLACK HOLES
description: After a decade of debate on the possible evidence for black holes in the sky, British astronomers now say, based on observations with their instruments aboard the Copernicus satellite, that such objects definitely exist.

title: Ann Coleman Married to F. A. Lynn
description: Miss Ann M. Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Coleman of New York, was married here yesterday evening to Frederick Anson Lynn. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey D. Lynn of Franklin, Mich.

title: China Adventure: Are They Ready for Us?
description: IT is midday, Sept. I, 1973. I am on the southern border of the People's Republic of China. The air is hot and still. With my five companions, I leave the oneroom customs building in the border town of Lo Wu, which is controlled by the British crown colony of Hong Kong. We proceed on foot alternately over railway tracks and on a pathway alongside toward the doorway to China. The doorway is a covered railway bridge 100 yards ahead. It spans a narrow, muddy river called the Shumchun and leads to the red soil of the Chinese village of Shumchun and the lime green hills of Kwangtung Province. We enter the cool darkness of this bridge. Just one New York City block away a flag is hanging limply. It has five yellow stars on a field of red ... it is the flag of the People's Republic of China.

title: Marcel MarceauLook, Ma, He's Talking
description: LOS ANGELES SWEATING slightly in the sunlight his white shirt halfbuttoned, his plate full of sausage and fruit jelloMarcel Marceau could be any middleaged businessman relaxing by the Pacific on a Sunday afternoon.

title: Barbara Hartig Is Bride
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Nov. 24Miss Barbara Ann Hartig, daughter of Mrs. Sylvester J. Hartig and the late Dr. Hartig, a physician, was married here this afternoon to Robert Ternavan, son of Mrs. Joseph Ternavan of Dayton, Ohio, and the late Mr. Ternavan. Msgr. Vincent W. Jeffers performed the ceremony in the Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church. The bride is an administrative assistant with Grey Advertising in New York, where her husband is a marketing manager with the Arcata National Corporation, printers.

title: Futurism, Suprematism and Other Classics In Two Shows That Illuminate One Another
description: FOR anyone  amateur or professional, curious layman or devoted scholar  with an interest in the history of modern art, the two exhibitions that have now come to the Guggenheim Museum are events of capital interest. Both the Lydia and Harry Lewis Winston Collectiona significant part of which constitutes one of these exhibitionsand the Kasimir Malevich show, organized by Diane Waldman, the Guggenheim's curator of exhibitions, contain a great many works that are normally inaccessible to all but a few specialists. And what luck for all of us that the museum has managed to bring them in at the same time, fig they have the additional interest of illuminating each other in many interesting ways.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Before they decide the fate of the San Diego Padres, baseball's National League club owners will have to decide what to do about Marje Everett.

title: Army Little Guys Win Title Again
description: By defeating Cornell, 207 the Army lightweight football team won the Eastern Intercollegiate Lightweight Football League title for the fourth straight year, kept alive a 14game winning streak and completed its second consecutive unbeaten season.

title: Missouri Twister Destroys Mobile Home, Killing Three
description: EMINENCE, Mo., Nov. 24 (UPI)  A tornado touched down early today in this tiny southern Missouri Ozarks community and tore a mobile home to bits, hurling three persons to their deaths. About 30 homes were damaged and six destroyed.

title: Ashe Gains Tennis Final In S. Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, SouthAfrica, Nov. 24 (AP) Arthur Ashe made sports history today, becoming the first black to reach the men's final of the South African tennis championships as he beat Cliff Drysdale of South Africa 64, 6.3, 62. It is the first time Ashe is playing in the tournament, which has a $125,000 purse.

title: Puerto Rican Veterans Here Seek Aid
description: Officers of the National Congress of Puerto Rican Veterans have charged that more than 60 per cent of the Vietnam veterans of Puerto Rican extraction in the metropolitan area are unemployed and that little is being done to ease their plight.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Board Leaves Stand on Nixon Unchanged
description: The executive board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a special meeting yesterday, left unchanged its noncommittal stand on whether President Nixon should he impeached.

title: 3 MORE COUNTIES ADOPT CHARTERS
description: ALBANY, Nov. 24  Three more counties in New York stateAlbany, Chautauqua and Chemunghave adopted charters that provide for elected County Executives with wide powers to supervise the administration of their governments.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Dick Butkus, mean on the field as the Chicago Bears' middle linebacker, shows his sense of humor off the field: People talk about me retiring. Well, I don't know. If I was young, fast, healthy and had a lot of money and my whole sex life was ahead of me, I'd retire like Secretariat.

title: Purdue Pins 2823 Defeat On Indiana
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 24 (AP)Bo Bobrowski capped his collegiate career with a pair of touchdowns today as Purdue won the 49th Old Oaken Bucket game, 2823.

title: News of the Screen
description: Although MetroGoldwynMayer recently dropped out of the filmdistribution business and lost its president, James T. Aubrey Jr., the company is alive and well and ready to produce movies for theaters as before, said Dan Melnick, MGM's production chief. We expect to make at least six major films over the fiext year, the first two of which are all set, he said. And we should be announcing several others fairly soon.

title: UConn Tops Holy Cross on Late Kick
description: STORRS, Conn., Nov. 24 (AP)Greg Sinay, a freshman, kicked a 33yard field goal with 48 seconds remaining to give Connecticut a 109 victory over Holy Cross today.

title: Rebozo's Problem
description: WASHINGTONAs long as he was on the Watergate offensive, President Nixon apparently concluded, he might as well leave nothing in doubt. So he told a group of Congressmen a few days ago that there was no substance to reports that a $100,000 political contribution by Howard Hughes, one of the world's richest men, had been diverted to his personal useor, indeed, spent on anything at all.

title: Camera World News: Japanese Show Opens Thursday
description: THE Japan Camera Industry Association (a division of the Japan Light Machinery Information Center, 437 Fifth Avenue, New York, 10016) is sponsoring their 20th annual New York Japan Camera Show the end of this week, with the show scheduled to open on Thursday and continue through Sunday. To occupy the 18th floor of the Stotler Hilton Hotel on Seventh Avenue and 33d Street (the Penntop Room and the adjoining Skytop Room), the show will be open from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. on Thursday, Friday and Saturday; and from noon to 6 P.M. on Sunday. Admission will be free to everyone.

title: Aiding Environment at a Profit
description: GARFIELD  One of the state's most active environmental groups is rooted firmly in the profit motive. The group, which is called the Committee for Resource Recovery, was started here last year by the Garden State Paper Company, which felt that its existence was threatened by new garbagedisposal methods.

title: Newspapers in Cincinnati Are Struck by Teamsters
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 (AP)Cincinnati's two daily newspapers canceled all editions today as negotiations with striking teamsters continued.

title: The common cold of mental ailments
description: To all outward appearances, Barbara L. is an attractive and vivacious young Wall Street secretary. For most of her day in the office, her smile is bright and the flow of her conversation is fluent and lively. But once in awhile, Barbara's face becomes a gaunt mask and her voice flattens into a monotone, reflecting the dark mood that lurks beneath the surface.

title: Wash. State Is Victor
description: SEATTLE, Nov, 24 (UPI) Andrew Tones ran for three touchdowns and Chuck Peck passed for two today as Washington State clobbered Washington, 5226, and left the Huskies without a Pacific8 Conference victory for the first time.

title: ALBERT CONDEMNS NIXON FUEL POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) President Nixon has tried to distort history and blame Congress for energy shortages deeply rooted in his own policy, House Speaker Carl Albert said today.

title: Miss Gillespie Married Here
description: Miss Wendy Eileen Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Gillespie of Freeport, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to James Samuel Pilafian, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Pilafian of Coral Gables and Key Largo, Fla.

title: CONFEREES STUDY ASBESTOS HAZARD
description: DURHAM, N.C.More than 125 scientists from 13 countries gathered here in the midst of the tobacco country last week to grapple with an urgent public health question: What risk does the general public face from the ingestion of asbestos, a mineral of a thousand uses whose potentially lethal fibers pervade the human environment?

title: Off We Go aBrownstoning in Brooklyn
description: The curious went trooping through Brooklyn brownstones again last week, admiring the restorations, stepping gingerly around works in progress and doing mental calculations.

title: News of the Stage
description: Robinson Jeffers's free adaptation of the grim and gory Euripedes tale Medea, presented on Broadway in 1947, has been freely adapted by Eugenie Leontovich for Off Broadway as Jason and Medea.

title: Tigers Bow, 4224
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 24 Thanks to three touchdowns by Rick Klupchak, brilliant defensive plays by Jim Conterato and Yale's victory over Harvard, Dartmouth won its fifth straight Ivy League football championship today by defeating Princeton, 4224.

title: A Year After the Massacre of the Hutu, a Sort of Peace Settles Over Burundi
description: KITEGA, Burundi, Nov. 24 (UPI)In the cool mornings the women, tall and stately in their long cotton dresses, come down from grass huts in the hills bearing vast clusters of green bananas on their heads for the daily Kitega market.

title: Hope L. Baker, Attended By 4, Becomes Bride
description: DOVER, Mass., Nov. 24Miss Hope Lincoln Baker, daughter of Mrs. Talbot Baker of Millis and Pocasset, was married here this afternoon to Christopher Armstrong Pantaleoni, son of Mrs. Raoul Pantaleoni of St. Louis.

title: Los Angeles Fire Curb
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (UPI) Mayor Thomas Bradley signed an ordinance yesterday requiring compliance within one year on firesafety measures for old residential buildings, a move prompted by the Stratford Apartment blaze in which 25 persons died on Nov. 15.

title: Flood Brings Peace to a Park
description: MOUNTAINSIDENot too many months ago, the winding road through Echo Lake Park was regularly cluttered with motorists. But this fall, the park was turned back to strollers and hikers. The road does not go through the park anymore.

title: Favored Forego Takes Roamer by Five Lengths
description: Forego, one of the biggest horses in training at 17 hands, carried the heaviest burden in the field of 10 in the $56,800 Roamer Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Yet the Lazy F Ranch gelding handled the 123 pounds as if it were a feather.

title: Call Me Ishtar
description: Call Me Ishtar is an antiMosaic mosaic, a patchwork satire of patriarchy, sublimation and suburbia. The book has two stars: Ishtar, once the Sumerian deity of love and war (in later incarnations Mother Goddess, Queen of Heaven, Angel of Death, Whore of Babylon), and Rhoda Lerman, American firstnovelist of formidable gifts. Sometimes, like good sisters, they cooperate; sometimes, like prima donnas, they compete. The result is an imaginative embarras de richesses, an unresolved esthetic rivalry between narratives and narrators.

title: 75 Years of Recording Going for Scrap?
description: BOTH Columbia and RCA have been in the business of making phonograph records since the turn of the century, when putting music on disk first became technically feasible and a commercial reality. Over the past 75 years, millions of disks have been prodttced by these two companies and they document every colorful twist and turn in America's musical life. The economics of the record industry being what they are, only a tiny fraction of this extraordinary legacy is presently available for public scrutiny or scholarly study: Most of it sleeps in two New Jersey warehouses in the form of the metal parts from which the original disks were pressed.

title: The Firemen's Strike
description: Before we get stable labor peace in New York City, we're going to have a series of machismo strikes in all our key municipal services. One will build on another, just to prove that the unions aren't afraidfirst transit, then welfare, then sanitation and finally the real heavyhitters, police and fire.

title: Jennie Tourel, MezzoSoprano in Opera, Is Dead
description: Jennie Tourel, the opera singer and artsong interpreter, who was renowned fora her warm mezzosoprano, died Friday of lung cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived at 20 West 58th Street.

title: Increase Expected In DeerPoaching
description: TRENTON  New Jersey game officials expect an increase in deerpoaching this year, apparently because of spiraling meat prices and the beef boycott earlier in the summer.

title: Helen Pearson Displays Pro's Attitude to Racing
description: Most housewives only have to worry about the little thingsmaybe where next month's rent is going to come from or maybe the kids' marks in school or maybe how hubby is going to get home without being mugged on the subway.

title: Lynn C. Perry Riverdale Bride Of Law Student
description: Miss Lynn Catharine Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rowland Perry Jr. of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married here yesterday after noon to Michael Meade Chamberlin, son of Mrs. Helen Russell Chamberlin of Ralston, Neb., and C. Meade Chamberlin of Omaha.

title: Bucks Shut Off Hudson To Beat Hawks, 11292
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 24 (UPI) The 30point scoring of Bob Dandridge and a strong secondhalf defense gave the Milwaukee Bucks a 11292 N.B.A. victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: Trojans Triumph, 2313
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 Southern California, paced by Pat Haden's passing and Anthony Davis's running, bulled its way into the Rose Bowl again by defeating the University of California, Los Angeles, 2313, today before 88,037 spectators in Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT A MAJOR HOLDUP IN SUEZ PARLEY
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 24  Israeli officials said today that a major gap was still separating Israel and Egypt on the question of disengaging their forces along the Suez Canal.

title: Manipulating the young viewer
description: Broadcasting is regarded with some solemnity by the American people as crucial to our democracythe primary medium for disseminating information, for presenting (too infrequently) debates and for assembling and reassembling the parts for that protean American product called public opinion. But Americans maintain just as solemn a regard for free enterprise, despite the fact that it no longer exists in our society.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WHATEVER happened to inflation? Unfortunately, it is alive and well and being proclaimed in Washington. The announcement by the Labor Department Wednesday that the Consumer Price Index had soared 7.9 per cent in the 12 months ended in October was an unwelcome reminder that inflation is still with us and to an extent unprecedented in more than two decades.

title: Islanders 64 Victims Of Wings
description: DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP)Billy Collins scored two goals and assisted on one tonight lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 64 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game.

title: 4th Harrier Title in Row For Shorter
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP)Frank Shorter of the Florida Track Club beat Doug Brown of the University of Tennessee by 2 seconds today in winning his fourth straight national Amateur Athletic Union crosscountry championship.

title: How TV Tackles Football
description: WHEN the referee blows the last whistle in tomorrow night's Green BaySan Francisco game, the Thanksgiving weekend onslaught of televised football will finally end. Ten games will have been broadcast in the New York area; that's about a full day and a half of air time. Perhaps as many as 80 million Americans will have watched some portion of this pigskin orgy.

title: How a Celebrity Hangs Onto His Money
description: When a celebrity hits the jackpot, either of two things may happen: The money slips through his fingers and is gone. Or he hangs onto it and invests it. These days many a celebrity has called in an investment adviser to help him follow the latter course.

title: Rattlesnake Races And Other Musts For the Traveler
description: HERE are a few musts for your travel calendar:

title: Nancy Jackson Bride of Eric Sampson
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 29Miss Nancy Beth Jackson and Eric Bennett Sampson were married here this afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church by Commissioner Bramwell Tripp, territorial commander of the Eastern territory for the Salvation Army.

title: Environment: Dispute on Tourists Delaying the Kennedy Library
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24 Ten years after his death, a planned memorial to President Kennedy is stirring controversy in this city, so closely associated with his Administration.

title: Syracuse Drops Finale for Coach
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 24 (AP) Ben Williams ran for one touchdown and threw for another in the first half, leading West Virginia to a 24.14 victory over Syracuse today.

title: Federal Grant Supports ESP Dream Research at Maimonides
description: On the night of Friday, July 20, a young woman in Brooklyn dreamed that she had seen a coworker looking at a picture of a collapsed building on the front page of The Daily News.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: James S. Kunen expressed perfectly my feelings of the last two years (The rebels of '70, Oct. 28). Having graduated in 1970, I've been eying the college campus with considerable scorn (part of it stems from envy, I guess): I recently visited my old dorm and was terribly depressed to see how young everyone. looked. My God, did I once have such a glow? As a former S.D.S.er and parttime guerrilla theater star, I found the university shockingly still. Where was the outrage over Watergate? Hid the next generation of college students undergone frontal lobotomies?

title: Food Prices: Farmers Selling Corn After Levels for Beef Cattle Drop
description: BAGLEY, Iowa, Nov. 24As hard as it may be for harried consumers to believe, the price of fattened beef cattle had dropped so low this week and the price of corn had risen so high that many Midwestern farmers have stopped feeding beef cattle.

title: Anne S. Wightman Is Married to Richard A. Dubbs
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anne Schleiter Wightman, daugiiter of Mrs. Sdileiter Wightman of Stonington, Conn., and the late John Valentine Wightman, to Richard Andre Dubbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Dubbs of Atherton, Calif.

title: N.F.L. Still Seems Unable to Tackle The Uppers and Downers of Drugs
ENGINEERS STUDY NEW POWER PLANT
description: SAN DIEGOEngineers here are working on a gascooled breeder nuclear power plant design that could become a strong competitor with the liquid metal type of breeder to which the United States is now giving highest priority.

title: On Magruder, Rizzo, unfaithful wives and which child broke the lamp
description: One of mankind's most ancient and persisting concerns is to know when somebody  leader, lover, friendis lying. Throughout history men have been required to fight duels, swear on Bibles, fling themselves bound into ponds to demonstrate that they were telling the truthwith thin results. One man, however, who insists that he can solve this ancient puzzle is Rudolph R. Caputo, a pleasant, dark, roundfaced man of about 30. As director of investigations for Smith & Wesson, a security firm which grew out of the old smallarms company, Caputo is one of New York's leading liedetector experts. His list of clients includes C.B.S., McGrawHill and Morgan Guaranty Trust, to name a few. And it is some indication of how far we have come into the age of technology that his father was a liedetector expert before him, first in the Navy, and then as a Federal narcotics agent.

title: Evicted Widow Still in Jail
description: LORDSBURG, N.M., Nov. 24 (AP)An elderly widow who fought attempts to take part of her ranch for a proposed highway interchange remained in jail today for refusing to comply with a court order to abandon her protests. Sheriff Gene Morue of Hidalgo County evictcd Rita Hill, 71 years old, yesterday.

title: Bulletin Linking Tongs to Crime Brings Coast Official's Apology
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24Evelle J. Younger, California's Attorney General, conceded here this week that his office had goofed in disseminating a confidential criminal intelligence bulletin warning law enforcement agencies of Chinese fraternal societies' involvement in heroin smuggling and gambling.

title: Rockland Residents Concerned Over Water
description: NEW CITY, N. Y.Are the wells in Rockland County really running dry? Residents believe that many are; not only the wells, but the lakes and rivers, too.

title: U.S. Golfers Still Lead World Cup
description: MARBELLA, Spain, Nov. 24 Jack Nicklaus, who played lousy, and Johnny Miller, who did only slightly better, managed to hold on to the lead today after the third round of the 31st World Cup competition.

title: A NotSoGlittering Way of Life
description: JOHANNESBURG  Black men newly recruited towork in South Africa's gold mines begin their careers in a steam bath  but it is no luxury.

title: Television
description: IT'S NOT as if the news about television can't be good. The Columbia Broadcasting System is resuming analysis by reporters and commentators immediately following appearances by a President or other persons of public importance. When it suspended all instant analysis last June, the network was widely and justifiably criticized for reneging on a journalistic duty. Now, in a generous gesture rare for broadcasting's executive suites, CBS, or more specifically William S. Paley, the chairman, has conceded error.

title: PARK CRITICIZED ON BEAR KILLINGS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (AP)  More than 200 black bears were killed by rangers at Yosemite National Park from 1960 to 1972, a conservationist says.

title: Dogs Trained for Rescue Roles
description: RIVER VALEOne day last July, a call came into the Washington headquarters of the German Shepherd Search and Rescue. Dog Association. The caller reported that a soldier, by then AWOL from his base in California, was missing in Cascades National Park.

title: CRITICS FORM BLOC IN TAIPEI ELECTION
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 24Running on a common platform highly critical of the Government, four independent candidates for the Taipei City Council are adding interest to what would otherwise be a cutanddried campaign.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MILBURNIt doesn't matter how much or how little, you spend at Georg Jensen, for you can be sure that your money is buying good design.

title: Ford Makes Grant to Find Alternative to Gas Engine
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. 24 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company has announced an agreement with the California Institute of Technology to study alternative systems to the internal combustion automobile engine.

title: Baltimore Aide Loses Plea
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP)An attempt by Baltimore County Executive Dale Anderson to have a 43count bribery, conspiracy and income tax evasion indictment against him dismissed was rejected yesterday by United States District Court Judge Joseph H. Young.

title: Gang Mutilates and Kills Bronx Man
description: A South Bronx man died yesterday several hours after he was set upon near his home by a gang of a dozen youths who beat and sexually mutilated him.

title: Mrs. Scaife Is Remarried
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 24Mrs. Eleanor Carnochan Scaife, widow of the Right Rev. Lauriston Livingston Scaife, former Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western New York, was married here this morning to James Carey Evans, a widower, of East Aurora.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: MIGRANT WORKERS GET TRAILER CITY
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 24 A trailer city for migrant agricultural workers, replacing two crumbling labor camps razed by bulldozers last September, was opened here this week.

title: VESCO MENTIONED BY DRUG INFORMER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 For more than a month Senate investigators have been study ing allegations that Fedora agents suddenly ended a narCodes investigation after an undercover worker brought Robert L. Vesco's name up as the reputed financial backer of the smuggling of 100 kilograms heroin.

title: Bullets Alter Roster
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)The Capital Bullets of the National Basketball Association activated today Nick Weatherspoon, a rookie who missed 14 games with a broken right hand, and asked waivers on Torn Patterson.

title: Amos Rogers Little 3d Marries Nancy Powers
description: LOCUST VALLEY, LI Nov. 24  Miss Nal.ry Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustin Jay Powers Jr. of Glen Head, was married here today to Amos Rogers Little 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Little Jr. of Helena, Mont. and Jackson Hole, Wyo.

title: Quakers Down Cornell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24Marty Vaughn led Penn its second straight winning season on Franklin Field day, throwing three touchdown passes as the Red and Blue beat Cornell, 3122, before 24,559 fans.

title: Gogolak to Kick Off Army's Campaign
description: NEWARK  Pete Gogolak of the New York Giants will open the Salvation Army's Christmas effort tomorrow by kicking off footballs in Military Park.

title: Palestinians Leave Soviet After Talks on Homeland
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Palestinian leaders who arrived in Moscow a week ago to discuss the possible founding of a homeland left today to attend the meeting of Arab leaders, beginning in Algeria Monday, Arab sources reported.

title: Both Coaches Vote Roses for Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 24 (UPI)Ties usually don't settle anything, but both coaches felt the 10.10 deadlock Michigan and Ohio State played today decided which team deserves to go to the Rose Bowl.

title: I.S. Bids Japan Build Up Her Defense Against Subs
description: Senior military and civilian defense officials are urging security dialogue with Japan centered upon the pooling of antisubmarine warfare resources.

title: U.S. PARKING TAX FOUGHT ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (UPI)  Business, labor and other groups have banded together in a campaign against Federal parking controls that could cost Southern California motorists hundreds of millions of dollars a year by 1976.

title: Father Offering $1 Million For Getty Heir's Release
description: LONDON, Nov.24 (Reuters)  J. Paul Getty 2d offered $1million in American money today for information that would bring the release of his son, J. Paul Getty 3d, reportedly kidnapped in Italy last summer. The offer was conditional on the youth's being freed without further mutilation.

title: Free Parking Is Set In Newark Garage
description: NEWARKAs a special service to Christmas shoppers, free evening parking in the underground Military Park garage, in the heart of Newark's downtown business district, will begin tomorrow.

title: Kathryn Riis Jones Engaged To Waverly Gretter King 3d
description: HANOVER COURTHOUSE, Va., Nov. 24.Mr. and Mrs. Thomas David Jones Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Riis Jones, to Waverly Gretter King 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. King Jr. of Richmond.

title: Shahn Print Show Coming to Trenton
description: TRENTON  Eightyseven unusual prints by the late Ben Shahn will go on view at the New Jersey State Museum next Sunday.

title: The Crucial Capital Spending Boom
description: A major boom in capital spending is under way in the United States. Expenditures are rising rapidly, and business surveys point to a continuation of this upswing in 1974.

title: Dance
description: AS I write, there are no performances at the New York State Theater. The New York City Ballet is on strike. Perhaps by the time these words appear, the strike will be over. I hope so. In any event it will be one of the strangest strikes ever to hit the New York performing arts. And believe me, if you want a wellaccredited record of strange strikes, just look into the New York performing arts.

title: KENNEDY FAVORED IN POLL ABOUT '78
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is the overwhelming choice of Democrats to be the party's 1976 Presidential nominee, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON Although it is not much in the headlines these days, the battle of the budget has not been suspended in Washington.

title: 14 Injured in Fight in Spofford Dorm
description: A counselor and 13 inmates of the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx were injured Friday night in a brief disturbance at the center, the police reported yesterday. None of injuries was serious.

title: Margaret Dearth Wed To Rupert Alan Linley
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Nov. 24Trinity Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Margaret Deiley Dearth, daughter of Mrs. Walter J. Salmon of Roslyn Harbor and Walter A. Dearth of Easton, Pa., to Rupert Alan Linley, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Rupert Linley of San Diego. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nils Blatz.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH most homeowners know that modern apartment houses are wired for master antenna television receptionone antenna on top of the building serves all of the television sets in that buildingfew realize that this same type of convenience can be, easily provided in their own home. A high percentage of homes have more than one television set, but most still have only one antenna connection for the family set located in the living room or den. Other sets in children's rooms or bedrooms usually have to settle for marginal pictures using their builtin rabbit ear antenna.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association has leased 8,500 square feet of store and basement space in the J. P. Stevens Building at 1.185 Avenue of the Americas for a bank branch. The 25year lease has an aggregate rent of $3,750,000.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Not only does Lamar Hunt have one of pro football's better placement kickers in Jan Stenerud of his Kansas City Chiefs, but he is starting to breed his own. Lamar Hunt Jr., age 17, has converted 23 extra points in 24 tries for St. Marks School in Dallas, and father glows with pride.

title: Sessue Hayakawa Is Dead at 83; Silents Star Was in River Kwai
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 (UPI) Sessue Hayakawa, the motiorpicture star who won an Academy Award nomination for his role as the Japanese prisoncamp commandant in The Bridge on the River Kwai, died last night at Kyoundo Hospital of a cerebral thrombosis complicated by pneumonia. He was 83 years old.

title: The Beam Boom Is Clobbering Paris, La Belle
description: PARISMme. Dupont has been selling thimbles and thread just off the Place de la Contrescarpe for about 35 years. It was never a rich way of life here in the 5th arrondissement, but she made enough to eat well and always had time to gossip with the neighbors. But over the years the real estate developers moved in, renovating old buildings, raising the rents and causing an exodus of workingclass tenants. Now Mme. Dupont will go to live with her daughter in the suburbs. She has no choice. Lately she has been taking in only about $5.50 a day.

title: Showdown In Soccer Is Set Up
description: For a while, 40 minutes to be precise, they were both scared, but at the end events went normally for the soccer teams of St. Louis University and Southern Illinois at Edwardsville. They won their games yesterday to set the stage for another showdown between the two to decide who will go to the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer finals in Miami in early January.

title: Rains Ebbing, Phnom Penh Fears Attack
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 22  In Cambodia, the rain is merciful. It fills the fields and swells the rivers beyond their banks, turning much of the flat countryside into a vast, shallow lake through which no army can move.

title: Wilson Is Unruffled as Governorship Reports Fly
description: Most of the northbound cars jon the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway were racing beyond the emergency 50mileanhour limit last Wednesday morning, but there was Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, identifiable by the No. 2 on his license plate, working in the back of his limousine that was clocked at a judicious 52 m.p.h. as it kept to the right.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Cutting Off Nixon's Legs
description: If you cut the legs off the President, Richard Nixon told, a group of House Republicans recently, America is going to lose. And Newsweek magazine quotes Mr. Nixon as saying of his Vice Presidentdesignate, Gerald R. Ford, I know Jerry can do the job, but consider what it would do to the country and to the Presidency. ... It's me this year, but it will be someone else in the future. It would destroy the Presidency.

title: Coin Decides Election
description: ELYRIA, Ohio, Nov. 24 (AP) Kenneth Krueck was elected to the Elyria City Council on the flip of a cointhe method the Lorain County Board of Elections used to break a tie. He and Don Rothgery received 5,813 votes each in the Nov. 6 elections.

title: Irish Agreement
description: We had fed the heart on fantasies, The hearts grown brutal from the fare; More substance in our enmities Than in our love....

title: Saigon Planes Reported in New Drive On Communist Areas North of Capital
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 24The South Vietnamese Air Force has staged further large air strikes against Communistheld areas northwest of Saigon, military sources reported today.

title: No Easy Choices
description: WASHINGTONFaced with a fuel shortage of growing but uncertain dimensions and soon to be armed with broad powers to dictate a national response, President Nixon now faces that most unwanted of all executive decisions: a choice among alternatives that neither he nor most citizens like.

title: Agriculture Department Set To Consolidate Field Offices
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, has announced plans for consolidating county field offices of four major agencies in his department into central onestop service centers.

title: CHILD CARE HELD TO BE SCATTERED
description: Voluntary childcare agencies asserted here yesterday that they had markedly expanded services for troubled youngsters.

title: QuadropheniaA Hit from the Who
description: THE Who's past achievements have been so fine that any new release runs the risk of disappointing. A new Who set arouses almost unmatchable expectations among both rock fans and those devotees of more serious music who became interested in the Who in 1969, at the time of the group's first major rock opera, Tommy. It is thus a great pleasure to discover that the band's new opera, Quadrophenia (Track MCA210004, two disks), is a telling extension of what was begun with Tommy.

title: Dirck Born Marries Miss Emelie Sullivan
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24  Miss Emelie Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon B. Sullivan of Corning, N.Y., was married here today in Christ Episcopal Church to Dirck Ten Broeck Born, son of Mrs. Henry R. Brigham of Boston and Donald Born of Francestown, N.H., retired professor of English at Boston University. The Rev. W. Murray Kenney performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Swoyer Has Nuptials
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Nov. 24Miss Elizabeth Swoyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Swoyer Jr., was married here this afternoon to David S. Rahilly, son of Mrs. Bernard J. Rahilly of Westfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Rahilly. The Rev. William A. Jones performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. James Coleman.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Dec. 1Motorsport Club of North Jersey Christmas party at San Carlo Restaurant, 620 Stuyvesant Avenue. Lyndhurst, N. J., 7:30 P.M. Information: phone Paula (201)4384322.

title: State's Abortion Rate Soaring
description: NEWARK  She is usually single, white and in her early 20's. Others are 50yearold grandmothers, and some are even as young as 11.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1973

title: Isabelle Schuyler Pettit Married to Robert Seaman
description: EVANSBURG, Pa., Nov. 24 In St. James Episcopal Church, Perkiomen, here this evening, Miss Isabelle Schuyler Pettit was married to Robert Foster Seeman by the Rev. Edward Plaits.

title: A Roundabout Route to Nagare
description: An American art critic who, I am inclined to think, tops all the rest of us, wrote not long ago that you can stand in front of one of the late Barnett Newman's canvases and go through something like a mystical experience, then turn away and look back again and see nothing but a stripe on the wall. I can't locate the exact quote, but that is the gist as I remember it, and as a Newman nonfan I find the comment extremely revealing and frank to the point of confession.

title: Passionate Orator For Water Needs
description: Martin Lang, the Commissioner of Water Resources, is probably the only man who ever spouted Latin at the Board of Estimate to argue for a sewer aipropriation. It was one of those long sessions that dragged on into the night. Finally it came time for sewers, a subject that the Commissioner discusses with a sort of religious fervor.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: Tenant Leader Fighting Personal Battle
description: A tenant of a decontrolled apartment in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn who has been a leader in fighting for tenants' rights is now in danger of losing her own apartment.

title: Sihanouk Presses Drive To Win a Seat in the U.N.
description: PEKING, Nov, 24  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian leader, has appealed for further international support to get his government in exile seated at the United Nations in place of the Phnom Penh Government.

title: Two Careers Flourish in Exile
description: ARTISTS sometimes flourish in exile because of the stimulus of an alien, exotic environment, because of the perspective that distance lends to old, familiar life patterns or because a tyrannized spirit has been liberated in a democratic society. Flourishing in Freedom is the motto of this year's festival concert of the AmericanIsrael Cultural Foundation, which takes place on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. Three of the major participants fled their native countries: William Steinberg, who will be conducting his Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, left Nazi Germany in 1936; Mikhael Maisky, cello soloist, and Shlomo Mintz, violin soloist, both making their American debuts, are Soviet emigres to Israel.

title: For Nonconformist, Fledgling Skipper A Tugboat With Esthetics May be Thing
description: When Eddie Layton of Forest Hills, Queens, began to shop around for his first boat, he didn't want one of the lookalike white cabin cruisers that fill the harbors in the local area. Instead, he embraced nonconformity by putting his money down on a 26foot tugboat with an 80  horsepower Diesel engine, the third pleasure craft of its kind in the metropolitan region.

title: Insiders Working Outside the Establishment
description: GREAT NECK, L.I.While some young political activists are swallowing their fire to work within the system, a group of their Establishment elders here have quit the system to work from without.

title: Raiders 420 Victors
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. Nov. 24Mark van Eeghen scored three touchdowns today to lead Colgate to a 420 triumph over Rutgers before a rainsoaked crowd of 12,000.

title: Separation
description: Here is an English miner's wife talking about her 4yearold daughter Ever since I left her that time had to go into hospital [two periods, 17 days each, child aged 2 years] she doesn't trust me any more. can't go anywhereover to the neighbours or in the shopsI've always got to take her. She wouldn't leave me. She went down to the school gates at dinner time [lunch] today. She ran like mad home. She said, Oh, Mum, I thought you was gone! She can't forget it. She's still round me all the time.

title: Enrollment Estimate Of Colleges Reduced
description: ALBANY  Enrollment in colleges and universities in Nassau and Suffolk Counties will continue to grow, but at a slower rate than projected last year, the State Department of Education reported last week.

title: AIRLINES PRODDED ON FOOD HYGIENE
description: MANILA, Nov. 23  The World health Organization is urging member governments to supervise more closely hygienic standards on airplanes because studies have shown laxity that could lead to mass infections of passengers.

title: Marketing Institute Lists Mrs. Fenwick
description: TRENTON  Mrs. Millicent Fenwick, director of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs, will speak on The Modern Consumer at the New Jersey Marketing Institute next Thursday. The institute will be held at the Forsgate Country Club in Jameshurg.

title: Don Bosco: Practical Classes
description: PATERSON  Some students at Don Bosco Technical High School, which is marking its 25th anniversary this year, are so interested in class projects that they devote six days a week to them.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Appalled at Blacks' Trip to South Africa
description: To THE EDITOR:I read with amazement Peter Hawthorne's article Nov. 10 entitled, Ashe Match and Foster Bout Mean More Erosion of Apartheid.

title: Polio Victim Disregards M. D.'s And Safely Has Her First Baby
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP)  Despite the cautions of doctors, Gail Roszhart and her husband Terry were determined to have a babyand adoption seemed unlikely.

title: Site of Bun's Wedding Being Restored
description: HOHOKUSInitial steps toward the restoration of the GothicRevival house in which Aaron Burr was married are now under way.

title: Government and Press
description: I first got a vivid sense of the Governmentmedia relationship, in Washington at least, when, as an ambitious youth of 27, I sought, in the late nineteenfifties, the advice of exSecretary of State Dean Acheson as to what to be when I grew up. Older men are invariably charmed by such questions from the young since it gives them a chance to talk about themselves: so he graciously gave his answer over Beefeater martinis and crab Maryland at the Metropolitan Club. As I was sitting there, exhilarated by the presence of a score of Notables among our fellow lunchers, a murmur of excitement filled the room, and two men made their way slowly, in single file, toward a table at the end. From all over came respectful calls of greetingHello there, Scotty! Hi, Scotty! Good to see you, Scotty!to each of which the rather chunky man in front responded, archbishoplike, with a nod, gentle smile, and slight benediction of the hand. As conversation resumed, my host turned to his friend Paul Nitze at the next table and asked, Paul, who is that with Scotty Reston? I don't know, said Nitze, former Director of Policy Planning at the Slide Deparbnent. But I'll certainly find out, and I'll give you a call after lunch.

title: Decisions, decisions
description: ACROSS

title: On ShillyShallying
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22At some point the American people are probably going to have to think about the consequences of indecision: about not being able to resolve the Nixon question, not being able either to believe in him or to get rid of him.

title: ERIC ARCHDEACON, 76, RETIRED BANKER, DIES
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 24 Eric L. F. Archdeacon, a retired banker and former consultant to the Department of the Army, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: Where Begonias still Thrive
description: AS days grow shorter, there is less sparkle in the indoor gardenas some houseplants relax into a winter rest period. When this happens to nine, I rely on winterblooming begonias to pep it up.

title: Freighter Is Burning in MidAtlantic
description: A freighter laden with cargo of highly flammable sulphur was burning in the middle of the Atlantic last night, according to the Coast Guard, which said the ship had radioed an SOS and reported an explosion about 6 P.M.

title: Common Market's Mediator
description: BRUSSELS  In October, at the start of the Arab oil boycott against the Netherlands, FrancoisXavier Ortoli, president of the Common Market Cmmission, confidently predicted that the other eight nations of the European Economic Community would show their slidarity with the Dutch in the energy supply question.

title: The Real Tara Inspires Visions of Scarlett and Rhett
description: JONESBORO, GA.Eight years ago Herb Bridges, a letter carrier from Newnan, in the rural countryside about 40 miles from here, got into a friendly argument over who played the role of Belle Watling in the movie Gone With the Wind.

title: Extension of Pier 90 Planned, For Berthing of Larger Ships
description: Pier 90, at the Hudson River and 50th Street, the northernmost of the three adjoining piers that are being transformed into the city's new consolidated passenger steamship terminal, is scheduled to grow by 50 feet.

title: Jazz Scholars Get a Journal
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A new magazine on the market includes articles about Fats Wailer, Billie Holiday and Artie Shaw, along with long review of records by Miles Davis, the Modern Jazz Quartet, Charlie Parker and other jazz musicians.

title: Art With Link to L.I. Shown
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. Lovers of Long Island will be delighted by the joint exhibition of William Merritt Chase and his students at the Parrish Musem in Southampton and the Heckscher Museum in Huntington.

title: Son to the Pforzheimers
description: NEWPORT CENTRE, Vt., Nov. 24  A son was born Nov. 13 at the North Country Hospital in Newport to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pforzheimer of Newport Centre. The child has been named Jesse. Mrs. Pforzheimer is the former Miss Marguerite Trenhom Robb, Her brother, Charles Rohb, is married to the former Lynda Bird Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson and the late President Johnson. Mr. Pforz heimer and his twin, John, own the Stone Factory, here, where they manufacture pipes.

title: PHASEOUT RUMORS CUT H.D.A. MORALE
description: Reports that the Housing and Development Administration will be dismantled when Abraham D. Beame takes office as Mayor have already caused a serious loss of morale in the controversial city superagency, according to its administrator, Andrew P. Kerr.

title: Some Soviet Hunters Are Termed Barbaric
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24 (Reuters)The Soviet youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda has denounced barbaric motorized hunters.

title: CHILD CARE HELD TO BE SCATTERED
description: Voluntary childcare agencles asserted here yesterday that they had markedly expanded services for troubled youngsters.

title: Greyhound Pays Widow
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP)Mrs, Charles Cory, who had nine Greyhound buses seized when the company failed to pay a damage judgment has received $195,000 from the concern, her attorney Jim Nance, said this week. Her husband died in 1966 when a bus hit his truck.

title: Barbara Harnett Engaged
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Nov. 24Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence T. Hartnett have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ellen Harnett, to Joseph Francis Hunt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hunt of Troy, N. Y.

title: Rain Ends Stagnation Alert
description: NEWARK, Nov. 24 (UPI)The National Weather Service today ended a 36hour air stagnation advisory for 12 North Jersey counties after a front moved in with increased winds and rain. The weather service said the advisory, which would have remained in effect until midnight today, was ended at 12:30 P.M.

title: West German Kickers Win
description: STUTTGART, Nov. 24 (UPI) West Germany defeated Spain, 21, in an exhibition soccer match today before 70,000 spectators. Jupp Heynckes scored both goals for the Germans.

title: Warriors Vanquish Knicks by 10799
Article 3  No Title
description: Baseball's internal politics and power struggles, so often a source of trouble and inefficiency for America's oldest organized massaudience sport, has created a new mess in the still unresolved disposition of the San Diego Padres.

title: Sunday Observer
description: This story about the New York town that chose a blind man to censor its movies has been lying here on the desk for weeks demanding attention.

title: Sex Course At Nassau Seeks Men
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.  The instructors in a course on human sexuality at Nassau County Community College here say they are faced with the problem of how to get men interested in sex more particularly, how to get them to attend a course entitled Family Life and Human Sexuality.

title: Oil Shortage Hits Stocks
description: Like residents of the bayou country around New Orleans who listen impassively as hurricane winds build, never thinking to flee, investors knew four weeks ago that a storm was brewing.

title: Trooper, 2 Others Are Cited For Valor
description: NEWARKA policeman, a state trooper and a veteran fireman, all of whom risked their lives in the line of duty, have been selected as this year's Valor Award winners by the 200 Club of Essex County.

title: Architecture
description: E have a rather special interest in an exhibition of photographs called Landscape/Cityscape at the Metropolitan Museum (through Jan. 6) and our concern has very little to do with photography as art. That primary aspect of the show should be dealt with by the appropriate critics.

title: Israelis to Rename Streets
description: NATANYA, Israel, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Natanya, a resort town on the Mediterranean 18 miles north of Tel Aviv, is to rename two of its principal streets Richard Nixon Boulevard and Holland Street in appreciation of the friendship and aid to Israel.

title: Future Social Events
description: Energetic Exploration Nov. 28The Explorers Club dinner was once an annual tribute to members who had hewn their way physically through earth's unchartered corners. In recent years, the dinners have called attention to the precarious state of our environment. The theme of the 1973 dinner at the WaldorfAstoria is one that has us all in a brown study the Energy Crisis. Wilard C. Butcher, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, is chairman of the national dinner committee, which comprises the heads of 112 leading corporations. Cooperation like that ought to put a dent in the crisis. Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated:

title: A grand drama with a petit hero
description: Rightwing Government officials seek to use their positions to discredit political rivals. With the knowledge and probable authorization of at least one Cabinet member, and with the cooperation of the intelligence community, they fabricate evidence in order to convict the innocent. To protect their superiors, a vast coverup operation is launched while error and inconsistency are muffled in the cloak of national security.

title: Arab Talks Open With Attack on Israel
description: STAOUELI, Algeria, Sunday, Nov. 25Egypt's Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, declared at the opening of the Arab foreign ministers' conference here last night, that the Arab countries should step up their use of the oil weapon.

title: A Cultural Loop Through Brooklyn
description: Culture shock! That's what they called it on the new Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan Culture Bus Loop II as the bus crossed the East River.

title: Photography
description: THE trouble with selfexpression in the arts is that it so often keeps the artist from expressing anything else. There is a whole great world out there waiting to be expressed. There are ideas, sentiments and desires that are shared by great numbers of inarticulate people, and that will probably never be expressed at all in any public way if artists do not express them. There are things that are happening that affect us all, but the artist who is too preoccupied with himself may very well miss them.

title: The Economic Future of New York City
description: The powerful negative forces that have acted upon New York in the last two decades or so are essentially five in number.

title: Dov Schechter to Wed Miss Miriam Seidman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Hillel Seidman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Miriam Seidman, to Dov Schechter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Schechter of Far Rockaway, Queens. A January wedding is planned.

title: Toyota Raising Prices
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 (UPI)Toyota, Japan's largest car manufacturer, today raised the retail prices of all models by an average of 7 per cent. The increases, which will raise the prices of Toyota cars, trucks and vans by an average of $78, will apply only in Japan.

title: Boycott of 2 Nations' Goods Asked Because of Whaling
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  The International Wildlife Federation has urged a boycott of Japanese and Russian goods in this country. The group said that unrestricted commercial whaling activities by Japan and the Soviet Union were threatening extinction of the last great whales.

title: A Bright Red Accent
description: There was a time, within the memory of middleaged people, when the cardinal was only occasionally seen north of New York City and the lower Hudson valley. Now cardinals are yearround residents well up into New England, and that has changed the whole picture of the winter season in the northeastern region of the United States.

title: Syosset Defeats Bellmore Kennedy, 206, for Title
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov, 24 North Shore teams continued their dominance over their South Shore rivals in Nassau County today as Syosset defeated Bellmore Kennedy, 20.6, for the Conference I championship at Hofstra Stadium.

title: WALTER C. SHAW
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP)Walter C. Shaw, executive deputy commissioner of the state's Office of General Services and a former Schenectady County Republican chairman, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Glenmont. He was 55 years old.

title: CHARLES C. FICHTNER
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 24 (UPI)Charles C. Fichtner, former dean of the University, of Arkansas College of Business Administration, died yesterday at the age of 75.

title: Broadway Revisited
description: Broadway and the commercial theater may be on the critical list, but public interest in American drama appears to be growing with each passing year. Two books have appeared this fall, both eloquent witnesses to the abounding vitality, variety and quality of the New York theater during the first half of the 20th century. That one, On Stage edited by Bernard Beckerman and Harold Siegman (Quadrangle, $9.95; after Dec. 31, $12.50), contains facsimile reproductions of 500 New York Times reviews of plays that opened between 1920 and 1970; the other, The Lively Years, offers descriptions, discussions and illustrations of some eight dozen plays produced in New York City between World War I and the present time. These two books have one thing in common: boththe one mainly and the other whollyare the work of a man of whom it may be said without exaggeration that he exerted a greater influence than any other individual on the American theater of his day.

title: British Soldier Killed in Ulster As Guerrillas Set Off Land Mine
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 24A bomb explosion today killed a British soldier, the 200th to die violently, in Ulster since troops were deployed in the province in the fall of 1969.

title: The President's Problem
description: WASHINGTONIf there are any more bombshells, I'm not aware of them, President Nixon told Republican Governors in Memphis in response to their questions on Watergate. That was last Tuesday. On Wednesday, his lawyers went into court and disclosed that another conversation was missing from the subpoenaed White House tape recordingsthis one a portion of a meeting between the President and his then chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman, three days after the Watergate breakin of June 17, 1972.

title: Aquarium Is Trying To Breed Whales
description: The New York Aquarium bas established what officials there describe as thy. first whale breeding colony in the world. Four beluga whales that have been scientifically paired and tested for compatibility and procreative characteristics will be used in the program.

title: The Stock Market
description: WASHINGTONThe very large decline of the stock market in the past three weeksabout 12 per centreemphasizes an old point and may emphasize a newer one.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Color Pages of Magazines Cited As a Source of Lead Poisoning
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19 The color pages of glossy magazines and newspaper advertising inserts, may be significant sources of lead poisoning in children, according to a study made at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station.

title: Written as if by people from different planets
description: It is a truth not universally acknowledged, that the short story is so subtle an art form, and at the same time so independent of its surroundings, that a reviewer does violence to any collection if he reads it straight through, as he would a novel. Only frail, meagerly developed stories profit from such an approach; the accumulative momentum, then, provides assurance from story to story that the author has really constructed a world for us. The richer and more demanding the story, the more it forces us to participate in its imaginative drama; to read too swiftly a number of stories that require us to think and feel  like Mary Lavin's superbly artistic stories would result in exhaustion that might wrongly be attributed to the stories.

title: 4 P.M. Game at Shea
description: It is the paradox of Joe Namath that he can spark the Jets from seemingly insurmountable situations to victories or near victories (see Baltimore, 1969; San Francisco, 1971; Cincinnati, 1973), but when it comes to routine situations against teams with winning records, he not only fails to produce miracles, but he also seldom generates victories.

title: ABORIGINES BEGIN VOTE IN AUSTRALIA
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 24  Aborigines throughout Australia began voting today for a representative body that will give their depressed and abused race a voice in official decisions affecting their interests for the first time.

title: Chinese Are in No Rush to Join Olympic Games Nations
description: PEKING, Nov. 24China's future in the Olympic movement, in particular the prospects for participation in the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, has been cast into new perspective by the admission of the AllChina Sports Federation into the Asian Games Federation at the meeting of its executive council in Teheran last week.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor. Nora Sayre's extended remarks on Nigel Nicolson's Portrait of a Marriage are a disappointment.

title: BUFFALO REVIVED BY U.S. RANCHERS
description: MURDO, S.D., Nov. 24 (AP) Hunted nearly to oblivion 100 years ago by sportsmen, the shaggyheaded American buffalo is flourishing again on the western plainsthis time under the watchful eyes of ranchers and park rangers.

title: Livein Guards Curb School Vandals
description: ELK GROVE, Calif., Nov. 24  The graffiti on the walls of the lowlying brickandstucco William Daylor High School are gone now. The grounds around the fiveyearold building are newly landscaped. Small pine and elm trees are braced against the everpresent wind that blows through the long Sacramento Valley from Stockton, 30 miles south.

title: Veronica S. Mallory to Be Bride of Michael B. Stubbs
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Day Mallory of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Veronica Sealy Mallory, to Michael Bryant Stubbs of New York and Essex, Conn. He is the son of Mrs. Merrill Stubbs, also of Essex, and the late Mr. Stubbs.

title: Essex to Get Major Art Show
description: WEST ORANGE Nearly 400 painters and sculptors, from Picasso to men working behind prison bars, will be represented the 19th annual art exhibition and sale sponsored by the 3,700member Essex County Section of the National Council of Jewish Women. The show opens next Saturday at the Y.M.Y.W.H.A., 760 Northfield Avenue; and will continue through Dec. 5.

title: CHALLENGE IS DUE ON WETLANDS ACT
description: LIDO BEACH, L.I., Nov. 24 Three builders who want to fill in wetlands here for housing will challenge the state's Tidal Wetlands Act next Tuesday at a hearing at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: C. J. Hawkins 3d Marries Miss Barlow
description: ROANOKE, Ind., Nov. 24 Miss Barbara Ann Barlow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Barlow of Fort Wayne, was married here this afternoon to Charles John Hawkins 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hawkins Jr. of New York. The Rev. E. J. Miller performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bridge
description: In days of old, knights would gallop to the rescue in shining armor, full of confidence in the rightness of their actions. The knights of the bridge table occasionally gallop to the rescue, but they are rarely wellarmored and rarely sure they are right.

title: Florida Wins, 147; Halts Miami Rally
description: MIAMI, Nov. 24 (AP) Joel Parker, a flanker, caught a 7yard touchdown pass and a 29yard aerial to set up another score tonight as Florida's Gators held off a fourth  quarter charge by Miami to claim a 14.7 football victory.

title: Cyprus, a Laboratory of TruceKeeping, Offers Aid
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 24 (Reuters)The problems facing the United Nations emergency force in establishing checkpoints on the CairoSuez road are familiar to the United Nations peace force in Cyprus, which provided the first contingents for the Middle East truce units.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Symposium Slated On State's History
description: TRENTONThe Economic and Social History of Colonial New Jersey will be the theme of the New Jersey Historical Commission's fifth annual New Jersey History Symposium next Saturday. The symposium, to be held at the State Museum here, will feature papers on 17thcentury and 18thcentury agricultural and industrial land riots and religious and educational institutions.
