title: Danish rhymes, frog fears, bear facts and weighty troubles
description: These 14 Danish nursery rhymes are quite different from what we are used to, but they read easily and well. Almost immediately they begin to seem familiar to us in their warmth and simplicity, and with the generous help of the drawings. The translatorartist is a Dane recalling his childhood. Within that context his fullcolor pictures set different moods to evoke the particular feelings of a rhyme, and which are always rather unexpected.

title: Library Acts to Draw Adults
description: WOODBRIDGE  This city's Free Public Library is participating in a countrywide project in which libraries systematically reach out to promote independent adult education.

title: Air Base Shortens Day
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 24 (UPI)The lunch hour at Kirtland Air Force Base, the largest employer in Albuquerque, will be cut from 60 to 30 minutes in an energy conservalion move. A spokesman said the action would shorten the work day by 30 minutes in the evening, reduce noon hour driving and encourage the use of car pools and buses.

title: How to Succeed As A Producerat 19
description: THEATRICAL producers are old folks, right Middleaged, at best And rich. And much to worldly wise ever to revive a play that flopped its way through a mere 16 performantes only a year or so ago: Right. Now throw away at that and consider Stever Steinlauf, the 19year  old producer of the successful new Off Broadway revival of Moonchildren, a revival that had a majority of New York's critics turning handsprings and that may finally win Michael Weller's play the audience it was denied on Broadway in 1972.

title: Some Quakers Urging Pastor to Oust Nixon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 24 (AP)President Nixon's pastor says he is under pressure to drop Mr. Nixon's church membership because of the President's handling of the Watergate scandal and the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Turtles, Insects and Rats Tested in Soviet Satellite
description: A biological space satellite launched in the Soviet Union last month has been identified by the Russians as a major experimental science mission loaded with specimens ranging from white laboratory rats and steppe turtles to insects and fungi.

title: A view from the sidelines
description: During the last decade The New York Times's C. L: Sulzberger has interviewed de Gaulle, Pompidou; Heath, Brandt, Saragat, Palme, Tito, Kadar, Sadat, Nasser, Boumedienne, Mrs. Gandhi, Mrs. Meir, BenGurion, Yasir Arafat, Castro, Hussein, Allende, Papadopoulos, Debray, Johnson, Nixon, Kissinger and many others, some of them more than once. With the exception of Mao, Brezhnev, Qadafi and Idi Amin he seems to have talked to everyone who is someone on the international scene.,

title: Carolyn Lee Bride Of A. C. Wathey 2d
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 24  In the Congregational Church of New Canaan tonight, Miss Carolyn Craig Lee, daughter of Mrs. Richard Sherman White of New Canaan and the late Sydney Smith Lee of Orlando, Fla., was married to Albert Claudius Wathey 2d, son of Albert Claudius Wathey of Sint Maarten, Netherlands Antilles, and the late Mrs. Wathey. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony.

title: OAKLAND MURDER BAFFLES POLICE
description: OAKLAND, Nov. 24Nearly three weeks have passed since the electionnight killing of the school superintendent, Marcus A. Foster, and the growing indication here is that the police are still without any major clues in their investigation.

title: the traveler's world
description: APLEA for help appeared in the letterstotheeditor column in last sunary's Travel Section from a traveler who has had less success than I in avoiding movies on long airplane flights. She protested that stewardesses intimidate passengers into pulling down window shades and turning out reading lights, practically compelling them to suffer through the movies with or without the earphones, and she asked how one can avoid movies aloft.

title: Music
description: WHEN the Metropolitan Opera puts on its new production of Offenbach's Tales of Hoffmann on Thursday, it will not exactly be the Tales with which most people are familiar. Of course, many producers take liberties with this work. The City Opera production not long ago omitted the postlude. But, by and large, there has been a traditional sequence: the Prologue, followed by the Olympia scene; the courtesan act in Venice; the Antonia scene and the postlude. However, Offenbach did die before finishing the opera and there is some doubt about the actual sequence he had in mind. At the premiere in 1881 there were major departures from Offenbach's piano score. The director of the OperaComique feared that the Tales would be too long, so he cut, transposed and did other violence to the score.

title: Revolutionaries
description: don't succeed, only break out

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Maryland K. C. allbreed and obedience, Fifth Regiment Armory, Howard and Preston Streets, Baltimore; 2,237 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Boy Bitten by Cobra Better
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (UPI)  A 15yearold youth was declared out of danger today less than twodays after being bitten by a deadly Asian cobra in his home. Carmen Hicks, described by his father as an aspiring zoologist, was admitted to Einstein Medical Center Thursday after being bitten on the thumb while re moving venom from the snake. The hospital found an antivenom serum at the Philadelphia Zoo and it was administered to the youth.

title: Transit Fare Talks
description: There is a type of succinct beggar near the city's subway and bus stations who sidles up, shows some small change in his hand and gets to the point: If you can give me 28 cents more I'll be able to get home tonight ...

title: Young American Singers Wanted, the Ad Said
description: CHICAGO.

title: STATE PREDICTS CUTS IN DAY CARE
description: Ten thousand children in New York State could be forced out of daycare services either by new Federal eligibility or expected fee requirements, according to estimates by the State Department of Social Services of the impact of Federal rules that went into effect on Nov. 1.

title: Martin Dwyer Dies at 76; Headed Aerial Products
description: ELKTON, Md., Nov. 24Martin Dwyer, formerly a manufacturer in Merrick, L. I., of distress signals for the Army and Navy Air Forces, and more recently a land developer and cattle breeder here, died yesterday in Wilmington, Del. He was 76 years old and lived here.

title: College Admissions Quotas
description: Some colleges and universities, in recent years, have applied quota systems to admit more blacks arid members of other minority groups. This practice has provoked charges of reverse discrimination against whites and challenges to its legality. Last week, the United States Supreme court agreed to consider one of the challenges, a move that could have farreaching implications for minority access to higher education.

title: Friends of the Revolution, and an enemy
description: Seven Who Shaped Our Destiny

title: JAPAN IN BIG OFFER FOR A U.N. COLLEGE
description: Japan has pledged $100million as a step toward creating a United Nationssponsored international network of research organizations to open next fall with headquarters in Tokyo, it was announced here last week.

title: Letters: Architecture Critic Lobs a Few At Those Lobbies
description: To the Editor:A walk through the new skyscrapers of Manhattan's Sixth Avenue  or AveRue of the Americas, as the visitors call it  can indeed be, as Sasha Cavander says, a trip into another world (Lobbying in Midtown Manhattan, Travel Section, Nov. 11). The new buildings west of Rockefeller Center do form a new kind of landscape, different from anything we have seen before.

title: AROUND THE
description: Toss out unused 1973 seed and plan to buy fresh next spring.... Add some new plants to the indoor collection; grow a few unknowns to teach or polish green thumbs.... Keep bird feeders well stocked from now until spring; provide water, too.... Oil lawn spreaders before storing.... Tie down climbing roses.

title: OTB Holds Up Plan for New Brooklyn Office After Complaints
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation announced yesterday that it had halted planning on a branch in the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn and was reviewing a $115,000 rental commitment because of community objections to a gambling place.

title: Ellen Losch Betrothed
description: MIAMI, Nov. 24Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Losch of Miami, formerly of Woodmere, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Joy Losch, to Glenn A. Burten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin F. Burten of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Miami. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Questions, Answers
description: Although the nation seemed to be preparing for the energy crisis, many questions remained about its origin, its timing and its dimensions. Here are the answers oil experts are offering:

title: Gardens
description: COME to our conservatory is an invitation that a young Connecticut couple can offer their friends. Just one step down from their living room is a contemporary concept of Grandmothers Victorian plant room. Complete with wicker furniture and a fieldstone floor (slate would be too slippery), the indoor atmosphere is just about perfeet for all sorts of indoor plants that climb, hang, drape and pose.

title: Harold Salembier Weds Mrs. Townsend
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Nov. 24Mrs. Anita Higgins Townsend of New York and Oyster Bay was married here this afternoon to Harold P. Salembier of New York and East Hampton. The Rev. Carlton Lee performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Dance: 2 New Rod Rodgers Works
description: The Rod Rodgers Dance Company presented two new works by Mr. Rodgers on Friday night as part of the company's Holiday Weekend of Dance series at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street.

title: Travel Notes: A Raft Of Gimmickry Lures Ship Passengers
description: EARLY this year, Parohodstvo, the Soviet state shipping line, organized a cruise and invited Government officials and union leaders from the Soviet Union, Poland, East Germany and other Iron Curtain countries to sail abroad the good ship Mikhail Kalinin and participate in a seminar entitled Peace in the Baltic.

title: If Jane Austen Had Only Recorded Pride and Prejudice
description: NOT everybody likes to be read to, but authors love reading their stuff aloudsome writers are even quite good at reciting their prose. They bring to a work an extra dimensiona contagious enthusiasm, an instinctive understanding of the cadences inherent in the sentence structure, a tone which sometimes can help illuminate a point of view when the words on the page may seem equivocal in intention or attitude.

title: FIRE KILLS WOMAN; HUSBAND IS INJURED
description: A woman died and her husband was burned and injured early yesterday when a twoalarm fire extensively damaged their twofamily house in Brooklyn, fire officials reported.

title: Union Beach Seeks to End Fiscal Ties To the State
description: UNION BEACHMunicipal officials in this Monmouth County town may soon be able to hire a new policeman or a clerktypist without going hatinhand to the state government.

title: Music in Review
description: Juan Serrano, formerly of Spain but now a resident of Detroit, made his first recital visit to New York in some years to play his brand of flamenco guitar music at Tully Hall on Friday night.

title: Lindsay Looks Back, Citing Achievements
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that because of the introduction of modern management systems, the city government he will turn over to Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame on Jan. 1 is in the best shape it has ever been in.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The Winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Vote to Decide Big 10 Berth
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 24Michigan rallied for 10 points in the fourth quarter, but missed two long fieldgoal attempts in a frantic final minute that would have broken a 1010 tie with topranked Ohio State today.

title: The Region
description: Manhattan teems with hospitals. From BeekmanDowntown northward along the East River to the great complexes of Bellevue, New York University and Cornell to ColumbiaPresbyterian on Washington Heights, the island has one of the greatest arrays of medical institutions in the world employing tens of thousands of doctors, nurses and technicians. And newly released Federal data show that the physicians who quarterback this vast team also charge some of the highest fees in the world.

title: FARM UNION OPENS PUBLICITY EFFORT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24The United Farm Workers announced here this week that the union was opening a national public service advertising drive as part of its nationwide boycott of table grapes, iceberg lettuce and Gallo wine.

title: Paterson to Open Its First Shopping Mall
description: PATERSON  This city is about to open its first shopping mall. By Christmas, lights will twinkle in a small stand of trees newly planted along a 250footlong pedestrian walk, the first part of a $1.2million redevelopment of a onceprosperous downtown retail area that had fallen on hard times.

title: Frank Nero: At the Age of 26, He Wears Two Political Hats
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD Frank Nero is a young man who believes that the oldfashioned virtues of hard work and long hours pay off in politics.

title: What's Doing in HAITI
description: THE TOURIST AS PHILOSOPHER  Just sitting on the veranda of a hillside hotel in PortauPrince, the capital of Haiti, is almost an extrasensory experience. The colors seem more vivid, the scents more exotic, the atmosphere more mystical than just about anywhere else in the Western Hemisphere. Dusk setties over a city already hazy from thousands of charcoal cooking fires and the smell of charcoal and spices gently engulfs you. You may never be able to describe what you feel, but many years later, you will remember the feeling. This predominantly black, largely poor, mostly illiterate country has got to be the most fascinating, bewildering land in the New World.

title: W.H.O. Chief Asserts China Is Raising Health Standards
description: MANILA, Nov. 24China is fast moving into health standards of more affluent countries in the west, and her experience may prove an asset to developing countries, according to the head of the World Health Organization.

title: Calls for Firewood Send Price Way Up
description: BURLINGTON  Firewood is selling like the proverbial hot cakes in New Jersey this fall, and the price is going up as demand increases.

title: Supermarkets, bottled gas, plastic bags, swimming pools
description: On a return visit last spring to Peyrane, a village in southern France, I made sure to arrive just before noon so I could greet my friends at the apritif hour. Obviously several of them would not be there, for it was 23 years since I had spent a year in Peyrane and become a part of the group that met every day over a pastis. Still, I assumed that even though individuals might die, move away or stay away from the bar because of their livers, they would be replaced. In a tight little community, such a group, composed of the Town Secretary, the doctor, the postman, the notaire, the husband of the schoolteacher, the cafe owner, played an essential role as a nerve center. By spending an hour with them, was sure that no important event, past or present, would escape me.

title: Foster Bout to Break South African Race Barrier
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 24The return fight between Bob Foster the world lightheavyweight champion, and the South African challenger, Pierre Fourie, at the Rand Stadium here next Saturday night will be historic in more ways than one.

title: S. Africa Names Bertram
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 24 (UPI)  Byron Bertram was named to South Africa's 1974 Davis Cup team today joining Cliff Drysdale, Bob Hewitt, Frew McMillan and Ray Moore. South Africa will play in the American zone, meeting Brazil at Montevideo, Uruguay, Dec. 14.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: It's an ill wind that blows nobody good, and exploding letter bombs from the Irish Republican Army, Arab guerrillas and other terrorists have created a business opportunity for a new company in Hauppauge, L. I.

title: SCOUTS REJECT BOY FOR LACK OF FAITH
description: HANOVER, Me., Nov. 24Claude Taylor was not allowed. to continue as a member of a Cub Scout pack because he had crossed the word God out of the Scout Promise on his application.

title: Suffolk Prepares Major Transit Program
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.  The Suffolk County administration is in the, process of preparing a transportation program that it hopes will transform commuter habits and freight movements on the Long Island Expressway and the Long Island Rail Road  if the Federal and state governments chip in with the necessary support.

title: Ohio State Tied
description: Michigan tied topranked Ohio State, 1010, and Big Ten football officials will vote today which of the two unbeaten teams will play in the Rose Bowl against Southern California, which routed the University of California, Los Angeles, 2313. Section 5.

title: Forest Park Gets Restored Carrousel
description: The early nineteenhundreds have been recreated in a small part of Forest Park, Queens, with the opening of a restored 69yearold carrousel, complete with band organ, gaily colored animals and chariots.

title: APPEAL ON SEMINARY ISSUED IN CINCINNATI
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 Alarmed by the establishment of a group to consider the future of the four campuses of the Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion, faculty members on the campus here warned today that dismantling the Cincinnati campus could be disastrous.

title: Cleric Focuses on Newark Whites
description: NEWARK  The nation's only Protestant minister specifically ordained to serve the white urban community is a tall, 26yearold MennoniteturnedPresbyterian.

title: Knights Break the Ice in Jersey Tonight
description: Their new skates may be a little tight, and their uniforms may not be the grandest, and it's not Madison Square Garden, but the Jersey Knights will make their debut tonight in the Cherry Hill (N.J.) Arena.

title: What's New At the Movies?
description: THE FRENCH CONSPIRACY, directed by Yves Boisset from a screenplay by Ben Barzman and Basilio Franchina and starring JeanLouis Trintignant, Michel Piccoli and Gian Maria Volonte, got. 7 favorable reviews (Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Richard Natale, Women's Wear; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Judith Crist, New York; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World), 1 mixed (Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV) and 5 negative (Vincent Canby, Times; Martin Levine, Newsday; Molly Haskell, Village Voice; Gene Shalit, NBC; Pauline Kael, New Yorker). At the 68th Street Playhouse and Eastside Cinema. For Vincent Canby's view, see Page 1.

title: Smash
description: Lenore and Barry, Jane, Barry and Lynn

title: Group Learns to Use Potter's Wheel
description: EDISON  A marriage of industry and the arts, forged in sentiment, has produced thousands of pottery objects fashioned by a group of professionals and their students.

title: Rice Victory Is Delayed: Lightning
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 24 (UPI)Carl Swierc romped 99 yards with a kickoff today to wrap up Rice's 149 decision over Texas Christian University in a game halted 15 minutes by a bolt of lightning that struck inside Anion Carter Stadium.

title: Fuel Crisis Dims Holiday Lights
description: HARLAN, Iowa, Nov. 24 In a show of civic solidarity perhaps unrivaled since the Indian threat, this western Iowa community  the selfproclaimed Christmas Cityhas pulled the plug on all outdoor Christmas lighting this year because of the nation's energy crisis.

title: The Middle East
description: Three meetings, one in a dusty tent near the Suez Canal, one a summit of Arab leaders starting tomorrow in Algeria, and the third a peace conference scheduled for Dec. 17 in Geneva, are the likely stepping stones toward a just and durable peace for the Middle East. The Suez conferences between Israeli and Egyptian generals have been halting and difficult. Progress has been slow. The Algiers summit is likely to be a tough test for Egypt's President Anwar elSadat. The Geneva conference, the long hopedfor facetoface negotiations between Israeli and Arab, are still uncertain. For as New York Times correspondents Terence Smith and Henry Tanner report from Jerusalem and Cairo, the thoughts of Egyptians and Israelis are not filled so much with the hope of peace but the fear of renewed war. Their reports:

title: AIRLINES PRODDED ON FOOD HYGIENE
description: MANILA, Nov. 23  The World Health Organization is urging member governments to supervise more closely hygienic standards on airplanes because studies have shown laxity that could lead to mass infections of passengers.

title: Farrell Defeats Tottenville, 166
description: Tom Roche, a halfback, ran for two touchdowns as he paced Msgr. Farrell to a 166 high school football triumph over Tottenville at the loser's field yesterday in Staten Island.

title: N.Y.U. Fund Drive
description: New York University announced it was initiating an eightyear drive to raise $300million, the largest goal ever set by a university here. Details on Page 61.

title: Two Council Hearings Scheduled This Week
description: Following are open City Council hearings to be held this week:

title: U.S. Agencies Plan Moves To Cut Retail Drug Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Federal officials say they are studying two proposals that probably would significantly lower retail prices of prescription drugs.

title: Margaret Goldie Wed
description: Miss Margaret Ellen Goldie and Gordon Roberts Jones were married here yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. John Gosney. The bride is a daughter of John G. Goldie of New York and Dundee, Scotland, and the late Mrs. Goldie. Mr. Jones is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant Jones of Albuquerque, N. M.

title: Crime and Punishment in China
description: PEKINGMany things openly discussed in other societies are considered indiscreet here and one taboo subject is crime and punishment. When I asked Chu Muchih, a member of the Communist Central Committee and head of Hsinhua, the New China News Agency, how crime was reported in the press, he replied: Generally we don't report such things because they are not in the mainstream of life.

title: New and Recommended
description: BURR, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $8.95.) Using the device an autobiography cum biography of the textbook villain, Mr. Vidal slyly upends American history; the result is a wicked entertainment.

title: Harvard Professor's Wife Slain After Rape in a Cambridge Park
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24 (AP)The wife of a Harvard professor was apparently dragged off the street today, raped and then shot dead in Longfellow Park about a block from her home, the police reported.

title: Quarterbacks Unnamed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24  The New York Giants and Philadelphia Eagles will play their version of who's at quarterback tomorrow afternoon when they meet at Veterans Stadium.

title: Athletic Reform Costs Brockport Soccer Bid
description: Brockport State is big in soccer and has turned out 31 allAmericans to prove it. When the administration and the student government of the school near Buffalo failed to provide the team with the money to participate in the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoff, students and coaches staged a rally that resulted in separating athletics from the physical education department.

title: Gas Supplies Cut Off
description: DENVER, Nov. 24 (AP)The Public Service Company of Colorado says it has cut off natural gas supplies to some, customers twice this month because of short supplies.

title: Stanton Plans Open House
description: STANTON  This Hunterdon County village, a place where Hessian soldiers were imprisoned and food for Washington's army was stored, will be the site next Saturdaly afternoon of the 12th annual Holly Trail House Tour. This year's tour  its theme is The Twelfth Year of Christmas  also will include a visit to a recently restored village dating to 1750.

title: The First 100 Books Are the Hardest
description: One day recently I received two blows, each of such severity that only an Irishman with an unshakable belief in the goodness of God could recover from either of them without resort to some kind of pill or other. The first, the most serious, was the elimination of the Los Angeles Dodgers from the National League West pennant race, by an utterly colorless organization called, I think, the Cincinnati Reds. The second, and less severe, was the receipt of a royalty statement from my agent enclosing a check for $204.04, being the amount due to me after deductions for taxes and agent's fees for six months' royalties on 20 of my books.

title: Fuel: The Crisis Is Near
description: Many, many municipalities are having problems in obtaining the fuel they need, and we cannot help them. HERMAN CRYSTAL, deputy director of the state's Division of Purchase and Property.

title: Chess. Materialism, the Philosophy of Patzers, Yields to Mobility
description: Savielly Tartakower, the Franco  Polish grandmaster and wit, once remarked, It is always better to sacrifice your opponent's men. For the average club player, that advice is hardly neededit's the only principle on which he operates.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Wilt Chamberlain makes his Nassau Coliseum debut as coach of the San Diego Conquistadors Wednesday night when his team takes on the Nets. The Denver Rockets will face the Nets for the first time on New York territory Friday night. The Nets lost to both teams in recent visits. Game time is 7:35 P.M.

title: Dreams we all had and few of us care to remember
description: When Pop Art breached the walls of academic snobbery, it made possible the rediscovery of some of our best popular culture. Winsor McCay, for example, the creator of Little Nemo in Slumberland, has begun to receive the recognition he deserves. Little Nemo is a comic stripbut much more than a comic strip, especially in comparison to the debased examples of the form popular in America since the late thirties. It is an elaborate and audacious fantasy that suffers only slightly from the cramped space imposed by its form. It is, in effect, a giant children's book, though no more limited to children than Alice in Wonderland, the Grimm tales, or any of the best books for children.

title: QUESTIONS
description: If you hive a question, or know the answer to a question asked in these columns, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. We will publish questions of general interest and the practical solutions. Please enclose a stamped, selfaddressed envelope.

title: DAM OWNER SHUNS REPORT OF CRISIS
description: LOWELL, Mich., Nov. 24The nation's energy crisis does not bother Michael Thomas too much. He owns his own dam and generating station.

title: Small Cars Are Big As Buyers Respond To Fuel Shortages
description: Small cars, for years the automobile industry's unsung but steady performers, have in the last few weeks suddenly become the glamorous items on the market, with drivers rushing to trade in their big, gaseating cars with an urgency that automobile dealers throughout the metropolitan area describe as panic and hysteria.

title: U. S. Must Set Domestic Goals
description: Chairman, City Planning Commission The role of the Federal Government, with its superior resources, has traditionally been to provide funds and guidance. The principle that the Federal Government would support national programs administered by the states and localities to achieve national purposes was established as early as 1787, when the Northwest Ordinance provided grantsinaid for public schools.

title: Will TV Ever Get Religion?
description: WHY religious drama has been absent from primetime television is anybody's guess. Perhaps the powers that be have judged that it's just not commercial, that there's no audience for it. If, in the theater, satire is what closes on Saturday night, in videoland religious drama is what goes largely unviewed on Sunday mornings.

title: What's Opened in the Theater?
description: GOOD EVENING, a revue by Peter Cook and Dudley Moore, got 22 favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Watts, Post; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Reidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Lewis, Bergen Record; Glover; AP; Gayer, UPI; Harris, WCBSTV; S. Klein, WNEW  TV; Sanders, WABC  TV; Bookspan, WPIXTV; Probst, WNBCRadio; A. Klein, WNYCRadio; Woodruff, WMCARadio; Scudder, WINSRadio; Kalem, Time; Gill, New Yorker; Simon, New York; Clurman, Nation; Wunderlich, Cue), 1 mixed review (Kroll, Newsweek) and 1 negative review (Holder, WNBCTV).

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: DRILLING DISPUTE ON COAST REVIVED
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 24The energy crisis has revived a bitter dispute here over offshore oil drilling.

title: Stacy B. Lloyd 3d Marries Mrs. Anne E. Pepper
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24In St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, here this afternoon, Mrs. Anne Emmet Pepper, daughter of Grenville Temple Emmet Jr. of Katonah, N. Y., and Mrs. Eustis Emmet of Washington, was married to Stacy Barcroft Lloyd 3d, a freelance writer. He is the son of Mr. Lloyd Jr. of Christiansted, St. Croix, the Virgin Islands, and Mrs. Paul Mellon of Upperville, Va.

title: Hospital in Bergen Names President
description: ENGLEWOOD  Abram A. Lebson, who has served on the board of trustees of Englewood Hospital for 41 years, has been named president of the hospital.

title: H. Rap Brown Undergoes Surgery for Back Abscess
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 24 (AP)H. Rap Brown, serving a sentence for robbery, has been operated on for an abscess while hospitalized with pneumonia, authorities said today.

title: LAW FIRM ACCUSES NIXON OF CRIMES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24A public, interest law firm here published today an exposition of what it asserts are indictable common crimes committed by President Nixon.

title: A Shabby Fiction About JFK
description: DAVID MILLER'S Executive Action, with a screenplay by Dalton Trumbo based on a story by Donald Freed and Mark Lane, suggests flatly (or better, perhaps, states equivocally) that President John F. Kennedy was assassinated not by a single crackpot, who also happened to be an extraordinarily lucky shot, but by three professional gunmen working with the kind of precision that was totally lacking at the Bay of Pigs.

title: College Basketball: New Coaches, New Rules, Same Old No. 1 U.C.L.A.
description: Another college basketball season begins this week with many old coaches in new places, the use of the 30second clock, pioneered in the Big Eight Conference, spreading, and the same final prediction  another national championship for the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: HomeLoan Vote
description: TRENTON  As the laineduck session of the 195th Legislature prepared for its final meetings this week, Assembly Speaker Thomas H. Kean scheduled another vote for tomorrow on a controversial legislative compromise that would raise the stateimposed ceilings on interest rates on conventional homemortgage loans.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Plea for Coast Fishing Limit
description: Asserting that the time is long past for America to act to save its dwindling marine fishery resources, the actor and sportsman, David Wayne, an officer of SWIFT (Salt Water International Fishing Treaties), has called on the United States Government to establish a 200mile coastal fishing zone for five years.

title: Religion: Control Stressed at Krishna Children's School
description: DALLAS, Nov. 24  Krishna Kumari was telling her kindergarten pupils a story about Lord Krishna and a bee the other day when she stopped to scold boy for inattention.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Ethnic mysteries, when well done, have always attracted a wide audience. The Inspector Ghote novels of H.R.F. Keating are a good example; the reader is diverted by the intricacies of a solid plot, but along the line there are illuminations of an alien culture. Tony Hillerman's DANCE HALL OF THE DEAD (Harper & Row, $5.95) is a fine example of the subgenre.

title: Boulder Brook Show
description: Children's Working Hunter ChampionshipChampion, Mrs. L. A. Warren's Direcho, 9 points; reserve, Lisa D'Ambrosio's Irish Blarney, 6.

title: L.I. Yacht Club Is Riding High
description: Last month, the South, Bay Cruising Club held a Discoverer's Day at Great River, L. I., to commemorate Columbus Day.

title: Ringo Dishes Up a Hot Fudge Sundae
description: HOW dreadful to have been a Beatle! Even if John Lennon.

title: Bernard Finch Wins Plea
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 24 (UPI)R. Bernard Finch, who served 12 years in a California prison for the murder of his wife, will take a test next month in an attempt to regain his medical license. Cole County Circuit Court Judge Byron Kinder said Tuesday that he could find nothing to indicate that Finch's moral character was had and upheld an earlier ruling that said he must he administered the test.

title: UNIVERSITY SHIFT UPSETS SPANIARDS
description: MADRID, Nov. 24  About 100,000 college freshmen in Spain, to the annoyance of their parents, have suddenly found themselves with nothing to do until January because, without warning, the Ministry of Education has changed the school calendar.

title: Counseling for Executives Is Losing Luster
description: The corporate financialcounseling business, which sprouted three or four years ago and became one of the new prerequisites of top management, is beginning look a bit faded.

title: Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Eleanor Ahbe Bride of W. N. Thomas 3d
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 24Miss Eleanor Anne Ahbe of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Leavitt Ahbe of West Palm Beach, and William Neil Thomas 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Neil Thomas Jr. of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Hunsdon Cary Jr. performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of BethesdabytheSea.

title: Are Museums a Luxury?
description: In an article, It Costs Too Much to Go to a Museum, on this page Nov. 11, Judi R. Kesselman complained that families are no longer able to drop in on museums now that museums have cash registers at the door and suggested fees that run as high as $1.50 for an adult. The money it might cost can buy hamburger for the evening meal. The responses to the article were numerous and largely approving. A reply to Mrs. Kesselman from the Director of the Metropolitan follows, along with comments by other readers.

title: Alfreda A. Liebmann Is Married
description: RYE, N. Y., Nov. 24In the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection here this afternoon, Miss Alfredo Ann Liebman was married to John Thomas Casey Jr. by the Rev. Clayton F. Nenno.

title: Stephanie Lucas to Wed
description: Miss Stephanie Lucas and Frank S. Tarnopol, teachers in Newark, plan to be married Saturday at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue. Jerome Lucas of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Tarnopol of the Bronx.

title: Jenkins Gets Party Post
description: LONDON, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Labor Party leader, Harold Wilson, has picked his former deputy, Roy Jenkins, as the opposition party's main spokesman in the House of Commons on home affairs. Mr. Jenkins was brought back into Labor's shadow Cabinet earlier this month after resigning from it 18 months ago, over the party's lukewarm attitude to Britain's membership in the European Common Market.

title: U.S.Aussie Davis Cup Final Shapes Up as Dandy
description: The Davis Cup, overshadowed in recent years by the sudden affluence in organized tennis, will resume its role as the premiere attraction in the sport Friday when the top professionals from the United States and Australia meet in Cleveland to decide the world team championship.

title: Women Pressing Adoption Campaign
description: WESTFIELD  New Jersey's, 152 Junior Women's Clubs are pressing their campaign for $25,000 and volunteer services to assist Spaulding for Children, an adoption project unique in this state. The club's drive follows the action taken at the annual convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs, at which delegates chose the private nonprofit agency as the Junior Club project for 197374.

title: MURRAY SHAPIRO
description: Murray Shapiro, retired president and founder of the Educational Equipment Company, designer and manufacturer of toys for children, died Thursday of a heart attack in Metropolitan Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 340 East 28th Street.

title: 3 Networks Will Carry Talk by Nixon Tonight
description: The three major commercial television networks announced yesterday that they would televise live at 7 P.M. today President Nixon's address on the energy crisis.

title: $300Million in Private Funds Sought in 8Year N.Y.U. Drive
description: New York University is heginning a $300million, eightyear private fundraising paign, one of the larger campaigns conducted by any institution in the country and the largest ever here.

title: Numismaties
description: IF high auction prices are an indication of strength in the hobby, numismaics has never been stronger. It is especially noteworthy that the surge in prices is not limited to such exotic items as the dubiously legal 1913 Liberty Head nickels and the noncontemporary presentation 1804 silver dollars. Tremendous interest is also being shown in the lowly cent, specifically the large copper cents of the 1790's and early 1800's.

title: Big A Regulars Oppose Sale
description: Five days a week, Carmine DeLuca drives a bus to Aqueduct Race Track in Ozone Park, Queens, where his passengers, their dreams wrapped up in The Daily Racing Form and the latest hot tip, wrestle with the odds and Lady Luck. But even the horses momentarily took second place recently when word spread that the Big A might be closed down and replaced by a sports complex in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Aristotle and Plato and Socrates were born too soon to flourish as National Football League philosophers. Centuries too soon. But their genius lives. Norm Van Brocklin, the coach of the Atlanta Falcons, is among us today. On the sideline during the game with the New York Jets, he will smoke cigarettes and talk to a guard, who will convey the next offensive play to the quarterback. In those moments of contemplation on strategy, the philosopher in him is dormant while the practitioner thrives. But in repose, Norm Van Brocklin often says more in a few words than most coaches do in a few days, or a few seasons. Not all of what he says is pleasant. Not all of it is even polite. But then, he is not trying to win friends. He is trying to win football games.

title: ...Fixing the Blame...
description: As Americans increasingly realize that the energy crisis is not just a passing annoyance, the search for scapegoats has begun, with the environmental movement a choice and obvious candidate. In an eloquent refutation of such demagogy John R. Quarles Jr., Deputy Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, points out that the longoverdue burdens imp posed by environmental concern have fallen on the nation's energy industries just at the moment when they are under severe strain for reasons having nothing to do with the environment.

title: Theater in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN. THE Long Wharf Theater in New Haven has acquired a reputation for presenting new British plays in excellent homegrown productions. One imagines Arvin Brown, the artistic director at Long Wharf, flying off to London every year on a shopping trip and returning with a bulging bag of scripts ready to be put into rehearsal. His latest offering (through December 14) is a new British playnew to us, at any ratethat is actually some 60 years old: The American premier? of The Widowing of Mrs. Holroyd, by D. H. Lawrence. And now when people ask if any really distinguished new work has appeared in the American theater this season usually an embarrassing questionthey can be confidently directed to Mr. Brown's theater at Exit 46 of the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: Houses Using Solar Energy Planned in Las Vegas Area
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 24 (UPI)Houses designed to save up to 80 per cent of the energy normally used in the average household are planned for the Las Vegas area, an Energex Corporation official said yesterday.

title: CLAIRE DODD DIES; FORMER ACTRESS
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 24Claire Dodd, who was considered one of the most beautiful blonde actresses in motion pictures in the nineteenthirties, died here yesterday after long illness.

title: 2 G.O.P. Leaders Step Down a Peg
description: TRENTONThe scorecard will reflect a few changes, to say the least, but there will still be some familiar names in the Republican leadership when the new Legislature convenes here on Jan. 15.

title: Two in Gang Linked to Slaying Of Senator Percy's Daughter
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (UPI)Two members of a gang of housebreakers were linked today to the unsolved slaying seven years ago of Valerie Percy, daughter of Senator Charles H. Percy, The Chicago SunTimes reported.

title: Lack of U.S. Funds Hurts Morris Housing Unit for Needy
description: MORRISTOWN  The Morris County Housing Authority, which was established more than a year ago to help local communities build apartments for the poor and the aged, has yet to be asked for aid by any of the 35 eligible municipalities.

title: The Energy Crisis: A Biological Vantage Point
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  One of the central themes in biology is the flow of energy through the ecosystem. Given the amount of this energy available to a species and data on birth and death rates, ecologists are able to make fairly accurate predictions of the species' population dynamics. As far as we know man is no exception.

title: ... Finding Solutions
description: In its authorization for immediate action, the Senate bill, like the programs suggested by the Administration so far, focuses on fuel conservation measures of relatively limited scope. It would allow the President to set highway speed limits, prohibit or curtail Sunday pleasure driving, reduce advertising lighting and prescribe maximum temperatures for office buildings.

title: Bukharin and the Bolshevik Revolution
description: Years later, long after he was dead, Bukharin's fox was still racing around the Kremlin, which was empty and desolate by that time, and playing hide and seek in the Tainitsky Garden  Svetlana Alliluyeva, Twenty Letters to a Friend.

title: 3,709 Boardwalk Entry 2d Best in U.S. for '73
description: The Boardwalk Kennel Club has come a long way in a short time. This comparative newcomer in the showgiving world will be staging America's second largest show of 1973, when it holds its seventh fixture next Sunday at Convention Hall in Atlantic City.

title: NIXON TO REVEAL STIFF FUEL CURBS IN TALK TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 President Nixon will announce tomorrow night what he described today as tough, strong action to meet the energy crisis. The principal steps are expected to be a ban on the sale of gasoline on Sundays and reduced distribution of home heating oil.

title: Stamps
description: THE humble postage stamp now ranks as the world's most expensive manmade item, considering that $250,000 was paid several year ago for the unique 1cent black on magneta of British Guinea, 1836a square inch of paper, with dogeared corners a smudgy postmark and a badly rubbed surface.

title: Trooper, 2 Others Are Cited For Valor
description: NEWARKA policeman, a state trooper and a veteran fireman, all of whom risked their lives in the line of duty, have been selected as this year's Valor Award winners by the 200 Club of Essex County.

title: Asphyxiated Couple Found In Car by Upstate Hunter
description: ILION, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP)A hunter today found the bodies of Lyle Ellsworth, 21 years old, of West Edmeston, and Lynn Marie Coffin, 15, of Frankfort, in a car off a rural road in the town of German Flats, the state police reported.

title: Library Of Art Critic Donated
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.IThe extensive library of Aline B. Saarinen, the late art historian and critic, has been abated to the Parrish Art Museum here.

title: Tenn. Stops Kentucky in 1614 Game
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. Nov. 24 (AP)  Bill Rudder raced 60 yards for a thirdperiod touchdown and Tennessee survived a late Kentucky rally for a 1614 Southeastern Conference victory.

title: News Summary and Index
Chavez and the Farm Workers
description: WASHINGTON  Si as puede. Yes, it can be done. That has been the motto, the rallying cry, of Cesar Chavez and his embattled United Farm Workers Union in their long struggle to organize the Chicano field workers of California.

title: BenGurion's Condition Is Now Termed Serious
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 24 (Reutors'The condition of David BenGurion, Israel's veteran elder statesman and first Premier, was reported to be serious tonight.

title: Brooklyn Horse Club Rides Into Jersey
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.A graceful musical cotillion on horseback preceded the Brooklyn Riding Club's gala Thanksgiving dinner dance last week, marking the group's 25th year of continuous riding. The club, which was founded at the turn of the century, disbanded for a few years and then regrouped in 1948.

title: Princeton Will Hold Tennis Jamboree Saturday
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24 A tennis jamboree featuring Arthur Ashe, Roscoe Tanner, Bob Lutz, Herb Fitz Gibbon, Gene Scott, Marjorie Gengler and players from Princeton University will be held next Saturday in the school's Jadwin gymnasium.

title: IMPEACHMENT BOOK OFFERED BY A.C.L.U.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)The American Civil Liberties Union made public today a handbook listing 17 things it said citizens could do to bring about the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: RCA Space Center Set for New Probe
description: PRINCETON  It started in a former rug factory, and it has now grown into a $25million, 400thousandsquarefoot complex that was the birthplace of 82 unmanned satellites now orbiting the earth.

title: Shultz Meets Finance Chiefs in France
description: AUTHON, France, Nov. 24Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz met today with colleagues from France, Britain, West Germany and Japan to discuss reform of the world monetary system, according to a communique issued in Paris.

title: Sub Sahara Rainfall Is Sparse for 6th Year
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 24 The annual rainfall in the sub Sahara was sparse this year, and a good portion of the hopedfor harvests of millet, sorghum and peanuts sits stunted in dusty fields or baked, halfgrown, beneath the yellow sand.

title: Tulsa Is Upset
description: WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 24 (AP)Wichita State scored three touchdowns in the second half today and upset Tulsa, 2819, in a Missouri Valley Conference game that dropped Tulsa into a share of the championship with North Texas State.

title: Broadcasting and the Government
description: The relationships between the United States Government and the licensed media have never been more in need of dispassionate and realistic analysis. This has never been a tranquil area, but recent events in Washington have raised the debate to new levels of intensity. Harry Ashmore's Fear in the Air identifies the critical areas of confrontation, but the net effect is that of a waterbug skittering over the surface.

title: OZARKS SHIFTING FROM OIL HEATING
description: POTOSI, Mo., Nov. 24 (AP) A number of persons living in the rural Missouri Ozarks only recently took advantage of innovations to heat their homes. Fuel oil, natural gas and propane heating units were taking the place of coal and wood.

title: Yule Bazaar to Aid School in Princeton
description: PRINCETON  The annual Christmas Bazar of Stuart Country Day School will be held next Saturday, starting at 10 A.M. The fundraising event has been held each year since the school was opened in 1963.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY EXHIBITIONS
description: PARENT'S MAGAZINE GALLERY, 52 Vanderbilt Ave. Photos by Nancy Dubin. Hours, 9 is 5 weekdays. Through Friday.

title: 16 in Africa Press Powers to End Aid To Racist Regimes
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 24Ministers from 16 East and Central African countries have called for diplomatic, economic and other sanctions against the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Japan, and Brazil unless they cease support for the white minority regimes of southern Africa.

title: BREZHNEV TO SEEK BACKING IN INDIA
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, will open new foreignpolicy offensive Monday with, a visit to India that will serve as a testing ground for Soviet strategy Asia in the postVietnam era.

title: Judith Kennedy Vermont Bride Of John Brown
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Nov. 24Miss Judith Anne Kennedy, daughter of Mrs. George Barber Jost of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Spofford Lake, N. H., and John J. Kennedy of Tempe, Ariz., was married here this afternoon to John Larzelere Broom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Broom of Rye, N. Y.

title: Stubborn Pitt Bows, 3513 By GORDON S. WHITE Jr.
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 24Penn State's mighty defense took control at the start of the third period today and stalled Pittsburgh's offense completely while the undefeated Nittany Lions moved from a 10point halftime deficit to defeat Pitt, 3513.

title: I.R.B. HEAD DENIES TAX HARASSMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) Donald C. Alexander, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, says his own investigation showed that the agency was not used to punish enemies or reward friends of the Nixon Administration.

title: Pioneer Streaking In For Study of Jupiter
description: After a 22month, 600millionmile voyage from earth, the first into the outer reaches of the solar system, Pioneer 10 is within 5,8 million miles of Jupiter and streaking in fast for man's first closeup examination of the planet that is so massive and turbulent that it is sometimes considered the stillborn twin of the sun.

title: Paul McKean Madden to Wed Sandra G. Coxe on March 30
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24  Miss Sandra Gordon Coxe, who will graduate next month from the University of Denver, plans to be married here March 30 to Paul McKean Madden, who will graduate is the spring from the University of Colorado.

title: N.F.L.'s Growth in '75 Seen
description: Quietly, the National Football League is moving slowly but surely down the road toward expansion.

title: Elizabeth Herberich Wed to L.A. Sneed
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Nov. 24 The Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Ann Herberich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Alfred Herberich of Westfield, to Larry Alan Sneed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Sneed of WinstonSalem, N.C.

title: Late Listings of TV Today
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: PERSEPOLIS RISING IN ANCIENT GLORY
description: PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Nov. 7 The grandeur of the ancient Persian religious capital of Persepolis is becoming a little more evident every year as a result of restoration work being done at the ruins on a barren, dusty, sunbaked hillside under the direction of five Italian specialists.

title: Miss Francine Grimaldi Has Nuptials
description: Miss Francine Grimaldi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfonse Grimaldi of Mount Vernon, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Stephan Koskinas, son of Mrs. Thomas Koskinas of Tenafly, N. J., and the late Mr. Koskinas.

title: Movies
description: NEED a cop? Try dialing 911. If that doesn't pan out, you might as well trot on down to the local bijou, where you're sure to spot a whole brigade of men in blue blazing their way across the silver screen.

title: Columbia Dedicates a Building To Help Teach Handicapped
description: Columbia University's Teachers College has dedicated a building designed and equipped to train teachers to diagnose and teach handicapped children.

title: Dr. Logan Dies in Fall
description: Dr. Arthur C. Logan, a board member of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation who was widely regarded as one of the most influential black leaders in the city, died yesterday in a fall from the 135th Street viaduct of the Henry Hudson Parkway. Details on Page 34.

title: Action Is Rumored In Exchange Rates
description: TOURS, France, Nov. 25 Ministers of the five leading noncommunist industrial powers met today for the second day at a Loire Valley chateau a few miles south of here to discuss ways to make the monetary system more stable in the face of a threatened world economic decline.

title: Lawri Sager Is Bride of Myron Cohen
description: Miss Lawri Sager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sager of New York and Deal, N. J., was married here yesterday afternoon to Myron Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cohen of North Miami Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed at the Carlyle by Rabbi Abraham Moseson of West Hempstead, L. I.

title: Major Bills In Congress
description: Nov. 26, 1973 ENACTED

description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25A coalition of minoritygroup students and faculty members at Princeton University is mounting a campaign for the cancellation of a debate scheduled here between Roy Innis, the director of the Congress of Racial Equality, and Dr. WilHam B. Shockley, the physicist and Nobel laureate.

title: French Rush to Make Le Havre Top Supertanker Port
description: LE HAVRE, FranceFifteen miles up the coast, dredges are clanging day and night, creating an oil port that will ultimately be able to handle tankers of up to 1 million tons.

title: Use of Lexington Ave. IRT, Busiest Line in City, Drops
description: The city's busiest subway routethe Lexington Avenue IRT Line  has suffered a patronage loss amounting to nearly one passenger in seven at its Manhattan stations over the past decade.

title: Living With Illusion
description: Over Thanksgiving we permitted ourselves a certain amount of selfcongratulation at the way the United States has responded to the disclosure of lawlessness in its leadership. It is still a good country, we said; it did not let evil go unnoticed; the system worked.

title: Answers in Fuel Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Following are some questions and answers concerning the impact of the fuelconservation neasures that were announced by the Administration tonight:

title: Cahill Expected to Press Jahos Nomination to Bench
description: FREEHOLD, Nov. 25The counsel to Governor Cahill said yesterday that he believed the Governor would press ahead with plans to nominate the director of the New Jersey Division of Criminal Justice to a Superior Court judgeship despite the opposition of the State Senate.

title: BAD STOCK NEWS LIFTS BOND PRICES
description: The bond marketthe baleful old man of the securities ousinesscocked art eye last week at the stock market's slump and took some satisfaction in the apparent bleakness of the outlook. Bond prices made their strongest advance in two months. The reasoning was simple. If the energy crisis should cause a recession bad enough to justify the steep decline in stock prices that got under way Oct. 29 and lasted at least through Nov. 21, the demand for credit very likely will diminish. Traders and their customers would therefore he working with a relatively small supply of bonds, which would tend to firm up pries.

title: SPY SAID TO LINK CHAPIN WITH HUM
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Donald H. Segretti has told Watergate prosecutors that was Dwight L. Chapin, while President Nixon's appointments secretary, who first alerted him early in 1972 to expect a telephone call from E. Howard Hunt Jr., according to sources close to the case.

title: Still Another Milestone For The Mousetrap'
description: LONDON, Nov. 25 (Reuters)  Britain's theatrical world today celebrated another longrunning record for Dame Agatha Christie's The Mousetrap, the first play to be performed continuously in the same theater for 21 years.

title: Pacers TopNets, 126124
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov: 25 Watch out! warned the Indiana Pacer statistician with about a minute left in the game tonight, Here comes Roche, the hottest. 3point player in the league,

title: Broncog Beat Chiefs, 1410, Take A.F.C. West Lead
The Whale Killers
description: Japan would have the world believe that it must eliminate the whales of this planet to satisfy the protein needs of its people. There is every reason for the world to believe, instead, that Japan's declared refusal to abide by the quotas set by the International Whaling Commission last June has much more to do with greed than with need.

title: Esso's Chief Sees Wider War. Risk In Mideast Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) An oilindustry executive said today that there was a risk of a real conflagration between the big world pimers unless a Middle East peace settlement was reached within a year.

title: Dan D. Coyle, Princeton Aide Who Led Information Unit
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25Dan D. Coyle, former director of public information at Princeton University and a member of the university's administration for nearly three decades, died today at his home near Centreville, Md. He was 57 years old.

title: Drive for Discipline In Fire Department Planned by O'Hagan
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that he would reestablish discipline to counter the breakdown of authority of superior officers over rankandfile firemen.

title: Dr. Arthur C. Logan Dies; Surgeon and Civic Leader
description: Dr. Arthur C. Logan, a board member of the city Health and Hospitals Corporation and a wellknown physician and surgeon, fell to his death yesterday from a viaduct of the Henry Hudson Parkway in upper Manhattan.

title: Pope Urges Christians To Face Energy Crisis
description: ROME, Nov. 25 (UPI)Pope Paul VI called upon Christians today to face the growing energy crisis with public spirit and to help one another through difficulties.

title: GOING OUT
description: PREMIERE Ned Rorem is only 50 years old, too young to be called a grand old man of American music, but he's a prolific and noted composer whatever you call him. The composer is midway in a twonight stand of his music at Alice Tully Hall, 65th Street and Broadway (EN 21911).

title: George Woodbury, Columnist And Editor in New England
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Nov. 25 (AP)George Woodbury, newspaper columnist and literary editor, died yesterday at Manchester Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Pop Music: Osmonds at the Garden
description: They oohed and squealed aver Donny, they ached and screeched over Little Jimmy. all 4 feet of him, belting his falsettoed way through Blue Suede Shoes. And so it went on at Madison Square Garden on Friday, when the Osmonds, all brothers in a family that obviously doesn't believe in zero population growththere are six of themcame back to New York.

title: Strategy Described as a Disaster by City's Official
description: President Nixon's plan for dealing with the nation's energy crisis was described by New York City's top energy official last night as shortsighted and inadequate, on the ground that it did not include rationing of fuel oil and gasoline.

title: The Sun Rises Earlier on Block Island as Town Tries to Save Fuel
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Nov. 25The day begins an hour earlier here than on the rest of the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Jets, Giants Beaten; Ohio State in Bowl
description: Both the New York Jets and Giants were defeated yesterday in rainy National Football League contests. The Jets, even with Joe Namath at quarterback, were beaten by the Atlanta Falcons, 2820, at Shea Stadium. At Philadelphia, the Eagles beat the Giants, 2016.

title: ISRAEL WILL JOIN THREE ARAB FOES IN PEACE PARLEY
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 25Israel accepted today an American proposal that she attend peace talks with Egypt, Syria and Jordan on Dec. 18.

title: MILITARY COUP IN GREECE REMOVES PAPADOPOULOS; NEW REGIME BEGINS PURGE
description: ATHENS, Nov. 25President George Papadopoulos, the former colonel who seized power here in 1967, was ousted today in a military coup.

title: Tenants Group Accepts A Plan to End Rent Strike
description: NEWARK, Nov. 25A monthold rent strike with strong racial overtones appears to be nearing an end here. The strike, a protest against an alleged lack of proper building security and other services, involves more than 60 tenants in the Zion Towers, a twoyearold, 28story highrise in the city's South Ward.

title: NIXON SECRETARY LINKED TO ERASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25President Nixon's personal secretary erased a key 18minute segment of one of the most important Watergate tapes, Administration officials said today.

title: Experts See Blue Skies Beyond Market Gloom
description: A number of stockmarket professionals, peering beyond the November fog on Watt Street and an energy crisis engulfing the entire nation, see better prices ahead for 1974.

Shockley, the physicist and Nobel laureate.

title: The Age of Ambiguity
description: PARIS, Nov. 25Sweet are the uses of ambiguity.

title: Jews Pray at Site of Fires At Synagogue in Brooklyn
description: Representatives of 11 Orthodox Jewish synagogues in the Flatbush, Gravesend and Sheepshead Bay areas of Brooklyn gathered yesterday in front of a twostory yeshivasynagogue that was destroyed by fire last Thursday and prayed that such things not happen again.

description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Arabs Hijack a Dutch Jet Carrying 288 in Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, Nov. 26Arab hijackers seized a Dutch jumbo jet with 288 passengers and crew members last night in a flight over the Middle East.

title: Moderates in Ruling Israeli Party, Spurred by the War, Fight to Unseat HardLine Leaders
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 25A major power struggle has erupted between hawks and doves in Israel's ruling Labor party in the wake of the October war.

title: Heart Research Has Key To Sudden Fatal Attacks
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25Psychologists and cardiologists working with dogs at the Harvard School of Public Health have linked Pavlovian methods and American technology to unlock the secret of why so many people die suddenly.

title: JOHN F. NOCE
description: LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 25John F. Noge, a violinist and retired faculty member of the New York College of Music, died yesterday in Memorial General Hospital in Union. He was 69 years old and lived at 449 Pelham Street.

title: Miss Amy L. Brinberg Wed to Bruce Kapner
description: RYE, N.Y., Nov. 25Miss Amy Lynn Brinberg and Bruce David Kapner, graduate students at the State University of New York at Buffalo, were married here today at the Westchester Country Club by Rabbi Samuel Silver.

title: Truth or Honesty
description: About two years ago, I showed a section of a book I was working on to a friend who appeared as a character in it. After she finished reading it, she said, But I never said some of these things. And it was much more complicated. If you remember....

title: Joseph Verner Reed, Patron of the Stage, Is Dead
description: Joseph Verner Reed, a founder of the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., and a leading patron of the American stage for a generation died yesterday in MemorialSloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 71 years old and lived on Jupiter Island, Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Two British Soldiers Killed On Patrol in Londonderry
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Nov. 25 (Reuters)Two British soldiers were shot and killed by guerrilla gunmen here tonight in a fresh outbreak of violence across Northern Ireland.

title: The Lights of Rotterdam Blaze Defiance of the Arabs' Embargo
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 22This great port, the biggest on earth, is spending energy as if there were no tomorrow.

description: BOXING

title: Bruins Defeat Kings, 31, For 8th Straight Victory
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25, (UPI)Ken Hodge scored two powerplay goals as the Boston Bruins beat the Los Angeles Kings, 3.1 tonight in a National Hockey League game and extended their winning streak to eight games.

description: The following is a supple. mentary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, Nov. 26Arab hijackers seized a Dutch jumbo jet with 288 passengers and crew members last night in a flight over the Middle East.

title: Mass Transit Experts Urged to Take a Bus
description: PRINCETON, Nov. 25 (UPI) Federal, state and local officials taking part in tomorrow's statewide conference on mass transit are expected to he given a realistic example of the problems presented by the automobile.

title: Jersey Aide Assails Intervention by U.S. In Sitin at Ramapo
description: MAHWAH, Nov. 25  Ralph A. Dungan, the state's Chancellor of Higher Education, has denounced as unnecessary Federal conciliation efforts that were instrumental in settling a sitin by a group of minoritygroup students at Ramapo College here last week.

title: 300 Demonstrate Here At the Greek Consulate
description: More than 300 demonstrators gathered in the rain outside the Greek Consulate yesterday afternoon in the wake of the coup d'tat that toppled the Government of President George Papadopoulos.

title: ExP.O.W. Will Marry
description: DENTON, Tex., Nov. 25 (UPI) A former prisoner of war in Vietnam, Lieut. Col. Warren Robert Lilly, has announced he plans to marry another Air Force pilot's widow, Mrs. Jill Parker Snow. She is an airlines stewardess he met on kind of a blind date last April.

title: A Guide to Maximum Mileage Based on One Tank of Gasoline
description: With the President's proposed ban on Sunday gasoline sales, the nation's drivers would be limited on Sundays to the mileage they could squeeze out of one tank of gas at the optimum.

title: Driver Found Slain in Rockland Is Son of Alleged Mafia Member
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 26The 20yearold son of an alleged Mafia member, dressed in the tuxedo he had worn to his brother's wedding, was found shot dead last night in a locked car with a revolver on the floor beneath his feet.

title: Stage: Visit Opens Phoenix Season
description: The New Phoenix Repertory Company could hardly have got its sevenweek season off to a better start last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. It gave us Harold Prince's brilliant new staging of Friedrich Dun renmatt's The Visit, one of the most stimulating and engrossing of all the plays written since World War II.

title: Pomeranian Is Best in Maryland Show
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 25A pert Pomeranian from New York, Ch. Sheeba's Little Dragonfly, owned and handled by Sam Zaneoff, was named best of 2,217 dogs at the 61st annual show of the Maryland Kennel Club in the Fifth Regiment Armory today.

title: Kungfu Films Irk the Experts
description: Kungfu had an honorable place alongside the karate, Korean tae kwon do and other martial arts exhibited yesterday at gymnasiums at City College and at Harlem River State Park. But hardly anybody had a kind word to say for kungfu movies.

title: Giacomin 50 Victor
description: Ed Giacomin did it again last night  a shutout, his third in five games, this time by a score of 50 over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Soviet Oil Find in Tatar Region Is Disclosed
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25The Soviet Union has successfully tapped new oil reserves in the Arlan oilfields of the Tatar region west of the Urals.

title: 150 Firemen Given New Assignments In Wake of Strike
description: Some 150 city firemen are being transferred today in the wake of the fiveandahalf hour strike by the Uniformed Firefighters Association on Nov. 16, a department spokesman said.

title: Pentagon Has Given Bonuses Of $3,500 to Retain Bandsmen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Because the Pentagon considers them to have critical military skills, more than 100 musicians were given an average of $3,500 in reenlistment bonuses last year so they would keep on playing such instruments as the piccolo, oboe and bassoon.

title: Ottawa Captures Grey Cup
description: TORONV, Nov. A (AP) A former Syracuse University star, Rick Cassata, threw a 38yard touchdown pas to Rhome Nixon in the first quarter and the Ottawa Rough Riders went on to win the Grey Cup today with a 2218 victory over the Edmonton Eskimos in the Canadian Football Leagues championship game.

title: Astronauts Test Cameras on Skylab
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 25 (AP)The Skylab 3 astronauts repaired and tested equipment today to get ready for their first full week of scientific study of the earth, the sun and the comet Kohoutek.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Arab World: Fighting Instills a New Confidence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21The Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, telephoned Hafez alAssad, the Syrian President, just after the Arabs' armies attacked Israel on Oct. 6, according to a fable making the rounds of Arab capitals, and the following dialogue ensued:

title: Browns Subdue Steelers, 2116, on Pruitt's Dash
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 25The Pittsburgh Steelers lost another game and another quarterback today. They may recover from both although they now have the pesky Cleveland Browns, today's victors by a 2116 score, breathing on their backs. The Pittsburgh starting quarterback, Terry Hanratty, lasted only three plays before leaving with a sprained right wrist which was to be Xrayed for a fracture after the team returned to Pittsburgh tonight.

title: 4 European Countries and West Berlin Spend a CarFree Sunday
description: HERLESHAUSEN, West Germany, Nov. 25The superhighways were bustling with traffic today and Sunday drivers were wandering through the countrysidebut only in East Germany.

title: Holiday Ends Here On Warm, Wet Note; Highways Crowded
description: The temperature rose to 65 degrees, a record for the date. just after noon yesterday as the long Thanksgiving weekend came to an unseasonably warm but seasonably wet end.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's busiest subway routethe Lexington Avenue IRT linehas suffered a patronage loss amounting to nearly one passenger in seven at its Manhattan stations in the last decade.

title: PHILIP O'CONNELL
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP)Philip P. A. O'Connell, a former assistant United States attorney, died yesterday at a nursing home here. He was 78 years old.

title: Falcons Down Jets, 2820; Giants Defeated by Eagles
description: The rain kept 14,000 fans home and sorearmed Joe Namath on perilously slippery turf yesterday, but three plays that involved neither the weather nor the quarterback turned out to be the significant keysto the jets' 2820 loss to the Atlanta Falcons.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Many Stations in City Area Already Closed on Sunday
description: Many service stations in the metropolitan area were already closed yesterday in anticipation of President Nixon's request to Congress for a ban on gasoline sales on Saturday night and Sunday.

title: Order to Save Bison Issued
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The Alaska Fish and Game Department has issued an emergency order to protect a rare white bison seen in the Copper River basin near Glenalien.

title: Answers in Fuel Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Following are some questions and answers concerning the impact of the fuelconservation measures that were announced by the Administration tonight:

title: WHITE HOUSE UNIT TAKES ON NEW LIFE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25For several months this year it appeared that the White House Office of Communications, the tough and ready operation that Charles W. Colson used last year to promote Richard Nixon's Presidency, was about to become a casualty of the Watergate scandals.

title: Rare Comic Books Stolen
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 Vintage comic books valued at $1,500, including a rare edition of Spiderman, were stolen from the People's Comics Store during the weekend. Terry Zwigoff, a partner in the store, said prices on many of the 1,000 missing comics ranged. from $25 to $40 each. Among them were mintcondition copies of Captain Marvel, Avengers, Fantastic Four, Iron Man, and Thor, he said.

title: Navy to Increase Security To Curb Sailors' Violence
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (AP) The commander of the Pacific Fleet has ordered increased security to stem mounting violence committed by gangs of sailors against other naval personnel, a Navy spokesman said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PLUNDERED PAST. By Karl E. Meyer. 353 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $12.95.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HASHIMOTO, Japan, Nov. 25 (AP)  At Geiberger of Santa Barbara, Calif., won the, individual title today in the United StatesJapan golf tournament with a threeround total of 218, but the Japanese took the team honors by 17 strokes.

title: ACTION REPORTED IN ARTS STRIKES
description: Efforts will be resumed today to resolve strikes that have halted performances the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and the New york City Ballet, and have curtailed exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Poor Hurt by College Program Shift
description: A change in Federal and state guidelines for College Bound Programs serving high school students in disadvantaged city areas has left many of the schools with severely curtailed programs, according to a city school official, while schools in the more affluent Queens and Staten Island areas maintain full programs with city funds.

title: Midiskirts Get a Warmer Reception the Second Time Around
description: Three years after the midiskirt was hooted off the scene by irate women determined not to hide their knees, it's back again. The difference: This time there is little ballyhoo and no insistence. Long skirts will hang alongside the more numerous shorter, ones in store stocks and women will be invited to make their choice. We're not making any great leap this time, explained Bill Blass, who said he believes knees should be covered this spring, but isn't getting up on any soapbox about it. The thing that happened in the midi disaster was that skirts dropped from the middle of the thigh to the middle of the calf. It was just too much for people to take.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Qaddafi Tells Israel Settlers to Go Home
description: PARIS, Nov. 25  Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the leader of Libya, said today that the only permanent settlement of the Middle East conflict was for all Jews who emigrated to Israel after 1948 to return to their lands of origin, and for Palestinians to regain their homes.

title: Recently Published Books
description: A Decade of Music by B. H. Haggin (Horizon Press, $10). A collection of essays.

title: Scali Out of Intensive Care
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 25 (UPI)  John A, Scali, the United States representative to the United Nations, was transferred from the intensive care unit to a regular hospital room today, five days after he underwent open heart surgery here. Dewey Schade, administrative assistant at St. Joseph's Hospital, said Mr. Scali could be released from the hospital in seven to nine days.

title: PAYROLLS STUDIED FOR RELIEF NAMES
description: The city's Human Resources Administration has started to check the payrolls of all city agencies to determine what city employes may also be receiving welfare checksand how many may be doing so wrongfully.

title: Regression in Greece
description: The Greek military has responded to recent violent civil protests against the dictatorship of President George Papadopoulos with the overthrow of Colonel Papadopoulos and his recentlynamed civilian Premier, Spyros Markezinis. However, instead of embracing the popular demand for a speedier return to parliamentary procedures, the leaders of this latest Greek coup appear determined to reinforce the rigid military rule that has reduced the Athens Government to its present state disrepute, both at home and abroad.

title: Wagner and Carey Reported to Be Interested in Governorship
description: Most of the attention in the coming Democratic gubernatorial race is focusing on Howard J. Samuels and Representatives Ogden R. Reid and Samuel Stratton, but two other leading Democrats former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Representative Hugh Careyare hinting that they might be interested in running. Both note that unidentified friends are urging them to run, the usual line for a potential candidate. How serious they are remains to be seen since both have floated trial balloons that burst in past campaigns.

title: Ashe Favored Today In S. Africa Net Final
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 25 (AP)Arthur Ashe is favored to become the first black man ever to win the South African open tennis tournament tomorrow when he faces Jimmy Connors in an allAmerican final.

title: An Air of Arab Confidence Is Felt in a Cafe in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21  Are your suitcases ready? the Syrian and Lebanese coffee drinkers at the Raslan Cafe asked their Palestinian friends. Are you ready to return to your homeland?

title: Excerpts From Fact Sheet on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Following are excerpts from a fact sheet distributed by the White House to accompany President Nixon's energy message tonight:

title: Papandreou Sees Hand Of C.I.A. in Athens Copp
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 25 (Reuters)  Andreas Papandreou, the exiled Greek political leader, charged tonight that today's coup in Athens was engineered by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Con Ed Presses Conversion to Coal
description: In the hope and expectation that a city ruling will be overturned, the Consolidated Edison Company disclosed yesterday that it was going ahead with the conversion of two generating plants from oil to coal.

title: Many Stations in City Area Already Closed on Sunday
description: Many service stations in the metropolitan area were already closed yesterday in anticipation of President Nixon's request to Congress for a ban on gasoline sales on Saturday night and Sunday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne is to meet today with the New York Football Giants' president, Wellington Mara, to discuss the future of the Meadowlands sports complex.

title: Red Smith
description: Hours before President Nixon's address on the fuel shortage, the National Football League and Columbia Broadcasting System took a bold step yesterday in their campaign to conserve energysolar energy, that is.
