But ever since, many of them have been unable to shake the terrible feeling that it was all a mistake and that invitation had turned into imposition.

title: American League Is Going to Bat for dh
description: Battle lines were being drawn yesterday for a renewal of one of the critical battles in baseballover the future of the controversial 10th man, the designated hitter. And the American League was preparing to testify that he had outhit, outscored and outdrawn the pitcher in his first summer at bat in the big leagues.

title: About New York Retiring From the Irish Mafia
description: James D. Carroll announced his retirement yesterday. He is the first deputy controller, and people at City Hall have been saying ever pince the election that he youd be the next Deputy Mayor. In fact, he could have been if he had wanted it, but he chose otherwise. Mr. Carroll is a man who can make up his mind.

title: Times Square Transvestite Gets Life Term for Murder
description: A transvesite who preyed on men in the Times Square area was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for the knifing death of a Manhattan College football coach during a robbery attempt in August, 1971.

title: Senate Gives Its Support To the Stadium Bond Issue
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29  With some of its most prominent members pointing toward New York and shouting, We're No. 1, the State Senate voted overwhelmingly here this evening to put the state's moral credit behind the financing of a new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Sludge Bidding Opened
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (UPI) The city opened bidding today for the transportation by barge and dumping into the sea of up to 150 million gallons of sewage sludge each year.

title: Man Jumps From S.I. Ferry
description: An elderly man jumped from the middle deck of a Staten Island ferryboat yesterday and disappeared, the police reported. They said the man, who appeared to be about 60, jumped from the ferryboat, the Herbert H. Lehman, shortly after it left the St. George terminal, bound for Manhattan. Two crewmen said they saw him jump shortly before 5 P.M.

title: F.C.C. to Ease Rule Limiting Networks During Prime Time
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday voted to ease regulations that, since 1971, have restricted the three television networks to three hours each night in the prime viewing hours of 7 to 11 P.M.

title: JOHN DABNEY PENICK, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 29John Dabney Penick, a Wall Street investment banker far 45 years, died yesterday at his home, 275 Bradford Avenue. He was 66 years old and lived also in Watch Hill, R.I.

title: Bridge:
description: New York enthusiasts have have three opportunities annually to compete in major tournaments in Manhattan. The third of them is the Winter Regional of the Greater New York Bridge Association beginning today at the New York Hilton.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES WELFARE SYSTEM
description: Despite the existence of services aimed at encouraging relief recipients to become selfsufficient, a new city research report said yesterday that the longer people were on welfare the more they depended on it.

title: Saving the Fare
description: Despite a hint that the White House is prepared modify its longstanding opposition to Federal transit operating subsidies, Governor Rockefeller and Mayorelect Beame face an uphill battle in Washington today in their bid to win Federal assistance to save the 35 cent subway fare.

title: Bayer Subsidiary Plans to Offer $18.50 a Share for Cutter Stock
description: Cutter Laboratories, Inc., announced yesterday that the Rhinechem Corporation, a subsidiary of Bayer, A. G., the giant West German chemical company, had indicated that it planned to make a cash tender offer for all the shares of Class A and B common stock of Cutter at a net price of $18.50 a share.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 29The New Jersey college basketball coaches met today for the first time this season. They didn't have much to say because their teams haven't played yet, except for Wynn Phillips of Union, who has a 10 won lost record. Some haven't settled on their starters, others already have problems.

title: Stocks Set Back Slightly During a Seesaw Session
description: Reports that military talks between Israel and Egypt had collapsed handed the stock market a mild setback yesterday in a seesaw session. Gold issues continued to perform as the market's strongest group.

title: 2,000 Pay Tribute at Dr. Logan's Funeral
description: The funeral of Dr. Arthur Courtney Logan filled Riverside Church to the balconies yesterday with friends and associates, the powerful and the ordinary, in tribute to the surgeon and civic activist who was regarded as one of the most influential black men in the city.

title: I.B.M. Names Treasurer
description: Bertram H. Witham has been appointed treasure of the International Business Machines Corporation, effective Feb. 1, 1974. He is presently a vice president and chief financial officer of I.B.M. World Trade Corporation, a subsidiary. Mr. Witham will succeed Harry M. Sibley, who will retire.

title: SOVIET PLANNING MORE SPACE SHOTS
description: ZVEZDNY GORODOK, U.S.S.R., Nov. 29  A senior Soviet space official disclosed plans today for more Soviet manned space flightsindividual Soyuz missions and linkups of the Soyuz with the Salyut orbital platform  before the joint SovietAmerican space mission in 1975.

title: ZIEGLER ASSAILS JAWORSKI STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29The White House bitterly attacked the staff of the special Watergate prosecutor today, charging that it has displayed an ingrained suspicion and visceral dislike for this President and this Administration.

title: Hesitant House
description: So many of the Nixon Administration scandals have revolved about campaign money, laundered and unlaundered, that Congress has a rare opportunity to assert moral leadership on a crucial issue. The House has already come perilously close to spurning that opportunity and it may still dog soimminently and to its shame.

title: Goodwilled Amateur Chefs Prove a Bit Too Amateurish
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Trot Driver Is Banned For Stroke of His Pen
description: It was an innocentenough question, as old as racing itself: Who d'ya like?

title: Banker Is Said to Disclose $100,000 Nixon Deposit
description: MIAMI, Nov. 29A former executive of a bank headed by Charles G. Rebozo has reportedly told the authorities here that President Nixon purchased a $100,000 certificate of deposn at the abour three years ago  about the time that Mr. Rebozo, his close friend, received the final installment of a $100,000 payment from Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire.

title: TOM HAMILTON
description: TYLER, Tex., Nov. 29 (UPI) Tom Hamilton, athletic director and baseball coach at St. Edward's University in Austin, died today at Tyler Medical Center. He was 48 years old and had suffered a cerebral hemorrhage last Friday.

title: Banker Is Said to Disclose $100,000 Nixon Deposit
description: MIAMI, Nov. 29A former executive of a bank headed by Charles G. Rebozo has reportedly told the authorities here that President Nixon purchased a $100,000 certificate of deposit at the bank about three years ago  about the time that Mr: Rebozo, his close friend, received the final installment of a $100,000 payment from Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire.

title: Dance: Alum in Round
description: With the opening of a fourday run last night by the Manuel Alum Dance Company at the BAMspace, the Brooklyn Academy of Music becomes the first major theater here to incorporate a nonproscenium setting as a regular performing area for dance.

title: Evans Is Suspended by Webster
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 29One day after saying he was tired of guys sounding off about who's playing and who's not playing, Alex Webster, the New York Giants' coach, suspended Charlie Evans, his unhappy fullback, indefinitely for conduct detrimental to the club.

title: WILLAM F. RASKOB
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 29 William F. Raskob, former secretary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., died Tuesday in St. Francis Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: NO NEW DATE SET
description: CAIRO, Nov. 29The EgyptianIsraeli military talks being held on the CairoSuez road broke down in disagreement today, and no date for a new meeting was set. Each side said it had no new proposals to make and could not accept the proposals made previously by the other side, according to authoritative sources.

title: COMPANIES PLAN RISE IN SPENDING
description: Appropriations of capital to expand plant and equipment by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers have been increased to a record $11.08billion in the third quarter, The Conference Board reported yesterday. The 2.4 per cent rise came on top of very substantial appropriations in the second quarter and the total was 56 per cent higher than in the third quarter of 1972.

title: Davis Cup: Smith vs. Newcombe
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 It will be Stan Smith versus. John Newcombe, and Tom Gorman against Rod Laver tomorrow afternoon in the opening two singles matches of the Davis Cup final between the United States and Australia.

title: General Strike in Grenada
description: SAN JUAN, P, R., Nov. 29 (UPI)Workers virtually shut down the Caribbean island of Grenada today in a general strike to protest tactics of Premier Eric Gairy. The strike was called by several unions and professional organizations, including those of doctors, to protest what the workers said was police brutality by the Government in Mr. Gairy's drive to attain independence for Grenada, an island of 110,000 persons in the southern Caribbean.

title: F.B.I. Man Chases And Captures Two After Being Beaten
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was recovering in a hospital here yesterday after chasing three men who had broken his jaw, capturing two of them and holding them at gunpoint until the police came to his assistance.

title: Jay Five Only Four
description: John Jay College has been forced to cancel its basketball game with New York Tech because six of the 10 varsity players are either sick or injured. The game, the season opener, was to have been played tomorrow night. Coach Mike Kalsky reported the injuries included ankles, knees, a hematoma of the thigh, a step throat and a kidney infection.

title: RABBI ISAAC J. ASSEO
description: Rabbi Isaac J. Asseo, who had led the Sephardic Center of the Mapleton section of Brooklyn, 2143 65th Street, since 1961, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Maimonides Hospital on Tuesday. He was 78 years old and lived at the synagogue.

title: Fear Is Voiced by Israelis That Fighting Will Revive
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 29Israeli forces remained on full alert on all fronts today, and Israeli officials expressed deep concern about the possibility of a renewal of fighting.

title: MATTHEW OFFERS TO GIVE TESTIMONY
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew yesterday said he had no knowledge of alleged attempts by the White House to get the Small Business Administration to burn its files on him.

title: State Department Is Wondering if Nixon Could Order Raids if Hanoi Broke Truce
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The State Department has been examining whether President Nixon could legally order a resumption of United States bombing in Indochina should North Vietnam begin a major offensive in violation of the Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

title: GEORGE LINDEN
description: George Linden, who retired as a New York Times linotype operator in 1961 after 40 years of service, died Tuesday at the Jewish Memorial Hospital. His age was 83, and he lived at 598 West 191st Street.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS FORD NOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The House Judiciary Committee approved the nomination of Gerald R. Ford as Vice President today by a vote of 29 to 8, with one vote of present.

title: SENATE APPROVES 9% MORT GAGES
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29  The State Senate today gave final legislative approval to a bill permitting conventional home mortgage interest rates to be raised from the current limit of 8 per cent to as high as 9 per cent.

title: People and Business
description: Williard M. Bright has been named president and chief operating officer of the CurtissWright Corporation, effective Feb. 1, 1974, and a director, as of yesterday. As president, he will succeed T. Roland Berner, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Philharmonic Musicians Gain and Lose in Pact
description: In ending their 10week strike Wednesday by ratifying a new threeyear contract, The New York Philharmonic musicians fell short of one of their stated major goals, but gained on other fronts.

title: Body of Pilot Found
description: LEBANON, N. H., Nov. 29 (AP)The body of the pilot of a light plane was recovered from its wreckage on Moose Mountain today about a half mile from the 1968 crash site of a jet that took 32 lives. The victim was identified as Rolf Glad, 25 years old, of Olean, N. Y. His twinengine Piper Aztec was on a flight from Albany and lost radio contact yesterday while on an instrument approach to Lebanon airport in heavy fog.

title: WATERGATE BURGLAR GUILTY IN AUTO CASE
description: MIAMI, Nov. 29 (AP)A convicted Watergate burglar, Frank Sturgis, was found guilty today on Federal charges of conspiracy and transportation of stolen automobiles to Mexico in 1968,

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: Tickets matching only the fast two win five 50cent tickets for any subsequent weekly drawing when shown to any lottery vender.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Kissinger is Still Hopeful Of December Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29Secretary of State Kissinger said today that despite reports of a breakdown in the ArabIsraeli military talks, he was still hopeful that a Middle East peace conference would begin next month.

title: Advertising: Product Paucity?
description: Here in the Northwest there may be considerable talk about Watergate, said the typically well dressed New York advertising man, but out West it's been business as usual. The energy crisis, though, is something else.

title: Weiskopf Trails 3 In So African Golf
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 29 (AP)Three South Africans shared: the lead today in the South African open golf tournament as Tom Weiskopf of the United States moved up to fourth place.

title: RICHARD J. LIGHTHALL
description: GULFPORT, Fla., Nov. 29Richard J. Lighthall, who retired in 1963 as a trust officer in the corporatetrust department of the Chemical Bank in New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home today. He was 75 years old and had lived in Sharon and Darien, Conn.

title: EMBARGO SOFTENS POLICY OF DUTCH
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 29Since the start of the Arab oil embargo against the Netherlands a month ago, the Socialistled Dutch Government has managed to keep the support of the proIsrael Dutch public while gently moving toward the demands of the Arab oil producers.

title: Jobless Rate Is Put At About 6% in '74
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Herbert Stein, Chairman, of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, forecast today that unemployment would approach 6 per cent next yearbut not exceea that figurepartly because of the fuel shortage but also because a business slowdown was in prospect anyway.

title: Several Hundred Friends Salute Roy Cohn, a Lawyer for 25 Years
description: The associates of Roy M. Cohn thotight that the end of his first 25 years as a lawyer in town was as good an occasion as any to honor him. So last night a few hundred of Mr.. Cohn's closest friends got together for a tribute that drew a crowd of widely mixed backgrounds and persuasions, from William F. Buckley Jr. to Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame.

title: RETAILERS' SALES ROSE IN NOVEMER
description: Consumer buying of apparel, home furnishings and related goods picked up during November, providing retailers with higher gains over the yearearlier month than they had in October, reports from several national leading retail chains indicated yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1973
description: International

title: Beanie, Byrne Seek New Port Authority
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame and Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne of New Jersey met here yesterday and agreed that Mr. Beame should be permitted to name one of the members of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15 billion tonmiles, 9.1 per cent above the corresponding week last year.

title: 100,000 Apply to Take a Police Test Alter MinorityGroup Recruiting Drive
description: An intensive recruiting drive supervised directly by Mayor Lindsay's office and focusing on black and Puerto Rican neighborhoods has produced more than 100,000 applicants, the biggest roster for a Civil Service test in city history.

title: CHAPIN IS INDICTED ON CHARGE BELIED ON SEMI LINKS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29President Nixon's former appointments secretary, Dwight L. Chapin, was indicted today on four counts of perjury in the Watergate scandals.

title: Seller of Greek Vase Staying Clear of Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 29  The American expatriate who sold a 2,500yearold Greek vase to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York for about $1million last year, Robert E. Hecht Jr., has so far stayed out of Italy, although he no longer risks arrest if he returns here.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE NEW AGENDA. By Andrew Greeley. 312 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: Fear Is Voiced by Israelis That Fighting Will Revive
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 29Israeli forces remained on full alert on all fronts today, and Israeli officials expressed deep concern about the possibility of a renewal of fighting.

title: SECRECY BACKED IN PLUMBER CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) The White House has told Federal investigators that the life of a foreign intelligence agent inside the Soviet Union would be endangered if a stillsecret plumbers operation were disclosed, informed sources said today.

title: Shortage of Drugs Is Termed Critical; Industry Seeks Oil
description: Because of the oil situation, the United States faces a critical shortage of penicillin, cortisone and other vital drugs, an industry spokesman said yesterday.

title: A Highway Funds Scandal Threatens Wallace's Political Future
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 29A major highway funds scandal is threatening the political future of George C. Wallace at a time when the twotime Governor is fast regaining his health and is reportedly preparing to plunge once again into state and national electioneering.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: History of Hoffmann
description: Jacques Offenbach, the hero of the boulevards, the Mozart of the ChampsElysees, composed exactly 100 operettas and one serious opera. It is, of course, the serious opera that the Metropolitan Opera is staging, in a new production. And the production is built around Joan Sutherland, who will be singing the four female roles in The Tales of Hoffmann.

title: FORD CO. PROTECTS ARGENTINE STAFF
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29The Ford Motor Company's subsidiary here has moved about 25 American executives and their families back to the United States in the last two days after receiving guerrilla threats against them, according to company officials and other reliable sources.

title: Sakharov Asks Soviet Consent To Accept a Post at Princeton
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, disclosed today that he had begun his applicaUtion procedure to go to the nited States to accept a teaching offer at Princeton University.

title: Stabilize the Dollar?
description: The top financial officials of the United States, France, Britain, West Germany and Japan holed up last weekend in a chateau south of Tours in the Loire Valley for secret talks on monetary matters. Precisely what they decidedif anythingremains a secret, although Secretary of the Treasury Shultz has disclosed that their discussions ranged over longterm reform of the world monetary system, the energy crisis and the dollar's recovery in value on foreign exchange markets.

title: Buzhardt Now Says White House Explanation of Gap in Tape Is Not a Certainty
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29J. Fred Buzhardt, Jr. conceded today that the official White House explanation of the 18minute gap in a Watergate tape recording was not a certainty but, instead, just a possibility.

title: MRS. GEORGE A. CULP
description: Mrs. George A. Culp, the former Jean Fay, associated with the Urban Coalition of New York for the last five years, died in the New York Hospital yesterday. She was 49 years old and lived at 185 West End Avenue.

title: Giants Underdogs to Tough Redskins; Jets Favored Here Over Tamer Colts
description: The pro football offering on television for Sunday is a doubleheader beginning with the Giants at Washington, Channel 2, 1 P.M., and followed by Cleveland at Kansas City, Channel 4, 4 P.M. The latter will preempt the Jets' game against the Colts here by decision of the National Broadcasting Company. The Jets are favored but not the Giants.

title: Dance: Ailey Performs for Its Life
description: Alvin Ailey is in trouble. One would not know it from the way his company is dancing and one would certainly not know it from the enthusiastic audiences that are crowding City Center's 55th Street Theater. But you might get the message from the fact that last night the company held a gala benefit in aid of none other than itself. Charity begins at home and the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater was last night not just singing for its supper but dancing for its life.

title: GEORGE S. H. ZAHM
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 29George Sperry Hier Zahm, president of Bantam U.S. Toys, Inc., of New York City and Port Chester, died here yesterday in the United Hospital. His age was 64, and he lived in Larchmont.

title: Airco, Inc., Promotes 4
description: Donald Reich, the senior financial officer of Airco, Inc., has been promoted from vice president finance to senior vice president. The diversified company also named three divisional presidents: Lawrence W. Kunkler at the Airco alloys division, David J. Craig at the industrial gases division and B. Joseph Werner at the Airco welding products division.

title: The Post and Stereotypers Agree on Contract Terms
description: The New York Post and New York Stereotypers Union No. 1 reached agreement last night on contract terms, according to Sidney Orenstein, labor relations counsel to The Post.

title: Infectious Hepatitis Virus Found by U.S. Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Government scientists announced today the first identification of the virus that causes infectious hepatitis, one of the most important known infectious diseases for which the causative agent has eluded science.

title: Beanie, Byrne Seek New Port Authority
description: Mayor  elect Abraham D. Beame and Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne of New Jersey met here yesterday and agreed that Mr. Beame should be permitted to name one of the members of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: TAX DEDUCTIONS FOR TENANT URGED
description: A state commission set up by Governor Rockefeller presented yesterday what it called a major new proposal to give tax relief to apartment tenantsand the commission was immediately accused by a State Senate leader of offering the public rewarmed hash.

title: Buzz Off
description: WASHINGTON (AP)A White House attorney said in Federal Court today he nearly duplicated the tones that obliterated conversation on an 18minute segment of a subpoenaed White House tape.News dispatch.

title: POLICE WOUND TWO IN HUNT FOR KILLER
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 29 (UPI)Three men were arrested tonight after a shootout with police officers searching for the (killer of a country and western musician in Nashville.

title: Fashion at Versailles: French Were Good, Americans Were Great
description: PARIS, Nov. 29There's already been a big offer from Las Vegas. And the woman behind it all would love to take the show on the road to London, and even New York.

title: Norris and Oilers Foil Knights, 32
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 29 (AP)Led by Jack Norris, Edmonton goalie, who posted his 10th victory of the season, the Oilers scored a 32 victory over the Jersey Knights in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: REV. O. ADOLPH ZELTNER
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Nov. 29The Rev. Dr. G. Adolph Zeltner, a retired Episcopal minister, died Wednesday at the Good Samaritan Hospital here. He was 77 years old and lived at 22 Forest Drive.

title: Ski Industry Fears Fuel Crisis Will Cost Billions in Business
description: Frederick Andresen, president of Ski Industries America, warned yesterday that the proposed mandatory Sunday closing of gasoline stations could endanger threequarters of a million jobs and $2billion worth of business.

title: Long Wait Near End For Navy
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29  George Welsh, the Navy coach, remembers how George Welsh, the Navy player, felt during the long twoweek drag of preparation prior to the annual ArmyNavy football game. He does not want boredom to upset his 1973 Midshipmen.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Northrop Corporation has received a $61.6million addition to a previously awarded Air Force contract for F5E jet fighters that are sold to allies.

title: 3 ARAB HIJACKERS REMAINING IN DUBAI
description: DUBAI, Nov. 29 (AP)The three Arab guerrillas who hijacked a Dutch jumbo jet and spent 68 hours in search of sanctuary in the Middle East and the eastern Mediterranean were reported still in this Persian,Gulf sheikdom today. Butt it was unclear whether they were prisoners or guests.

title: Opera: Cluttered Tales
description: Bayreuth is not the only place where opera is given as though darkness covers the face of the earth. The new production of Offenbach's Tales of Hoffmann, unveiled last night at the Metropolitan Opera, is a curiously moody setting. And it is prevailingly dark, in the best German expressionistic manner. This is so although the sets and costumes were designed by Allen Charles Klein of New York. Bliss Hebert, the director, also is a New Yorker. The sets correspond closely to the production Mr. Klein did several years ago for the Seattle Opera in which Joan Sutherland was the star, as she also was last night.

title: BONN AIDES FEAR MAJOR RECESSION
description: BONN, Nov. 29West German officials are fearful of major recession next year if the current oil crisis intensifies, and say the signs of a downturn are already becoming apparent.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: New York637561

title: CHRYSLER TO CUT BIGCAR VOLUME
description: DETROIT, Nov. 29  The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it planned to shut down briefly two of the three Chrysler plants where fullsize cars are assembled, and that the third plant would be converted to the production of compact cars.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state announced graduated increases in payments for fosterchild care. The increases for the first time take into consideration the accelerating costs of maintenance as the child's age increases, said Frederick A. Schenck, director of the Division of Youth and Family Services.

title: Canadian Javelin Is Sued for Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Canadian Javelin, Ltd., the embattled minerals development company, and its two principal officers with stock fraud.

title: BREZHNEV CALLS FOR ASIAN TALKS
description: NEW DELHI, Nov, 29Leonid I. Brezhnev, on the eve of his departure for Moscow, called tonight for a thorough and comprehensive discussion of an Asian collective security plan.

title: TRANSIT MEETING WITH ROCKEFELLER DECLINED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29President Nixon declined today to meet tomorrow with Governor Rockefeller, Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame and Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso, who are coming here to seek Federal funds to save New York City's 35cent fare.

title: Law Cripples Army Recruiting
description: An eleventhhour reluctance to commit at least nine years of their young lives to the military turned a number of good football players away from Army in recent yearsplayers who might have contributed to a better 1973 Army season than the dismal 09 wonlost record so far.

title: Notes on, People
description: Clifford Irving was ordered paroled from the twoandahalfyear prison sentence he is serving for the Howard R. Hughes auto  biography hoax, but he won't be released until next Valentine's Day, Feb. 14.

title: Tito, at 81, Indicates He May Step Down
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 29Marshal Tito, who will be 82 years old next May 25, opened the door today to the possibility that he might step down as President of Yugoslavia if his physical and mental abilities fell below the level required for the position.

title: Racetrack Unions Meet With OTB
description: Leaders of labor unions at Aqueduct, Roosevelt Raceway and Yonkers Raceway met yesterday to formulate plans for jobsecurity negotiations with the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Bonds Aids Brother; He's Arrested, Too
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP)  The San Francisco Giants' rightfielder, Bobby Bonds, was arrested early today and charged with interfering with policemen who were trying to give his brother a speeding ticket, Belmont police said.

title: San Diego Official Warns League
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 29 (AP)Word that National League club owners may reject the sale of the San Diego Padres to a group headed by a racetrack owner, Mrs. Marjorie Lindheimer Everett, has brought an angry reaction from the San Diego City Attorney, John Witt. It sounds as if they are trying to play games, Witt said. If they try to move the franchise, we, will proceed with our $12million lawsuit against the city and institute antitrust action.

title: BRITAIN ASSURED BY ARABS ON Oil
description: LONDON, Nov. 29  Saudi Arabia and Algeria, two of the largest Arab oil producers, assured Britain today of continuing petroleum supplies but indicated that further price increases would be imposed worldwide.

title: Laird Plans to Resign When Ford Takes Over
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)Melvin Laird said today that he planned to resign as President Nixon's chief domestic adviser after Representative Gerald R. Ford got final Congressional approval and assumed the VicePresidency.

title: Infectious Hepatitis Virus Found by U.S. Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Government scientists announced today the first identification of the virus that causes infectious hepatitis, one of the most important known infectious diseases for which the causative agent has eluded science.

title: Complaints Are Few On Blackout of Jets
description: Fewer than 100 persons have called the National Broadcasting Company to ask about the New York television blackout of the JetsBaltimore Colts game at Shea Stadium on Sunday.

title: 2Party State Panel Asks Campaign Spendlng Curbs
description: A special legislative commission has reached bipartisan agreement for a substantial overhaul of the state laws governing political campaign financing.

title: Beanie Invites 4,000 to His Inaugural And to Party at Metropolitan Opera
description: Abraham D. Beanie, the quiet and methodical 67yearold Mayorelect, has invited 4,000 people to what will be one of the largest inaugural fetes in the city's historyat the Metropolitan Opera Houseon Jan. 1, the day he is sworn in as the city's 105th Mayor.

title: Senator Would Curb Institutional Deals As Spur to Market
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 29The chairman of a Senate subcommittee on financial markets disclosed here today that he will introduce legislation to both limit stockholdings by institutional investors and encourage individual investors to return to the stock market.

title: BEANIE NAMES AIDE FOR POST IN ALBANY
description: Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame yesterday named Stanley M. Friedman, 37yearold associate counsel to the City Council's majority leader, as his legislative representative in Albany.

title: U.S. Hopeful of 12Mile Sea Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29An Administration official expressed cautious optimism; today that a convention establishing a global 12mile territorial sea limit would emerge from a United Nations conference next summer that 148 nations are expected to attend.

title: Plastics Industry Hurt by Lack Of Raw Materials Made of Oil
description: Randel Plastics, Inc., of Long Island City used to have 95 persons on its payroll. Last week there were only 48.

title: Energy Revolution
description: Progress is getting a bad name. It led straight to the rape of the environment, and now to the energy crisis. Nowhere is the price of progress more evident than in the twentiethcentury city. The architect's and builder's world is completely artificial, sealed, climatecontrolled and standardized, totally dependent on enormous energy consumption. Today's structures are peoplecontainers with lifesupport systems, as if built on the moon. It has been 1984 for a long time, but no one has noticed.

title: NET CAPITAL RULE PROPOSED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)  The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a rule change to clarify financial obligations of brokers and dealers.

title: BOISE CASCADE MAPS $1.1BILLION OUTLAY
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation announced yesterday a $1.1billion capital expenditure program to be carried out over a period of five years. The program will also utilize $100million of carryover expenditures from previous years.

title: LEE B. MOREY
description: Lee B. Morey, a former senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolff, died Wednesday in Tucson, Ariz, He was 80 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: CHAPIN IS INDICTED ON CHARGE HE LIED ON SEGRETTI LINKS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29President Nixon's former appointments secretary, Dwight L. Chapin, was indicted today on four counts of perjury in the Watergate scandals.

title: Fed May Be Sharply Expanding Credit Supply, Analysts Assert
description: The Federal Reserve may have initiated a vigorous expansion of the nation's credit supply, spurred by energy shortages that have made an economic downturn more likely next year.

title: Ever Had Stuffed Tufoli? Try It This Weekend
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Safety Board Wants All Airlines Alerted on Possible Improper Loading of Dangerous Chemicals
description: The National Transportation Safety Board called on aviation authorities yesterday to alert all airlines to unsafe conditions, including possible im proper loading of dangerous chemicals, that could have led to the crash of a cargo jet in Boston on Nov. 3.

title: Handicapped Children Open in Show Today
description: EAST HADDAM, Conn., Nov. 29The show that opens tomorrow for a twoday run at the Goodspeed Opera House is of a sort that has not been tried before.

title: Europe Is Toning Down Its AntiInflation Program
description: PARIS, Nov. 29Faced with a growing threat of unemployment arising from the energy shortage, the economic authorities of Europe are toning down the measures they were planning to use in the fight against inflation.

title: Pothole Victim Gets $150,000 for Injuries
description: A pothole cost the city $150,000 yesterday in the settlement of a damage suit in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Red Smith
description: The late Elmer Layden, when he was commissioner the National Football League, didn't consider it worth answer when asked what he thought of an embryo called the AllAmerica Conference. Let them get a football first, he said. Inside five years the newcomers had several footballs and some of Layden's employers had lost their shirts. The N.F.L. hollered uncle.

title: Soviet Says Fischer Reneges on Rematch Because of Greed
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29The Soviet press today accused Bobby Fischer, the 30yearold world chess champion, of reneging on a promise of a rematch with the man he dethroned, Boris Spassky, and charged that the American grandmaster was motivated only by money, money and money.

title: CITIES SERVICE SETS SALE OF BUILDINGS
description: The Cities Service Company confirmed yesterday that it was seeking to sell the eight buildings it owns in the financial district and announced that it was also offering for sale office buildings in Atlanta and Fort Wayne, Ind.

title: TRANSIT MEETING WITH ROCKEFELLER PUT OFF BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29President Nixon declined today to meet tomorrow with Governor Rockefeller, Mayorelect Abraham D. Beanie and Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso, who are coming here to seek Federal funds to save New York City's 35cent fare.

title: NO NEW DATE SET
description: CAIRO, Nov. 29The EgyptianIsraeli military talks being held on the CairoSuez road broke down in disagreement today, and no date for a new meeting was set. Each side said it had no new proposals to make and could not accept the proposals made previously by the other side, according to authoritative sources.

title: Democrats Name Chairman For Fund Raising in '74
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP)  Stephen Leroy Kling, a St, Louis insurance executive, was named yesterday to head the Democratic National Committee's fundraising efforts for the 1974 elections.

title: Department Store Fire in Japan Kills 100
description: KUMAMOTO, Japan, Nov. 29 (AP)Fire and smoke stampeded thousands of panicky shoppers in a department store here today and the police said more than 100 were killed and 100 injured in the worst such blaze in Japan's history. Casualties were expected to mount.

title: Action at Lewisburg
description: LEWISBLTRG, Pa. Nov. 29  Last night, members of the Lewisburg branch of the N.A.A.C.P.  the first prison branch, one of only three in the countrypeppered a visitor with questions about prison reform. What was he doing? What was the press doing? What about the politicians? What was happening in Congress?

title: Flyers Tie Rangers On Late Goal, 22
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29The Philadelphia Flyers, also known as The Broad Street Bullies, rallied in the closing minutes of the third period tonight to tie the New York Rangers, 22.

title: School Bond Approved
description: GREENFIELD, Mass., Nov. 29 (AP)Bonding for a vocational technical school serving 17 Franklin County towns was approved in a regional vote yesterday.

title: Chapman's Coast Date Has $10Million Lure
description: There's very little that John Chapman wants, only $10million or so. The Canadian harness driver, who performed at Yonkers last night, is leaving for California this morning to drive Delmonica Hanover in the American Trotting Classic at Hollywood Park tonight, and there's a fair chance that he'll Race get what he wants.

title: Sports Today 1
description: BASKETBALL

title: ADVANCE HALTED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The rise in prices of stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market that took place on Wednesday proved shortlived. Prices fell on both marts yesterday.

title: Pop Music: Glitter Marks Teresa Brewer's Return
description: Teresa Brewer, making her first appearance in New York in 15 years, is surrounded by a remarkable array of diversions at the Rainbow Grill. There is Bobby Hackett, giving her lovely backing with his cornet on a couple of old ballads. There is Bunny Briggs, joining Miss Brewer in an old Ellington song, but given no chance to dance. There is Al Gray, the onetime Basie trombonist, adding uncharacteristic plunger mute touches to a Dixieland number, that also features Johnny Mince, Tommy Dorsey's clarinet in the late thirties.

title: 2 GREEK LEADERS ASSAIL MILITARY
description: ATHENS, Nov. 19The new military rulers of Greece were criticized publicly by two political leaders today for the announcement of plans last night to govern indefinitely by decree until the people were considered ready for elections.

title: BRITAIN TO IMPROVE NATIONAL RAIL GRID
description: LONDON, Nov. 29The British Government has announced a fiveyear program to modernize the nationalized railway system, mainly at the expense of urban road building.

title: HEALTH VAN GIVEN TO CENTRAL WARD
description: NEWARK, Nov. 29A $110,000 healthscreening unit consisting of a fully equipped medical van was turned over to the Timothy Still Memorial Health Center today along with a check for $20,000 from the WarnerLambert Company.

title: Jupiter's Magnetism Found to Be 40 Times the Earth's
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Nov. 29Pioneer 10, the first spacecraft to navigate the outer solar system, hurtled deep into the magnetic field of Jupiter tonight and found the field's reach to be greater than expected, its strength 40 times that of the earth's magnetic field and its direction south instead of north.

title: Mahaffey Is Leader With 137
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. Except for Ben Crenshaw, who failed to qualify, it was a good day for rookies and young professionals in the $150,000 Walt Disney World golf classic. John Mahaffey, a 25yearold Texan who won his first tour about a month ago, led with a 36hole total of 137, seven under par.
